(Punjab).—Educated at Gordon's Hospital, New Grammar School, and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and forest settlement officer; on special duty, Jan.-May, 1878, and again, Nov., 1881, in the forest department; deputy commissioner, March, 1889; on special duty at Hissar, Nov., 1890.

ANDERSON, FRANCIS CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1871; from Nov., 1871, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, personal assistant to the chief commissioner, and acting deputy commissioner; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, Aug., 1881; commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, Feb., 1882; acted as secretary to chief commissioner in Oct., 1882, 1885, and March, 1888; confirmed in that appointment, Jan., 1891; officiating commissioner, Nagpur division, April, 1892; prepared excise manual for the Central Provinces, 1885.

ANDERSON, HENRY AIKEN, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Repton Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1873, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and officiating under secretary to Government, March, 1880; assistant political officer, Kurram, under the Government of India, Aug., 1880; on special duty, camp of exercise, Delhi, Nov., 1885; officiating district judge, in 1884, 1886, and 1887; deputy commissioner, May, 1889; acted as commissioner and superintendent, Derajat, in 1892.

ANDERSON, JAMES, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived, 14th Nov., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1884; on special duty connected with the Wahabi case, June, 1870; retired, 1888.

ANDERSON, JAMES DRUMMOND, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1875; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Assam, Jan., 1880, and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Jan.-Dec., 1882; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, July, 1886; deputy commissioner, April, 1889; author of 'A Short List of Words of the Hill Tipperah Language,' 1885.

ANDERSON, JOHN ALEXANDER, B.L., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Grammar School and University of Aberdeen, and was also a student of the Inner Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating divisional judge, March, 1883, again in 1889, and from April, 1891; district judge, April, 1889.

ANDERSON, J.W.M., Colonel, late Revenue Survey Department, Bombay.—First commission, Jan., 1855; from Nov., 1863, served in the revenue survey department, Mysore, as assistant superintendent and deputy superintendent; from April, 1881, served as superintendent of the Scinde settlement survey; 1st grade superintendent, Jan., 1885; retired, March, 1888.

ANDERSON, ROBERT HILDEBRAND, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1876; served as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating embarkation agent and superintendent of emigration, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; confirmed as joint magistrate and deputy collector, Aug., 1887; has also acted as district and sessions judge.

ANDERSON, WILLIAM ROBERT LE GUYT, Major, I.S.C.—First commission, 63rd foot, Oct., 1870; admitted to the Bombay staff corps, Oct., 1871; aide-de-camp to Governor of Bombay, 1876; deputy accountant-general, military department, Jan., 1882; military accountant, 2nd class, March, 1890; served in the Egyptian war, 1882 (medal and Khedive's star).

ANDREW, DAVID CLAPHAM, Lieutenant-Colonel, I.S.C., late Survey of India.—Ensign, Bengal Infantry, Dec., 1859; arrived in India, 7th March, 1860; joined the revenue survey department as assistant surveyor, Dec., 1862; deputy superintendent of revenue survey 3rd grade, Jan., 1878; was in charge of Bassein District, British Burma survey, Nov., 1879, and was transferred to the South Deccan survey, Nov., 1880; 2nd grade deputy superintendent, March, 1886; retired, March, 1889.

ANDREW, JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Kingstown School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and forest settlement officer; head assistant to collector and magistrate, N. Arcot, April, 1888; principal assistant to collector, district magistrate, and agent, Ganjam, Dec., 1891.

ANDREWS, W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 30th March, 1876.

ANLEY, GEORGE AUGUSTUS D'AUVERGNE, late Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the government of India as executive engineer, 4th class, 25th Jan., 1861; served in the Bengal public works department, and temporarily under the municipality of Calcutta; officiating assistant to chief engineer and assistant secretary to the government of Bengal, April, 1876; held charge of office of chief engineer, and secretary to government of Bengal, Dec., 1878; superintending engineer, 3rd class, March, 1882; 2nd class, March, 1886; retired, Nov., 1888.

ANNESLEY, ROBERT, Major, Judicial Department, N.W. Provinces.—Entered the army in 1855, and served in the Crimean and Abyssinian
campaigns; retired in 1869; joined the service, 4th Jan., 1871, as assistant district superintendent of police and officiating cantonment magistrate, and was confirmed in the latter appointment, June, 1877; judge, small cause court, June, 1880; 1st class cantonment magistrate, Oct., 1886.

ANSON, GEORGE WEMYSS, Major, I.S.C., Oudh Commission.—1st commission, 11th Jan., 1867; private secretary and A.D.C. to lieut.-governor, N.W. Provinces, May, 1871, and Feb., 1875—June, 1878; from April, 1872, served as officiating cantonment magistrate and officiating assistant commissioner; confirmed in latter appointment, Sept., 1875, and in the former, Sept., 1877; agent, Balrampur estate, June, 1886; in addition cantonment magistrate, Aug., 1887; and deputy commissioner, Nov., 1890.

ARBUTHNOT, SIR ALEXANDER JOHN, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Madras C.S., Member of the Council of India.—Educated at Rugby, and Haileybury College, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1842; arrived in Madras, Sept., 1842; served in the revenue department as assistant collector and magistrate, and also held the posts of Malayan translator to government, secretary to the college and university boards, and deputy and acting registrar to the Sudder court; director of public instruction, March, 1855; chief secretary to government and additional member of council for making laws and regulations, Oct., 1862; member of Madras Council, Oct., 1867, to Oct., 1872; temporary governor of Madras in the absence of Lord Napier, Feb.-May, 1872; retired from the Madras civil service, Oct., 1874; member of governor-general's council, June, 1875, to 1880, and acted as president of the council, Nov., 1878, and March, 1879; vice-chancellor of the university of Madras, Oct., 1871, and of the university of Calcutta, Oct., 1878; counsellor of the Empress of India, Jan., 1877; appointed member of the council of India, 1st Nov., 1887; is the author of various publications on educational and other subjects in connection with India, among which are 'Reports of selected cases determined in the Court of Foujdarl Adawlut,' 1851; 'A compilation of papers relating to public instruction in Madras,' 1855; 'Memoir of Sir Thomas Munro,' 1831; &c.

ARBUTHNOT, SIR CHARLES GEORGE, Lieut.-General, K.C.B., R.A.—1st commission, Royal Artillery, June, 1843; served in the Crimean campaign, 1855, and was present at the siege and fall of Sevastopol (medal and clasp, brevet of major, 5th class Medjidie, Turkish medal); deputy adjutant-general, R.A., in Bengal, March, 1873, to Sept., 1877; acted as inspector-general of ordnance, Oct., 1877, to Sept., 1878; inspector-general of artillery in India, Sept., 1878, to July, 1880, during which period he served as brigadier-general in the operations in Afghanistan (medal, K.C.B.); deputy adjutant-general, R.A.; with the headquarters of the army in England, Sept., 1880, to Aug., 1883; inspector-general of artillery in England, Sept., 1883, to April, 1885; president, ordnance committee, May, 1885, to Jan., 1886; commander-in-chief, and member of the governor's council, Bombay, 16th Feb. to Dec., 1886; commander-in-chief, and member of council, Madras, Dec., 1886, to March, 1891.

ARBUTHNOTT, JOHN CAMPBELL, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1879; assistant magistrate and collector, Bhagalpur, Dec., 1879; transferred to Assam, Feb., 1883, and served as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1890.

ARDAGH, JOHN CHARLES, C.B., C.I.E., Colonel, R.E., Private Secretary to Governor-General of India.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; entered royal engineers as lieutenant, 1st April, 1859; captain, Aug., 1872; major, Nov., 1878; lieutenant-colonel, Nov., 1882; colonel, Nov., 1887; attached to the special embassy during the congress at Berlin, June, 1878, and was made a C.B. (civil), July, 1878; appointed assistant to Her Majesty's commissioner for the delimitation of the frontier of Bulgaria, Sept., 1878; appointed commissioner for the demarcation of the Greek frontier, June, 1881; was employed during the conference at Berlin on the Greek frontier in 1880, and during the conference at Constantinople on the same subject in 1881; served in the Egyptian campaign of 1882-4, including the operations at Alexandria, and the battle of Tel-el-Kebir (medal with clasp, bronze star, brevet of lieutenant-colonel and 4th class of Osmanieh); served in the Soudan in 1884, commanding royal engineers and chief of the intelligence department; battles of Teb and Tamai; 2 clasps, C.B. (military), May, 1884; served in Soudan expedition, 1884-5—Nile; commandant of base at Cairo, and in the expedition of 1885-6 with the frontier field force; has received the 3rd class of the Medjidieh; appointed private secretary to the Right Hon. the Marquess of Lansdowne, governor-general of India, Dec., 1888; C.I.E., Jan., 1892.

ARGYLL (DUKE OF), HIS GRACE GEORGE DOUGLAS CAMPBELL, K.T.—Born in 1823; succeeded to the dukedom in 1847; took an active part in the controversy in the Presbyterian Church of Scotland relating to patronage, and published various pamphlets and essays in connection therewith, 1842-1848; elected chancellor of the University of St. Andrew's, 1851; lord privy seal, 1852-1855; postmaster general, 1855; lord privy seal, 1859; in 1860 he was again appointed postmaster general, and subsequently lord privy seal; secretary of state for India, Dec., 1863, to Feb., 1874; lord privy seal, May, 1880; resigned in April, 1881; elected rector of the university of Glasgow, Nov., 1854; presided over the 25th annual meeting of the British Association, held at Glasgow, Sept., 1855; president of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, 1861; is hereditary master of the Queen's household in Scotland, a trustee of the British Museum, and hereditary sheriff and lord lieutenant of Argyllshire; published the 'Reign of Law' in 1866; 'Primeval Man' 1869; a small work on the history and antiquities of Iona, 1870; 'The Patronage Act of 1874,' 1874; observations 'On the important question involved in the relation of Landlord and Tenant,' 1877; and in 1879, 'The Eastern Question from the Treaty of Paris to the Treaty of Berlin, and to the second Afghan War.'

ARMSTRONG, FRANCIS B., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham Proprietary College, and King Edward's School, Birmingham; junior clerk, financial department,
India Office, 30th March, 1869; senior clerk, Sept., 1883.

ARMSTRONG, John Arthur, Lieut.-Col., R.E., late Public Works Department, Punjab.—1st commission, June, 1860; joined the public works department, Nov. 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant engineer; served in the Hazara Campaign, 1868, as assistant engineer in charge of field telegraph; executive engineer, Sept., 1869; assistant to chief engineer, and assistant secretary to government, April, 1877; served in Kashmir on special road work, 1881-82; superintending engineer, 3rd class, March, 1886; retired, March, 1887.

ARMSTRONG, John Scobell, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 3rd March, 1866; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Bengal; deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Dec., 1877; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, and collector of customs, Calcutta, April, 1883; port commissioner, Calcutta, Nov., 1887; retired, July, 1892.

ARNOLD, George, late Store Department, India Office.—Clerk in storekeeper's department, Royal Arsenal, Woolwich, Oct., 1855, to Dec., 1858; sub-inspector of stores, India store depot, Dec., 1858; supervisor, 1st grade, March, 1877; retired, 1886.

ARNOTT, James, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, M.D., C.M., Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867, and was employed under the military department till Aug., 1868, including service in the Abyssinian Expedition (medal); and subsequently as assistant-surgeon in the David Sassoon Hospital, Poona, and in the European General Hospital, Bombay, and as professor of pathology in the Grant Medical College; also acted as civil surgeon, and registrar of marriages, Poona, and in medical charge of the Deccan and civil engineering colleges, and as superintendent of the lunatic asylum and jail; acting surgeon, Gokuldas Tejpal Hospital, Bombay, Jan., 1878; also acted as presidency surgeon and marine surgeon, Bombay; surgeon, European General Hospital, Bombay, March-April, 1882; professor of midwifery, Grant Medical College, and obstetric physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital from April, 1882; physician, European General Hospital, May, 1891.

ARNOTT, Napoleon, Major, R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, 22nd Dec., 1865; arrived in India 13th Dec., 1868, and served in Bengal and the Punjab on irrigation duty; executive engineer, Jan., 1879; officiated as secretary to agent to governor general, Baluchistan, and as secretary to defence committee in 1882; employed on special defence works, Aug., 1887; superintending engineer, Dec., 1889; deputy director general, military works, Sept., 1890.

ARTHUR, Oswald George, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Winchester and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 8th Nov., 1890, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

ARTHUR, Sigismund Raynor, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1888; assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1889.

ARUNDEL, Arundel Tagg, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived, 18th Nov., 1865; served in various districts of Madras from Aug., 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, and acting collector and magistrate; private secretary to governor of Madras, July, 1875; acting deputy director, revenue settlement, April, 1878; president of the municipal commission, Madras, June, 1881; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1882; principal assistant to collector and magistrate, agent, Vizagapatam, Oct., 1884; district and sessions judge, Kistna, Dec., 1884; collector and magistrate, Kistna, Aug., 1887.

ASHBURNER, Lionel R., C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1848; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Broach, Surat, and Kaira; on the outbreak of the mutiny in 1857, was appointed superintendent of police, Kaira, and organised a body of horse and foot for the protection of the eastern frontier; special commissioner for trial of rebels, 1858; collector and magistrate, Kandeish, 1861; revenue and police commissioner, N. division, 1872; member of council, Bombay, Aug., 1877; retired, 1883.

ASHTON, G., Financial Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 7th April, 1884; attached to financial department.

ASTON, Henry Faure, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the South African College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 9th Oct., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting political assistant in Kathiawar (April, 1871, to June, 1874), acting judge and sessions judge, railway magistrate and cantonment magistrate; on famine duty, Sholapur, Sept., 1877; acting under secretary to government of Bombay in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations, Dec., 1881, to March, 1883; 1st grade assistant judge and sessions judge, Aug., 1883; judicial assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, March, 1885; 3rd grade judge and sessions judge, Nov., 1886; 2nd grade, June, 1891; on special duty in connection with settlement cases, Baroda, in 1888.

ATA-ULLAH KHAN, Mirza, Sardar Bahadur, Hon. Lieut.-Colonel.—British agent at Kabul, June, 1885; retired, June, 1891.

ATKINS, Charles Herbert, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at King Henry VIII's School, Coventry, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 30th Nov., 1891; and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

ATKINS, John De Courcy, Bombay C.S.—Educated at University College School, London University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1880, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer; acted as under-secretary to government, Bombay, revenue, financial, &c., departments,
in 1886, and again in 1889 and 1890; acting postmaster-general, Bombay, April-Sept., 1891.

ATKINSON, Frederic James, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as probationer, 8th July, 1873, and served in Bengal as district grain accountant and on audit duty and as officiating accountant-general; served also as assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Bengal, and N.W. Provinces; assistant comptroller, Burma, December, 1888; officiating comptroller and commissioner of paper currency in 1890; deputy accountant general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, June, 1891.

ATKINSON, John Nathaniel, Madras C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1878, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and assistant sessions judge; on special duty under the commissioner of salt revenue, April, 1885; acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue, Oct. to Dec., 1885; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Sept., 1886; sub-collector and magistrate, Jan., 1891.

ATLAY, Venerable B. T., M.A., late Ecclesiastical Department, Bengal.—Arrived in India, 17th Oct., 1867; chaplain of St. Paul's Cathedral and of the general hospital, Dec., 1867; senior chaplain, Oct., 1877; chaplain of Naini Tal, Feb., 1879; senior chaplain, St. Paul's Cathedral, and chaplain of the general hospital and presidency jail, Jan., 1882; commissary to the Lord Bishop, and officiating chaplain in charge of the diocese, March, 1883; archdeacon of Calcutta, Sept., 1883; retired 1889, and was appointed vicar of Willesden.

ATUL CHUNDER DUTT, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Free Church Institution, Calcutta, and at Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Madras, 14th Jan., 1890, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate.

AUCOTT, Elliott, Funds Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 27th Feb., 1886.

AULAD HUSSAIN, Khan Bahadur, C.I.E., Central Provinces Commission.—Joined the service, 29th July, 1844; served in various subordinate posts till Dec., 1864, when he was appointed extra-assistant commissioner; on special duty at the Delhi assemblage, Dec., 1876; C.I.E., Jan., 1882; acting small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, July, 1883; assistant commissioner, 1st class, Sept., 1883; settlement officer, 2nd grade, Jan., 1885.

AUSTIN, Ware Plumptre, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School, and Gloucester School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived 28th Dec., 1864; served in the Madras revenue and judicial department from May, 1865, as assistant magistrate and collector, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector, magistrate, and political agent; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1884, and again in 1888; collector and magistrate, Nov., 1886; acting collector of sea customs, and of the Madras district, protector of emigrants, superintendent of stamps and stationery, and chairman of the harbour trust board, Jan., 1891; confirmed, Nov., 1891.

AYLING, William Bock, Madras C.S.—Educated at Weymouth College and Magdalene College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras Civil Service after open competition of 1886; arrived in Madras 30th Jan., 1889, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate.

BADCOCK, Francis William, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1869; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant-magistrate, joint magistrate, and deputy collector, and officiating district and sessions judge, and was placed on special duty, as settlement officer, Bhagulpore, Monghyr, and Purneah, July, 1873, and also in the office of the board of revenue, Calcutta, Jan., 1879; officiating inspector-general of registration March, 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Oct., 1881; district and sessions judge, Jan., 1888.

BADDELEY, William Lewis Clinton, Major, R.E., Madras Public Works Department.—Joined the department, 23rd July, 1874; assistant engineer, Aug., 1875; executive engineer, 4th grade, May, 1883; 3rd, March, 1885; deputy chief engineer and under-secretary to government, Nov., 1886; executive engineer, 2nd grade, April, 1889.

BADEN, Edmund, late Auditor's Department, India Office.—Writer, 4th Jan., 1859; senior inspector, Sept., 1860; retired, Sept., 1892.

BADEN-POWELL, Baden Henry, C.I.E., late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at St. Paul's school; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; assistant commissioner, May, 1862; officiating postmaster-general, Punjab and Scinde, Aug., 1865; from July, 1866, to April, 1869, served as small cause court judge, Lahore, and subsequently in the forest department as officiating conservator and officiating inspector-general, and was placed on special duty, Nov., 1872, and April, 1876; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Umballa, April, 1880; on special duty in Madras, Oct., 1880, to Oct., 1881; additional commissioner, Lahore and Rawulpindi, Oct., 1881; deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1882; officiating judge, chief court, Punjab, May, 1883, and again April, 1884, and Jan., 1887; divisional judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; divisional judge, 1st grade, Sept., 1886, but to continue to act as judge of chief court; confirmed in latter appointment March, 1890; retired, May, 1890, but employed on special duty under Government of India, revenue and agricultural department; has published 'Punjab Products,' 'Punjab Manufactures,' 'Manual of the Land Revenue System and Land Tenures of British India,' and 'Manual of Jurisprudence for Forest Officers.'

BADGLEY, William Francis, Colonel, I.S.C., late Survey of India.—First commission, April, 1857; arrived in India, May, 1857; served during the mutiny in Central India and Oudh, and afterwards with the Lushai expedition in charge of a survey party (medals and clasp); appointed to the Topographical Survey, May, 1865, and was employed in Rewah and Bundelcund, and in the Khasi, Garo, and Naga Hills; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Dec., 1880; in charge of Guzerat survey, March,
1884; officiating assistant surveyor-general in charge of photographic and lithographic offices, March, 1886; retired, June, 1889.

BADOCK, HENRY W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 11th Feb., 1876.

BAGNELL, HENRY WILLIAM JAMES, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eastbourne College, Keble College, Oxford, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India 1st Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883; forest settlement officer, Aug., 1887; 2nd assistant collector, May, 1891.

BAGSHAWE, CECIL, Forest Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as temporary sub-assistant conservator, 26th Oct., 1869; assistant conservator, 14th Aug., 1871; deputy conservator, Oct., 1876; employed in the military department in the Kuram Valley, Aug., 1879, and at the Forest school, Dehra Dun, Dec., 1879; conservator, 3rd grade, Jan., 1889; 2nd grade, Oct., 1891; conservator of the school circle and director of the Forest school, March-Nov., 1890.

BAILEY, FRÉDÉRICK, Lieut.-Colonel, R.E., late Forest Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as a lieutenant, R.E., 12th Nov., 1864; served under the military department till July, 1867, when he was appointed assistant engineer, 1st grade, P.W. department; executive engineer, 3rd grade, June, 1871; from Aug., 1871, served in the forest department as deputy conservator and superintendent of forest surveys; conservator of forests, and director of Indian forest school, in addition to his duties as superintendent of forest surveys, Sept., 1878; promoted to 2nd grade of conservators, April, 1883; retired, April, 1892; is lecturer on forestry at Edinburgh University, and secretary to Royal Scottish Geographical Society.

BAILLIE, DUNCAN COLVIN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Inverness Academy, Glasgow Academy, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1879, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; assistant settlement officer, 1st grade, April, 1888; officiating collector and magistrate, Sept., 1889; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Sept., 1889; 1st grade, May, 1891; provincial superintendent of census operations, April, 1890.

BAINBRIDGE, GEORGE, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, M.D., M.R.C.P., M.R.C.S., L.S.A., Bcmbay Medical Department.—Joined the service 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Khandesh, Feb., 1871; acted as deputy sanitary commissioner; also as ophthalmic surgeon and professor of ophthalmic medicine and surgery and of comparative anatomy. Grant Medical College, May, 1878; surgeon-major, April, 1879; acting Presidency surgeon, Aug., 1882; acting senior surgeon of Sir Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and professor of surgery, Grant Medical College, Feb., 1885; civil surgeon, Karachi, Dec., 1891.

BAINES, JERVOISE ATHELSTANE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant political agent, acting educational inspector, and cantonment and railway magistrate; on special duty at Bombay as compiler of general administration report, Sept., 1878, and again Sept., 1879; acting under secretary to government revenue, financial, and general departments, March, 1880; deputy superintendent of census operations in Bombay Presidency, and under secretary to government, general department, (census), April, 1880; 2nd assistant collector and forest settlement officer, Dec., 1882; on special duty to supervise the work under the Income Tax Act in the Bombay Presidency, May, 1886; also acting as director of agriculture from Dec., 1886; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, Oct.-Nov., 1886; acted as junior collector and magistrate, 1887, 1888, and 1889; on special duty, June, 1888; served under the government of India as census commissioner for India from Aug., 1889.

BAIRD, ANDREW WILSON, Lieut.-Col., R.E., F.R.S., A.I.C.E., Mint Department, Calcutta.—Lieutenant, R.E., Dec., 1861; arrived in India, March, 1863; served from May, 1864, in the Bombay public works department as assistant engineer, and was employed on the harbour defences and reclamations; executive engineer, Oct., 1867; served in the Abyssinian Expedition as assistant field engineer, 1868 (medal); from Dec., 1868, served in the trigonometrical survey as assistant surveyor, and was employed in Kattywar and Guzerat; assistant superintendent 1st grade, Oct., 1871; in July, 1877, was appointed to the general superintendence and control of tidal observations upon the Indian coasts; on deputation as commissioner, Venice Geographical Congress and Exhibition, Aug., 1881; deputy superintendent, July, 1882; officiating master of the mint, Calcutta, in 1885 and 1886; 3rd grade deputy superintendent, March, 1886; mint master, Calcutta, Aug., 1889; is the author of various contributions to the Bombay Gazetteer, and of papers and reports on tidal observations, including a paper read before the British Association, 1876, and an account of the spirit-levelling operations of the great trigonometrical survey of India, read before the British Association in 1885; joint author of the annual tide tables for Indian ports.

BAKER, EDWARD NORMAN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Finchley; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1878; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; services placed at disposal of census commissioner, March, 1881; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, May, 1882; and in addition to his own duties, April, 1884; under secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1885; deputy commissioner 3rd grade, June, 1890; has also officiated as magistrate and collector.

BAKER, FRANCIS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Berkhamstead Grammar School and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; first assistant
secretary to government, Nov., 1873, and again in 1879; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, April, 1874; junior secretary, board of revenue, May, 1878, and officiated as secretary, Sept., 1878; officiating junior secretary to government, March, 1881; under secretary to government, May, 1881; superintendent of Dehra Dun, March, 1882; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Aug., 1886; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, March, 1888; magistrate and collector, March, 1889.

BAKER, MONTAGU BERNARD, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1864, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan, and acting judge and sessions judge; acting judicial commissioner in Scinde, and judge of the Sadar court, April, 1879; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Kandeish, May, 1882; 1st grade judge, Nasik, Jan., 1884; retired, June, 1891.

BAKER, OSWALD, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Burma.—Joined the Bengal medical service, 1873; was employed under the military department up to May, 1874, and served subsequently in Burma as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail; medical officer to the mission to Siam under Major C. W. Street, Feb., 1879; surgeon-major, April, 1885; officiating inspector-general of jails for Burma, May, 1887; joint medical officer, Simla, Sept., 1889; junior civil surgeon, Rangoon, Dec., 1890.

BALFOUR, SIR GEORGE, General, R.A., K.C.B., F.R.G.S., M.P.—2nd lieutenant, Madras Artillery, Dec., 1825; served with the Malacca field force, 1832-1833, in the Kurnool campaign, 1839, and throughout the China war, 1840-1842 (medal); consul at Shanghai, March, 1844, to Oct., 1846; member of the military and marine boards, Madras, Feb., 1851-1857; C.B., 1854; inspector-general of ordnance and magazines, Fort St. George, May, 1857 to 1861; member of the military finance commission, 1859-1860, and president of that commission, 1860-1862; served on the royal commission on recruiting in 1866 and 1868-70; assistant to the comptroller in chief, war office, 1868-1872; K.C.B., June, 1870; from 1872 to 1892 sat in the House of Commons for Kincardineshire; general, Oct., 1877; retired from the army, Dec., 1879.

BAMBER, HENRY WILLIAM JOHN, late Police Department, Bengal.—From 1st Oct., 1857 to May, 1862, served as assistant superintendent, and superintendent of salt chowkies; from May, 1862, served in the Bengal police department, and was promoted to district superintendent, 1st grade, Aug., 1885; retired, July, 1891.

BANERJEE, GOOROO DAS, DR., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Appointed puisne judge, high court, Calcutta, 5th Nov., 1888.

BANKS, SAMUEL HENRY O'BRIEN, F.R.C.S.I., Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Bombay Medical Department.—Joined the service 1st Oct., 1866, and arrived in India, 17th April, 1867; served in the Abyssinian campaign, and afterwards on civil, military, and jail duty; surgeon-major, Oct., 1878; presidency surgeon, 3rd district, Nov., 1888; presidency surgeon, 2nd district, and marine surgeon, Nov., 1889; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1889; in medical charge, Elphinstone College, Jan., 1891.

BANNERMAN, PATRICK WILSON, Colonel, I.S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Bombay Army, June, 1852; assistant to the superintendent, Neemuch, July, 1859; assistant to governor-general's agent, Central India, 1860; political assistant, Bhopawar, Aug., 1865; also Bhel agent and commandant, Malwa Bhel corps; political agent, Rewah, March, 1871; political agent, Bhopal, 1880; resident, Eastern States, Rajputana, Oct., 1881; resident, Gwalior, March, 1882; acted as agent to governor-general for Central India in 1883-1884, and again in 1887; reverted to military department, 1888.

BANTON, WILLIAM, late Accounts Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 29th Dec., 1848; junior clerk, accountant-general's department, India office, Sept., 1858; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; also assessor of income tax, 1879; retired, Dec., 1892.

BARBOUR, SIR DAVID MILLER, K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1863; served in Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; under secretary, government of India, financial department, Aug., 1873; accountant general, Punjab, and deputy commissioner, paper currency, Lahore circle, June, 1877; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, April, 1878; accountant-general, Madras, and commissioner of paper currency, Jan., 1880; on special duty with the government of India, May, 1881; accountant-general, Bengal, Sept., 1881; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments; Jan., 1882; Bengal legislative council, Jan. to Oct., 1882; secretary, government of India, department of finance and commerce, July, 1882; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; on special duty in India, Sept.-Oct., 1886, and on special duty in England to serve as member of the Royal Commission on Currency in 1886; ordinary member of council of governor-general, 22nd Nov., 1888; K.C.S.I., Jan., 1889; author of 'The Theory of Bimetallism.'

BARCLAY, ERNEST, Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from 18th Sept., 1861, as French interpreter to the supreme court, Madras; acting deputy clerk of the crown and acting assistant registrar, and was appointed government solicitor, Feb., 1876.

BARCLAY, PRINGLE DAVID, Railway Department, Government of India.—Joined the department, March, 1875, as assistant traffic superintendent, Rajputana state railway; class 2, revenue establishment of state railways, Jan., 1880; traffic superintendent, Punjab Northern railway, March, 1881; Eastern Bengal railway, June, 1884; officiating manager, in addition, June, 1892.

BARKLEY, DAVID GRAHAM, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examina-
tion of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; officiating small cause court judge, Delhi, Sept., 1863; personal assistant to commissioner, Umballa, Nov., 1864; officiating registrar, chief court, Punjab, Aug., 1866; on special duty in the chief court, Nov., 1870, and again at Simla, June, 1871, and at Lahore, April, 1872; assistant sessions judge, March, 1873; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1874; additional commissioner, Delhi, May, 1876, and subsequently at Jallundar and Lahore; officiating judge, chief court, Punjab, Aug., 1878, and again in 1880; civil and sessions judge, Nov., 188c; commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, Sept., 1881; additional judge, chief court, Jan., 1882; additional member of Governor-General's council for making laws and regulations, May, 1883, and again in 1884; judge of the chief court, Punjab, Feb., 1886; retired Jan., 1887; has published 'Directions to Revenue and Settlement Officers, Non-Regulation Law.'

BARLOW, Sir Richard Wellesley, Bart., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed acting judge, small cause court, Tellicherry, Nov., 1869; acting civil and sessions judge, Chingleput, Feb., 1870; from 1871 to 1878 served as collector and magistrate of Chingleput, and subsequently as commissioner, Nilgiris, 1878-1880, and again in 1881; government member of the Lawrence Asylum committee, April, 1878; major commandant Nilgiri Volunteer Rifles, Dec., 1878, to Nov., 1879; acted as member of the Board of Revenue in 1880 with charge of the Inam department, and again in 1881, in charge of settlement department, and in 1886; collector and magistrate, and additional sessions judge, Nilgiris, Feb., 1882; collector of sea customs and of the Madras district, and protector of emigrants, Madras, Jan., 1883; acting resident, Travancore and Cochin, Feb. to Aug., 1884; additional member of the council, Madras, Sept., 1885; chairman of the Harbour Trust Board, May, 1886; superintendent of stamps and stationery, April, 1887, in addition to his other duties; retired Nov., 1889.

BARNES, Francis Carnac, Financial Department, Government of India.—Served in the financial department from 9th November, 1872, and was appointed assistant to accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1877; assistant comptroller-general, Calcutta, Nov., 1878; private secretary to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, April, 1882; class 4 of financial department, Aug., 1885; services retained under the government of Bengal as superintendent of stamps and stationery, April, 1887.

BARNES, Hugh Shakespear, Bengal C.S., Foreign Department, Government of India.—Educated at Malvern College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to financial department of government of India Dec., 1876, and appointed assistant to accountant-general in the N.W. Provinces; private secretary to the financial member of the governor-general's council, Dec., 1876; acted as under secretary in the home department in 1878; on special duty under the foreign department, Nov., 1879; assistant to resident, Kandahar, Nov., 1880; served in the Afghan campaign, 1881, as political officer with General Wilkinson's brigade; assistant to the governor-general's agent in Beloochistan, 1881-83; political agent in Quetta and Pishin, June, 1883; in charge of arrangements, supplies, &c., for passage of Afghan boundary commission across Belooch Desert, Aug., 1884; officiating under-secretary to Government of India, foreign department, April, 1889; and was confirmed in that appointment, May, 1890; officiating deputy secretary in the same department, May, 1890; resident, 2nd class, and revenue commissioner, Baluchistan, Dec., 1890; officiated as governor-general's agent and chief commissioner in 1891.

BARNETT, Ebenezer M., late Store Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 10th Nov., 1852; junior clerk, store department, July, 1860; senior clerk, March, 1868; retired, 8th May, 1887.

BARODA CHARAN MITRA, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Appointed under native civil service rules an assistant magistrate and collector, 30th March 1886, on probation; confirmed, 23rd March, 1888.

BARR, David William Keith, Lieutenant-Colonel, I.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Sept., 1864; served in Abyssinian expedition (medal); boundary commissioner, Rewa Kantha, and Malwa Bheel agency, 1869; political assistant and boundary officer, Bhopal, July, 1869; assistant to governor-general's agent, Central India, 1870; officiating political agent, 2nd class, Jodhpur, 1878-79; political agent Bhagelkund, July, 1881; also superintendent Rewa state; resident (2nd class) at Gwalior May, 1887.

BARRETT, Edwin Clifford, Survey of India Department.—Appointed probationary assistant surveyor, Indus-Sind revenue survey, 18th Nov., 1862; assistant superintendent, 2nd grade, Dec., 1868; accompanied Lushai expeditionary force, 1871-2 (medal and clasp); assistant superintendent, 1st grade, July, 1882; 4th grade deputy superintendent, Oct., 1884; 3rd grade, May, 1889; 2nd grade, July, 1892.

BARROW, Frank, Lieutenant-Colonel, I.S.C., Oudh Commission.—1st commission, lieutenant, 2nd Dragoons, 18th Sept., 1867; admitted to Bengal Staff Corps, 18th Sept., 1867; from Aug., 1869, served under the government of India, in the foreign department, as assistant commissioner in Oudh, and in 1870 and 1871 officiated as junior secretary to the chief commissioner, and as cantonment magistrate and deputy commissioner for various periods; appointed deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, June, 1880; 2nd grade, April, 1881.

BARROW, Frank Hunter, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bruton and Felsted Grammar Schools, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1870; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Nov., 1881; magistrate and collector, March, 1887.

BARROW, Oscar Theodore, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Gloucester College School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in
India, 3rd Dec., 1877; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to financial department, government of India, Oct., 1882; assistant accountant-general, Bengal, Feb., 1884; officiating deputy accountant-general, May, 1885; assistant accountant-general, Bengal, Sept. and Nov., 1885; and deputy accountant-general, Oct., 1885; comptroller of Indian treasuries, Nov., 1886; assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Mar., 1887; class 4 of enrolled officers, May, 1887; enrolled officer, class 3, Nov., 1887; deputy accountant general, Bombay, class 2, April, 1888; officiating accountant-general and deputy commissioner, paper currency, N.W.P., May, 1888; accountant-general, Bengal, April, 1891.

BARROW, Reginald Pocock, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oxford University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India 13th Nov., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1886.

BARRY, Thomas David Collis, Surgeon-Captain, Bombay Educational Department.—Joined the department, 27th May, 1839, as acting chemical analyst, professor of chemistry and medical jurisprudence, Grant Medical College, and professor of chemistry, Elphinstone College; confirmed in these posts, April, 1892.

BARRY, William, M.R.C.S., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Glasgow, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 14th Feb., 1863; from Dec., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; employed on famine duty under the government of Bengal, Dec., 1873, to Jan., 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Banda, Aug., 1877; from May, 1881, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1882; 2nd grade, April, 1887; retired March, 1890.

BARSTOW, Henry Clements, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from July, 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating small cause court judge; served under the government of India, foreign department, Jan., 1874, to Oct., 1875, as officiating political agent, 1st class, Bhopal; officiating superintendent, Dehra Dun, Feb., 1876; officiating civil and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Banda, Jan., 1880; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Cawnpore, April, 1880; retired, Nov., 1886.

BARTER, Joseph Francis, Brigade-Surgeon, late Madras Medical Department.—Joined the Madras medical service, July, 1859; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1860; from April, 1862, served in the Central Provinces as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, and acted for various periods as inspector-general of jails and as sanitary commissioner; rank of surgeon-major July, 1873; sanitary commissioner, superintendent of vaccination, and inspector-general of dispensaries, Central Provinces, Dec., 1878; civil surgeon and superintendent of lunatic asylum, Nagpur, July, 1883; brigade-surgeon, March, 1886; retired, April, 1890.

BARTHOLOMEW, Robert, Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Cavalry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 2nd April, 1862; from 1st Aug., 1866, served in the Punjab commission as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant, Sept., 1881; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884, Delhi, officiating as divisional judge; deputy commissioner, July, 1886; 2nd grade, Feb., 1887; 1st grade, Nov., 1890.

BARTLETT, Hubert Frederick, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; transferred to the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1880, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, June, 1885; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Aug., 1885; magistrate and collector, July, 1889.

BARTON, Ebenezer Johnston, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived, 10th Nov., 1862; from Sept., 1863, served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1882; also served as officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, Sept., 1871, and was on special famine duty, Bhagulpore division, Dec., 1873; retired, Aug., 1887.

BASANTA KUMAR MULLICK, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College School, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 13th Jan., 1890, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

BATCHELOR, Stanley Lockhart, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Edmund's College, Ware, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1889, and served in Bombay as assistant magistrate and collector.

BATE, Thomas Elwood Lindsay, Surgeon-Major, Jail Department, Punjab.—Joined the service, 31st March, 1875; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1875; served in military department to Nov., 1880, when he was appointed civil surgeon, Gujrat; officiated as inspector-general of prisons, Punjab, in 1889 and 1890, and was confirmed in that appointment, April, 1891.

BATESON, Robert Sander, Deputy-Surgeon-General, late Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1856; arrived in India, and was attached to military department as assistant surgeon, 7th Aug., 1856; placed in medical charge of the civil station and in executive charge of jail at Umballa, Nov., 1871; civil surgeon, 2nd class, Oct., 1877; brigade-surgeon, Oct., 1882; retired Sept., 1886.

BATTEN, Hallet George, Burma Commission.—Joined the service, 17th Oct., 1869, and on 13th Feb., 1871, was appointed extra assistant commissioner, Burma; assistant commissioner, Nov., 1877, and deputy commissioner, May,
BATTEN, John Kaye, Madras C.S.—Educated at Haileybury College, and at Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1884; arrived in Madras, 29th November, 1887, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate.

BATTY, Herbert, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, professor of logic and moral philosophy in the Deccan College, Poona (1872-75), assistant judge and sessions judge (1st grade, Feb., 1883), and acting judge and sessions judge; under secretary to government of Bombay, political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations, Nov., 1885; acted as district and sessions judge between 1886 and 1888; acting chief presidency magistrate, Bombay, April, 1888; acting remembrancer of legal affairs, May, 1888, and again in 1890; confirmed, June, 1892.

BAYLAY, Charles Allen, Colonel, I.S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal Artillery, Dec., 1857; assistant commissioner, Berar, Jan., 1866, and subsequently in Loodianah; political assistant, Rajputana, 1868-70; assistant general superintendent for suppression of Thagi and Dakaits, Dec., 1870; political agent, Haraoti and Tonk, 1876; additional political agent, 1st class, Kotah, Dec., 1879; acted as resident, western states of Rajputana in 1884; political agent in Kotah, 1888; retired, May, 1890.

BAYLEY, Charles Stuart, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow and Heidelberg; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1877; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, January, 1878; officiating assistant secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, July, 1880; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, general and revenue departments, March, 1881, and subsequently in the financial department, Oct., 1882; member of the executive committee, Calcutta International Exhibition of 1883-84, Aug., 1883; officiating under secretary, government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Feb., 1884; officiating registrar, high court, March, 1884; under secretary, government of India, revenue and agricultural department, April, 1885; assistant commissioner, Ajmere, Sept., 1886; political agent, Bikanir, June, 1888; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Jan., 1889; officiating political agent, Bikanir, Dec., 1890; confirmed, Sept., 1891.

BAYLEY, Lyttelton Holyoake, Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Advocate-general, Bombay, 17th March, 1866; judge of the high court, Bombay, June, 1869; acting chief justice, May-Dec., 1883, Nov., 1887, to Feb., 1888, and from June, 1892.

BAYLEY, Sir Steuart Colvin, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived in India 4th March, 1856; assistant magistrate and collector, 24 Pergunnahs, Nov., 1856; junior secretary to government of Bengal, Feb., 1863; officiated as secretary to the government of Bengal in 1865, 1867, and 1871; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Monghyr, Feb., 1867; officiating civil and sessions judge, Shahabad, May, 1867; commissioner, Dacca division, July, 1873, and subsequently of the Patna division, Sept., 1873; secretary, government of Bengal, May, 1877; additional secretary, government of India, financial department, Aug., 1877; personal assistant to H.E. the Viceroy, for famine affairs, Sept., 1877; additional secretary, government of India, public works department, famine branch, in addition to his own duties, Dec., 1877; secretary, government of India, home department, June, 1878; officiating chief commissioner, Assam, June, 1878; officiating lieutenant-governor of Bengal, July-Nov., 1879; chief commissioner of Assam, June, 1880; resident, 1st class, Hyderabad, March, 1881; governor-general's council, 9th May, 1882; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, April, 1887; retired Dec., 1890; appointed secretary, political and secret department, India Office; assumed charge, 13th Jan., 1891.

BAYNE, Charles Gerwien, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Uppingham, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1880, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, and officiating assistant secretary to chief commissioner; junior secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1886; under secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1887, and officiating secretary to chief commissioner, Feb., June, and Aug., 1888; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Nov., 1888; junior secretary to chief commissioner, Dec., 1890; secretary to chief commissioner, March, 1891; officiating chief secretary, March, 1892.

BEACHCROFT, Francis Porten, B.A., B.L., late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant, April, 1878; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Dec., 1883; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; 2nd grade, April, 1889; 1st grade, April, 1891; officiating judge of chief court, Punjab, April to Nov., 1890, and from May, 1891; retired, Nov., 1891.

BEADON, Cecil, Colonel, Madras Cavalry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 24th March, 1858; from May, 1862, served in the Punjab commission as assistant commissioner, cantonment magistrate, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, March, 1877; on special duty in connection with viceregal durbar, Nov., 1880; officiated as commissioner and superintendent at various periods; also officiated as divisional judge, Dera Ismail Khan, July to Oct., 1889.

BEAMAN, Frank Clement Offley, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant superintendent of police; acting assistant to the political agent,
Kathiawar, March, 1882, to Jan., 1883, and again 1885-86; acting junior collector and magistrate and political agent, March-April, 1883; from April, 1883, served in the judicial department, and was appointed acting judicial assistant to political agent, Kathiawar, May, 1884, and 3rd grade assistant judge, May, 1885; special settlement officer, Baroda, May, 1886, and November, 1887; acted district and sessions judge, Oct., 1887; 2nd grade assistant judge, April, 1890; judicial assistant to the political agent in Kathiawar, May, 1891.

BEAMES, JOHN, Bengal.C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 16th March, 1858; from March, 1859, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and from Dec., 1861, in Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, July, 1867; officiated as commissioner, Orissa division, Aug., 1873, and subsequently as commissioner of the Chittagong, Rajshahiye, and Cooch Behar and Dacca divisions; commissioner, Burdwan division, Nov., 1888; officiating member of board of revenue, March, 1887, and April, 1889; commissioner, Bhagulpore, Aug., 1887; president of the police revision committee, Aug., 1890; commissioner, Presidency division, Nov., 1891; author of 'Outlines of Indian Philology,' 1867; 'Comparative Grammar of the Modern Aryan Languages of India,' 1872-1879, and 'Grammar of the Bengali Language,' 1891; edited Sir H. M. Elliot's 'Races of the N.W. Provinces of India,' 1869.

BEAN, MAURICE, Captain, R.I.M., Port Officer, Bombay.—Joined the service as assistant port officer, Bombay; officiating port officer, Madras, April, 1891; port officer, Bombay, October, 1891.

BEARD, H. G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; writer, India store depot, 1st Feb., 1866; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

BEATSON, JOHN FULLARTON, Surgeon-General, M.D., C.I.E., late Bengal Medical Service.—B.A. and M.D., University of Glasgow; licentiate of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh; assistant surgeon, Bengal, 16th June, 1843; served with the army of the Sutlej, 1845-46, taking part in the defence of Ferozepore, and battle of Ferozeshah (medal and clasp); served in the Punjab Campaign, and was present at various actions (medal); surgeon, June, 1857; in charge of the Allahabad General Field Hospital during the period of the Mutiny; surgeon-major, June, 1863; garrison surgeon, Allahabad, 1865-68; medical storekeeper, Umballa, 1868-69; deputy inspector-general Meerut, May, 1869; surgeon-general, Nov., 1875; Companion of the Order of the Indian Empire, Jan., 1878; retired, March, 1880.

BEATTY, JOSEPH, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1852; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1855; served in the Madras public works department from March, 1855, as assistant engineer, and executive engineer; supervisor of the canals, Godavari, May, 1874; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, Aug., 1877; promoted to 1st grade, Oct., 1878; retired, May, 1889.

BEATTY, THOMAS BERKELEY, Surgeon-General, M.D., late Bombay Medical Service.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin (A.B. and M.B.); joined the Bombay medical service, May, 1851; arrived in India, 27th June, 1851; civil surgeon, Karachi, July, 1853; superintendent of vaccination, April, 1856; acting civil surgeon, Poona, 22nd May, 1866, and again in 1872; superintendent, Matheran, Dec., 1867; deputy-surgeon general, Poona, Oct., 1876; principal medical officer, Malta Expeditionary Force, May to Sept., 1878; surgeon-general with the government of Bombay, April, 1880; retired, March, 1885; is the author of various contributions on medical subjects in the Transactions of the Medical and Physical Society, Bombay.

BEAUMONT, THOMAS, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., F.R.C.S.I., late Madras Medical Department.—Arrived in India, 13th Sept., 1857; served under the military department till Feb., 1864, when he was appointed residency surgeon, Indore; residency surgeon, Hyderabad, June, 1881; also superintendent of vaccination and superintendent of medical school; retired, Oct., 1885.

BEAUMONT, WILLIAM, late Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras revenue survey department from 27th May, 1858, as assistant superintendent, and deputy superintendent; reorganisation committee, Madras, March, 1871; promoted to 1st class deputy superintendent, June, 1877; board of examiners, Nov., 1882; retired, Nov., 1887.

BEAVAN, REGINALD, Colonel, I.S.C., late Survey of India Department.—Ensign, 4th May, 1860; arrived in India 11th June, 1860; served in the military department, and in Sept., 1867, was appointed to the staff corps, and in July, 1868, to the topographical survey department as assistant surveyor; served with various survey parties, and in July, 1880, organised and took charge of the Baluchistan topographical survey; deputy superintendent, 4th grade, Nov., 1884, and 3rd grade, June, 1889; retired, June, 1892; in the military department served in Southern Afghanistan, from Oct., 1878 (medal); accompanied the Marri field force and the Bozdar field force in 1880 and 1881.

BECHER, ALFRED READ, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined, July, 1868; arrived in India, 14th Oct., 1868; served in the Punjab as assistant engineer on the Sirhind canal; from April, 1873, served in the accounts branch, Punjab, as assistant controller, and deputy controller; transferred to Bombay, Nov., 1875; served subsequently in Hyderabad, Oudh, Rajputana, and Mysore; examiner of accounts, Calcutta, June, 1886; 3rd class examiner, Sept., 1886; officiated as deputy accountant-general and under secretary to Government of India in 1888 and 1889, and from Oct., 1890.

BECKETT, HENRY BARRON, Punjab Commission.—Served from 10th May, 1850, in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating inspector of schools, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Peshawur, Aug., 1884; officiated as divisional judge, Dec., 1884, and again in 1886 and 1890; and was appointed district judge 1st grade, Oct., 1885, and deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Aug., 1886; 1st grade, May, 1889; officiated as commissioner in 1891.

BEDFORD, CHARLES AUGUSTUS S., Bengal Commission.—Joined the service, 25th July, 1864, as assistant commissioner; civil assistant
political officer, Lushai expeditionary force, Feb., 1889; deputy commissioner, April, 1891.

BEDFORD, JAMES PERCH, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Madras, 14th Dec., 1889, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

BEGBIE, ALFRED GLYNN, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, July, 1861; arrived in India, Nov., 1870; joined the public works department, Feb., 1871, as assistant engineer in the railway department, Central India; executive engineer, Oct., 1871; Agra-Gwalior railway survey, Nov., 1872; officiating deputy controller of accounts, Bengal, Aug., 1874; officiated as examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, at Calcutta and Bombay, 1874-75; controller of accounts, Mysore, Aug., 1875; examiner guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, 1878; Punjab Northern railway accounts, 1880; deputy accountant-general, and ex officio under secretary to Government of India, Jan., 1886; officiating accountant general, public works department, and deputy secretary, government of India, April, 1886, to March, 1887; examiner, 1st class, May, 1886; officiating accountant-general and deputy secretary to government of India, public works department, May to Oct., 1887, and Sept., 1888, and confirmed in those appointments, Oct., 1889.

BEHARI LAL GUPTA, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Colootola Branch School, Calcutta, Calcutta University, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 29th Sept., 1871; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1871; on famine relief duty, Sept., 1874; presidency magistrate, Calcutta, and coroner of Calcutta, June, 1881; officiating district and sessions judge, April, 1884; March, 1885, and Feb., 1887, and confirmed, Nov., 1888.

BEIGHTON, THOMAS DURANT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King Edward's School, Birmingham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived 4th Dec., 1867; served in Bengal in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating small cause court judge, officiating district and sessions judge, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty in connection with boundary disputes on the Bhutan frontier, Jan., 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1878; district and sessions judge, May, 1885; author of 'The Ethnography of the Bhutan Frontier.'

BELCHAMBERS, ROBERT, Judicial Department, Bengal.—Registrar of the high court, Calcutta, from 1862; is also keeper of records, taxing officer, accountant-general, and sealer; author of 'Practice of the Civil Courts,' and other legal publications.

BELL, CHARLES ALFRED, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 3rd Nov., 1891, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

BELL, HENRY JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Gordon's College, Aberdeen, Aberdeen University, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 26th Nov., 1890, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

BELL, HORACE, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed probationary assistant engineer, 7th July, 1862; served in the Central Provinces and Central India, and was promoted to executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1871; subsequently served on the Punjab northern state railway, and on the Rajputana state railway, as superintendent of way and works, and as acting manager, also as officiating engineer-in-chief on the Sindia and Neemuch state railways; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, Jan., 1880; transferred to Bengal, Nov., 1881; engineer-in-chief, Dacca and Mymensingh railway surveys, Dec., 1881; while on furlough superintended assistant engineers on practical course in England; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Jan., 1883; on special duty, Aug., 1883, on committee for considering reorganisation scheme for public works department; manager and engineer-in-chief, Tirhoot state railway, Feb., 1884; held charge Nalhati railway, July-Sept., 1884; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1886; acting director, North-Western Railway, July to Oct., 1887; engineer-in-chief and manager, Tirhoot State Railway, Oct., 1887, to March, 1888; engineer-in-chief, Great-Western of India railway survey, Sept., 1888, and of the Moghal Sarai Howrah railway survey, Feb., 1889; consulting engineer to the Government of India for railways, Aug., 1890; chief engineer, 3rd class, Oct., 1890; 2nd class, June, 1891; 1st class, Jan., 1892; author of 'Laws of Wealth,' a work on political economy for native readers.

BELL, JAMES RICHARD, M.I.C.E., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the service, Oct., 1868, and served as assistant engineer, executive engineer, and superintendent of works in various projects; received the special thanks of the Government of India in connection with the construction of the Ferozepore bridge, 1887; engineer-in-chief, Hyderabad-Umarkot railway survey, Jan., 1890; in charge of Mari extension of the Sind-Sagar branch of the North-Western railway, Feb., 1890; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Oct., 1890; 2nd class, Nov., 1890; 1st class, June, 1892; officiating consulting engineer to the government of India for state railways, July-Oct., 1891; on special duty, Oct.-Dec., 1891; engineer in chief of the Mari-Attock extension railway and frontier railway surveys, Dec., 1891.

BELL, MATTHEW DENNY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; acting senior assistant collector, Ganjam, March, 1887; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Nov., 1889.

BELL, NICHOLAS DODD BEATSON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton Bank, St. Andrews, Edinburgh Academy and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1889, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

BELLETT, GEORGE, M.A., Education Department, Bengal.—Joined the service, 1st Feb.,
1861; served successively as 2nd master, headmaster, and professor, Dacca College; inspector of schools, Nov., 1868; professor, Presidency College, Dec., 1873; principal, Berhampore College, May, 1875; 2nd class, educational service, March, 1876; subsequently served as officiating principal, Patna College, officiating principal, Presidency College, and officiating director of public instruction (Jan., 1883); inspector of schools, Nov., 1881, 1st class, educational service, June, 1887.

BELLINGHAM, HORACE, Financial Department, India Office.—Writer, 18th May, 1892; clerk specially attached, Sept., 1892.

BENNETT, WILLIAM CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd class, and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed to take up land for railway purposes in Fyzabad, Feb., 1870; manager of encumbered estates, Gonda, March, 1872, to Feb., 1875; officiated as city magistrate, Lucknow, in 1878 and 1879; officiating secretary to government, Oudh revenue department, Sept.-Nov., 1879; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1882; director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1881; secretary, board of revenue, May, 1886; officiating secretary to government, revenue and judicial departments, June, 1886; confirmed, Nov., 1888; officiated as chief secretary in 1887, 1888, 1889, and 1891; secretary in judicial department, April, 1889; member of lieutenant-governor's legislative council, Feb., 1889, to Dec., 1891; author of 'History of the Chief Clans of the Rae Bareli District'; and contributions to the Oudh Gazetteer.

BENGEL, ALFRED, Auditor's Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 20th Nov., 1866; junior examiner, June, 1867; senior examiner, July, 1877.

BENNETT, J., M.D., Brigade-Surgeon, late Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1865; arrived in India, 26th Sept., 1865; services placed at disposal of civil department, Sept., 1870; civil surgeon, Murrree, Dec., 1872; superintendent of vaccination, Punjab, July, 1877; superintendent-general of vaccination, Punjab, March, 1880; deputy sanitary commissioner, Eastern Circle, Dec., 1881, to April, 1884; civil surgeon, Mooltan, Jan., 1883; also superintendent of central jail, Dec., 1883; civil surgeon, Rawalpindi, April, 1884; civil surgeon, 1st class, Sept., 1884; medical adviser to his Highness the Maharaja of Patiala, Aug., 1885; retired Sept., 1890.

BENSLEY, EDWIN CLEMENT, Surgeon-Major, late Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1859; served from 22nd July, 1863, as civil assistant surgeon at Midnapore and Rajshahiye; civil surgeon, Rajshahye, Oct., 1875; rank of surgeon-major, Feb., 1877; retired, Nov., 1885.

BENSON, CHARLES, M.R.A.C., Madras Revenue Department.—Joined the service, 30th Jan., 1874, as assistant superintendent, Saidapet farms; assistant director of agriculture, April, 1884; assistant commissioner of land records and agriculture, April, 1887; assistant director of that department, Nov., 1887; deputy director of agriculture, Jan., 1892.

BENSON, RALPH SILLERY, M.A., LL.B., B.L., Madras C.S.—Educated at Rathmines School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1873, and served as assistant collector and magistrate (Salem), acting head assistant collector and magistrate of Cuddapah during the famine of 1876-78, acting assistant commissioner and acting commissioner (Nilgiris), 1878 to 1881, and acting collector and magistrate; was specially appointed as officer for the settlement of lands in the Nilgiri districts; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, North Arcot, June, 1882; on special duty as secretary to the local self-government committee, Oct., 1882; forest settlement officer, May, 1883; and secretary to the committee for drafting new municipal and local board bills; acting under-secretary to government in the chief secretary's department, Jan., 1885, and again in Oct., 1887; acting registrar, high court, July, 1885; acting secretary to the commissioners of land revenue, Nov., 1887, to April, 1888; sub-collector and joint magistrate and acting district and sessions judge, April, 1888; district and sessions judge, Nov., 1889; author of the 'Settlement Registers and Descriptive Memoirs of the Nilgiri Districts', and of the 'Report on the Settlement of the Nilgiri District,' 1885.

BENSON, THOMAS, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Tavistock Grammar School, Marlborough College, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant settlement officer, manager of the Awa estate under the court of wards, officiating district and session judge, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, Oct., 1883; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1885; district and sessions judge, April, 1887.

BENTHALL, ERNEST, late Store Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India Office, 19th Dec., 1865; junior clerk, Nov., 1866; senior clerk, Dec., 1877; retired, Dec., 1889.

BENTINCK, BARON JOHN, Punjab Commission.—Educated at Leyden University (doctor of Roman and Dutch law); joined the service, 6th Dec., 1869, as assistant commissioner; officiated as magistrate at various periods; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1892.

BENTON, ALEXANDER HAY, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the University and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1861; arrived in India, 20th Feb., 1864; and served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; judicial assistant, Nov., 1876; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1879; divisional judge, Nov., 1884; judge of Chief Court, Punjab, Nov., 1889.

BERESFORD, JOHN STUART, M.E., M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces, 26th July, 1867; executive engineer, Sept., 1872; had charge of various divisions of Ganges Canal; personal assistant to chief engineer, irrigation, May, 1877, and from Nov., 1884, to March, 1885; employed on Betwa
BERESFORD, LORD W. LESLIE DE LA POER, Colonel, V.C., C.I.E., 9th Lancers.—First commission, as cornet, June, 1867; served in the Jowaki-Afreedee expedition, 1877-8 (medal and clasp); served also in the Zulu war of 1879, and was present at battle of Ulundi (Victoria Cross, medal, and clasp); served in the Afghan war, 1878-80, and was present at the capture of Ali Musjid (medal and clasp); A.D.C. to Viceroy of India, 1875 to 1881; military secretary on the personal staff of the viceroy and governor-general, 13th Dec., 1881; served with the Burmese expedition of 1886, as military secretary to governor-general (brevet of lieut.-colonel and clasp).

BERKELEY, JAMES CAVAN, C.I.E., Colonel, I.S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Oct., 1875; served in civil employ from June, 1862, as assistant to the governor-general's agent in Central India; also served as boundary settlement officer, deputy opium agent in Malwa, assistant general superintendent for Thagi and Dakaiti, and sessions judge and registrar for Mhow; political agent, Haaroti and Tonk, 1873; political agent, Bhagalcund, Jan., 1879, to Nov., 1882; political agent, Jacobabad, 1882; officiating resident, Gwalior, March, 1883; on special duty, Kashmir, April-Aug., 1884; political agent, Bundelcund, 1884; officiating resident, Nipal, 1885; resident, 2nd class, and governor-general's agent at Baroda, April, 1886; reverted to military department, Nov., 1887.
