BERNARD, SIR CHARLES EDWARD, K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S., Revenue and Statistics Department, India Office.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1858, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and was appointed under-secretary to government of India, financial department, Aug., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the Central Provinces as judge of the small cause court, Nagpur, settlement officer, secretary to the chief commissioner (July, 1864), commissioner of Nagpur division (Feb., 1869), and acting judicial commissioner; from May, 1871, to Jan., 1875, served in Bengal as member of the lieutenant-governor's council, and acting secretary to the government, first in the judicial department, then in the revenue department, and lastly in the scarcity and relief department; from Nov., 1876, served as commissioner of Nagpur division; secretary to Sir Richard Temple, Bart., K.C.S.I., deputed on a special mission to the Bombay and Madras Presidencies, Jan., 1877; judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Aug., 1877; additional secretary to the government of India in the department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Aug., 1877, and in the financial department, Dec., 1877; served as secretary to the government of India in the home department, May, 1878, to July, 1880; secretary to government of India in revenue and agricultural department, July, 1881; from July, 1880, acted as chief commissioner of British Burma, and was confirmed in this appointment April, 1882; retired, March, 1888, and was appointed secretary in the revenue and statistics department, India office.

BERNARD, JAMES HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1832; arrived in India 30th Dec., 1834; assistant magistrate and collector, Midnapore, Jan., 1835; personal assistant to the chief commissioner, British Burma, June, 1886; services replaced at disposal of government of Bengal, Feb., 1887; officiated as under secretary to government of Bengal in 1887; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Dec., 1891.

BERRILL, EDWARD, Police Department, N.W. Provinces.—Joined the service as adjutant military police, Central Provinces, 14th Aug., 1838; inspector of police, N.W. Provinces, 27th Feb., 1861, and assistant inspector-general, Dec., 1861; acted for various periods as district superintendent, and was appointed to that post, May, 1867; assistant inspector-general, railway police, Oct., 1885, and of the special branch, June, 1888; in addition district superintendent of police, Jan., 1890; served in the mutiny in Barrow's volunteer cavalry, July, 1857 to April, 1858.

BEST, JAMES WILLIAM, B.A., B.L., Madras C.S.—Educated at Wimborne Grammar School, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 8th Dec., 1862; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and sub-collector and joint magistrate in various districts; from Jan., 1875, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, South Canara, Sept., 1877; officiated as judge of high court, Jan., 1890; district and sessions judge, Chingleput, Jan., 1891; officiating judge of the high court, Feb., 1892.

BETTINGTON, ALBEMARLE, late Bombay C.S.—Entered the Bombay civil service from Haileybury, 1830; served in the usual grades in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed deputy collector of continental customs and excise, 1843; collector and magistrate, Ahmedabad, 1849; inspector-general of prisons and commissioner of police, Bombay, 1855; retired 1861; author of 'The Destruction of Life by Snakes and Hydrophobia.'

BEVAN, JAMES FORBES, Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as assistant, 21st June, 1866; arrived in India 14th Sept., 1866, and served in various lines in Bengal and the Punjab; superintendent, 19th June, 1880; held charge of the Indore, Rajputana, Arakan, Bengal, Burma and Bombay divisions; in charge, check office, June, and Oct., 1891; officiating director, construction branch, Sept., 1891; in charge, Bombay division, Jan., 1892.

BEVERIDGE, HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 20th Jan., 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating deputy commissioner, Cooch Behar, and magistrate and collector (2nd grade, April, 1874); on special duty in Munipore under the government of India, foreign department, Nov., 1863; from Oct., 1874, served in the judicial department as officiating district and sessions judge, and was appointed district and sessions judge, Marc,
1875; author of a 'History of Backergunge,' and 'The Trial of Nandakumar.'

BEVERLEY, HENRY, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sedbergh School, Yorkshire, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived 31st Oct., 1861; from May, 1862, served in the revenue and judicial department as assistant magistrate and collector, deputy commissioner, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1865, and Aug., 1867; registrar-general of assurances, March, 1867; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Dec., 1870; inspector-general of registration, Dec., 1870; superintended the first census of Bengal in 1872; superintended the census of Calcutta, 1876; officiating judge of Nuddea, April, 1875; officiating inspector-general of jails, Lower Provinces, Aug., 1876; district and sessions judge, and grade, and additional judge, 24-Pergunnahs and Hooghly, Dec., 1877; member of the prison conference, 1877; member of the census committee, 1878; officiating commissioner of police, Calcutta, and chairman of the corporation, March, 1880; special census officer of Calcutta and suburbs, Dec., 1880, and published a report on the census, 1881; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Nov., 1883; member, Bengal legislative council, Jan., 1884; member of sanitary commission, Calcutta, Sept., 1884; officiated as judge of the high court, Calcutta, 9th April, 1884, to 15th Sept., 1884, and again from 12th Jan., 1885; confirmed, 3rd May, 1885; has published a 'Registration Manual' and 'The Land Registration Act.'

BHAGWAN CHUNDER CHAKARBUTTI, late Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 9th Oct., 1861, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 1st grade, May, 1884; retired, Nov., 1891.

BHARAT SINGH, KUNWAR, Bengal C.S. (N.-W. Provinces and Oudh).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 16th Feb., 1880; confirmed, March, 1882; served as assistant magistrate and collector and assistant commissioner; joint magistrate, March, 1892.

BIDDULPH, CUTHBERT EDWARD, M.A., Political Department, Government of India.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; joined the service as probationary assistant settlement officer, Sind, 16th Jan., 1878; services placed at disposal of agent to governor-general for Baluchistan, Nov., 1878; assistant to the political superintendent, Sawant Wari, in charge of the Sir Dasai, Feb., 1880; from Aug., 1880, to June, 1881, served in the commissariat department; assistant survey and settlement commissioner, Baroda, Nov., 1883; revenue settlement officer, Meywar, Dec., 1886; assistant commissioner, Berar, Feb., 1891; acting cantonment magistrate, Secunderabad, March, 1892; served during the Afghan War of 1878-80 in political charge at Dadur in Kutchi in 1878-9, of Sibi district in 1879, and in commissariat charge of Bolan Pass, 1880 to 1881 (medal); author of 'Our Western Frontier of India,' 'Afghan Politics,' 'Afghan Poetry of the 17th Century;' and 'Army Reforms in Native States.'

BIDDULPH, JOHN, Colonel, I.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Cornet, Bengal cavalry, Jan., 1858; arrived in India, 4th March, 1858; served with various cavalry regiments, and received the mutiny medal; aide-de-camp to the Viceroy, May, 1872, to Feb., 1877; on special duty as member of mission to Yarkand, &c., 1873-74; employed on a secret mission to the countries beyond Gilgit, 1876 (brevet of Major); on special duty in Gilgit, Sept., 1877; acting agent to governor-general, Beloochistan, May-Nov., 1882; political agent, Bhopawur, Dec., 1882; acted as resident and boundary settlement officer in Meywar, 1885; political agent in Haroati and Tonk, April, 1886; resident and class and commissioner, Ajmere, April, 1890; officiating agent in Baluchistan, July, 1891; officiating resident, Gwalior, April, 1892; author of 'Tribes of the Hindukush.'

BIDDULPH, THOMAS HENRY STILLINGFLEET, Financial Department, Government of India.—From July, 1869, to March, 1871, served as accountant, public works accounts, in Central India and Punjab, and as examiner of railway accounts; probationer in financial department, March, 1871; assistant to the accountant-general N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1874; on special duty at Durbanagh in Bengal, June, 1874, to May, 1875; from Jan., 1879, served as assistant accountant-general in the N.W. Provinces, and also in the Punjab, Nov., 1881, to April, 1882, and as deputy accountant-general in Madras, April-Oct., 1882; officiated for various periods as deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh; controller, Hyderabad, Dec., 1884; confirmed in class 3 of enrolled officers, June, 1888; class 2, April, 1892; author of a work on the silver question.

BIDEN, W. M., B.A., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Mark's College, Chelsea, and King's College, London; provisional assistant, art library, South Kensington Museum, 1870; clerk, 2nd class, India Store Depot, 1st July, 1875; supervisor, 2nd grade, June, 1886; B.A., London University, 1880.

BIDIE, GEORGE, Surgeon-General, A.M., M.B., F.L.S., F.R.C.S.E., C.I.E., late Madras Medical Department.—Educated at the University of Aberdeen; joined the medical service as assistant surgeon, 20th Feb., 1856; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1856, and served under the military department till June, 1859; was subsequently employed as civil surgeon of Guntoor, 1859-61, medical officer of the Mysore farm commissariat establishments, and medicinal garden, Hoonsoor, 1861-64, professor of botany and materia medica in the Medical College, acting principal medical storekeeper, and superintendent of the lunatic asylum, Madras, and served in Mysore and Coorg, Nov., 1867, to Feb., 1868, on special duty in the coffee districts; secretary to the surgeon-general, Indian medical department (military), March, 1870; superintendent of the government central museum, Aug., 1872, to Dec., 1884, and again Jan., 1885; on special duty at Otacamund in connection with cinchona commission, Oct., 1873; fellow of Madras university, April, 1879; secretary to the surgeon-general, H.M.'s forces, left wing, April, 1880, to Nov., 1884; brigade surgeon, Feb., 1883; board of examiners, May, 1883; served in public department, Nov.-Dec., 1883, in connection with Calcutta International Exhibition, and special committee for promotion of art and manufacture; deputy surgeon-general, H.M.'s forces, British Burma division, Dec.,
1884 to Jan., 1885; sanitary commissioner, Madras, April, 1885; member of committee in connection with the scheme of technical education, Sept., 1885; acting surgeon-general with the government of Madras from April, 1886; confirmed in appointment, Oct., 1886; retired April, 1890; author of numerous publications connected with the botany and zoology of the Madras Presidency.

BIERNACKI, ANDREW, late Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st sub-engineer, Punjab Northern railway, temporary, Jan., 1870; confirmed 10th Oct., 1871; revenue establishment of state railways, Class IV., as assistant locomotive superintendent, Jan., 1876, Class III., Nov., 1878, and Class II., Jan., 1882; locomotive and carriage superintendent, Sind section, N.W. railway, May, 1887; deputy locomotive superintendent in class I., July, 1889; retired, 1890.

BIGG-WITHER, ARCHIBALD CUTHBERT, Lieut.-Colonel, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed assistant engineer from Thomason College, Oct., 1866; after serving in the Bengal Infantry from Jan., 1862; executive engineer, Sept., 1871; served chiefly on the Indus Valley State Railway, and in Baluchistan from 1885, where he was employed on the frontier road circle in 1888; secretary to agent to governor-general, Baluchistan, and 3rd superintending engineer, May, 1890; 2nd, July, 1891.

BIGGE, WILLIAM, M.A., B.L., Judicial Department, Burma.—Educated at New College, Oxford; acted as 1st judge of the small cause court, Rangoon, from 19th January, 1886, and was confirmed in that appointment, 28th Sept., 1886; officiating judge of Moulmein Town, Feb., 1892.

BIGGS, C., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 3rd April, 1882.

BIGGS, THOMAS HESKETH, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, 26th Sept., 1868, and served as assistant to accountant-general in Bombay, the Central Provinces, and Madras; assistant to comptroller-general, Dec., 1873; on special duty in Madras in connection with the inquiry into certain frauds in the stamp department, Dec., 1873, to Feb., 1874; served subsequently in the Punjab, the Central Provinces, Bengal, Bombay, and Assam, as assistant to accountant-general, officiating for various periods as deputy accountant-general; appointed comptroller, Assam, Aug., 1880; assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Jan., 1883; officiating comptroller of Indian treasuries, Oct.–Nov., 1883; deputy accountant-general, Punjab, in 3rd class of the financial department, 1885; comptroller, Burma, March, 1887; author of 'The Grammar of Indian Finance.'

BIGNELL, EDWARD DUNCAN FREDERICK, Major, I.S.C., Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, 7th July, 1866; lieutenant, Oct., 1871; wing officer, July, 1876; adjutant, Malwa Bhil Corps, 1881 to 1887, and again in 1889 and 1890; second in command of Meywar Bhil Corps, and second assistant resident, Meywar, April, 1890; officiating commandant of the corps, and political superintendent, Hilly Tracts, Meywar, April, 1891.

BIGNELL, WILLIAM KYD D'OYLEY, Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian Telegraph department, Feb., 1857; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1866; superintendent, Nagpur, Jan., 1868; served in the Punjab from 1873; 1st grade superintendent, Aug., 1881; officiating director, construction branch, director-general's office, Nov., 1883, to Feb., 1884; officiating director, Nov., 1886, to Feb., 1887; superintendent, Class IV., Oct., 1887; arranged telegraphs during Hazara expedition, 1888.

BIRCH, EDWARD ALFRED, Brigade-Surgeon Lieut.-Colonel, M.D., F.R.C.S., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1866; served through the Behar famine, March, 1874, and afterwards as civil surgeon at various stations; from Nov., 1881, officiated as surgeon superintendent, Presidency General Hospital, and also held charge of the office of sanitary commissioner, Bengal, June-July, 1882, and acted as professor of midwifery at the Medical College, and obstetric physician, Eden Hospital, May, 1883; surgeon superintendent, Presidency Hospital (sub pro tem.), Dec., 1883; confirmed in this appointment, Jan., 1885; civil surgeon, Hooghly, July, 1889; principal and professor of medicine, and first physician, College Hospital, June, 1890.

BIRCH, ERNEST G., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1849; served in the revenue and survey departments, Bengal, and was appointed superintendent of survey, northern division, 1854; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Baraset, 1858; magistrate and collector, Burdwan, 1860; civil and sessions judge, Moorshedabad, 1864, and subsequently of Shahabad; additional judge of Chittagong, 1870; district and sessions judge of Burdwan, 1872; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1873; retired 1879.

BIRCH, FREDERICK MACDONALD, Colonel, I.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India 15th May, 1854; from Jan., 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, small cause court judge, and deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty in Cashmere, July, 1864, and again, Dec., 1878, and with the financial commissioner's office, May, 1866; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Oct., 1879, to Oct., 1880, and subsequently in the Mooltan and Hissar divisions; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st class, Nov., 1880; reverted to military department, 1891.

BIRCH, WILLIAM BRERETON, Colonel, I.S.C., late Punjab Administration.—Arrived in India as ensign, 30th Nov., 1858, and was posted to 32nd Native Infantry, Bengal; served with the China forces 1861-62 (medal); joined the Bengal police department, July, 1863, and served as superintendent in various districts; member of Calcutta examination committee for judicial and police officers, March, 1867; vice-chairman, Burdwan municipality, March, 1867; officiating deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, and a visitor of the Presidency jail and lunatic asylums, Feb., 1869; commanded Sylhet frontier police battalion, on Looshai expedition, Sept., 1871, to March, 1872; 2nd assistant superintendent, Andamans, April, 1873; 1st assistant superintendent, 1885; services replaced at the disposal of the military department, March, 1888; officiating cantonment magistrate, 2nd class, Punjab, July, 1889; retired Nov., 1890; author of a report on sugar manufacture in the N.W. Provinces and Bengal (1881), a report on jail manufactures in India (1881), and of the Andamans and Nicobar Manual, 1886.
BIRD, CHARLES AUGUSTUS, late Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from June, 1866, and was appointed principal assistant collector, May, 1881, district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Oct., 1884, and collector and magistrate in the same district, Feb., 1885; district and sessions judge, Godavari, Sept., 1888; retired, Aug., 1890.

BIRD, CHARLES PAVIN, B.L., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; district judge, 2nd grade, Sept., 1886; officiating divisional judge, Feb., 1888; district judge, 1st grade, March, 1889; divisional judge, April, 1892.

BIRD, HUBERT MOORE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portarlington School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant and joint magistrate and assistant commissioner, and also acted as deputy commissioner and magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, April, 1884; joint magistrate, Sept., 1887; deputy commissioner, July, 1890; magistrate and collector, April, 1891.

BIRDWOOD, SIR GEORGE C. M., Kt., K.C.I.E., C.S.I., M.D., LL.D., Revenue and Statistics Department, India Office.—Educated at the Plymouth Grammar School, and University of Edinburgh (M.D. and L.R.C.S., 1854); Bombay medical service, 1854; between 1855 and 1857 served under the military department, and held temporary charge of the civil station of Sholapore, including the jail; served in the Persian War of 1856-57 (medal and clasp); from April, 1857 to 1868, held successively the professorships of anatomy and physiology, botany and materia medica in the Grant Medical College, Bombay; curator of the Government Central Museum, Bombay, 1857, and with the assistance of Dr. Bhau Daji and the leading natives of Bombay foundee the Victoria and Albert Museum and Victoria Gardens, Bombay; Sheriff of Bombay, 1864, and subsequently registrar of the University of Bombay; special commissioner for the government of Bombay at the Universal Exhibition at Paris, 1867; appointed to assist Dr. Forbes Watson in connection with the annual exhibitions at South Kensington commenced in 1871; special assistant in the statistics and commerce department, India Office, Jan., 1872; is also visitor to the India Museum; C.S.I., 1877; Kt., 1881; LL.D., Cambridge, 1886; was a royal commissioner for the Colonial and Indian Exhibition of 1886, and a member of the finance committee appointed to assist the Prince of Wales in connection with the exhibition; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887; chairman of the committee of the Indian section of the Paris exhibition, 1889; and a royal commissioner for the Chicago Exhibition of 1893; author of the following publications: 'The Economic Vegetable Products of the Bombay Presidency'; a paper 'On the Genus Boswellia (Frankincense Trees)', Linn. Trans. of 1869; 'Handbook to the British Indian Section of the Paris Universal Exhibition of 1878;' an official 'Report on the Miscellaneous Old Records of the India Office,' 1879 (2nd ed., 1890; 3rd ed., 1891); a work on 'The Industrial Arts of India,' published in 1880 by the Science and Art Department; 'The Arts of India,' a handbook to the collection of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, 1881, and several other handbooks on Indian art published by the department in connection with Indian exhibitions held at York, Berlin, Copenhagen, Stockholm, and Amsterdam; an introduction to the 'Dawn of British Trade to the East Indies,' 1886; an appendix on Aryan fauna and flora to Professor Max Müller's 'Biographies of Words,' 1888; a 'Report on Spanish Chestnuts,' 1892; and author also of various contributions to the 'Quarterly Review,' the 'Asiatic Quarterly Review,' &c., &c.; and editor of 'The Register of Letters, &c. of the East India Company, 1600-10,' 1893.

BIRDWOOD, HERBERT MILLS, M.A., LL.D., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University and Peterhouse, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858, and afterwards transferred to the Bombay service; arrived in Bombay, 26th Jan., 1859, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, under secretary to government in the judicial department, and secretary to the legislative council, Bombay, acting political assistant in Kathiawar, senior assistant judge and session judge, and registrar of the high court; judge and session judge, Surat, March, 1875; 1st grade judge, Dec. 1877; on special duty at Oodeypore, Sept., 1880; judicial commissioner in Scinde and judge of the Sadar court, Feb., 1881; on special duty in Bombay, March, 1881; judge of the high court, Bombay, Jan., 1883; member of council of governor of Bombay, April, 1892; edited vols. iv and v and (in collaboration with Mr. H. J. Parsons) vols. vi to viii of 'West's Code of Acts and Regulations'; is compiler of a catalogue of Bills introduced into the Bombay Legislative Council in 1862-5, and also of papers relating to the constitution and functions of the Legislative Council (Selection No. xcii. N.S. from Records of Bombay Government).

BIRKS, ARTHUR RAWSON, B.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Highgate School, and Corpus Christi College, Cambridge; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1873, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner; transferred to Burma, April, 1874; served in the grade of assistant commissioner, and acted as collector of customs, Bassein, March, 1878, and as judge of Moulmein, 1880-1882; on special duty in Rangoon, Aug., 1882; officiating director of public instruction, Aug., 1882; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, May, 1884; 3rd grade, Aug., 1886; 2nd grade, Jan., 1889; 1st grade, Oct., 1890; officiating commissioner, Southern division, June, 1892.

BISHOP, EDWARD F., Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 15th March, 1866; senior clerk, June, 1882.

BISSET, WILLIAM SINCLAIR SMITH, C.I.E.,
Lieut.-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service Dec., 1866, as assistant engineer, Rohilcund; railway branch, Bengal, 1870; assistant consulting engineer, Bengal, July, 1870; also officiating manager, Calcutta and S.E. state railway; superintendent Darjeeling railway survey, Oct., 1870; Holkar state railway, Nov., 1870; executive engineer, March, 1871; deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, April, 1872; manager, Holkar state railway, Dec., 1875; on special duty, Madras famine relief works, 1877; served in the Afghan war, 1878-80 (medal); manager, Rajputana and Scindia railway, Sept., 1879; class 1, grade 2, state railway revenue establishment, June, 1881; agent, Bombay, Baroda, and Central India railway company, Jan., 1885; supernumerary, class I, grade 1, Nov., 1885; C.I.E., June, 1888.

BLACK, CHARLES E. D., late Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Educated at Harrow School (Latin verse prize, 1862); supplemental clerk, science and art department, 1866-69; writer, India office, 20th Sept., 1869; geographical department clerk, July, 1873; detached in 1880 to be assistant private secretary, and subsequently, from May, 1884, principal private secretary to H.M.'s secretary of state, home department (Rt. Hon. Sir William V. Harcourt); secretary to the royal commission on the blind, the deaf, and dumb, &c., July, 1885; clerk for geographical records, India office, Sept., 1885; retired, Oct., 1892; author of the 'Annual Abstracts of the Reports of the Surveys, and of other Geographical Operations in India' from 1873 to 1878, and of a 'Memoir on the Indian Surveys, 1875-90.'

BLACK, SAMUEL, Lieutenant-General, C.S.I., I.S.C.—First commission as ensign, Bengal N.I., Dec., 1844; served in the Punjab campaign, 1848-49 (medal); from May, 1854, served in the public works department, Lower Provinces, embankment circle; staff officer, Punjab irregular force, Jan., 1857; medal for service in the mutiny; executive engineer, public works department, Punjab, Jan., 1860; military secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1862-83; attained colonel's allowances, Dec., 1882; services replaced at disposal of government of India, military department; appointed governor, Aitchison College, Oct., 1886.

BLAIR, HARRISON FALKNER, B.A., B.L., High Court, North-Western Provinces.—Called to the bar, Inner Temple, June, 1864; appointed puisne judge, high court of judicature, North-Western Provinces, 1st April, 1892.

BLAKESLEY, EDMUND HOLMES, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Charterhouse and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India 30th Oct., 1889, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

BLANC, HENRI JULES, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., F.R.C.P., M.R.C.S. (Lon.), late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 10th Feb., 1859; arrived in India, 7th Aug., 1859, and served in the military department and also as acting civil surgeon in various stations, and as superintendent of vaccination; served in the China War, 1860-62; was a member of the Abyssinian mission, 1864, and was confined in chains during 21 months by the Emperor Theodore; subsequently joined the expeditionary force, and was present at the storming of Magdala central jail, April, 1875; senior surgeon, Jamsetji Jiibhoy Hospital, Bombay, and professor of surgery and clinical surgery, Grant Medical College, May, 1876, to Aug., 1882; also acted as professor of anatomy, and curator of the museum, May-June, 1879; physician, European General Hospital from Aug., 1882; retired, April, 1887.

BLANFORD, HENRY FRANCIS, late Meteorological Department, Government of India.—Arrived in India, and was appointed assistant in the geological survey, 1st Oct., 1855; in charge of geological museum, Sept., 1856, to May, 1857; in charge of geological survey party, Madras, May, 1857 to 1860; was subsequently engaged in the Calcutta museum, and in surveying in the Sonthal country; resigned the service, Dec., 1861; appointed professor in the Presidency college, Calcutta, Dec., 1862; 2nd grade, educational department, Jan., 1866; meteorological reporter to government of Bengal, April, 1867; meteorological reporter to the government of India for the purpose of organising the meteorological department, Jan., 1875; retired 1886; author of numerous reports and monographs, and contributions to scientific journals and societies, including reports on the geology of the Nilgiri Hills, and the cretaceous rocks of the Trichinopoly district ('Memoirs of Geological Survey'), on the Calcutta cyclone of 5th Oct., 1867 (in conjunction with Colonel Gastrell), on the winds of Northern India ('Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society'), and official reports on the meteorology of India, 1875, 1876, 1878 to 1884; is also author of a monograph on the Belemnitidae and Nautilidae of the cretaceous rocks of Southern India, of 'The Rudiments of Physical Geography for the use of Indian Schools,' 'The Indian Meteorologist's Vade Mecum,' and a chart of the average rainfall of India; edited and contributed to the Indian Meteorological Memoirs (2 vols. and 2 parts).

BLATHWAYT, CHARLES GEORGE, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate, Kanara, Oct., 1882; senior collector, March, 1886; retired, July, 1890.

BLENKINSOP, FREDERICK HENRY, Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Madras Medical Department.—Arrived, 7th May, 1869, and served with various regiments to Oct., 1888, including service in the Burmese expedition; medical officer, Coonoor, May, 1889; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Cuddapah, July, 1890; Trichinopoly, May, 1891.

BLENNERHASSETT, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton, and Wimborne Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1865; served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; from Feb., 1882, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district judge, 3rd grade, March 1883, and 2nd grade, July, 1890.

BLISS, HENRY WILLIAM, C.I.E., B.A., Madras
C.S.—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 15th Dec., 1863; served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, sub-collector, and joint magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; on famine duty, July, 1877, to Feb., 1878; from Feb., 1878, served as commissioner of salt revenue, and of abkari revenue, and was appointed customs collector throughout the Madras Presidency under the Sea Customs Act of 1878, Aug., 1882; on duty to Bombay, Oct., 1879, and to Calcutta and N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1880, to examine the working of the salt department; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1882; on duty to Orissa to report on the system of salt administration, Jan., 1884; on special duty at Madras in connection with the abkari committee, March, 1884; additional member of the board of revenue in addition to his duties as commissioner of salt revenue, Feb., 1886; member of the finance committee under the government of India, April, 1886; fourth member of board of revenue and commissioner of salt and abkari revenue, April, 1887; second member of the board of revenue, &c., Jan., 1889, and first member, Oct., 1889; C.I.E., May, 1889; acting commissioner of land revenue, June, 1890; additional member of legislative council, Dec., 1890, to April, 1891, and again, Dec., 1891, to March, 1892; commissioner of land revenue, Madras, April, 1891.

BLISSETT, T., late Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 1st March, 1850; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1866; superintendent, Arracan division, Aug., 1869; personal assistant to director-general, 1873-75; served subsequently in the Dacca and Scinde divisions, and in the store department, and from 1882 in Bombay; 1st grade superintendent, Aug., 1883; retired, Jan., 1889.

BLOOD, BAGOT WILLIAM, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 7th Aug., 1866, as assistant engineer; executive engineer, Sept., 1872; superintendent of way and works, Rajputana State Railway, Nov., 1879; superintending engineer, and class, Dec., 1890; 1st class, June, 1892.

BLOOMFIELD, ALFRED, Colonel, I.S.C., late Central Provinces Commission.—First commission as ensign, March, 1856; served in the Central Provinces from July, 1864, as assistant commissioner; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, March, 1867; deputy commissioner, July, 1870; inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Oct., 1876; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Aug., 1881; 1st class, Aug., 1889; reverted to military department, March, 1892; author of 'Notes on the Baigas of the Central Provinces,' 1885.

BLYTH, Ven. GEORGE FRANCIS POPHAM, M.A., late Ecclesiastical Department, Burma.—Archdeacon of Rangoon, Oct., 1879; retired, 1887.

BLYTH, WILLIAM DUNBAR, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Liverpool Collegiate Institution, and Queen's College, Cork; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1879; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, July, 1880; officiating under-secretary, government of Bengal, judicial, political, and appointments departments in 1881 and 1882; under-secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, April, 1882; officiating chief secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1886; officiating inspector-general of registration, July, 1886; 1st inspector of registration offices, Oct., 1886; inspector-general of registration, April, 1887; officiating magistrate and collector, March, 1890; confirmed, Nov., 1890.

BOAS, HENRY JULIUS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces and Oudh).—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 19th Nov., 1891, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

BODDAM, WELBY WROUGHTON, Colonel, I.S.C., late Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 12th Dec., 1851; arrived in India, 2nd July, 1852; served with the military police, 1857-61; district superintendent of Lahore police, Feb., 1861; deputy inspector-general, March, 1878; promoted to 1st grade, May, 1881; officiating inspector-general, Punjab, March, 1883, and again, Feb., 1885; deputy inspector-general of police, 1st grade, Rawalpindi, March, 1887; retired, March, 1888.

BODDY, OWEN VIDAL, Major, R.E., Madras Public Works Department.—Arrived in India, 11th Feb., 1873; assistant engineer, April, 1873; executive engineer, March, 1883; employed in the military works branch, government of India, Aug., 1887, to Feb., 1888; deputy chief engineer and under secretary in the public works department, Feb., 1891.

BOILEAU, HENRY, Lieut.-Colonel, I.S.C.—Served under the military department from May, 1865, to April, 1873, when he was appointed officiating assistant commissioner, Burma; on special duty to Mandalay, May, 1873; assistant commissioner, 4th grade, and superintendent of immigration, Sept., 1874; also sub-registrar of deeds, Rangoon, Aug., 1875; on special duty in connection with the Imperial assemblage, Delhi, Nov., 1876; private secretary and aide-de-camp to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, Jan., 1877; cantonment magistrate, Dinapore, and small cause court judge, July, 1878; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Aug., 1885, continuing to be employed as cantonment magistrate; deputy commissioner, March, 1887.

BOLSTER, J. A., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd Feb., 1872.

BOLTON, CHARLES WALTER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College School, London, Royal College, Mauritius, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 7th Oct., 1872; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Oct., 1872; officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, April, 1877; under secretary, government of Bengal, March, 1879; officiating under secretary, government of India, home, revenue, and agricultural department, Feb., 1880; on deputation as under
secretary in the judicial, political, and appointments departments, government of Bengal, Feb., 1883; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, in addition to his own duties, March, 1884; officiating magistrate and collector, April, 1884; officiating inspector-general of registration, Oct., 1884; senior marriage registrar, Calcutta, Nov., 1884; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1885; magistrate and collector, Sept., 1888; officiating secretary to the board of revenue, July, 1889, and again, March, 1891; confirmed, Dec., 1891.

BOMFORD, GERALD, Surgeon-Major, M.D.—Joined the service, 30th Sept., 1874, and served in the military department, and as professor and resident surgeon in the medical college, Calcutta; superintendent, Calcutta lunatic asylum, April, 1890; acted as secretary to the surgeon-general and sanitary commissioner in 1888 and 1890, and was confirmed in that post, Aug., 1891.

BOMPAS, CECIL HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Westminster and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1880, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

BCNAVIA, EMANUEL, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 4th August, 1857; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1857; served under the military department up to Dec., 1861, and was present at the capture of Lucknow, March, 1858, and in the Trans-Gogra campaign; assistant civil surgeon, Lucknow, Dec., 1861; on special duty, May, 1866; health officer, Lucknow, and superintendent of museum, observatory, and agricultural society's garden, April, 1867; rank of surgeon, Aug., 1869; was engaged for some time in 1872 under the military department in analysing drinking water; principal of medical school at Balrampur, in addition to other duties, Jan., 1873; officiating sanitary commissioner, Oudh, Sept. to Nov., 1874, and again Jan. to March, 1877, also officiating as inspector-general of prisons, Oudh; officiating civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Fyzabad, Dec., 1877; civil surgeon, Etawah, Dec., 1881; retired, April, 1888; has published works on date culture in India, and 'The Villager's Domestic Medicine,' 1885.

BONHAM-CARTER, NORMAN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1888, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

BONUS, ARTHUR RIVERS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Clifton College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to Bombay civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India 17th Jan., 1887; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1887; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, Aug., 1889; retransferred, March, 1892.

BONUS, JOSEPH, Major-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay Engineers, June, 1855; arrived in India, March, 1857; during the mutiny served at the siege and storming of Jhansi, the capture of Calpee and Gwalior, and various other operations and engagements (medal and clasp); joined the Bombay public works department as assistant engineer, June, 1859, and was employed on the Bombay harbour defences, Oct., 1860; from Sept., 1861, served as deputy consulting engineer for railways in Sind; officiating deputy consulting engineer and assistant secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, railway branch, March, 1870; from Nov., 1871, served as superintending engineer on Indus Valley state railway, and officiated as engineer-in-chief, Aug., 1872; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, July, 1873; engineer-in-chief, Sindia state railway, Sept., 1876; transferred to Punjab northern state railway, May, 1877; officiating consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, July-Oct., 1878; engineer-in-chief, Pindi-Peshawur section, Oct., 1879; medal for services in the Afghan War, 1879-80; superintending engineer, 1st class, April, 1881; acting consulting engineer for railways, and joint secretary to government, Bombay, with temporary rank of chief engineer, 3rd class, May, 1882; and again Aug., 1885, to April, 1886; senior deputy consulting engineer and under secretary to government, railway branch, from Nov., 1883; chief engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1885; retired, Nov., 1888.

BOOTH, WILLIAM, M.A., Bengal Education Department.—Served in the department from 27th Nov., 1876, as professor in the Presidency College, and officiating principal, Hooghly College; principal, Dacca College, June, 1884; class 3 of educational department, July, 1886; professor of physics, Presidency College, Nov., 1890.

BOSANQUET, OSWALD VIVIAN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 17th Sept., 1887, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate; officiating political assistant, 3rd class, and 2nd assistant to resident at Hyderabad, and assistant secretary for Berar, May, 1890; confirmed, April, 1892.

BOUGHEY, GEORGE FLETCHER OTTLEY, Lieut.-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, June, 1862; arrived in India, 5th Jan., 1865; served in the Bhutan expedition, 1865-66 (medal & clasp); joined the public works department, Nov., 1860, as assistant engineer, railway branch, N.W. Provinces; executive engineer, Rajputana railway, Sept., 1870; deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, May, 1877; officiating assistant director, state railways, central system, 1878; assistant secretary, railway branch, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1879; served in the Afghan War, 1878-79-80 (medal); personal assistant to chief engineer, buildings and roads and railway branches, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1880; officiating manager, Nizam's state railway, Jan., 1881; manager, Indus Valley and Kandahar railway, Jan., 1882; 1st class, state railway revenue establishment, Oct., 1882; manager, Eastern Bengal state railway, Nov., 1885; officiating manager, North-Western railway, April, 1891.

BOULNOIS, CHARLES, B.A., LL.B., late Punjab Chief Court.—Educated at King's Coll., London, and London University; called to the bar (Middle Temple), 30th April, 1855, and
in the same year was admitted advocate of the supreme court of Fort William, in Bengal; practised at the bar of the supreme court, 1855 to 1860; professor of law in the presidency college, Calcutta, 1857-61, and again in 1882-3; judge of the court of small causes, Bengal, 1860, and first judge of the court, 1861; officiating secretary to the government of Bengal, in the legislative department, 1862-4; officiating deputy secretary to the government of India, legislative department, 1864; appointed judge of the chief court, Punjab, in Feb., 1866, and was senior judge in the court from 1867 until his retirement in 1877; in 1831 was appointed reporter of appeal cases, which appointment he still holds; member of the senate of the Punjab university college, 1869, and fellow of the Punjab university, 1832; editor of law reports in the supreme court, 1856-60; joint author of 'Notes on Customary Law,' by Boulnois and Rattigan, 1876.

BOULTON, CHARLES FREDERICK, Colonel, I.S.C., late Sind Commission.—Arrived in India, 6th Aug., 1852; on military duty up to Sept., 1856, when he was appointed acting assistant collector and magistrate, Satara; from 1860 served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate; superintendent, Bombay, Baroda, and C.I. railway police, Jan.-Aug., 1866; served subsequently in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting judge and sessions judge; manager of encumbered estates in the Karachi, Hyderabad, and Shikarpur collectortates, March, 1877; collector and magistrate, Dec., 1879; acting commissioner in Sind, March-June, 1884.

BOURDILLON, JAMES AUSTIN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1870; officiating under secretary, government of India, financial department, Sept., 1874, and subsequently in the home department, March, 1876; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, Dec., 1875; from Aug., 1876, served in the registration department as inspector of registration offices, and officiating inspector-general; deputy superintendent of census, Dec., 1880; inspector-general of registration, Dec., 1881; magistrate and collector, April, 1887; officiating secretary to board of revenue, June, 1892.

BOUSTEAD, R., Surgeon-Major, F.R.C.S. (Edin.), M.R.C.S. (Eng.), late Bombay Medical Department.—Civil surgeon, Thana, 21st Jan., 1876; acted as superintendent of vaccination, 1876; superintendent of Matheran, Feb., 1882; acted as surgeon, Gokuldas Tejal Hospital, 1883; civil surgeon, Ahmednagar, July, 1887; retired, Feb., 1889.

BOUTFLOWER, WILLIAM NOLAN, B.A., Education Department, N.W.Provinces.—Served in the education department from 9th Aug., 1869, as professor in the Agra College, and officiated as principal, July-Dec., 1872; 3rd professor in the Muir Central College, Allahabad, Oct., 1874; officiating inspector of schools, July, 1875, to May, 1876; professor of mathematics, Muir College, March, 1876; 3rd grade of educational officers, April, 1878; officiating meteorological reporter to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April-June, 1881; 2nd grade of educa-

tional officers, Feb., 1890; officiating inspector of schools, July, 1890; confirmed, Feb., 1892; author of 'Elementary Statics and Dynamics, and 'The Indian Arithmetic.'

BOVILL, EDWARD, M.B., Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Department.—Joined the service 1st Oct., 1872, and served on general, jail, and hospital duty; civil surgeon, Dec., 1885.

BOWEN, CHARLES, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1858; arrived in India, April, 1863; joined the Madras P.W. department, Nov., 1863, and, from June, 1864, served under the Mysore government; executive engineer, March, 1867; assistant to chief engineer, and secretary to chief commissioner, Mysore, June, 1869; officiating engineer in chief and joint secretary to government, Feb. to June, 1880; served in the Madras P.W. department, April, 1883, to September, 1885, as deputy chief engineer and under secretary to government; served again under the Mysore government from Sept., 1885; superintending engineer, April, 1886.

BOWER, GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Caistor Grammar School, Eton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 10th December, 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner; officiated as under secretary to government, March, 1889; joint magistrate, March, 1890; deputy superintendent, family domains of the Maharaja of Benares, April, 1890.

BOWIE, MATHEW MORTON, Colonel, I.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th June, 1858; from June, 1863, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, and deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty in connection with the Delhi assemblage, Nov., 1876; commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration, Central Provinces, June, 1880; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Nagpur, Sept., 1880; inspector-general of police and prisons, Central Provinces, April, 1882; colonel, June, 1888; officiated as commissioner for various periods; commissioner, Nerbudda division, April, 1892.

BOWRING, LEWIN BENTHAM, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Mount Radford School, Exeter, and at Leipzig; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1843; assistant magistrate and collector, 1845; assistant to treasurer, Calcutta, 1846; assistant to resident at Lahore, 1847-49; deputy commissioner, Punjab, 1849-54; private secretary to Lord Canning, 1853-62; chief commissioner of Mysore and Coorg, 1862-70; retired, 1870; has published 'Eastern Experiences,' and contributed papers to the Asiatic Society of Bengal.

BOYD, CHARLES CLIFFORD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Haileybury College, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 23rd Nov., 1890, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1891.

BOYD, HUGH ARTHUR, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Banff Grammar School, Old Aberdeen Gymnasium, Aberdeen University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed after open
competitive examination of 1838; arrived, 4th Dec., 1890, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

**BOYS, HENRY SCOTT, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1863; from Dec., 1864, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed superintendent of the encumbered estates of Sitapur and Kheri, June, 1872; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1881; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; 1st grade, April, 1887; acted as commissioner of division in 1883, 1887, and 1888; retired, 1889.**

**BRACKENBURY, HENRY, Lieut.-General, C.B., R.A.—First commission, 1st Sept., 1837; served in the Indian Mutiny, 1858, the Ashanti expedition, 1873, and the South African war, 1879-80; assistant adjutant and quartermaster-general, Cyprus, July, 1878; military secretary, South Africa, May, 1879; private secretary to Viceroy of India, March to June, 1880; military attaché, Paris, Jan., 1881; deputy adjutant and quartermaster-general, Egypt, Sept., 1884; brigadier-general, Egypt, Jan., 1885; deputy quartermaster-general at headquarters (intelligence branch), Jan., 1886; deputy adjutant-general, and director of military intelligence, June, 1887, to March, 1891, when he was appointed military member of viceroy's council; took his seat, 25th April, 1891.**

**BRACKENBURY, MAULE CAMPBELL, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Railway Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1865; arrived in India, June, 1875; joined the P.W. department, June, 1875; executive engineer, March, 1877; served in the Perak expedition, 1875-76 (medal and clasp), and the Afghan War, 1879-80 (medal and two clasps and bronze star); officiating deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, 1881; assistant manager, Punjab northern state railway, Feb., 1883; officiating manager and traffic superintendent, Mysore railway, April, 1883; acting deputy consulting engineer, Bombay, Oct., 1884; deputy manager, North Western state railway, Sind Section, Dec., 1885; 1st class, state railway revenue establishment, Jan., 1886; manager, Sind Section, March, 1887; undersecretary to government of India, railway branch public works department, Nov., 1887, and deputy director-general of railways, April, 1888; officiating deputy secretary to the government of India, public works department, Feb. to June, 1889; officiating manager, Oudh and Rohilkhand railway, July, 1890; confirmed, May, 1892.**

**BRADBURY, JAMES FRANCIS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1868; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1878; also served as officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, Sept., 1876, and officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1878; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Aug., 1885; 1st grade, Feb., 1890.**

**BRADFORD, SIR EDWARD RIDLEY COLBORNE, Colonel, K.C.B., K.C.S.I., A.D.C., I.S.C.—Cornet, 6th light cavalry, Madras, Feb., 1854; proceeded to Persia under General Jacob in 1856; political assistant in Western Malwa, and in command of 1st Regiment Central India Horse, Nov., 1866; political agent, Bhagelcund, 1871; political agent, Bhurtpur, Jan., 1873; general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoitee, May, 1874; agent to governor-general, Rajputana, Dec., 1878; also chief commissioner of Ajmere; secretary, political and secret department, India office, Feb., 1887; accompanied H.R.H. Prince Albert Victor on his visit to India in 1889-90; K.C.B., May, 1890; resigned on his appointment as chief commissioner metropolitan police, London, June, 1890.**

**BRADLEY, HERBERT, B.L., Madras C.S.—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1878, and served in South Canara as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting head assistant, and was in charge of the South Canara forests, Sept., 1883, to April, 1885; acting deputy commissioner, salt revenue, April, 1885, and on special duty with the commissioner, July, 1885; secretary to the commissioner of salt, abkari and separate revenue, April, 1888; officiating district and session judge, Jan., 1892; officiating collector and magistrate, March, 1892.**

**BRADLEY, J. A., Legal Adviser's Department, India Office.—Clerk to the legal adviser to the secretary of state, 1877.**

**BRADSHAW, JOHN, M.A., LL.D., Madras Education Department.—Educated at Enniskillen Royal School and Trinity College, Dublin; head master of Bishop Corrie's School, Madras, 1868; head master, Mangalore College, 31st Dec., 1870; acting inspector of schools, Sept., 1871; member of conference of inspectors of schools, Jan., 1873; professor of history, Presidency College, April, 1875, continuing to act as inspector of schools; fellow of University of Madras, July, 1875; from Sept., 1872, has served as inspector of schools, and was promoted to 3rd class of the department, March, 1884; member of committee for preparing a scheme for examination for the degree of licentiate of teaching, Oct.-Nov., 1883; board of examiners, Oct., 1884; member of committee for revision of the grant-in-aid code, 1885; president of committee for preparation of the pre-matriculation text, 1886 and 1888; president of Middle school examination committee, 1888; vice-chairman of board of examiners for upper-secondary examination, 1889-90; has edited the Aldine editions (new series) of Gray and Milton, Chesterfield's Letters, and an edition of Milton with notes, and has also published an English Anthology, and a concordance to Milton.**

**BRANDIS, SIR DIETRICH, Ph.D., K.C.I.E.—Educated at Universities of Copenhagen, Gottingen, and Bonn; lecturer on botany at University of Bonn, 1849; served in the forest department of the government of India from 16th Jan., 1856, and was appointed inspector-general of forests, April, 1864; C.I.E., Jan., 1878; retired, 1883; appointed a member of the board of visitors of the Royal Indian Engineering College, 1886; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887; author of 'Forest Flora of North-West and Central India, London, 1874,' of the article on 'Teak,' in the Encyclopaedia Britannica, &c.,
&c.; is director of the practical course of forestry on the continent in connection with Cooper's Hill College.

BRANDRETH, Ashton Milnes, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1855; arrived in India 30th Dec., 1857; served in the public works department from 8th Jan., 1858, as assistant engineer, assistant principal, Thomason College, and executive engineer; transferred to the Punjab, Sept., 1861, and served on the Western Jumna Canal; assistant secretary, government of India, May to Dec., 1863; assistant secretary, public works department, Punjab, May, 1867; officiating assistant to chief engineer and secretary to Government, Nov., 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1871; officiating superintendent engineer, Western Jumna Canal, April, 1871; principal, Thomason College, 1879 to 1891.

BRANDT, Francis, B.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, under secretary to government in the revenue department, and in the departments under the chief secretary, acting sub-secretary to board of revenue, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; on special duty, board of revenue, 1872; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, April, 1874; collector and magistrate, South Canara, Oct., 1877, and afterwards in the Nilgiris, 1883; district and sessions judge, Trichinopoly, June, 1878; member of rent law committee, Sept., 1882; judge of the high court, Madras, Sept., 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886; retired, Dec., 1887.

BRANFOOT, Arthur Mudge, Surgeon-Lieut.-Col., M.B., M.R.C.S., L.R.C.P., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant-surgeon, 30th March, 1872; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1872, and served under the military department till March, 1873, and subsequently as civil surgeon at Cocanada, and Madras, and as resident surgeon at the general hospital, Madras, and professor of pathology in the Medical College, April-July, 1878; assistant physician, general hospital, and professor of hygiene, Medical College, July, 1878; superintendent of the lying-in-hospital, and professor of midwifery, Medical College, July, 1881; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886.

BRANSON, James Charles Emerton, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 16th Jan., 1882, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, officiating deputy-commissioner, and officiating city magistrate of Lucknow; transferred to Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885; officiating assistant accountant-general, Madras, March, 1886; deputy accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1889; officiating accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, March, 1892.

BRERETON, Alfred, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as assistant engineer, March, 1873, and served in the railway branch; executive engineer, April, 1880; assistant director, North-Western railway, Nov., 1887; district traffic superintendent, Nov., 1888; deputy manager, July, 1891.

BRERETON, Ashley F., Revenue and Statistics Department, India Office.—Educated at Bedford School; supernumerary writer, 13th Feb., 1860; temporary clerk, Dec., 1860; clerk in registry department, Jan., 1869; junior clerk, financial department, April, 1874; senior clerk, Nov., 1885; transferred to revenue and statistics department, 1886.

BRERETON, Herbert James, Financial Department, Government of India.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School; joined the service, 7th April, 1873; from Feb., 1874, served in the office of the accountant-general, N.W. Provinces; assistant accountant-general, Bombay, July, 1877; N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1877; Burma, April, 1878; Punjab, Aug., 1879; N.W. Provinces, March, 1884; Central Provinces, March, 1888; N.W. Provinces, July, 1888; comptroller, Assam, June, 1890.

BRERETON, Reginald Hugh, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1882, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, April, 1889; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, Nov., 1891.

BRETT, Alfred Corbyn, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 31st Oct., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Dec., 1874; district and sessions judge, Jan., 1878.

BRETT, Cecil Michael Wilford, B.L., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Guildford Grammar School, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, April, 1885; member central examination committee, April, 1886; registrar, high court (appellate side), April, 1886; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1890; officiating judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpore, April-Sept., 1891.

BRIDGES, Albert, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1887, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating district judge, &c.

BRIDGES, James Emile, B.L., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Royal College, Tournai, and University of Bonn; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1876, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner and settlement officer; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, land revenue, and agricultural department, and officiating director of agriculture, Nov., 1884; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Aug., 1886, 3rd grade, Dec., 1888; officiating chief-secretary, March - July, 1890; commissioner, March, 1891.

BRIGGS, W. H., Surgeon-Major, late Madras Medical Service.—First commission, 30th Sept., 1875; surgeon-major, June, 1885; medical
officer on personal staff of governor of Madras, Dec., 1886 to March, 1889; served in the Jowaki campaign, 1877-1878 (medal and clasp), the Afghan campaigns, 1878-1880 (medal), and the Nile campaign, 1884-1885 (medal and clasps and Khedive's star).

BRIGHT, WILLIAM ROBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1890; deputy commissioner, March, 1892.

BROADBENT, JOHN EDWARD, Major, R.E., India Military Works Department.—First commission, 17th July, 1866; arrived in India, Dec., 1866, and served as assistant engineer; executive engineer, June, 1870; assistant secretary, military department, Dec., 1882; second deputy secretary, March, 1890; deputy-director-general, military works, for fortifications, April, 1892.

BROADFOOT, RAMSAY DOUGLAS, B.L., Madras C.S.—Educated at Kensington School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Nov., 1883.

BROCKMAN, WILLIAM DRAKE, A.M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, N.W. Provinces.—Served in the Punjab as sub-assistant revenue surveyor, 1852-55; joined Thomason College at Roorkee, and from there was appointed to the public works department, April, 1883, and served in the N.W. Provinces in the buildings and roads branch as assistant engineer; transferred temporarily to railway department, Nov., 1859, to Dec., 1860; employed on famine relief works on Ganges Canal in 1861, and again in 1877-78 in the Rae Bareli division; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1874; on special duty in the public works secretariat, Nov., 1878; superintendent of works, Agra, Oct., 1883; superintending engineer, 3rd class, March, 1886; superintending engineer, 1st circle, provincial works, Oct., 1887, and superintending engineer, 2nd class, Nov., 1887; 1st superintending engineer, Dec., 1889; charge of 3rd circle of superintendence, buildings and roads branch, June, 1890; retired, March, 1892.

BRODIE, NORMAN SOMERVILLE, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at University College School and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India 12th Dec., 1887, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate; acting assistant to government, judicial and legislative departments, Dec., 1890 to April, 1891, and from July, 1891; acting under secretary in the revenue department, Dec., 1891.

BRODIE, VERNOR ALEXANDER, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India 6th Jan., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, forest settlement officer, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; senior assistant to collector, magistrate, and agent, Vizagapatam, Feb., 1885; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Malabar, Jan., 1891; acting collector and magistrate, Jan., 1891.

BROJENDRA COOMAR SEAL, B.L., Bengal C.S.—From 23rd Oct., 1865, served in the subordinate judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, May, 1873, and district judge, Bankoora, and assistant session judge, Burdwan, April, 1881; district and sessions judge, June, 1887.

BROJENDRA NATH DE, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Hare School, Calcutta, Canning College, Lucknow, Calcutta University, and St. Mary's Hall, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 6th September, 1875; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Oct., 1886; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1891.

BROOKE, THOMAS HENRY BARSTOW, Colonel, I.S.C., late Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, April, 1855; arrived in India, 13th May, 1855; was employed under the military department up to 1864, including service in the China expedition, 1857-59; from Feb., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted as superintendent of the school of industry and central jail, and as judge of the small cause court, Jubbulpore, 1874; cantonment magistrate, Saugor, Nov., 1874; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, March, 1883; reverted to military duty, 1889.

BROOKE, WILLIAM ROBERT, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 13th Sept., 1857; superintendent, Bombay, Jan., 1866; served in the Punjab, 1866-1871; 1st grade superintendent, Aug., 1877, officiating as director of traffic; director, construction branch, June, 1883; officiating deputy director-general, Nov., 1886, to Feb., 1887; and Aug., 1887, to March, 1888; permanent, July, 1889; director-general of telegraphs, April, 1890.

BROOKE, WILLIAM SAURIN, Colonel, I.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Dec., 1858; arrived in India 3rd January, 1859; served in the Central Provinces from Jan., 1863, as assistant commissioner; acting assistant settlement officer, Chanda, Oct., 1865; acting registrar-general, Central Provinces, Jan., 1869; cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, May, 1869; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1873; acting inspector-general of police and jails, Aug.-Nov., 1883.

BROWN, CHARLES DALLAS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India
22nd Nov., 1887, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate.

BROWN, FRANCIS DAVID MILLETT, Colonel, A.I.C.E., V.C., I.S.C., late P.W. Department, Government of India.—1st commission, 8th Dec., 1855; lieutenant, 1st Bengal European regiment, June, 1857; served in the Indian mutiny and was present at siege and capture of Delhi and Lucknow (medal, 2 clasps, Victoria cross); also in the N.W. Frontier campaign, the 2nd Eusufzai expedition, and the Umbeyla campaign (medal and clasp); served in public works department, N.W. Provinces (irrigation) from Sept., 1865; executive engineer, March, 1871; assistant secretary, N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1871; supervising engineer, April, 1889; principal, Thomason Civil Engineering College, 1891; reverted to military department, Aug., 1892.

BROWN, FREDERICK LATHAM, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as assistant engineer, 15th July, 1869; transferred to superior accounts establishment, April, 1878; examiner, state railway accounts, Lower Burma, Nov., 1885; officiating engineer-in-chief and manager, Burma state railway, Dec., 1885, and again in Sept., 1886; examiner, telegraph accounts, March, 1889; deputy accountant-general for inspection duty, Nov., 1891; on special duty in secretariat, April, 1892.

BROWN, GEORGE EUSTACE RIQUO GRANT, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at St. Paul's School, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Burma division of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Burma 9th Dec., 1889, and served as assistant commissioner.

BROWN, RICHARD CECIL, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Clergy Orphan School, Canterbury, and Keble College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1889, and served in Bombay as assistant magistrate and collector.

BROWN, THOMAS EDWIN BURTON, M.D., C.I.E., Brigade-Surgeon, late Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1838; arrived in India, 11th Feb., 1859; from Nov., 1860, served as professor of chemistry and chemical examiner, medical school, Lahore; principal, medical school, March, 1872; professor of surgery and midwifery in addition to his other duties, April-Dec., 1876; also officiated as civil surgeon of Lahore on several occasions, and as meteorological reporter, July-Aug., 1879; retired Oct., 1889; C.I.E., Jan., 1891; author of a work on the symptoms and treatment of the poisons used in the Punjab.

BROWN, WILLIAM BARCLAY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Ayr Academy and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after competition of 1883; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1886; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Assam as assistant commissioner, June, 1889.

BROWNE, CLEMENT METCALFE, Major-Gen., R.E., late India Public Works Department.—First commission, Bombay Engineers, 1854; joined the public works department, June, 1856, as assistant engineer; transferred to Punjab, May, 1859; executive engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1868; officiating assistant to chief engineer, Punjab, and assistant secretary, public works department, Oct., 1868; assistant to chief engineer, military works, Murree, April, 1872; officiating superintending engineer, military works, Allahabad, Aug., 1873; superintending engineer, Punjab (provincial), Feb., 1877; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Jan., 1883; rank of chief engineer, March, 1886; chief engineer and secretary, public works department, Burma, Oct., 1886; chief engineer, 2nd class, Nov., 1886; officiating chief engineer and secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1887; retired, May, 1888.

BROWNE, LORD HENRY ULLICK, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College, Dec., 1830; arrived 1st Sept., 1851; served in the revenue and judicial department, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1866; also served as private secretary to the president of the governor-general's council, Feb., 1853, under secretary to the government of Bengal, July, 1859, officiating under secretary to the government of India, home and financial department, April, 1860, registrar of the Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, April, 1861, superintendent of stamps and stationery, Oct., 1865, and officiating additional judge, Jessore and Nudde, Feb., 1867; commissioner, Chittagong division, Dec., 1869, and subsequently of the Presidency, and Rajshahiye and Cooch Behar divisions; chairman of the justices of the peace, Calcutta, Feb., 1872, and officiating member, board of revenue, June, 1878; retired, Oct., 1886.

BROWNE, Sir JAMES, Maj.-Gen., K.C.S.I., C.B., R.E., Foreign Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Aug., 1838; joined the public works department, June, 1860, as assistant engineer in the Punjab; executive engineer, April, 1866; transferred to military works, 1873, and subsequently to the railway branch, Oct., 1874; superintendent of works, Indus Bridge, Indus Valley state railway, Jan., 1875; during 1878-79 served in the Afghan war as superintending engineer with the Quetta field force (medal); C.S.I., July, 1879; assistant secretary to government, buildings and road branch, Punjab, May, 1882; superintending engineer, 3rd class, military works, Oct., 1882; served in the Egyptian expedition as commanding engineer, 1882 (medal and clasp, bronze star, 3rd class Osmanieh, C.B.); transferred temporarily to railway branch for employment on the Hunrai road, Biluchistan, 1883; engineer-in-chief, Sind-Pishin state railway, 1884; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Jan., 1884, 1st class, March, 1887; K.C.S.I., Jan., 1888; quarter-master-general in India, sub pro temp., with local rank of major-general, May, 1890; governor-general's agent in Baluchistan, March, 1892.

BROWNE, Ven. JAMES FRANCIS, B.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Madras.—Joined the service as junior chaplain, Madras, 20th July, 1870; senior chaplain, July, 1880; archdeacon of the diocese of Madras and commissary to the Lord Bishop, Feb., 1884; senior joint chaplain of St. George's Cathedral, Feb., 1884; in charge of the diocese, May to Oct., 1884; and again in May, 1890; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886.

BROWNE, SAMUEL HASLETT, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Punjab Medical Department.—Joined the service, March, 1874, and arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1874; served on hospital duty and on military duty in Afghanistan in 1878; from Aug., 1879, served in the Central Provinces on general
and jail duty; served under the government of India from Dec., 1886, in joint medical charge, Simla; appointed principal of medical college, Lahore, Oct., 1889.

BROWNE, WILLIS, F.I.A., India Office.—Writer, 15th Oct., 1867; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878; actuarial clerk, Feb., 1882; fellow of institute of actuaries, 1887; actuary funds department, 1890; actuary to India office, 1892.

BROWNE, WILLIAM RICHARD, M.D., Ch.M., Surgeon-Major, Madras Medical Department.—Joined the service, April, 1873; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1873, and served on military and civil and jail duty in Madras; resident surgeon in general hospital, and professor of pathology, Medical College, Nov., 1883; surgeon-major, April, 1885; acted for various periods as surgeon in general hospital, and professor of surgery, Medical College, and was confirmed in that appointment, May, 1890; fellow of Madras University, Aug., 1892; field service in Rumpa Hill tracts and Jeypore territory in 1879-80.

BROWNING, COLIN ARROTT ROBERTSON, M.A., C.I.E., late Educational Department, Central Provinces.—Senior inspector of schools, N.W. Provinces, 26th June, 1862; acted as director of public instruction, Central Provinces, May, 1864; to March, 1865, and as inspector-general of education, Central Provinces, April-Oct., 1868, and again March, 1869, to July, 1870; director of public instruction in Oudh, July, 1870; inspector-general of education, Central Provinces, Oct., 1873; on special duty at Calcutta in connection with education conference in 1882; C.I.E., Jan., 1886; retired Jan., 1889; author of 'The Indian Official Thesaurus,' 'The Annals of the Indian Empire,' 'Mahomedan Education in Oude,' 'A List of Sanscrit Manuscripts existing in Oudh,' and various reports on education in the Central Provinces; has edited several school and textbooks, and was joint editor of the 1st edition of the Central Provinces Gazetteer.

BROWNING, HERBERT ARROTT, Captain, I.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission, 21st Jan., 1881; assistant commissioner, Sept., 1886.

BROWNLLOW, HENRY ALEXANDER, Lieut.-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1849; deputy superintendent, Ganges Canal, Feb., 1852; and afterwards on the Eastern and Western Jumna Canals; during the mutiny served at the battle of Budlekesera, the siege of Delhi, and in the Rohilkund campaign (medal and clasp); superintendent, Eastern Jumna Canals, 1858; superintending engineer, N.W. Provinces, irrigation, March, 1865; 1st grade superintending engineer, Sept., 1870; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary, irrigation, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1872; superintending engineer, Bari Doab, Punjab, April, 1874; acted as chief engineer and joint secretary, Punjab, Feb.-May, 1876, and as chief engineer and secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, irrigation, June, 1876; officiating inspector-general of irrigation, and deputy secretary to government of India, April, 1877; chief engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1879; chief engineer and secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, irrigation, July, 1878, and afterwards in the buildings and roads branch; inspector-general of irrigation and deputy secretary to government of India, Feb., 1882; retired, Nov., 1886.

BROWNRIGG, FRANCIS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rossall, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1881, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant settlement officer, Nov., 1888; joint magistrate, April, 1890; has acted as city magistrate, inspector-general of registration, &c., and magistrate and collector.

BRUCE, ALEXANDER BANNERNAN, B.A., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Glasgow Academy, Chanowry School, Aberdeen, Milne's Institution, Fochabers, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.
