BRUCE, HENRY ALEXANDER, M.D., Principal Inspector-General.—Educated at the University of St. Andrew's and the University of Edinburgh, where he graduated M.D. in 1829; diploma of the Royal College of Surgeons, Edinburgh, 1828; assistant surgeon on the Bengal medical establishment, 1830; arrived at Calcutta, Jan., 1831; was employed on regimental duty, and served through the Cabul campaign, 1838 to 1841; was present at the storming of Ghuznee, 1839 (medal), and with the garrison of Cabul, 1839-40; in medical charge of the force sent to oppose Dost Mahomed in the Hindoo Koosh, Sept., 1840; surgeon to the envoy of Herat, Jan., 1841; was posted to the Sirmoor rifle battalion, Feb., 1841; principal medical storekeeper to the army of reserve, Nov., 1842; served in the Sutlej campaign, 1846, and was present at the battles of Aliwal (medal) and Sobraon (clasp); rank of surgeon, June, 1847; medical storekeeper, Cawnpore, and staff surgeon, Dec., 1852; superintending surgeon, Sirhind circle, May, 1859; inspector-general of hospitals, Upper Provinces, April, 1862; principal inspector-general, medical department, November, 1865; retired, Sept., 1866; fellow of the University of Calcutta, Jan., 1865.

BRUCE, RICHARD ISAAC, C.I.E., Punjab Commission.—Served in the Punjab as extra assistant-commissioner from May, 1863; assistant commissioner, Dec., 1868; prepared a gazetteer of the Dera Ghazi Khan district, and a manual of the Biluch language; on special duty in connection with Major Sandeman's 2nd Kalat mission, 1876; 1st assistant to agent to governor-general, Biluchistan, Feb., 1877; compiled a history of the Marri-Biluchi tribe; acted as agent, Biluchistan in 1878, 1882 and 1885; political agent at Thal-Chotiali from 1882; rejoined Punjab commission and appointed deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, May, 1888; 1st grade, Nov., 1889; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Derajat, July, 1890.

BRUNYATE, JAMES BENNETT, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at St. Paul's School, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 9th Dec., 1891, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

BUCK, SIR EDWARD CHARLES, Kt., C.S.I., B.L., LL.D., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 2nd Feb.,
1862; from May, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, settlement officer, and officiating secretary, board of revenue; director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1875; commissioner for the government of India at the Melbourne International Exhibition of 1880; officiated as secretary to the government of India in the revenue and agricultural department, July, 1881, and was confirmed in that appointment, April, 1882.

BUCKLAND, CHARLES EDWARD, B.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1870; attaché, foreign department, Nov., 1871; officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Barrackpore, Jan., 1874; on special duty in Behar, Jan., 1874; on famine duty, March, 1874; officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1875; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, April, 1874, to Jan., 1877; assistant secretary, government of Bengal, Aug., 1876; private secretary to Sir Richard Temple during his mission to Madras and Bombay, Jan., 1877; private secretary to governor of Bombay, May, 1877; officiating under-secretary, government of India, home department, May, 1878; private secretary to president of governor-general's council, Nov., 1878; officiating press commissioner with government of India, Feb., 1879; superintendent of stamps and stationery, Bengal, May, 1880; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1882, and again in 1883, 1884, and 1886; confirmed, May, 1887; secretary to board of revenue, May, 1890; officiating secretary to government of Bengal, general, revenue and statistical departments, July, 1889, again in Oct., 1889, and from March, 1891; confirmed, Dec., 1891; edited 'Excise Manual,' 1884.

BUCKLE, HENRY, Judicial Department, Burma.—Served in the Burma commission from 7th Aug., 1867, as assistant commissioner, and was in charge of the town magistrate's office, Akyab, Sept., 1871, to Nov., 1874, and of the Hill Tracts of Northern Arakan, Dec., 1874, to Jan., 1876; in command of an expedition beyond the frontier against the Shandus, Nov., 1876; from June, 1878, served as deputy commissioner in various districts; president, Henzada municipal committee, Dec., 1884; officiating commissioner, March, 1888, March, 1890, and Jan.-March, 1892; additional sessions judge, Jan., 1891.

BUCKLEY, LLEWELLYN EDDISON, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and at New College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 19th Sept., 1887, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to magistrate and collector.

BUCKLEY, ROBERT BURTON, M.I.C.E., M.I.M.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as assistant engineer, July, 1869; executive engineer, March, 1876; officiating assistant secretary, public works secretariat, government of India, Jan., 1881; services lent to Calcutta corporation, June, 1881; officiating under-secretary, public works secretariat, government of India, Dec., 1883; in same capacity in Bengal, July, 1886, and again, Feb., 1887; under-secretary to government of India, public works department, April, 1887, to Dec., 1889; superintending engineer, 3rd class, March, 1892.

BULL, CHARLES ALBERT, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the department as executive engineer, Nov., 1868, and served in the railway branch; engineer-in-chief, Madras railway surveys, Nov., 1884, and Cuddapah-Nellore railway, Sept., 1886; also in charge of Madras state railway surveys, July, 1887; superintendent of way and works, Cuddapah-Nellore railway, Sept., 1887; superintendent of works, Burma state railway, Sept., 1891; superintending engineer, 3rd class, June, 1892.

BULLOCK, FREDERICK D'OLBERT, LL.B., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kingstown Grammar School, St. Aubin's Grammar School, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; judge, small cause court, Delhi, Jan., 1873; judicial assistant, Dec., 1877; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; divisional judge, Oct., 1885; officiating judge, chief court, Punjab, May, 1892.

BULLOCK, FREDERICK SHORE, Bengal C.S. (Hyderabad).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, officiating cantonment magistrate, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, small cause court judge, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate, 1st grade, June, 1885; magistrate and collector, April, 1889; judicial commissioner, Hyderabad, April, 1892.

BULLOCK, ROBERT, Colonel, I.S.C., late Berar Commission.—First commission Madras army (infantry), 11th Dec., 1858; from July, 1862, served in the Berar commission as assistant commissioner, officiating assistant resident, officiating small cause court judge, and deputy commissioner (March, 1880); boundary commissioner for demarcation of the Dhans frontier, Feb. to June, 1886; judicial commissioner, sub pro tem., Aug., 1888; civil and sessions judge, July, 1889; retired, April, 1891.

BULMAN, ALBERT ROBINSON, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Richmond Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating secretary to financial commissioner, July, 1874; judicial assistant, 1st grade, March, 1878; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Dec., 1882; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Lahore, Aug., 1884; 1st grade deputy commissioner, March, 1886; officiating commissioner, Umballa, Jan., 1887; retired, April, 1889.

BUNBURY, CECIL EDWARD FRANCIS, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Wellington College and Keble College, Oxford; appointed to the
Bengal civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1885, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

BURGESS, GEORGE DOUGLAS, C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1870, and served in the British Burma commission as assistant commissioner, assistant collector of customs, and deputy commissioner; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, and officer in charge of state prisoners, Jan., 1879; secretary to chief commissioner, July, 1881; officiating commissioner, Sept., 1884; commissioner, April, 1886; C.S.I., 1st Jan., 1889; judicial commissioner, Upper Burma, Jan., 1892.

BURGESS, JAMES, C.I.E., LL.D., F.R.G.S., M.R.A.S., M.Soc.As., Paris, late Archaeological Survey of India.—Educated at Dumfries, Glasgow, and Edinburgh; archaeological surveyor and reporter for Western India, 15th Jan., 1874; also archaeological surveyor for Southern India, Nov., 1881; director general of the archaeological survey of India, March, 1886; was a fellow of the University of Bombay; retired 1890; author of scientific papers in the Philosophical Magazine, 'The Indian Antiquary,' 'Views of Architecture and Scenery in Gujarat and Rajputana,' 'Reports of the Archaeological Survey of Western and Southern India,' and, conjointly with the late J. Ferguson, LL.D., C.I.E., 'The Rock Temples of India.'

BURKE, CHARLES TOLER, B.E., M.I.C.E., Bombay Public Works Department.—Joined the service, 23rd July, 1868, and served as assistant engineer; executive engineer, March, 1876; acted as under-secretary in the department in 1890 and 1891, and was confirmed in that appointment, May, 1892; author of articles on various waterworks schemes.

BURKE, JOHN, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the department, 2nd June, 1864; superintendent, 2nd grade, Aug., 1883; officiating director of traffic, Feb., 1886; superintendent, Class IV., 2nd grade, Oct., 1887; has held charge of various divisions.

BURKITT, WILLIAM ROBERT, M.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; called to the bar at the Middle Temple, appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 11th Oct., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1875, and magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1880; district and sessions judge, Aug., 1887; additional judicial commissioner in Oudh, March, 1891; judicial commissioner, July, 1891.

BURLS, E. GRANT, Store Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India office, 20th Oct., 1863; junior clerk, store department, Dec., 1865; senior clerk, Jan., 1875; assistant director-general of stores, June, 1891.

BURLTON, HENRY MONTGOMERY BARTON, Colonel, I.S.C.—Ensign, 5th Native Infantry, Bengali, Aug., 1855; served in the Indian Mutiny, 1858–59, and was present at the capture of Gwalior, the actions of Jaora and Alipore, and other operations (medal and clasp); served subsequently in the Bhutan campaign, 1862, and the Abyssinian expedition, 1867–68 (medal); assistant cantonment magistrate, Morar, 1870; cantonment magistrate, Mhow, 1881; cantonment magistrate, Morar, Dec., 1884, and at Umballa, Nov., 1886; cantonment magistrate, 1st class March, 1887; reverted to military duty, 1891.

BURN, CHARLES WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India 26th Nov., 1889, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

BURN, RICHARD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces and Oudh).—Educated at the Liverpool Institute, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 2nd Dec., 1891, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

BURN, ROBERT NATHANIEL, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the department as an accountant, Aug., 1870; assistant controller, Sept., 1873; in charge of accounts, Northern Bengal state railway, Sept., 1879; deputy examiner, Jan., 1880; examiner, Jan., 1882; auditor, Oudh and Rohilkhand railway, April, 1886; government examiner of accounts, East Indian railway, Feb., 1889; examiner of telegraph accounts, April, 1890.

BURNE, HENRY KNIGHTLEY, C.B., General, I.S.C.—Ensign, Dec., 1843; arrived in India, 25th May, 1844; served throughout the Sutlej campaign, 1845–46, including battles of Moodkee and Ferozeshah, and with the expedition against Kota Kangra (medal and clasp); during the Burmese war of 1852–53, was military secretary to General Godwin, commander of the force, and was present at the capture of Prome and Pegu (medal and clasp and brevet rank of major); acted as deputy assistant quartermaster-general, May-Oct., 1849; and as cantonment joint magistrate, Umballa, Nov., 1849; acting brigade major, Umballa, 1849–51, and as deputy assistant adjutant-general, Sirdhind division, 1851–52; deputy judge advocate general, April, 1852; 2nd assistant secretary to government of India, military department, July, 1856; 1st assistant secretary, Jan., 1858; deputy secretary, March, 1862; secretary to government of India, military department, June, 1870 to Dec., 1881; C.B., May, 1875.

BURNE, KNIGHTLEY GREY, Burma Commission.—Served in the Bengal police as assistant superintendent and acting district superintendent, from 26th Oct., 1865 to May 1872, and from the latter date in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, and acted as town magistrate and superintendent of jail at Mogulmein, 1872–75; officiating director of public instruction, Aug.–Nov., 1882; deputy commissioner, July, 1886.

BURNE, SIR OWEN TUDOR, Major-Gen., K.C.S.I., C.I.E., Council of India.—Ensign, 20th foot, 15th April, 1855; served in the Crimea; also in the Indian Mutiny of 1858–59, and was present in fifteen actions (including the siege and capture of Lucknow); promoted for gallantry at Lucknow to captaincy and brevet majority; after serving in the field as adjutant of regiment, and brigade-major to a field-column, was appointed military secretary to the commander-in-chief in India (the late Field Marshal
Lord Strathnairn), 1861–62, and afterwards A.D.C., and at times officiating military secretary to that general officer when commander of the forces in Ireland, 1865–68; private secretary to viceroy of India (Earl of Mayo), 1869–72; political A.D.C. to secretary of state for India, 1872; assistant secretary in political and secret department, India Office, 1873; secretary in that department, 1874; on special duty in India as private secretary to the viceroy (Earl of Lytton), 1876–78; member of the council of India, 1st Jan., 1887; was a royal commissioner of the Health and the Colonial and Indian exhibitions of 1882 and 1886; vice-president of the Society of Arts, 1888–92; appointed by H.M. the Queen a governor of the Imperial Institute, 1891; is a royal commissioner for the World's Exposition in Chicago, 1891–93; vice-president of the council of India, 1891–92; author of 'Clyde and Strathnairn' in the 'Rulers of India' series, and of various contributions to periodical literature.

BURRIDGE, Charles E., Store Department, India Office.—Appointed 2nd class clerk, 16th March, 1888.

BURROWS, Leonard Robert, M.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Lincoln Diocesan School, St. Nicholas College, Lancing, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, Dec., 1865; president of municipal commission, Madras, 1875–1880; sub-collector and joint magistrate, March, 1882; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants, Sept., 1883; collector and magistrate and additional sessions judge, Nilgiris, Sept., 1884; retired, Aug., 1889.

BURTON, William Henry, Colonel, R.E., late Madras P.W. Department.—Arrived in India, 26th July, 1857, and was appointed to the public works department, May, 1858, and served in Oudh and Hyderabad; executive engineer, July, 1865; exchanged for temporary service out of India, and appointed to Portsmouth district, and charge of Needles division, Aug., 1867; proceeded to China, Nov., 1875, where he acted for some time, in 1876–7, as commanding royal engineers; returned to India, Nov., 1877; member of defence committee on coast defences, Dec., 1877; executive engineer, Madras, Jan., 1878; superintending engineer, 3rd class, April, 1880; retired, Dec., 1890.

BUSTEDD, Henry Elmsley, M.D., C.I.E., Brigade Surgeon, late Mint Department, Calcutta.—First commission, Indian medical service (Madras establishment), Aug., 1855; arrived in India, March, 1856; civil surgeon, Cuddalore, Jan., 1861; assistant assay master, Madras mint, Feb., 1865; acted as assay master for various periods, and also as mint master and commissioner of paper currency; deputy assay master, Bombay, April, 1868; from Feb., 1869, served in the Calcutta mint as officiating assay master, and was appointed deputy assay master, Nov., 1870, and confirmed as assay master, Sept., 1872; also acted as mint master in 1873 and 1875; retired June, 1886; C.I.E., Jan., 1887.

BUTLER, James, Lieut.-Col., I.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, 19th foot, Feb., 1866; arrived in Madras, 24th May, 1866; served in the Burma commission from Oct., 1868, as assistant commissioner and town magistrate; appointed a deputy commissioner, July, 1881; president of the Henzada Municipal Committee, Oct., 1884; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Aug., 1886; and 1st grade, Dec., 1888; author of 'Mergui Gazetteer.'

BUTLER, Spencer Harcourt, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 29th Oct., 1890, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant collector and magistrate; joint secretary, board of revenue, March, 1892.

BUTLER, William G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Bradfield and Eton; junior clerk, store department, India office, 31st Jan., 1867; assistant private secretary and précis writer to secretary of state, 1874–78; senior clerk, Dec., 1889.

BUTTERWORTH, Alan, Madras C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived 15th Dec., 1885, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant secretary and under secretary to government; acting under secretary, public, &c., departments, Dec., 1891.

BUTTS, Henry Hill, Barrister-at-Law, Oudh Commission.—Extra assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Gonda, 3rd June, 1863; from Nov., 1865, to Oct., 1873, served as assistant settlement officer and officiating settlement officer, and from the latter date as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; subordinate judge, 1st grade, Fyzabad, Aug., 1879; district judge, 3rd grade, Fyzabad, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1882; author of the 'Lucknow Settlement Report.'

BUYERS, John Walker, C.I.E., M.A., M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed executive engineer, N.W. Provinces, 18th Nov., 1869; 1st executive engineer, Jan., 1880; engineer-in-chief, Garo Hills survey, Dec., 1881; superintending engineer, March, 1887; C.I.E., May, 1889; engineer-in-chief, Mu-valley railway, July, 1889; retired, 1891.

BYATT, J., Store Department, India Office.—Assistant clerk, education department, May, 1869; to May, 1873; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, May, 1873; supervisor, 2nd grade, Nov., 1880; 1st grade, July, 1888.

CADELL, Alan, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, Guetersloh Gymnasium, Westphalia, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from July, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from April, 1867, to March, 1881, served in the settlement department in Allahabad, Mozaffarnagar, and Banda, and was placed on special duty, June, 1867, and again in March, 1869, to conduct the prosecution of the Munsif of Deoband; promoted to settlement officer, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, May, 1880; officiating commissioner of excise and stamps and inspector-general of registration, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, March, 1883; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1885; offi-
ciating civil and sessions judge, April, 1886; commissioner, Agra division, May, 1889; Rohilkhand division, Feb., 1890.

CADELL, ALEXANDER, Lieutenant-General, late R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 13th June, 1845; joined the public works department, April, 1848; executive engineer, Rawul Pindi, 1850; executive engineer, Nagpore, April, 1856; executive engineer in Oude road department, Dec., 1853; superintendent of works, northern road, and Saugor division, 1863; superintending engineer, Punjab, 1864; from 1867 to 1878 served in Indore, first as superintending engineer, and then as chief engineer, and secretary to the governor-general's agent for Central India; also officiated as chief engineer and secretary to government N.W. Provinces, 1874-75; chief engineer, 1st grade, Jan., 1879; chief engineer and secretary to government of Bengal, 1879-80; deputy inspector-general of military works, 1881; inspector-general, military works, 1881-82; retired, March, 1882.

CADELL, PATRICK ROBERT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Haileybury College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 7th Dec., 1891, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

CADELL, THOMAS, Colonel, V.C., I.S.C.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, April, 1854; arrived in India, July, 1854; during the mutiny served at the siege of Delhi (medal, clasp, and Victoria cross); and subsequently in the operations in Oudh and Bundelkund; 2nd in command, Malwa Bheel corps, deputy Bheel agent, and political assistant, April, 1861; officiating commandant, Malwa Bheel corps, and Bheel agent, March, 1869; political agent, Eastern States, Rajputana, April, 1870; political agent, Ulwar, Nov., 1870; political agent, Marwar, Nov., 1877, and in Meywar, April, 1878; commandant, Erinpoora force, and political agent, Western Rajputana, Oct., 1879; chief commissioner and superintendent, Port Blair and the Nicobars, from Dec., 1879; reverted to military department, April, 1892.

CALCRAFT-KENNEDY, BENNET CHRISTIAN HUNTINGDON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Dulwich College, Queen's College, Oxford, and King's College, London; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 22nd Nov., 1891, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

CALL, C. F., Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., late Store Department, India Office.—Entered the royal engineers, 16th July, 1866; served on the Indian establishment with the Bengal sappers and miners, and afterwards in the public works department, buildings and roads and railway branches, Feb., 1869, to Sept., 1881; served in the Afghan war, 1878-80, including the march from Kabul to Kandahar (medal and 2 clasps, bronze star, and brevet of major); assistant superintendent, India store depot, Jan., 1883, to Feb., 1887.

CALLAGHAN, T., Registry Department, India Office.—2nd class clerk, 27th March, 1885.

CALNAN, DENIS, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at French College, Blackrock, Ireland, and Queen's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1886, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant commissioner; assistant magistrate and collector, July, 1890; joint magistrate, Oct., 1891.

CAMERON, ARCHIBALD, Surgeon-Lieutenant-Colonel, M.D., Indian Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, April, 1868; arrived in India, Nov., 1868, and served as civil medical officer at various stations in Oudh; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Fyzabad, Dec., 1870; served subsequently in the same capacity at Bara Banki, Lucknow, Sultanpur, and other places; surgeon-major, April, 1880; in medical charge of camp of lieutenant-governor, Nov., 1884; civil surgeon, 1st class, Allahabad, Feb., 1886; civil surgeon, Benares, and superintendent, district jail, lunatic asylum, and government college, July, 1892.

CAMERON, CHARLES, Surgeon-Lieutenant-Colonel, Indian Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 27th July, 1859; arrived in India, 28th Jan., 1860; was employed under the military department 1860-66, and served in the Bhootan campaign (medal); from April, 1866, served in the civil department in Oudh, as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at Bahraich and Rae Bareli; rank of surgeon, July, 1871; surgeon-major, Sept., 1875; served also as civil surgeon and jail superintendent at Bara Banki and at Gonda.

CAMERON, DUNCAN, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1876; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; confirmed as joint magistrate and deputy collector, Aug., 1887; has also acted as divisional judge (Punjab), and district and sessions judge.

CAMERON, LEWIS, Surgeon-Lieutenant-Colonel, M.D., late Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1866; from Feb., 1873, served as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon in Bengal; retired, Aug., 1891.

CAMPBELL, ALEXANDER WILLIAM DENNISTOWN, Major, I.S.C., Judicial Department, N.W. Provinces and Oudh.—Joined the service, 30th Sept., 1871; served under the military department to April, 1882, when he was appointed cantonment magistrate, N.W. Provinces, 2nd class; 1st class, March, 1891.

CAMPBELL, ARCHIBALD COLIN, late Assam Commission.—Served in Assam from 27th April, 1861, as assistant commissioner and personal assistant to chief commissioner; was personal assistant to the chief civil officer, Bhutan field force, 1865 (medal and clasp); superintendent of emigration and embarkation agent, Dhubri, Sept., 1875; promoted to deputy commissioner, Dec., 1878; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, May, 1886; acted as commissioner, Assam Valley Districts, in 1889; retired, 1890.

CAMPBELL, ARCHIBALD EDWARDES, Colonel, I.S.C., late Assam Commission.—First commission, Jan., 1851; served in the Sonthal campaign, 1855-56, and in Central India, 1857-58 (medal and clasp); from May, 1862 served in the Assam commission and was promoted to deputy commissioner, Dec., 1866; inspector of labourers,
Sibsagar, Feb., 1882; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, Aug., 1883; retired, 1890.

CAMPBELL, COLIN G., Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; junior clerk, military department, 13th Jan., 1876; private secretary to permanent under secretary of state from 1877 to 1892; senior clerk, 1889; appointed reading clerk to the council, 1890.

CAMPBELL, DUNCAN JOHN ALFRED, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Tonbridge School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1877, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate; transferred to Burma, Aug., 1878, and served as assistant commissioner, boundary officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; cantonment magistrate, and small cause court judge, Thayetmyo, in 1883; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Feb., 1886; deputy commissioner, May, 1888.

CAMPBELL, DUNCAN MCNEIL, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Madras Public Works Department.—Arrived, 8th April, 1869, and served in the Madras Presidency as assistant engineer and executive engineer; under-secretary to government in the public works department, Oct., 1885, to Nov., 1886; superintending engineer, July, 1890.

CAMPBELL, FRANCIS JOHNSTONE GRAHAM, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, 20th January, 1864; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1875, and district and sessions judge, and grade, April, 1880; 1st grade, April, 1887; retired Oct., 1890.

CAMPBELL, GERALD EDWARD LYON, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1884; head assistant, Dec., 1890.

CAMPBELL, JAMES McNABB, M.A., LL.D., C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Glasgow Academy and Glasgow University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant conservator of forests, acting under secretary to government in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and compiler of the 'Gazetteer' and 'General Administration Report of the Bombay Presidency'; on famine duty, April-Aug., 1877; acting municipal commissioner, Bombay, April, 1880; acting under secretary to government in the revenue, financial, and general departments, Oct., 1880; acted as collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery in 1881; 1st assistant collector, Bombay presidency, May, 1885; junior collector and magistrate, Nov., 1890; collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Nov., 1891.

CAMPBELL, JOHN SCARLETT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Grange, Sunderland; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1847; arrived in India, Jan., 1848, and served as assistant magistrate and collector in the N.W. Provinces; joint magistrate, Moradabad, 1856; during the mutiny was present at the siege of Delhi, and subsequently took charge of the Rohtuk district as deputy commissioner, 1st class; commissioner, Saugor division, Central Provinces, Jan., 1862; judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, 1864; officiating chief commissioner, Central Provinces, 1865; judge of the chief court, Punjab, 1871; on assassination of Lord Mayo in 1872, was deputed to enquire into and report on the administration of the convict settlement in the Andaman Islands; retired, 1878; author of a 'Memo. on proposed changes in the mode of selection and training of candidates for the Indian Civil Service.'

CAMPBELL, JOHN STRATHEDEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1883, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; senior assistant commissioner, Garhwal, Dec., 1886; joint magistrate, Nov., 1890.

CAMPBELL, LORNE AUGUSTUS, Madras C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived, 30th Dec., 1864; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1866; under-secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, Jan., 1875, to Feb., 1881, and acted on several occasions as secretary to Government, and as sub-secretary, board of revenue; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Oct., 1882; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1884.

CAMPBELL, RICHARD HAMILTON, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras Civil Service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived, 18th Dec., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1886; acting assistant secretary, judicial and legislative departments, Dec., 1891; acting under secretary, revenue department, May, 1892.

CAMPBELL-WALKER, INCHES, Colonel, I.S.C., late Forest Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1859; from May, 1865, served in the Madras forest department as assistant conservator and deputy conservator; appointed by the secretary of state a commissioner for the Vienna Exhibition, April, 1873; knight commander of the order of Francis Joseph of Austria for services at the Vienna Exhibition; officiating inspector of forests, Feb., 1874, to Sept., 1875; on duty at the forest conference, Simla, Sept., 1875; member of the forest bill committee, Madras, Jan., 1876, and again, March, 1882; on special duty to New Zealand, March, 1876, to Nov., 1877, and in Nilgiris, S. Coimbatore, and Tinnevelly, Dec., 1877; member of forest draft bill committee, March, 1882; conservator of forests, 1st grade, Dec., 1884; retired, Jan., 1892; author of reports on forest management in Germany, Austria, and Great Britain (1872), and on the forests of New Zealand.

CANDY, EDWARD TOWNSHEND, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments.
as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; on special duty, Poonah, March, 1866; from Oct., 1873, acted as judicial assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1878; acting judicial commissioner and judge of the sadar court in Sind, May, 1883; 2nd grade, judge and sessions judge, Ahmedabad, Aug., 1883; 1st grade judge, Surat, Feb., 1885; judge and sessions judge, Feb., 1885; acting remembrancer of legal affairs, July-Nov., 1885; officiating judge of high court, Bombay, Jan., 1889, to Jan., 1890, and again in May, 1890; confirmed, April, 1892.

CANDY, RICHARD EDWARD, BOMBAY C.S.—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting educational inspector; acting director of public instruction, Berar, June, 1872, to Dec., 1873; first assistant collector and magistrate, Oct., 1877; junior collector and magistrate, May, 1885; senior collector, Sept., 1888.

CAPPEL, SIR ALBERT JAMES LEPPOC, K.C.I.E., late Indian Telegraph Department.—Appointed to the telegraph department, 10th Feb., 1877; 1st grade superintendent and personal assistant to director general, Dec., 1866; director of traffic, May, 1869; deputy director-general, Feb., 1879; director-general of telegraphs, June, 1883; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887; director-general of telegraphs, Feb., 1888; retired 1889.

CAPPEL, EDWARD LOUIS, BOMBAY C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from May, 1882, served under the government of Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; transferred permanently to the Bombay civil service, June, 1885; acting junior collector, May, 1887; 2nd assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1889; director of land records and agriculture, June, 1891.

CARD, H. C., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 22nd Jan., 1875.

CARDEW, ALEXANDER GORDON, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Somersetshire College, Bath, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1882, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting deputy registrar high court, and acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments (July, 1885); on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1884, and again in 1885; on special duty as secretary to the Malabar land tenures committee, Dec., 1885; acting under secretary to government, revenue department, Oct., 1886, and May, 1887; assistant secretary, judicial and legislative departments, Sept., 1888; under secretary, revenue department, Nov., 1888; acting inspector-general of jails, Sept., 1891, and from Feb., 1892.

CARDOZO, HENRY O'CONNELL, Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras revenue survey department from 21st March, 1859, and was promoted to deputy superintendent, 1st class, March, 1883, and to superintendent, July, 1887.

CAREY, ARTHUR DOUGLAS, BOMBAY C.S.—Educated at the City of London School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; served in the salt department from May, 1872, to March, 1877, and from May, 1877 to Feb., 1882, as assistant collector of salt revenue, and acting deputy collector, and was appointed collector of salt revenue, Bombay, April, 1881; on special duty to Sambhar, Oct., 1881; from Feb., 1882, served under the government of India as officiating commissioner, inland customs; commissioner, salt revenue, Northern India, Dec., 1882; officiating commissioner of customs, salt, opium, and akbari, and reporter-general of external commerce for Bombay, March, 1891; confirmed, May, 1891; on special duty in Lisbon, in connection with Goa Treaty negotiations, 1891-92.

CAREY, HIRZEL DENIS DE MUSSENDEN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 25th Nov., 1891, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

CAREY, LIONEL SLADE, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India 14th Dec., 1882, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acting district superintendent of police, July, 1883; acting inspector of schools, May-July, 1884; acting deputy commissioner, 1884; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, June to Dec., 1885; settlement officer, Oct., 1886; deputy commissioner and revenue secretary, Dec., 1891.

CARGILL, JAMES DUDLEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Brighton Grammar School, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 13th Nov., 1891, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

CARLYLE, ROBERT WARRAND, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Glasgow University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; acting under secretary to government of Bengal, April, 1888; confirmed, Dec., 1888; joint magistrate and deputy collector, June, 1890; has officiated also as under secretary to the government of India, home department, and as magistrate and collector.

CARMICHAEL, CHARLES PAGET, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and subsequently at Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1849; arrived in India, March, 1849; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1854; officiating registrar of Sudder Dewany and Nizamat Adawlut, April, 1854; officiating civil auditor, Aug., 1854; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan.,
1856; deputed as civil officer with the relieving force to Shahjahanpur, April, 1858; magistrate and collector, Budaun, Feb., 1862; officiating commissioner, Kumaun, May, 1867, to Jan., 1868; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1870; from April, 1873, acted as commissioner and agent to governor-general, Benares, and was confirmed in these appointments, March, 1877; also held the substantive appointment of district and sessions judge, Jan., 1877; officiated as member of the board of revenue in 1877-78-79, and was appointed permanently to the board in 1882; retired March, 1884.

CARMICHAEL, David Fremantle, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury, 1851; assistant collector and magistrate, Dec., 1851; head assistant registrar, court of Sudder and Foujdaree Adawlut, Feb., 1855; deputy secretary to government, Oct., 1856; secretary to board of examiners, Oct., 1856; private secretary to governor of Madras, March, 1859; fellow of Madras university, Oct., 1859; collector and magistrate and agent, Vizagapatam, July, 1863, to April, 1867, and afterwards at Ganjam; acting judge, high court, Madras, April to July, 1869; employed in preparation of Vizagapatam district manual; acting member, board of revenue, Aug., 1871; president of committee for examination of assistants, July, 1871; Inam commissioner, Aug., 1871; on special duty as president of the committee for inquiring into the action of government officials during cyclone in 1872, May, 1872; secretary to government, revenue department, Nov., 1872; additional member of council for making laws and regulations Feb., 1874; on special duty with government at imperial assembling, Delhi, Dec., 1876; chief secretary to government, June, 1877; ordinary member of council, Madras, Dec., 1878; on tour as special commissioner through Hill tracts of Ganjam, Vizagapatam, and Godavari, Feb., 1881; retired, 1886.

CARMICHAEL, George, Bombay C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Aberdeen Grammar School and at University of Aberdeen and Balliol College, Oxford; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1836; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1837; forest settlement officer, Nov., 1838; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, Aug., 1839; officiating deputy commissioner, June, 1890.

CARNDUFF, Herbert William Cameron, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Collegiate School, University of Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1831; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1833; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1833; officiated as cantonment magistrate and as joint magistrate and deputy collector; appointed under secretary to government of Bengal, May, 1835; acted as registrar, appellate side, high court, Calcutta, March, 1890; confirmed, Oct., 1890.

CARR, Reginald Childers Culling, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheam school, the Charterhouse, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1833; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1835; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1836; on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1838; additional special assistant to district magistrate and collector, March, 1839; acted as under secretary to government in the revenue and chief secretary's departments in 1839 and 1890; assistant secretary, judicial and legislative departments, Sept., 1891; acted as private secretary to governor in Dec., 1891.

CARSTAIRS, Robert, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Edinburgh Collegiate School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty under board of revenue, Nov., 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1886; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1888; author of 'British Administration in India.'

CARTER, Albert M., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College; temporary clerk, India office, 4th Nov., 1861; junior clerk, March, 1866; senior clerk, Aug., 1882.

CARTER, George Markham Strange, Burma Commission.—Appointed chief inspector of police, June, 1875; assistant district superintendent, Feb., 1880, and district superintendent, Oct., 1882; appointed to the commission as assistant commissioner, March, 1886; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1890.

CARTER, Henry Vandyke, Brigade Surgeon, M.D. (Lon.), late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 27th Jan., 1853; arrived in India, 29th March, 1858, and served on military duty and as professor of anatomy and physiology and curator of museum at the Grant Medical College, and assistant surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital; also as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Satara; on special duty in England, May, 1874, and in Bombay and Kathiawar, 1875; appointed surgeon to the Gokuldas Tejal Hospital, Bombay, Nov., 1879; brigade surgeon, Sept., 1882; principal and professor of medicine and clinical medicine, Grant Medical College, and first physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, 1886; retired, Aug., 1888.

CARTER, Philip John, Burma Forest Department.—Arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1875; and was appointed assistant conservator; deputy conservator, April, 1881; on duty at Port Blair, Nov., 1886; rejoined his Burma appointment, June, 1889; conservator, 3rd grade, Feb., 1892.

CARTER, Thomas Tupper, Colonel, R.E. (Bengal), late Survey of India.—First commission, Dec. 1855; arrived in India, Dec., 1859; served with the Sikkim Field Force, 1860-61, as survey officer; from May, 1861, to April, 1862, served as assistant engineer in the public works department, Punjab; appointed to the great trigonometrical survey of India, March, 1862, and served as assistant in the Kashmir and Kumaon and Garhwal surveys; served in the Umbeyla Campaign, 1863 (medal and clasp); surveyor, 3rd grade, April, 1866; in charge of the survey party with the Abyssinian expedition, Dec., 1867, to March, 1868; was subsequently in charge of survey parties on the Brahmaputra, in Madras, Guzerat, Kumaon, Gwalior, and Central India; deputy superintendent, 1st grade, March, 1886; retired, Jan., 1887.

CASEY, Arthur Edwin Comerford, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portora Royal School, and Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service
after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, Kumaon, May, 1882; retired, Oct., 1880.

CASSON, HERBERT ALEXANDER, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Newton Abbot Proprietary College, Marlborough College, and Hertford College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1889, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

CAVE-BROWNE, E.R., C.S.I., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the College School, Taunton; junior clerk in the treasury, East India House, 12th April, 1854, and from 1858 in the India Office; accountant-general's department, 1860; senior clerk, June, 1867; assistant in the accounts branch of the financial department, Jan., 1872; assessor of income tax 1872; deputy accountant-general, Feb., 1879; C.S.I., Jan., 1888.

CAWLEY, GEORGE JOHN, Police Department, Bengal.—Joined the service, 1st May, 1862, as assistant superintendent of police, Assam; district superintendent, Dec., 1876; transferred to Bengal, Dec., 1883; district superintendent, 1st grade, Sept., 1891.

CAYLEY, H., Brigade Surgeon, late Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1857; from April, 1872, served as civil surgeon and officiating superintendent of vaccination, superintendent of royal botanical gardens, ophthalmic surgeon and professor of ophthalmic surgery, Medical College, Calcutta (from Jan., 1876), superintendent of the eye infirmary, and marine surgeon; rank of brigade surgeon, April, 1884; medical board, India office, 1885; retired, April, 1887.

CENTER, WILLIAM, M.B., M.A., Brigade-Surgeon-Lieutenant-Colonel, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined Indian medical department in 1865; arrived in India, 11th April, 1866; from March, 1871, served under the government of the Punjab as chemical examiner and professor of chemistry and surgery in the Lahore medical school; officiating meteorological reporter in addition to his other duties, May, 1872; surgeon-major, Oct., 1877; served under the government of India, Aug.-Nov., 1882, as statistical officer in sanitary department; officiated as principal of the Lahore medical school in 1878, 1882, and 1883; civil surgeon, Lahore, and superintendent lunatic asylum, 1883; civil surgeon, 1st class, Aug., 1885; professor of forensic medicine and midwifery, Lahore medical college, April, 1888; brigade surgeon, April, 1889.

CHAMBERLAIN, SIR NEVILLE BOWLES, General, G.C.B., G.C.S.I.—Ensign, Bengal Infantry, 1837; served through the Afghan campaigns of 1839-42 (medal); present with the governor-general's body-guard at the battle of Maharajpore, Dec., 1843 (bronze star); deputy assistant quartermaster-general to the army, 1843; hon. aide-de-camp to Lord Dalhousie, 1848; served in the Punjab campaign of 1848-49, including the actions of Chillianwallah and Goojerat (medal and two clasps); military secretary to the chief commissioner for affairs of the Punjab, March, 1853; commandant, Punjab irregular force, Dec., 1854; adjutant-general of the Bengal army, July, 1857; C.B., 1857; aide-de-camp to the Queen for services in the mutiny; commanded the force on the N.W. frontier of India in various expeditions against the hill tribes (medal and clasp); commander in chief, Madras, and member of the governor's council, Feb., 1876 to 1881; was appointed head of the special mission to Cabul, Aug., 1878, which, however, was not allowed to enter the Ameer's territory.

CHAMIER, FRANCIS EDWARD ARCHIBALD, Major-Gen., I.S.C., late Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, 7th April, 1850; aide-de-camp to General Outram throughout the Oudh campaign; commanded the Kapurthala contingent during its service in Oudh, in 1858 (medal and two clasps); from March, 1858, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, officiating settlement officer, and officiating commissioner, in various divisions; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Bara Banki, April, 1873; district judge, 1st grade, Rae Bareli, Feb., 1882, and afterwards at Fyzabad; returned to Europe, 1888.

CHANNING, FRANCIS HORLEY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and settlement officer; settlement secretary to financial commissioner, Jan., 1878; senior secretary to the financial commissioner, March, 1882; officiated as divisional judge, Nov., 1885, and again April, 1887; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, March, 1886; district judge, 1st grade, Jan., 1888, but to continue to act as divisional judge; on special duty, civil secretariat, Jan., 1889; divisional judge, May, 1890.

CHAPMAN, CHARLES, Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 6th Aug., 1884.

CHAPMAN, EDMUND PELLY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1889, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

CHAPMAN, ROBERT ALEXANDER BOSWELL, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Haileybury College, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1888; and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, Nov., 1891.

CHAPMAN, ROBERT BARCLAY, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1850; arrived 6th March, 1850; served in Bengal in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; under secretary to government of India, home, financial, and foreign departments, April, 1856, to April, 1860; called to the bar (Inner Temple) Jan., 1863; junior secretary, board of revenue, Lower Provinces, June, 1865; acting commissioner, Nudder division, Nov., 1866, to Jan., 1869; served subsequently as secretary to government of India, financial department, and government director of Bank of Bengal; retired, 1881.

CHARLES, FENDALL LOWIS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Repton School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov.,
1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting railway magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty, demarcation of forests in Nasik, July, 1875; forest settlement officer, Dharwar, Nov., 1881; assistant collector and magistrate, Sept., 1883; acting municipal commissioner, Bombay, Oct., 1886; junior collector and magistrate, April, 1890.

CHARLES, GEORGE Gwyther, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the department, 9th May, 1857; arrived in India, 3rd Oct., 1857, and held charge of various offices in Bengal and the North-Western Provinces; inspector, April, 1862; assistant superintendent, Feb., 1863; superintendent, April, 1880; class IV., 2nd grade, Oct., 1887; has held charge of various divisions.

CHARLES, JOHN GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 15th Dec., 1865; assistant magistrate and collector, April, 1866; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1870; on special duty (member of cattle plague commission), June, 1870; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, July, 1871; officiating deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, March, 1876; joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1876; officiating presidency magistrate, Calcutta, Dec., 1877; officiating chief presidency magistrate, Calcutta, March, 1878; district and sessions judge, Jan., 1885.

CHARLTON, A., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 8th April, 1882.

CHATFIELD, KYRLE MITFORD, M.A., Educational Department, Bombay.—Served from 29th March, 1866, as principal and professor of logic and moral philosophy at the Elphinstone College, Bombay; also acted as educational inspector and as director of public instruction, and was confirmed in the latter appointment, Nov., 1874.

CHATTERTON, FRANK WILLIAM, Colonel, Bengal Infantry.—Arrived in India as ensign 4th Nov., 1859; employed under the military department till Feb., 1869, from which date he served in Jhansi and Kumaon as officiating assistant commissioner; from May, 1873, served as cantonment magistrate of Roorkee; also appointed a small cause court judge, Roorkee, March, 1879; 1st class cantonment magistrate, Agra, Dec., 1880; commandant of Bengal Presidency Volunteers; honorary aide-de-camp to Viceroy, Dec., 1888.

CHERRY, JOHN WILLIAM, Forest Department, Madras.—Joined the service, 5th Feb., 1869, as assistant conservator; deputy conservator, Jan., 1872; conservator, Oct., 1891.

CHESNEY, SIR GEORGE TOMKYNES, Lieutenant-General, R.E., K.C.B., C.S.I., C.I.E., M.P.—Joined the service, 1848; served in the public works department from 1851 as executive engineer in the Lower Provinces, N.W. Provinces, and Punjab; assistant to principal of Thomason College, 1856; controller and examiner of accounts, public works department, Lower Provinces, Nov., 1860; inspector-general of public works accounts, Bengal, Jan., 1862; also ex-officio under secretary to government of India; accountant-general, public works department, May, 1864; on the institution of the Royal Indian Engineering College at Cooper's Hill in 1870, was appointed president of the college, and continued in that post till 1880, when he was appointed military secretary to the government of India; military member of governor-general's council, May, 1886; resigned, April, 1891; served in the Indian mutiny, 1857-8, as brigade major of engineers Delhi field force, battle of Budulukserai, siege of Delhi (very severely wounded); medal with clasp, brevet of major; K.C.B., Jan., 1890; M.P. for Oxford, 1892.

CHEVIS, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Lancing College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1885, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

CHIPPER, E., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 3rd Dec., 1875.

CHIPPERFIELD, A. E., late Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 27th June, 1881; resigned, Jan., 1886.

CHISHOLM, JAMES WRIGHT, late Central Provinces.—Served in the Central Provinces from 24th Oct., 1856, as deputy collector, assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and settlement officer, and was appointed inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Oct., 1871; inspector-general of police and jails, Oct., 1876; secretary to the chief commissioner, June, 1880; commissioner of the Chhattisgarh division, March, 1883; retired, 1889.

CHISHOLME, JOHN JAMES SCOTT, Major, 5th Lancers.—1st commission sub-lieutenant 9th lancers, 10th Jan., 1872; captain, March, 1878; major, Dec., 1883; served in the Afghan war, 1878-9-80; military secretary on the personal staff of the governor of Madras (Lord Conmara, G.C.I.E.), 10th Aug., 1888; reverted to military department, Dec., 1890.

CHITPAL SINGH, RAJA, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces and Oudh).—Appointed a covenanted civilian under native civil service rules without probation, 12th Dec., 1881; served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade; 2nd grade, April, 1889.

CHOLMELEY, NORMAN GOODFORD, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Charterhouse, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1884, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1890.

CHRISTIE, ARCHIBALD, B.L., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating district and divisional judge; on special duty, Kurram field force, Oct., 1878; officiating under secretary to government of Punjab, Aug. to Dec., 1884; district judge, Sept., 1887.

CHRISTIE, CHARLES HOWARD PEREGRINE, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Public Works Department Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, April, 1866; joined the department, March, 1866; served as assistant engineer, assistant consulting engineer for railways, acting examiner of railway accounts, and acting deputy
consulting engineer; deputy controller, public works accounts, Madras, irrigation branch, Jan., 1873; examiner, 4th class, Jan., 1880; transferred to Central India, Sept., 1880; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, April, 1881; 3rd class examiner, Sept., 1886; examiner, public works accounts, Madras, March, 1887; attached to accountant-general's office for inspection duty, Dec., 1891.

CHRISTIE, GEORGE FRANCIS STEPHEN, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Dulwich College, and Caius College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1891, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

CHRISTIE, JAMES THOMAS, C.I.E., Police Department, Punjab.—Entered the accountant-general's office, Jan., 1855; served in the police department from March, 1861, and under the government of India in the foreign department, Sept., 1887, and Feb., 1880 (in Afghanistan); district superintendent of police, 1st grade, Dec., 1886.

CHRYSTIE, GEORGE, Colonel, Police Department, Madras.—Joined the service, 12th Dec., 1857; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1858, and served in the suppression of the mutiny, &c.; from Aug., 1863, served in the Madras presidency as assistant superintendent of police; superintendent, April, 1873; acting deputy inspector-general, April, 1891; confirmed, Dec., 1891.

CHUCKERBUTTY, ALFRED WILLIAM GOODEVE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at University College School and University College, London; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 30th Dec., 1892, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

CHUCKERBUTTY, ARTHUR GOODEVE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College School and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1886, and served as assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal.

CHUNDER MADHUB GHOSE, Judicial Department, Bengal.—Member of the legislative council of Bengal, 1883 to 1885; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 13th Jan., 1885.

CHURCH, WILLIAM THOMAS, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rugby, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1880; superintendent, Dehra Dun, Jan., 1882; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, July, 1885, 1st grade, Aug., 1887; officiated as commissioner, Rohilkund, in 1889; retired April, 1890.

CHURCHILL, RIGHT HON. LORD RANDOLPH HENRY SPENCER, LL.D. (Hon.), M.P.—Born 1849; educated at Eton and Merton College, Oxford (graduated B.A., 1871); represented Woodstock in the House of Commons from Feb., 1874, until Nov., 1885, when he was returned for South Paddington; secretary of state for India, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886; chancellor of the exchequer and leader of the House of Commons, in the Marquis of Salisbury's second ministry, Aug., 1886, but resigned after a few months' tenure of office.

CLARK, JOHN, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Old Aberdeen Grammar School and the University of Aberdeen, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1887, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Assam as assistant commissioner, April, 1890.

CLARK, WILLIAM OVENS, B.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Portora School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; on famine duty, Bengal, Feb., 1874; on special duty in the public works department, March, 1882; officiating cantonment magistrate, Mooltan, April, 1883; on special duty in the Punjab civil secretariat, March, 1885; officiating additional divisional judge, May, 1885 and in 1890; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1888; district judge, Sept., 1890; officiating divisional judge from March, 1891.

CLARKE, SIR ANDREW, Lieut.-General, G.C.M.G., C.B., C.I.E.—2nd Lieutenant, Royal Engineers, June, 1844; in 1848 was employed on special service in New Zealand, and was aide-de-camp to lieutenant-governor, Tasmania, June, 1849, to June, 1853; governor and commander-in-chief, Straits Settlements, Aug., 1873, to May, 1875; member of council of governor-general of India in charge of public works, June, 1875 to 1880; commandant, school of military engineering, Chatham, April, 1881, to June, 1882; inspector-general of fortifications and director of works, ordnance department, War Office, June, 1882, to June, 1886.

CLARKE, C.B., M.A., late Educational Service, Assam.—Appointed to the Bengal educational department, 8th Dec., 1865; served as professor at the Presidency College, and as inspector of schools; officiating superintendent of the Calcutta botanical garden, May, 1869; 1st class of the education department, March, 1876; on special duty in England, March, 1879, to April, 1883; officiating director of public instruction, December, 1884; transferred to Assam as inspector of schools, March, 1885; retired, June, 1887.

CLARKE, HERVEY MORRIS STANLEY, Colonel, I.S.C. — Arrived in India as ensign, Madras Native Infantry, 13th March, 1854; served with the Central India Horse, during 1858-60; from Sept., 1861, served in the N.W. Provinces police department; district superintendent, April, 1863; personal assistant to inspector-general of police, Dec., 1871; acted at various times as assistant inspector-general, government railway police; deputy inspector-general, Oct., 1885; inspector-general of prisons, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1886; reverted to military duty, 1890.

CLARKE, ROBERT, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Royal School, Raphoe, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant, and was in charge of the
Jhelum settlement, Aug., 1878; officiating registrar, chief court, Punjab, May, 1881; officiating divisional judge, Oct., 1886; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1886, and 2nd grade, May, 1889.

CLARKE, SYDENHAM CUBBON, Colonel, late Madras Public Works Department.—Arrived in India, 9th Jan., 1862; appointed assistant engineer, Mysore, Oct., 1862; executive engineer, Sept., 1867; served at Chatham, March to Sept., 1874; acting professor of surveying, Royal Indian Engineering College, Cooper's Hill, Sept., 1874, to Dec., 1875; returned to Madras, Nov., 1876; served under the Government of India on the Peshawur-Jellalabad state railway, Nov., 1879, and in Baluchistan; temporary superintendent of works, Madras, April, 1883; officiated for various periods as superintending engineer, and in May, 1889, was posted for charge of public works, stores, and workshops; retired, March, 1891.

CLARKE, TREDWAY GEORGE, Colonel, I.S.C.—Ensign, Madras Infantry, 1853; served in the Mysore commission from Oct., 1857; deputy superintendent, Mysore commission, Nov., 1862; deputy commissioner, Mysore, 1873; from 1875 acted as secretary to the chief commissioner, and was confirmed in this appointment, 1877; commissioner, Nagar division, May, 1879; commissioner of Coorg, 1881; officiating resident in Mysore and chief commissioner of Coorg, Dec., 1884, to March, 1885; and afterwards commissioner; reverted to military duty, Jan., 1891.

CLARKE, WILLOUGHBY CHARLES STANLEY, Colonel, I.S.C., late Assam Commission.—Commission as ensign, June, 1851; arrived in India, 15th Oct., 1851; was employed on military duty till 1862, including service in the Sonthal Expedition, 1855, and in the China Expedition, 1860-61; also served as superintendent of police and magistrate, governor-general's camp, Sept., 1859, to Jan., 1860; from June, 1862, served in the Assam commission, and was promoted to deputy commissioner, July, 1867; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, Jan., 1885; returned to Europe, 1889.

CLAY, ARTHUR LLOYD, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cholmeley Grammar School, Highgate, at Cologne, and at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 29th Nov., 1862; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1874; from Sept., 1874, to June, 1877, served in Assam as deputy commissioner, 1st grade, and district and sessions judge of Sylhet; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, July, 1879; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Manbhoom, Aug., 1879; officiating commissioner of Chota Nagpore, Sept., 1884; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Backergunge, March, 1886; has officiated as commissioner of the Chittagong and Burdwan divisions; retired July, 1890.

CLAY, WILLIAM McKINLEY, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 28th Oct., 1862; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating deputy commissioner (wards' estate, Patna); on famine relief duty, 1873-74; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1887; retired, 1888.

CLEGG, ROBERT BAILEY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Manchester Grammar School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Jan., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1885.

CLEGHORN, JAMES, Surgeon-Colonel, M.D., Indian Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical department, March, 1865; arrived in India, 26th Sept., 1865; served in Bengal, and held various military medical charges, and officiated as civil surgeon of Howrah and Moorshedabad, 1867, and of Mooltan and Cawnpore, 1868-69; from Feb., 1870, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed civil surgeon, Azimgarh, June, 1870; junior civil surgeon and superintendent, district jail, Allahabad, April, 1873; held medical charge of the camp of the lieutenant-governor on several occasions, including Imperial assemblage at Delhi, 1876; civil surgeon of Naini Tal, March, 1876, and subsequently at Mirzapur, Cawnpore, and Allahabad; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1877; on special duty to Calcutta, Dec., 1880; officiating surgeon superintendent, Presidency General Hospital, Calcutta, June, 1885 to March, 1886, when he was appointed civil surgeon of Lucknow; brigade surgeon, Dec., 1888; inspector-general of civil hospitals, Punjab, September, 1891.

CLERK, GEORGE PERCY, Madras Revenue Department.—Joined the service as probationary assistant director, revenue settlement, 14th Sept., 1871; assistant director, July, 1872; on special duty, North Arcot, in connexion with famine relief works; deputy director, Sept., 1880; deputy commissioner of revenue settlement, April, 1887.

CLEVELAND, CHARLES RAITT, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Christ's College, Finchley, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1887, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; assistant settlement officer, Jan., 1890; assistant to commissioner of settlements and agriculture, Nov. 1890.

CLIFFORD, SAMUEL LE POER TRENCH, Punjab Commission.—From 1st April, 1861, served in the subordinate judicial department; officiated as deputy registrar of the chief court, and in Jan., 1872, was appointed registrar of the judicial commissioner's court in Oudh; deputy registrar of chief court, Punjab, Oct., 1872; officiated for various periods as judge, small cause court, and as judicial assistant; appointed judicial assistant, Jan., 1884; author of 'Notes on the Code of Criminal Procedure.'

CLINTON (BARON), RIGHT HON. CHARLES HENRY ROLLE HEPBURN STUART TREFUSIS.—Educated at Eton, and at Christ Church, Oxford; M.P. for North Devon from 1857 to 1866; under secretary of state for India, July, 1867 to Dec., 1868; appointed a charity commissioner for England and Wales, 1874.

CLOETE, HENRY DANIEL, Colonel, I.S.C., late Police Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras Army, Dec., 1849; arrived, 27th April, 1850; served in the Madras police department from June, 1860, as superintendent, deputy inspector-
general, acting commissioner and acting chief magistrate of police for the town of Madras; inspector-general of police, Madras, from Dec., 1861 to 1885.

CLOETE, Josias Gordon, Colonel, late Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras Infantry, Feb., 1857; arrived in India, May, 1857; served in the Madras police as assistant superintendent, June, 1861, to June, 1863, and from the latter date in the revenue survey; deputy superintendent, Jan., 1872; on special duty preparing code of rules for survey department, July, 1873 to March, 1874.

CLOGSTOUN, Herbert Frederick, Madras C.S.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived 25th Nov., 1864; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1866; acting assistant superintendent of police, April, 1867, to April, 1868; acting deputy director of revenue settlement, March, 1872; on special duty in connection with state relief works, Kurnool, Dec., 1876; acting principal assistant collector and magistrate and agent to governor, Vizagapatam, Jan., 1880; joint sessions judge in Rumpa cases, Jan., 1880; from March, 1880, served in the financial department as officiating accountant-general, Bengal, and deputy accountant-general, Madras; member of board of examiners, Madras, June, 1882; accountant-general and commissioner of issue of state paper currency, Madras, July, 1882; officiating comptroller and auditor-general and head commissioner of paper currency, Calcutta, Aug. to Nov., 1887; accountant-general, class 2, provisionally, Nov., 1887; member of board of revenue, commissioner of revenue settlement, and director of land records and agriculture, Oct., 1889.

CLOUGH, J. W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 25th July, 1892.

COATES, John Martin, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., late Bengal Medical Department.—First commission, 1855; in medical charge of 1st Bengal military police battalion, Dec., 1856; civil assistant surgeon, April, 1859; superintendent of jails, Hazaribagh, Nov., 1866; surgeon-major, Aug., 1867; civil surgeon, Moorsheadabad, Dec., 1871; in joint medical charge, Simla, and in charge of Sind commander-in-chief's staff, 1873; sanitary commissioner for Bengal, May, 1874; principal and professor of medicine, Medical College, Calcutta, and ex officio 1st physician to the college hospital, April, 1880; also officiated as inspector-general of jails, Aug., 1879; brigade surgeon, May, 1881; officiating surgeon-general, Bengal, in addition to other duties, June, 1884; president of a committee of enquiry on sanitary matters in connection with Kidderpore docks, March, 1885; retired, July, 1890; has published a vocabulary of the dialects of Chota Nagpur.

COBB, Henry Venn, LL.B., Madras C.S.—Educated at King's School, Canterbury, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 18th Nov., 1886, and served in the revenue survey and settlement department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate; has also acted as assistant secretary to government.

COBB, William Hey, B.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at St. Peter's School, York, Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 25th Dec., 1884; served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant-magistrate and collector, and assistant-commissioner; city magistrate, Lucknow, July, 1880; officiating magistrate and collector, Agra, April, 1892.

COCKERELL, Horace Abel, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1853; served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; also as superintendent of survey, Sept., 1859, and as officiating chairman, justices of the peace, Calcutta, and commissioner of police, March, 1869, and Dec., 1872; commissioner of the Chittagong division, June, 1872, and subsequently of the Dacca and Burdwan divisions; secretary to the government of Bengal, judicial and political departments, April, 1878; lieutenant-governor's council, April, 1878, and again, March, 1880 and 1882; board of revenue, March, 1883; officiating lieutenant-governor of Bengal, Aug., 1885; retired, Aug., 1887.

COCKS, Walter Carew, Auditor, India Office.—Appointed 1st Aug., 1874.

CODRINGTON, George Henry Forbes, Lieut.-Colonel, I.S.C., late Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 4th May, 1857; served on military duty till Dec., 1865, and subsequently in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent, and district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade superintendent, April, 1883; reverted to military department, 1892.

COGHLAN, Robert Nesbit, Customs Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd April, 1871; from March, 1872, served as general manager of the customs' bonded warehouses, Bombay, and as acting assistant commissioner of customs, salt, and opium, in charge of the tobacco department, Bombay; from March, 1874, served as assistant collector of salt revenue; collector of sea customs, Karachi, and assistant commissioner of salt revenue in Sind, Sept., 1882; collector of customs and salt revenue in Sind, March, 1891.

COLDSTREAM, William, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, officiating personal assistant to financial commissioner, officiating registrar, chief court, Punjab, and officiating deputy commissioner; judicial assistant, July, 1876; deputy commissioner, March, 1877; officiating commissioner and sessions judge, Lahore, April, 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Umballa, Sept., 1883; deputed to Calcutta to act as one of the representatives of the Punjab in the committee on museum and exhibition held there, Dec., 1883; officiating commissioner, Hissar, April, 1884; Lahore, Feb., 1887.

COLE, William Hammond, M.A., Survey of India Department.—Served in the education department, N.W. Provinces, April, 1862, to March, 1864, as professor of mathematics at the Government College, Agra; from Jan., 1867, served in the great trigonometrical survey of
India as assistant surveyor attached to the computing office, Dehra; assistant superintendent of surveys, Sept., 1869; deputy superintendent July, 1882; appointed to charge of head quarters office, Dehra Dun, and survey detachment in Kashmir, Jan., 1884; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; 2nd grade, Oct., 1890; author of various contributions to the 'Account of the Operations of the Great Trigonometrical Survey of India,' and to the 'Synopsis of the Results of the Operations of the Great Trigonometrical Survey,' also of various translations relating to geodesy.

COLLEN, Maj.-Gen. Sir E. H.
