H., K.C.I.E., I.S.C.—First commission, royal artillery, July, 1863; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, May, 1873; 3rd assistant secretary to government of India, military department, March, 1875; 2nd assistant secretary, April, 1876; 1st assistant secretary, Dec., 1876; deputy secretary, military department, April, 1884; accountant general, military department, government of India, July, 1886; secretary to government of India, military department, 1887; C.I.E., Jan., 1889; K.C.I.E., Jan., 1893.

COLLIER, Frank Robert Stanley, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1872; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating cantonment magistrate; on famine duty, March, 1874; officiating collector of customs, Calcutta, May, 1884; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Oct., 1886; magistrate and collector, April, 1889; published an annotated edition of the Bengal Municipal Act, 1884, another of the Bengal Local Self-Government Act and Rules, 1886, and the Bengal Municipal Manual, 1887.

COLLIER, George H., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Uppingham School; junior clerk, India office, 17th Feb., 1876.

COLLIN, Edward Woodfield, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1878; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; private secretary to financial member of governor-general's council, Jan., 1880; served under the government of India, foreign department, Jan. to July, 1881, and in the financial department, March to Sept., 1885; settlement officer, Mozaffarpore, Jan., 1886; officiated as director of land records, Bengal, April, 1888; joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1889; on special duty in 1889 and 1890.

COLLINS, Arthur Herbert, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 1st Jan., 1879, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Aug., 1889; has also officiated as district and sessions judge.

COLLINS, Sir Arthur John Hammond, Knt., Q.C., Madras High Court.—Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge, of which he was fellow; called to the bar, Gray's Inn, 1860; Q.C. and bencher of his inn, 1877; recorder of Poole, 1873-9, and of Exeter from 1879, until he was appointed chief justice of the high court of judicature, Madras, 28th Nov., 1885; vice-chancellor, Madras University, 1889.

COLLINS, S. A., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, Dec., 1885.

COLQUHOUN, Archibald Ross, A.M.I.C.E., India Public Works Department.—Entered the public works department in Oct., 1871, as apprentice engineer; served in the grades of assistant and executive engineer in various divisions of Burma; on special duty as personal assistant to Major Street on his mission to Siam, Jan.-May, 1879; executive engineer, 3rd grade, Nov., 1881; was posted to special duty in Upper Burma as civil officer, and appointed a deputy commissioner, Feb., 1886; retransferred to public works department, and posted to Baluchistan, Aug., 1889; services lent to British South African Company, 1891; author of 'Across Chryse,' 'Among the Shans,' 'The Truth about Tonquin,' 'The Opening of China,' 'Burma and the Burmans.'

COLVIN, Sir Auckland, K.C.M.G., K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton; appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1858; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; officiating under secretary to the government of India in the home department, May, 1864, and in the foreign department, Jan. to Nov., 1865; settlement officer, 2nd grade, July, 1869; secretary, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, March, 1870; on special duty to Naini Tal, in connection with the revision of settlement in the Allahabad district, June, 1870; officiating secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, April, 1873, and again in 1875; officiating commissioner of excise and stamps, and inspector-general of registration, June, 1873; member of commission for investigating disturbances in Poona and Ahmednagar, Aug., 1875; magistrate and collector, Basti, Feb., 1877, and afterwards at Bijnor; officiating commissioner of inland customs under the government of India, Nov., 1877; transferred for employment in Egypt, Jan., 1879, and served as controller of Egyptian finance, and subsequently as finance minister to the Egyptian government; acted as consul-general in Sir E. Malet's absence; financial member of council of the governor-general of India, Oct., 1883; lieutenant governor of the N.W. Provinces, and chief commissioner of Oudh, November, 1887 to November, 1892.

COLVIN, Bazett Wettenhall, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1850; arrived in India, 29th June, 1850; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector till Jan., 1854; and subsequently in the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed assistant commissioner, Kumaon, April, 1855, magistrate and collector, Mainpuri, July, 1865, and civil and sessions judge, Allahabad, July, 1873; officiated as commissioner of the Jhansi division, April, 1873, and of the Rohilkund division, Nov., 1873; on special duty at Agra during visit of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, Feb., 1876; officiating secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, May, 1876; commissioner, Meerut division, Jan., 1877; additional member, governor-general's council, Jan., 1877, to May, 1881; member, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1882; retired, April, 1885.
COLVIN, Clement S., Public Works Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College, and by private tuition in England and on the Continent; temporary clerk, 1863; junior clerk, military department, 1864; funds department, 1867; private secretary to secretary of state (the Duke of Argyll), 1873-74; private secretary to permanent under secretary of state, 1874-77, and accompanied Sir Louis Mallet on his deputation to India, in 1875-76; senior clerk, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, 1877; resident clerk, 1877 to 1885; public works department, 1877; government director of Madras irrigation and canal company, 1880-82; assistant secretary in the public works, railway and telegraph department, Sept., 1882; assistant government director of Indian railway companies, 1882; secretary, public works department, March, 1892.

COLVIN, Elliot Graham, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 4th Jan., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1883; transferred to Assam as personal assistant to chief commissioner, May, 1884; acting assistant secretary to chief commissioner, June, 1884; assistant political agent, Rajputana, Sept., 1886; political assistant, 3rd class, May, 1888; private secretary to lieutenant governor of Bengal, April, 1887; 1st assistant to governor general's agent in Beluchistan, and political assistant, 2nd class, April, 1889; served under financial department of government of India from June, 1890; officiating postmaster-general, Bengal, July, 1890; joint magistrate and deputy collector, May, 1891.

COLVIN, John Russell Colquhoun, Captain, I.S.C.—Joined the service, 13th Aug., 1879, as lieutenant, 76th Foot, and served under the military department to August, 1886, when he was appointed assistant to the agent in Rajputana; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, N.W.P. and Oudh, Nov., 1887; governor to H.H. the Nawab of Rampur, April, 1889.

COMINS, Denis Wood Deane, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Bengal Jail Department.—Joined the service, 22nd Oct., 1881, and served on general and jail duty, and as officiating first resident surgeon, medical college hospital, Calcutta; officiated as protector of emigrants, Calcutta, Sept., 1888, and was confirmed, Jan., 1889; from Jan., 1891, served under the government of India, finance and commerce department; appointed inspector-general of jails, Bengal, March, 1892.

CONDOR, James, late Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Sept., 1870; executive engineer, Neemuch railway, Oct., 1873; Punjab northern state railway, 1874; personal assistant to engineer-in-chief, Punjab northern railway, June, 1875; provisional assistant director of state railways, western system, 1877; traffic superintendent, Indus Valley state railway, in 2nd class of the state railway revenue establishment, May, 1878; officiating manager, southern section, Western Rajputana railway, Aug., 1879; manager, Holkar, Sindia-Neemuch, and Neemuch-Nusserabad railways, Feb., 1881; officiating manager, Nagpur-Chhattisgarh and Wardha coal railways, Nov., 1883; traffic superintendent, Rajputana-Malwa railways, Sept., 1884; class I., grade 3, revenue establishment, April, 1887; retired, 1890.

CONDON, James Hunt, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon, late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, Feb., 1859; arrived in India, 25th July, 1859; served under the military department till Oct., 1861, when he was appointed civil assistant surgeon in Oudh; from April, 1868, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was promoted to surgeon, Feb., 1871, and surgeon-major, July, 1873; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Cawnpore, March, 1871; brigade surgeon, Oct., 1886; retired, March, 1891.

CONINGHAM, Henry Evelyn, Major-General, I.S.C., late Police Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 18th March, 1855; served in the Madras police department from Dec., 1861, as assistant superintendent and superintendent, and acted as deputy inspector-general, Sept., 1883, to May, 1884; 1st grade superintendent, Nov., 1884; retired, Feb., 1886.

CONNAUGHT AND STRATHEARN, Duke of, H.R.H. Arthur William Patrick Albert, K.G., K.T., K.P., G.C.S.I., G.C.M.G., G.C.I.E., C.B.—Commander-in-chief, and 2nd member of council, Bombay, 14th December, 1886, to March, 1890.

CONNEMARA (Baron), Right Hon. Robert Bourke, G.C.I.E.—Educated at Enniskillen Royal School and at Trinity College, Dublin; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, Nov., 1852; M.P. for Lynn Regis from Dec., 1868; parliamentary under secretary of state for foreign affairs, Feb., 1874, to April, 1880; a royal commissioner on the laws relating to copyright, Oct., 1875; privy councillor, April, 1880; again parliamentary under secretary for foreign affairs, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886; appointed governor of Madras, Sept., 1886; took his seat as governor, 7th Dec., 1886; created a peer, 12th May, 1887; resigned, 1st Dec., 1890.

CONNOLLY, John Francis, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Belvedere College, Dublin, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 6th November, 1890, and served as assistant commissioner in the Punjab.

CONNOLLY, Edward Robert, Colonel, I.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 9th April, 1888; from Sept., 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; on special duty as assistant to Major Cavagnari, Feb., 1879, and again at Khyber, Feb., 1880; judicial assistant, 2nd grade, Sept., 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Bannu, Nov., 1884; also district judge; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Feb., 1887; retired, Aug., 1890.

CONSTABLE, Edwin Theobald, M.A., late Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as mathematical professor, Bareilly College, 25th Feb., 1862; inspector of public instruction, 1st circle, Aug., 1870; inspector of schools, Meerut division, Dec., 1877; Benares division, Dec., 1882; officiating director of public instruction, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Feb., 1883; 1st grade of education officers, April, 1883; inspector of schools, Meerut, and inspector of European schools, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Sept., 1884; officiating director of public instruction, April, 1890; retired, Sept., 1891.
CONWAY-GORDON, LEWIS, C.I.E., Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, 1857; joined the public works department, May, 1862, and served in the Punjab; assistant principal, Roorkee College, 1865; assistant consulting engineer, railway department, and examiner of accounts, Punjab, Oct., 1866; deputy consulting engineer and assistant secretary, railway branch, Punjab, Oct., 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, Punjab, Sept., 1870; deputy consulting engineer to government of India for guaranteed railways, 1871; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, April, 1872; officiating superintending engineer, Indus Valley railway, March, 1874; controller of accounts, Madras, 1875 to 1879; 1st class examiner, Jan., 1879; officiating manager, Indus Valley railway, April, 1881; deputy accountant-general, public works department, and ex officio under secretary to government of India, Sept., 1881; acted as accountant-general and deputy-secretary, May to Aug., 1883; deputed on special duty to England in 1884, to give evidence before the select committee of the House of Commons on railways in India; temporarily manager, Eastern Bengal state railway, 1884; manager, North-Western railway, Jan., 1886; director, North-Western railway, March, 1887; director-general of railways and deputy secretary to government of India, public works department, May, 1887; retired, May, 1892.

CONYBEARE, HENRY CRAWFORD ARTHUR, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Westminster School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty for preparation of provincial gazetteer, July, 1877; joint magistrate, Jan., 1885; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1890; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1891; author of 'An Account of Pargana Dudhi, in South Mirzapur,' and of contributions to the provincial Gazetteer.

COOK, HENRY, Surgeon-Colonel, M.D., late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 31st March, 1865; arrived in India, 31st Aug., 1865, and served as civil surgeon at various stations, superintendent of vaccination, and superintendent of jail; acted as second surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and professor of anatomy and curator of museum at the Grant Medical College, 1879-80, and as senior surgeon and professor of surgery 1881-82; civil surgeon, Dharwar, Dec., 1881; civil surgeon, Poona, with medical charge of the Deccan College and College of Science, and superintendent of lunatic asylum, April, 1883; also superintendent and teacher of medicine and therapeutics at the medical school; acted as deputy sanitary commissioner, Oct., 1884; brigade-surgeon, April, 1887; deputy-surgeon-general, Sept., 1890; reverted to military department, 1891.

COOK, HENRY, M.D., F.R.C.P., F.G.S., F.M.S., Surgeon-General, late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 24th Jan., 1855; arrived in India, 28th July, 1855, and served under the military department up to 1859, also holding the civil surgeoncy of Karachi in 1856; served with the Persian expeditionary force in 1857 (medal); appointed medical officer to political agency, Khelat, April, 1859; and accompanied H.H. the Khan of Khelat and Sir H. Green on a military expedition into Mekran; from April, 1861, served as civil surgeon in Ahmednagar and Satara, and as superintendent of Mahabaleshwar, and assistant collector and magistrate at that station; scientific officer, Abyssinian field force, Dec., 1867 (medal); from June, 1871, served in Bombay as acting 2nd physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and acting professor of physiology and of hygiene at the Grant Medical College, and was confirmed in these appointments, May, 1873; 1st physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, principal and professor of medicine and hygiene, Grant Medical College, Sept., 1876; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879; deputy surgeon-general, June, 1884; retired, Nov., 1886; author of various papers published in the transactions of the Medical and Physical Society of Bombay, on the geology, topography, and meteorology of different portions of Baluchistan, and on other scientific and medical subjects, also of various reports on similar subjects published by order of government, and of a paper read before the British Association on the registration of atmospheric ozone in Bombay, with reference to epidemic cholera, 1869.

COOK, HENRY DAVID, M.B., C.M., Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Madras Medical Department.—Joined the service as assistant surgeon, 1st April, 1870; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1870, and served on military, general and jail duty; surgeon-major, April, 1882; surgeon 1st district, and medical inspector of emigrants, Madras, May, 1888.

COOKE, CRAWFORD BOYD, Lieut.-Colonel, I.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission as ensign, March, 1864; served under the military department up to Dec., 1868, and subsequently as assistant commissioner in Burma; acted as assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Jan., 1871 to Feb., 1874; from Feb., 1874, to May, 1877, served as political agent at Bhamo, Upper Burma, and from May, 1879, to Jan., 1884, as cantonment magistrate in Nowgong, Bundelcund; from Jan., 1884, served as deputy commissioner and officiating commissioner in Burma, and was appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Dec., 1885; commissioner, Oct., 1890; author of the 'British Burma Manual.'

COOKE, FREDERICK JAMES, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Bath College and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1886, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; transferred temporarily to Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, Nov., 1891.

COOKE, G. H., Survey of India.—Joined the survey department, 6th Dec., 1866, and was appointed assistant superintendent, May, 1871; in 1871-2, served with the Lushai expeditionary force (medal); on special duty, Chittagong, Nov., 1872; served in various districts, and at head-quarters, Calcutta, and was appointed deputy superintendent, 4th grade, Oct., 1885, and 3rd grade, Aug., 1889.

COOKE, HENRY GIRAUD, Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1869; served in Bengal as
assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1881; magistrate and collector, June, 1886.

COOKE, HENRY READE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; compiler of general administration report of the Bombay Presidency for 1879-80; first assistant collector, June, 1885; junior collector and magistrate, Dec., 1890.

COOKE, JOHN EDWARD, Financial Department, Government of India.—From Oct., 1863, to April, 1868, served as assistant secretary to the government of India in the financial department; officiated as deputy accountant-general, first in Bengal and then in Hyderabad, and as accountant-general in Bengal, 1868-69; deputy accountant-general, Central Provinces, Aug., 1870, and in Madras, Jan., 1874; officiating accountant-general, Madras, Aug.-Oct., 1874; assistant comptroller-general, May, 1875; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Oct., 1878, to July, 1883, and officiated as accountant-general in 1880, 1882, and 1883; deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, July, 1883; acted as accountant general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, in 1884; deputy auditor-general, Dec., 1885; comptroller of Indian treasuries, April, 1886; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Nov., 1886, and again, June, 1888; officiating deputy auditor-general, in 1887, 1888, and 1890.

COOKE, SAMUEL, M.A., F.I.C., F.G.S., A.M.I.C.E., Educational Department, Bombay.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1868, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of chemistry and geology at the Engineering College, Poona, and also acted as principal of the college for various periods; promoted to 3rd grade of the education department, June, 1875; and grade, Dec., 1890.

COOKE, THEODORE, C.I.E., M.A., M.I., LL.D., Educational Department, Bombay.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; arrived in India, Nov., 1860; from June, 1865, served in the Bombay educational department as principal of the Civil Engineering College, Poona, and also officiated as lecturer on chemistry and geology; 1st grade of the educational department, March, 1883; acting director of public instruction in 1884, 1889, and from April, 1892; also as director of land records and agriculture in 1891.

COOPER, CHARLES PHILIP, Barrister-at-Law, Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 28th Jan., 1863; served from June, 1864, as examiner of the insolvent debtors court, Bombay; also acted as master and registrar in equity, commissioner for taking accounts, and taxing officer in the high court; police magistrate, Bombay, from Oct., 1871; acting first judge of the small cause court, Sept., 1873; senior magistrate of police and revenue judge, Bombay, June, 1874; chief presidency magistrate and revenue judge, Bombay, June, 1878.

COOPER, H. A., B.A., Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, accountant-general's department, 3rd June, 1880; junior examiner, audit department, Nov., 1881; graduated B.A., London University, 1887.

COPESTON, FREDERICK SELWYN, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 23rd October, 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Burma, as assistant commissioner, Sept., 1874; on special duty in Rangoon, Nov., 1879; on forest demarcation duty, Toungoo, Jan., 1880; deputy superintendent of census, Sept., 1880; judge under the Land Acquisition Act, March, 1881; officiating deputy commissioner, Dec., 1881; commissioner of excise and stamps, March, 1885; additional sessions judge, Tenasserim and Pegu, March, 1886; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1887; commissioner, Dec., 1890.

CORBETT, FRANK VINCENT, Lieut.-Colonel, R.F., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1866; assistant engineer, Feb., 1877; served on canal duty, and was appointed executive engineer, March, 1877; employed chiefly on the Betwa Canal; 3rd superintending engineer, Dec., 1889; 2nd class, Oct., 1890; 1st class, March, 1892.

CORDERY, JOHN GRAHAM, M.A., C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 22nd Oct., 1856; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and officiating small cause court judge; from Oct., 1864, to Sept., 1868, served in the Hyderabad Assigned Districts as deputy commissioner and assistant resident; officiating director of public instruction, Punjab, Jan., 1872, to May, 1873; deputy commissioner, 1st class, March, 1877; officiating secretary to government of Punjab, April-Aug., 1878; commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, April, 1879; also acted as political agent and superintendent, Bahawalpur State, May-Nov., 1879; commissioner, Peshawur, April, 1881; resident, Hyderabad, April, 1883; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; retired, July, 1888.

CORNISH, ROBERT, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Lancing College, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine relief duty, 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1882; magistrate and collector, Dec., 1887.

CORNISH, WILLIAM HENRY, Bengal Police Department.—Joined the service, 21st Jan., 1859; served in the military department to May, 1863, when he joined the police department as assistant superintendent; district superintendent, April, 1870; 1st grade, Oct., 1890; served in Assam, 1870-74, and 1879-83.

CORNISH, WILLIAM ROBERT, Surgeon-General, F.R.C.S., C.I.E., late Madras Medical Service.—Studied at St. George's Hospital (scholar and prizeman); appointed to the Madras medical service, April, 1854; arrived in India, and July, 1854; served under the military department, and also as civil surgeon of Coimbatore, 1857-58; secretary to the director general of the medical department, Oct., 1858, to Feb., 1870; consulting physician to the Irrigation
Canal Company, April, 1860; on special duty at Calcutta as Madras member and secretary to the commission for the reorganization of medical establishments, Nov., 1865, to April, 1866; secretary of Madras medical fund, 1864-70; on special duty for revision of medical code of regulations, 1869-70; sanitary commissioner, Madras, March, 1870, to April, 1880; member of committee for review of general hospital establishments, 1873-74; on special duty as member of the cinchona alkaloid commission in 1874 and 1879; during the famine of 1876-78, was specially engaged in organising a system of sanitary and medical inspection; surgeon-major, April, 1874; was superintendent of Madras census, and proceeded on special duty to Calcutta as member of census committee, Jan.-Feb., 1878; brigade-surgeon, Nov., 1879; appointed C.I.E., Jan., 1880; deputy surgeon-general, April, 1880; surgeon-general with the government of Madras, 1880 to 1885; was member of a commission to draw up a code for famine relief, and member and president of a committee on local government; additional member of council, Madras, for making laws and regulations, Dec., 1883; retired from the service, April, 1885; was appointed fellow of Madras University, Feb., 1867, and president of the medical faculty, 1880-85; hon. physician to the Queen; author of various contributions to the medical press, of sanitary reports to government, and the Madras census report, 1873; was for some time editor of the 'Madras Quarterly Journal of Medical Science.'

CORNWALL, WILLIAM WOLFRAN GARDNER, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1861; from Dec., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating superintendent of Dehra Dun, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and assistant settlement officer; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Fatchpur, March, 1881; and afterwards at Farukhabad; retired, Aug., 1887.

COSTELLO, CHARLES PETER, F.R.C.S., Surg.-Col., Bengal Medical Department (Assam).—Joined the service as assistant surgeon, 10th Feb., 1859; served with the 6th Punjab infantry in the Umbeyla campaign, 1863-4 (medal and clasp); and in the Jowaki expedition, 1877-8 (clasp); served also in the Afghan war, 1878-80, with the Koorum field force, and the Khyber line force (medal); sanitary commissioner, Assam, Sept., 1888; deputy surgeon-general, Jan., 1889.

COTGRAVE, THOMAS MANSON, Salt Department, Bombay.—Joined the service as acting assistant commissioner of customs, salt and opium, 30th Jan., 1866; opium inspector, Bombay, May, 1866; confirmed as assistant commissioner, July, 1867; assistant collector, salt revenue, Feb., 1874; deputy collector of salt revenue, April, 1890.

COTTON, SIR ARTHUR THOMAS, General, Kt., K.C.S.I., R.E.—Joined Addiscombe, 1818; arrived in Madras, Sept., 1821, as 2nd lieutenant of engineers; assistant to superintending engineer, tank department, May, 1822; served with the Burmese expedition, 1824-26; from June, 1826, served as superintending engineer in the tank department, and in 1828 was appointed to the charge of the Cauvery irrigation, being also employed in the survey and improvement of the Paumber pass; in 1844 was appointed to the northern division of the tank department, and was employed in carrying out the systematic irrigation of the Godavari delta; promoted to chief engineer, 1852; in 1858 was ordered to Cuttack, and planned works for the irrigation of the Mahanadi delta, and was afterwards employed under the government of Bengal, reporting upon the water communication between the Ganges and Calcutta; resigned government service in 1862; in 1863, was employed under the Madras irrigation company, reporting on their works, and also inspecting the Ganges canal works, and proposed additional works, which were afterwards carried out as the Lower Ganges Canal; also projected works for the Sone irrigation, which have since been partially executed; general, 1876; retired from the army in 1877.

COTTON, HENRY JOHN STEEDMAN, C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Magdalen College School, Brighton College, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1865; arrived, 29th Oct., 1867; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial department, and was appointed officiating small cause court judge, Sealdah, March, 1872; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, June, 1873; officiating registrar, high court, Dec., 1873; assistant secretary, government of Bengal, June, 1875; junior secretary, government of Bengal, April, 1876; magistrate and collector, 3rd grade, Nov., 1878; officiating commissioner, Chittagong, Sept., 1879, and again, April, 1884; secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1882; officiating commissioner of police, Calcutta, and chairman of the corporation of the town of Calcutta, April, 1887; port commissioner, Calcutta, May, 1887; secretary to government of Bengal, financial and municipal departments, May, 1890; acting chief secretary, Dec., 1891; member of lieut.-governor's council, June, 1892; author of a 'Memorandum on the Revenue History of Chittagong,' 1880, 'Memorandum on the Land Tenures of Bengal,' 1884, 'England and India,' 1883, and 'New India, or India in Transition.'

COUCH, RIGHT HON. SIR RICHARD, Knt.—Recorder of Bedford, 1858 to 1862; judge of the high court of judicature at Bombay, 1862-66; chief justice, Bombay, 1866-70; chief justice of Bengal, March, 1870, to April, 1875, and was president of the commission appointed to inquire into the charges made against the Gaekwar of Baroda, Feb., 1875; made a privy councillor, and sworn in, 27th Nov., 1875; a member of the judicial committee, Jan., 1881.

COUCHE, T. B., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 22nd Jan., 1875.

COUPER, SIR GEORGE E. W., Bart., K.C.S.I., C.B., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sandhurst, and served in H.M.'s 15th regiment for two years before joining the East India College, Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1846; served in Bengal and the Punjab in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; under secretary, government of India, home and finance department, 1853; under secretary, government of
India, foreign department, 1854; secretary to chief commissioner of Oudh, 1855; served through the siege of Lucknow, and was present at several engagements during the mutiny as aide-de-camp to Sir H. Lawrence and Sir John Inglis, and afterwards to Sir James Outram; commissioner in Oudh, 1858; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1859; judicial commissioner of Oudh, 1863; chief commissioner of Oudh, 1874; lieutenant-governor of N.W. Provinces, 1876, as well as chief commissioner of Oudh; retired 1882.

COURTENAY, ROBERT, B.A., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1874; served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; compiler of the 'General Administration Report of the Bombay Presidency for 1883-84'; acted as assistant judge, first grade, at intervals from Dec., 1885; retired, Sept., 1890.

COURTNEY, DAVID C., Lieut.-Col., R.E., Store Department, India Office.—Entered the Royal Engineers, 17th April, 1866; served in the South African war, 1879; present at the battle of Ineyazane, defence of Etshowe and advance on Ulundi (medal with clasp); assistant-inspector of works, Royal Arsenal, Woolwich, 1880-83; served in the Soudan expedition of 1884-85, and was present at the action of Kirbekan (brevet of major, medal with two clasps, bronze star); retired from army, November, 1887; appointed assistant superintendent of the India store depot, 1st April, 1887.

COWAN, SAMUEL HUNTER, Colonel, I.S.C., late Survey of India.—First commission, lieutenant R.A., 9th Dec., 1859; arrived in India, 9th April, 1860; served in the military department, and on the 19th Jan., 1867, was admitted to the staff corps; assistant superintendent, survey department, Bengal, 10th Jan., 1867; held charge of the Cachar survey, Nov., 1878, to Nov., 1879; and of the Hooghly River survey, April, 1882, to July, 1883; deputy superintendent, April, 1883; 3rd grade, July, 1888; 2nd grade, March, 1891; retired, Oct., 1891.

COWIE, DONALD WILLIAM GARDEN, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in Madras, 30th Nov., 1886, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate; acting deputy registrar, high court (appellate side), May, 1891; acting assistant secretary, judicial and legislative departments, May, 1892.

COWIE, HENRY GEORGE, B.A., Financial Department, Government of India.—From Nov., 1868, to April, 1876, served in the grades of assistant accountant-general and assistant comptroller-general, and as assistant commissioner of paper currency, in the N.W. Provinces, and at Calcutta; from April, 1876, to March, 1883, served in the Central Provinces as deputy accountant-general and deputy commissioner paper currency; comptroller, Assam, March, 1883; class 3 of the financial department, Sept., 1883; deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1887, and officiating accountant-general, Aug. and Nov., 1887, and May, 1888; deputy accountant general, Madras, Jan., 1890.

COWIE, THOMAS RENNY, Colonel, I.S.C., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, 12th Aug., 1860; employed under the military department till Aug., 1869, from which date he served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, sub-judge, and deputy commissioner; cantonment magistrate, 1st class, Allahabad, Feb., 1881, and subsequently at Cawnpore, 1886; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Oct., 1888; district and sessions judge, April, 1891.

COWLEY, FRANCIS WILLIAM RICE, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived 2nd Dec., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; services placed at the disposal of the public works department, March, 1873; deputy commissioner, wards' estate, Patna, June, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Feb., 1878; from April, 1879, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge; officiating judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpore, May, 1886, and again in Aug., 1887; confirmed, Sept., 1887.

COX, ARTHUR FREDERICK, Madras C.S.—Educated at King's College School and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1871, and served in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty in connection with visit of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, Nov., 1875; from Sept., 1882, served in the financial department, and was appointed officiating assistant accountant-general, first in Madras and afterwards in Bombay; assistant comptroller-general, 3rd class, July, 1883; deputy accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1885; officiating accountant-general, Bombay, and commissioner of state paper currency, May, 1886; sub-collector and magistrate, Nov., 1887; and acting district and sessions judge, Oct., 1887; confirmed as district and sessions judge, April, 1889; employed under Government of India, in financial department, May, 1889, as acting accountant-general, Bombay; confirmed, Oct., 1889; compiled 'The North Arcot District Manual.'

COX, HARRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Olave's Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1877; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Oct., 1889; has also acted as district and sessions judge.

COX, HENRY WILLIAM HOLMES, Colonel, I.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras Infantry, Nov., 1857; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1857; served in the Madras police from April, 1861, and was promoted to superintendent, April, 1873; assistant inspector-general, Dec., 1881; acting commissioner of police, Madras city, September, 1883; presidency magistrate, Oct., 1883; political officer in charge of ex-King Theebaw of Burma, Dec., 1885, to April, 1886; deputy inspector-general
of police, Aug., 1886; acted as inspector general in 1890; commissioner of police, Madras city, Dec., 1891.

COX, JOHN HUGH, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Clifton College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived, 21st Nov., 1890; and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

COXE, HENRY REYNELL HOLLED, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1884; and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Burma, Nov., 1887, as assistant commissioner; under secretary to chief commissioner, Nov., 1888; resumed appointment in Bengal, April, 1891.

CRADDOCK, REGINALD HENRY, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Reading Grammar School, Wellington College, and Keble College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1884; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Central Provinces, Dec., 1884; assistant to commissioner of settlements and agriculture, Dec., 1888; assistant commissioner, Nagpur, Sept., 1889; also settlement officer, Nov., 1890.

CRAIG, JAMES, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed assistant engineer, 19th July, 1866; executive engineer, Sept., 1872; officiating superintending engineer and secretary to the agents to the governor-general for Rajputana and Central India, April-Oct., 1891; officiating superintending engineer and secretary to the agent for Baluchistan, April, 1892; superintending engineer, 3rd class, June, 1892; and class, June, 1892.

CRANBROOK (EARL OF), Rt. Hon. Gathorne Gathorne-Hardy, G.C.S.I.—Born 1st Oct., 1814; educated at Shrewsbury School, and at Oriel College, Oxford (B.A. in 1836, 2nd class in classics); called to the bar at the Inner Temple in 1840, and practised as a barrister for several years; contested Bradford unsuccessfully 1847; sat in the House of Commons for Leominster from 1856 to 1865, when he was returned for Oxford; under secretary of state for the home department, 1858; president of the poor law board, July, 1866; secretary of state for the home department, May, 1867, to Dec., 1868; secretary of state for war, Feb., 1874; raised to the house of peers as Viscount Cranbrook, May, 1878; secretary of state for India, March, 1878, to May, 1880; lord president of council, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886, and again, Aug., 1886; created Earl of Cranbrook and Baron Medway, Sept., 1892.

CRASTER, GEORGE AYTON, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 11th Dec., 1849; served under the military department till 1853; from Nov., 1853, served as assistant and executive engineer in Assam, Oudh, and the Punjab; promoted to executive engineer, 1st grade, April, 1865; transferred to N.W. Provinces as officiating superintending engineer, March, 1869; officiating superintending engineer and deputy secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, public works department, April, 1872; superintending engineer, 3rd class, April, 1872; promoted to 1st class, March, 1881; retired, 1886.

CRAWFORD, CHARLES EDWARD GORDON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant political agent, railway magistrate, and cantonment magistrate; also acted as district superintendent of police, Aug.–Oct., 1878; from Jan., 1879, acted in the judicial department as assistant judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; 2nd grade assistant judge, Aug., 1883; also acted as judge and sessions judge in various districts, and as judicial assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, Feb.–May, 1885; registrar, high court, Bombay, September, 1885; acting judge and sessions judge, Thana, May, 1890; on special duty in political department, June, 1892.

CRAWFORD, JAMES ADAIR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 17th Sept., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Feb., 1881, served in the political department, and acted as assistant to the governor-general's agent for Rajputana, boundary settlement officer in Meywar, and assistant to the resident at Hyderabad (June, 1881); attache, foreign department of government of India, May, 1882; in charge of office of press commissioner, June, 1882, to Nov., 1883; acting political agent, 3rd class, and assistant commissioner, Ajmere, April, 1884; assistant secretary, foreign department, Jan., 1885; political agent, Quetta and Pishin, Nov., 1885, to March, 1886; junior under secretary to government, foreign department, March, 1888; political agent, 2nd class, and acting first assistant and secretary for Berar to resident at Hyderabad, May, 1890; under-secretary to government of India, foreign department, April, 1892.

CRAWFORD, JOHN THOMSON, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Perth Academy, Edinburgh University, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1864; from Feb., 1865, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; subordinate judge, 1st grade, Aug., 1879; from Nov., 1880, served as district judge, 3rd grade, Fyzabad, and from Jan., 1882, as deputy commissioner; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Unao, March, 1885.

CRAWFORD, RICHMOND IRVINE, Colonel, I.S.C., Sind Commission.—1st commission, Oct., 1857; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1857; served in the pursuit of the Gwalior rebels in 1858 (medal and clasp for Central India); from September, 1864, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, and (from April, 1867) as superintendent of police; from May, 1873, acted as political superintendent of Thar and Parkar, and was confirmed in this appointment, May, 1875; deputy commissioner, Thar and Parkar, Aug., 1881; collector and magistrate, Shikarpur, June, 1885; and subsequently at Karachi; has acted as commissioner in Sind.
CRAWFURD, JAMES, B.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Collegiate School and University of Glasgow, and Dublin University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1868; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1869; officiating under secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1875; under secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1876; first inspector of registration offices, Dec., 1877; registrar, high court, Nov., 1878; district and sessions judge, March, 1885.

CRAWLEY, CHARLES EDWARD, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the department, and was attached to the accountant general's office, Bombay, 25th Feb., 1874; acted as assistant accountant general, Madras, May, 1877 to Jan., 1878; assistant commissioner paper currency, Bombay, March, 1878; acted as deputy comptroller general, Calcutta, Aug., 1883, and comptroller, Central Provinces, April, 1884; assistant accountant general, Calcutta, Oct., 1883; Bombay, Aug., 1884; officiated as deputy accountant-general, Punjab, Jan., 1888; assistant comptroller, India Treasuries, Jan., 1889; assistant accountant-general and examiner of local accounts, Bengal, March, 1889; officiating comptroller, Burma, March, 1892.

CRAWLEY-BOEVEY, ARTHUR WILLIAM, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, special assistant to political agent, and acting political agent in Rewa Kantha; from May, 1873, to Dec., 1874, served in Baroda as acting assistant resident, and performed the duties of the cantonment and railway magistrate, and small cause court judge, May-Nov., 1873; in special charge of Sachin state, Dec., 1874; on special duty at Baroda, Feb., 1875; on famine duty at Kaladgi, Aug., 1877; talukdari settlement officer, Gujerat, June, 1879; pro tem. special officer for the settlement of claims to giras and watsans in Baroda territory, April, 1883, and again April, 1885; acting chief presidency magistrate and revenue judge, Bombay, May, 1887; junior collector and magistrate, May, 1889; senior collector and magistrate, Nov., 1891.

CREGEEN, ARCHIBALD CRELLIN, M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1859, as assistant engineer, Central Provinces; transferred to Punjab, Feb., 1861; executive engineer, April, 1866; railway department, Central India, Holkar state railway, Oct., 1870; engineer-in-chief, provincial light railway survey extensions, Lucknow, June, 1878; Neemuch-Naseerabad survey, Nov., 1878; engineer-in-chief, Western Rajputana state railway, Aug., 1879; engineer-in-chief, Vizagapatam-Raipur railway survey, Oct., 1882; member of committee on reorganisation of public works department, Sept., 1883; engineer-in-chief, construction establishment, Nagpur-Bengal railway, Oct., 1884; superintending engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1885; agent and chief engineer, Indian Midland railway, Feb., 1886; retired, Feb., 1888.

CRESSWELL, CHARLES ARTHUR, Lieut.-Col., I.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission, royal artillery, Jan., 1866; arrived in Madras, 12th Jan., 1867; joined the Burma commission, Feb., 1871, as officiating assistant commissioner and cantonment magistrate at Toungoo; personal assistant to chief commissioner, Dec., 1875; boundary officer, Sandoway, March, 1881; president, Sandoway Town committee, April, 1884; deputy commissioner, March, 1885.

CROFT, SIR ALFRED WOODLEY, K.C.I.E., M.A., Educational Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the secretary of state, 8th Dec., 1865; served as professor, Presidency College, principal, Dacca College, inspector of schools, and officiating principal, Presidency College, and officiating registrar, Calcutta University, and was promoted to 2nd class of the educational service, Feb., 1877; director of public instruction, Aug., 1878; president of the commission to draw up a code for European schools, Oct., 1881; on special duty with the government of India, as member of the education commission, Jan., 1883; C.I.E., May, 1884; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887; member of the legislative council of Bengal, Feb., 1887; on special duty with the Government of India for the preparation of a report on education in British India, May–Sept., 1887; is also fellow, member of the syndicate and president of the Faculty of Arts of Calcutta University.

CROFTON, JAMES, Lieutenant-General, late R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 9th Dec., 1844; joined the public works department, Nov., 1847; assistant engineer, Punjab circle, Dec., 1849; superintendent, 1st division, Bari Doab canal, July, 1854; executive engineer, Punjab irrigation, 1858; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Jan., 1862; superintendent, Sutlej canal surveys; officiating superintendent, Eastern Jumna canals, 1863; chief engineer, irrigation, and under secretary to government, Punjab, Sept., 1864; chief engineer, 1st class, April, 1872; inspector-general of irrigation and deputy secretary to government of India, public works department, April, 1874, to Jan., 1882, when he resigned the service.

CROLE, CHARLES STEWART, Madras C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh High School and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, 9th Dec., 1863; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acted as sub-secretary, board of revenue, July–Sept., 1869, and as collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants in 1879–80; acting commissioner of salt revenue, Madras, Jan.–March, 1880; district and sessions judge, Kistna, June, 1881; collector and magistrate, Nov., 1882, in the district of Kistna, and afterwards in the districts of Madura and Anantapur; district and sessions judge, North Malabar, Aug., 1886, and North Arcot, Jan., 1887; member of board of revenue, Dec., 1890; compiled the Chingleput District Manual.

CROMBIE, ALEXANDER, M.D., Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 30th March, 1872; officiating resident surgeon, Calcutta Medical College Hospital, Jan., 1873; professor of surgery, Medical College, in addition to his own duties, Oct., 1873; professor of materia medica, Sept., 1874; transferred to Burma, Feb., 1875, and appointed
junior civil surgeon, Rangoon, and health officer to the port; from April, 1877, served in Bengal as civil surgeon, also at Simla as joint medical officer, March, 1880, to Feb., 1882; civil surgeon, Dacca, with charge of the jail, March, 1882; also superintendent of the lunatic asylum, medical school and Mitford Hospital; surgeon-major, March, 1884; officiating surgeon superintendent, presidency general hospital, Calcutta, March, 1886; confirmed, June, 1889.

CROMER (Baron), Rt. Hon. EVELYN BARING, G.C.M.G., K.C.B., K.C.S.I., C.I.E.—Lieutenant, R.A., June, 1878; captain in 1870, and major in 1876; A.D.C. to Sir Henry Storks, in Ionian Islands, in 1861, and secretary to him in 1865, during the enquiry into the outbreak in Jamaica; private secretary to the governor-general of India (the Earl of Northbrook), 1872 to 1876; commissioner of the Egyptian public debt, 1877-9; comptroller-general in Egypt, Sept., 1879; financial member of council of governor-general of India, June, 1880; agent and consul-general in Egypt, and a minister plenipotentiary in the diplomatic service, Aug., 1883; financial assistant at the conference in London, on Egyptian finance, June to Aug., 1884; has 1st class of Medjidie.

CRONIN, JOHN JOSEPH, Captain, I.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission, Aug., 1880; assistant commissioner, July, 1886.

CROOKE, WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Erasmus Smith’s Grammar School, Tipperary, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Dec., 1886; deputy commissioner, July, 1886; magistrate and collector, Feb., 1890; author of a rural and agricultural glossary for the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, an ‘Ethnographical Handbook for the N.W. Provinces and Oudh,’ and ‘Gazetteer of Jalesar.’

CROSS (Viscount), Rt. Hon. RICHARD ASHETON CROSS, G.C.B., G.C.S.I.—Born 30th May, 1823; educated at Rugby School, and at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he graduated B.A. in 1846; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1849, and for several years went the northern circuit; represented Preston in the House of Commons, March, 1857, to March, 1862, and S.W. Lancashire from Dec., 1868; secretary of state for the home department, Feb., 1874, to 1880; bencher of the Inner Temple, 1876; hon. LL.D. of Cambridge, Oct., 1878; G.C.B. in 1880; again secretary of state for the home department, June, 1885; and was appointed president of the royal commission on the Education Acts; in Lord Salisbury’s second administration, Aug., 1886, was appointed secretary of state for India, and raised to the peerage under the title of Viscount Cross; G.C.S.I., Aug., 1892; was formerly an ecclesiastical commissioner for England; is a deputy lieutenant for Lancashire, and late chairman of the Lancashire quarter sessions; author of two legal works—‘The Acts relating to the Settlement and Removal of the Poor, with Notices of Cases, Indices, and Forms,’ 1853; and ‘The General and Quarter Sessions of the Peace; their Jurisdiction and Practice in other than Criminal Matters’ (written in conjunction with Mr. H. Leaming), 1858, 2nd edition, 1876.

CROSTHWAIT, SIR CHARLES HAUKE TOP, K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at St. John’s College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857; from Nov., 1858, to March, 1877, served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector and settlement officer, and acted as secretary to the board of revenue for two years from March, 1875; from April, 1877, served in the Central Provinces as commissioner of the Nagpur and Jubbulpur divisions, and was appointed judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Aug., 1881, and additional member of the governor-general’s council for the purpose of making laws and regulations, Dec., 1881; acting chief commissioner, British Burma, March, 1883, to April, 1884; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Jan., 1885; member of the public service commission, Dec., 1886; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; chief commissioner of Burma, March, 1887; K.C.S.I., May, 1888; member of council of governor-general, Oct., 1890 to Feb., 1891, and again from April, 1892; appointed lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1892; author of ‘Notes on the N.W. Provinces’ and ‘Land Revenue Law.’

CROSTHWAIT, ROBERT JOSEPH, B.A., B.L., C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors’ School, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1863; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty on the revenue committee at Naini Tal, July, 1872; assistant superintendent, sub-judge, and registrar of Dehra Dun, Dec., 1873; small cause court judge, Allahabad, March, 1875; registrar of the high court, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1878; acting judicial commissioner, British Burma, Dec., 1878, to Feb., 1881; acting secretary to the government of India, legislative department, March to May, 1881; district and sessions judge, Allahabad, May, 1881; additional secretary to government of India, legislative department, Jan., 1883; acted as judicial commissioner of the Central Provinces in 1882 and 1883, and was confirmed in the appointment, Jan., 1885; member of viceroy’s legislative council, June, 1889; officiating chief commissioner, Central Provinces, July-Oct., 1889; resident and agent to the governor-general, Central India, Jan., 1891; C.S.I., May, 1890.

CROW, WILLIAM, Store Department, India Office.—Clerk under the inspector-general of railway stores, 23rd Oct., 1883.

CROWDY, JOHN HENRY, Lieut-Colonel, R.E., late Military Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1857; posted to Indian establishment, Sept., 1870; from Dec., 1870, served as executive engineer in the Punjab; transferred to military works, 1872, and served in the Punjab, the N.W. Provinces and Bengal; superintending engineer, 3rd class, March, 1886; retired, March, 1890.
CROWE, WILLIAM HENRY, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Godolphin Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, professor of mental and moral philosophy and logic at the Deccan College, Poona, acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan, and assistant judge and sessions judge; editor of the 'Bombay Gazetteer,' Oct., 1868; acting special judge under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, March, 1882; on special duty at Kathiawar, Nov., 1882; appointed and grade judge and session judge, Thana, Aug., 1883, and afterwards at Satara; 1st grade judge, Sept., 1885.

CROZIER, ROBERT G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College; temporary clerk, India Office, 30th Nov., 1865; junior clerk, Jan., 1867; senior clerk, March, 1887.

CRUICKSHANK, ALEXANDER, M.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen University and King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in various districts of Madras from Oct., 1863, as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, principal assistant collector, and acting district and sessions judge; collector and magistrate, South Arcot, special agent, French settlement, and political agent for Pondicherry, Sept., 1878; collector and magistrate, Anantapur, Nov., 1885; district and sessions judge, of Cuddapah, Jan., 1886, and of Kurnool, Aug., 1886; retired, Nov., 1887.

CRUICKSHANK, ALEXANDER WALMESLEY, B.L., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and officiating magistrate and collector; junior secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1878; under secretary to government, N.W.P., Sept., 1886; settlement officer, Oct., 1886; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1890; magistrate and collector, Nov., 1891.

CRUICKSHANK, JOHN, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., late Medical Department, Bombay.—Appointed to the Indian medical service, 20th Feb., 1856; arrived in India, 9th April, 1856; civil surgeon, Dharwar, Jan., 1865; from March, 1866, acted as surgeon to the governor of Bombay, also as private secretary, Oct., 1866; on special duty to Egypt as surgeon to Lord Mayo, Nov., 1868; superintendent of Mahabaleshwar, Dec., 1870; from April, 1871, served as inspector-general of prisons, Bombay, and was a member of the prisons conference at Calcutta, Jan., 1877; retired, April, 1887.

CRUICKSHANK, JOHN DONALDSON, Colonel, R.E., Bombay Public Works Department.—First commission, 9th Dec., 1850; probationary assistant engineer, July, 1862; executive engineer, Dec., 1865; on special duty, Karachi, in 1875-76; superintending engineer, Nov., 1891.

CRUMP, CHARLES GEORGE, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 21st Jan., 1884, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, N.W. Provinces; resigned, March, 1886.

CRUMP, HENRY ASHBROOKE, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1885; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Nov., 1885; assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Dec., 1889; 2nd class, Dec., 1891; 1st class, April, 1892.

CRUMP, LOUIS CHARLES, Bombay C.S.—Educated under private tuition and at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 10th Dec., 1890; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1891.

CULLEN, PETER, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieutenant-Colonel, M.D., late Medical Department, Central Provinces.—Joined the Bengal medical service, July, 1859; arrived in India, 24th Jan., 1860; was employed under the military department, including service in the China War; from Feb., 1862, served in the Central Provinces as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail; also superintendent of cotton affairs, May, 1865; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1877, and of brigade-surgeon, April, 1888; retired, June, 1892.

CUMINE, ALEXANDER, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Glenalmond; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1874, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting superintendent of police, railway magistrate, and acting junior collector and forest settlement officer; acting special assistant collector and settlement officer, Ratnagiri, Nov., 1884; and assistant collector, May, 1887; 1st assistant collector, Nov., 1890.

CUMING, JOSEPH HENRY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces and Oudh).—Educated at Westminster, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 3rd Dec., 1891, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

CUMMING, CHARLES LENNOX BRUCE, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India 29th Nov., 1867, and served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; principal assistant to collector, magistrate and agent, Ganjam, Nov., 1883; retired, March, 1888.

CUMMING, JOHN ARTHUR, Madras C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen Grammar School, and Aberdeen University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 16th Dec., 1887, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to magistrate and collector.

CUMMING, JOHN GHEST, Bengal C.S.—Educated at High School, Glasgow, and Glasgow University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived 3rd Nov., 1890, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.
CUMMING, WILLIAM GORDON, Colonel, R.E., C.I.E., India Public Works Department.—First commission, Madras engineers, 1860; arrived in India, 7th Oct., 1862; joined the public works department, Feb., 1864, as assistant engineer, Port Blair; executive engineer, April, 1866; transferred to Madras, Aug., 1868; Hyderabad, May, 1870; from Feb., 1874, served in British Burma; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, civil and military works branch, May, 1881; temporary superintending engineer, Rangoon, Jan., 1883; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Jan., 1884; officiating secretary to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, Oct., 1884; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, April, 1887; confirmed, May, 1888; chief engineer, 3rd class, May, 1888; 2nd class, March, 1892; C.I.E., Jan., 1893.

CUNNINGHAM, JAMES MACNABB, Surgeon general, M.D., C.S.I., late Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1851; superintendent of central prison, Bareilly, 1861, and subsequently at Meerut; officiating superintendent, government press, N.W. Provinces, 1863; surgeon, April, 1864; secretary to sanitary commissioner, 1866; professor of hygiene, Calcutta medical college, 1866; sanitary commissioner, Bengal, 1869; sanitary commissioner with the government of India, 1875; surgeon-general, March, 1880; retired, March, 1885.

CUNNINGHAM, WILLIAM JOHN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Clapham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Aug., 1873, served in Mysore as assistant commissioner on special duty at Bangalore and Chitaldrug, acting deputy commissioner, additional secretary in the famine department (Aug., 1878), and secretary to the chief commissioner, general department (Jan., 1879); political agent, assistant to the resident in Mysore, and secretary to the chief commissioner, Coorg, April, 1881; political agent, 3rd class, and assistant to the resident, Hyderabad, Dec., 1883; under secretary, government of India, foreign department, Sept., 1885; acting secretary, Nov., 1889; deputy secretary, May, 1890.

CUNNINGHAM, SIR ALEXANDER, Major-General, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., R.E.—Educated at Christ's Hospital, and Addiscombe; first commission, Bengal engineers, 1831; aide-de-camp to governor-general, 1834; sent specially to Cashmere, 1839; engineer to king of Oudh in 1840; served in the Gwalior campaign of 1843-44, and was present at the battle of Punnar (bronze star); from Feb., 1844, served as executive officer on the staff, Gwalior contingent; head of a mission to Thibet in 1846; engineer for laying down the boundaries of the N.W. frontier, Jan., 1847, to 1849; served in the Punjab campaign of 1848-49, including the battles of Chillianwallah and Goojerat (medal with two clasps, and brevet of major); executive engineer, Mooltan, Dec., 1852; chief engineer, Pegu and Tenasserim, Oct., 1856; chief engineer, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1858; also secretary to government; archaeological surveyor to government, 1861; retired June, 1862; C.S.I., May, 1871; C.I.E., Jan., 1878; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887; author of many articles on antiquarian subjects in the journal of the Bengal Asiatic Society, and other periodicals; 'The Bhilsa Topes, or Buddhist Monuments of Central India,' 1854; 'An Essay on the Aryan Order of Architecture,' 1846; 'Ladak: Physical, Statistical, and Historical,' 1854; 'Mahabodhi,' 1892; and official reports on the Antiquities of Northern Hindostan.

CUNNINGHAM, ALEXANDER FREDERICK DOUGLAS, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kensington Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab (civil department), Sept., 1878; on special duty as political assistant to Major Cavagnari for employment in Afghanistan, Nov., 1878; political officer, Khyber, Oct., 1879; 1st assistant to chief political officer, Afghanistan (Kabul), Feb., 1880; officiating secretary to government, April-May, 1881; officiating superintendent, Kapurthala state, Feb., 1884; under secretary to government, Punjab, Dec., 1884; officiated as deputy commissioner at Dera Ismail Khan, Feb., 1885, at Hazara, 1886, and at Bannu, April, 1887; on special duty at Rawul Pindi dindarbar, March, 1885; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1887; officiated as divisional judge, Jhelum, Aug., 1887, and deputy commissioner and district judge, Sept., 1887; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1888; on special duty, Feb.-June, 1891.

CUNNINGHAM, DAVID DOUGLAS, Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, M.B., F.R.S., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1st April, 1868; from 19th Dec., 1874, served as special assistant to the sanitary commissioner with the government of India; professor of physiology, Calcutta Medical College, from June, 1879; also acted as government quinologist, and was in charge of the cinchona plantations, Sept., 1879; officiating superintendent of botanical gardens, Aug., 1880; appointed to conduct special cholera inquiries in immediate connection with the sanitary commissioner with the government of India, Dec., 1884; on special duty as naturalist with the Tibet Mission, 1886; has also acted as special assistant to the sanitary commissioner with the government of India; honorary surgeon to H.E. the Viceroy; author of many medical and scientific treatises, the result of microscopical and physiological research in relation to cholera and other subjects.

CUNNINGHAM, Sir Henry S., K.C.I.E., late Calcutta High Court.—Advocate-general, high court, Madras, and additional member of the governor's council, 1872-77; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, Nov., 1877; member of the famine commission, May, 1878 to Jan., 1881; member of the finance committee, March, 1886; resigned his seat in the high court, Calcutta, July, 1888; K.C.I.E., Jan., 1889.

CURRIE, BERTRAM WODEHOUSE, Council of India.—Appointed to the council of the secretary of state for India, 11th Dec., 1880; and on the completion of his ten years of office in Dec., 1890, was re-appointed for a further term of five years; appointed a delegate to international monetary conference at Brussels, 1892.

CURRIE, FENDALL, B.L., Colonel, Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1858,
as cornet, 1st European light cavalry; assistant commissioner, Hazaribagh, Feb., 1863; from Sept., 1863, served in the Oudh commission, and was appointed small cause court judge, Sitapur, June, 1868, and junior secretary to chief commissioner, Nov., 1868; on special duty to collate laws and regulations in force in Oudh, May, 1869; on special duty for taking up lands for railway purposes, Oct., 1869; city magistrate, Lucknow, Feb., 1870; on special duty to review the Bara Banki forgery report, March, 1874; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1878; officiated as commissioner in the Rae Bareli division, Aug., 1882; and subsequently in the Fyzabad and Lucknow divisions; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Oct., 1883; commissioner, March, 1888; author of commentaries on The Penal Code, Act XLV. of 1866, The Indian Code of Criminal Procedure and The Oudh Rent Act, 'The Oudh Land Revenue Manual,' a Commentary on Act XXII. of 1886,' and the 'Indian Law Examination Manual.'

CURRIE, GEORGE MAINWARING, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 28th Oct., 1862; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1884, and 1st grade, Aug., 1887; retired, March, 1892.

CURSETJEE RUSTOMJEE, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, London; called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India 29th Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, April, 1886, and 1st grade, Oct., 1889; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1891.

CURTIS, GEORGE SEYMOUR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1888; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1889; in 1889-91 acted as assistant political resident, Aden.

CURTIS, J., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—2nd class clerk, 26th Aug., 1891.

CURZON, THE HON. GEORGE NATHANIEL, M.P.—Eldest son of Lord Scarsdale; educated at Eton and Balliol College, Oxford; B.A., 1882; Fellow of All Souls' College, 1883; M.A., 1884; private secretary to Lord Salisbury, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886; M.P. for the Southport Division of Lancashire, 1886, and again, 1892; under secretary of state for India, Nov., 1891 to Aug., 1892; author of 'Russia in Central Asia,' published in 1889, and of a work on 'Persia,' published in 1892.

CUSHING, THOMAS, Store Department, India Office.—Clerk to inspector of scientific instruments, store depot, Dec., 1867; inspector of scientific instruments, May, 1876.

CUTHBERTSON, CLIVE, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's, Adelaide, Glenalmond School, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived, 13th Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885; officiating under secretary to government of Bengal, March, 1888, and confirmed Nov., 1889; held that post until Nov., 1890; officiated as under secretary to the government of India, home department, in March, 1890.

CUTTLE, G., Store Department, India Office.—2nd class clerk, India store depot, 5th April, 1882.

DALLAS, A. M., Deputy Surgeon-General, C.I.E., late Medical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India and was appointed assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, June, 1856; superintendent, central jail, Oct., 1859; inspector-general of prisons, April, 1863; surgeon, Feb., 1868; special duty, Calcutta, Jan., 1877; brigade surgeon, Dec., 1882; deputy surgeon-general, and surgeon-general, Punjab, Sept., 1884; inspector-general of civil hospitals, Punjab, April, 1885; retired, March, 1889.

DALMAHOY, PATRICK CARFRAE, Colonel, Bengal Infantry, late Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign 1st Jan., 1857; adjutant of the Hamirpur district police, Oct., 1858, to Sept., 1860; commandant of the same, Oct., 1861; from Jan., 1862, served as district superintendent of police up to April, 1867, when he was appointed assistant inspector-general, government railway police; officiating commandant of the Mhairwara police battalion Sept., 1869, to April, 1871; deputy inspector-general, Oct., 1882 to 1885.

DALTON, GODFREY JOHN BECTIVE TUTTE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Columba's College, Rathfarnham, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived 12th Jan., 1864; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1876, and deputy commissioner, April, 1878; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1887.

DALY, SIR HENRY DOMINICK, General, G.C.B., C.I.E.—Ensign, first European regiment, Bombay, Dec., 1840; served in the Punjab campaign, 1848-49, and was present at the siege of Mooltan, the battle of Goojerat, and the pursuit and surrender of the Sikh army (medal and two clasps); served in the campaign on the N.W. Frontier, 1850-51, including the passage of the Kotah Pass, and the expedition against the hill tribes; during the Indian mutiny served at the siege of Delhi, the siege of Lucknow, in the campaign in Oude, the action at Nawabganj, the passages of the Goomtee, Gogra, &c. (C.B., medal, brevet of lieutenant-colonel); commandant, Central India Horse, June, 1862; agent to governor-general, Central India, 1871, to Feb., 1881.

DALY, HUGH, Lieut., C.I.E., I.S.C., Burma Political Department.—Arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1882, and served in the military department; from Nov., 1884, served in the political department as political assistant, Rajputana; on special duty in Upper Burma, June, 1886, and with the Northern Shan column in Nov., 1887; appointed superintendent, Northern Shan States, May, 1888; political assistant, 2nd class, May, 1889; on special duty at Mandalay, May to June, 1891; political assistant, 1st class, Nov., 1891.

DALY, WILLIAM WATT, C.I.E., Bengal Police.—Served in the police department from 19th Nov., 1862; attached to Looshai expeditionary force in command of frontier police, Nov., 1871, to March, 1872; district superintendent, March,
1873; with Garrow Hills expedition, 1873-4; commandant of frontier police in command of Surma Valley division, May, 1883; district superintendent of police, 1st grade, April, 1888; deputy inspector general of police, April, 1891; C.I.E., Jan., 1891.

DAMES, MANSEL LONGWORTH, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant and divisional judge; on special duty with the Kabul troops, Jan., 1879; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1887; officiating divisional judge, Deratap, July, 1890, to March, 1891; author of a Biluchi grammar and text-book.

DAMPIER, HENRY LUCIUS, C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, Dec., 1843; arrived in India, 18th Sept., 1849; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1860; junior secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1861, and secretary, Nov., 1861; commissioner, Nuddea division, July, 1863; on special duty in the famine districts, 1866; between April, 1867, and Nov., 1874, served as secretary to the government of Bengal in the revenue and general departments, and as officiating secretary to the government of India, home department, in 1872; special member of the Bengal legislative council, Dec., 1874; board of revenue, Oct., 1877; Bengal legislative council, Jan., 1879; president of commission for amendment of rent law in Bengal, 1881; retired, July, 1884.

DANCE, GEORGE WHITMORE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1881, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Oct., 1889.

DANE, LOUIS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1876, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner and district judge; on special duty in the Punjab secretariat, Aug., 1879; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, Oct., 1879, to April, 1882; on special duty, Lahore Rakhs, 1884-85; officiating registrar, chief court, June, 1886; officiating district judge, March, 1887; settlement officer, Gurdaspur, Oct., 1887; officiating deputy commissioner, in addition to his own duties in 1888, 1889, and 1891; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, May, 1889.

DANE, RICHARD MORRIS, Bengal C.S.
