(Punjab).—Educated at Kingstown School, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; served under the foreign department of the government of India, July, 1878, to April, 1879; secretary to financial commissioner, Punjab, Nov., 1880; on special duty in public works department, Feb., 1882; officiating undersecretary to government, Punjab, March to Aug., 1882; on special duty under government of India, foreign department, as boundary settlement officer, Central India, Jan., 1883, to March, 1884; and assistant commissioner, Ajmere, Jan.-June, 1885; served subsequently as officiating deputy commissioner, Punjab; settlement officer, Gurdaspur, Nov., 1885; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1889; officiating commissioner of excise, inspector general of registration, &c., April, 1890, to Dec., 1891.

DANIELL, CAIRNES ANTHONY, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1854; from Jan., 1859, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant under the commissioner of Meerut, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed superintendent, Dehra Dun, April, 1866; settlement officer, 1st grade, June, 1868; magistrate and collector, Moradabad, July, 1869; civil and session judge, Gorakhpur, April, 1877; commissioner, Benares division, and agent to the governor-general, March, 1881; member, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, March, 1884; retired, Nov., 1889.

DANIELL, CLARMONT JOHN, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1855; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, under secretary to government, deputy commissioner, Jhansi, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Cawnpore, Aug., 1872; civil and sessions judge, Gorakhpur, Aug., 1878; fellow of Calcutta University, June, 1883; officiating commissioner, Allahabad division, Aug., 1881, and of the Agra division, Oct., 1883; 1st grade judge, April, 1885, Farakhabad; retired, Oct., 1886.

DANSEY, EDWARD PRINCE, Forest Department, Bengal.—Joined the service, 20th Dec., 1872, as assistant conservator; deputy conservator, Sept., 1882; assistant inspector-general of forests, June, 1888; conservator of forests, 3rd grade, May, 1891; 2nd grade, Feb., 1892.

DANVERS, FREDERICK C., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and King's College, London, and, after a special training preparatory for Addiscombe, studied for two years for a civil and mechanical engineer; East India House writer, old establishment, 26th Jan., 1853; junior clerk, public and ecclesiastical department, India office, 1858; public works department, 1861; senior clerk, June, 1867; assistant secretary in the public works department, Feb., 1875; assistant secretary in the revenue department, 1877; registrar and superintendent of records Jan., 1884; in 1855 designed a salt-weighing machine, of which a number were manufactured in this country for the use of the Madras government; in 1859 was deputed by the secretary of state to Liverpool and Manchester to report on traction engines, with a view to their being used in India; in Oct., 1891, and again in April, 1892, was deputed to Lisbon to examine the Portuguese records there and at Evra relating to India; author of articles published in 'Engineering' relative to public works in India, 1866-75; of a design for crossing the East India Railway under the Hooghly from
Howrah to Calcutta, transmitted to India by the secretary of state in 1868; of 'Statistical Papers relating to India' (printed parliamentary paper No. 308 of 1869); of memorandum on Indian coals, with reference to their employment as fuel for Indian railways and steamers, 1867; of memorandum on coal-washing and artificial fuel, 1869; of 'Coal Economy' (printed by order of the secretary of state, 1872); of 'A Century of Famines, being particulars of all the Famines that have visited India since the year 1770, and an inquiry as to the best means of providing against them,' 1877; of 'Spon's Information for Colonial Engineers—India' (published by E. and F. Spon, London, 1877); of 'Agriculture in India,' a paper read before the Society of Arts, 1878 (Society's silver medal); of 'Famines in India,' read before the Society of Arts in 1886; of a 'Report on the Records of the India Office,' printed by order of the secretary of state for India in Council, 1887; of 'Chiefs, Agents, and Governors of Bengal,' 1888; and of a 'Report on the Portuguese Records relating to India,' 1892.

DANVERS, Sir Juland, K.C.S.I., late Public Works Department, India Office.—Educated at King's College, London; East India House writer, 22nd March, 1842; junior clerk, Feb., 1847; minute branch, secretary's department, 1847; private secretary to chairman and deputy, 1848-53; senior clerk, Feb., 1852; assistant, minute branch, secretary's department, 1857; assistant secretary in the railway and electric telegraph department, India office, and assistant director of Indian railway companies, Feb., 1858; secretary in the railway and telegraph department, and deputy director of Indian railway companies, Sept., 1858, to July, 1861; government director of Indian railway companies, 1861; secretary in the public works, railway and telegraph departments, Aug., 1880, continuing to be director of Indian railway companies; visited India in his official capacity in 1875-76; author of the annual official reports on railways in India presented to Parliament from 1859 to 1882; K.C.S.I., 1886; retired, March, 1892.

DARLINGTON, Edwin, Customs Department, Burma.—Joined the service as superintendent of the Burma secretariat, June, 1868; from March, 1872, served as collector of customs, Akyab; also in the Burma secretariat, on special duty, Oct., 1874, to Jan., 1875; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1875; officiating junior secretary to chief commissioner, Sept., 1876; collector of customs, Rangoon, July, 1877; chief collector, Sept., 1880; also vice-chairman of the Rangoon port commissioners, March, 1882.

DARRAH, Henry Zouch, B.A., LL.B., B.L., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Rathmines School, Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1882; acting manager of the Awa estate, March, 1883; acting director of agriculture in Assam, June, 1884; acting secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, March-April, 1886; director of land records and agriculture, Assam, Jan., 1887; on special duty in the Central Provinces in 1887, and in Burma, 1890: author of a 'Monograph on Cotton in Assam,' 'Burma and Assam,' 'The Eri Silk of Assam,' 'The Cattle of Assam,' 'An Experiment in Survey and Settlement,' and a 'Note on the People of Assam.'

DAUKES, Frederick Clendon, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Uppingham Grammar School, Blackheath Proprietary School, and Downing College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, April, 1872; officiating under secretary to government, Sept., 1873; assistant settlement officer, 3rd grade, Banda, Nov., 1873; attaché, foreign department, government of India, 1873; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, foreign department, 1876-77; secretary, public service commission, Sept., 1886; under secretary, government of India, home department, from Dec., 1877; officiating secretary to the chief commissioner of Assam, July, 1888; confirmed, Nov., 1890; C.I.E., Jan., 1892; translated Terentyef's 'Russia and England in Central Asia.'

DAVIDSON, James, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the High School and University of Glasgow, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and cantonment magistrate; on famine duty in Mysore, Oct., 1877, to Aug., 1878; acting first assistant collector, Nov., 1883; second assistant collector, Nov., 1886; forest settlement officer, Nasik, Aug., 1887; first assistant collector and magistrate, Nov., 1888.

DAVIDSON, James Young, late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as assistant-engineer, 9th Dec., 1869, and served in the Central Provinces; executive engineer, Oct., 1875; from Jan., 1882, served as manager, in class 2 of the state railway revenue establishment, on the Wardha coal, and Nagpur-Chhattisgarh railways; in charge of Umaria colliery, Jan., 1886; acting engineer-in-chief Nagpur-Bengal railway, Feb., 1886; class 1, revenue establishment, April, 1887; retired, 1889.

DAVIDSON, Lionel, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at University College School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in Madras, 22nd Dec., 1889, and served as assistant to collector and magistrate.

DAVIDSON, Robert, C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1852; served as assistant to collector and magistrate in various districts; sub-judge of Cuddapah, 1860; small cause court judge, Chittoor, 1862; civil and sessions judge, Trichinopoly, 1867; district and sessions judge of Cuddapah, Aug., 1873, and subsequently of Chingleput; acted as collector and magistrate of Kurnool during the famine, 1877-78; third member, board of revenue, March, 1878; chief secretary to government of Madras, Dec., 1878; legislative council of Madras, 1880 to 1883; provisional member of the executive council May-July, 1881; 1st member, board of revenue, March, 1882; member of the special committee
appointed to frame a famine code for Madras, Oct., 1882; retired, June 1884.

DAVIES, ARTHUR MATCHAM, Maj.-Gen., I.S.C., late Police Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 23rd Jan., 1849; served in the Madras police department from Sept., 1862, as assistant superintendent and superintendent; acting personal assistant to commissioner of police, Madras, Sept., 1866; deputy inspector-general, Nov., 1881 to 1886.

DAVIES, CHARLES ALLAN WILLIAM, Hyderabad Commission.—Joined the service, 22nd March, 1855, as attaché to deputy commissioner, N. Berar; extra assistant commissioner, July, 1858; also assistant commissioner, paper currency, July, 1868; special assistant commissioner, July, 1891.

DAVIES, CHARLES MERSON, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed assistant locomotive superintendent, 15th Sept., 1875; superintendent, March, 1880; class 1, grade 3, Jan., 1888.

DAVIES, HENRY SAMUEL PRICE, Captain, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 25th June, 1878; and from April, 1883, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty at Rawal Pindi Durbar, March, 1885; served under the foreign department of the government of India in 1885 and 1886; acted as private secretary to the lieutenant governor of the Punjab in 1887 and 1888; settlement officer, Oct., 1888.

DAVIES, J., late Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; clerk in principal storekeeper's office, Tower of London, under the board of ordnance, May, 1842; inspector of stores, 1851; sub-inspector of stores, East India House, July, 1855; senior clerk, June, 1860; assistant superintendent of the India store depot, March, 1877; superintendent, June, 1880; retired, Dec., 1888.

DAVIES, JAMES ACWORTH, B.L., Madras C.S.—Educated at Denmark Hill Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1869, and served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue, March, 1880; assistant secretary to government in the judicial and legislative departments, April, 1880; acting under secretary in the chief secretary's department, July, 1880; member of the board of examiners, Jan., 1882; acting district and sessions judge, South Canara, June, 1882; under secretary in the revenue department, Oct., 1882; acting secretary to the board of revenue, June, 1883; from Oct., 1883, acted as registrar, high court, Madras, and was appointed sub-collector and joint magistrate, Kistna, July, 1884; district and sessions judge, Tanjore, March, 1888.

DAVIES, SIR ROBERT HENRY, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S., Council of India.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1844; served in the N.W. Provinces and cis-Sutlej Territory as assistant commissioner; settlement officer, Baree Doab, 1851; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Azimgurh, 1858; secretary to government of Punjab, 1859; financial commissioner, Oudh, 1864; chief commissioner, Oudh, 1869; lieutenant-governor, Punjab, 1871; retired, 1878; member of council of India, 3rd March, 1885.

DAVIES, SIR WILLIAM GEORGE, Maj.-Gen., K.C.S.I., I.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India 5th Jan., 1849; from April, 1854, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; deputy commissioner, May, 1862; commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Nov., 1876, and subsequently in the Jullundur division; financial commissioner, Punjab, Dec., 1883; additional member of the governor-general's council, March, 1886; author of a report on the settlement of the Shahpur district; K.C.S.I., Feb., 1887; retired, April, 1887.

DAVIS, ARTHUR WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Rossall, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1882, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, March, 1891; on special duty with Manipur Field Force in 1891.

DAVIS, JOHN SAMUEL CHAMPION, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at College School, Taunton, Rossall, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1880, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent, Dehra Dun, April, 1882, and officiating superintendent in 1882-83; officiating cantonment magistrate, Chakrata, Sept.-Oct., 1885; junior secretary, board of revenue, Oct. 1886, and Feb., 1890; acting joint secretary, Jan., 1891; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Dec., 1888; 1st grade, Dec., 1890.

DAWKINS, CLINTON E., late India Office.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Balliol College, Oxford, where he graduated B.A. in June, 1883; junior clerk, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, India office, 6th Feb., 1884; political department, 1886; assistant private secretary, and précis writer to the secretary of state, Aug., 1886; private secretary to the chancellor of the exchequer (Rt. Hon. G. J. Goschen), Nov., 1886; resigned the service, April, 1891.

DAWSON, WALTER HILL, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Kensington Grammar School, St. Peter's, Weston-super-Mare, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service (Burma) after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1888, and served as assistant commissioner in Burma; officiating under-secretary to chief secretary, Oct., 1891; confirmed, April, 1892.

DAY, ARTHUR S., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College, Bedford Grammar School, and Clifton College; writer, India office, 26th Oct., 1874; clerk, 2nd class, Nov., 1878.

DAYARAM GIDUMAL, B.A., LL.B., Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, and joined the service as assistant collector, 3rd Jan., 1885; acting small cause court judge, July, 1886; employed from May, 1883, to April, 1886, in compiling a Jaghir record for Sind; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, 3rd March, 1887; acting assistant judge and sessions judge, June, 1887.

DEAN, EDWARD JOSEPH.—Superintendent Bengal secretariat press, 1st May, 1868, and of
the public works department press and deputy superintendent of government printing, April, 1869; superintendent of government printing, Calcutta, April, 1873; retired, May, 1891.

DEANE, THOMAS, Lieut.-Col., I.S.C.—First commission, 21st hussars, March, 1862; lieutenant, Bengal staff corps, March, 1863; adjutant, governor-general's body guard, Jan., 1871; 3rd assistant secretary to the government of India, military department, Jan., 1877; 2nd assistant secretary, April, 1884; deputy secretary, July, 1886; director army remount department, Nov., 1889.

DEAS, JOSEPH, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1870, and served in N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, joint magistrate, and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating deputy commissioner; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1885; district and session judge, Aug., 1887; legal remembrancer, Dec., 1890; secretary to lieutenant-governor's legislative council, Dec., 1890; member of the council, Jan., 1891.

DE BEAUREPAIRE, E.L., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 31st March, 1885.

DE BOURBEL, RAOUl, Major-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, as lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 1850; joined the public works department, Nov., 1852; executive engineer, Lower Provinces, Dec., 1853; assistant to chief engineer, Lower Provinces, Jan., 1857; deputy consulting engineer, railway department, and assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, May, 1860; officiating consulting engineer and under secretary, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1862; superintending engineer, Gowhatta, June, 1865; deputy consulting engineer for railways, Oudh, Feb., 1870; superintending engineer, 2nd grade, railway branch, Oudh, Sept., 1870; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, 1871; in temporary charge of public works department in Biluchistan, 1879-80; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, 1880; chief engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1884; retired, 1885.

DE BRETT, EDWARD ADOLPHUS, Bengal C.S., (Central Provinces).—Educated at Winchester College and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1888, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

DE FABECK, WILLIAM FREDERICK, Surgeon-Major-General, M.D., Madras Medical Department.—Entered the army medical department, June, 1855; joined the Madras medical department, June, 1857, and served under the military department from that date to May, 1871, also holding the civil surgeonies of Kurnul, Chittur, Vellore, and Nagode (Central Provinces), during that period; from Nov., 1873, served in British Burma as acting garrison surgeon, Rangoon, and acting civil surgeon and superintendent of Lock Hospital, Moulmein (May, 1874), and was confirmed in the latter appointment, 1877; also health officer, Moulmein, Feb., 1878, and was in medical charge of the central jail for various periods; deputy surgeon-general, Nagpore force, and Central India regiments, March, 1886; surgeon-general with the government of Madras, May, 1890; served in the Crimean Campaign, 1855-6 (medal and clasp), and in the Indian Mutiny, 1859 (medal).

DEIGHTON, KENNETH, B.A., late Education Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as professor, Agra College, 10th Feb., 1862; principal, Agra College, March, 1864; 2nd grade of educational officers, April, 1883; officiating principal, Benares College, July, 1883; inspector of schools, Rohilkund division, April, 1885; retired, 1890.

DE LA COURNEUVE, STEWART HOWARD THOMAS, Burma Commission.—Joined the service, 24th Jan., 1873; extra assistant commissioner, Feb., 1880; assistant commissioner, March, 1886; deputy commissioner, March, 1891.

DE LAESSOE, ALBERT FREDERICK, Captain, C.M.G., C.I.E., Foreign Department, Government of India.—Served in the Danish Army from April, 1867; attached to foreign legion of French Army, Sept., 1870, to Aug., 1871; chevalier of legion of honour, 1871; from 1873 to 1880 served as instructor in Persian army and chief to staff college in Persia; appointed translator to government of India, foreign department, Feb., 1881; resigned the Danish service, Aug., 1882; in charge of office of press commissioner, Nov., 1883; attached to Afghan Boundary commission, Sept., 1884; on special duty with Sir West Ridgeway in St. Petersburg and London; political assistant and cantonment magistrate, Nasirabad, Nov., 1887; political assistant and assistant commissioner, Marwara, July, 1889; in similar capacity at Ajmere, May, 1892.

DELEVINGNE, WALTER NORMAN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the City of London School, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 25th Nov., 1891, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

DE MARSAC, FREDERICK ROOME, late Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed, 8th March, 1864; assistant superintendent, Jan., 1866; superintendent, April, 1880; attached to office of superintendent of stores, March, 1891; in charge, store department, May, 1891; retired, March, 1892.

DE VILLE, LOUIS, Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd July, 1892.

DENMAN, JOHN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1880, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1888; joint magistrate, Nov., 1891.

DENNISTON, JAMES LAWSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portland Grammar School, Mill Hill Grammar School, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, officiating magistrate and collector, and
officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Feb., 1885; deputy commissioner, March, 1888.

DENNY'S, CHARLES JOHN, Captain, Judicial Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 1st May, 1873; services placed at disposal of Punjab Government, July, 1881; officiating assistant cantonment magistrate, Aug., 1881; confirmed, Oct., 1882; cantonment magistrate, and class, March, 1886; 1st class, June, 1888.

DE PALEZIEUX-FALCONNET, GRENVILLE PULTENEY, Major-General, R.E., late Military Works Department, India.—First commission, Madras engineers, 1852; joined the Madras public works department, Aug., 1854, as assistant engineer; from Dec., 1854, served in the Bengal public works department as executive engineer, Pegu; Mhow division, Rajputana, Nov., 1864; officiating superintending engineer, military works, Allahabad, 1872; superintending engineer, Meerut, April, 1874, and afterwards at Moradabad and Rawal Pindi; superintending engineer, 1st grade, June, 1879; officiated as inspector-general of military works, 1883-84; retired, 1886.

DERBY (EARL OF), RIGHT HONOURABLE EDWARD HENRY SMITH-STANLEY, K.G., D.C.L.—Born 21st July, 1826; educated at Rugby, and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he took a first class in classics in 1843; contested Lancaster unsuccessfully, March, 1843, but was elected for Lyme Regis, which he represented till Oct., 1869, when he succeeded to the House of Peers; made tours to the West Indies and the East in 1850-52; under secretary of state for foreign affairs, May-Dec., 1852; secretary of state for the colonies, and sworn a privy councillor, Feb., 1853; president of the board of control, May, 1853; secretary of state for India, Sept., 1853-59; during his tenure of this office the management of the Indian empire was transferred to the Crown; was secretary of state for foreign affairs from July, 1866, to Dec., 1868, and during this period conducted the negotiations for the settlement of the Luxemburg difficulty; lord rector of the university of Glasgow, April, 1869; was again appointed foreign secretary in Feb., 1874, but resigned in March, 1878; in Dec., 1882, he joined Mr. Gladstone's administration as secretary of state for the colonies; elected lord rector of the university of Edinburgh in Nov., 1874; appointed chancellor of the university of London, 1891; was a member of the royal commission on army purchase in 1856-57, of the Cambridge university commission in 1856-60, and of the commission on the organisation of the Indian army in 1859-59; chairman of the commission on the sanitary state of the Indian army in 1859-61, and of the commission on patents in 1863-64; has also served on the royal commissions on capital punishment, on railways, on city companies, and for the London Exhibition of 1886.

DE RENZY, ANNESLEY CHARLES CASTRIOT, Surgeon-General, B.A., C.B., late Bengal Medical Service.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; entered the Bengal medical service, 1851; served through the Burmese war, 1852-53 (medal and clasp), and in the Mutiny campaigns, 1857-8, including capture of Lucknow (medal and clasp); appointed first sanitary commissioner, Punjab, 1868; surgeon-major, July, 1871; in 1877 undertook an inquiry into the causes of the great mortality among coolies proceeding by steamer to Assam, and made recommendations which led to a great reduction in the number of deaths; deputy surgeon-general, Nov., 1877; sanitary commissioner, Assam, 1878; served in the expedition against the Nagas, 1879 (clasp and C.B.); deputy surgeon-general, Punjab Frontier Force, 1880; retired, Dec., 1882; author of sanitary reports to government on the Punjab and Assam; and of a paper on the sanitary state of British troops in Northern India.

DEVONSHIRE (DUKE OF), HIS GRACE SPENCER COMPTON CAVENDISH.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge (graduated B.A. in 1854, LL.D. in 1862); attached to Earl Granville's special mission to Russia in 1856; sat in the House of Commons for North Lancashire, from March, 1857, to Dec., 1868, when he was returned for the Radnor boroughs; D.C.L., Cambridge, 1862; appointed a lord of the admiralty, March, 1862; under secretary for war, April, 1863; secretary of state for war, Feb.-July, 1865; postmaster-general, Dec., 1868, to Jan., 1871; chief secretary for Ireland, Jan., 1871, to Feb., 1874; received the freedom of the city of Glasgow, Nov., 1877; lord rector of the university of Edinburgh, Jan., 1879; was returned for N.E. Lancashire in April, 1880, and became secretary of state for India; secretary of state for war, Dec., 1882, to June, 1885; was a royal commissioner for the Exhibition of 1886; chairman of the royal commission on the labour question, 1891; chancellor of Cambridge university, 1892.

DEY, GEORGE GOODAIR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at North London Collegiate School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1869; served in the revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, July, 1880; also served in Assam, in 1880, as officiating judge of Sylhet and Cachar; district and sessions judge, Sept., 1887.

DHANJISHA NAVROJI PARAKH, Surgeon-Major, L.R.C.P., M.R.C.S. (London), Bombay Medical Service.—Joined the service, Sept., 1874; arrived in India, 5th May, 1875; was employed under the military department till 1881; served subsequently as assistant civil surgeon, Poona, and acted as deputy sanitary commissioner in 1881, as obstetric physician, Jamsetji-Jijibhoy Hospital, and professor of midwifery, Grant Medical College, in 1883 and 1886, as presidency surgeon in 1884, and as civil surgeon at Surat, April, 1886; surgeon to the Gokuldas Tejpal native general hospital, Jan., 1887.

DIACK, ALEXANDER HENDERSON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at University of Aberdeen, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1882, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating district judge, and settlement officer; senior secretary to financial commissioners, Nov., 1891.

DICKENS, CRAVEN HILDESLEY, Lieutenant-General, C.S.I., late R.A.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal artillery, June, 1838; adjutant and quartermaster, 1846; captain, March, 1853; assistant to secretary, government of India, public
works department, June, 1855; chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, April, 1864; secretary to government of India, public works department, March, 1865, to Feb., 1877; retired 31st Dec., 1878; is a visitor of the Royal Indian Engineering College, Cooper's Hill.

DICKINSON, RICHARD, Financial Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 1851; junior clerk, minute branch, secretary's department, 1853; private secretary to chairman and deputy chairman, 1855-58; senior clerk, financial department, India office, 1858; assistant secretary in the financial department, June, 1867.

DIMMOCK, HENRY PEERS, M.R.C.S., L.R.C.P., Surgeon-Major, Bombay, Educational Department.—Joined the service, 31st March, 1880; civil surgeon, Sept., 1887; acted on various occasions as third physician, Jamsetji-Jijibhoy hospital, professor at Grant medical college, and chemical analyser; superintendent, Mahabaleshwar, Sept., 1889; obstetric physician and professor of midwifery, Grant medical college, June, 1891.

DIXON, JAMES, Burma Police Department.—Appointed inspector of police, Sept., 1870; assistant district superintendent, Oct., 1877, and district superintendent, Jan., 1883; deputy inspector general of civil police, July, 1889.

DOBIE, WILLIAM HERBERT, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the department, 23rd May, 1872; on famine duty as district grain accountant, Chumparan, July, 1874, and at Purneah, Jan., 1875; assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1875; from Jan., 1876, served in Bengal, as acting deputy accountant-general, and as assistant comptroller-general; served in Madras, 1878-83, and in the Punjab, Oct., 1883, to Nov., 1884; assistant accountant-general and examiner of local accounts, Bengal, in 3rd class of the financial department, Dec., 1884; assistant accountant-general, Punjab, April, 1885; deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, March, 1886; comptroller, Assam, April, 1887; deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Oct., 1890; officiating comptroller, Hyderabad, July, 1891.

DOBIE, STANLEY LOCKER, Surgeon-Lieutenant-Colonel, Madras Medical Department.—Joined the service, 30th March, 1872; superintendent of lunatic asylum, Madras, Jan., 1882; served in Afghanistan and Egypt; medical officer, Ootacamund, April, 1883, to Nov., 1889; superintendent of lunatic asylum, Madras, Jan., 1892.

DODD, CHARLES, Education Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as officiating professor of English literature, Agra College, 4th Aug., 1868; head master, Bareilly College, Dec., 1868; officiated at various periods as professor at that and other colleges; professor of English literature, Agra and Benares Colleges, Dec., 1874; inspector of schools, Sept., 1884; officiating principal, Benares College, in 1887 and 1888.

DODD, CHARLES ALBERT, Colonel, I.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, 23rd Royal Welsh Fusiliers, 12th Nov., 1857; medal and clasp for service during the Mutiny; from Feb., 1860, served in the police department, and was employed on special duty at Lucknow, 1860; personal assistant to inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, March, 1861; district superintendent, Aug., 1861; secretary to committee at Calcutta for revising forms of police statistics, Feb., 1869; from April, 1870, served as superintendent, government press, and curator of government books, N.W. Provinces; also superintendent of emigration, Jan., 1883.

DODERET, WILLIAM, Bombay C.S.—Educated at University College School, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883; compiler of Bombay Administration Report, 1886-7; forest settlement officer, May, 1888; 2nd assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1890; special under-secretary to government in the department of famine relief, Feb.-May, 1892.

DOGSON, CYRIL GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1884; also forest settlement officer, July, 1887; and assistant collector and magistrate, June, 1891.

DOIG, SCROPE BERDMORE, M.I.C.E., Sanitary Department, Bombay.—Joined the service, 16th July, 1867, as assistant engineer; executive engineer, Nov., 1872; on special duty, Ahmednagar water-supply scheme, in 1891, and again as member of Sind irrigation commission; sanitary engineer, and member of sanitary board, Jan., 1892.

DONALD, WILLIAM, late Financial Department, Madras.—Arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1856; from 23rd May, 1859, served in the central public works office, and the civil paymaster's office, Madras, and was appointed to 5th class of financial department, Aug., 1862; examiner of claims, July, 1865; secretary to committee for examination of assistants, June, 1868; assistant accountant-general, Madras, Aug., 1869; director of incorporated bank of Madras, March, 1871; 3rd class of financial department, Feb., 1874; appointed assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Nov., 1874, and subsequently at Madras, June, 1875, and acted on several occasions as accountant-general and commissioner of paper currency; member of board of examiners, May, 1883; deputy accountant-general, Madras, Dec., 1884; officiating accountant-general, Madras (class 3), May-July, 1886, and Aug.-Nov., 1887; confirmed in class 2, March, 1887; compiled the manual of rules and regulations for the use of junior members of Madras civil service; retired, 1889.

DONOVAN, CHARLES, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1863; from Feb., 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector, and was placed on special duty at Cawnpore, May, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1879; served in Assam, Sept., 1879, to June, 1882, as deputy commissioner, 1st grade; judge, 3rd grade, Benares, Jan., 1885; 2nd grade, April, 1887; retired, June, 1889.

DORMER, SIR JAMES CHARLEMAGNE, K.C.B., Lieutenant-General.—First commission, May, 1853; served in the Crimean campaign and
Indian Mutiny; aide-de-camp to commander-in-chief, East Indies, July, 1858; served with China expeditionary force, 1860-61, and subsequently at home and in Cyprus and Malta; acting chief of staff and deputy adjutant-general, Egyptian expedition, 1882; major general, Feb., 1885; served in the Soudan expedition, 1885; deputy adjutant-general (for auxiliary forces), at headquarters in England, Oct., 1885; Dublin district, Nov., 1886; Egypt, 1888; lieutenant-general and commander-in-chief, Madras, March, 1891.

DOSABHAI FRAMJI, C.S.I., late Presidency Magistrate, Bombay.—Served from 6th Oct., 1860, as income tax assessor; police magistrate, July, 1866; special officer for the Imperial licence tax, May, 1867; collector of income tax and certificate tax, May, 1866; sheriff of Bombay, Dec., 1871; member of the town council, Sept., 1873; from June, 1874, served as second magistrate of police, Bombay, and also held the posts of chairman of the municipal corporation (Sept., 1875, to Dec., 1876), chairman of the justices of the peace, additional member of the governor's council for making laws and regulations (Sept., 1877), special officer to hear appeals against the licence tax assessment (Aug. 1878), special collector of licence tax, and acting collector of stamps and stationery (Aug.–Sept., 1882); joint commissioner of income tax in addition to his duties as presidency magistrate, April, 1886; retired, 1888; author of 'Moral and Miscellaneous Essays,' 'The British Raj,' 'History of the Parsees,' and 'Travels in Great Britain.'

DOUGLAS, SHOLTO JAMES, B.L., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1878; served in Assam as assistant commissioner and inspector of labourers; from April, 1885, served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, July, 1889; has officiated as district and sessions judge.

DOUIE, JAMES McCrone, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the High School, Edinburgh, University of Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1876, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, secretary to the financial commissioner (1881-82), and settlement officer (Aug., 1883); senior secretary to financial commissioner, April, 1889; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1891; has published a translation of the Biluchinama, with a Biloch grammar.

DOVETON, JOHN CHADWICK, Colonel, I.S.C., Forest Department, Central Provinces.—First commission, Oct., 1858; assistant conservator of forests, 1st grade, Central Provinces, 8th April, 1864; deputy conservator, May, 1865; conservator, Sept., 1868.

DOWDEN, THOMAS FREEMAN, Colonel, R.E., late Railway Branch, Government of India.—1st commission, Dec., 1856; joined the Bombay public works department, Aug., 1859; under secretary to government, 1865; deputy consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, 1872; officiating manager Rajputana state railway, April, 1878; manager, Dhond and Manmad state railway, Dec., 1878; officiating consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, Oct., 1879; served in the Afghan war, 1879-80 (medal); officiating superintending engineer and secretary to agent to governor-general, Biluchistan, April, 1880; acting senior deputy consulting engineer, and under secretary to government, Bombay, Nov., 1881; assistant to director-general of railways, 1884; superintending engineer, 3rd class, July, 1886; deputy consulting engineer, Calcutta, April, 1886; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lucknow, Feb., 1887; superintending engineer, 2nd class, March, 1889; 1st class, March, 1891; reverted to military duty, June, 1892.

DOYLE, BERNARD, Surgeon-Major, B.A., M.B., M.Ch., Medical Department, Punjab.—Appointed to the Indian Medical Department, and arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1876; served in military department to April, 1881, and afterwards as civil surgeon and deputy sanitary commissioner; served in Burma, Nov., 1886 to Feb., 1887; medical adviser to Maharaja of Jhind, 26th Sept., 1887; surgeon-major, March, 1888; civil surgeon, Umballa, March, 1890; civil surgeon and superintendent of lunatic asylum, Delhi, June, 1890.

D'OYLY, WARREN HASTINGS, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 28th May, 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments; inspector-general of jails, May, 1876; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, July, 1876; officiating opium agent, Behar, 1878, 1885-87 and 1889-90; officiating commissioner, Bhagulpore, 1884-85, and April, 1889; retired, Nov., 1891.

DRAKE, FRANCIS C., B.A., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Winchester and New College, Oxford; junior clerk, Record Office, 23rd Feb., 1892; junior clerk, India Office, 22nd Aug., 1892.

DRAKE-BROCKMAN, EDWARD FORSTER, Brigade - Surgeon - Lieut. - Colonel, F.R.C.S., L.R.C.P., Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 1st Oct., 1866; arrived, 23rd April, 1867, and served under the military department, Madras, and also as acting civil surgeon, superintendent of jail, and superintendent of fish liver oil factory, Calicut; was also in medical charge of lock hospital, Madras, and central cholera hospital, Vepery, 1869-70; resident assistant surgeon, general hospital, and professor of pathology in medical college, Madras, Oct., 1870, to Feb., 1875; also acting professor of medical jurisprudence, Sept., 1872; ophthalmic surgeon, general hospital, and professor of ophthalmic surgery and physiology, March, 1875; surgeon-major, Oct., 1875; fellow of Madras university, March, 1885; brigade-surgeon, April, 1890.

DRAKE-BROCKMAN, ELLIOT GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1888, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

DRAKE-BROCKMAN, HENRY VERNON, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at the Charterhouse, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1886; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Central Provinces, Dec., 1886; acting under secretary to chief commis-
sioner, March, 1890, and again, Jan., 1892; assistant commissioner, April, 1890; acting commissioner of excise, April, 1892.

DRAKE - BROCKMAN, RALPH RHENIUS EVANS, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., A.I.C.E., Madras Public Works Department.—Arrived in India, 1st March, 1864, and joined sappers and miners, and from Dec., 1864, served in the public works department; assistant engineer, Nov., 1865; executive engineer, March, 1870; superintending engineer, Nov., 1883; acted in 1889 as joint secretary to government and chief engineer, general buildings and roads branch.

DREW, WILLIAM WILSON, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and acting deputy commissioner; from May, 1882, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, and railway magistrate, and was permanently transferred to the Bombay civil service, June, 1885; appointed inspector of factories, town of Bombay, May, 1887; acting junior collector land revenue, customs, &c., June, 1888; 2nd assistant collector, Nov., 1888; provincial supt. of census operations, April, 1890; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1891.

DRIBERG, JOHN JAMES STREET, Assam Commission.—Joined the service as deputy magistrate, and deputy collector, in Bengal, Nov., 1861; from Dec., 1863, served in Assam as extra assistant commissioner, and was placed on special duty as assistant civil and political officer with the Bhutan Duars Field Force, Oct., 1864, to June, 1865 (medal and clasp); assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, May, 1880; deputy superintendent of census in Assam, Oct., 1880; superintendent of emigration, June, 1882; deputy commissioner, May, 1886; inspector general of jails, police, and registration, superintendent of stamps, &c., Nov., 1891.

DRUMMOND, Hon. Sir EDMUND, K.C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Haileybury College; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1831; arrived in India, 6th March, 1833; assistant collector and magistrate, Monghyr, Jan., 1834; on special resumption and settlement duty, Dec., 1835, to Sept., 1839; officiating magistrate of Behar, Sept., 1839; collector of Burdwan, July, 1850; collector, magistrate, and salt agent, Poooree, 1852; accountant, government of Bengal, military accountant, deputy accountant-general, government of India, member of mint committee, and director of bank of Bengal, 1854; accountant-general, government of India, 1856; auditor-general, government of India, president of board of audit, government director of bank of Bengal, and member of mint committee, 1860; financial secretary, government of India, 1862; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, March, 1863; retired 1868; member of council of secretary of state, 1875-85; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

DRUMMOND, JAMES RAMSAY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, University of Glasgow, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; district judge, 2nd grade, March, 1890; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1890.

DRURY, GEORGE MARSTON, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed traffic superintendent, class iii., state railways revenue establishment, 30th Jan., 1878, and served chiefly on the Eastern Bengal state railway; class ii., grade i, 1889; traffic superintendent, East Coast railway, Nov., 1891.

DRYSDALE, ALEXANDER TOVEY, late Forest Department, Hyderabad Administration.—Arrived in India, Dec., 1864; from April, 1865, served in the Central Provinces as head master of government school and officiating inspector of schools; from June, 1868, served in the forest department, Berar, as assistant conservator, deputy conservator, and conservator (3rd grade, Sept., 1882); retired, Jan., 1887.

DRYSDALE, THEODORE, Central Provinces Commission.—Assistant master, government school, Saugor, April, 1861; served in the Central Provinces commission from 10th Jan., 1863, as officiating assistant commissioner; appointed extra assistant commissioner, April, 1864; superintendent of the judicial commissioner's office, June, 1864; registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, May, 1869; held executive charge of the jail, Saugor, 1877; deputy superintendent of census operations in the Central Provinces, April, 1880; judge, small cause court, Nagpur, Nov., 1884; on special duty in connection with the settlement of the Sarangarh State, Jan.-Feb., 1885; deputy commissioner, April, 1885; cantonment magistrate, Kamptee, Dec., 1885, to July, 1889; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Sept., 1889; compiled 'Report on the Census of the Central Provinces, 1881.'

DU BOULAY, JAMES HOUSEMAYNE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1877; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1889, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

DUCAT, WALTER MARDEN, Col. R.E., late Bombay Public Works Department.—Joined the service as second lieutenant, 13th June, 1850; arrived in India, May, 1858; assistant engineer, Aug., 1859; special assistant engineer, Jan., 1860; executive engineer, Aug., 1863; captain, Feb., 1868; lieutenant-colonel, Jan., 1884; and colonel, July, 1885; superintending engineer, Nov., 1886; retired, April, 1890.

DUFF, ALAN COLQUHOUN, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1881, and served in the Central Provinces as supernumerary assistant commissioner; assistant commissioner, April, 1885; acting under secretary to chief commissioner, Nov., 1885; acting commissioner of excise, &c., April, 1888; judge, small cause court, Oct., 1891; commissioner of excise, March, 1892; deputy commissioner, March, 1892.

DUFFERIN AND AVA (MARQUIS OF), RIGHT HON. FREDERICK TEMPLE HAMILTON BLACKWOOD, K.P., G.C.B., G.C.S.I., G.C.M.G., G.C.I.E., D.C.L.—Educated at Eton and Christ Church, Oxford; specially attached to Lord John Russell's Mission to Vienna in 1855; in 1860
was appointed British commissioner in Syria to enquire into the massacre of Christians, and for his services on this occasion was nominated a K.C.B.; under secretary of state for India, 1864-1866; under secretary for war, in 1866; chancellor of the duchy of Lancaster, Dec., 1868, to April, 1872; governor-general of Canada, May, 1872, to Oct., 1878; ambassador at St. Petersburg, Feb., 1879; ambassador at Constantinople, May, 1881; from Nov., 1882 to April, 1883, he was engaged in Egypt in the settlement of the various questions arising out of Arabi's rebellion; viceroy and governor-general of India, 13th Dec., 1884; left India to take up post of ambassador at Rome, Dec., 1888; lord warden of the Cinque Ports, Nov., 1891; ambassador at Paris, Dec., 1891; K.P. in 1863; lord-lieutenant of the county of Down, 1864; privy councillor, Dec., 1868; earl of the United Kingdom, Nov., 1871, and Marquis, 1888, taking the style of Ava in addition to Dufferin by special command of Her Majesty; president of the Royal Geographical Society, May, 1878; LL.D., Harvard University, June, 1878; LL.D., Dublin University, Jan., 1879; D.C.L., Oxford University, June, 1879; G.C.B., 1883; chancellor of the Royal University, Ireland, 1886; has published 'Narrative of a Journal from Oxford to Skibbereen during the year of the Irish Famine,' 1846-47; 'Letters from High Latitudes,' the result of a yacht voyage to Iceland in 1859; 'Irish Emigration and the Tenure of Land in Ireland'; 'Mr. Mill's plan for the Pacification of Ireland examined;' 'Contributions to an Enquiry into the State of Ireland,' is also the author of various works in light literature.

DUKE, FREDERICK WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Arbroath High School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1884; has also acted as magistrate and collector.

DUMERGUE, JOHN WILLOUGHBY FRANCIS, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and assistant resident and acting resident in Travancore; Malayan translator to government, March, 1884; head assistant collector and magistrate, Nilgiris, Feb., 1885; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Nov., 1889; has acted as collector and magistrate, and district and sessions judge.

DUNCAN, DAVID, M.A., D.Sc. (Edinburgh), Education Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras education department from 20th May, 1870, as professor of logic and moral philosophy at the Presidency College, and was registrar of the Madras University from April, 1875, to March, 1879, and again 1881-86; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1877; 3rd class of the education department, April, 1880; principal and professor, Presidency College, from March, 1884; also acted for various periods as director of public instruction, and as commissioner for the unconv. civil service examinations; second class of the education department, Aug., 1885; 1st class, Dec., 1888.

DUNCAN, HARVEY TUCKETT, Major-General, C.S.I., late Madras S.C.—Ensign, 46th regt., N.I., Madras, June, 1848; was employed in the Mofussil police, 1860; inspector-general of police, British Burma, March, 1862; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1873; political resident, Mandalay, 1875 to 1878; retired from the army, Feb., 1880.

DUNCAN, WILLIAM ALEXANDER MACKENZIE, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Milne's Institution, Focharbers, Aberdeen University, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 28th Nov., 1890, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner.

DUNLOP, ALEXANDER JOHNSTON, Berar Commission.—Appointed assistant to cotton commissioner, Central Provinces and Berar, 1st May, 1869, and assistant commissioner, Feb., 1876; from 1869-74, held charge in addition to other duties of a government experimental farm; served as officiating secretary for Berar to the resident, 1877-8, and as judge of small cause court, June, 1878; inspector-general, revenue department, to Nizam's Government, April, 1885, and survey and settlement commissioner, Nizam's Government, April, 1887; deputy commissioner, Berar, July, 1880.

DUNLOP-SMITH, JAMES ROBERT, M.A., Captain, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1879; admitted to the Bengal staff corps from March, 1882; from March, 1883, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; private secretary to the lieutenant-governor of the Punjab, Dec., 1883; settlement collector, April, 1888.

DUPERNEX, HUBERT EMILE LEONCE PAUL, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at St. Paul's School and Caius College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1887; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

DURAND, ALGERNON GEORGE ARNOLD, C.B., Lieutenant-Colonel, I.S.C.—First commission, 21st Dec., 1872; served under the military department to June, 1889, when he was sent on deputation to Gilgit; appointed British agent there, July, 1889; C.B., July, 1892.

DURAÑD, SIR EDWARD LAW, Bart., C.B., Lieut.-Col., I.S.C., Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, 10th Oct., 1865; arrived in India, June, 1866; served with the 66th regiment, and was transferred to Bengal staff corps, Oct., 1868; A.D.C. and private secretary to lieut.-governor of the Punjab, June, 1870; from Feb., 1871, served in the foreign department under the Government of India in Rajputana and Central India; served as political agent of Manipur, and as first assistant on special duty in foreign office; political agent, 3rd class, May, 1881; assistant commissioner, Afghan boundary commission, Oct., 1885; on special duty to England, Oct. to Dec., 1886; officiating resident, Nepal, Feb., 1888; confirmed, May, 1889; author of 'Report on Fars and Sketch Map of part of the Country,' and 'Report on Pearl Fisheries.'

DURAND, SIR HENRY MORTIMER, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1873; assistant magistrate and collector in Ben-
gal, March, 1873; on famine duty, Nov., 1873; from June, 1874, served in the foreign department of the government of India, and was appointed officiating 1st assistant to the governor-general's agent, Rajputana, July, 1876; officiating assistant secretary, foreign department, Nov., 1877; political assistant, 1st class, Dec., 1877; political secretary to major-general Sir F. Roberts with the Kabul field force, Sept., 1879 (medal and two clasps for Afghan campaign); under secretary, government of India, foreign department, March, 1880; C.S.I., Feb., 1881; officiating private secretary to the Viceroy, June, 1880; secretary to government of India, foreign department, Feb., 1885; is secretary of the orders of the Star of India, and of the Indian Empire; has published a work on the first Afghan war, 1871, and a life of Sir H. M. Durand, 1883; K.C.I.E., Jan., 1889.

DURRANT, WILLIAM S., M.A., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at Whitgift, and Lycée St. Omer; B.A., London (with honours in French), 1888; M.A. (Classics), 1891; junior clerk, India office, 18th Sept., 1879.

DUTHOIT, WILLIAM, D.C.L., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Exeter College, Oxford; called to the bar at the Inner Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1857; served from Sept., 1858, in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed deputy superintendent, family domains, Maharaja of Benares, May, 1862; officiating inspector-general of registration and commissioner of excise and stamps, March, 1875; magistrate and collector, Shahjahanpur, April, 1877; on special duty under the government of India, financial department, Dec., 1879; on special duty under the orders of the high court, N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1881; officiating puisne judge, high court, June, 1881; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Aug., 1881; officiating judicial commissioner, Oudh, May, 1882; employed on the opium commission, under government of Bengal, March to Oct., 1883; judicial commissioner of Oudh, March, 1884; retired, Aug., 1886.

DUTT, RUSSICK LALL, M.D., Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 30th March, 1872, and served in the military department and as civil surgeon at various stations; has also officiated as surgeon-superintendent, Presidency general hospital and medical inspector of emigrants.

DYMOTT, DONALD FREDERICK DYMOtt, M.B., Surgeon-Major, Madras Medical Department.—Joined the service, 31st March, 1880; assistant physician, general hospital, July, 1884; resident physician, March, 1885; acting secretary to the surgeon-general, June, 1886; acting inspector of vaccination, and deputy sanitary commissioner, June, 1887; confirmed, June, 1888.

DYSON, JOHN, late Oudh Commission.—Joined the service, 8th June, 1888, as deputy magistrate and deputy collector in Bengal; from Dec., 1861, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; officiating city magistrate of Lucknow, Sept., 1866; also officiating superintendent of excise and stamps, Aug.–Oct., 1867; small cause court judge, Lucknow, 1869; on special duty on committee for compiling the laws and regulations in force in Oudh previous to 1861, Jan., 1870; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Sitapur, April, 1883; district judge, 1st grade, Fyzabad, Aug., 1886; officiating commissioner, Fyzabad, Sept., 1886; officiating judicial commissioner, Oudh, Aug., 1889; additional judicial commissioner, July, 1890; retired, March, 1891.

EADES, F. T., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, 22nd Jan., 1875.

EALES, CHARLES LINDSTEDT MODELLER, B.L., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Dulwich College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1878, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating cantonment magistrate, Fyzabad, March-Aug., 1885; joint magistrate, Nov., 1887; has also acted as magistrate and collector, and district and sessions judge.

EALES, HERBERT LOVELY, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Dulwich College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1879; served in British Burma as assistant commissioner; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Dec., 1885; deputy commissioner, May, 1888; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, April-May, 1890; superintendent of census, July, 1890; deputy commissioner, Magwe, May, 1892.

EARDLEY-WILMOT, SAINT-HILL, Forest Department, North-Western Provinces and Oudh.—Joined the service, 27th Sept., 1873, as assistant conservator; deputy conservator, Nov., 1883; conservator, 3rd grade, Oct., 1891.

EARLE, ARCHADE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Uppingham, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882; officiating private secretary to the lieutenant-governor, Feb., 1886; officiating under secretary to government of Bengal, judicial, political and appointment departments, Feb., 1889; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Jan., 1891.

EAST, WILLIAM ALBERT, M.A., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived 26th Nov., 1863, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant registrar, and deputy registrar and sealer of the high court, assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; superintendent of Panchgani, Nov., 1876; junior collector and magistrate and political agent, Dharwar, June, 1881; senior collector, June, 1885; retired, May, 1891.

EBDEN, EDWARD JAMES, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Queen Elizabeth's School, Ipswich, and Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865, arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Sept., 1872, served in the forest department as acting deputy conservator in the Kanara district; employed on famine duty, Dharwar, April, 1877, and in Mysore, Oct., 1877, to July, 1878; from July, 1878, served as assistant collector, railway...
magistrate, forest settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate; first assistant collector and magistrate, Aug., 1881; junior collector and magistrate, June, 1888; senior collector and magistrate, Nov., 1890.

EDGAR, Sir John Ware, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1862; assistant magistrate and collector, July, 1863; served in Cachar from Dec., 1863, as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; on special duty with the Lushai expeditionary force, Oct., 1871; officiating junior secretary to the government of Bengal, June, 1872; magistrate and collector, Shahabad, Feb., 1873; officiated as commissioner in various divisions in Bengal, 1880-83; 1st grade magistrate and collector, Nov., 1881; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, judicial, political, and appointment departments, Sept., 1884, and subsequently in the financial department, May, 1885; commissioner of Chittagong, Dec., 1885; chief secretary to government of Bengal, Aug., 1887; K.C.I.E., May, 1889; additional member of governor-general's council, Jan., 1892; retired, July, 1892.

EDGE, Sir John, Knt., Q.C., B.A., LL.B. Judicial Department, N.W. Provinces and Oudh.—Called to the bar, Middle Temple, 1866; Q.C., 1886; went the northern and north-eastern circuit, and was appointed chief justice, high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1886; vice-chancellor, Allahabad University, Nov., 1887.

EDGELL, W., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley; writer, India office, 31st July, 1869; temporarily employed as shipping inspector of railway stores, Jan., 1872; receiver of wharf stores, Jan., 1873; supervisor, 2nd grade, March, 1877; 1st grade, June, 1886.

EDGERLEY, Steyning William, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and officiating cantonment magistrate; from May, 1881, served in Sind as acting deputy collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration, and acting Sindi translator to government; 2nd assistant collector in Sind, 1885 and 1886; under secretary to government of India, home department, Oct., 1888; private secretary to the governor of Bombay, March, 1889.

EDIS, Frederick, late Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; writer, India Office, 29th July, 1872; clerk under the inspector-general of railway stores, March, 1877; retired, Dec., 1889.

EDMONSTONE-MONTGOMERIE, Charles Waterton, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Copenhagen and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1887, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

EDWARDS, Alfred Clarke, M.A., B.L., Bengal Educational Service.—Arrived in India, 28th Sept., 1878, and served as professor in the Presidency College, and principal, Rajshahye College, and afterwards of the Dacca College; class 3 of educational service, Jan., 1889.

EDWARDS, Herbert, late Store Department, India Office.—2nd class clerk, March, 1887; resigned, June, 1892.

EGERTON, Sir Robert Eyles, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service from the East India College, Haileybury, in 1850; served in the Punjab as assistant magistrate and collector and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed to the charge of the settlement of the Lahore district, 1854-58; deputy commissioner, 1856; officiating commissioner, Lahore, 1863; additional commissioner, Peshawur, Nov., 1863, to Feb., 1864; commissioner, Nagpur, Central Provinces, March, 1864; officiated as judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, at various times from 1865 to 1867; financial commissioner of the Punjab, March, 1868; additional member, governor-general's council, July, 1871, and again in 1872 and 1877; lieutenant-governor of the Punjab, April, 1877, to April, 1882, when he resigned the service.

EGERTON, William, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rossall School, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived 5th Dec., 1890, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

ELIAS, Ney, C.I.E., Foreign Department, Government of India.—Extra attache, foreign department, March-Sept., 1874; second in command, Yunnan expedition, and assistant to resident in Mandalay, Sept., 1874, to May, 1875; officiating political agent, Bhamo, April-Aug., 1875, in addition to other duties; extra attache, foreign department, Oct., 1875; from Oct., 1877, served as joint commissioner of Ladakh; political assistant, 1st class (supernumerary), June, 1879; on special duty to Yarkand, June-Aug., 1879; on special duty to Kashgar, March-Aug., 1880; political agent with the Kashgar Mission, May, 1885; political agent, March, 1886; C.I.E., Jan., 1888; boundary settlement officer, Jeypore, 1887-88; assistant agent, Rajputana, March, 1888; on special duty in connection with Sikkim expedition, Nov., 1888; British commissioner, Anglo-Siamese boundary commission, Oct., 1889; agent to the governor-general in Khorassan and Seistan, Dec., 1891.

ELIOT, John, M.A., Meteorological Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, June, 1869; from 27th Dec., 1869, to Feb., 1876, served in the N.W. Provinces as professor of mathematics, Thomason College, and also at Muir College; superintendent of the meteorological observatory, Allahabad, and meteorological reporter to government; from Feb., 1876, served in Bengal, as professor, Presidency College, and meteorological reporter, also as officiating meteorological reporter to government of India, April, 1878, and Dec., 1881; 2nd class, Bengal education department, March, 1881; officiating principal, Presidency College, and registrar of Calcutta University, Jan., 1883; appointed meteorological reporter to government of India, May, 1880.

ELLIOTT, Lawrence Edward, Lieutenant, I.S.C., Burma Commission.—1st commission, Aug., 1880; assistant commissioner, July, 1886;
in 1890, acted as superintendent, Northern Shan States.

ELLENOR, T. R., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

ELLERCAMP, H. McD., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 10th Oct., 1879.

ELLIOT, ALGERNON, Berar Commission.—From 28th Jan., 1869, served in the police department of the Central Provinces, and as assistant commissioner, Berar; deputy commissioner, April, 1889; in 1890 officiated as civil and sessions judge.

ELLIOT, FREDERICK AUGUSTUS HUGH, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from June, 1873, to Nov., 1875, served in Berar as educational inspector, and acting director of public instruction; principal of the Raja's school, and tutor and governor of the Gaekwar of Baroda, Dec., 1875; on special duty, Baroda, April, 1882; C.I.E., May, 1883; on duty with the Gaekwar of Baroda, 1884; survey and settlement officer, Baroda, March, 1890.

ELLIOT, FREDERICK EDEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1858; arrived in India, 16th March, 1858; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Hamirpur, April, 1877, and civil and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1881; 1st grade, Jan., 1887.

ELLIOTT, SIR CHARLES ALFRED, LL.B., K.C.S.I., Lieutenant-Governor of Bengal.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1856, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from April, 1858, to May, 1861, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner, and from Feb., 1863, to Oct., 1866, in the Central Provinces as settlement officer, Hoshangabad; served subsequently as settlement officer, Farakhabad, and as secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, 1870-1877; commissioner, Meerut, Oct., 1877; famine commissioner, Mysore, Sept., 1877; additional secretary to government of India, famine branch, May, 1878; secretary to famine commission, June, 1878; census commissioner, Oct., 1880; chief commissioner of Assam, March, 1881; president of the committee for the retrenchment of public expenditure, Feb., 1886; K.C.S.I., Feb., 1887; ordinary member of governor-general's council, Dec., 1887; appointed lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 18th Dec., 1890; author of 'Chronicles of Unao' and of the Famine Commission Report, 1879, and the Finance Commission Report, 1887.

ELLISON, THOMAS EDWARD, late Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at St. Andrew's College, Bradford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 19th Oct., 1864; assistant commissioner, 3rd class, Delhi, Aug., 1865; transferred to Central Provinces, Oct., 1868; assistant commissioner, 1st class, Oct., 1881; judge, small cause court, Nagpur, Sept., 1883; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1884; retired, Dec., 1890.

ELPHINSTON, JOHN, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 5th Feb., 1855, and served in Bombay and Sind as assistant collector and magistrate, deputy collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and collector and magistrate (Jan., 1873); senior collector and magistrate, Ratnagiri, Oct., 1876; collector and magistrate and political agent, Kolaba, Sept., 1880; retired, Nov., 1886.

ELPHINSTONE, GRAHAM WARBURTON, Madras C.S.—Educated at Eton and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 19th Nov., 1887, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate.

ELSMIE, GEORGE ROBERT, B.L., C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1858, and was appointed assistant commissioner, Punjab; officiating judge small cause court, Lahore, Nov., 1863; on special duty at Lahore, July, 1867; officiating under secretary to government of India, Oct., 1868; deputy commissioner, May, 1870; from 1871 to 1877 officiated as additional commissioner of Jullundur and Amritsar, and of Peshawur; civil and session judge, March, 1877; officiating judge, chief court, 1878-79; commissioner and superintendent, Lahore, Nov., 1880; judge, chief court, Punjab, Jan., 1882; commissioner and superintendent, Lahore, Feb., 1883; 2nd financial commissioner, May, 1887; appointed also additional member of governor-general's legislative council, May, 1888, which office he resigned, Dec., 1888; first financial commissioner, March, 1889; on special duty at Rawal Pindi Durbar, March, 1885; author of 'Notes on Peshawur Crime'; C.S.I., Jan., 1893.

ELWIN, EDGAR ALFRED, Madras C.S.—Educated at Dover College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1883, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; manager Jeypore estate, July-Oct., 1890; acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments, April to July, 1891.

ELWIN, ERNEST BARNES, Madras C.S.—Educated at Doyer College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 5th January, 1891, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

ENTHOVEN, REGINALD EDWARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Wellington College and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1889, and served in Bombay as assistant magistrate and collector.

ERSKINE, CLAUDIUS JAMES, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1840; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge; private
secretary to governor of Bombay, 1844; oriental translator to government, 1847; also deputy secretary to government of Bombay, Persian department, 1847; secretary to government of Bombay in the general and judicial departments, 1854; civil auditor, 1854; director of public instruction, 1855; senior assistant judge and sessions judge, Konkan, 1857; judge and sessions judge, Konkan, 1859; member of legislative council of India, 1860; also puisne judge of court of Sudder Dewani, Bombay, 1862; judge of the high court of judicature, Bombay, 1863; member of council, Bombay, 31st Oct., 1865; retired in 1867.

ERSKINE, GEORGE ELPHINSTONE, Colonel, Kumaun Commission.—Arrived in India as cornet, Bombay light cavalry, 9th Dec., 1857; was employed under the military department including service with the Rajputana field force, till Feb., 1863, when he joined the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner from May, 1865, to July, 1871, served as assistant settlement officer, and acting settlement officer; also officiated as personal assistant to financial commissioner in 1867-69, and as superintendent of excise and stamps in 1868-69; personal assistant to chief commissioner, Oudh, July, 1871, to April, 1873; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, May to Aug., 1876; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, in forest branch, and Oudh revenue department, 7th April, 1878; commissioner, Sitapur division, Jan., 1882; Lucknow division, March, 1888, and Kumaun division, Jan., 1890; on special duty to inquire into condition of tenantry in Oudh, Dec., 1882, to May, 1883.

ERSKINE, HENRY NAPIER BRUCE, C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 23rd Sept., 1853, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, special officer for income tax, assistant-commissioner and acting educational inspector in Sind, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; collector and magistrate, Nasik, July, 1869; acting revenue and police commissioner, northern division, June, 1877; from June, 1879, acted as commissioner in Sind, and was confirmed in this appointment, Oct., 1882; on special duty at Bombay, Dec., 1880; 1st grade commissioner, July, 1881; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; retired, Aug., 1888.

ETESON, A., M.D., Deputy Surgeon-General, late Medical Department, Assam.—Joined the Indian medical department as assistant surgeon, May, 1854; arrived in India, 30th June, 1854; held various military medical charges, and was promoted to surgeon-major, May 1874; medal for services during the mutiny; secretary to surgeon-general, Indian medical department, March, 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Eastern frontier district, and sanitary commissioner, Assam, Jan., 1884; retired, Jan., 1889.

EUAN-SMITH, SIR CHARLES BEAN, Colonel, K.C.B., C.S.I.—Ensign, Madras infantry, March, 1859; arrived in India, June, 1859; served in Abyssinian expedition, 1867-68, and was present at capture of Magdala (medal); secretary to Sir F. Goldsmid's mission to Persia, Aug., 1870, to Nov., 1872; C.S.I., Nov., 1872; private secretary to Sir Bartle Frere, on special mission to Zanzibar and Muscat, Nov., 1872, to July, 1873; on special duty in India office, 1873-74; political agent and consul-general, Zanzibar, May, 1875; on special duty, foreign department, on occasion of Prince of Wales' visit to Calcutta, 1875; first assistant resident, Hyderabad, March, 1876; political agent, and consul-general, Muscat, July, 1879; during the Afghan War, 1879-80, was on special political duty on the staff of Lieutenant-General Sir D. Stewart, and subsequently with General Hill's division, May, 1880, and with the Kabul-Kandahar force under General Roberts, Aug., 1880 (medal with two clasps, bronze star, brevet of lieutenant-colonel); acted as resident, Meywar, in 1882 and 1884; assistant political agent, Banswara, Dec., 1882; from May, 1883, served as additional political agent, Bhurtpur and Karauli; appointed consul-general at Zanzibar, 1888; K.C.B., Nov., 1890; appointed envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary at Tangiers, March, 1891.

EVANS, HENRY FARRINGTON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from May, 1870, to Sept., 1879, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 3rd grade, Sept., 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, April, 1880; officiating district and sessions judge, July, 1881; special judge, Jhansi, July, 1882; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Oct., 1882; district and sessions judge, Jan., 1887; on special duty in Madras and Bombay, Nov., 1890, to April, 1891, and as member of Deccan agriculturists relief act commission, Dec., 1891, to May, 1892.

EVANS, LOFTUS GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner, district judge, &c.; joint magistrate, Sept., 1886; judge, small cause court, Allahabad, March, 1891; district and sessions judge, April, 1891.
