EVANS-GORDON, WILLIAM EDEN, Captain, I.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, 15th July, 1876; admitted to Madras staff corps, 3rd July, 1877; from Feb., 1883, served under the foreign department of the government of India with the Central India horse; boundary settlement officer Central India, Oct., 1883, to March, 1884; and from the latter date served as officiating political assistant; attaché, foreign department, government of India, Oct., 1885; translator of foreign European languages in addition to other duties, Aug., 1887; assistant secretary, foreign department, Nov., 1887; appointed political officer in charge of Sardar Ayub Khan, March, 1888; assistant resident, Kashmir, and joint commissioner, Ladakh, Nov., 1890.

EVERETT, STEPHEN H., Audit Department, India Office.—Educated at Dulwich College; writer, India office, May, 1872; junior examiner, audit department, Dec., 1873.

EVERS, BENJAMIN, M.D., C.M., Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Medical Department, Central Provinces.—Joined the service, April, 1868; arrived in India, 27th Oct., 1868; served with
the 18th and 11th Native Infantry; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at various stations from April, 1876.

EWART, CHARLES HENRY, Colonel, I.S.C., Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 20th Feb., 1857; arrived in India, and April, 1857; from Feb., 1861, served in the police department, Punjab, as district superintendent, and was promoted to deputy inspector-general, 2nd grade, May, 1881, 1st grade, March, 1883; acting inspector general, and under secretary to government, police department, March, 1892.

EWBANK, ALFRED LLOYD VANDYKE, M.A., Education Department, Bengal.—Appointed, 16th Jan., 1868; arrived, 28th Feb., 1868; served as professor, Patna College, and as officiating inspector of schools; principal, Dacca College, March, 1876; and class, education department, Aug., 1878; professor, Patna College, Oct., 1879; principal, Patna College, Oct., 1881.

EYRE, GERVAS SELWYN, B.L., Major, I.S.C., Burma Commission.—1st commission, 12th June, 1869; served in military department until July, 1879, when he was appointed assistant commissioner in Burma; with the Burma field force, Nov., 1887; on special duty with the force operating against the Chins, May, 1888; deputy commissioner, May, 1888; Royal Humane Society's medal for saving lives of two brother officers.

FAGAN, PATRICK JAMES, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1887, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating district judge, &c.; officiating junior secretary to government, Oct.-Nov., 1890.

FAICHNIE, ALEXANDER GEORGE, Post Office Department, Central Provinces.—Joined the post office department, Jan., 1883; served for some time as superintendent of the Rawal Pindi military horse van, and bullock train; deputy postmaster-general, Central Provinces and Berar, Nov., 1879.

FAIRRIE, J. S., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Clapham Grammar School, and King's College, London; writer, India Office, 1st Jan., 1869; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

FAIRWEATHER, JAMES, M.D., Deputy Surgeon-General, late Medical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 20th March, 1856; in civil charge of Rawal Pindi and its jail, April, 1869; civil surgeon at Gurdaspur, April, 1874, and subsequently at various other stations in the Punjab; brigade surgeon, Nov., 1879; officiated as sanitary commissioner in 1878, 1879, and 1883; officiating surgeon-general, Punjab, April, 1885; officiating inspector-general of prisons, July, 1886; acted as medical adviser to His Highness the Maharaja of Patiala in 1884, 1885, and 1886; retired, 1886; has contributed papers on professional subjects to the 'Indian Medical Journal' and the 'Lancet.'

FANSHAWE, ARTHUR UPTON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, Nov., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, and acting commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and inspector-general of registration; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, July, 1880, and acted as secretary in 1880 and 1881; in charge of model farm, Nagpur, July, 1880, to Jan., 1881; from April, 1881, served in the postal department as officiating postmaster-general, Bombay, and was confirmed in this appointment, March, 1882; also officiated as director-general of the post office of India, Aug., 1884; officiating secretary to government of India, finance and commerce department, December, 1888; on special duty under government of India, home department, Jan., 1889; postmaster-general, 1st grade, Feb., 1888; director general of the post office of India, May, 1889.

FANSHAWE, HERBERT CHARLES, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Bedford, Tonbridge, and Repton; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1873, and was appointed assistant commissioner in the Punjab; served temporarily in Bengal on famine duty, Feb.-Nov., 1874; officiating settlement officer, Rohtak, Aug., 1875, to Feb., 1876, and again in 1877; acting under secretary to government, revenue department, Punjab, March, 1879; assistant to the officer on special duty in Kashmir, June to Sept., 1879; officiating junior secretary to government, Oct. to Dec., 1882, and again in 1883 and 1884; officiating secretary to government, Jan. to April, 1884, and again in 1888 and 1889; officiating junior secretary to government, Punjab, Dec., 1887, confirmed, Nov., 1888; revenue secretary to government of Punjab, March, 1890; officiated in 1890 as chief secretary; deputy commissioner, April, 1892; author of 'Rohtak Settlement Report,' and 'Punjab Famine Code.'

FARMER, HENRY RICHARD, Madras C.S.—Educated at Loughborough, Bromsgrove, and Uppingham Grammar Schools; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1868, and served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; acted as Tamil translator to government, Feb., 1880, to Sept., 1881; on special duty completing treatise on Madras Act viii. of 1865, July, 1882; acting district and sessions judge, Kurnool, Dec., 1887; Vizagapatnam, Nov., 1889.

FARQUHAR, WILLIAM, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., late Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 28th May, 1858; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1858, and served under the military department in Madras, Burma, and the Straits Settlements; also held civil medical charge, Toungboo, in 1859; medical officer, Ootacamund, from Nov., 1882; promoted to brigade surgeon, April, 1885; deputy surgeon-general, Belgaum and Western Districts, July, 1885; retired, July, 1890.

FARRAN, CHARLES FREDERICK, Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; called to the bar (Middle Temple), 1864; served as reporter, high court, Bombay, 1868-1874, also as acting government professor of law, April, 1868, to June, 1870, and Perry professor of jurisprudence, June, 1870, to Jan., 1872; acted as clerk of the crown, Sept., 1874, to Sept., 1876, and was confirmed in this appointment, May, 1880; acting advocate general, Bombay May-Dec., 1884; acted as
additional judge of the high court, Bombay, Nov., 1886 to Nov., 1887; appointed judge of the high court, April, 1890.

FARRAN, G. H., M.A., Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 17th May, 1866, as head assistant in the prothonotary's office, high court, Bombay, acting prothonotary, ecclesiastical and admiralty registrar, acting official assignee of the insolvent debtors' court, and acting clerk and sealer of the insolvent debtors' court; deputy registrar, commissioner for taking affidavits, and judge's clerk, Nov., 1873; assistant commissioner for taking accounts and assistant taxing master, July, 1876; has also acted as master and registrar in equity, commissioner for taking accounts, and taxing officer.

FARRELL, G., Surgeon-Colonel, C.B., late Punjab Medical Department.—Joined the service as surgeon, 4th Aug., 1856; deputy surgeon-general, Sept., 1886; officiating inspector-general to civil hospitals, Punjab, Nov., 1888, and was confirmed in the appointment, March, 1889; from Dec., 1888, to Feb., 1889, was honorary surgeon to the viceroy; retired, Sept., 1891.

FARRER, HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Heversham Grammar School, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1875; served in revenue and judicial department as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; postmaster-general, Madras, June, 1886.

FASSON, HERBERT JOHN HAMILTON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the High School, Quebec, and Bray College, Wicklow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector on famine relief duty at Dinagepore, March, 1874; assistant settlement officer, Chittagong, June, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1885.

FAULDER, CECIL JOSEPH SALKELD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1876; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, Dec., 1887; magistrate and collector, March, 1892.

FAWCETT, CHARLES GORDON HILL, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Harrow and Pembroke College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 9th Nov., 1890; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1891.

FAYRER, Sir Joseph, Surgeon-General, K.C.S.I., LL.D., M.D., F.R.S.S. (London and Edinburgh), F.R.C.P., F.R.C.S., Medical Board, India Office.—Acting assistant surgeon, R.N., Aug., 1847; assistant surgeon, royal artillery, 1849; joined the East India Company's service April, 1850, and served under the military department, also holding civil surgeoncy of Cheera Poonjee, Nov., 1850; served in the Burma campaign, and officiated as civil surgeon, Rangoon, Feb., 1853; appointed residency surgeon, Lucknow, by Lord Dalhousie, for services during war in Burma; honorary assistant resident at Lucknow, Sept., 1854; civil surgeon, Lucknow, March, 1856; brevet rank of surgeon for services in defence of Lucknow residency during the siege, Sept., 1858; officiating professor of surgery and ex-officio 1st surgeon of Medical College Hospital, Calcutta, May, 1859; confirmed in these appointments, June, 1860; medical charge of Mysore princes, June, 1860; fellow of University of Calcutta and member of the senate, March, 1861; served for two years as president of the medical faculty, and received the public thanks of the faculty; surgeon, July, 1863; consulting surgeon to Howrah General Hospital Nov., 1865; president of the Asiatic Society of Bengal, 1867; J.P. for Calcutta, Feb., 1868; government trustee for India Museum, 1860; officiating surgeon to viceroy, Jan.–Feb., 1869; accompanied H.R.H. the Duke of Edinburgh in his tour through India, Jan.–March, 1870; surgeon-major, June, 1870; honorary physician to the Queen, July, 1871; accompanied H.R.H. the Prince of Wales to India, 1875–76, in medical charge of his party; retired, 1874; president of medical board, India Office, Dec., 1874; member of army sanitary commission; member of senate of Army Medical School at Netley; consulting physician to Charing Cross Hospital; author of 'Clinical Surgery in India,' 'Clinical and Pathological Observations in India,' 'Thanatophobia of India' (presented to the Indian government, by whom it was published in 1872), and other works; has also published numerous papers, monographs, and addresses, on medical and scientific subjects.

FENNER, HENRY ALGERNON SHRAPNEL, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed 2nd assistant engineer, 20th June, 1861; 1st assistant engineer, April, 1865; executive engineer, Sept., 1868; 3rd superintending engineer, March, 1887; 2nd, Dec., 1889; 1st, July, 1891; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary to the government of the Punjab, Jan.–Feb., 1892.

FENTON, LAYARD LIVINGSTONE, Major, I.S.C., Bombay Political Department.—Joined the service, 8th Jan., 1870, and after serving under the military department, was transferred to the revenue survey department as assistant superintendent, Nov., 1873; assistant to political agent, Kathiawar, March, 1889; acting superintendent of surveys under the Rajasthanik court in 1885, 1887 and 1889; confirmed, Dec., 1890; acted as president of the court in 1891, and from May, 1892.

FENTON, MICHAEL WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 18th Nov., 1883, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Nov.–Dec., 1885; officiating under secretary to government, April, 1887; confirmed, Oct., 1887; assistant commissioner, Nov., 1891; author of 'Punjab Municipal Manual.'

FENTON, T. C., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 22nd May, 1873; attached to the store department till Aug., 1879, and subsequently to the registry department.
FERARD, Henry Cecil, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1885, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, Sept., 1890.

FERET, C. J., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd Jan., 1875.

FERGUSON, Henry Tanner, late Railway Department, Government of India.—Joined public works department as locomotive superintendent, Rangoon and Irrawaddy Valley railway, Oct., 1879; Punjab Northern state railway, Aug., 1881; class i, state railway, revenue establishment, Jan., 1886; deputy locomotive superintendent, North-Western railway, Jan., 1886; deputy locomotive superintendent, Eastern Bengal railway, Oct., 1887; officiating locomotive superintendent, Feb., 1888; retired, 1888.

FERGUSSON, Rt. Hon. Sir James Bart., G.C.S.I., K.C.M.G., C.I.E., M.P.—Born in 1832; educated at Rugby, and University College, Oxford; entered the Grenadier Guards, and served in the Crimean campaign, 1854-55 (medal and three clasps); retired from the army in 1855; represented the county of Ayr in parliament in the Conservative interest from Dec., 1854, to April, 1857, and from Oct., 1859 to 1868; under secretary of state for India, June, 1866, to July, 1867; under secretary for the home department, July, 1867, to Aug., 1868; governor of South Australia, Aug., 1868; governor of New Zealand, March, 1873-1874; governor of Bombay, April, 1880, to March, 1885; parliamentary under secretary of state, foreign office, Aug., 1886; royal commissioner for the Adelaide Exhibition of 1887; postmaster-general, Sept., 1891, to Aug., 1892.

FERRAR, Michael Lloyd, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Belfast Academical Institution, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 21st Jan., 1863; from Jan., 1864, to Sept., 1865, served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Oudh, Sept., 1865, and served as assistant commissioner; from July, 1868, to April, 1875, served in the settlement department, and was appointed to take up lands for railway purposes in Lucknow, Aug., 1870; officiating commissioner, Fyzabad, in 1882 and 1883, and 1889; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1883; magistrate and collector, March, 1884; officiating commissioner, Fyzabad, April, 1889; commissioner in Oudh, Aug., 1890; officiating commissioner, Gorakhpur, April, 1891; confirmed, July, 1891.

FFINCH, Benjamin Traill, Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indo-European telegraph department, 5th Nov., 1857; deputy director of the Persian Gulf section, from April, 1875; director Persian Gulf section, March, 1884; also acted as assistant political agent, Gwadur, Aug., 1879, and as political agent, Aug., 1884; employed in connection with renewals of Persian Gulf telegraph cables, 1890.

FIDDIAN, James Pauli, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Birmingham Grammar School, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1875, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Bellary, Dec., 1884; also acted as collector and magistrate, and district and sessions judge; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1885; collector and magistrate, Jan., 1892.

FIDDIAN, William, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Huddersfield College, Shrewsbury Grammar School, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868; served in revenue and judicial department, Bengal; on famine duty, May, 1874; officiating commissioner, Soonderbunds, Jan., 1879; joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1880; magistrate and collector, April, 1886.

FIELD, Charles Dickenson, M.A., LL.D., Barrister-at-Law, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 11th Oct., 1860; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating judge of the principal court of small causes, Kishnaghur and Jessore, officiating magistrate and collector, and registrar, high court (July, 1867); from Dec., 1870, served in the judicial department, and was placed on special duty in connection with a commission to consider the question of amending the rent law of Bengal, May, 1879; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Oct., 1879; lieutenant-governor's council, Dec., 1879; judge, high court, Oct., 1880; retired, Sept., 1886; author of 'Rent Law Procedure in Bengal,' 'Essays on Indian Topics,' 'Chronological Table of, and Index to, the Indian Statute Book,' 'The Law of Evidence in British India,' 'The Law relating to Protestant Curates,' 'The Regulations of the Bengal Code,' 'A Digest of the Law of Landlord and Tenant in Bengal,' and 'Landholding and the Relation of Landlord and Tenant in various Countries.'

FIELD, George A., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; supernumerary writer, 30th May, 1859; clerk in registry department, Sept., 1860; employed in military department, 1867; assistant to registrar, March, 1882.

FILGATE, Alexander Jerome, Colonel, R.E. late Public Works Department, India.—First commission, 1857; served in the China war, 1860 (medal and clasps); joined the Madras public works department, Oct., 1863, as assistant engineer, South Canara; deputy controller, public works accounts, July, 1865; deputy consulting engineer for railways, and examiner of accounts, Feb., 1866; from March, 1867, served in the public works department of the Government of India, as assistant accountant-general; deputy accountant-general, and ex-officio under secretary to government, March, 1872; officiating accountant-general and deputy secretary to government of India, March, 1879, to Nov., 1880; confirmed as accountant-general, and deputy secretary, Sept., 1881; member of finance committee, April, 1886, to March, 1887; retired, Nov., 1890.
FINUCANE, MICHAEL, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Munchin's College, Limerick, Limerick Collegiate Academy, and Queen's College, Cork; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1872; manager, Raj Durbhunga, Sept., 1879; settlement officer, Jan., 1880; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, judicial, political, and appointment departments, Jan., 1882; on special duty, Midnapore, May, 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Feb., 1884; director of the agricultural department in Bengal, Dec., 1884; member, central examination committee, April, 1886; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1888; 1st grade, May, 1891; edited Bengal Tenancy Act viii, of 1885.

FIREBRACE, FREDERICK, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, Dec., 1861; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces, May, 1865; assistant principal, Roorkee College, 1865-68; officiating assistant consulting engineer for railways, Bengal, May, 1868; manager, Calcutta and S.E. railway, Feb., 1870; executive engineer, Sept., 1870; Neemuch railway survey, Feb., 1871; assistant director of state railways, March, 1875; manager, Rajputana state railway, Nov., 1876; 1st class, state railway revenue establishment, April, 1877; on duty at the Royal Engineering College, Cooper's Hill, Sept., 1878, to Nov., 1879; under secretary to government of India, railway branch, Jan., 1880; superintending engineer, 2nd class, July, 1885; 1st class, March, 1889; chief engineer, 3rd class, July, 1891, and Jan., 1892; consulting engineer and joint secretary to government (railway branch), Bombay, Feb., 1887; author of a 'Manual of Surveying.'

FISCHER, FRANCIS NORTON, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1889, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

FISHER, CECIL, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived 15th Dec., 1890, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

FISHER, FREDERICK HENRY, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Boston Grammar School, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent and small cause judge of Dehra Dun, March, 1879; officiating civil and sessions judge, Saharanpur, Oct., 1881; on special duty in connection with the preparation of the 'N.W. Provinces Gazetteer,' Dec., 1881; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1885; retired, Aug., 1885.

FISHER, JOHN HADDEN, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of
1860; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1861; from June, 1853, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating small cause court judge; from Jan., 1872, to April, 1879, served in the Central Provinces as deputy commissioner; from April, 1879, served in the N.W. Provinces as joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade; magistrate and collector, April, 1880; retired, July, 1890.

FISHER, WILLIAM ROGERS, B.A., Forest Department, N.W. Provinces.—Appointed assistant conservator, 28th Sept., 1872; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1872; deputy director of forest school, Dehra Dun, April, 1881, and Feb., 1884; conservator and director of the school, March, 1885; conservator of the 3rd grade, Dec., 1888; 2nd grade, May, 1890; assistant professor of forestry, Cooper's Hill College, from Nov., 1890; editor of 'The Indian Forester,' and author of a translation of the 'Aménagement des Forêts.'

FITZGERALD, EDWARD AMBROSE, Brigade Surgeon, late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 27th July, 1859; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1860, and was employed under the military department, 1860-68; from Feb., 1868, served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon and superintendent of jail, Jaunpur; rank of surgeon, July, 1871; surgeon-major, July, 1873; served subsequently as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at various stations in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh; brigade surgeon, Dec., 1887; retired, March, 1890.

FITZGERALD, SIR GERALD, K.C.M.G., Admiralty, late Financial Department of the Government of India.—Educated at St. Mary's College, Galway, and in France; appointed to the late ordnance office, Aug., 1855; junior clerk, war office, Jan., 1856; was estimate clerk, war office, 1861-1863; assistant commissioner for the investigation of the system of accounts in the public works department, India, Sept., 1863; officiating deputy comptroller-general of military expenditure, March, 1864; transferred to the financial department, India, Feb., 1868; personal assistant to financial member of governor-general's council, July, 1869; assistant comptroller-general, Aug., 1869; officiating deputy comptroller-general, Sept., 1870; deputy accountant-general, Madras, April, 1871; in charge of the office of accountant-general, British Burmah, Dec., 1871; officiating deputy comptroller-general, March, 1872; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Aug., 1872; and deputy comptroller-general, Nov., 1876; allowed to accept temporary service under the Egyptian government, Jan., 1877, and appointed director-general of accounts in Egypt, Dec., 1878, and member of the committee of finance, 13th March, 1884; accountant-general of the navy, 1st June, 1885, and deputy and assistant to the parliamentary and financial secretary, by order in council of 18th Nov., 1885; was attached to the intelligence department for the military operations at Alexandria in 1882; commissioner of the royal patriotic fund; member of the pensions commutation board; C.M.G. in 1880, and K.C.M.G. in 1885; 3rd class of the order of Osmanieh, 1880; 2nd class of the order of the Medjidie, 1884; grand cordon of the order of the Medjidie, 1885; war medal and Egyptian bronze star for service in the Egyptian campaign, 1882.

FITZGERALD, JAMES, Colonel, I.S.C., late Berar Commission.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, June, 1856; arrived in India, Sept., 1856; was employed under the military department up to 1862, including service in the mutiny, 1857-59, and was present at the siege and capture of Delhi (medal and clasp); served in the China war, 1860, and was present at the capture of Pekin (medal and two clasps); from Aug., 1862, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, railway magistrate, and deputy commissioner; retired, April, 1880.

FITZGERALD, JAMES RICHARD, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Uppingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Aug., 1875, served under the foreign department, government of India, as assistant general superintendent, thagi and dakaiti department, and assistant to resident, Hyderabad; on special duty in connection with control of Moghias, Jan., 1878; political assistant, 1st class, March, 1878; officiating 1st assistant and secretary for Berar to resident, Hyderabad, March, 1882; held charge of the office of resident, May, 1882; from July, 1882, served in Ajmere, as assistant commissioner, and acted as commissioner, Aug.-Oct., 1882; magistrate of the district of Ajmere, Oct., 1882; first assistant, governor-general's agent, Biluchistan, May, 1883; political agent, 3rd class, Oct., 1883; held charge of the agent's office in 1883-84, and of the Kalat political agency, Nov.-Dec., 1884; from April, 1885, acted as 1st assistant and secretary for Berar, Hyderabad; retired, 1888.

FITZGERALD, Sir W. GERALD SEYMOUR VESLEY, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., India Office.—Educated at Harrow, and Oriel College, Oxford; called to the bar (Lincoln's Inn, 1865); private secretary to governor of Bombay, 1867-72; political aide-de-camp to the secretary of state for India, 14th Aug., 1874; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; K.C.I.E., Aug., 1887.

FITZMAURICE, JOHN DAY STOKES, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, Jan., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1884; forest settlement officer, May, 1886; acting assistant judge and sessions judge, July, 1887.

FITZPATRICK, Sir DENNIS, B.A., K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and small cause court judge, and was placed on special duty in England in connection with Begum Sumroe's case, March, 1869, and at Calcutta in the legislative department of government of India, May, 1873; deputy secretary to the government of India in the legislative department, 1874; secretary in the legislative department from 1877 to 1885; was also secretary to the governor-general's council; acted as judge of the chief court, Punjab, in 1876-77, and as secretary to government of India, home department, Jan.-April, 1885; acting chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Dec., 1885; C.S.I.,
Feb., 1887; member of the public service commission, 1887, and acting resident in Mysore; chief commissioner of Assam, Sept., 1887; resident at Hyderabad, Aug., 1889; lieutenant-governor of the Punjab, March, 1892; K.C.S.I., May, 1890.

FLEET, JOHN FAITHFULL, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, educational inspector, acting assistant political agent, and acting collector and magistrate; first assistant collector, Dec., 1878; on special duty in England, Jan.–May, 1879, and again in 1884 and 1885; epigraphist to the government of India, Jan., 1883; junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Sholapur, June, 1886; senior collector, Nov., 1889; acting commissioner, Dec., 1891.

FLEMING, ALLAN STOPFORD, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Harrow, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1882, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner; officiating under secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1888; deputy commissioner, April, 1890.

FLETCHER, WILLIAM MORRIS, Revenue Survey Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India 2nd June, 1865, and served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant superintendent of revenue survey, acting assistant settlement officer, and acting deputy superintendent of survey; on special duty in connection with the famine, Nov., 1876; superintendent of survey, Sept., 1879; acted as survey and settlement commissioner in 1891, and from Jan., 1892.

FOORD, EDWARD ARCHIBALD, Lieutenant-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—Second lieutenant, Madras Engineers, 9th Dec., 1842; arrived in India, July, 1844; assistant civil engineer, Oct., 1846; adjutant of engineers, 1850–52; assistant to secretary board of revenue, public works department, Madras, Aug., 1852; served as 1st class district engineer in South Arcot and Tanjore, Dec., 1856, to May, 1863; superintending engineer, Tanjore and Trichinopoly, May, 1863; inspecting engineer for civil and military buildings, Madras, Dec., 1872; superintending engineer, Kista and Nellore, June, 1874; deputy chief engineer and under secretary to government of Madras, Dec., 1875; chief engineer, 2nd class, and joint secretary to government, buildings and roads branch, Feb., 1877; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government, public works department, April, 1877; resigned the public works department and retired from the army, 31st Dec., 1878.

FOOTE, ROBERT BRUCE, F.G.S., late Geological Survey of India.—Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined 28th Sept., 1858; served in various districts of the Madras Presidency, the Nizam's territory, and Bombay; deputed to Vienna Exhibition in joint charge of the survey collections, 1873; 1st grade officer, April, 1876; deputy superintendent, June, 1881; fellow of the Madras University and member of the faculty of engineering, 1884; designation changed to superintendent of survey, Sept., 1885; officiated as director in 1887; retired, Oct., 1891; author of various contributions to the survey publications.

FORBES, ARTHUR, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sedbergh School, Yorkshire, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, Dec., 1867; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Sept., 1873; also secretary to the central relief committee, Jan., 1874; assistant commissioner in Assam, Nov., 1874, to May, 1876; on special duty at Sibsaugor, Jan., 1876; joint magistrate and deputy collector, May, 1878; junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1882; magistrate and collector, May, 1887; officiating commissioner of excise, March, 1890; commissioner, Patna, June, 1892.

FORBES, ARTHUR TREVOR, Madras C.S.—Educated at Thame Grammar School, Oxford, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in Madras, 18th Oct., 1887, and served as assistant to magistrate and collector.

FORBES, GEORGE FORREST GREENLAW, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1883, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Nov., 1889.

FORBES, GEORGE STUART, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen Grammar School and University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1872, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting principal assistant, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue; from Sept., 1880, to Jan., 1883, was employed in the Madras secretariat as acting under secretary in the revenue department, assistant secretary, judicial and legislative department, and under secretary in the departments under the chief secretary, and also served on the board of examiners from Jan., 1882; from Jan., 1883, served under the government of India in the home department as officiating under secretary, also in the foreign department, on special duty, Dec., 1884, and as junior under secretary, Jan., 1885; also in charge of duties of press commissioner, March, 1885; officiating under secretary to government of India, foreign department, March, 1887; 1st assistant and secretary for Berar to the resident at Hyderabad; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Sept., 1888; district and sessions judge, April, 1890; collector and magistrate, Jan., 1891.

FORBES, JOHN GREENLAW, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, 9th Dec., 1854; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1857; during the mutiny, 1857–58, served at the siege of Delhi, the relief of Lucknow, the siege and capture of Lucknow, and various engagements (medal and three clasps); served in the public works department, Punjab, from 21st June, 1858, as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and from July, 1863, in the N.W. Provinces; on special duty in the Madras Presidency, Feb.,
1867, reporting on the Kaveri, Krishna, and Godavari canals; superintendent of irrigation works, Oudh, Dec., 1867; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Oudh, July to Nov., 1872; from Nov., 1872, served as superintending engineer in the irrigation branch in the N.W. Provinces, in the Punjab (Bari Doab Canal), and in Bengal (Sone circle), and officiated as chief engineer and joint secretary, irrigation branch, Bengal, May to July, 1877; on special duty under the government of India to prepare a revised scheme for the Sardar canal, June, 1878; on special duty on the Scinde, Punjab, and Delhi, and Indus valley railways, Nov., 1878; superintending engineer and secretary to resident, Hyderabad, Dec., 1879; chief engineer and joint secretary, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, buildings and roads branch, April, 1881, and in the irrigation branch from Nov., 1881; chief engineer, and class, March, 1886; 1st class, March, 1887; secretary to governor of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Nov., 1887; officiated as inspector-general of irrigation and deputy-secretary to government of India, public works department, Feb.-May, 1889; confirmed, Dec., 1889; secretary in the same department, Nov., 1890; reverted to military department, Aug., 1892.

FORBES, L. R., late Bengal Non-Regulation Commission.—Served in the judicial department, Bengal, from March, 1864, and on the 1st May, 1875, was appointed assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1887, and at the Chittagong Hill Tracts, Jan., 1888; retired, March, 1891.

FORBES, WILLIAM A., C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1847; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the N.W. Provinces, Punjab, and Oude; served as political officer throughout the mutiny; medal with clasp for Lucknow; magistrate and collector, Jaunpore, 1862; commissioner, Allahabad division, 1872; officiated as member, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces; retired, 1875.

FORBES, WALTER ERNEST, Colonel, I.S.C., late Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as lieutenant, Bengal artillery, 13th April, 1859; served from Oct., 1860, in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating settlement officer; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1876; commissioner, Lucknow division, July, 1883; Fyzabad division, Oct., 1883; retired, June, 1889; author of report of the Partabgarh Settlement.

FORD, ERNEST, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at St. Paul's School, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 6th Dec., 1890, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

FORD, WILLIAM, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1842; arrived in India, 7th July, 1842; attached to the N.W. Provinces, and served in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner and joint magistrate and deputy collector; on special duty in the Sikh states, April, 1846; assistant to the governor-general's agent, N.W. Frontier, May, 1846; served subsequently in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and superintendent, ciss-Sutlej territory, and officiating deputy commissioner; magistrate and collector, Gurgaon, 1856; deputy commissioner, 1st class, 1858; deputed on special duty to Cashmere, March-Nov., 1860; commissioner and superintendent, Hissar division, Oct., 1864; Mooltan division, March, 1865; placed in charge of the state of Bhawalpoor, 1866; retired 1869; author of a report on native government as contrasted with the English system.

FORDHAM, JOHN WILLIAM, late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department as assistant accountant, July, 1859; assistant controller, July, 1869; deputy controller, Holkar and Neemuch state railways, Dec., 1871; examiner, 4th class, Jan., 1880; ditto, 2nd grade, Sept., 1881, and 1st grade, Feb., 1884; officiating examiner of accounts, Rajputana-Malwa railway, Sept., 1884; examiner, 3rd class, May, 1886; retired, 1889.

FORREST, GEORGE WALTER, B.A., Director of Records, Calcutta.—Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge; joined the service, 19th Dec., 1872, as head master, high school, Surat; acted at various periods as professor of history and political economy, Elphinstone College, and professor of English literature, Deccan College; professor of mathematics, Deccan College, July, 1879; acting census commissioner for Bombay, 1882; on special duty in connection with the Bombay records, 1884-6; professor of English history, Elphinstone College, Aug., 1887; in addition, director of records, Bombay, April, 1888; professor of English literature, Elphinstone College, March, 1889; officer in charge of records of the government of India, March, 1891; author of 'Articles on Indian Finance,' 'Selections from Bombay State Papers (Maharatta Series),' 'Selections from Bombay State Papers (Home Series),' 'Selections from the State Papers preserved in the Foreign Office of the Government of India, 1772-1785,' and 'The Administration of Warren Hastings'; has also edited, with a memoir, 'Selections from the writings of Mountstuart Elphinstone.'

FORSYTH, WILLIAM, F.R.C.S., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 9th May, 1876, and served at various stations as civil medical officer; officiating health officer, Calcutta, April, 1891; confirmed, March, 1892.

FOSTER, CHARLES J., General, C.B.—Served with the 16th Lancers during the campaign in Afghanistan under Lord Keane, including the siege and capture of Ghuznee (medal); served also at the battle of Maharajpore, 9th Dec., 1843 (bronze star); and in the campaign on the Sutlej in 1846, including the battles of Buddiwal, Aliwal (as aide-de-camp to Brigadier Cureton), and Sobraon (medal and clasp); appointed to the council of the secretary of state for India, July, 1878; retired, 1888.

FOSTER, HERBERT WILLIAM, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Liverpool Institute, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1882, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting principal assistant collector and magistrate, and acting registrar, high court; head assistant, Jan., 1890; registrar, high court (appellate side), Dec., 1890.
FOSTER, WILLIAM, B.A., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd Sept., 1832; B.A., London University, 1838; editor, India Office List, from Aug., 1891; in 1892 assisted in editing 'The Register of Letters, etc.,' of the East India Company, 1600-10.

FOSTER, WILLIAM SHRUBSOLE, M.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; served in Madras from Nov., 1861, as assistant magistrate and collector, and sub-collector; fellow of university of Madras, April, 1873; collector and magistrate and political agent, Godaveri, April, 1875; retired, 1885.

FOWLER, JAMES TOWNSHEND, F.R.G.S., F.S.A., late Education Department, Madras.—Principal, government normal school, Madras, 2nd Dec., 1855; fellow of Madras university, Sept., 1857; on special duty superintending formation of normal schools, May, 1858; from Jan., 1859, served as inspector of schools, and was promoted to 1st class of educational department April, 1880; on special duty to Calcutta as member of the educational committee, Feb., 1882, and again, Aug., 1882, to March, 1883; acting director of public instruction, Madras, April-June, 1883; retired, Dec., 1888.

FOX, CHARLES EDMUND, Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Burma.—Officiated as government advocate, British Burma, 1879-80, and 1884-5, and as additional recorder, Rangoon, Dec., 1885 to Jan., 1886, and Jan., 1888; confirmed as government advocate, March, 1886.

FOX, CHARLES EDWARD, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 9th Jan., 1866, as master and registrar in equity, commissioner for taking accounts and local investigations, and taxing officer, high court, Bombay.

FOX, FRANCIS WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Independent College, Taunton, and Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873, and served in the Central Provinces, and from March, 1877, in Burma, as assistant commissioner; superintendent of central jail, Moulmein, in 1877 and 1878; transferred to N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1883, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, and acting district and sessions judge; assistant commissioner, 2nd class, Jhansi, May, 1885, 1st class, Nov., 1887; judge of the small cause court, Allahabad, Jan., 1889; district and sessions judge, April, 1890.

FOX, G. J. B., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 6th July, 1877.

FOX-STRANGWAYS, MAURICE WALTER, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Charterhouse, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1882; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Nagpur, Nov., 1882; assistant commissioner, Oct., 1887; settlement officer, Nov., 1887; judge, small cause court, Jan., 1892; commissioner of excise, March, 1892; deputy commissioner, April, 1892.

FOXTON, WILLIAM, B.A. (Oxon), late Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd Aug., 1857; from Oct., 1857, served in the educational department as acting professor at the Poona and Elphinstone College, and head master of the English school, Ahmednagar, and was appointed tutor to ex-Amers of Hyderabad, Sind, July, 1860; from Oct., 1860, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, deputy collector of income tax, acting judge and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; appointed judge of the court of small causes, cantonment magistrate, and superintendent of jail, Karachi, also Sindi translator to government, May, 1876; acting collector of customs and shipping master, Karachi, and assistant collector of salt revenue in Sind, April, 1886; retired, April, 1887.

FRANCIS, EDWARD BELCHAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Repton Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; transferred temporarily to Bengal on famine duty, Feb. to Nov., 1874; officiating superintendent of Chamba, April to Aug., 1879; officiating secretary to financial commissioner, Aug., 1879, and again in 1883-84; officiating judicial assistant in various districts, 1880-83; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Feb., 1885; 1st grade, May, 1887; deputy commissioner, May, 1889.

FRANCIS, FREDERICK WILLIAM, Hyderabad Administration.—Joined the service 15th Sept., 1873, as assistant superintendent, Bombay revenue survey; divisional inspector, land records and agriculture, Dharwar, May, 1891; director of land records and agriculture, Hyderabad, Aug., 1891.

FRANCIS, WALTER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 11th Nov., 1890, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

FRANKLIN, BENJAMIN, M.D., Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Medical Department.—First commission, April, 1869; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869; civil surgeon in Oudh, Dec., 1869, to June, 1876; superintendent, Central Prison, Lucknow, July, 1876; on special duty with the Viceroy, Dec., 1880; civil surgeon of Simla, Dec., 1881, to Nov., 1886; honorary surgeon on the personal staff of the Viceroy, Jan., 1886; on special duty with the lieutenant-governor of the Punjab, Nov., 1886, to March, 1887; civil surgeon and superintendent of lunatic asylum, Jubbulpore, Oct., 1887.

FRANKS, CHARLES N. B., Public Works Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 19th Nov., 1856; junior clerk, railway department, India Office, 1860; senior clerk, Feb., 1875.

FRANKS, EDWARD, Military Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 1st Sept., 1858; junior clerk, financial department, India Office, Dec., 1866; funds department, 1867; senior clerk, military department, Aug., 1881.

FRASER, ALEXANDER, General, C.B., R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 8th Dec., 1843; joined the public works department, Sept., 1850, as executive engineer, Lower Provinces; executive engineer, Arracan, 1853; and subsequently at Rangoon; garrison engi-
FRASER, Henry, Colonel, late Police Department, Central Provinces.—First commission, Madras cavalry, 1854; arrived in India, 14th March, 1854; assistant to general superintendent, thagi and dakaiti department, Nagpur, July, 1860; joint magistrate, Nagpur and Berars, Aug., 1861; from Nov., 1861, served in the police department, Central Provinces; acted as inspector general, July-Aug., 1868; 1st class, district superintendent, Nov., 1885; reverted to military duty, 1890.

FRASER, Hugh, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wellington College, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, June, 1885; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Feb., 1888; acting registrar of high court, N.W. Provinces, in 1883; confirmed, April, 1886; on special duty in secretariat, Nov., 1891, to April, 1892; deputy commissioner, March, 1892; magistrate and collector, April, 1892.

FRASER, James Denholm, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Christ's Hospital, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1891, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

FRASER, Stuart Mitford, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1885; forest settlement officer, Aug., 1887; tutor and guardian to the Raja of Kholapur, the Chief of Kagal, and Kunvar Saheb of Bhavnagar, May, 1889.

FRAZER, Robert Watson, B.A., LL.B., M.R.I.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Rathmines School, Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1877, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, engineer and manager of the Parla Kumed estate (Jan.-Feb., 1882), acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting deputy director of revenue settlement; retired, 1886.

FREMANTLE, Selwyn Howe, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived, 27th Nov., 1890, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

FRENCH, Francis Coope, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Marlborough and Eton, and at Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1889, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner.

FRIZELLE, Joseph, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1863, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Punjab, May, 1864, and served as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating small
cause court judge, and officiating cantonment magistrate; judicial assistant, July, 1876; deputy commissioner, April, 1877; divisional judge, and grade, Nov., 1884; officiating judge, chief court, Punjab, June, 1888; divisional judge, 1st grade, and additional judge of chief court, March, 1889; confirmed as judge of chief court, May, 1889.

FROST, CHARLES EVITT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Kensington Grammar School, and foreign schools; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate and political agent, acting railway magistrate, and acting forest settlement officer; second assistant collector, Dec., 1884; first assistant collector, Aug., 1887; junior collector and magistrate, Nov., 1891.

FRY, HENRY J. W., B.A., Store Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 18th Aug., 1873; B.A. (Honours in Logic and Moral Philosophy), London University, 1875.

FRY, THOMAS DUNCAN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1889, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

FRYER, FREDERICK WILLIAM RICHARD, B.L., C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at foreign schools, and at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and settlement officer; officiating settlement secretary to financial commissioner, Oct., 1875; judicial assistant, April, 1877; on special duty with the Quetta field force, Oct., 1878, and again, Feb., 1879; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1882; officiating superintendent, Kapurthala state, May, 1883; commissioner in Burma, Aug., 1886; financial commissioner, Burma, June, 1888; C.S.I., May, 1890; retransferred to Punjab, and appointed commissioner and superintendent, March, 1891; officiating chief commissioner, Burma, from May, 1892; author of 'A Report on the Settlement of the Dera Ghazi Khan District.'

FRYER, W. H., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, 25th July, 1892.

FULLER, JOSEPH BAMPFYLDE, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1875; from Nov., 1875, to July, 1882, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and acting joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed on special duty as assistant director of agriculture and commerce, Feb., 1878; transferred to Central Provinces, July, 1882, and appointed acting director of agriculture and commerce, and acting junior secretary to the chief commissioner; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Aug., 1882; commissioner of settlements and agriculture, Oct., 1885; also junior secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1890; C.I.E., Jan., 1892; author of 'A Primer of Agriculture,' and 'Field and Garden Crops of the N.W. Provinces and Oudh.'

FULTON, EDMUND McGILDDOWN HOPE, Bombay C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Rugby School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial department as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner, branch inspector-general of registration and educational inspector in Sind, acting judge and sessions judge, and agent for Sardars in the Deccan; appointed registrar of the high court, Bombay, Feb., 1881; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Feb., 1886; transferred to Lower Burma as judicial commissioner, May, 1891.

FURLONG, MALCOLM, Colonel, I.S.C., late Burma Commission.—Joined the Madras army as ensign, and arrived in India, 10th Feb., 1857; served at the capture of Copul, 1858, and with the Bellary movable column, 1859 (medal); personal assistant to inspector-general of police, Burma, June, 1865; served in the Burma commission from Aug., 1867, as assistant commissioner, assistant secretary to the chief commissioner (July, 1869, to Feb., 1871), and town magistrate of Prome; from Jan., 1880, acted as deputy commissioner of Moulmein, also officiating as judge in 1880; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, May, 1884; president, Moulmein municipal committee, Jan., 1885; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Dec., 1888; retired, 1891.

FURNIVALL, W. C., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, May, 1869, as supervising engineer on the Delhi and Rewari railway; 1st grade superintending engineer, Rajputana railway, March, 1874; under secretary to government of India, railway branch, Oct., 1873, in charge of Rajputana railway as engineer-in-chief; officiating director of railways, central system, and joint secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, May, 1877; joint secretary and officiating chief engineer, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1879; director of construction for state railways, March, 1880; chief engineer, and secretary to chief commissioner, British Burma, Oct., 1880; services lent to the Bengal Central, and Bengal and N.W. railway companies, May, 1883; Nizam's guaranteed railway company, March, 1884; chief engineer, 2nd class (supernumerary), March, 1882; retired from public works department, 1886.

GABBETT, POOLE ROBERT, Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Madras Medical Department.—Joined the service in Oct., 1871, and served in the Madras presidency; served in England (Woolwich), Jan., 1877; at Gibraltar, March, 1881; in Egypt with expeditionary force, Feb., 1885; in England, June, 1885; in the Madras presidency, March, 1889; appointed surgeon to His Excellency the Governor, Jan., 1891.

GAFFNEY, JOHN BURKE, Brig.-Surg.-Lieut.-Colonel, Medical Department, Central Provinces.—Appointed to the Indian medical service, 1st Oct., 1866, having previously served as assistant surgeon, Her Majesty's home service, 1864-65; arrived in India, 27th April, 1867; was employed under the military department, including service in the Nicobar expedition, 1867; house surgeon, medical college hospital, Calcutta, March, 1868; from June, 1868, served in the Central Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, and assistant to the deputy commissioner, Upper Godavary district; from June, 1878, served as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at Raipur, and afterwards at Seoni and Saugor.
GAISFORD, Gilbert, Major, I.S.C., Foreign Department, Government of India.—Joined the service 22nd Feb., 1868; admitted to staff corps, March, 1870; from May, 1870, served with the Punjab frontier force, and throughout the Jowaki expedition, 1877-8 (medal); assistant superintendent of levies in Baluchistan, April, 1883; assistant political officer on expedition to Zhob, Sept., 1884; officiating political agent, Quetta, April, 1889 confirmed, Feb., 1891; served throughout the Afghan war, 1878-80 (medal).

GAIT, Edward Albert, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1884, and served as assistant commissioner in Assam; provincial superintendent of census operations, 1890; acted as secretary to the chief commissioner, Oct., 1891, to Jan., 1892.

GAITSKELL, Arthur, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Cheltenham, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Burma division of the Bengal civil service, after open competition of 1887; arrived in Burma, 9th Dec., 1889, and served as assistant commissioner.

GALBRAITH, Edgar, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portora Royal School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent and small cause court judge, Dehra Dun, March, 1885; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Dec., 1886; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, June, 1889; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Feb., 1890; has officiated as district and sessions judge, magistrate and collector, and inspector-general of registration and stamps and excise commissioner.

GALTON, Charles Arthur, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley, Magdalen Grammar School, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, 10th Nov., 1863; served in Madras from Aug., 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant commissioner (Nilgiri Hills), acting under secretary to government in the revenue department (March, 1872, to March, 1873), secretary to the board of revenue (Oct., 1879, to March, 1881, and in 1881-82), and acting collector of sea customs at Madras, and protector of emigrants; district and sessions judge, Dec., 1883; collector and magistrate, Oct., 1884; district and sessions judge, Nov., 1885; acting commissioner of salt and abkari revenue, April, 1886; acting additional member, board of revenue; acting secretary to government, revenue department, July, 1888; confirmed, Nov., 1888.

GAMBLE, James Sykes, M.A., F.L.S., Forest Department, North-Western Provinces.—Educated at Magdalen college, Oxford; appointed assistant conservator of forests, Oct., 1871; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1871, and served in British Burma; transferred to Bengal, Aug., 1872; served under the government of India as assistant to the inspector-general of forests, April, 1877, to Jan., 1879; deputy conservator, Bengal, July, 1880; conservator, 3rd grade, Sept., 1882; transferred to Madras, Dec., 1882; conservator, 2nd grade, Dec., 1887; transferred to N.W. Provinces as conservator of school circle, and director of the Forest school, Dehra Dun, Oct., 1890; 1st grade conservator, Feb., 1892.

GAMBLE, Reginald Arthur, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1885; transferred to financial department, government of India, as acting assistant controller of India treasuries, Nov., 1889; acting deputy accountant general, Allahabad, June, 1890; officiating under secretary in the finance and commerce department, Jan., 1891.

GANPATRAO BHASKAR, Rao Bahadur, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from Aug., 1874, as 4th judge of the court of small causes, Bombay; appointed 3rd judge, May, 1888; and 2nd judge, May, 1889.

GANPATRAO DAMODHAR PANSE, Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, and assistant collector and magistrate, 13th Dec., 1881; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, June, 1884; and assistant collector and magistrate, Dec., 1890.

GARBETT, Colin Hubert, Colonel, I.S.C.—First commission in army, 27th June, 1859; from 4th Dec., 1866, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1879.

GARBETT, Hubert, late Public Works Department, Punjab.—Joined the public works department, Nov., 1854; executive engineer, Bari Doab canal, Feb., 1860; Western Jumna canal, Aug., 1863; executive engineer, 1st grade, on the inundation canals, Punjab, Feb., 1870; superintendent of works, Derajat circle, Punjab, 1870; superintending engineer, July, 1878; superintending engineer, Bari Doab circle, Jan., 1880; and in the Derajat circle, April, 1882; superintending engineer, and class, March, 1881; officiated as superintending engineer, 1st class, at intervals, from May, 1881; retired, 1890.

GARDINER, John William, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Lycée Imperial Bonaparte, Paris; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty under financial department of government of India, Sept.-Nov., 1873; again on special duty, Nov., 1880; promoted to judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1880, and to deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1885; settlement officer in addition to his own duties, March, 1887; officiating divisional judge, Rawul Pindi, June, 1888; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, April, 1889; retired, Nov., 1889.

GARDINER, Richard, Major, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, 8th Jan., 1868; 2nd assistant engineer, Rajputana state railway, 10th Nov., 1870; 1st assistant engineer, Sept., 1872; executive engineer, Western Rajputana section, Feb., 1875; deputy manager, Class ii., state railway revenue...
establishment, July, 1882; in the office of director-general of railways, Jan., 1885; officiating under secretary to government of India, public works department, railway branch, Nov., 1886; manager and engineer-in-chief, Bhavnagar-Gondal railway, June, 1887; also charge of Morvi railway, June, 1887.

GARRETT, ANNESEY JOHN, Lieut.-Colonel, I.S.C., Hyderabad Administration.—Educated at Marlborough; first commission, 29th May, 1866; military secretary to the resident, Hyderbad, March, 1890.

GARRETT, CHARLES BAZETT, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 2nd March, 1858; from Jan., 1859, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating registrar of assurances, district and sessions judge, and magistrate and collector; judge of the principal court of small causes in Nuddea and Jessore, Dec., 1882; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Feb., 1883; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs in 1884, 1888, and 1891.

GARRETT, H. W., Political Department, India Office.—Educated at the King's School, Ely; clerk, and class, accountant general's department, India office, 12th April, 1882; transferred for service in the political department, June, 1890.

GARRETT, JAMES HUGH ELIOT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Reading Grammar School, Clifton College and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1887, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

GARSTIN, JOHN HENRY, C.S.I., Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived, 1st Dec., 1857; served in revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed private secretary to H.E. Lord Napier, March, 1866; acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Jan., 1871; collector and magistrate, South Arcot, and political agent, Pondicherry, May, 1871; served as acting secretary, and additional secretary to government, revenue department, 1876-80; C.S.I., May, 1878; collector and magistrate and agent, Vizagapatam, March, 1880, to April, 1881; board of revenue, July, 1882; appointed to revise the establishments of collectors and divisional officers in Madras Presidency, Feb., 1883; member of the committee in connection with the draft tenancy bill, July, 1885; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886; second member of board of revenue and commissioner of land revenue, April, 1887; acting first member, July to Sept., 1887; member of council of governor of Madras, Jan., 1889; acting governor of Madras, 1st Dec., 1890, to 23rd Jan., 1891; author of a 'Review of the Madras Famine of 1876-78'; and compiler of the 'District Manual of South Arcot,' 1878.

GARSTIN, NORMAN ANTHONY, Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service, 22nd Oct., 1857, as deputy collector and magistrate, Bengal; transferred to Oudh, Sept., 1859, as extra assistant commissioner; assistant district superintendent of police, Dec., 1863; district superintendent, Jan., 1867; 1st grade, Oct., 1890.

GARTH, SIR RICHARD, Knight, M.A., Q.C.—Educated at Eton, and Christ Church, Oxford; called to the bar in Lincoln's Inn in 1847, and went the home circuit; represented Guildford in Parliament, 1866-68; nominated chief justice of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, March, 1875; retired, March, 1886.

GARTHWAITE, LISTON, B.A. (London), late Education Department, Madras.—Served from 3rd April, 1857, as head master of the Zillah school, Cuddalore, of the provincial school, Calicut, and of the normal school, Cannanore, and as deputy inspector of schools; also acted as Malayan translator, and Canarese translator to government; from Sept., 1869, served as inspector of schools; compiled Canarese and Malayan Arzis for the secretary of state, and also various text-books; fellow of Madras University, March, 1884; 2nd class, education department, May, 1884; on special duty at Madras in connection with preparation of a scheme for development of technical and scientific education, in 1884-85, and again in 1885-86; retired, Dec., 1888.

GATES, FRANK CAMPBELL, B.L., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882; from Aug., 1884, served in Burma as assistant commissioner; on special duty in Upper Burma, March, 1887; junior secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1887; under secretary, Oct., 1887; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Aug., 1889; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, Jan., 1890; junior secretary to chief commissioner, March, 1891; officiating secretary, March, 1892.

GATHERER, ARTHUR BRANDER, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1864, and served in the public works department, Madras and Mysore; executive engineer, Sept., 1873; assistant secretary to resident, public works department, Hyderabad, Dec., 1885; superintending engineer, March, 1889; transferred to Burma, April, 1889.

GAY, EDWARD, M.A., late Financial Department, Government of India.—Appointed by the secretary of state as assistant in the finance department, Sept., 1865; assistant comptroller-general of accounts and acting assistant commissioner of paper currency, Calcutta, June, 1867; acting deputy accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1868; deputy comptroller-general, Calcutta, Sept., 1869; 1st class of the financial department, Jan., 1871; on special duty in England, March, 1872, to Dec., 1873; acting accountant-general, Bengal, May, 1874, to Jan., 1875; accountant-general, Bombay, and commissioner of paper currency, April, 1879; officiating comptroller and auditor-general, April, 1885; comptroller and auditor-general and head commissioner of paper currency (provisionally), Nov., 1887; confirmed, Nov., 1888; retired, Nov., 1891.

GEAKE, EDWARD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Plymouth College and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1886, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

GEE, HERBERT WALTER, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Sherborne School and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1887, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating district judge, &c.
GEIDT, Bernard George, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1876; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, Dec., 1876; transferred to Assam, Oct., 1877, and served as assistant commissioner and assistant inspector of immigrants; personal assistant to the chief commissioner, Jan., 1882; officiated as deputy commissioner in 1884 and 1887; retransferred to Bengal as joint magistrate and deputy collector, Jan., 1888; has also officiated as district and sessions judge.

GELL, Right Rev. Frederick, D.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Madras.—Fellow of Christ College, Cambridge; nominated lord bishop of Madras, 16th May, 1861; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1861; acting metropolitan bishop, Calcutta, March, 1870, to Feb., 1877.

GEOGHGAN, Henry Thomas, B.A., M.I.C.E., late Railway Branch, Government of India.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; joined the public works department, Nov., 1868, as executive engineer, Punjab Northern state railway; superintending engineer, Indus valley railway, May, 1877; officiating consulting engineer to government of India for state railways, Feb., 1879; engineer-in-chief, Bhopal railway, June, 1879; engineer-in-chief, Madras state railway surveys, Feb., 1885; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1886; retired, 1890.

GEORGE, Edward Claudius Scottney, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Dulwich and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in Burma, 7th March, 1887, and served as assistant commissioner; officiating deputy commissioner, Aug., 1890.

GEORGE, James Morgan Tomkins, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Malvern College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service (Burma), after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1885, and served as assistant commissioner in Burma; officiating under secretary to chief commissioner, May-Aug., 1891.

GIBB, Malcolm Cooper, LL.B., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1883; on special duty, Surat, June, 1887; and assistant collector and magistrate, Nov., 1890.

GIBSON, Edward, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Alban's Grammar School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived, 25th Nov., 1864; served in Madras revenue and judicial department from Feb., 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate and acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, and was on special duty, Jan., 1868, inquiring into condition of poorer classes, North Arcot, and on famine duty in Kurnool, Nov., 1876, to March, 1878; acting under secretary to government, chief secretary's department, Feb., 1880; private secretary to governor of Madras, Dec., 1880; sub-collector and joint magistrate, June, 1882; secretary to the board of revenue, Jan., 1884; acting collector, district magistrate, and government agent, Tanjore, July, 1886; collector and magistrate, Sept., 1888; acting member of board of revenue, Nov., 1891.

GIBSON, Frederick Edward, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Bath Grammar School, London University, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Nellore, Oct., 1883; retired, Aug., 1887.

GIBSON, Henry William, Barrister-at-Law, Oudh Commission.—Volunteer in the Meerut light horse, 1857-58; served subsequently in the military police, 1858-61; assistant district superintendent of police, Oudh, June, 1861; district superintendent, 4th grade, April, 1863; from July, 1864, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, and officiated as settlement officer, Feb.-Dec., 1865; acted as superintendent of encumbered estates, Sitapur, July to Oct., 1874; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1877; 1st grade, July, 1883.

GIBSON, J. R., Revenue Survey Department, Bombay.—Joined the service, 27th Feb., 1862; arrived, Sept., 1860, and served as assistant superintendent, assistant settlement officer, and deputy superintendent; from 1881 to 1885, served in Egypt, being attached to the intelligence department during the campaign of 1882 (medal and Khedive's star); superintendent, revenue survey, Ratnagiri, May, 1885; from 1885 to 1890, was again employed under the Egyptian government, and received the order of the Osmanieh; resumed his post in May, 1890, but returned immediately to Egypt.

GILES, Arthur Henry, Police Department, Bengal.—Joined the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent, 14th Feb., 1863; district superintendent, Jan., 1866; officiating personal assistant to inspector-general, March, 1869; officiating deputy commissioner of police and justice of the peace for the town of Calcutta, May, 1870; 1st grade district superintendent, April, 1885; deputy inspector-general, Oct., 1890; served temporarily under the government of Ceylon in 1888.

GILES, Edward, M.A., Bombay Educational Department.—Arrived in India, 14th May, 1873, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of history and political economy, Elphinstone College, Bombay; from May, 1875, served as educational inspector, and was promoted to the 2nd grade of the department, March, 1883.

GILES, Frank, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; under secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1886; officiating secretary to board of revenue, Sept., 1887; senior assistant commissioner, May, 1888; officiating commissioner, Kumaun, April-June, 1889, and June-Oct., 1891; deputy commissioner, Almora, Oct., 1891.

GILES, Robert, M.A., Sind Commission.—Arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1868; assistant
settlement officer, Indus survey, March, 1869; served from Jan., 1870, as deputy collector, superintendent of police, and educational inspector in Sind; and assistant collector in Sind, July, 1884; deputy commissioner, Upper Sind frontier, Dec., 1885.

GILL, JOHN EDWARD, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 23rd Jan., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Aug., 1887; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1889; settlement officer, 2nd grade, March, 1890; joint magistrate, 1st grade, July, 1890; author of 'Gazetteer of the Ghazipur District.'

GILLAN, Rev. G. G., M.A., late Ecclesiastical Department, Bengal.—Assistant chaplain of the Church of Scotland, 4th Jan., 1866; served under the military department with the 91st Highlanders at Dum Dum, 1866, and with the 72nd Highlanders at Umballa, 1871; chaplain, Jan., 1876; senior chaplain of the church of Scotland in Bengal, and of St. Andrew's Church, March, 1880; retired, 1889.

GILLAN, ROBERT WOODBURN, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Ayr Academy and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 11th November, 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

GILLILAND, JOHN HOWARD, B.A., Bengal Education Department.—Appointed to the service, 15th June, 1877, and served in the Presidency and the Howrah colleges as professor of civil engineering; class 3 of educational service, June, 1887; professor in Presidency College, Nov., 1888.

GILLMAN, HERBERT FRANCIS WEBB, Madras C.S.—Educated at Dulwich College and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed member of the Madras civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived, 1st Dec., 1888, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate.
