GIRINDRA NARAIN DEB, KUMAR, Bengal C.S.—Officiating deputy magistrate and deputy collector, Burdwan, Aug., 1878; appointed to the Bengal civil service under the native civil service rules, and served as probationary assistant magistrate and collector from Dec., 1880; confirmed in his appointment in the civil service, 19th Feb., 1886.

GLADSTONE, CECIL ERNEST, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served in the Punjab as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty at Delhi at the Imperial assemblage, Dec., 1876, and again, in the foreign department of the government of India, Feb., 1877; from Sept., 1885, acted as district judge, Rawul Pindi; transferred to Burma as deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Sept., 1886; 1st grade, May, 1889; officiated as commissioner, Southern Division, April, 1889; re-transferred to the Punjab, Dec., 1889; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1889.

GLASS, JAMES GEORGE HENRY, C.I.E., M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—2nd assistant engineer, Central Provinces, 27th June, 1867; executive engineer, April, 1871; secretary to chief commissioner, public works department, Central Provinces, July, 1885; superintending engineer, Aug., 1888; C.I.E., May, 1890.

GLAZIER, EDWARD GEORGE, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at North London Collegiate School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 25th Sept., 1861; from April, 1862, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1879; retired, 1891; author of 'Report on the district of Rungpore,' 'Further Notes on the Rungpore Records,' 'Report on the Famine in Rungpore.'

GLENNY, WILLIAM HENRY, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Newry School, Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and acting district and sessions judge, and was placed on special duty, Jan., 1868, enquiring into the condition of the poorer classes, South Arcot; collector and magistrate, Kurnool, April, 1880; acting director of revenue settlement and agriculture, Oct., 1885; in charge of the Inam department, Oct., 1885; collector and magistrate, North Arcot, May, 1886; retired, 1888.

GLOSTER, JOHN CLERKE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Midleton College, Cork, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1891.

GODFREY, CHARLES WILLIS, Colonel, I.S.C., Revenue Survey Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1858, and served in the Bombay artillery; from Aug., 1864, served in the Bombay revenue survey department as assistant superintendent, and acting deputy superintendent, and was promoted to superintendent of survey, Jan., 1885; colonel, Dec., 1888; acted as survey and settlement commissioner, June, 1889.

GODFREY, GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873; assistant magistrate and collector, Bengal, Oct., 1873; on famine duty, May, 1874; transferred to Assam, Dec., 1874, as assistant commissioner, and acted as assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, July to Oct., 1877; from Jan., 1880, served in Bengal as officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; again transferred to Assam, Oct., 1883, and served as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1885; acting inspector-general of police, jails, registration, commissioner of excise and superintendent of stamps, April, 1892.

GODELEY, SIR ARTHUR, K.C.B., Under Sec. of State, India Office.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; Hertford scholar, 1868;
Ireland scholar, 1870; Eldon law scholar, 1874; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn, 1876; private secretary to the first lord of the treasury, 1872-74, and again, 1880-82; commissioner of inland revenue, 1882-83; permanent under secretary of state for India, 30th Sept., 1883; K.C.B., Jan., 1893.

GODSELL, WILLIAM, Audit Department, India Office.—Junior examiner, 30th Sept., 1860; senior examiner, June, 1863; junior inspector, Dec., 1868; senior inspector, Oct., 1892.

GOLDINGHAM, JOHN DALRYMPLE, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1853; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-judge, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; from July, 1862, to July, 1865, served as judge of the court of small causes, Madura, and from Oct., 1868, to Oct., 1872, as civil and sessions judge at the same place; district and sessions judge, Nellore, Nov., 1872, to Feb., 1881, and afterwards at Bellary; retired, Sept., 1888.

GOLDSMITH, SEPTIMUS JESSE, Surgeon-Major.—Joined the Bombay medical service, April, 1873; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1873; served as civil surgeon in North Canara and Guzerat; agency surgeon, Baghelkhand, Sept., 1875; also tutor to Maharaja of Rewah from Oct., 1883; afterwards in medical charge of Baghelkhand Agency and dispensaries; retired, March, 1891.

GOLDWYER-LEWIS, The Ven. ALEXANDER, B.A., B.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Bombay.—Joined the service as chaplain, 19th May, 1875; senior chaplain, May, 1885; archdeacon and commissary, Oct., 1890.

GOMPERTZ, HENRY JAMES COLLEY, Madras Revenue Survey Department.—Appointed, 10th Aug., 1859; served as assistant superintendent on special duty on boundary questions, Bellary, April, 1871-1872; deputy superintendent, 1st class, July, 1887; employed in Oct., 1888, on special duty on boundary questions, Puducottai, and in Jan., 1889, Karikal and Tanjore.

GONNE, CHARLES, C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1853; arrived in India 10th March, 1854; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge, and was appointed judge of the small cause court, Ahmednagar, May, 1861; joint judge and sessions judge, Thana, March, 1863, and acted as judge and sessions judge June, 1863, to March, 1864; acting judge and sessions judge, Poona, and agent for Sardars in the Deccan, April-June, 1864; acting registrar, high court, Bombay, June-Oct., 1864; from Oct., 1864, served as secretary to government of Bombay in the judicial and political departments; chief secretary to government in the political, secret, judicial, and separate departments, April, 1879; temporary member of council, Bombay, March-April, 1884; retired in 1885.

GOODFELLOW, CHARLES AUGUSTUS, Major-General, R.E., V.C., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined Addiscombe, July, 1853; 2nd lieutenant, June, 1855; arrived in India, March, 1857; served with the Central India field force, 1857-58 (medal and clasp, V.C.), and with the Okhamandal and Kattiarwar field force, 1859; joined the public works department as special assistant engineer, harbour defences, Bombay, April 1860; executive engineer, Feb., 1862; joined the Abyssinian Expedition, Dec., 1867, as brigade major of royal engineers (medal); executive engineer, 1st grade, Jan., 1877; superintending engineer, 3rd class, May, 1884; and 1st class, Nov., 1886; chief engineer for irrigation and officiating superintending engineer, September, 1887; chief engineer, 1st class, Aug., 1888; reverted to military duty, Nov., 1891.

GOODFELLOW, WILLIAM WEST, Lieut.-General, C.B., R.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—2nd lieutenant, Bombay Engineers, Dec., 1851; arrived in India, Oct., 1853; joined the public works department, July, 1854; served with the Persian expeditionary force, 1856-7 (medal and clasp), and with the Abyssinian expedition, 1867 (C.B. and medal); executive engineer, Bombay defences, Jan., 1869, to May, 1870; acting controller of public works accounts, June - July, 1870; served subsequently as executive engineer at Aden and in the Poona districts; from June, 1876, served as superintending engineer, and was promoted to 1st class, March, 1882; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government of Bombay, public works department, April, 1885; returned to Europe, 1887.

GOODRICH, HARRY ST. AUBREY, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras from July, 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, deputy director of revenue settlement, acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting district and sessions judge, Nellore, Feb.-Sept., 1881; appointed collector and magistrate, March, 1882, in South Canara, and subsequently in the districts of Ganjam and Vizagapatam; on duty to Calcutta as additional member of governor-general's legislative council, Dec., 1884, to March, 1885, and again, Nov., 1885, to March, 1886; on special duty at Madras conferring upon proposals for legislating on relations of landlord and tenant in Malabar, March, 1885; member of the draft tenancy bill committee, July, 1885; collector and magistrate, Bellary, Nov., 1885; retired, Feb., 1890.

GOODRICKE, G. M., late Bengal Customs Department.—Served from 30th Nov., 1859, as preventive officer and appraiser, Calcutta custom house, and was appointed assistant collector of customs, July, 1871, and deputy collector of Calcutta, March, 1880; also superintendent of excise revenue, collector of stamp revenue, and a collector under the Licence Tax Act; retired, 1889.

GOODRIDGE, JOHN PERCH, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1869; served as assistant commissioner in the Central Provinces, and held acting appointments at various dates as district superintendent of police, inspector of schools, cantonment magistrate, and small cause court judge, and was deputed on famine duty to Madras, Sept., 1877; assistant commissioner, 1st class, Bilaspur, Nov., 1884; deputy commissioner, Sept., 1889; in addition political agent, Chhattisgarh Feudatories, Dec., 1889; officiated as commissioner of settlements and agriculture in 1889; and as
commissioner, Chhattisgarh division, in 1890; additional sessions judge, Jubbulpore and Nerbudda divisions, Jan., 1892.

GOPAL DAS, RAJ BABADUR, Punjab Commission.—Served in the settlement department and subordinate judicial department of the Punjab from 6th July, 1851; appointed extra judicial assistant, Oct., 1888; author of 'Manual for preparation of Records of Rights' and of histories of the Gujranwala and Peshawur districts.

GOPENDRA KRISHNA DEB, KUMAR, M.A., B.L., Bengal C.S.—Served in the subordinate executive service, Bengal, from 27th Jan., 1876, and officiated as registrar of Calcutta and second inspector of registration offices; appointed to the Bengal civil service under the native civil service rules, Nov., 1882, and served as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Sept., 1891.

GORDON, ALEXANDER EVANS, Lieut.-Colonel, I.S.C.—First commission, 18th April, 1865; from May, 1872, served in the Bengal non-regulation commission as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty with H.H. the Maharajah of Johore, Dec., 1875; cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Dum-Dum, March, 1876; tutor to the Maharajah of Durbhunga, June, 1877; on special duty in Calcutta, Jan., 1880, and in the foreign department, Nov., 1880; on deputation to Cooch Behar, Dec., 1883; deputy commissioner, March, 1887.

GORDON, DONALD CLUNES, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the public works department in 1868, as assistant controller of accounts, N.W. Provinces; served subsequently as deputy controller in the Punjab; controller, 3rd class, on the Indus Valley state railway, July, 1874, and afterwards on the Punjab northern railway; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, 1877-79, and afterwards in Madras; examiner, P.W. accounts, Madras, May, 1881; examiner, 1st class, Sept., 1886; examiner, public works accounts, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, March, 1887; examiner, public works accounts, Punjab, March, 1891.

GORDON, GEORGE, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Radley College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1885, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner.

GORDON, HAMILTON WINKUP, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 12th Nov., 1864; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; officiating inspector of schools, July, 1872; joint magistrate and deputy collector, March, 1879; district and sessions judge, Nov., 1881; officiating judge of high court, Calcutta, April, 1888, April, 1889, and April, 1890.

GORDON, HUNTLY PRYSE, late Madras C.S.—Educated at New College, London, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, small cause court judge, assistant commissioner (Nilgiri Hills), and acting district and sessions judge; appointed collector and magistrate, Kurnool, Dec., 1878, and afterwards at Bellary, April, 1880; and in South Arcot, Nov., 1885; retired, Oct., 1887.

GORDON, LEWIS, Central Provinces Commission.—Joined the service as assistant district superintendent of police, Bengal, 20th July, 1869; extra assistant commissioner, Punjab, April, 1870; district superintendent of police, Ajmere, May, 1873; on special duty with the Maharajah of Jodhpur, Nov., 1874; assistant commissioner, British Burma, March, 1875; in executive charge of Moulmein central jail, Nov., 1876; assistant commissioner, Central Provinces, Jan., 1878; officiated in addition as cantonment magistrate in 1884 and 1888; personal assistant to the chief commissioner, Feb., 1887; small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, Dec., 1890; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1891.

GORE, ST. GEORGE CORBET, Major, R.E., Survey of India Department.—Joined the service, 8th Jan., 1870; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1872; from March, 1873, served on the great trigonometrical survey of India; on service in Afghanistan, Feb., 1879 to May, 1880; with Sir D. Stewart's column on march from Kandahar to Kabul, as officer in charge of survey; attached to Afghan boundary commission, Aug., 1884; deputy superintendent, March, 1886; on military duty in Europe, Feb., 1888 to Jan., 1889; charge of trigonometrical branch office, drawing section, Jan., 1889; officiating assistant surveyor-general, Oct., 1889; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Oct., 1890.

GORST, RIGHT HON. SIR JOHN ELDON, Q.C., M.P.—Graduated at St. John's College, Cambridge; 3rd wrangler, 1857; M.A., 1860; fellow of his college; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1865; Q.C., 1875; civil commissioner of Waikats, New Zealand, 1861 to 1863; represented Cambridge (borough) in the House of Commons, 1866 to 1868, and Chatham, 1875 to 1892, when he became member for Cambridge University; solicitor-general in Lord Salisbury's first administration, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886; under secretary of state for India, in Lord Salisbury's second administration, Aug., 1886, to Nov., 1891, when he was appointed financial secretary to the treasury; was British Plenipotentiary at the labour conference at Berlin, 1890; author of 'The Maori King.'

GOUGH, ARCHIBALD EDWARD, M.A., Educational Service, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the department, 2nd Nov., 1868, and served as Anglo-Sanskrit professor, Benares College, and as professor of English literature and professor of history and philosophy at the Muir College, Allahabad, and also officiated for various periods between 1872 and 1878 as principal, Benares College, and held charge of the meteorological observatory; served in Bengal, 1878-1886, as professor in the Hooghly and Presidency Colleges, and principal of the Calcutta Madrassa; educational officer, 2nd grade, and principal, Muir Central College, Allahabad, July, 1886; author of 'Papers relating to the Collection and Preservation of the Records of Ancient Sanskrit Literature in India,' 1878, &c.

GOULDSBURY, DUDLEY ELPHINSTONE, Major, Punjab Administration.—Joined the service, 16th Oct., 1866; arrived in India, 1st March, 1867; served in military department to June, 1882, when he was transferred to the Punjab as officiating cantonment magistrate, Ferozepur; re-transferred to military department, Oct., 1882; re-
sumed his appointment, May, 1883; transferred to Jullundur, Aug., 1889; 1st class cantonment magistrate, Feb., 1891.

GOVAN, GEORGE MONCKIEFF, Surgeon-Major, M.D., L.R.C.S., L.R.C.P.E., late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, Dec., 1851; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1852, and served under the military department up to 1883, in Bengal, Burma, and Assam, and throughout the Bhootan campaign, 1864-1866 (medal and clasp for Burma); rank of surgeon, June, 1864; surgeon-major, Dec., 1871; from Jan., 1883, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed civil surgeon, 2nd class, Fatehgarh, and posted to Azamgarh; officiating deputy sanitary commissioner, Aug., 1883; superintendent of pilgrim hospitals in Kumaun and Garhwal in addition to other duties, Aug., 1883; served subsequently as civil surgeon at Budaoon and at Almora; retired, March, 1887.

GRACE, CHARLES HALLYBURTON, Col., I.S.C., late Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, as ensign, Madras infantry, March, 1854; served in the Central Provinces from Sept., 1859, as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and settlement officer, and was appointed deputy commissioner, 1st class, Sept., 1883, at Jubulpore; acted as commissioner of the Jubulpore division, May-June, 1882; reverted to military department, 1892.

GRACEY, HUGH KIRKWOOD, B.A., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at City of London School, London University, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and in Oudh as assistant commissioner.

GRACEY, THOMAS, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Educated at Enniskillen Royal School; 1st commission, 17th Dec., 1862; 1st assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1867; executive engineer, Sept., 1870; engineer-in-chief, Pindi to Kohat section of Punjab Northern Railway, 1879; engineer-in-chief, provincial railways under construction, N.W. Provinces and Oudh railway branch, Oct., 1882; special superintending engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, public works department, Burma, April, 1887; superintending engineer, Feb., 1888; officiating consulting engineer for railways, and joint secretary to government, railway branch, Madras, July, 1890; officiating consulting engineer to the government of India for railways, central division, March, 1891; confirmed, June, 1891; in similar capacity, Lucknow, June, 1892; chief engineer, 3rd class, June, 1892.

GRAHAM, ROBERT ARTHUR, Madras C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1891, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

GRAHAME, WILLIAM FRANCIS, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 4th Jan., 1864; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from Oct., 1866, and was placed on special duty in July, 1868, with Dr. Janssen in connection with the solar eclipse; collector and magistrate, Anantapur, June, 1882; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1882.

GRANT, ARTHUR JAMES, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Berkhamstead Grammar School, Dulwich College, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1889, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating under secretary to government, Nov., 1891; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioners, Dec., 1891; confirmed, March, 1892.

GRANT, SIR CHARLES, K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, Trinity College, Cambridge, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1858; arrived in India, 8th April, 1858; attached to the N.W. Provinces, and served in the revenue and settlement departments; transferred to Central Provinces, Nov., 1863, and served as settlement officer and acting deputy commissioner; in charge of settlement commissioner's office, Jubulpore, Jan., 1868; secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Nov., 1861; compiled the 'Central Provinces Gazetteer'; commissioner of Chattisgarh division, Nov., 1870, and subsequently of the Jubulpore and Narbada divisions; acting judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Aug., 1877; acting chief commissioner, April to Nov., 1879; additional member of governor-general's council, Dec., 1879; acting secretary, government of India, home, revenue, and agricultural departments, May, 1880; foreign secretary, government of India, Sept., 1881; retired, Feb., 1885.

GRANT, CHARLES, Colonel, late Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 4th Jan., 1857; arrived in India, 6th Feb., 1857; served with the Guzerat Horse, and subsequently with the Mahratta Horse; special officer in charge, Kathiawar local battalion, and extra assistant political agent, Dec., 1867; in charge of state prison, Asirgarh, March, 1870; assistant resident, Persian Gulf, June, 1871, and acted as resident in 1877; political agent, Eastern States, Rajputana, April, 1878; political agent, Muscat, Feb., 1880; superintendent, Rajputana railway police, Dec., 1880; from Feb., 1881, served as cantonment magistrate, Nimach; retired, Jan., 1887.

GRANT, GEORGE, Brigade-Surgeon, M.B., late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 10th Feb., 1859; arrived in India, 11th July, 1859, and served under the military department till 1860; from June, 1860, served under the government of the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, Bijnor, and was in medical charge of the lieutenant-governor's camp, Nov., 1861; civil assistant surgeon and superintendent of jail, Farakhabad, March, 1862; on special deputation to Calcutta to give evidence in a criminal case at the high court, Jan., 1864; officiating superintendent, government press, and curator of government books, N.W. Provinces, and chemical examiner, N.W. Provinces, Oudh and Central Provinces, Aug., 1866; superintendent of new central prison, Farakhabad, Dec., 1866; rank of surgeon, Feb., 1871; representative of N.W. Provinces at the
prison committee, Calcutta, Jan., 1877; officiating inspector-general of prisons and civil hospitals, N.W. Provinces, in 1877, 1879, and 1882; superintendent, central and district jails, Bareilly, Dec., 1877; deputy sanitary commissioner, 1st circle, Dec., 1883; retired, Oct., 1885.

GRANT, GEORGE FRANCIS MYTON, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Brighton; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1864, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner, branch registrar-general, education inspector in Sind, and acting talukdari settlement officer; in charge of the Sachim state, May, 1879; acted as collector, magistrate, and agent at Surat, 1879-80, and subsequently in the Panch Mahals, and at Broach, Kaira, and Kaladgi; junior collector of salt revenue, Bombay, Dec., 1882; acting collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Nov., 1883; acting collector of customs, Bombay, May, 1884; junior collector and magistrate and political agent, Thana, March, 1885; senior collector, Sept., 1886; acting commissioner, northern division, May, 1889, southern division, June, 1889; appointed commissioner, northern division, April, 1890, and 1st grade commissioner, June, 1890; retired, Nov., 1890.

GRANT, GREGORY COLQUHOUN, Colonel, I.S.C., late Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1853; on military duty till Nov., 1860, including service with the Okhamandal field force, in Oct., 1859; served subsequently as deputy collector and magistrate in Sind; judge and sessions judge, March, 1865; also acted as judicial commissioner in Sind, and judge of the sadar court; reverted to military department, 1890.

GRANT, J. G. GARROW, Dr., late Emigration Department, Bengal.—Served in the emigration department from 22nd May, 1863, as medical inspector and protector of labourers, Kooshtes; on special duty at the Presidency, Oct., 1870; protector of emigrants and superintendent of labour transports, Calcutta, Feb., 1871; superintendent of emigration, Calcutta, Jan., 1874; retired, 1889.

GRANT, JOHN ANDREW, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; served under the foreign department, government of India, at Kurram, May-Aug., 1880; transferred to Umballa-Karnal settlement as settlement officer, Dec., 1883; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Sept., 1884; officiating registrar, chief court, June, 1885; on special duty at Sialkot, Nov., 1885; assistant commissioner, and grade, Sept., 1887, and 1st grade, April, 1890.

GRANT, JOHN HAY, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived, 6th Feb., 1857, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, railway magistrate, assistant revenue and police commissioner, acting collector and magistrate, and acting commissioner of customs, salt, and opium; junior collector, Kaladgi, Sept., 1877; municipal commissioner, Bombay, Nov., 1877 to Feb., 1881; collector of Bombay, and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Aug., 1883; special commissioner for Bombay for purpose of international exhibition at Calcutta, Nov.-Dec., 1883; president of a commission to make certain enquiries in connection with Abkari act, July, 1885; commissioner of income tax for town and island of Bombay, in addition to his other duties, April, 1886; retired, Jan., 1888.

GRANT, JOHN PETER, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1855; assistant magistrate and collector, Jessore, June, 1857; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Sept., 1862; officiating comptroller of government salt chowkies, Nov., 1862; officiating junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1863; deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Dec., 1863; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Feb., 1867; small cause court judge, Kishnagur, April, 1874; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1875; 1st grade, district judge, Jan., 1878; officiating judge, high court, February, 1886; retired, Jan., 1889.

GRANT, JOHN PYNE, Colonel, I.S.C., Revenue Survey of Mysore.—First commission as ensign, Bombay infantry, Jan., 1856; joined the revenue survey, 1860; superintendent of revenue survey, Mysore, Jan., 1868.

GRANT, TREVOR JOHN CHICHELE, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, in the grades of assistant and joint magistrate, and deputy collector, and was promoted to magistrate and collector, May, 1874; officiating secretary, board of revenue, April, 1874; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1878.

GRANT, T., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk 2nd class, 28th May, 1875.

GRANT-DUFF, Rt. Hon. Sir Mountstuart Elphinstone, P.C., G.C.S.I., C.I.E., F.R.S.—Born in 1829; educated at Edinburgh, and at Balliol College, Oxford; M.A. in 1853; called to the bar at the Inner Temple in 1854; represented the Elgin burghs in parliament from Dec., 1857, to July, 1881; under secretary of state for India, Dec., 1863, to Feb., 1874; under secretary of state for the colonies, April, 1880, to Aug., 1881; governor of Madras, Nov., 1881, to 1886; was lord rector of the university of Aberdeen, 1866 to 1872; author of 'Studies in European Politics,' 'Elgin Speeches,' 'A Political Survey,' &c.

GRAVES, SOMERSET HENRY PAUL, Major, I.S.C., late Burma Police Department.—First commission, 2nd Sept., 1868; served in the 26th native infantry, and in June, 1885, was appointed superintendent of police, Port Blair; deputy inspector-general of police, Upper Burma, May, 1887; reverted to military duty, 1888.

GRAY, EVELYN, B.L., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; forest settlement officer, March, 1884, and again in 1886 and 1889; acted as junior collector and magistrate in 1886 and 1887; and assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1889; transferred to Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, Dec., 1891; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1892.
GRAY, Malcolm Alexander, B.A., Major, I.S.C., Assam Commission.—Ensign, 3rd (Buffs) Regt., 7th Nov., 1868; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1870; served in the Assam commission, from Aug., 1873, as officiating assistant commissioner and assistant inspector of immigrants; confirmed as assistant commissioner, July, 1877; forest settlement officer, Oct., 1885; deputy commissioner, Sept., 1888.

GRAY, Percy, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wellington College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 30th December, 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; officiating cantonment magistrate, Roorkee, Oct., 1883; junior secretary, board of revenue, April-July, 1885; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Sept., 1887, and assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Feb., 1890; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Dec., 1890; judge, small cause court, Allahabad, May, 1891; has also officiated as magistrate and collector, and registrar, high court; confirmed in the latter post, March, 1892.

GRAY, R., Brigade-Surgeon, M.B., late Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1859; arrived in India, 11th March, 1860; civil assistant surgeon, Gujranwala, Feb., 1863; superintendent, central jail, Jan., 1864; civil surgeon, Mooltan, May, 1868; officiated as inspector-general of prisons, March, 1869, to March, 1871, and again in 1877; surgeon-major, July, 1873; in medical charge of lieutenant governor's camp, Nov., 1877; served afterwards as civil surgeon of Murree, Mooltan, and Lahore; inspector-general of prisons, Punjab, Sept., 1884; retired, April, 1891.

GRAY, Wellington, Brigade - Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, L.M., L.Ch., Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 31st March, 1866; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1866, and was appointed professor of anatomy and curator of museum at the Grant Medical College, and surgeon at the Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, Bombay; curator of Victoria and Albert Museum, and professor of botany, Grant Medical College, June, 1871; also acted as professor of chemistry and medical jurisprudence, and chemical analyser to government; secretary to the surgeon-general, Indian medical department, June, 1878; senior surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, and professor of surgery and clinical surgery, Grant Medical Hospital, May, 1883; brigade-surgeon, June, 1888; principal of the Grant Medical College, Dec., 1888.

GREAVES, Lieut.-Gen. Sir George Richards, K.C.B., K.C.M.G.—1st commission, 30th Nov., 1849; Captain, Oct., 1859; Major, March, 1864; Colonel, Sept., 1872; Major-Gen., Oct., 1882; served in the Indian mutiny of 1857-8, and in the Eusofzye expedition of 1858 (medal with clasp); served in the war in New Zealand as D.A. Quarter-master-Gen., 1862-66 (brevets of Major and Lieut.-Col., and medal); chief of the staff of Ashantee expedition of 1873-4, present at battles of Omoaful and Ordahsu, and capture of Coomassie (medal with clasp and C.B.); served in Soudan campaign in 1885 as chief of the staff to Sir Gerald Graham (K.C.B., medal with clasp); appointed commander-in-chief of Bombay army, and second member of council of governor of Bombay, and took his seat, 13th March, 1890.

GREAVES, Richard Herbert, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 19th Jan., 1870; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, March, 1884; transferred to Assam for employment as district and sessions judge, Sylhet, Oct., 1887.

GREENE, Walter James, India Office.—Writer, 1st July, 1867; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878; attached to the financial department; clerk for examination of army non-effective accounts, March, 1885.

GREENSHIELDS, Robert Scott, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Birkenhead School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1879; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1879; transferred to Assam, March, 1882, and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, Assam, March, 1886; officiated as director of the department of land revenue and agriculture, in 1889; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1889.

GREENSTREET, William Lees, Lieut.-Col., R.F., Military Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission as lieutenant, Oct., 1864; arrived in India, Jan., 1870; joined the public works department, Feb., 1871, as assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces; transferred to military works branch, 1872; executive engineer, Nov., 1874; superintending engineer, 3rd class, July, 1885; 2nd class, Dec., 1889; 1st class, Nov., 1891; took part in the Hazara expedition, 1891; officiating chief engineer, Poona, May, 1892.

GREER, Richard Townsend, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Erasmus College, Drogheda, and Kingstown School, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1877, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner, assistant secretary to chief commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; returned to Bengal, Nov., 1888, as joint magistrate and deputy collector.

GREEVEN, Richard, B.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Dulwich and at Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1888, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, Dec., 1891; assistant superintendent and small cause judge, Dehra Dun, March, 1892.

GREGG, William Henry, M.B., D.P.H., Surgeon - Lieut. - Colonel, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1869; served in the 4th Bengal native infantry, May, 1870, to Dec., 1873; in the Looshai campaign, 1871-2 (medal and clasp); civil surgeon, Dinagapore, 1873, Jessore, 1875, Hooghly, 1876-86; lecturer on botany, Hooghly government college, 1877-86; officiating protector of emigrants, Calcutta, April, 1888; sanitary commissioner, Bengal Jan., 1889.
GREIG, G., late Forest Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India, 20th Sept., 1857, as a lieutenant, 93rd Sutherland Highlanders; retired from the army, June, 1865; joined the forest department, Dec., 1868, and was appointed assistant conservator, Aug., 1869, deputy conservator, March, 1871, and conservator, Nov., 1876; promoted to 1st grade of conservators, April, 1883; retired, 1889.

GREY, CHARLES, Political Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, military department, India office, 18th May, 1864; private secretary to parliamentary under secretary of state, April-July, 1866; financial department, 1866; assistant précis writer to the secretary of state, 1872; accompanied Sir Bartle Frere on his mission to Zanzibar, 1872-1873; political department, 1874; reading clerk to council from 1875 to 1890; senior clerk, April, 1877.

GREY, LEOPOLD JOHN HERBERT, Colonel, C.S.I., I.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 3rd Jan., 1857; assistant commissioner in Assam, Feb., 1865; officiating civil officer with Bhootan Dovar field force, Dec., 1865; from April, 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, but was employed under the government of Bengal, Dec., 1868, to June, 1869; on special duty, Oct., 1869, to March, 1870; political agent, Bahawalpur State, March, 1871, to Jan., 1873, and again in 1877; judicial assistant, 1st grade, July, 1876; on special duty in connection with Imperial assemblage, Sept., 1876, to Jan., 1877; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1876; officiating civil and session judge, Peshawur, Aug., 1881; secretary to board of examiners (under government of India), March, 1882; commissioner and superintendent, Delhi division, March, 1886; officiated as first financial commissioner in 1891.

GREY, WILLIAM FRANCIS HUNGERFORD, Major, I.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, 21st regiment, Aug., 1868; served in the Burma commission from April, 1874, as assistant commissioner, and acted as assistant secretary to chief commissioner, June-Oct., 1876; boundary officer, Paungde, Aug., 1881; cantonment magistrate, and small cause court judge, Thayetmyo, Sept. 1882; was elected president of the Kyaukpyu town committee, March, 1884; and of the Akyab municipal committee, Dec., 1885; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1886.

GRIERSON, GEORGE ABRAHAM, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Bees, Shrewsbury, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1873; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge; on famine duty, March, 1874; officiating inspector of schools Oct., 1880; on special duty in the revenue department, Dec., 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Oct., 1884; magistrate and collector, March, 1890; has published various works in connection with the Behari language and its dialects, translations, collections of folk songs, &c., also 'Behar Peasant Life,' 1885; 'Report on Colonial Emigration from the Lower Provinces of Bengal,' 1883; 'Curiosities of Indian Literature,' 1885; 'Vidyapati and his Contemporaries,' 1885; 'Modern Vernacular Literature of Hindustan,' 1890; 'Inscriptions of Pigadasi,' 1891.

GRIERSON, JOHN, Colonel, I.S.C., India Public Works Department.—2nd lieutenant, Bombay artillery, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, 24th Jan., 1858; joined the P.W. department, Feb., 1864; executive engineer, Jan. 1871; from May, 1872, served as deputy controller of accounts, Bombay; deputy examiner, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1875; examiner of accounts, Dec., 1876; transferred to Burma, July, 1880, and subsequently to Bombay, Rajputana, and to N.W. Provinces; examiner of telegraph accounts, Aug., 1885; 2nd class examiner, May, 1886; 1st class, Feb., 1891.

GRIFFIN, HENRY DALY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at French College, Blackrock, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, N.W. Provinces; assistant superintendent, Dehra Dun, April, 1889; joint magistrate, July, 1890.

GRIFFIN, SIR LEPHEL HENRY, K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1860; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; on special duty compiling the 'Punjab Chiefs,' Oct., 1867; under secretary to government, Punjab, April, 1870; on special duty to frame track rules between Punjab and Rajputana states, Feb., 1873; superintendent, Kapurthala state, April, 1875; deputy commissioner, 1st class, April, 1877; acted as secretary to government, Punjab, from Feb., 1876, and was confirmed in this appointment, Nov., 1878; on special duty at the Paris exhibition, July, 1878; during the occupation of Afghanistan, held the special appointment of chief political officer in north and west districts of that country (Afghanistan medal); resident, 1st class and agent to the governor-general, Central India, Feb., 1881; K.C.S.I., May, 1881; royal commissioner, Indian and colonial exhibition, 1886; retired, Jan., 1889.

GRIFFITH, HUGH, Brigade-Surgeon, late Medical Department, Burma.—Joined the Indian medical department (Madras establishment), 1859; served under the military department from 1859 to 1871, and also held civil surgeonies of Thayetmyo and Hoshungabad during that period; civil surgeon and health officer, Rangoon, April, 1871; also superintendent of lunatic asylum, and in charge of state prisons and lock hospital, June, 1871; in medical charge of Rangoon jail, Nov., 1871, to March, 1885; also superintendent of vaccination, May, 1875; in medical charge, Burma state railway, Nov., 1885; brigade-surgeon, March, 1886; retired, May, 1890.

GRIFFITH, RALPH THOMAS HOTCHKIN, M.A., C.I.E., late Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1853, and served as professor and head master, Benares College, also as officiating inspector of public instruction, 3rd circle; principal, Benares College, Jan., 1861; superintendent of observatory, Benares, May, 1866; promoted to 1st grade, April, 1873; on special committee under government of India, for selection of text-books, May, 1877; inspector-general of schools, N.W. Pro-
vinces, March, 1878; director of public instruction, Feb., 1879; retired, 1885.

GRIFFITHS, WILLIAM, M.A. Barrister-at-Law, Education Department, Bengal.—Appointed, 1st July, 1869; arrived in India, 20th Jan., 1870, and served as assistant professor, civil engineering department, Presidency College; professor, Presidency College, Feb., 1876; principal, Hooghly College, April, 1880; and class, education department, July, 1883.

GRIGG, EDWARD EVANS, Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Infantry, Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, Dec., 1861; served under the military department till Jan., 1864, and subsequently as assistant commissioner in Assam up to March, 1867, when he was transferred to the Oudh commission, and served as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner in various districts officiating cantonment magistrate, Lucknow, May—June, 1881; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, May, 1885; 2nd grade, Feb., 1888; 1st grade, Dec., 1888; officiating commissioner, May, 1892.

GRIGG, HENRY BIDEBELL, M.A., C.I.E., Madras C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived 8th Jan., 1865; assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1866; acting inspector of schools, Feb., 1867; from March, 1872, to Feb., 1876, served as assistant commissioner and acting commissioner, Nilgiris; acting under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, Feb., 1876, and acting secretary, March, 1877; on special duty, preparing annual administration report, Oct., 1877; under secretary, public department, Oct., 1879; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1880; fellow of University of Madras, March, 1880; director of public instruction and commissioner for the unconv. civil service examinations, July, 1880; acting resident in Travancore and Cochin in 1890, and again in 1891; C.I.E., Jan., 1890; compiler of the 'Nilgiri District Manual.'

GRIMES, HENRY ROBERT, late Jail Department, Madras.—Assistant deputy commissioner of paper currency, Vizagapatam, 29th Nov., 1864; from April, 1866, served as superintendent of the central jail, Coimbatore; inspector-general of jails, Madras, July, 1884; retired, April, 1889.

GRIMLEY, REGINALD FEARN, Madras C.S.—Educated at King Edward's School, Birmingham, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1891, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

GRIMLEY, WILLIAM HENRY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at King Edward's School, Birmingham, and Trinity College Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India 12th Dec., 1863; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiated as superintendent of surveys, Feb., 1869, and as inspector of schools, Aug., 1870; on special duty in connection with the examination of candidates for the native civil service, Jan., 1874; officiated as secretary to the board of revenue, 1874 to 1877, and again in 1879 and 1883-84; junior secretary to the board of revenue, 1877-79; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, March, 1879; officiating collector of customs and ex-officio shipping master, Calcutta, April, 1881; served under the financial department from April, 1885; commissioner of income tax in Bengal, March, 1886; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Dec., 1887; officiating commissioner, Chota Nagpur, April, 1889; confirmed, Oct., 1889; author of 'The Sea Customs Law,' 1878; 'Tariff Act, with notes,' an 'Income Tax Manual' (being Act II of 1886 with notes), 'Manual of Revenue Sale Law, and Certificate Procedure.'

GRINDLAY, WALTER, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1881; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; retired, 1888.

GRISH CHANDER CHAUDHURI, B.L., Bengal Judicial Department.—Served in the judicial department from 9th March, 1866, as subordinate judge, and judge of small cause courts; appointed subordinate judge, 1st grade, April, 1883.

GROSE, JAMES, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 7th Oct., 1860; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, under secretary to government in the revenue department, secretary to commissioner for unconv. civil service examinations, secretary to the central committee for the examination of assistants, sub-secretary board of revenue (Aug., 1867), and receiver of the Carnatic property; fellow of the Madras University, May, 1868; acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, March, 1870; secretary to board of revenue, 1870 to 1877; collector and magistrate, Nellore, March, 1877; acting member, board of revenue, April, 1886; acting director of revenue settlement, Nov., 1886; on special duty to Delhi, March, 1888; acting Imam commissioner, May, 1888; additional member of legislative council of Governor of Madras, Oct., 1888, and Jan., 1891; member of board of revenue, and commissioner of land revenue, Jan., 1890.

GROVES, FREDERICK W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Associate of King's College, London; M.A. and LL.B., University of London; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn; temporary clerk, India Office, 1st Aug., 1863; junior clerk, May, 1864; senior clerk, Aug., 1879.

GROVES, HENRY SAMUEL, B.A., Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as probationer financial department, July, 1873; served in the offices of the accountant-generals of Bombay, Punjab, Madras, and Bengal; assistant accountant-general of Bombay, Nov., 1887; deputy accountant-general, Punjab, Nov., 1890.

GROWSE, EDWARD FREDERICK, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 18th Nov. 1881; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as
assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, July, 1890.

GROWSE, FREDERICK SALMON, M.A., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Oriel and Queen's Colleges, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1860; from Dec., 1861, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Bulandshahr, Jan., 1879; officiated as sessions judge in 1887 and 1888; retired, April, 1891; has published a translation of Tulsi Dass's 'Rāmāyaṇa,' also 'Mathura: a District Memoir,' 'Bulandshahr: Sketches of an Indian District,' and 'Indian Architecture of To-day.'

GUBBINS, FREDERICK BEBB, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1835; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, Delhi division; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Moradabad, 1842, and subsequently in Rohtak and Banda; magistrate and collector of Benares, 1852; civil and sessions judge, Benares, 1857; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Benares, agent to governor-general, and superintendent of ex-rajah of Coorg, 1858; retired 1863.

GUN, WILLIAM HENRY MAFFETT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Greenock Academy, and Glasgow University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1871; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Feb., 1883; district and sessions judge, December, 1888.

GUNTER, AUSTIN HERBERT, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Dover College, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 22nd Nov., 1891, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

GUPTA, KALI PADA, M.A., M.B., F.R.C.S., Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Medical Department.—Joined the service, 13th June, 1872, on inspection duty, medical relief measures, Burdwan District; served as superintendent of vaccination and on general and jail duty; on special duty to Nuddea medical fever relief operations in 1881; resumed his post as superintendent of vaccination, metropolitan circle, Nov., 1886; in 1888 acted in addition as sanitary commissioner for Bengal; civil surgeon, Noakhali, July, 1891.

GURDON, EVELYN PULTENEY, Colonel, I.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India 2nd April, 1852; from Aug., 1860, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and small cause court judge; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1881; additional commissioner, Jullundur, Umballa, and Amritsar divisions, Nov.–Dec., 1881, and subsequently in the Lahore and Rawul Pindi divisions; promoted to commissioner and superintendent, Aug., 1884; divisional judge, 1st grade, Oct., 1885; retired from civil employment, Jan., 1890.

GURDYAL SINGH, SIRDAAR, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 26th Jan., 1880; assistant commissioner, Jan., 1882; and has officiated as deputy commissioner and district judge.

GÜTERSLOH, FREDERIC NICHOLAS, late Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1874, as assistant engineer on the Indus Valley state railway; in charge of locomotive and carriage department, Holkar state railway, Oct., 1875; officiating manager and locomotive superintendent, Holkar state railway, 1877; manager, Wardha Valley railway, Dec., 1878; locomotive superintendent, Rajputana railways, March, 1880; 1st class, 2nd grade, locomotive department, state railways, Jan., 1886, and 1st grade, March, 1890; retired, June, 1891.

HABIB-ULLAH, MAULVI SATVID, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S. (North Western Provinces).—Appointed by the government of India to be an assistant magistrate and collector, N.W. Provinces, under the statutory rules, 14th Feb., 1887.

HACKETT, CHARLES AUGUSTUS, late Geological Survey Department.—Joined the department as assistant, 15th Nov., 1861; served in the Sone Valley, on the Vindhyaans, in Central India, and in Jalapar and South Rewah; promoted to 2nd grade, June, 1881; designation changed to deputy superintendent of the geological survey of India; deputy superintendent, 1st grade, Dec., 1887; officiated also as superintendent; retired, July, 1888.

HACKETT, ARTHUR LUKE, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1867; served under the military department, also acting as civil surgeon at various stations, and as superintendent of jail; surgeon, April, 1873; from June, 1874, acted as presidency surgeon, also as ophthalmic surgeon at the general hospital, Sept., 1874; garrison assistant surgeon, Bangalore, and superintendent of jail, 1877–78; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Bellary, 1878–81; surgeon-major, April, 1879; surgeon, 3rd district, Madras, Feb., 1881, and acted as superintendent of prisons, in 1881 and 1883; was subsequently appointed civil surgeon at Cannanore, April, 1883, at Salem, July, 1883, and at Nagapatam; principal medical storekeeper, Madras, 1885; surgeon, 2nd district, Madras, health officer, and superintendent of lock hospital, Oct., 1885.

HAIG, CHARLES THOMAS, Major-General, R.E., late Survey of India.—Obtained his first commission from Addiscombe, June, 1854; lieutenant, Bombay engineers, May, 1856; arrived at Bombay July, 1856; served with the Persian expeditionary force, 1856–57 (medal and clasp), and with the Rajputana field force, 1857 (medal and clasp); assistant executive engineer at Neemuch, May, 1858; appointed as assistant in the great trigonometrical survey of India, Sept., 1859; served with the Okhamandal field force in 1859, and was subsequently variously employed in the survey department in Cutch, Kattywar, Guzerat, Meywar, Malwa, the Deccan, and Kanara; deputy superintendent, Oct., 1867; on deputation as commissioner, Venice geographical exhibition, April-Nov., 1881; deputy superintendent, 1st grade, Nov., 1883; officiating deputy surveyor-general in charge of trigonometrical survey branch, Oct., 1884; confirmed, Feb., 1887; retired from civil employment, 1890.

HAINES, SIR FREDERICK PAUL, Field-Marshal, G.C.B., G.C.S.I., C.I.E.—Entered the army as
ensign in 1839; captain in 1846; lieutenant-colonel in 1850; colonel in 1854; major-general in 1864; military secretary to Sir Hugh Gough in the war on the Sutlej, 1845; was present at the battles of Moodkee and Ferozeshah (medal and clasp); served through the Punjab Campaign of 1848 and 1849, and was present at Rannuggar, the passage of the Chenab, and the battles of Chillianwallah and Goojerat; served with the 21st fuziliers through the campaign of the Crimea, 1854-1855 (medal with four clasps, 5th class of the Medjidie and Turkish medal); K.C.B., 1871; lieutenant-general, 1873; brevet-general, and G.C.B., 1877; commander-in-chief of the Madras army, and member of the governor's council, May, 1871 to 1875; appointed colonel of the 104th regiment, 1874; commander-in-chief of the forces in India, with local rank of general, and extraordinary member of the governor-general's council, April, 1876 to 1881, and directed the military operations of the Afghan campaigns of 1878-9 and 1879-80; thanked by both houses of parliament, 4th Aug., 1879, and 5th of May, 1881.

HAINES, HERMANN A., Political Department, India Office.—Educated at Wellington College, and Keble College, Oxford; junior clerk, financial department, India Office, 15th Nov., 1881; political department, 1886; précis writer, Dec., 1889.

HALL, CHARLES FREDERICK, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from May, 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating superintendent of jail, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Bareilly, Dec., 1882; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Budaun, Feb., 1883; retired, Dec., 1886.

HALL, M. S., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, India Office, 21st Jan., 1875; clerk, 2nd class, Oct., 1878.

HALL, WILLIAM THOMAS, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Rossall, Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1878, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner and settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; director of land records and agriculture, Oct., 1887; on special duty to Perak tin mines in 1888-89.

HALLEN, JAMES HERBERT BROKENCOTE, F.R.C.S., Revenue and Agricultural Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 23rd May, 1850, as veterinary surgeon; acted as principal veterinary surgeon, Abyssinian field force, Dec., 1867; president of the Indian cattle plague commission, Nov., 1869; inspecting veterinary surgeon, Bengal army, July, 1872; ditto, horse-breeding operations, May, 1875; inspecting veterinary surgeon and general superintendent, horse-breeding operations, Nov., 1884; inspector-general, civil veterinary department in India, April, 1892; author of 'Manual of the more deadly forms of Cattle Disease in India.'

HALLETT, HENRY HONYWOOD HUGHES, Colonel, I.S.C., Jail Department, Central Provinces.—First commission as ensign, July, 1858; arrived in India, 11th Aug., 1858; was employed under the military department up to 1868, including service with the Bundelcund field force, 1859; from Dec., 1868, served in the Central Provinces as personal assistant to chief commissioner, assistant commissioner, acting district superintendent of police, acting cantonment magistrate, and was appointed superintendent of the school of industry and central jail, Jubbulpore, Aug., 1878; in addition, superintendent of reformatory school, June, 1891; acting also as small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, 1883, and as cantonment magistrate at various periods.

HALLETT, JOHN REVANS, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the University of Melbourne; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 17th Oct., 1864; assistant magistrate and collector, Burdwan, May, 1865; inspector of schools, Aug., 1870; officiating judge of the small cause courts, Bhagulpore and Monghyr, March, 1876; second inspector of registration offices, March, 1876; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1878; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Sept., 1880, and 1st grade, Dec., 1887; retired, Feb., 1890.

HALLIDAY, SIR FREDERICK JAMES, K.C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1824; arrived in India, 8th June, 1825; served in Bengal as junior assistant to the agent in the Saugor division and assistant registrar of the Sudder court; joint magistrate and deputy collector in Bundelcund, and afterwards in Noacolly and Bullooh, 1831-35; magistrate and collector of the zillah court at Dacca, Feb., 1835; magistrate, collector, and salt agent, Cuttack, Feb., 1836; secretary to the sudder board of revenue, April, 1836; secretary to the government of Bengal, judicial and revenue departments, May, 1838; member of the general committee of public instruction, June, 1838; junior secretary to the government of India, revenue, judicial, and legislative departments, in addition to his other duties, March, 1840, to 1843; secretary to the government of India, home department, 1849; member of governor-general's council, Dec., 1853; lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1st May, 1854; retired in 1859; member of council of secretary of state for India, 30th Sept., 1868, to 31st Dec., 1886.

HALLIDAY, FREDERICK MYTON, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury; arrived, 30th Oct., 1856; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, officiating civil and sessions judge, and magistrate and collector (1st grade, May, 1871); officiated as opium agent, Benares, in 1876 and 1877; commissioner, Presidency division, April, 1878, and Patna division, June, 1878; officiating member, board of revenue, Sept., 1884, to April, 1885, and from July, 1886 to Feb., 1887, and again in Nov., 1887, and March, 1888; chairman, port commissioners, Calcutta, April, 1887; officiated at various periods as additional member of governor-general's council; confirmed as member of board of revenue, April, 1889; resigned, Nov., 1891.

HALLIFAX, ARTHUR GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal
civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived, 28th Dec., 1890, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

HALLIFAX, CHARLES JOSEPH, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton, and All Souls' College, Oxford; appointed member of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1888, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating councillor to H.H. the Raja of Suket, March, 1891.

HAM, WILLIAM JAMES, Postal Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, and was attached to the sea post office, Bombay, 6th May, 1868; supernumerary inspector, 1st grade, director-general's office, Oct., 1877; deputy postmaster-general, Central India, May, 1880, and at Calcutta, attached to the railway mail service, April, 1882; assistant director-general, June, 1887; officiating deputy postmaster-general, Burma, Dec., 1889; inspector-general, railway mail service, Sept., 1890.

HAMBLIN, RICHARD EBB, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, and Christ College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 4th Jan., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, June, 1887; joint magistrate, March, 1890; officiating magistrate and collector, 1887, and again in 1890; officiating deputy commissioner, March, 1891.

HAMILTON, FRANK SUMNER, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Manchester Grammar School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1885, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

HAMILTON, RIGHT HON. LORD GEORGE FRANCIS, M.P.—Born Dec., 1845; educated at Harrow; ensign, Rifle Brigade, 1864; transferred to the Coldstream Guards, 1868; was elected member for Middlesex, Dec., 1868, and represented that county in parliament until the election which followed the Reform Bill of 1885, when he was returned for the Ealing Division; under secretary of state for India, Feb., 1874; vice-president of the committee of council on education, April, 1878; first lord of the admiralty in the Marquis of Salisbury's first administration, June, 1885, and again, Aug., 1886.

HAMILTON, RICHARD ERRIS, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, 1st Aug., 1868; served as assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, March, 1869, also in British Burma, May, 1870; assistant comptroller-general, June, 1872; from July, 1873, to March, 1876, served in Bombay as assistant accountant-general and as assistant commissioner of paper currency, and subsequently in Calcutta, March, 1876, to Dec., 1877; reposted to Bombay, March, 1878; officiated as deputy accountant-general in Bombay, the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, the Punjab, and Madras, 1879-81; officiating assistant secretary, government of India, financial department, March, 1882; controller and deputy commissioner of paper currency, Central Provinces, Jan., 1883; officiating comptroller, India treasuries, April, 1891; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, March, 1892.

HAMILTON, THOMAS SHARP, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Old Trafford School, Manchester, the College, Chester, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant judge and sessions judge; promoted to and assistant collector, Feb., 1883; 3rd grade, assistant judge, Nov., 1887; 3rd grade judge and sessions judge, April, 1890; 2nd grade, May, 1891.

HAMILTON, WILLIAM ROBARTS, B.L., Police Department, Bombay.—Joined the service, 1st Feb., 1869, as superintendent in the political, &c., departments, of the secretariat; assistant to the revenue and police commissioner, Oct., 1869; 1st grade deputy collector, May, 1874; city magistrate, Sept., 1874; Huzur deputy commissioner, July, 1876; 3rd presidency magistrate, Jan., 1883; 2nd Aug., 1890; author of a police manual, and works on 'Local Self-Government' and 'Villages.'

HAMMICK, MURRAY, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; from Jan. to June, 1882, served in Coorg as acting 1st assistant commissioner and district magistrate; from Jan., 1883, served in the Madras secretariat as assistant secretary, judicial and legislative departments, and acting under secretary in the revenue department; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, South Canara, April, 1885; acting postmaster-general, Madras, Jan.-May, 1886; secretary to the commissioners of land revenue, Oct., 1887; has also acted as secretary to the board of examiners, and to the board of revenue, and as collector and magistrate.

HAMMICK, STEPHEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough, and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant educational inspector, acting assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; assistant political agent, and tutor to the Maharaja of Kolhapur, Feb., 1873; on famine duty, Kaladgi, Sept., 1877; judicial assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, Aug., 1883; 3rd grade judge and sessions judge, Shikarpur, Feb., 1885; acting remembrancer of legal affairs, June, 1885; 2nd grade judge, Sept., 1885; member of Deccan agriculturists' relief act commission, 1891-92; 1st grade judge, April, 1892.

HAMNETT, FREDERICK HARPER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and was on special duty, Sept., 1882, preparing the Madras administration report; from March, 1885, to March, 1886, served in the financial department as assistant accountant-general, Madras, and acting deputy-accountant-general; acting sub-collector, Godavari, April, 1886; head assistant to collector and
magistrate, Nov., 1887; sub-collector and joint magistrate, June, 1891.

HAMNETT, GEORGE, C.I.E., late Registration Department, Madras.—Served from 11th March, 1843, in the public works and revenue departments as writer, head clerk, and manager and surveyor in office of consulting engineer for railways; uncoventional assistant to the consulting engineer, Jan., 1859; receiver of the Carnatic property, Feb., 1875; marriage registrar for town of Madras, Jan., 1866; first uncov. assistant, chief secretary's office, Feb., 1867; inspector-general of registration, Nov., 1880; C.I.E., June, 1885; was also registrar-general for Mysore, including Bangalore; retired 1889; appointed additional member of the legislative council of the governor of Madras, Aug., 1890.

HANCOCK, GEORGE EDWARD, Colonel, I.S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1859, and served under the military department till Nov., 1863; from Nov., 1863, to March, 1868, served as assistant superintendent of revenue survey, and assessment, Gujarat; from March, 1868, acted as political and personal assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar; acting superintendent of the Rajkot and Limbdi states, Aug., 1869; acting assistant resident at Aden, May, 1870, and at Baroda, May, 1871; assistant general superintendent for thuggee and dacoity, Oct., 1871; acting cantonment magistrate, Baroda, Oct., 1871; assistant political agent, Mahi Kantha, July, 1872; from Oct., 1873, served as superintendent of surveys under Rajasthank court, Kathiawar, and acted on various occasions as president of the court; on special duty at Delhi, Nov., 1876, to Jan., 1877; acting joint administrator of Gondal state, Nov., 1880, to Feb., 1881; on special duty with the Thakor Saheb of Gondal on tour in Europe, April, 1883; on special duty to inquire into administration of Rajpipla state, Nov., 1883; third assistant political agent, Kathiawar, Feb., 1885, continuing to be superintendent of surveys; president of the Rajasthank court, Kathiawar, Jan., 1886; political superintendent, Savantvadi, May, 1891; resumed his post in Kathiawar, Oct., 1891.

HANDLEY, ALFRED PERCIVAL, B.L., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Joined the service, 14th March, 1890, as officiating chief presidency magistrate and judge of the court for trial of pilots, Calcutta, and served until Oct., 1891; from Feb., 1892, acted as presidency magistrate, and was appointed judge of Calcutta small cause court, May, 1892.

HANDLEY, FRANCIS FREDERICK, B.L., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Sydenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 7th Oct., 1872; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; officiating inspector-general of registration, and senior marriage registrar, Calcutta, Dec., 1880; first inspector of registration offices, Dec., 1881; officiating district and sessions judge, 1884, and 1888; acting inspector-general of registration, April, 1885; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Nov., 1885; district and sessions judge, April, 1889.

HANDLEY, JAMES WILLIAM, M.A., B.L., Judicial Department, Madras.—Served in Madras as government pleader from 29th Oct., 1868, to July, 1881; fellow of Madras University, March, 1881; first judge of the court of small causes, Madras, July, 1881; officiating judge of the high court, July to Nov., 1885, and from July, 1889.

HANKEY, HERBERT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1856; served in the Punjab till 1862, and subsequently in the Lower Provinces, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Malda, 1867, and subsequently at Chittagong; superintendent of transport during famine of 1874; inspector-general of police, Lower Provinces, 1876; retired, 1878.

HANKIN, EDWARD LEWIS, Major-General, I.S.C., late Madras Police.—Ensign Indian army, Dec., 1847; arrived in India 16th June, 1848; served in the public works department, Madras, from Aug., 1853, to July, 1859; served subsequently in the police department as superintendent of police and acting deputy inspector-general, and temporarily in the department of the deputy inspector-general of hospitals, Jan.—June, 1861; acting magistrate of police for town of Madras, March, 1870; joint magistrate, Ootacamund, Nov., 1870, to Sept., 1876; superintendent of family payments and pensions, Oct., 1876; secretary to government, military department, Madras, Dec., 1882; returned to Europe, 1888.

HANNAN, JOHN, Madras Public Works Department.—Joined the service, July, 1866, and served in the Madras presidency as assistant engineer and executive engineer; superintending engineer, Dec., 1891.

HANNAY, ALEXANDER LIDDERDALE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Uppingham, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1891, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

HANNYNGTON, JOHN CHILD, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived, 8th Nov., 1857; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, small cause court judge, and acting collector and magistrate; district and sessions judge, Salem, Nov., 1873; on special duty, Dec., 1880, as arbitrator of boundary disputes between states of Travancore and Cochin; on tour with H.H. the Maharajah of Travancore on various occasions; resident of Travancore and Cochin, April, 1882; retired, Nov., 1892.

HAPPELL, WILLIAM ALEXANDER, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Crosshill School, Maybole, Glasgow University, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1864; assistant collector and Magistrate, Nov., 1865; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Sept.-Nov., 1879; sub-collector and joint magistrate, April, 1880; acting commissioner of salt revenue, Madras, April to Nov., 1881; district and sessions judge, Nellore, Jan., 1883; collector and magistrate, Kista, Nov., 1883; collector and magistrate, and government agent, Godavari, Sept., 1886; retired, Jan., 1892.

HARCOURT, ALFRED FREDERICK POLLOCK, Colonel, I.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 15th Oct., 1855; from Sept., 1862,
served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating small cause court judge; judicial assistant, 1st grade, March, 1877; deputy commissioner, April, 1877; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1883; retired, March, 1889; author of 'Down by the Drawl,' 'The Royal Umbrella,' and 'Kulu Lahoul and Spiti.'

HARDIE, R., Council of India.—Appointed to the council of the secretary of state for India on 17th March, 1887; vice-president, 1892-93; was previously engaged in the profession of banking, and held the office of secretary and treasurer of the Bank of Bengal for 15 years; in 1886 was a member of the finance committee appointed by the government of India for the reduction of expenditure.

HARDING, FRANCIS HENRY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Tonbridge School, and St. Catherine's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, March, 1885; district and sessions judge, May, 1890.

HARDING, HERBERT OLIVE DENMAN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1886, and served in the revenue survey and settlement department, and as assistant to magistrate and collector.

HARDING, HERBERT W., Audit Department, India Office.—Associate of King's College, London; writer, India office, 27th April, 1868; junior examiner, audit department, Nov., 1873.

HARDY, RICHARD GILLIES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Witney Grammar School, and Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Aug., 1885; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, May, 1885; magistrate and collector, July, 1889; officiated as commissioner of Jhansi, 1889.

HARE, Lancelot, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. John's College, Hurstpierpoint, and City of London School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments in Bengal and Assam as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; on famine duty, July, 1874; assistant secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, March, 1879, and officiating secretary March, 1880; officiating inspector-general of police, jails, and registration, commissioner of excise, and superintendent of stamps, Assam, July, 1880; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Nov., 1884; magistrate and collector, June, 1890; officiated as commissioner, Dacca division, in May, 1891.

HARE, ROBERT DOUGLAS, Berar Commission.—Joined the service as extra assistant commissioner, Chota Nagpur (Bengal), 14th June, 1866; served on famine duty, May, 1874, and in Berar from Oct., 1875; assistant commissioner, May, 1878; judge of small cause court, June, 1883; deputy commissioner, July, 1889; director of land records and agriculture, July, 1890, to Aug., 1891.

HARI KISHEN KAUL, PANDIT, M.A., Punjab Commission.—Probationer under native civil service rules, 17th April, 1890.

HARINGTON, ARTHUR HENRY, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; served in Oudh from Aug., 1863, as assistant commissioner and junior secretary to chief commissioner; from Dec., 1866, to Jan., 1868, served under the government of India as officiating assistant secretary, foreign department, and officiating under secretary, home department; officiating superintendent of excise and stamps, Oudh, July, 1868; appointed to take up lands for railway purposes, Nov., 1868; officiating personal assistant to financial commissioner, March, 1869; officiating settlement officer, Hardoi, March, 1870; manager of encumbered estates, Fyzabad and Gonda, 1872-75; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1879; magistrate and collector, Saharanpur, Oct., 1883; acted as commissioner in the Lucknow, Sitapur, Rae Bareli, Fyzabad, and Allahabad divisions; commissioner in Oudh, June, 1889; commissioner, Allahabad division, Nov., 1889; Meerut division, May, 1891; author of 'Economic Reform in Rural India.'

HARINGTON, HERBERT BARING, M.A., late Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1857, as assistant in telegraph department; for services during the mutiny at the relief of Lucknow received medal and clasp; from Feb., 1860, served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating settlement officer; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, 1869-73; also officiating director of public instruction, April-July, 1870; deputy commissioner, July, 1875; district judge, and grade, Lucknow, Aug., 1879; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Sultanpur, Dec., 1881; officiated as commissioner of the Sitapur division in 1876, and of the Rae Bareli division in 1881, 1884, and 1885; retired, Nov., 1887.

HARMAN, C., Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 10th Aug., 1878.

HARRIDANCE, H., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 8th March, 1878.
