HARRIS, EDWARD BRANSON, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bedford Commercial School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1877; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Feb., 1888; magistrate and collector, June, 1892.

HARRIS, (BARON), RIGHT HON. GEORGE ROBERT CANNING, G.C.I.E.—Educated at Eton, and at Christ Church, Oxford, where he graduated B.A. in 1874; is J. P. and D. L. for Kent, and deputy chairman of the East Kent Quarter Sessions; under secretary for India in Lord Salisbury's first administration, June, 1885, to Feb., 1886; under secretary of state for war, Aug., 1886; took his seat as Governor of Bombay in succession to Lord Reay, 12th April, 1890.

HARRIS, RICHARD WILLIAM, Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 11th July, 1892.
HARRIS, ROBERT LISTON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at King's College School, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1877, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating district judge; deputed to settlement department, Dec., 1883, to Feb., 1884; officiating divisional judge and officiating deputy commissioner for various periods; 2nd grade district judge, Nov., 1889.

HARRISON, ALFRED INGLEBY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Highgate Grammar School and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 29th Nov., 1890, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating cantonment magistrate.

HARRISON, CHARLES WILLIAM INGLEBY, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, 11th June, 1858; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1860; served in the public works department, irrigation branch, North-Western Provinces, from 10th April, 1863, as assistant engineer, executive engineer, and assistant to chief engineer, and was employed on the Eastern Jumna, Rohilkhund, and Ganges canals; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1881; deputed to Bengal as member of commission to enquire into system of canal administration in Orissa, Dec., 1884, to April, 1885; superintending engineer, 2nd class, May, 1886; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary to government, Bengal, July, 1886, and as secretary, April-June, 1888; superintending engineer, 1st class, Feb., 1888; 3rd chief engineer, Dec., 1889; 2nd, July, 1891; 1st, March, 1892; chief engineer and joint secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1890; officiating secretary, May, 1890; confirmed, July, 1891.

HARRISON, FRANCIS CAPEL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1884; served in Assam from Jan. to May, 1889, as assistant commissioner; officiating assistant accountant-general, Madras, May, 1889, and deputy accountant-general, Bengal, March, 1890; confirmed, Sept., 1890; officiating under-secretary to government of India, finance department, May, 1892.

HARRISON, HENRY ANTHONY, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; arrived in India, 3rd April, 1855; served from May, 1856, to Sept., 1858, in Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, Cuttack, and subsequently in the N.W. Provinces; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1862; assistant, settlement department, Feb., 1864; magistrate and collector, Hamirpur, March, 1872; magistrate and collector, Farukhabad, 1873-1877; officiating commissioner, Jhansi division, Sept., 1875; civil and sessions judge, Allahabad, March, 1878, and subsequently at Mirzapore, Farukhabad, and Meerut; 1st grade judge, March, 1884; retired, June, 1887.

HARRISON, JOHN HENRY, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Erasmus Smith's School, and Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant superintendent, Dehra Dun, Nov., 1876; officiating assistant director of department of agriculture and commerce, Nov., 1880; acting junior secretary, board of revenue, March, 1881; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Aug., 1885; 2nd grade settlement officer, Oct., 1887; has also officiated as magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 1st grade, April, 1889; deputy commissioner, April, 1891.

HARRISON, PERCY, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at St. Paul's School and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

HARRISON, RICHARD PRYCE, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1834; arrived in India, 19th Sept., 1835; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and officiating collector, Moorsheadabad, 1849; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Bograh, 1850; officiating abkari commissioner, Dacca division, 1851; magistrate, collector, and salt agent, Cuttack, 1853-56; civil and sessions judge, 1856; accountant-general, government of Madras, and a government director of the Madras bank, 1859; accountant-general and auditor-general to government of India, and a government director of the bank of Bengal, 1860; also first member and president of the board of audit; comptroller-general, 1863-67; resigned, April, 1867.

HARRISON, WILLIAM PRINGLE, Lieut.-Col., Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India as ensign, 10th Feb., 1861; employed under the military department till Oct., 1867, from which date he served in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner, and acted as district superintendent of police in 1873-74, and as superintendent of encumbered estates in Sultanpur in 1874; sub-judge, Patna, Aug., 1870; cantonment magistrate of Fyzabad, July, 1881, and subsequently of Lucknow, April, 1883; also acted as district judge in 1884-85; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1888.

HART, GEORGE HENRY REEVES, Financial Department, Government of India.—Probationer in financial department, 20th July, 1869; from Dec., 1870, served as assistant to comptroller-general; on special duty in Behar, Jan.-March, 1874; assistant to private secretary to viceroy, April, 1874, to April, 1876; assistant to accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1877; from Feb., 1878, acted as private secretary to governor of Bombay, and was confirmed in this appointment, March, 1880; placed in class 4 of financial department on return; appointed assistant accountant-general in charge of paper currency office, Bombay, Aug., 1887, class 3 of financial department; deputy accountant-general, Lahore, Jan., 1886; Bombay, Feb., 1891; in 1886 and 1890, acted as assistant secretary to the government of India, finance and commerce department.

HART, JOHN HENRY EUSTACE, M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1854; joined the Bombay
public works department, Jan., 1855, and served as civil engineer at Satara, Nasik, and Dharwar; acting executive engineer for reclamations, Bombay, May, 1869; architectural executive engineer and surveyor, Bombay, May, 1871; acting superintendent, harbour works, Karachi, Nov., 1874; acting superintending engineer in Sind, April, 1876; acting chief engineer for irrigation, Sept., 1877; superintending engineer 1st class, March, 1880; joint secretary to government of Bombay for irrigation, March, 1880; chief engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1885; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government of Bombay public works and irrigation department, Sept., 1887; retired, 1888.

HART, WILLIAM, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service in 1834; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate and assistant judge and sessions judge; commissioner for enquiring into claims, &c., South Mahratta country, 1847; secretary to government of Bombay, in the general and ecclesiastical departments, 1855, also in the public works department, and railway branch, 1856; puisne judge of the court of Sudder Dewani, 1860; revenue and police commissioner, Southern division, 1862; additional member of Bombay council for making laws and regulations, 1864; retired in 1865.

HART-DAVIES, THOMAS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from May, 1876, served in Sind as educational inspector, acting judge and session judge, and acting assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration; manager of encumbered estates in Sind, Oct., 1879, to Sept., 1885; 1st assistant collector, April, 1887; joint judge and sessions judge, Ahmedabad, June, 1891; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Surat, April, 1892.

HARTNOLL, HENRY SULIVAN, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Exeter Grammar School, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant commissioner, Burma, Dec., 1883; deputy commissioner, July, 1890.

HARTT, WILLIAM EDWARD, Railway Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 19th April, 1876; assistant traffic superintendent, class 4, superior revenue establishment of state railways, 1878; class 3, Aug., 1879, and class 2, Jan., 1882; district traffic superintendent, 1882.

HARTWELL, SYDNEY CHARLES ELPHINSTONE, Railway Department, Government of India.—Appointed traffic superintendent, Oudh and Rohilkund railway, 1st Jan., 1889; officiating manager, Sept., 1891.

HARVEY, EDWARD, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, 22nd Dec., 1859; served in the public works department from April, 1864; executive engineer, military works branch, June, 1871; served in the Lushai expedition, 1871-2 (medal and clasp), in the Jowaki Afridi campaign, 1878-9 (clasp), and in the Afghan war, 1879-80 (medal, brevet of major); superintending engineer, May, 1889; member of accounts committee, 1888-9.

HARVEY, JOHN, Educational Department, Punjab.—Served as assistant master and officiating head master in the Zillah schools at Amritsar, Lahore, and Gujrat, from 1st Nov., 1866; head master district school, Delhi, March, 1876; assistant inspector of schools, April, 1877; tutor to H.H. the Raja of Chamba, Nov., 1879; inspector of schools, Nov., 1883; 3rd grade, Delhi circle, 1889.

HARVEY, ROBERT, Surgeon-Colonel, M.B., D.S.O., late Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1865; officiating civil surgeon, Sept. to Dec., 1865; officiating sanitary commissioner, Bengal, Jan., 1878; member of committee to report on management of the medical institutions, and on medical expenditure in Bengal, March, 1878; civil surgeon, Bankoora, May, 1878; officiating professor of midwifery, Medical College, Calcutta, and superintendent-general of vaccination, Aug., 1878; civil surgeon, 24 Pergunnahs, and medical inspector of emigrants, Nov., 1878; also in medical charge of the Alipore and Russa jails, May, 1879; also superintendent of emigration, July, 1879; officiating professor of midwifery, medical college, and obstetric physician to the college hospital, Sept., 1880; confirmed in this appointment, Sept., 1882; also officiating principal of the college, May to July, 1882; honorary surgeon on personal staff of H.E. the Viceroy, May, 1883; brigade-surgeon, Jan., 1889; reverted to military department, March, 1890.

HARVEY, WILLIAM LEATHEM, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal Academical Institution, Belfast, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Oct., 1884; forest settlement officer, April, 1887; officiating under secretary to government, revenue, financial and general departments, March, 1891; confirmed, Aug., 1891.

HARWARD, ALFRED EDGAR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rossall School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1885, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

HASHMAT-ULLA, MAULVI, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed a probationer under the native civil service rules, March, 1886; confirmed as member of the civil service, 13th June, 1889, as assistant magistrate and collector.

HASTED, JOHN ORD, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—2nd lieutenant, Madras engineers, Dec., 1853; arrived in India 2nd Dec., 1855; served in the Madras public works department from 30th Jan., 1856, as assistant engineer, and was promoted to executive engineer, April, 1865, and superintending engineer, Feb., 1877; officiated as chief engineer for irrigation, and joint secretary to government for various periods between 1875 and 1884; and was confirmed in this appointment and promoted to chief engineer, 2nd class, April, 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1883; chief engineer, 1st class, Sept., 1886; secretary to the government of Madras, public works department, general and buildings and road branches, 1886; retired, July, 1890.

HASTINGS, F.T.C., India Office.—Educated at Haileybury College; admiralty writer, 8th Oct., 1868, to Jan., 1874; civil service copyist
from Jan., 1874, to Feb., 1877; clerk specially attached to the political and secret department, India office, 7th March, 1877; resident clerk, July, 1888; assistant private secretary to the secretary of state, June, 1892.

HASTINGS, WARREN, Captain, I.S.C., Berar Commission.—1st commission, 28th Feb., 1874; served in Bengal as cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge from Jan., 1881; special assistant commissioner, Berar, Sept., 1887; deputy commissioner, July, 1891; in charge of provincial census operations, April, 1890.

HATCH, WILLIAM KEITH, Surgeon-Major, M.B., C.M. (Aber.), F.R.C.S. (London), Bombay Medical Department.—Arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1877; second surgeon of the Jamsetji Jijibhoy hospital, and professor of anatomy, &c., Grant medical college, May, 1884; acted as medical officer on the governor's personal staff, Jan. to March, 1885; surgeon-major, March, 1889.

HATCHELL, CHARLES Surgeon-Major, late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 23rd July, 1858; arrived in India, 30th Sept., 1858; served in N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon from Dec., 1859, to Oct., 1864, and was subsequently employed under the military department, and served in the Bhutan expedition; served again under government of N.W. Provinces from Nov., 1869, and was appointed civil assistant surgeon, and superintendent of jail, Bulandshahr; rank of surgeon, July, 1870; served subsequently as civil surgeon at Bulandshahr, Jaunpur, Muzaffarnagar, Aligurh, and Farukhabad; senior surgeon-major, July, 1878; retired, Oct., 1888.

HATHORNTHWAITE, JAMES THOMAS, M.A., Educational Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 3rd Oct., 1872, and served in the Bombay educational department from that date as professor of mathematics at the Elphinstone College, Bombay, and also acted as principal of the college for various periods; promoted to 3rd grade of the education department, Dec., 1877.

HAWES, ARTHUR B., Captain, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Westminster; ensign, Bengal army, 12th Dec., 1849; chief executive officer of telegraph from Bagdad to Constantinople, 1857-58; captain, May, 1858; retired, Oct., 1858; assistant auditor, India office, March, 1859; member of committee for valuation of military equipments, April, 1863; author of a work on small arms ammunition.

HAWKINS, CESAR RICHARD, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Harrow School, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1862; served in Bengal as assistant collector and magistrate, and from Feb., 1865, in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Peshawur, March, 1870; officiating secretary to financial commissioner, 1876; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Jan., 1879; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; officiating divisional judge, Feb., 1885; officiating commissioner and superintendent, April, 1887; and again in Feb., 1888; confirmed, April, 1889; retired, Nov., 1890.

HAY, GEORGE WILLIAM ROBERTSON, Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, M.D., Bombay Medical Department.—Joined the service, 1st April, 1868; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1868; served in the military, civil, and jail branches of the service, and was appointed port surgeon at Aden, June, 1876; secretary to the surgeon-general, Poona, 1891.

HAYWARD, MAURICE HENRY WESTON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Harrow and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1889, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

HAZLETT, HENRY JAMES, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon - Lieut.- Colonel, Madras Medical Department.—Joined the service 1st April, 1867; arrived in Madras 8th Nov., 1867, and was employed on general military and jail duty; on special duty as analyst to salt commission, Madras, Feb. - June, 1876; surgeon-major, April, 1879; surgeon, 4th district, Jan., 1887, to May, 1888; also professor of medical jurisprudence in Medical College, Aug., 1887; employed in military accounts department of government of India, June, 1888, and again in 1889.

HEATON, JOSEPH JOHN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bradford Grammar School, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and assistant judge; acting under-secretary to government of Bombay, political, judicial, and educational departments, Oct., 1887; 3rd grade assistant judge and sessions judge, July, 1889; 2nd, Nov., 1891; 1st, April, 1892.

HEAVISIDE, WILLIAM JAMES, Lieut.-Col., R.E., late Survey of India.—Joined Addiscombe, Aug., 1857; lieutenant, Bengal Engineers, June, 1859; arrived in India, Nov., 1861; served in the public works department as assistant engineer from Sept., 1862, to Feb., 1865; assistant field engineer with the Bhutan force, 1865-66 (medal and clasp); joined the great trigonometrical survey, as 2nd grade assistant, Jan., 1866; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1872; served with the Southern Afghanistan field force in 1878-79, on special survey duty (medal, brevet of major); served subsequently in Khandeish and Bombay native states, and was promoted to deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; retired, July, 1888.

HEBBERT, FREDERICK BENBOW, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the department as assistant engineer, 1st Oct., 1874; executive engineer, Sept., 1883; officiating deputy consulting engineer for railways, Lucknow, April, 1887; under-secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, March, 1888; on special duty under director-general of railways, Aug., 1888; officiating assistant secretary to the government of India, public works department, Jan., 1889; officiating under-secretary, Feb.-June, 1889; officiating under-secretary and deputy director-general of railways, July, 1890; confirmed, May, 1892.

HEBBERT, HENRY, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1832; arrived in India, 2nd March, 1833; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the grades of assistant collector.
and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge, and was appointed deputy secretary to government in the Persian department, Jan., 1835; deputy collector of continental customs and excise, 1849; collector and magistrate of Broach, March, 1852; from March, 1853, served in the judicial department, and was appointed judge and sessions judge of Ahmedabad, July, 1853; judge and sessions judge, and agent for the governor, Surat, March, 1856; judge of the court of Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, 1857, and again in 1860; judge of the high court of judicature, Bombay, June, 1862; retired, May, 1863.

HEMING, Dempster, Lieut.-Colonel, Police Department, Madras.—First commission, 16th Nov., 1861; probationary assistant superintendent of police, Dec., 1865; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1874; assistant with the government of Madras, July, 1888, and again, April-Nov., 1890; superintendent of police, Jan., 1892.

HENDERSON, Edward Piercy, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and St. Peter's College, Radley; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; from Feb., 1878, has served as government advocate, Punjab.

HENDERSON, George, M.D., Surgeon-Major, late Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1859; arrived in India, 20th November, 1859; civil assistant surgeon, Shahpur, May, 1862; officiating professor of medicine and surgery, April, 1865, to Jan., 1867; superintendent of Lahore central jail, April, 1868; officiating superintendent, botanical gardens in Bengal, Dec., 1872; civil surgeon, Gujranwala, Dec., 1875, and subsequently at other stations in the Punjab; civil surgeon, 1st class, Oct., 1886; retired, Nov., 1889.

HENDERSON, Philip Durham, Colonel, C.S.I., Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras cavalry, Feb., 1857; attaché, foreign department, May, 1871; under secretary to the government of India, foreign department, Nov., 1872, to July, 1874; resident, 3rd class, on special duty in Cashmere, 1874; political officer on staff of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales, Sept., 1875; C.S.I., March, 1876; general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoity from March, 1878; resident in Mysore, and chief commissioner, Coorg, April, 1892.

HENNESSY, Septimus Hope, late Judicial Department, Central Provinces.—Joined the service as acting extra assistant commissioner, 13th July, 1864, and was confirmed 8th July, 1867; acted as deputy commissioner, and as judge small cause court for various periods, and was appointed to the latter office at Jubulpore in Sept., 1889; acted also as cantonment magistrate from Nov., 1888; retired, January, 1892.

HENNIKER, Frederick Chandos, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at St. Paul's School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1887, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner.

HENRY, Edward Richard, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Edmund's College, Ware, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived, 22nd Oct., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1882; on famine duty, Tirhoot, Dec., 1873; private secretary to lieutenant-governor of Bengal in 1879, and 1880 to 1882; magistrate and collector, May, 1890; officiating secretary to board of revenue, Nov., 1890; officiating inspector-general of police, April, 1891; confirmed, May, 1892.

HENSLowe, Cecil William Edward, late Railway Department.—Joined the public works department, June, 1866, as assistant engineer, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, and in the Central Provinces (1870-71); transferred to railway establishment, Jan., 1880; engineer-in-chief and manager, Cawnpur-Farukhabad and Muttra-Hathras railways, Dec., 1880; class 2, revenue establishment of state railways, May, 1881; manager, Cawnpur-Achneyra state railway, 1884; transferred to Burma state railway, Dec., 1886; retired, 1890.

HENVEY, Frederick, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Dec., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, under secretary to government, officiating secretary to board of revenue, and officiating junior secretary to government, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1869; placed on special duty for purpose of compiling a narrative of the famine of 1869-70, April, 1871; under secretary to government of India, foreign department, July, 1874; officiating resident, Nipal, Jan., 1877, to March, 1878; on special duty, Kashmir, April, 1878; resident, 2nd class, and commissioner, Hyderabad assigned districts, Jan., 1883; resident, Eastern Rajputana states, Dec., 1885; officiating agent to the governor-general in Central India, May, 1888; confirmed, Jan., 1889; retired, Jan., 1891.

HERALD, John Lumgair, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Arbroath High School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1882; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Assam as assistant commissioner, Oct., 1888.

HERBERT, Charles, Captain, I.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1874; served under the military department to 1882, including Afghan war of 1879-80; extra aide-de-camp to Viceroy, June, 1878, and again from March, 1882; officiated as assistant to the governor-general, Rajputana, June, 1882; magistrate of Abu, Nov., 1882; on deputation to Meywar States to settle boundary disputes, Nov., 1883; officiating cantonment magistrate, Nasirabad, May, 1884; returned to his post in Rajputana, July, 1884; again officiated as cantonment magistrate at Nasirabad, Nov., 1885; confirmed in political department, March, 1886, and held various officiating appointments; confirmed as assistant commissioner, Ajmere, April, 1889; assistant to the agent, Rajputana, and chief commissioner, Ajmere-Merwara, March, 1891; officiating
political agent in Eastern States of Rajputana, May, 1891 to Feb., 1892.

HERBERT, PATRICK C.H., India Office.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; junior clerk, accounts branch, India Office, 11th March, 1872; judicial and public department, 1877; resident clerk, 1885-88; senior clerk, May, 1891; private secretary to parliamentary under-secretary of state (Mr. G. W. E. Russell, M.P.), Oct., 1892; editor of India Office List from July, 1887, to Aug., 1891; compiled jointly with Mr. Newmarch the India Office cypher code.

HERRON, HERBERT GEORGE WHITLEY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India 27th Dec., 1887, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, Nov., 1888, and officiating under secretary to chief commissioner; resumed his post in Bengal, Nov., 1890.

HERSCHEL, JOHN, Colonel, F.R.S., R.E., late Survey of India.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1855; first commission, Dec., 1856; arrived at Calcutta, Jan., 1859; served in the great trigonometrical survey from Nov., 1859, in the grades of assistant surveyor and deputy superintendent; 1st grade deputy superintendent, Jan., 1884; retired, March, 1886.

HERVEY, HAMILTON LAW, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Giggleswick School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 27th March, 1887; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1888.

HEWAT, RICHARD A., Military Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 18th Aug., 1838; junior clerk, military department, India office, Aug., 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1875.

HEWETSON, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; served in Burma, from March, 1886, as assistant commissioner; judge, civil court, Mandalay, May, 1886; district officer, Kyaukpyu; returned to Madras, Oct., 1888; senior assistant to collector and district magistrate and agent, Ganjam, July, 1889.

HEWETT, JOHN PRESCOTT, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Winchester, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner; in charge of provincial gazetteer, Aug., 1883; acted as assistant accountant-general, Jan., 1884; junior secretary, board of revenue, April, 1884; officiating under secretary to government of India, home department, Oct., 1886, and confirmed in the appointment, Aug., 1887; officiated as private secretary to the viceroy, in 1888, and as secretary to government of India, home department, March, 1890; officiating census commissioner for India, July, 1890; deputy secretary to government of India, home department, Dec., 1890; C.I.E., May, 1891; officiating secretary, Jan., 1892; officiating private secretary to Viceroy, April, 1892; author of contributions to provincial gazetteer.

HEWISH, JOHN, Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 1st Feb., 1869; senior clerk (supernumerary), Sept., 1883.

HEWITT, JAMES FRANCIS KATHERINUS, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; arrived, 12th Feb., 1859; assistant magistrate and collector, Feb., 1860; officiating deputy commissioner, Lohardugga, July, 1863; settlement officer, Chuttergurh, Dec., 1864; deputy commissioner, wards' estate in Behar, Feb., 1873; officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, May, 1874; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Sept., 1874; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Oct., 1878; commissioner, Chota Nagpur division, March, 1879; retired, July, 1885.

HEYWOOD, JOHN MAGEE, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined Addiscombe, Aug., 1854; 1st commission, Bengal engineers, June, 1856; arrived in India, April, 1858; served in the Bengal public works department from April, 1858, as assistant engineer and executive engineer; on special duty, Oct., 1866; deputed to examine reservoirs in France and Spain while on leave in 1867; ordered to report on arrangements connected with towing in inland rivers in Belgium; special survey duty, Sept., 1870; deputed on special duty to the N.W. Provinces and Punjab, Aug., 1876; superintending engineer, 2nd class, May, 1881; officiating chief engineer, and joint secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, April, 1883, to Feb., 1884; superintending engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1884; chief engineer and joint secretary, irrigation branch, Punjab, 1886; chief engineer, 3rd class, Nov., 1886; retired, Dec., 1889.

HIGGENS, ALFRED WILLIAM BUCKLE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Haileybury College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector; on famine duty, July, 1877, to Nov., 1878; on special duty as secretary to the draft forest bill committee, April-Nov., 1882; deputy conservator of forests, 1st grade, Cuddapah, Dec., 1882; also forest settlement officer, July, 1886; sub-collector and joint magistrate, June, 1890; principal assistant to collector, Jan., 1891; collector and magistrate, Jan., 1892.

HIGGINS, JOHN JAMES, Police Department, Central Provinces.—Appointed acting adjutant military police, Narsinghpur, for services rendered during the mutiny under Sir Henry Havelock, Dec., 1858; from March, 1861, served in the police department of the Central Provinces, and was promoted to district superintendent, 1st class, June, 1879; on special duty at Kalahandi, June, to Aug., 1882.

HIGHAM, THOMAS, M.I.C.E., India Public Works Department.—Appointed probationary assistant engineer, July, 1867; arrived in India, Oct., 1867; served in the irrigation department, Punjab and was promoted to executive engineer, Sept., 1873; assistant secretary to government, irrigation branch, Nov., 1882; superintendent
of works, Derajat, Sept., 1883; superintending engineer, Aug., 1886; 3rd class, Jan., 1887; 2nd class, Dec., 1890; 1st class, June, 1892; officiated as chief engineer and joint secretary to government, Punjab, July-Oct., 1891; author of 'Hydraulic Tables.'

HILDEBRAND, ARTHUR HEDDING, C.I.E., Burma Commission.—From Feb., 1868, to March, 1872, served in the Burma police department as assistant superintendent and acting superintendent; from March, 1872, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner and acting deputy commissioner, and was sent on special mission to Chiangmai, March, 1875, and in charge of expedition to Western Karenni, Jan., 1876; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1885; superintendent of the Shan States, Jan., 1888; C.I.E., May, 1883.

HILDEBRAND, GODFREY, Lieut.-Col., R.E., late Military Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, Oct., 1864; arrived in India, Jan., 1868; joined the P.W. department, March, 1869, and served in Bengal and the N.W. Provinces; transferred to military works, May, 1872; secretary to defence committee, 1881; superintending engineer, March, 1886; deputy director-general, military works, Sept., 1890, to 1891.

HILL, CLAUDE HAMILTON ARCHER, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Mark's School, Windsor, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1887; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1888; acting under-secretary, political, &c., departments, and secretary to legislative council, Jan., 1892.

HILL, F. G., Funds Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 6th July, 1882.

HILL, HARRY CHARLES, India Forest Department.—Arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1872, and appointed assistant conservator of forests; deputy conservator of forests, April, 1879; transferred to the Punjab as officiating conservator, Jan., 1883; conservator of forests, 2nd grade, and ex officio secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, in the forest department for Upper Burma, March, 1887; on deputation to Calcutta as officiating inspector-general of forests, Aug., 1889, and to Bombay in the same capacity, March, 1891.

HILL, HENRY, Public Works Department, India Office.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy and Edinburgh University; India office writer, old establishment, 1859; junior clerk, financial department, 1860; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1867-74; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; revenue, statistics and commerce department, 1874; assistant secretary in the revenue, statistics, and commerce department, Sept., 1877; assistant in the public works department, and assistant government director of guaranteed Indian railway companies, June, 1892; compiled the annual official Reports on Sanitary Measures in India from 1873-74 to 1877-78, and the Moral and Material Progress Reports from 1873-74 to 1875-76.

HILL, JOHN, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, royal engineers, June, 1862; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1865; appointed to the great trigonometrical survey of India as assistant surveyor, Dec., 1866, and was employed in Kumaon and Garhwal, and afterwards in Bombay, and on the eastern frontier; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Oct., 1870; deputy superintendent, July, 1882; attached to Afghan boundary commission, Sept., 1884; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Oct., 1884; 2nd grade, Oct., 1890; in charge of tidal and levelling operations, Poona, June, 1891.

HILL, THOMAS COUTTS, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 1st Aug., 1857; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1867; superintendent, British Burma, Feb., 1879; 1st grade superintendent, March, 1885; employed in connexion with occupation of Upper Burma, 1886 (special thanks of government); class IV., 1st grade, Oct., 1887.

HILL, WILLIAM, Colonel, I.S.C., late Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Aug., 1853; served in the Mysore commission from July, 1859, as junior assistant; deputy superintendent, 3rd class, Mysore commission, Nov., 1862; deputy commissioner in Mysore, April, 1873; acted for various periods as commissioner in the Nandurdrug and Nagar Divisions; acting commissioner of Coorg, 1881; from March, 1885, served as civil and sessions judge of the civil and military station of Bangalore; returned to Europe, 1891.

HILSON, ARCHIBALD HAMILTON, M.D., Deputy Surg.-General, Bengal Medical Department.—Served in the army medical department from Dec., 1855; appointed assistant surgeon on the Bengal medical establishment, 29th Jan., 1857; arrived in India, 3rd June, 1857, and served under the military department in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab, including service in the Mutiny (medal), and in the Bhootan campaign (medal and clasp), also temporarily holding the civil surgeoncies of Moradabad, 1860, and Aligarh, 1863, and serving as civil assistant surgeon, Gorakhpur, 1864; rank of surgeon, Jan., 1869; from April, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, Naini Tal, and officiating civil surgeon at Bijnor and Moradabad; also held charge of the jails at Bijnor and Moradabad, and of the lock hospital at the latter place; civil surgeon, Naini Tal, Oct., 1874; civil surgeon, 1st class, and superintendent, lunatic asylum, and principal, medical school, Agra, March, 1876; brigade surgeon, Sept., 1884; deputy surgeon-general, Bengal, Dec., 1887; officiating inspector-general of civil hospitals from April, 1888; confirmed, April, 1889; author of various professional papers on snake-bite, leprosy, and diseases of the eye, of a 'Memorandum on the Medical Education of the Native Women in India,' 1872, and of the annual reports of the Agra medical school, 1875 to 1886.

HOARE, HERBERT JAMES, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at private schools and at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant superintendent, Dehra Dun.

HOBART, ROBERT THOMPSON, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Oct., 1862 served in the N.W. Provinces
as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; deputy inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1873; inspector-general of prisons, Oct., 1882; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1886; retired, Dec., 1889.

HOBDAY, JAMES RAMSAY, Major, I.S.C., Survey of India Department.—1st commission, 13th Jan., 1869; probationary assistant superintendent, survey department, Sept., 1874; confirmed, July, 1875; served in the Afghan war, 1879, and with Upper Burma Field Force, 1886; deputy superintendent, 4th grade, Jan., 1887; 3rd grade, Nov., 1890; accompanied special expedition in Upper Burma along the Chinese frontier, 1890-91.

HOBHOUSE (Baron), Rt. Hon. ARTHUR HOBHOUSE, Q.C., K.C.S.I., C.I.E.—Born 10th Nov., 1819; educated at Eton and Balliol College, Oxford, where he gained a first-class in classics in 1840; called to the bar, 1845, and practised in the Rolls court; Q.C. in 1865; appointed a charity commissioner in 1866; endowed schools commissioner, 1869; legal member of council of the governor-general of India, 1872-1877; K.C.S.I., Jan., 1877; arbitrator under the Epping Forest Act, 1878; privy councillor, and member of the judicial committee, 1881; created a baron in 1883; one of the quorum of the House of Lords for judicial purposes; author of 'The Dead Hand,' a collection of addresses connected with endowments and the settlements of land, 1880; contested Westminster unsuccessfully in the general election of 1880.

HOBHOUSE, ARTHUR F., late Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at Royal College, Boulogne; junior clerk, India board, political and secret department, 30th Oct., 1840; private secretary to the president, 1849-52; public department, 1852; private secretary to the permanent under secretary of state, India Office (Sir George R. Clerk, K.C.B.) 1853-60; senior clerk, public department, 1860; assistant secretary in the public department, June, 1867; retired, June, 1887.

HOBHOUSE, SIR CHARLES PARRY, BART., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1844; arrived in India, 22nd July, 1844, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and in the financial department, government of India, as assistant to the sub-treasurer, and assistant to accountant-general; collector of Burdwan, 1857-59; magistrate and collector, 1859; officiating civil and sessions judge, 1859-60; deputed on special duty in 1860 to adjudicate on suits arising out of the indigo disturbances, Nuddea and Jessore; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, and government advocate, 1862, and also member of council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal for making laws and regulations, 1863-64; civil and sessions judge, 1864-66; on special duty in Calcutta to revise law relating to stamp duties; additional member of governor-general's council, 1866; on special duty as chairman of the Orissa famine and orphan relief fund, 1867; judge of the high court of judicature, 1868 to 1871; retired 1872.

HODGSON, J., Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 19th Aug., 1873.

HODSON, RICHARD GEORGE, Education Department, Burma.—Joined the education department as deputy inspector of schools, Mysore, April, 1861; inspector of schools, April, 1867; was for two years in special charge of all Canarese normal schools in the province; acting director of public instruction, Mysore and Coorg, April, 1879, to April, 1880; transferred to Burma as acting principal, government high school, Rangoon, April, 1880; from Oct., 1881, served as inspector of schools in Burma, and officiated as director of public instruction in 1884, and again in 1887 and 1888; has translated Munshi Srinivasaya's 'Dialogues in Canarese.'

HOEY, WILLIAM, M.A., D.Lit., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Wesleyan Connexional School, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 18th Oct., 1872, and served in N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner, and assistant magistrate; officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, Sept., 1879; joint magistrate, 1st grade, s.p.t., March, 1885; has acted as magistrate and collector of Banda, Fatehpur, and Etawah, and was employed on archaeological explorations in Gonda in 1884; officiating deputy commissioner, Partabgurh, March, 1887; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Aug., 1887; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1890; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1890; author of contributions to the 'Gazetteer of Oudh,' and to the 'Imperial Gazetteer of India,' 'A Monograph on Trades and Manufactures in Northern India,' 'A History of Asafud-Daulah, Nawab Wazir of Oudh,' 'Buddha: His Life, His Doctrine, and His Order,' and 'Memoirs of Delhi and Fyzabad.'

HOGG, ADAM GEORGE FORBES, Major-General, C.B., I.S.C., late Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Jan., 1854; served with the Persian expedition, 1857 (medal and clasp), in the Indian mutiny, the China war, 1860, the Abyssinian expedition, 1867-68, as deputy adjutant quartermaster-general (medal and brevet of major), and in the Afghan war, 1879-80, as director of transport with Bombay reserve and brigade on Kandahar line, and, subsequently, with the Kabul field force (medal and clasp, brevet of colonel); appointed political resident and collector of stamp revenue with charge of the vice-admiralty court, Aden, May, 1885; reverted to military duty, 1890.

HOGG, SIR FREDERIC RUSSELL, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India 12th Feb., 1857; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; postmaster-general, Punjab and Sind, July, 1863; officiating postmaster-general, Bombay, April, 1867; postmaster-general, Bengal, Nov., 1868; officiating deputy director-general of post office of India, March, 1870; officiating director-general, 1871-72, and again, 1873-76, and 1880-82; representative of the government of India at the postal congress, Paris, 1878; confirmed as director-general of post office of India, March, 1882; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; K.C.I.E., May, 1888; retired, April, 1890.

HOGG, STAPLETON C., Financial Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 25th July, 1861; junior clerk, accountant-general's department,
HOGG, Sir Stuart S., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1853; arrived in India, Jan., 1853; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner till 1859, and afterwards in Oudh as deputy commissioner; magistrate and collector, Burdwan, Bengal, 1861; chairman, justices of the peace, Calcutta, 1866; commissioner of police, Calcutta, and member of council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1874; retired 1878.

HOGG, Theodore William, Colonel, I.S.C.—First commission, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, 28th Jan., 1858; served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner from Aug., 1867, and acted as cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, 1874–80; also acted at various times as small cause court judge at the same place; small cause court judge, March, 1883; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1889.

HOJEL, Abraham Nickson, Brig.-Surgeon, M.K.Q.C.P., L.R.C.S.(Ir.), late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 27th July, 1859; arrived in India, 16th Feb., 1860, and served under the military department till Feb., 1865; professor of anatomy and physiology, and curator of the museum, Grant Medical College, and assistant surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, Feb., 1865; also acted as surgeon to coroner of Bombay, and professor of medicine at the Grant Medical College; from July, 1866, to Nov., 1871, served in the Persian Gulf as civil surgeon, Bushire, and assistant to the resident; served subsequently under the military department, and as acting ophthalmic surgeon, presidency surgeon and marine surgeon, Bombay; appointed professor of physiology, Grant Medical College, and second physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, Sept., 1876; also acted as 1st physician of the hospital and principal of the college, March–April, 1878, as surgeon of the Gokuldas Tejpal Native General Hospital, Oct., 1883, to May, 1884; brigade surgeon, and confirmed as physician of the European General Hospital, April, 1887; retired, April, 1891.

HOLDERNESS, Thomas William, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 17th Feb., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, March, 1877; junior secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1878, and officiated as secretary in 1879 and 1881; under secretary to government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Sept., 1881, to 1885; joint magistrate, N.W. Provinces, April, 1885; under secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1886; officiated as secretary to government in the financial department in 1887, 1888, and 1890; director of land records and agriculture, Nov., 1888; appointed secretary to government, financial department, March, 1892, at the same time acting as secretary in the judicial department.

HOLDICH, Thomas Hungerford, Lieut.-Colonel, R.E., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, royal engineers, Dec., 1862; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1865; served on special survey duty in the Bhutan campaign, 1865 (frontier medal and clasp); joined the topographical survey as assistant superintendent, July, 1866; on special survey duty with the Abyssinian expedition, 1867–68 (medal); served subsequently in the Gwalior and Central India topographical survey, and was appointed to the charge of the Vizagapatam agency and Central Provinces survey, Dec., 1873; joined the Afghanistan field force in 1879, and was in charge of survey operations in Northern Afghanistan during second period of the campaign, and was assistant field engineer during defence of Sherpur (medal and clasp); in charge of Kohat topographical survey, Feb., 1881; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1883; in charge of Biluchistan topographical survey, Oct., 1883; attached to the Afghan boundary commission, Sept., 1884; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, March, 1889; 1st grade, July, 1892; on special duty as survey officer with the Zob field force in 1890; author of contributions to the records of the Royal Geographical Society, on the subject of the geography of Afghanistan and the Indian frontier; also to the journal of the Royal United Service Institute, on military instruction in topography.

HOLIDAY, Frederick C., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 17th June, 1861; junior examiner, June, 1863; senior examiner, Dec., 1868.

HOLLOWAY, William, C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1843; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate till 1857, when he was appointed subordinate judge of Calicut; civil and sessions judge, Tellicherry, 1861; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, 1862; retired in 1877.

Holme, Henry Edward, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 27th Sept., 1890, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner.

Holmes, William, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Windermere College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating superintendent of Dehra Dun; appointed to take charge of H.H. Amir Yakub Khan, March, 1880; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, April, 1881; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, March, 1883; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, Dec., 1883; joint magistrate, 1st grade, June, 1884; deputy commissioner, and grade, Aug., 1887; magistrate and collector, Dec., 1888.

Holmes, William Cuthbert, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1877, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; from June, 1881, to Aug., 1882, served in Bombay as officiating assistant accountant-general; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Coimbatore, Dec., 1884; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1890; acting district and sessions judge, June, 1891.
HOLMS, JOHN MITCHELL, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1883, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, April, 1889; junior secretary to board of revenue, May, 1889, and from Feb., 1891; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oudh, March, 1892.

HOLMWOOD, HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Uppingham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1879; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Feb., 1890; officiating inspector general of registration, March, 1890; confirmed, Nov., 1890.

HOLROYD, WILLIAM RICE MORLAND, Colonel, I.S.C., late Educational Department, Punjab.—First commission as ensign, Dec., 1853; served from 11th Aug., 1858, in the Punjab educational department as inspector of schools, and was appointed director of public instruction, Punjab, Feb., 1868; 1st grade, education department, April, 1870; under secretary to government of Punjab, educational department, Oct., 1884; reverted to military duty, Oct., 1890.

HOLT, JAMES RICHARD, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Beecive College, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1880, and served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; officiating deputy superintendent, family domains of Maharaja of Benares, Oct., 1884; officiating under secretary to government, Nov., 1884, to Feb., 1885; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Nov., 1888; officiated in educational department, 4th grade, as professor in Muir Central College, March, 1889; retired, Aug., 1892.

HOME, ALEXANDER LEFEVRE, Bengal Forest Department.—From 1st March, 1864, served in the forest department in the Punjab, Central Provinces, and Bengal, and was appointed deputy conservator, 1st grade, and assistant comptroller-general of forests, Sept., 1882, and conservator of forests, 3rd grade, Bengal, April, 1883; 2nd grade, June, 1886; 1st grade, April, 1892.

HOME, FREDERICK JERVIS, Colonel, C.S.I., R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, 11th June, 1858; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1860; served in the public works department, N.W. Provinces, irrigation branch, from Feb., 1861, as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and was employed on the Ganges, Eastern Jamuna, and Agra canals, and other works; superintending engineer, Jan., 1883; officiating chief engineer, irrigation branch, and joint secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, 1885; superintending engineer, 2nd class, March, 1886; on special duty in the Bhurtpur state, Oct., 1886; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary, Punjab, Nov., 1886; superintending engineer, class I., Nov., 1887; 3rd chief engineer and joint secretary to government of the Punjab, Dec., 1889; officiating secretary, Sept., 1890; inspector-general of irrigation and deputy-secretary to the government of India, public works department, Nov., 1890; C.S.I., May, 1892.

HOME, ROBERT, Colonel, C.I.E., R.E., late Public Works Department, Punjab.—First commission, Bengal engineers, 1853; assistant engineer, irrigation department, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1856; transferred to Punjab, Nov., 1858; executive engineer, July, 1861; superintendent of works, Sutlej canal, Nov., 1867, and afterwards on the Sirhind canal, Jan., 1869; superintending engineer, Sirhind canal circle, Dec., 1869; officiating chief engineer for irrigation, and joint secretary to government of Punjab, Dec., 1876, to Jan., 1879; chief engineer and joint secretary for irrigation, Punjab, 1882; officiating inspector-general of irrigation, and deputy secretary to government of India, public works department, in 1884 and 1885; confirmed in this appointment, Nov., 1886; chief engineer, 2nd class, March, 1886; retired, Dec., 1889.

HOOKER, W. H., Store Department, India Office.—Supervisor, 2nd grade, India store depot, Aug., 1877; 1st grade, July, 1888.

HOOPER, JOHN, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1871, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; settlement officer, Basti, Nov., 1884; 1st grade, April, 1889; magistrate and collector, April, 1890; secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1890.

HOOPER, WILLIAM ROE, Brigade Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, Feb., 1859; arrived in India, Aug., 1859, and served in Bengal, holding various military medical charges; from July, 1861, served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon, and was appointed superintendent of central prison, Benares, Dec., 1864; rank of surgeon, Feb., 1871; civil surgeon of Benares, Sept., 1874; Lucknow, May, 1890; civil surgeon and jail superintendent, Benares, Nov., 1890; Lucknow, Aug., 1891.

HOPE, CHARLES WILLIAM WEBLEY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Mannamead School, Plymouth, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1885, and served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, Aug., 1890; assistant commissioner, Oudh, June, 1891; has acted as city magistrate, Lucknow, and as under-secretary to government.

HOPE, HUGH RICHARD, Brigadier-General, Madras Secretariat.—Joined the service, 4th Nov., 1860; arrived, 10th Dec., 1860, and was attached to 1st King's Dragoon Guards; aide-de-camp to Sir W. Denison, Governor of Madras, Oct., 1863, to Nov., 1864; adjutant, 1st Madras Light Cavalry, Nov., 1865; brigade-major, Aug., 1876; deputy assistant adjutant general, June, 1877; assistant adjutant general, Jan., 1882; commandant, 1st Madras Lancers, Sept., 1886; deputy adjutant general, March, 1888; secretary to government, military department, Oct., 1891.

HOPE, JAMES, B.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive ex-
amination of 1861; assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1863; served in Bombay from Oct., 1864, to July, 1867, and subsequently in Madras, and was appointed principal assistant collector, Ganjam, Sept., 1870; acted as collector and magistrate and political agent in the districts of Ganjam, Kurnool, and Godaveri, 1870-77; from Jan., 1877, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge of Chingleput, and from Dec., 1882, in South Arcot; retired, 1888.

HOPE, Sir Theodore Cracraft, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., Barrister-at-Law, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 5th June, 1853, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and educational inspector; private secretary to governor of Bombay, May, 1860; president of committee on finances of educational department, March, 1861; joint commissioner with the secretary in the public works department to receive North Kanara from the Madras government, Feb., 1862; deputy commissioner of customs, salt, and opium, Oct., 1862; collector and magistrate, Kaira, Jan., 1867; collector and magistrate and agent to governor, Surat, March, 1867; acting municipal commissioner, Bombay, Nov., 1871; acting commissioner of customs and opium, Nov., 1874; member of tariff committee at Calcutta, Dec., 1874; from July, 1875, served as additional member of the governor-general's council for making laws and regulations, also acting as secretary to the government of India in department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, and was appointed additional secretary for famine, Dec., 1876; reappointed as additional member of governor-general's council in 1877 and 1878; commissioner, Northern division, and agent to governor, Surat, Jan., 1878; on special political duty in England, Oct.-Nov., 1878; provisional member of council of governor of Bombay, Oct., 1880; commissioner, 1st grade, July, 1881; from April, 1881, acted as secretary to government of India, finance and commerce department, and was confirmed in this appointment, Aug., 1881; ordinary member of governor-general's council in charge of public works department, July, 1882; retired, Jan., 1883.

HOPKINS, E. S., Financial Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, registry department, 14th Nov., 1883; transferred to financial department, Sept., 1891.

HOPKINS, Henry Mayne Reid, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Dulwich College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1887, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

HOPKINS, John Arthur, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 14th Oct., 1861, and served as assistant magistrate and collector; also officiating district superintendent of police, March, 1872, inspector of schools, 1872-76, and officiating inspector-general of registration, July, 1875, to Feb., 1876; magistrate and collector, March, 1878; officiating commissioner, Chota Nagpore division, June, 1888; Orissa division, Feb., 1889; Patna, Oct., 1890, and June, 1892; acting opium agent, Bihar, June, 1892.

HOPKINSON, William, Colonel, Bengal Infantry.—First commission, 1859; from 28th Nov., 1867, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, as assistant commissioner, and sub-registrar of assurances; cantonment magistrate, Dinapore, March, 1874, and subsequently of Barrackpore, and small cause court judge, Nov., 1875; deputy-commissioner, 3rd grade, April, 1886; cantonment magistrate, Dinapore, April, 1887; Barrackpore, May, 1891; retired, Jan., 1892.

HORDERN, Peter, B.A., late Educational Department, Burma.—Appointed to the education department, 19th Nov., 1861; arrived in India, March, 1862; assistant professor of English literature, Presidency College, Calcutta, March, 1862; director of public instruction, British Burma, Nov., 1867; fellow of Calcutta University, April, 1876; retired, 1889; author of a 'Handbook of Rules and Practice of the Education Department, Burma.'

HORNE, William Ogilvie, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1882, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting deputy registrar, high court, Sept., 1886, to July, 1887; head assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1890; officiating secretary to commissioner of salt &c. revenue, in 1891, and from July, 1892.

HORSFALL, Jeremiah Garnett, C.I.E., B.L., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Giggleswick Grammar School, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed district and sessions judge, South Malabar, April, 1878, and collector and magistrate, Kistna, Jan., 1879, and afterwards in Vizagapatam and Ganjam; retired, April, 1890; C.I.E., May, 1890.

HORSFALL, Thomas Mendelssohn, B.L., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Wilhelms Gymnasium, Berlin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1880, and again, Sept., 1881; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, Madura, Dec., 1884, also forest settlement officer, Nov., 1885; acted as collector and magistrate; member of the board of examiners, May, 1888; registrar of high court (appellate side), Sept., 1888; principal assistant to the collector, &c., Ganjam, and acting district and sessions judge, Dec., 1890; collector and magistrate, Dec., 1891; district and sessions judge, Jan., 1892.

HORSFORD, Norman Macleod Thomas, Colonel, I.S.C., Port Blair Administration.—Arrived in India as ensign, Bengal Infantry, 29th Dec., 1857; served at the siege and capture of Lucknow, March, 1858, at the action of Nawabganj, June, 1858, and at the capture of Fort Oomerin, in Oudh, Dec. 1858 (medal and clasp); from Aug., 1861, to Dec., 1867, served in the police department, N.W. Provinces, as assistant inspector-general, and dis-
trict superintendent; from Dec., 1867, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; junior secretary to chief commissioner, Aug., 1869, to Jan., 1874, and acted for various periods as personal assistant to chief commissioner; officiating director of public instruction, Oct., 1873, to Jan., 1874; superintendent of encumbered estates, Rae Bareli, 1874-76; officiating superintendent of excise and stamps, and inspector-general of registration, April, 1876; cantonment magistrate, Lucknow, March, 1878; city magistrate and Wasika officer, Lucknow, April, 1883; officiating assistant director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Aug.-Nov., 1884; district judge, 3rd grade, April, 1886; deputy commissioner, March, 1887; chief commissioner, Andaman and Nicobars, and superintendent of Port Blair, April, 1892.

HORSLEY, WILLIAM HENRY, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's School, Canterbury, and Corpus Christi College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870; served as assistant collector and magistrate, and was in charge of the forests in Khandeish, Oct., 1872, to Feb., 1874; employed from March to Oct., 1874, on famine relief operations in Dinagepore, in Bengal, and subsequently on forest demarcation work in Khandeish; on famine duty, Kaladgi, Aug., 1877; forest settlement officer, Nov., 1878; second assistant collector and acting junior collector and magistrate, Sept., 1883; from June, 1884, acted as assistant judge and sessions judge, and from May, 1886, as 2nd grade judge; joint judge and sessions judge, May, 1887; 3rd grade judge and sessions judge, June, 1891.

HORSPPOOL, W. P., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Educated at the Newark Collegiate School; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 19th Aug., 1878.

HÖRST, HENRY, late Survey Department, Government of India.—Librarian and accountant, Thomason College, Roorkee, Jan., 1853; sub-assistant, great trigonometrical survey, Sept., 1854; in charge of picket which repulsed night attack on Murree Sanitarium, Sept., 1857 (mutiny medal); transferred to topographical survey, senior department, April, 1868; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Oct., 1869; served in various parts of India, and was appointed deputy superintendent, Burma topographical survey, Sept., 1882; 3rd grade, deputy superintendent, Nov., 1884; retired, 1889.

HOSE, JOHN WALTER, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Dulwich and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1886; and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, May, 1891; acting under-secretary to government, Dec., 1891.

HOSKING, EDWARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1869, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan, and registrar of the high court; judge and sessions judge, Khan-deish, Jan., 1884; 2nd grade judge, Sept., 1885; district judge, Thana, March, 1888; 1st grade judge and sessions judge, Karachi, June, 1891; acted as judicial commissioner and judge of the sadar court in Sind, in 1890-91, and from May, 1892; judicial commissioner, Lower Burma, Nov., 1892.

HOSKINS, WILLIAM HENRY, Colonel, I.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras infantry, July, 1858; arrived in India, 7th Sept., 1858; served in Madras police department from May, 1863, as assistant superintendent and superintendent.

HOUGH, ALFRED LACEY, Burma Commission.—Joined the service, 25th Oct., 1870, as sub-assistant conservator of forests; appointed to the commission as extra assistant commissioner, Oct., 1874; assistant commissioner, Feb., 1885; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1891.

HOUGHTON, BERNARD, Madras C.S. (Burma).—Educated at All Saints, Bloxham, Wellingborough Grammar School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 23rd Jan., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1885; transferred for employment in Burma, Aug., 1886; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Dec., 1888; deputy commissioner, March, 1891; author of an essay on the language of the Southern Chins.

HOUSE, HENRY FREDERICK, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Bristol Grammar School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Feb., 1890; assistant superintendent, Dehra Dun, April, 1891; officiating magistrate and collector, April, 1892.

HOUSLEY, ARTHUR W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, India office, 19th Feb., 1872; junior clerk, June, 1882.

HOUSTON, JOHN, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., late Madras Medical Department.—Appointed, 4th Aug., 1855; arrived in India, 3rd March, 1856, and served in Mysore in various military charges, and also as civil surgeon, chemical examiner, and superintendent of jail; surgeon-major, Aug., 1867; from July, 1871, served as surgeon to the Mysore commission; brigade surgeon, June, 1881; officiating residency surgeon, May, 1883; surgeon to the Mysore government; retired, March, 1886.

HOWARD, EDWARD STAFFORD.—Educated at Harrow, and Trinity College, Cambridge; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1875; represented East Cumberland in the House of Commons from April, 1876, till the general election of 1885, when he was returned for the Thornbury division of Gloucestershire, but lost his seat in the succeeding election of 1886; under secretary of state for India, April-Aug., 1886.

HOWARD, WILLIAM STUART, M.I.C.E., Bombay Public Works Department.—Joined the service as probationer, 10th June, 1859; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1859; assistant engineer, 1st class, April, 1864; executive engineer, Dec., 1865; acted as principal, engineering college, Poona, 1867; acting secretary to the government of Bombay, public
works department, Sept., 1887; chief engineer, Aug., 1888; 1st class, Nov., 1891; secretary to government of Bombay, public works department, June, 1892.

HOWELL, ARTHUR PEARSE, M.A., late Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1858; from May, 1859, to April, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, assistant secretary, and acting under secretary to the government; from April, 1864, to March, 1873, served in the secretariat of the government of India, first as under secretary, financial department, and then as under secretary and acting secretary, home department; also as acting deputy secretary, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, and was placed on special duty March, 1869; commissioner, Jubbulpore division, Central Provinces, April, 1877; secretary, famine commission, March, 1878; on special duty, June, 1878; commissioner, Nerbudda division, Sept., 1878; acting judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Dec., 1879, to Feb., 1880, and again in 1885; commissioner, Hyderabad assigned districts, June to Dec., 1882; member of education commission under the government of India, Dec., 1882, to Sept., 1883; commissioner, Nerbudda division, Sept., 1883; officiating resident, 1st class, Hyderabad, March, 1888; retired, Aug., 1889; author of notes (2) on education in India in 1866-67 and 1870-71, the former of which was presented to parliament; of a note on jails and jail discipline in India, and of a paper on educational legislation.

HOWELL, MORTIMER SLOPER, LL.D., C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Christ's Hospital, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from Jan., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; officiating inspector of public instruction, April, 1867; assistant superintendent and small cause court judge, Dehra Dun, March, 1868; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Feb., 1871; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Nov., 1879; from March, 1880, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge in various districts; acted as additional judicial commissioner in Oudh in 1891, and was confirmed in that post, Dec., 1891; author of a grammar of the classical Arabic language.

HUDLESTON, WILLIAM, C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1845; assistant collector and magistrate, Canara, July, 1847; head assistant, Chingleput, May, 1854; head assistant and acting deputy registrar, court of Sudder Adawlut, Sept., 1854; deputy secretary to government in the departments under the chief secretary, Feb., 1855; secretary to board of examiners, March, 1855; acting deputy secretary in the revenue and public works department, Dec., 1857; acting deputy collector of sea customs, Madras, May, 1858; sub-secretary, board of revenue, July, 1858; secretary, board of revenue, April, 1861; secretary to government, revenue department, Jan., 1867; chief secretary to government, Nov., 1872; member of council, June, 1877; acted as governor of Madras, May to Nov., 1881; retired, June, 1882.

HUDSON, CHARLES WILLIAM MAITLAND, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Doveton Protestant College, Madras, Madras University, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1887; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1888.

HUDSON, WILLIAM HEBARD, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1861; from Jan., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; from Dec., 1873, to Jan., 1875, served under the government of Bengal on famine duty in Behar; from May, 1880, served in the judicial department, N.W. Provinces, as civil and sessions judge; retired, Jan., 1890.

HUGHES, ARTHUR JOHN, C.I.E., M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service 11th July, 1862, and arrived in India 7th Dec., 1862; executive engineer, Dec., 1869; assistant secretary to government of Bengal, irrigation branch, May, 1872; on famine works, Salem district, Sept., 1877; served under the foreign department in Kashmir, Dec., 1884, to Feb., 1885; superintending engineer, Nov., 1888.

HUGHES, DAVID ERSKINE, Brigade Surgeon-Lieut.-Col., M.D., F.R.C.S., late Bombay Medical Service.—Joined the service, March, 1866; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1866; served under the military department, and also acted as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Satara, 1880-81, as surgeon of the European general hospital, Bombay, 1881, and as civil surgeon at Surat, 1881-82; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Belgaum, from May, 1882; brigade surgeon, Oct., 1888; civil surgeon, Poona, Sept., 1890; has acted as deputy sanitary commissioner, and as first physician of the Jamsetji Jijibhoi hospital; reverted to military department, Sept., 1892.

HUGHES, EDWARD WILLIAM MACKENZIE, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the department, April, 1871, as assistant engineer, Punjab, irrigation, and was employed on the Sirhind canal; locomotive superintendent, Dhond-Manmad state railway, May, 1879; locomotive superintendent, Indus valley railway, Feb., 1881; class I, state railway locomotive establishment, Jan., 1886; deputy locomotive superintendent, North-Western railway, Jan., 1886; on special duty in Mexico in 1887-88; locomotive superintendent, East Coast railway, Jan., 1892.

HUGHES, GEORGE, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Liverpool Institute, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 23rd Oct. 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating district judge; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, Nov., 1887; district judge, Aug., 1890; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Dec., 1890; retired, Dec., 1891.

HUGHES, THEODORE WILLIAM HUGHES, A.R.S.M., F.G.S., Geological Survey of India.—
Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined, 11th Nov., 1862; was employed chiefly in the Central Provinces, Central India, and Bengal, in connection with coal and iron deposits; 1st grade officer, April, 1883; superintended Rewah coal explorations from March, 1883; designation changed to deputy superintendent of the geological survey of India; superintendent, April, 1887; author of contributions to the survey publications.

HUGHES, WALTER CHARLETON, M.I.C.E.—Joined the service, 23rd July, 1868; arrived, 3rd Oct., 1868; served in various grades of the public works department, Bombay; assistant secretary to government in that department, April, 1882; under secretary, March, 1884; secretary, Nov., 1888; chairman, Bombay port trust, June, 1892.

HUGHES, WILLIAM Gwynne, Colonel, I.S.C., late Burma Commission.—First commission as ensign, June, 1858; arrived in India, 11th Sept., 1858; was employed on military duty and in the police department, Burma, till June, 1864; transferred to the Burma commission, June, 1864, and served as assistant commissioner in the Amherst district, cantonment magistrate of Rangoon, town magistrate of Akyab, superintendent of the Hill Tracts, Arakan (Nov., 1871), and deputy commissioner (1st grade, July, 1886); author of 'The Hill Tracts of Arakan'; retired, June, 1889.

HUGHESDON, JOSEPH CHARLES, Barrister-at-Law, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Sutton Valence Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, small cause court judge, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; on famine duty, June, 1877; appointed district and sessions judge, Tinnevelly, March, 1880; retired, Aug., 1888.

HULLAH, ARTHUR, Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed assistant superintendent, 20th Feb., 1869, and employed on various lines; superintendent, Aug., 1885; in charge, Rajputana division, April, 1882.

HUME, ALLAN OCTAVIAN, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1849; arrived in India, 7th March, 1849; served in N.W.
