Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Etawah, March, 1858; officiating civil and sessions judge, Bareilly, May, 1867; commissioner of customs, N.W. Provinces, Punjab, and Central Provinces, July, 1867; officiating secretary to government of India, home department, 1870-71; secretary to government of India in department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, June, 1871; member of board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1879; retired, 1882.

HUME, WILLIAM WHEELER, Colonel, I.S.C., late Bengal Police.—1st commission, 5th Aug., 1854; served in the Indian mutiny with the Meerut volunteer cavalry; afterwards as a volunteer with the artillery during siege and capture of Delhi (medal and clasp); district superintendent of police, Aug., 1863; 1st grade, April, 1888; reverted to military duty, 1889.

HUMFREY, JOHN, Lieut.-Col., Bombay Police Department.—Joined the service, 2nd June, 1865, and arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1865; lieutenant in staff corps, Nov., 1868; served in the Abyssinian expedition in charge of commissariat camel train (medal), Nov., 1868; assistant superintendent of police, Aug., 1873; on special duty in political department for short periods in 1873, 1874, 1876, 1877, 1883; superintendent of police, Aug., 1875; inspector-general of police, Bombay, February, 1890; on special duty to England with Thaker Sahib of Morvi's eldest son, March, 1890; resumed his post, Nov., 1890.

HUMPHRYS, I. H., Accounts Department, India Office.—Educated at the Royal School, Raphoe, and Trinity College, Dublin (exhibitor and prizeman); clerk, 2nd class, 5th July, 1872; junior clerk, Feb., 1876.

HUNT, SAMUEL, late Funds Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, East India House, examiner's office, 18th June, 1851; revenue department, India office, 1858; senior clerk, Aug., 1860; financial department, 1867; funds department, 1882; retired, Sept., 1892.

HUNT, SAMUEL BRADSHAW, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Col., Madras Medical Service.—Assistant surgeon, 31st March, 1865; arrived, 10th Dec., 1865, and served under the military department, and also as civil surgeon at Coimbatore and at Vizagapatam with charge of the jail and lunatic asylum; from May, 1875, served as surgeon in the 4th, and subsequently in the 3rd district, Madras.

HUNTER, FREDERICK MERCER, Lieutenant-Colonel, I.S.C., C.S.I., C.B., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India as ensign, Bombay infantry, June, 1861; was employed on military duty up to Aug., 1871, from which date he served as assistant political resident at Aden; also acted on various occasions as political resident, as cantonment magistrate, and as Arabic interpreter; first assistant at Aden, Sept., 1880; also political agent for the Somali coast, and collector of abkari and deputy collector of salt revenue; acting political agent at Aden, 1887, and at Cutch, July, 1888; confirmed in latter appointment, Feb., 1889.

HUNTER, GEORGE YEATES, Brigade-Surgeon, M.R.C.S. (Lon.), L.S.A., late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 23rd July, 1858; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1858, and served in the military department, and as civil surgeon in various stations; acting second surgeon, Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, acting professor of anatomy, Grant Medical College, and curator of the museum, Bombay, April-Oct., 1872; acting superintendent of lunatic asylum, Colaba, Nov.-Dec., 1872; civil surgeon, Karachi, Feb., 1882; presidency surgeon, Bombay, in medical charge of jail, house of correction, Byculla Schools and Elphinstone College, May, 1884; brigade surgeon, Feb., 1885; retired, Oct., 1888.

HUNTER, JOHN MUIR, Lieutenant-Colonel, I.S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, R.A., April, 1864; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1865; boundary settlement officer, Baroda and Mahi Kantha states, Oct., 1869; from June, 1872, served as assistant political agent in Mahi Kantha, Kolhapur, and Kathiawar; assistant to the political agent and magistrate of Kathiawar state railway, Jan., 1880; from Feb., 1883, served as superintendent...
of surveys under the Rajasthnik court, Kathiawar, and was employed on special duties in settling claims in dispute between native states, from Dec., 1884; acting president, Rajasthnik court, May, 1887, and again in 1889; confirmed, May, 1891; assistant agent, Baroda, Oct., 1891; first assistant political agent, Mahi Kantha, Jan., 1892.

HUNTER, Sir William Guyer, Surgeon-General, M.D., K.C.M.G., F.R.C.P., F.R.C.S., M.P.—Educated at King's College, London, Aberdeen University, and at various hospitals; joined the Bombay medical service, 1850; served in the Burmese war and Indian Mutiny; principal of the Grant Medical College, Bombay, 1868; surgeon-major, Feb., 1870; surgeon-general, Bombay, Feb., 1877; vice-chancellor of the university of Bombay, 1879; retired, March, 1880; consulting physician to Charing Cross Hospital, 1883; served on the cholera commission in Egypt, 1883; British delegate to the international sanitary conference at Rome, June, 1885; hon. commandant of the volunteer medical staff corps, Sept., 1885; was returned to the House of Commons for Hackney (central division) in 1885, and again in 1886.

HUNTER, Sir William Wilson, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., M.A. (Oxford), and LL.D. (Cambridge), late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Universities of Glasgow, Paris, and Bonn; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 10th Nov., 1862; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1863; superintendent of labour transport, Kooshtea, July, 1865; on deputation for compiling a history of Beerbhoom, March, 1866; officiating inspector of schools, May, 1866; officiating superintendent of stamps and stationery, Dec., 1868; compiler of 'Bengal Gazetteer,' and on deputation in home department, government of India, July, 1869; compiler of 'Gazetteer of India,' Jan., 1871; officiating under-secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1871; director-general of statistics, government of India, Sept., 1871; on special duty to England for purpose of compiling statistical account of Bengal, and 'Imperial Gazetteer,' March, 1875, and March, 1876; on special duty in England, March, 1877, to Nov., 1881; director-general of gazetteers, Oct., 1877; C.I.E., 1878; director-general of gazetteers and statistics, June, 1878; director-general of statistics, Dec., 1881; additional member, governor-general's council, Dec., 1881, and again Dec., 1883, and Dec., 1885; president of the education commission, Feb., 1882 to Nov., 1883; deputed to England to give evidence before the committee of the House of Commons on Indian railways, May, 1884; C.S.I., 1884; member of the finance committee, Feb., 1886; K.C.S.I., Feb., 1887; retired, Sept., 1887; author of 'The Annals of Rural Bengal,' 1868; 'A Dictionary of the Non-Aryan Languages of India and High Asia,' 1868; pamphlets on Indian legislation and finance, 1869; memorandum on the older records of the board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, 1870; 'The Indian Mussulmans,' 1871; 'The Province of Orissa,' 1872; 'Famine Aspects of Bengal Districts,' 1874; a 'Collected Edition of Essays on the External Policy of India,' by the late J. W. S. Wyllie, 1875; 'A Life of Lord Mayo,' 2 vols., 1875; 'A Statistical Account of Bengal,' 20 vols., 1875-77; a summary of certain of the older M.S. Records in the India Office, 1878; a Statistical Account of Assam, 1879; 'The Imperial Gazetteer of India,' 9 vols., 1881, 2nd edition, 14 vols., 1887; 'The Indian Empire,' 1881; 'England's Work in India,' 1881; 'A Brief History of the Indian People,' &c.

HURRY, Arnold Eardley, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at City of London School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1882, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; transferred to Burma, 1886; deputy commissioner, May, 1890; re-transferred as assistant commissioner and officiating district judge, Dec., 1890.

HUTCHESON, George, M.D., C.M., Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Indian Medical Service.—Joined the service as assistant surgeon, 1st Oct., 1866; surgeon, July, 1873; surgeon-major, Oct., 1880; served on general and military duty, and from Feb., 1870, to Sept., 1871, on special duty as chemical analyst; on special duty, cholera enquiry, Sept., 1872, to Dec., 1873; officiated as statistical officer to the government of India, in the sanitary and medical department; sanitary commissioner and superintendent-general of vaccination, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1886; author of 'Cholera, its causes, and mode of dissemination,' and 'Cholera as a preventible disease.'

HUTCHINGS, F. S., Auditor's Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 23rd June, 1879.

HUTCHINS, Sir Philip Perceval, K.C.S.I., B.L., Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived, 27th Feb., 1858; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acted as deputy secretary to government in the revenue department in 1862 and 1863, and in the departments under the chief secretary in 1862, as secretary to board of examiners in 1863, and as judge of the court of small causes, Chittoor, Sept. 1863; private secretary to governor of Madras, Nov., 1863; registrar, high court, March, 1865; from Feb., 1869, acted as civil and sessions judge in various places, and was appointed district and sessions judge, Madura, April, 1873; member of rent law committee, Sept., 1882; acting secretary, revenue department, Dec., 1882; on special duty in connection with reorganization of judicial establishments, March, 1883; board of examiners, May, 1883; judge of the high court, Madras, Nov., 1883; fellow of the Madras University, March, 1884; member of governor's council, Dec., 1886; C.S.I., Jan., 1888; member of the council of the governor-general, Nov., 1888; K.C.S.I., May, 1891.

HUTCHINSON, Frederick Thomas, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 25th March, 1871, as assistant controller; deputy controller, May, 1874; examiner, Sept., 1881; examiner, public works accounts, Bombay, May, 1890.

HUTCHINSON, Henry Stephen, Colonel, I.S.C., Survey of India Department.—1st commission, lieutenant, Bengal Artillery, 9th Dec., 1859; served with the artillery until Aug., 1867, when he was admitted to the staff corps, and appointed to the survey department, as assistant superintendent; received charge of
Bassein district cadastral survey, May, 1883; deputy superintendent, Aug., 1884; 3rd grade, April, 1886; 2nd grade, Oct., 1891.

HUTCHINSON, JAMES BIRD, Lieut.-Col., I.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 26th May, 1864; from March, 1868, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating settlement officer; district judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1884; services placed at the disposal of the government of India, Aug. to Oct., 1887; officiated as commissioner and superintendent, Nov., 1891, and June, 1892; has published a 'Guide to Dalhousie,' and a general index of regulations and acts in force in the Punjab.

HUTTON, EDWARD, Postal Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as superintendent of mails, Jubbulpore, 10th Feb., 1858; superintendent travelling post office, Nov., 1877; inspector, field force, Peshawur column, Feb., 1879; presidency postmaster at Calcutta, April, 1881; acted as postmaster-general, Lahore, in 1890, at Bombay in 1891, and at Calcutta from April, 1892.

HYDE, HENRY, Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Madras Medical Department.—Arrived, 27th June, 1867; surgeon, Oct., 1871; Zillah surgeon and jail superintendent, April, 1872; civil surgeon, Nov., 1884.

HYNES, GEORGE JOHN, Post Office Department, Government of India.—Entered the post office department, 4th May, 1868; assistant director-general of the post office of India, Oct., 1880; deputy postmaster-general, Burma, June, 1887; postmaster-general, Punjab, Jan., 1891; deputy director-general of post office of India, July, 1891.

IBBETSON, DENZIL CHARLES JELF, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Collegiate School, Adelaide (South Australia), and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1870, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; deputy superintendent, census, Punjab, Aug., 1881; compiler, 'Punjab Gazetteer,' March, 1883; officiating director of public instruction, March, 1884; deputy commissioner, April, 1885; officiating superintendent, Kapurthala state, Nov., 1885; on special duty in connection with census conference, Dec. 1889, and jail conference, Jan., 1890; officiated as 2nd financial commissioner in the Punjab in 1890; in charge of Gujrunwala settlement, May, 1891; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Jullundur, Nov., 1891; member of Deccan agriculturists commission, Dec., 1891; has published 'Census Report of the Punjab,' 'Report on the Settlement of the Karnal District,' 'Outlines of Punjab Ethnography,' 'Gazetteer of the Districts of the Punjab.'

ILBERT, COURTENAY PEREGRINE, C.S.I., C.I.E.—Educated at Marlborough, and Oxford; scholar, and afterwards fellow of Balliol College; first class (classics), moderations, 1862, and in the final schools, 1864; Hertford scholar, 1861; Ireland scholar, 1864; Craven scholar, 1864; Eldon Law scholar, 1867; called to the bar at Lincoln's Inn, 7th June, 1869; counsel to education department, 1878-82; took his seat as law member of the council of the governor-general of India, 1st May, 1882, and was president of the council, 3rd Feb. to 8th March, 1886; resigned, 13th Nov., 1886; vice-chancellor of Calcutta University, Feb., 1885 to Nov., 1886; assistant parliamentary counsel to the treasury, 1886.

IMPEY, WILLIAM HENRY LOCKINGTON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wellington College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, Naini Tal, Nov., 1886; acting under-secretary to government of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Dec., 1887; confirmed, May, 1888; settlement officer, 2nd grade, Oct., 1889; acting secretary to government, financial department, April, 1892.

INAM ALI, MAULVI, B.A., Punjab Commission.—Appointed assistant professor, Government College, Lahore, 31st Oct., 1887; appointed probationer under native civil service rules, 4th Feb., 1888; assistant commissioner, Dec., 1888.

INCH, G. F., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 9th Oct., 1879.

INGLIS, JOHN FORBES DAVID, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1840; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed junior under-secretary to the government of India, foreign department, in 1846; assistant to resident at Lahore, 1847; deputy commissioner in the Punjab, 1849; magistrate and collector of Bareilly, 1858; judge of Moradabad, 1862; commissioner of Rohilkundh, 1864; member of board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, 1867; additional member of governor-general's council, 1870, and was reappointed in 1873 and 1875; temporarily finance member of governor-general's council, April to Dec., 1874; officiating chief commissioner of Oudh, March-Nov., 1875, and again in July, 1876; retired, Feb., 1877.

INGLIS, THOMAS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Wellington College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1880; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, May, 1880; acting junior secretary to board of revenue, July, 1891.

INNES, JAMES JOHN McLEOD, Lieutenant-General, V.C., R.E., late Public Works Department, India.—First commission in Bengal engineers, 1848; served under the civil engineer, Punjab, from 1852; assistant engineer, Bari Doab canal, 1854; assistant to chief engineer, Oudh, Jan., 1857; during the mutiny served at the defence of Sultanpur, and the siege of Lucknow, the action of Sultanpur, and the siege of Lucknow (medal and two clasps, V.C.); executive engineer, Cawnpore, Dec., 1857; garrison engineer, Presidency, April, 1858; controller and examiner of accounts, Lahore, Feb., 1861; officiating accountant-general, public works department, 1865-66, and again 1867-68; on special duty on Bank of Bombay committee, 1868-69; superin-
tending engineer, Punjab, Oct., 1869; accountant-general and deputy secretary, public works department, June, 1870; chief engineer, 1st class, Sept., 1881, and deputy inspector-general, military works; inspector-general of military works, 1882; retired, 1886.

INNES, Lewis Charles, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse and Haileybury, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1844; served as assistant collector and magistrate in various districts till Jan., 1855, and afterwards in the judicial department, and was appointed sub-judge of Combaconum, Feb., 1856, and civil and sessions judge of Nundial, July, 1858; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, Feb., 1865, to Sept., 1883, and officiated on several occasions as chief justice; retired, 1883; fellow of the University of Madras, 1865 to 1883, and was on the syndicate, 1873-83; vice-chancellor of the university, 1874 to 1880.

INNES, William, Railway Department, Government of India.—Appointed class II, superior revenue establishment state railways, July, 1884; served on the Eastern Bengal and the Punjab Northern state railways, and was appointed traffic superintendent, Burma state railway, Nov., 1885; class I, grade 3, July, 1889.

IRELAND, William de Courcy, B.A., LL.D., late Burma Commission.—Joined the service as accountant in office of commissioner of Pegu, April, 1859; assistant superintendent of forests, Toungoo, April, 1860; collector of customs, Nov., 1860; from April, 1861, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, town magistrate, and deputy commissioner (1st grade, June, 1879); on special duty, Aug., 1878; acted as inspector-general of police in 1875, 1881-1883, and 1885, and as commissioner of Arakan, June-Sept., 1880; boundary officer, Akyab district, Sept., 1880; additional sessions judge, Tenasserim, Jan., 1886; commissioner, Irrawaddy division, July, 1886, and Arakan division, Jan., 1890; retired, Dec., 1890.

IRVINE, George Duncan, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from May, 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting collector of sea customs at Madras and protector of emigrants, and acting collector and magistrate; district and sessions judge, Kurnool, July, 1882, and afterwards in various other districts; retired, June, 1891.

IRVINE, Robert Hamilton Grant, late Bengal Police.—Joined the service as deputy magistrate and deputy collector, Aug., 1861; appointed assistant superintendent of police, April, 1863; district superintendent, July, 1869; 1st grade, July, 1889; retired, Sept., 1891.

IRVINE, William, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at St. Anne's School, Brixton, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from May, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, acting cantonment magistrate, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed on special duty under the board of revenue, Jan. to April, 1879; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Ghazipur, Dec., 1881; 1st grade, July, 1885; retired, 1888; author of 'Canal Rates versus Land Revenue,' 'The Rent Digest: or the Law Procedure relating to Landlord and Tenant, Bengal,' 'Bangash Nawabs of Farukhabad,' and settlement report of Ghazipur district.

IRVING, L. A., Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Army Medical Department.—Medical officer on the personal staff of the governor of Bombay (Rt. Hon. Lord Reay, LL.D., C.I.E.), 1885 to 1890.

IRWIN, Alfred Macdonald Bulteel, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1876, and served in the Punjab till June, 1877, and subsequently in British Burma as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1886.

IRWIN, George Robert, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Hyderabad Administration).—Educated at Uppingham, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1878, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and officiating city magistrate, Lucknow; assistant secretary to government of India, foreign department, Dec., 1886; officiating junior secretary, Nov., 1887, and May, 1888, and under secretary, foreign department, April, 1889, and again, May, 1890; first assistant secretary for Berar to resident, Hyderabad, March, 1892.

IRWIN, Henry, C.I.E., M.I.C.E., Madras Public Works Department.—Joined the service as assistant engineer, Central Provinces, 1st Feb., 1868; executive engineer, Sept., 1872; superintendent of works, Simla imperial circle, Oct., 1881; transferred to Madras public works department as superintending engineer, and appointed consulting architect to government, Sept., 1889.

IRWIN, Henry Crossly, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School, St. Edmund's Hall, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1871, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, Oct., 1886; deputy commissioner, July, 1889; magistrate and collector, Nov., 1889; author of 'The Garden of India, or Chapters on Oudh History and Affairs.'

ISAACSON, S. H. H., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Writer, India Office, 15th April, 1866; clerk, 2nd class, Sept., 1878.

ISMAY, Stanley, B.L., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1871; served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting inspector of schools, acting district superintendent of police, and acting deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty in the Kalahandi state, Jan., 1882; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, May, 1884; officiating inspector-general of police and jails, May to Nov., 1885, and again in April, 1890; judge, small cause court, Jubbulpore, Dec., 1889; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1890;
IZAT, ALEXANDER, M.I.C.E., late Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1863, as assistant engineer, Hyderabad; executive engineer, March, 1868; transferred to railway branch, 1870, as executive engineer, Nizam's state railway; Holkar state railway, Oct., 1874; transferred to Dhond and Manmad railway, Bombay, 1877; engineer-in-chief, Kathiawar state railways, 1879; engineer-in-chief, Bombay Eastern Deccan state railway, Aug., 1879; superintending engineer, 3rd class, April, 1880; officiating under secretary to government of India, railway branch, Jan., 1883; services lent to Bengal and N.W. railway company as agent and chief engineer, Feb., 1883; 1st superintending engineer, Feb., 1887; retired, 1889.

JACKSON, ARCHIBALD, Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 24th Dec., 1892.

JACKSON, ARTHUR MASON TIPPETTS, B.A., B.L., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Westminster School, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 17th December, 1888, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

JACKSON, CHARLES JULIAN, Brigade-Surgeon, M.D., late Bengal Medical Department.—Joined the service, 1855; served in Bengal from Sept., 1859, as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon at various stations; also officiated as sanitary commissioner, Bengal, Jan., 1872; civil surgeon, 24 Pergunnahs, with medical charge of Alipore and Russa jails, and medical inspector of emigrants, Feb., 1883; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail and lunatic asylum, Moorsabad, 1885; surgeon-major, Aug., 1867; brigade surgeon, Jan., 1881; retired, April, 1887.

JACKSON, EDWIN JAMES, Survey of India Department.—Joined the service, 26th Sept., 1864; assistant superintendent, Nov., 1868; deputy superintendent, Oct., 1885; 3rd grade, Oct., 1890.

JACKSON, FREEMAN HENRY, Lieut.-Colonel, I.S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay Infantry, 1861; arrived in India, 10th Jan., 1862; from Jan., 1867, acted in charge of office of assistant resident, Amreli, and was appointed to settle boundaries in Eastern Kathiawar, Jan., 1868; acting assistant-resident, Dwarka, and commandant of H.H. the Gaekwar's battalion, March, 1869; assistant resident, Baroda, in charge Okhamandal, July, 1874; on special duty, Baroda, Jan., 1875; treasury officer, Baroda Residency, Feb., 1875; acting cantonment magistrate, Baroda, April, 1875; extra assistant general superintendent, thuggee and dacoity department, June, 1875; from May, 1876, served as assistant agent to the governor-general, Baroda, and from Feb., 1879, as superintendent of the Gaekwar's contingent, Kathiawar, assistant in charge of Amreli Mahals, and superintendent for the improvement of the breed of horses in Kathiawar; officiated for various periods as resident and governor-general's agent, Baroda.

JACKSON, HUGH MILBOURNE, Captain, R.E., Survey of India Department.—First commission, 19th June, 1877; entered the department as assistant superintendent, June, 1883; deputy superintendent, 4th grade, April, 1889; 3rd grade, July, 1892; served in the Burma expedition, 1886, the first Southern Shan expedition, 1886-87, and with the Northern Karen column, 1888-89.

JACKSON, WILLIAM GRIERSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Manchester Grammar School, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Feb., 1877, to Jan., 1880, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, 4th grade; deputy superintendent of family domains of Maharaja of Benares, March, 1882; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Nov., 1887, and 1st grade, April, 1889; also officiated as magistrate and collector, district and sessions judge, and deputy commissioner; confirmed in the latter grade, Aug., 1891; author of Mirzapur volume of N.W. Provinces Gazetteer.

JACOB, EDWARD FOUNTAINE, Railway Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 1st Oct., 1876, as assistant engineer; district traffic superintendent, Feb., 1880; attached to public works secretariat, government of India, April, 1888; deputy traffic superintendent, North-Western railway, May, 1890.

JACOB, GEORGE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Highgate Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; in charge of forest settlement and demarcation officer's office, Khandeish, Oct., 1881, to Feb., 1882; from May, 1883, served as assistant judge and sessions judge, and also from Dec., 1884, to Oct., 1885, as assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; from March, 1886, served as senior assistant judge, and from Nov., 1886, as joint judge and sessions judge; acting registrar, high court, appellate side, Feb., 1888; 1st assistant judge, Nov., 1891.

JACOB, HERBERT BRUCE, Colonel, I.S.C., late Judicial Department, Bombay.—First commission, Dec., 1857; served from 26th June, 1869, in the educational department, Central Provinces, and was appointed inspector of schools, 3rd grade, April, 1871; acting inspector-general of education, 1882-84; cantonment magistrate, Karachi, 1889 to 1892.

JACOB, STEPHEN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Highgate School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, officiating registrar in the judicial commissioner's court, and officiating deputy commissioner, till Dec., 1878, when he was transferred to Bengal; on special duty, legislative department, government of India, April, 1879, and again in March, 1880; officiated as under secretary and as assistant secretary in department of finance and commerce, government of India, in 1880 and 1881; assistant comptroller-general, in class III. of the financial department, Nov., 1880; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, Nov., 1881, and in 1882; on special duty with the government of India in department of finance and commerce, Jan. and Dec., 1882; joint magistrate and deputy collector,
2nd grade, June, 1882; under secretary, government of India, finance and commerce department, July, 1882; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, July, 1883; deputy auditor-general, Dec., 1884; officiating accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oude, Feb., 1885; deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Nov., 1885; secretary to the finance committee, March, 1886; on special duty, financial department, Feb., 1888; accountant-general, class I, and commissioner of the department of state paper currency, Bombay, May, 1888; officiating comptroller and auditor-general and head-commissioner of paper currency, April, 1890; confirmed, Nov., 1891.

JACOB, SYDNEY LONG, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 13th January, 1869, and served in Bombay and Punjab as assistant engineer, and executive engineer; served through the Afghan War, 1878-79 (medal); superintending engineer, Oct., 1890.

JADU NATH ROY, Bengal Judicial Service.—Joined the service, 13th July, 1871, as officiating munshi; sub-judge, July, 1873; small cause court judge, June, 1883.

JAMES, ARTHUR HUTTON, Police Department, Bengal.—Joined the service, 16th Feb., 1863, as assistant superintendent of police, Assam; also assistant commissioner, Nov., 1866; promoted to district superintendent, Oct., 1873; transferred to Bengal, Dec., 1875; assistant inspector-general, railway police, Nov., 1884; district superintendent, 1st grade, Sept., 1891.

JAMES, HENRY EVAN MURCHISON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Cathedral School, Carlisle, and Durham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and as acting assistant commissioner, branch inspector-general of registration and educational inspector in Sind; from May, 1873, acted as under secretary to government in the revenue, financial, and general departments, and was confirmed in this appointment, Nov., 1875; also acted as postmaster-general, Bombay, from Nov., 1875; 2nd grade, postmaster-general, Bombay, Nov., 1877; postmaster-general, Bengal, March, 1882; acted as director-general of the post office in India, 1883-85; on special duty in England, Aug., 1884, to April, 1885; deputy director-general, Nov., 1885; senior collector and collector and magistrate, Ahmedabad, April, 1888; 2nd grade commissioner, June, 1890; 1st grade, Nov., 1890; acting commissioner in Sind, June, 1891.

JAMES, STEPHEN HARVEY, M.R.A.S., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Probos Grammar School, and Shrewsbury Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; junior secretary, board of revenue, May, 1875, and officiated as secretary, 1877; under secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, and officiating junior secretary, Aug., 1877; on special duty under the orders of the high court, Feb., 1881, and under the orders of the local government in 1882-83; registrar, high court, May, 1881; legal remembrancer, N.W. Provinces, May, 1884; officiating deputy secretary to the government of India, legislative department, March, 1885; officiating secretary to the government of India, legislative department, Dec., 1885; confirmed as secretary, Sept., 1887.

JAMESON, ARTHUR SAMUEL, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 1st Jan., 1886, and served in the locomotive department, North-Western railway; transferred to Eastern Bengal state railway, Aug., 1888; district locomotive superintendent, July, 1889; locomotive superintendent, Oct., 1890.

JAMESON, ROBERT, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon Lieutenant-Colonel, Sanitary Department, N.W. Provinces.—Joined the Bengal medical service as assistant surgeon, Oct., 1865; arrived in India, 11th April, 1866, and was employed on civil and military duty; in 1868 was in medical charge at Calcutta of troops and coolies, en route to Abyssinia; served in Abyssinia with 12th Bengal cavalry; served in Bombay and Punjab, 1868 and 1869, and in the N.W. Provinces from 1870 on civil and jail duty; deputy sanitary commissioner, Nov., 1886.

JAQUET, ROBERT G., Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 11th May, 1877.

JARDINE, JOHN, Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived 30th October, 1864, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; acting under secretary to government, political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations, June, 1869, to May, 1871; from May, 1871, to Oct., 1873, served in Kathiawar as political assistant, and was in charge of the agency in Sept., Oct., and Dec., 1871; also appointed judicial assistant in Kathiawar, June, 1873; acting registrar of the high court, Bombay, Oct., 1873; secretary to the Baroda commission for the trial of the Gaekwar, Feb.-May, 1875; acting judge and sessions judge at Ratnagiri, Tanna, and Khan-deish, Oct., 1875, to Feb., 1877; secretary to the delegates of the government of India in the negotiations for a commercial treaty with Portugal, March to Sept., 1877, also acting as deputy secretary to government of India, legislative department, April, 1877; acting secretary to government of Bombay, political, judicial, educational, secret, and Persian departments, Nov., 1877, to Jan., 1878; from Feb., 1878, served in British Burma as judicial commissioner, and also presided in court of recorder of Rangoon, Oct.-Nov., 1881; president of the educational syndicate, Sept., 1881; president of the Pongdeh reformatory committee, Nov., 1881; acting chief secretary to government of Bombay, Oct., 1885; judge of the High Court, Bombay, Nov., 1885; author of 'Notes on Buddhist Law'; editor of Moung Tet Pyo's Customary Law of the Chin Tribe, also of a reprint of Dr. Tandy's translation of Father Sangermano's description of the Burman Empire, and a compilation of printed judgments of the judicial commissioner of British Burma; wrote a preface to Dr. Forchhammer's 'King Wagaru's Dhamma-Satham'.

JARDINE, WILLIAM ELLIS, Madras C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and
Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in Madras, 20th Feb., 1889, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate.

JARRETT, Henry Sullivan, Colonel, I.S.C., Legislative Department, Government of India.—First commission, Dec., 1856; during the mutiny was present at the outbreak at Mooltan, 1853, and was engaged in the pursuit of the mutineers under Brigadier-General Farquharson (medal); also served in the Mahsud Waziri expedition, 1860 (received medal and clasp), and the 2nd Eusufzai expedition, 1863 (received clasp); secretary to board of examiners, Fort William, March, 1871; in addition, assistant secretary, legislative department, government of India, from Aug., 1875.

JEFFREYS, William, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, North-Western Provinces.—First commission as lieutenant, 8th June, 1854; arrived in India, 24th Jan., 1856; served in the irrigation branch, Punjab, from May, 1857, as assistant engineer, executive engineer, and officiating superintendent, Western Jamuna canal; also officiated as assistant principal, Roorkee College; transferred to N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1862; temporarily transferred to P.W. secretariat, government of India, Nov., 1864, to April, 1865; transferred to Bengal, and specially deputed to investigate a project of irrigation and navigation for the river Gandak, Oct., 1867, to April, 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1869; officiating assistant to chief engineer, and assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, May, 1869; supervising engineer, 3rd class, April, 1872; 1st class, Jan., 1880; acting chief engineer and joint secretary, irrigation branch, March, 1887; retired, Nov., 1887.

JEHANGIR K. N. KABRAJI, Bombay C.S.—Appointed in India as probationer under native civil service rules, 14th Jan., 1888; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1888; confirmed as member of the civil service, 24th Feb., 1890.

JEHANGIR, Pestanji, C.I.E., Khan Bahadur, late Bombay C.S.—Joined the service as assistant master, Elphinstone institution, Bombay, 10th Oct., 1853; served in the settlement department from April, 1857; 1st grade, deputy collector, Aug., 1869; C.I.E., Jan., 1882; talukdari settlement officer, May, 1889; retired 1889.

JENKINS, John Lewis, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Bristol Grammar School, and Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 15th Jan., 1880, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from June, 1881, served in Sind as acting deputy collector, and acting city magistrate, Karachi; 3rd assistant collector in Sind, June, 1885; manager of encumbered estates in Sind, and educational inspector, September, 1885; and assistant collector, May, 1889; 1st assistant, Feb., 1892; assistant commissioner in Sind, March, 1892.

JENKINS, Robert Gedoin, Colonel, I.S.C., late Madras Police.—Ensign, Madras infantry, Dec., 1856; arrived in India, 8th Feb., 1857; served in the Madras police from July, 1863, and was promoted to superintendent, 1872; on special duty at Madras, July-Oct., 1874; and in the Godaveri district, June-Sept., 1879; acted as assistant inspector-general in 1874 and 1879, and as deputy inspector-general in 1885; 1st grade superintendent, Feb., 1886; reverted to military duty, 1890.

JENKINS, Thomas Lowten Layton, B.L., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1877; served in revenue and judicial departments in Bengal, and Assam (1882), as assistant magistrate and collector and assistant commissioner; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Aug., 1888.

JENKINS, Thomas Morris, Lieut.-Col., I.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, March, 1866; arrived at Madras, 16th Sept., 1866, and served with the 2nd regiment; joined the Madras staff corps, June, 1869; served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner from April, 1874; acted as port officer and collector of customs, Bassein, in July, 1881; settlement officer, 1st grade, Dec., 1884, to June, 1885; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Nov., 1885; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1886.

JENKINSON, Sir Edward George, K.C.B., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces.)—Educated at Harrow and Haileybury College; appointed to the East India company's service in 1856, and served in the N.W. Provinces as joint magistrate and deputy collector of Benares, and afterwards of Farukhabad; served through the Indian mutiny, for which he received medal and the thanks of the Queen and the Governor-General; served also as settlement officer, magistrate, and collector; commissioner of revenue in Jhansi, and commissioner in Oudh; retired, 1880; was private secretary to Earl Spencer when lord-lieutenant of Ireland, and assistant under secretary for police and crime, 1882-5; C.B. in 1883, and K.C.B. in 1888.

JENKYNS, Edward S., late Accounts Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 25th Feb., 1846; junior clerk, audit department, India office, Sept., 1858; accountant-general's department, 1860; senior clerk, Dec., 1868; retired, Dec., 1892.

JEROISE, Alan Arthur Clarke, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived, 23rd March, 1857, and served in various districts of Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, political agent and collector of stamp revenue, and acting deputy commissioner of customs and opium; junior collector and magistrate, Belgaum, Sept., 1877; senior collector and magistrate, March, 1879; retired, April, 1887.

JOBBINS, William Henry, Superintendent of Government School of Art, and Art Gallery, Calcutta.—Appointed July, 1887.

JODU NATH ROY, Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 13th July, 1861, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, and small cause court judge, Midnapore, June, 1873; judge of the court of small causes at Kooshtea, Choodanga, and Meherpore, May, 1883; subordinate judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1883; judge, Calcutta court of small causes, July, 1887.

JOHNSON, Sir Allen B., Lieut.-General, K.C.B., I.S.C., late Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Winchester; joined the service (infantry), July, 1846; appointed to 4th
Sikhs as volunteer for service in Burma; medal and clasp for Pegu; in civil employ in Punjab, 1854; Indian Mutiny in 1858; medal and clasp and brevet for Lucknow; assistant adjutant-general, 1861; military department, Calcutta, 1862; assistant secretary to government of India in the military department, 1875; deputy military secretary, 1876; secretary in the military department, India Office, from 18th Jan., 1877; temporarily employed as military secretary to the government of India, 1879-1881; C.B., 1881; retired from India Office and was made K.C.B., May, 1880.

JOHNSON, The Most Rev. Edward Ralph, D.D.—Appointed bishop of Calcutta and metropolitan of India, 14th Dec., 1876.

JOHNSON, Sir Edwin Beaumont, General, G.C.B., C.I.E., R.A.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal Artillery, June, 1842; served in the Sutlej campaign, 1845-46, including battles of Ferozeshah and Sobraon (medal and clasp), and in the Punjab campaign, 1848-49, and in pursuit of the Sikhs and Afghans (medal and two clasps); deputy judge advocate-general, Sirhind division, April, 1849; served in the Indian mutiny (medal and two clasps), and was assistant adjutant-general of artillery, Jan., 1856-63; assistant military secretary, Horse Guards, 1865-72; quartermaster-general, Bengal, July, 1873; adjutant-general, March, 1874; member of council of secretary of state for India, 1st Sept., 1874, to Feb., 1877; military member of council of governor-general of India, March, 1877-80; director-general of military education, War Office, Dec., 1884.

JOHNSON, Evans Charles, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1867; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from Jan., 1868, in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant commissioner and acting commissioner (Nilgiris), acting sub-collector, and acting district and sessions judge; on special duty, Rumpa disturbances, 1879-80; sub-collector and joint magistrate, South Arcot, Jan., 1883; from Feb., 1883, acted as principal assistant in Vizagapatam, and as collector, magistrate, and agent in the same district, and afterwards in Kurnool; acting district and sessions judge, Vizagapatam, May, 1884, to April, 1885; collector and magistrate, May, 1886; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1886; collector and magistrate and agent to the governor, Ganjam, May, 1890.

JOHNSON, John, Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872; junior clerk, June, 1882.

JOHNSON, Thomas George, Captain, I.S.C., Burma Commission.—1st commission, Aug., 1877; assistant commissioner, March, 1884; deputy commissioner, Mar., 1891.

JOHNSTON, Charles, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at High School, Dublin, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 5th Jan., 1889, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; retired, April, 1892.

JOHNSTON, David Landale, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces and Oudh).—Educated at Boston Grammar School, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 19th Nov., 1891, and served as assistant commissioner.

JOHNSTON, John Leech, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Raphoe, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting political superintendent of Akalkot, acting collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge; and grade judge and sessions judge, Kanara, Jan., 1884; 1st grade judge and sessions judge, Feb., 1886.

JOHNSTONE, Donald Campbell, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Edinburgh Academy; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1879, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; served under the government of Bombay from May, 1882, as assistant collector and magistrate, Belgaum, to Feb., 1884, when he was re-transferred to Punjab; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Punjab, Oct., 1887; confirmed, Nov., 1888; officiated as senior secretary at various periods; district judge, Dec., 1891.

JOHNSTONE, Frederick John, M.I.C.E., India Public Works Department.—Served in the public works department, Central Provinces, from July, 1861, and was appointed executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1871; assistant to the chief engineer, Aug., 1873; officiating controller of public works accounts, April to Nov., 1875; transferred temporarily to Punjab, Oct., 1879; promoted to superintending engineer, Nov., 1880; posted to British Burma, Jan., 1881; transferred to Assam as superintending engineer, and secretary to chief commissioner in the public works department, Jan., 1884; 1st class superintending engineer, March, 1886; chief engineer, June, 1888; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary to the government of Bengal, Feb., 1891; confirmed, June, 1891; secretary to the government of Bengal, public works department, March, 1892.

JOHNSTONE, Hugh, Surgeon-Lieutenant-Colonel, A.M., M.D., Medical Department, Burma.—Joined the Indian medical service, 29th Sept., 1867; arrived in India, 2nd May, 1868, and served in Calcutta at the General Hospital and as house surgeon at the Medical College Hospital; in medical charge of the British residency, Mandalay, Upper Burma, July, 1869; civil surgeon of Akyab, March, 1877; from April, 1878, officiated as civil surgeon, Rangoon, and was appointed junior civil surgeon, Rangoon, April, 1880, and civil surgeon, May, 1880; also port health officer and in charge of the lock hospital and meteorological observatory.

JOHNSTONE, Sir James, Colonel, K.C.S.I., late Assam Commission.—Ensign, Bengal infantry, 1858; assistant superintendent of police, 1864; in charge of Keddahs in the Gurjat Mehals of Cuttack, 1868-74; assistant commissioner in Assam, 1874; political agent, Manipur, 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, March, 1884; K.C.S.I., Feb., 1887; retired from Assam Commission, 1888.

JOHNSTONE, James William Hope, Colonel, I.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 4th Feb., 1853; from March, 1858, served
in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, deputy commissioner, and officiating settlement officer; officiated as commissioner and superintendent, Peshawur, in 1880 and 1883, also in the Jullundur division, Sept., 1880; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Rawal Pindi, Feb., 1881; civil and sessions judge, Peshawur, Sept., 1881; 1st grade divisional judge, Nov., 1884; retired, Feb., 1886.

JOLL, HENRY, late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 26th July, 1867, and served as assistant engineer and executive engineer; superintending engineer, Nov., 1890; retired, March, 1892.

JOLLIFFE, E. W., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, 2nd April, 1885.

JONES, H. H., Store Department, India Office.—2nd class clerk, India Store Depot, July, 1888.

JONES, JOHN ALFRED, Madras Sanitary Department.—Joined the service as executive engineer, public works department, Madras municipal commission, Jan., 1877; acted as president of the municipal commission in 1886 and 1888; appointed sanitary engineer to government of Madras, April, 1890; author of 'Switches and Crossings,' a manual for railway and tramway engineers, and of a manual for district and municipal boards.

JONES, OSWALD ROUTH, Judicial Department, Madras.—Joined the service, 3rd Sept., 1870, under the military department; served subsequently in Natal, Mauritius, and in England; in April, 1879, was appointed to the Madras Presidency as assistant superintendent of police; assistant inspector-general of police, Aug., 1886; superintendent, Aug., 1889; chief presidency magistrate, March, 1891.

JONES, THOMAS, Barrister-at-Law, late Bengal Judicial Department.—Assistant secretary, government of Bengal, 7th April, 1866; clerk and officiating 5th judge, Calcutta court of small causes, Jan., 1873; registrar and chief ministerial officer of the court, June, 1882; 4th judge, Oct., 1884; and 3rd judge, Oct., 1889; retired, 1892.

JONES, WILLIAM BRITTAIN, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 15th Sept., 1856; from March, 1857, to April, 1865, served in the N.W. Provinces, and Punjab, as assistant magistrate and assistant commissioner; from April, 1865, served in the Central Provinces as deputy commissioner, acting superintendent of cotton affairs, secretary to the chief commissioner, and acting commissioner in the Jubulpore, Nerbudda, and Nagpore divisions; on special duty as commissioner for drawing up land revenue and tenancy bills for Central Provinces, Sept., 1874; on special duty in the home department, Calcutta, Nov., 1876, also in April, 1877, and at Simla, May, 1877; commissioner, Hyderabad assigned districts, April, 1877; resident, Hyderabad, June, 1882; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, 1st May, 1883; retired, Jan., 1885.

JONES, WILLIAM RICHARD SUMPTION, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Deputy superintendent, Roorkee workshops, Nov., 1867; joined the public works department, Feb., 1873, as executive engineer, N.W. Provinces, irrigation; transferred to the locomotive department, Rajputana state railways, April, 1879, as deputy locomotive superintendent; carriage and wagon superintendent, Ajmere, in 2nd class of the state railway revenue establishment, Jan., 1880; class I., grade 3, revenue scale, Jan., 1886; grade 2, April, 1891.

JONES - BATEMAN, HERBERT BURLETON, Bengal C.S. (North - Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1876, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, Aug.-Nov., 1883; joint magistrate, Aug., 1886; small cause court judge, March, 1892; district and sessions judge, April, 1892.

JOPP, A. ABERCROMBIE, late Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy, and Royal Indian Military College, Addiscombe; entered the Royal Engineers, 10th Dec., 1860; retired Feb., 1879; secretary, office of agent-general for government of New South Wales, London, Feb., 1874, to March, 1879; director-general of stores, India office, April, 1879; retired, June, 1891.

JOPP, CHARLES HENRY, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 19th Oct., 1873; second assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1886; and first assistant, Nov., 1889; acting registrar, high court, Bombay, May, 1890; joint judge and sessions judge, Ahmedabad, April, 1892.

JOPP, JOHN, Brigadier-General, Political Department, Bombay.—1st commission, 20th Oct., 1850; served at capture of fort of Sheik Othman, near Aden, in 1858, in the Abyssinian war of 1868 (medal), and in the Afghan war, 1879-80, as assistant quartermaster-general, and took part in march to Candahar (medal); deputy quartermaster-general, Bombay, May, 1888, to May, 1890; brigadier-general, May, 1890; political resident and collector of stamp revenue, in charge of vice-admiralty court, and commandant Aden brigade, May, 1890.

JOSEPH, HUGH GORE, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; transferred for employment as deputy-commissioner in Burma, Aug., 1886; re-transferred to Madras, Oct., 1887, as head assistant to collector and magistrate; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Feb., 1890; has acted as collector and magistrate, and district and sessions judge.

Joubert, Charles Henry, M.B., Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 30th March, 1872, and was in military employ until 1874; served as civil surgeon, resident surgeon, Presidency Hospital, officiating superintendent of emigration, officiating health officer for Calcutta, officiating sanitary commissioner for Bengal, and officiating professor, Medical College; confirmed in the latter appointment, June, 1890.
JOWERS, HAROLD, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Shrewsbury, and New College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1891, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

JWALA PRASAD, KUNWAR, B.A., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces and Oudh).—Appointed a probationer under the native civil service rules, Dec., 1884; confirmed, as assistant magistrate and collector, Feb., 1887; has translated Sir Alfred Lyall’s ‘Asiatic Studies’ into Hindustani.

JWALA PRASAD, PANDIT, M.A., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Appointed a probationer under native civil service rules, July, 1886; confirmed in the civil service, 12th March, 1889, as assistant commissioner.

KASHINATH TRIMBAK TELANG, M.A., LL.B. (Bom.), C.I.E., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay Judicial Department.—Served from 15th June, 1887, as government professor of law; appointed judge of the High Court, Bombay, 25th Nov., 1889.

KAVASJEE JAMASJEE BADSHAH, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Elphinstone High School, Bombay University, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1879; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating embarkation agent and superintendent of emigration, Oct., 1882; postmaster-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Feb., 1887.

KAYE, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1858; arrived in India, 8th April, 1858; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating small cause court judge, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Bareilly, April, 1877, officiating civil and sessions judge, Gorakhpur, March, 1880, and commissioner of the Jhansi division, Dec., 1881; commissioner of the Agra division, July, 1885, and of the Rohilkhand division, Nov., 1889; acting member of board of revenue, Jan.-Nov., 1890; on special duty in connection with the police reorganisation commission, Nov., 1890, to April, 1891; commissioner of the Rohilkhand division, April, 1891; junior member of board of revenue, Nov., 1891.

KAY-SHUTTLEWORTH, Rt. Hon. Sir Ughtred James, Bart., M.P.—Educated at Harrow, and at the London University; sat in the House of Commons as member for Hastings from Oct., 1869, till 1880; served for two years on the London School Board, and was also a member of the royal commission on reformatory and industrial schools; in 1885 was returned for the Clitheroe division of N.E. Lancashire, and was appointed under secretary of state for India in Feb., 1886, and shortly afterwards chancellor of the duchy of Lancaster; in the election of 1886, and again in 1892, was returned for N.E. Lancashire; parliamentary secretary, admiralty, Aug., 1892; was for some time vice-president of University College, London.

KEATINGE, RICHARD Harte, Lieut.-General, V.C., C.S.I., R.A., Indian Staff Corps.—First commission, Bombay artillery, June, 1842; from 1847 was employed in civil duties on the N.W. frontier, and was appointed assistant superintendent, Nimar, Dec., 1851; in the Mutiny of 1857 served in Central India, and was present at the sieges of Dhar and Chandere, and in the fighting near Mundesore (dangerously wounded, brevet of major, medal and clasp and V.C.); also took part in pursuit of Tantia Topec, 1858-59; political agent, Nimar, 1860; political agent, Gwalior, and subsequently in Kattywar, 1862; served in Kattywar against the rebel Wagheers in 1865; agent to the governor-general in Rajputana, 1868; also ex-officio chief commissioner of Ajmere; chief commissioner of Assam, 1874 to June, 1878.

KEDAR NATH ROY, M.A., B.L., Bengal C.S.—From 1878 served as munshi, and on 27th July, 1883, was appointed member of the statutory civil service as assistant magistrate and collector; author of three legal works.

KEDAR NATH MOZUMDAR, B.A., B.L., Bengal Judicial Department.—Served in the subordinate judicial department, from 15th December, 1865, and was appointed subordinate judge, 1st grade, July, 1890.

KEEPER, WILLIAM NAPIER, Surgeon-Major, late Indian Medical Department.—Assistant-surgeon, Bengal Medical Establishment, 1st Oct., 1860; served under the military department up to 1884, when he was appointed senior medical officer, Port Blair and the Nicobars; served in the Looshai campaign, 1871-72 (medal and clasp), the Duffla expedition, 1874-75, the Jowaki campaign, 1877-78 (clasp), the Afghan campaign, 1878-79-80 (medal and clasp), the Zaimush expedition, 1879, and the Egyptian campaign, 1882 (medal and clasp, Khedive’s bronze star, and 4th class Order of the Osmanieh); retired, Dec., 1889.

KEEGAN, DENNIS FRANCIS, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, M.D., Indian Medical Service.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; joined the Bengal medical service in 1866; arrived in India 13th Dec., 1866; from Nov., 1868, served with the Central India Horse, and acted as residency surgeon, Indore, 1877-78; served in the Afghan War, 1879-80 (medal and clasp, bronze star); residency surgeon, Indore, and civil administrative medical officer, Central India, June, 1881; author of several articles and papers on medical subjects.

KEELAN, BERNARD CALLASE, Surgeon-Major, L.K. and Q.C.P., M.R.C.S., L.M.K. and Q.C.P. (Ir.), late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Bombay medical service, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867, and served under the military department, and also as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail at various stations; served in the Abyssinian campaign, and was present at the storming of Magdala (medal); civil surgeon, Sukkur, Jan., 1881; civil surgeon, superintendent of jail, lunatic asylum, and medical school, Hyderabad, April, 1884; retired, March, 1891.

KEENE, CHARLES JAMES, Railway Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 29th Dec., 1874, as assistant traffic superintendent, Punjab northern state railway; served also on the Northern Bengal state railway, the North-Western and other railways; district traffic superintendent, class ii., grade i., 1839.
KEENE, HENRY G., C.I.E., M.R.A.S., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1847; arrived in India, 3rd Oct., 1847; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; superintendent, Dehra Dun, May, 1856; magistrate and collector, April, 1860; civil and sessions judge April, 1867; officiated as commissioner of the Agra division in 1872 and 1875, and of the Allahabad division in 1874; retired, 1883; fellow of the Calcutta University; member of committee of the Muhamadan College of Aligurh; medal from the zoological society; medal and diploma from the Austrian Exhibition of 1863; author of 'Indian Administration,' 1867; 'History of Hindustan,' 1885; 'Life of Madhava Rao Sindhi,' 1892; and numerous contributions to the periodical press.

KEENE, HENRY GEORGE HARRIS, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the department, and was attached to the accountant-general's office, Rangoon, 14th March, 1874; assistant accountant-general, Feb., 1878, and assistant comptroller-general, March, 1878; class iv. of financial department, Jan., 1890.

KEESS, JAMES, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., M.R.C.P., and L.M. (London), and M.R.C.S., late Madras Medical Department.—Served in the subordinate medical department as warrant officer from 11th Sept., 1848, to May, 1855; assistant surgeon, 4th Aug., 1856; arrived 11th Sept., 1856, and served under the military department up to May, 1862, and subsequently as civil surgeon and superintendent of district jail, Kurnool, and was placed on special duty experimenting on alkaloids in Gudalur and Wynaad, June, 1866; fort surgeon, Madras, and professor of anatomy and physiology in the Medical College, April, 1867; medical inspector of seamen, Aug., 1868; acting principal medical storekeeper and inspector of emigrants, May, 1869; acting health officer and superintendent, lock hospital, Madras, April, 1880; fellow of Madras University, May, 1882; principal and professor of medicine in the Medical College, and senior physician, General Hospital, Aug., 1883; retired, Jan., 1887; author of 'Syllabus of Medicine for use of Medical Students,' 'Notes on Zoology and Comparative Anatomy,' 'History of the Madras Medical College,' a pamphlet on the 'Prevention of Cholera,' and a 'Calendar of the Medical College.'

KEITH, STANLEY, Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Lancing College; writer, India Office, 6th June, 1873; clerk, 2nd class, April, 1879.

KEITH, THOMAS W., Accountant-General, India Office.—Educated at Highgate School; East India House writer, old establishment, 20th Aug., 1845; junior clerk, treasury, 1848; senior clerk, Sept., 1858; accountant-general's department, 1860; accountant, Jan., 1872; assessor of income tax, 1872; accountant-general, Feb., 1879.

KELLAKKA COVILAGOM MANAVEDAN RAJA, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Madras University; appointed by government of India as probationer for the civil service, 4th June, 1880; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1882; acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant, Aug., 1888.

KELLEHER, JAMES, B.L., Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Catholic University of Ireland; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 20th Sept., 1869; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, Oct., 1879; transferred to Assam as district and sessions judge of Sylhet, March, 1884; services replaced at disposal of government of Bengal, Sept., 1887; district and sessions judge, Dec., 1887; author of 'Possession in the Civil Law,' and 'Principles of Specific Performance and Mistake.'

KELLEY, W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India Office, 9th Oct., 1879.

KELLNER, EDWIN WELSH, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department as assistant comptroller-general, 29th April, 1870; served as deputy accountant-general, and, for a short period, as accountant-general, Bengal, 1874-76; deputy comptroller-general, Jan., 1877; assistant commissioner of paper currency, Calcutta, Dec., 1877; deputy comptroller-general in 1st class of financial department, Aug., 1878; acted as accountant-general, Bengal, in 1883, 1886, and 1887; officiating comptroller and auditor-general, Aug., 1887; officiating as accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh in 1887; and Madras, 1888; class i., finance department, enrolled list, July, 1889; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, in 1889; accountant-general, Punjab, March, 1890.

KELLY, CHARLES ARTHUR, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 14th Nov., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, and grade, June, 1868; also served as assistant-superintendent of survey, 1863-64, and officiating inspector of schools, 1866; appointed small cause court judge, Bhagulpore, Jan., 1876, and served subsequently in the judicial department; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Jan., 1879; retired, Jan., 1888.

KELSALL, JOHN, late Madras C.S.—Educated at University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; from March, 1865, to Jan., 1867, served as probationary assistant-superintendent of police, and subsequently in the revenue and judicial departments in various districts of Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, principal assistant, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled the Bellary 'District Manual'; appointed district and sessions judge, Aug., 1880, in the Godavari district, and afterwards in South Malabar and Vizagapatam; retired, Nov., 1889.

KEMBALL, SIR ARNOLD BURROWES, General, K.C.B., K.C.S.I., late Political Department, Government of India.—Educated at Addiscombe; and lieutenant, Bombay artillery, Dec., 1837; served in the Afghan war, 1838-39, and was present at the siege and capture of Ghuznee (medal); appointed assistant to the resident at Bushire, Feb., 1842; political resident, Persian Gulf, May, 1852; consul general, Bagdad, and political agent, Turkish Arabia, April, 1855, to
1873; served in the Persian expedition of 1857, and was present at the capture of Mohumrah (medal and clasp, C.B., and brevet of major); served with the Turco-Persian boundary commission, 1873; during the Russo-Turkish war, 1876-77, was British military attaché at the headquarters of the Turkish army.

KENBALL, CHARLES GURDON, Barrister-at-Law, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1850; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1850; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, judicial assistant commissioner (in Sind), and deputy magistrate; collector and magistrate, Karachi, Nov., 1861; served as judge and sessions judge, Surat, from Jan., 1866, to June, 1870, and from the latter date acted as judge of the high court, Bombay, in which appointment he was confirmed in Aug., 1871; acted as member of council, Bombay, in 1880, and again in 1881; retired in 1885.

KEMBLE, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 8th April, 1858; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Oct., 1873; inspector-general of jails, July, 1876; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1878; officiating opium agent, Benares, May, 1882; opium agent, Behar, May, 1884; officiating commissioner, Patna, May-Nov., 1890; acting member of board of revenue, June, 1892.

KENNEDY, JAMES, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, settlement officer, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1879; magistrate and collector, Gorakhpur, March, 1884; retired, April, 1890.

KENNEDY, JOSEPH, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at the High School and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1874; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty, Madras, in 1878; transferred to Assam, May, 1884, as assistant commissioner, 1st class; deputy commissioner, July, 1886.

KENNEDY, Sir MICHAEL KAVANAGH, General, K.C.S.I., R.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, 11th June, 1841; arrived in India, Nov., 1842; assistant engineer, roads and tanks, June, 1843; executive engineer at Surat, Aden, and Satara, 1848-60; on special duty, Ceylon, Madras, and Calcutta, Oct., 1860 to April, 1861; superintending engineer, Southern division, April, 1862; secretary to government of Bombay, public works and railway departments, July, 1863; resigned the public works department in 1880; controller-general of supply, Kabul expedition; additional secretary to government of India for supply and transport, 1880.

KENNEDY, ROBERT MUIRHEAD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1877; and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting junior collector and magistrate, and railway magistrate, Bandra; 2nd assistant collector, April, 1888; 1st assistant, May, 1891; in 1891 acted as political agent, Mahi Kantha, and as administrator, Rajpipla state.

KENNEDY, THOMAS JOHN, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Liverpool Institute, Balliol College, Oxford, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1880, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; transferred to Central Provinces, Oct., 1885; settlement officer, Raipur, Oct., 1885; retransferred to the Punjab, and appointed assistant commissioner, Lahore, Nov., 1887; officiating district judge, Oct., 1890, and from April, 1891; also officiating divisional judge, Kulu.

KENNEDY, WILLOUGHBY PITCAIRN, Major, I.S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Joined the service, 8th Feb., 1870, and served under the military department; assistant to political agent, Mahi Kantha, March, 1875; served subsequently in the same capacity at Aden, Zanzibar, Baluchistan, and Kathiawar; assistant to the agent to the governor-general, Central India, Aug.-Oct., 1880; acted as administrator of the Porbandar State in 1888 and 1889; and as political agent, Kolhapur, in 1890; special political agent, Cambay, Oct., 1890.

KENNEY - HERBERT, ARTHUR ROBERT, Colonel, Madras Cavalry.—Cornet, 20th Sept., 1859; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1859; served on regimental duty with various cavalry regiments; adjutant, governor's body guard, Sept., 1865; deputy assistant quarter-master general, 1873-76; major, Sept., 1879; military secretary to the governor of Madras, May, 1881, to April, 1884; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, military department, Dec., 1881; from April, 1884, acted as secretary to the government of Madras, military department, and was confirmed in that appointment, Dec., 1885; retired, April, 1892.

KENSINGTON, ALFRED, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 12th Feb., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; on special duty in civil secretariat, Oct., 1882; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, Nov., 1882; settlement officer, April, 1884; on special duty in Umballa settlement, Dec., 1889; appointed under-secretary to government of India, finance and commerce department, April, 1890; officiating as deputy secretary, Jan., 1891.

KERNAN, JAMES, M.A., Q.C., late Judicial Department, Madras.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; judge of the high court, Madras, 3rd May, 1870; fellow of the Madras University, Feb., 1871; vice-chancellor of the Madras University, June, 1885, and 1887; officiating chief justice, July to Nov., 1885, and in July, 1888; retired, July, 1889.

KERR, T. COULTER, Captain, Store Department, India Office.—Surveyor of shipping, 1st April, 1831.
KERSHAW, Louis James, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Belfast Methodist College and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 31st Oct., 1890, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Assam as assistant commissioner, March, 1892.

KETTLEWELL, G., B.A., Inspecting Veterinary Surgeon, Madras.—Arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1854; served under the military department till Dec., 1881, when he was appointed principal, Veterinary School, Lahore; inspecting veterinary surgeon, Madras Army, April, 1891.

KEYS, Arthur Innes, Registry Department, India Office.—Appointed clerk, London office, Indo-European Telegraph Department, 1880; on abolition of that office, services transferred to India office, 1st Jan., 1889.

KEYSER, Alfred, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Guildford Grammar School, and Royal Academy, Gosport; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1865, and served as assistant-collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate and political agent, Surat, Dec., 1884; senior collector, &c., April, 1887; acting commissioner, Southern division, March, 1890; retired, March, 1892.

KHANDERAO CHIMANRAO BEDAR-KAR, Rao Bahadur, B.A., LL.B., Judicial Department, Bombay.—Joined the service, 25th April, 1863, as Gujarati and Marathi translator and interpreter, high court; deputy registrar and sealer, Feb., 1867; services lent to H.H. the Maharaja Holkar, Oct., 1890; 4th judge, Bombay small cause court, Dec., 1890, continuing to be in the foreign service.

KHarsedji Manekji Kharsedji, Khan Bahadur, B.A., Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 29th May, 1874, as judge of the court of small causes, Ahmednagar, and subsequently at Ahmedabad; appointed 4th judge, Bombay small cause court, June, 1888, and 3rd judge, May, 1889.

KHarsedji Ratanjji Bamani, Bombay C.S.—Probationer under the native civil service rules, and assistant-collector and magistrate, Nov., 1882; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, Jan., 1885; and assistant, April, 1892.

Khushwaktrae, Rae, B.L., Bengal Civil Service (N.W. Provinces).—Appointed by the Government of India probationary assistant magistrate and collector, under the native civil service rules, 16th April, 1890.

Kiernander, Charles Robert Campbell, late Financial Department, Government of India.—Assistant accountant-general, British Burma, 5th Aug., 1864; officiating deputy accountant-general, Central Provinces, April, 1870; assistant accountant-general, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1870; from Feb., 1874, to Jan., 1876, served as deputy accountant-general in the Punjab, and subsequently in Bombay, N.W. Provinces, British Burma, and Bengal; officiated as accountant-general, Bengal, in 1878 and 1879; inspector of local offices of account, Oct., 1878; deputy comptroller-general in 1st class of financial department, Feb., 1883; assistant secretary, government of India, financial department, Nov., 1884, to Jan., 1885; comptroller of Indian treasuries, April, 1885; deputy auditor-general, Oct., 1886; officiating deputy comptroller-general, Aug., 1887; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, Sept., 1890, and again from May, 1891; deputy comptroller-general, April, 1891; retired, March, 1892.

Kilby, George Charles, B.L., Bengal Judicial Service.—Deputy superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, 28th Feb., 1876.

Kilby, Sanford James, Bengal Preventive Service.—Assistant collector of customs, Chittagong, 30th June, 1865; deputy magistrate and deputy collector, July, 1866; from Aug., 1868, to Dec., 1876, served in the police department, and was appointed assistant superintendent, 1st grade, May, 1874; on famine relief duty, Dec., 1873, and March, 1876; on special duty in Chumparum, April, 1874; from Dec., 1876, served in the customs preventive service, and was appointed superintendent, Jan., 1877; also in charge of the Sulkea salt golahs, April, 1880; served in Madras as deputy commissioner, akbari and salt department, Sept.-Nov., 1885, when he returned to his Calcutta appointment.

Kilgour, Frederick, Colonel, I.S.C., Police Department, Madras.—First commission, 11th July, 1857; probationary assistant superintendent of police, Nov., 1865; assistant superintendent, Aug., 1873; superintendent, June, 1874; deputy inspector-general, May, 1892.

Kimberley (Earl of), Right Hon. John Wodehouse, K.G.—Born 7th Jan., 1826; educated at Eton, and Christ Church, Oxford, where he graduated B.A. in 1847, with 1st class in classics; succeeded to title of Baron Wodehouse, May, 1846; under secretary of state for foreign affairs, Dec., 1852, to 1856; ambassador at St. Petersburg, 1856-58; under secretary for foreign affairs, June, 1859, to Aug., 1861; on a special mission to the North of Europe, in connection with the Schleswig-Holstein question, 1863; under secretary of state for India, April-Nov., 1864; lord lieutenant of Ireland, Nov., 1864, to July, 1866; raised to earldom of Kimberley, May, 1866; elected governor of the Hudson's Bay Company, April, 1868; lord privy seal, Dec., 1868, to July, 1870; secretary of state for the colonies from July, 1870, to Feb., 1874; member of the royal commission to enquire into the working of the Penal Servitude Acts, Feb., 1878; secretary of state for the colonies, May, 1880; held provisionally the office of chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, on Mr. Bright's resignation, June, 1882; secretary of state for India, Dec., 1882, to June, 1885, Feb. to Aug., 1886, and again from Aug., 1892; was a royal commissioner for the exhibition of 1886; has been a member of the senate of the University of London since 1859, and was for some time president of University College, London (resigned, 1887).
