Kincaid, Charles Augustus, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Sherborne School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1891, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

Kincaid, William, Major-Gen., I.S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Madras Army, March, 1849; appointed to adjust boundaries disputes, Bhopal agency, March, 1864; assistant political agent, Bundelcund, small cause court judge and canton-
ment magistrate, Nowgong, 1866; second in command, Malwa Bheel corps, Nov., 1870; political agent, Bhopal, Aug., 1876; political agent, Bhopawur, and commandant, Malwa Bheel corps, Oct., 1879; political agent, Bhopal, June, 1881; returned to Europe, 1887.

KINDERSLEY, JOHN ROBERT, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury in 1847; served in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector till 1857, when he was appointed assistant judge of Mangalore; subordinate judge, Bellary, 1859; civil and sessions judge, Rajahmundry, March, 1865, and subsequently at Bellary; officiating judicial commissioner, Mysore, Sept., 1866, and again 1868; judge of the high court of judicature, Madras, June, 1877; retired in 1884.

KING, GEORGE, C.I.E., M.B., LL.D., F.R.S., Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1865; house surgeon, Medical College Hospital, from 9th May to 25th Aug., 1866, when his services were placed at disposal of government of India, military department; superintendent of Royal Botanical Gardens, ex-officio professor of botany in Calcutta Medical College, and ex-officio superintendent of cinchona plantation in British Sikkim, from July, 1871; surgeon-major, Oct., 1877; also officiating quinologist, Dec., 1879; brigade surgeon, April, 1880; C.I.E., Jan., 1890; superintendent of botanical gardens, Calcutta, and professor of botany in Calcutta medical college, July, 1871; in addition, director of the botanical survey of India, May, 1891; author of 'Manual of Cinchona Cultivation in India,' and other botanical works, and editor of 'Annals of the Royal Botanical Gardens, Calcutta.'

KING, JOSHUA, M.A., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 26th Oct., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant judge and session judge; in charge of the small cause court, Ahmedabad, April-May, 1864; acting under secretary to government, revenue, financial, and general departments, May, 1866; acting collector and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Bombay, July, 1869, to Jan., 1870; talukdari settlement officer, Dec., 1874, to Feb., 1876, and again, Feb., 1876, to Nov., 1877, for carrying Bombay Act VI of 1862 into effect, and manager under Act XV of 1871; on special duty, Baroda, Nov., 1877, to June, 1879; junior collector and magistrate, Ahmednagar, May, 1879; senior collector and magistrate and political agent, Satara, May, 1884; retired, 1886.

KING, LUCAS BLACKER BURNET, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 11th Oct., 1860; from Nov., 1861, served in the Bengal revenue, survey, and judicial departments, and was appointed superintendent of survey, Aug., 1866, joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Jan., 1877, and district and sessions judge, 1st grade, July, 1880; retired, Aug., 1885.

KING, LUCAS WHITE, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Ennis College, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 27th Nov., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating junior secretary to financial commissioner, Punjab, Sept., 1882; revenue officer, Swat river canal, Feb.-May, 1885; transferred to foreign department as officiating political agent, and assistant commissioner, Ajmere, June, 1885; political agent, 3rd class, sub-pro-tam, Oct., 1885; boundary settlement officer, Meywar, Tonk border, Feb., 1887; officiating political agent, and assistant commissioner, Ajmere, March, 1887; assistant to resident, Mysore, and secretary to chief commissioner, Coorg, July, 1887; on special duty with Maharaja of Mysore, Dec., 1887; first assistant to agent to the governor-general for Central India, Feb.-July, 1888; re-transferred to Punjab as assistant commissioner, Sept., 1890; also political officer, Shirani Field Force, Oct., 1890.

KING, WALTER GAWEN, M.B., C.M., D.P.H., Surgeon-Major, late Madras Medical Department.—Arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1874, and served under the military department in Madras and Burma; acted as Zillah surgeon, and superintendent of district jail, as surgeon to His Excellency the Governor, and as professor at the Presidency College; civil surgeon, June, 1877; also superintendent of jail, March, 1878; district surgeon, April, 1890; has twice officiated as inspector of vaccination, and deputy sanitary commissioner; reverted to military department, Jan., 1892.

KING, WILLIAM, B.A., D.Sc., Geological Survey of India.—Educated at Queen's College, Galway; appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined the service, 4th March, 1857; served in various districts of the Madras presidency, and was appointed deputy superintendent for Madras, Nov., 1868; served subsequently in the Godavari district and the Nizam's territories, and discovered the Singareni coal-field, 1871-72; deputed to Vienna in joint charge of the survey collections at the Exhibition, 1873; 1st grade officer, April, 1875; fellow of the Madras University and member of the Faculty of Engineering, 1884; officiated as superintendent of the geological survey, May-Nov., 1884; designation changed to superintendent of survey; appointed director, April, 1887; author of contributions to the survey publications.

KINGSMILL, JAMES, late Central Press, Bombay.—Joined the service as general superintendent of the Government Central Press, and editor of the 'Bombay Government Gazette, 16th March, 1872 to 1891.

KIPLING, JOHN LOCKWOOD, C.I.E., Education Department, Punjab.—Joined the government service as architectural sculptor, Bombay, May, 1865; from April, 1875, served in the Punjab as principal of Mayo School of Industrial Art, and curator, Lahore Museum.

KIRKHAM, THOMAS BROWN, B.L., Educational Department, Bombay.—Joined the educational department, 1st Jan., 1862; arrived in India, 21st June, 1862, and served as headmaster of the Poonah High School, principal of the Elphinstone High School, Bombay, and professor of English literature at the Elphinstone College; was also a member of the first municipal corporation of Bombay, Aug., 1873; from
April, 1878, served as educational inspector, and was promoted to 2nd grade of the department, April, 1885; on special duty in England in connection with technical education, Nov., 1886.

KIRKWOOD, TOWNSEND MOLLOY, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bromsgrove Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived, 2nd Dec., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1876, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1880; served temporarily under the public works department, Oct., 1869, to Oct., 1871, and was employed on famine duty, Bhagulpore, March, 1874; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, April, 1886; retired, 1888.

KISCH, HERMANN MICHAEL, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1873; assistant magistrate and collector, Bengal, Nov., 1873; on famine duty, Patna, March, 1874, and at Bellary, Feb., 1877; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, May, 1878; under secretary, judicial and political departments, Jan., 1880; officiating secretary in the financial department, June, 1881; officiating under secretary, government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Dec., 1883; postmaster-general, Bengal, Nov., 1885; officiating deputy secretary to government of India, finance and commerce department, Jan., 1889; officiating director-general of post office of India, May, 1890; on deputation to Vienna Postal Congress, April-July, 1891; author of the statistical account of Chittagong district.

KISSORY MOHUN CHATTERJEE, B.A., B.L., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Officiated as judge of the small cause court in 1888 and 1889, and was confirmed as 4th judge, 3rd Oct., 1889.

KITTS, EUSTACE JOHN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portland Grammar School, Mill Hill Grammar School, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1874, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Berar, Aug., 1875, and served as assistant commissioner and also as small cause court judge of Akola; on special (famine) duty in Madras, 1877-78; assistant commissioner, Ajmere, May to Nov., 1883; from April, 1884, served in the N.W. Provinces, and was appointed joint magistrate, 2nd grade, May, 1885; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1887; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1888; small cause court judge, Jan., 1890; district and sessions judge, Dec., 1890; author of 'Berar Census Report,' and 'Castes and Tribes found in India.'

KNAPP, ARTHUR ROWLAND, Madras C.S.—Educated at Westminster, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1891, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

KNIGHT, RAYMONT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's College, Stony Stratford, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Jan., 1885; assistant collector, April, 1885; 2nd assistant and forest settlement officer, March, 1892.

KNOWLYS, HENRY BOLD, late Berar Commission.—Served as a writer in the Ceylon civil service, 15th Feb., 1859, to Aug., 1866; from Sept., 1866, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Sept., 1873; deputy commissioner, May, 1886; retired, July, 1891.

KNOX, GEORGE, late Punjab Administration.—Assistant engineer, May, 1854; from June, 1856, served in the Punjab commission, and was appointed personal assistant to commissioner of Jullundur, April, 1864; assistant commissioner, 1st class, Oct., 1864; deputy commissioner, 1st class, Dec., 1877; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Rawul Pindi, Nov., 1878, to April, 1879; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; retired, 1890.

KNOX, GEORGE EDWARD, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865; from June, 1867, served in the N.W. Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from March, 1877, served in the judicial department, and was appointed small cause court judge, Allahabad, Aug., 1877; judge, 3rd grade, March, 1884; officiating legal remembrancer, Feb., 1885; member of the lieutenant-governor's council for making laws and regulations, Dec., 1886; district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, continuing to act as legal remembrancer, Sept., 1887; confirmed in the latter post, Sept., 1887; judge of the High Court, N.W.P., Dec., 1890; author of a 'Digest of the Criminal Law of the Bengal Presidency,' a 'Digest of Civil Procedure,' 'The Legal Remembrancer, 1879-82,' and 'Treatise upon the Indian Stamp Law.'

KNOX, HUBERT THOMAS, B.L., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1868, and served in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting deputy commissioner of salt revenue, acting principal assistant, joint sessions judge for trying Rumpa cases, and assistant commissioner (Nilgiris); acted as district and sessions judge, Ganjam, April-Sept., 1884, and afterwards in North Arcot; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Malabar, Oct., 1884; district and sessions judge, Trichinopoly, Nov., 1887; collector and magistrate, Nov., 1888; district and sessions judge, Bellary, Feb., 1890; resigned, Jan., 1892.

KNYVETT, WILLIAM LEYCESTER NATHANIEL, Colonel, I.S.C., late Police Department, Bengal.—First commission, 10th June, 1854; served in the Bengal police department from June, 1863, as district superintendent (1st grade, April, 1875); officiating personal assistant to inspector-general, July, 1875; deputy inspector-general, April, 1885; officiating inspector-general of police, Bengal, July, 1888; reverted to military duty, 1891.
KONSTAM, EDWIN MAX, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 29th Nov., 1890, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

KOUGH, CHARLES, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Kingstown, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1867, and served in various districts of Madras in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, head assistant, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; forest settlement officer, March, 1884; acted for various periods as collector and magistrate in the districts of Madura, Cuddapah, and North Arcot; collector and magistrate, Kurnool, Nov., 1887.

KRISHNA CHUNDER CHATTERJEE, B.A., B.L., Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 19th Dec., 1865, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, May, 1877; small case court judge, Backergunge, Dec., 1877; subordinate judge, 1st grade, May, 1884.

KRISHNA GOVINDA GUPTA, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Mymensing Zilla School, and Pogose School, Dacca, and matriculated at Calcutta University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, March, 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Sept., 1884; has also officiated as magistrate and collector, and as junior secretary to the board of revenue, and was confirmed in the latter appointment, May, 1890; in 1891 acted as commissioner of excise, Bengal; magistrate and collector, March, 1892.

KRISHNA MOHUN MOOKERJI, B.L., Judicial Department, Bengal.—Served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, from 28th March, 1865, and was appointed subordinate judge, 1st grade, Dec., 1884.

LAING, JAMES ANDERSON, M.D., Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Madras Medical Department.—Assistant-surgeon, 1st April, 1870; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1870, and served in the Madras medical department as civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, and acting resident surgeon at the General Hospital, Madras; deputy sanitary commissioner and inspector of vaccination, Feb., 1878; surgeon-major, April, 1882; officiating sanitary commissioner, April, 1886; confirmed in appointment, June, 1888.

LAKSHMAN GOPAL DESHMUKH, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, 16th April, 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, June, 1885; and assistant collector and magistrate, Nov., 1889.

LAKSHMI KANTHA RAO PANTULU, JIDDU, DEWAN BAHAADUR, Madras Revenue Department.—Joined the service, 1st Jan., 1855, and served in various subordinate posts; deputy director of revenue settlement, Aug., 1883; member of committee on draft tenancy bill, July, 1885; deputy commissioner, April, 1887; from June to Sept., 1890, acted as secretary to revenue commissioner; compiled the 'Manual of the Revenue Settlement Department,' 1887.

LAL BEHARI DE, REV., late Bengal Education Department.—Served from 3rd Sept., 1867, first as head master, and afterwards as assistant professor, in the Berhampore College; assistant professor in the Hooghly College, Jan., 1872; 3rd class of the education department, May, 1885; author of 'Govinda Samanta, or Bengal Peasant Life,' 'Folk Tales of Bengal,' 'Recollections of Alexander Duff.'

LAMB, RICHARD AMPHLETT, Bombay C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Highgate Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 21st Oct., 1879, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; forest settlement officer, Khandeish, March, 1885; transferred to Burma as deputy commissioner, March, 1887.

LAMBE, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, March, 1881; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1886; magistrate and collector, Mainpuri, April, 1889; deputy commissioner, Jalauan, Nov., 1890; magistrate and collector, Ghaziurp, April, 1892.

LAMBERT, JOHN, C.I.E., Police Department, Bengal.—Served from 23rd Nov., 1863, as assistant superintendent, district superintendent, and officiating personal assistant to the inspector-general; on special duty, March, 1872; visitor of the presidency jail, and of the lunatic asylums, July, 1872; deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, Feb., 1874; served under the government of India, foreign department, from March, 1882, to March, 1884, as officiating political resident, 2nd class, and general superintendent of the operations for the suppression of thuggee and dacoity; acted as commissioner, Calcutta, and president of the boiler commission, 1885–86; commissioner of police, Calcutta, April, 1889; member of lieutenant-governor's council, June, 1892.

LAMBERT, PARRY, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Punjab.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1857; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, 8th Jan., 1858, and served in Oudh and the Punjab; executive engineer, Dec., 1863; officiating controller of Punjab northern state railway accounts, Sept., 1875; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Madras, May, 1876; examiner, 3rd class, Oct., 1878; transferred to the office of examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, March, 1879; transferred to Bombay, as officiating examiner, public works accounts, Dec., 1879; from Dec., 1881, served in the N.W. Provinces as examiner, public works accounts, and officiated in Bengal, Feb.–Dec., 1882; examiner, 1st class, May, 1886; transferred to Bombay, May, 1884; and to the Punjab, Sept., 1886; reverted to military department, 1891; retired, March, 1892.

LANDON, CHARLES PALMER, Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed assistant superintendent, 1st Sept., 1868, and served on various lines; superintendent, June,
1880: held charge of Upper Burma field division, 1886 (services acknowledged by government); Dacca division, Jan., 1888; in charge, Calcutta telegraph office, Nov., 1890, and from July, 1891.

LANE, CLAYTON TURNER, Colonel, I.S.C., Police Department, Hyderabad Administration.—Ensign Bengal army, 11th Dec., 1858; from March, 1863, served in the Punjab as assistant superintendent, and district superintendent of police; transferred to Berar police, Sept., 1865; inspector-general of police and jails, Hyderabad assigned districts, April, 1877; is also inspector-general of jails and registration and stamps, and registrar of joint stock companies.

LANE, JAMES HORSBURGH, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 1st Feb., 1857; superintendent, 1st grade, Bombay, Aug., 1870; officiating deputy director-general, March, 1872, and again Feb.–April, 1886; director of traffic, Feb., 1879; officiating deputy director-general, Feb., 1886, and Jan., 1890; confirmed, April, 1890; officiating director-general, April, 1892; compiler of 'Word Code for Foreign Telegrams.'

LANE, JOHN MACDONALD, M.I.E.E., late Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the Indian telegraph department, 22nd Sept., 1862; assistant superintendent, 1st grade, Jan., 1866; superintendent, Bengal, Oct., 1869; served subsequently in the Malabar Coast and Nagpur divisions; 1st grade superintendent, British Burma, Sept., 1883, and afterwards in Bombay; charge of Bengal division, Dec., 1889; retired, April, 1891.

LANE, H. H., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd July, 1892.

LANE, WILMOT, Barrister-at-Law, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 13th January, 1855; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; from Aug., 1863, to March, 1866, served in Oudh as officiating deputy commissioner, Lucknow; magistrate and collector, Mainpuri, Jan., 1872; civil and sessions judge, Moradabad, Aug., 1877; commissioner, Rae Bareli division, Sept., 1880, and subsequently of the Agra and Meerut divisions; officiating as member, board of revenue, N.W. Provinces, Oct.–Dec., 1883; retired, April, 1889.

LANG, ARTHUR MOFFATT, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, N.W.Provinces.—1st commission, June, 1852; arrived in India, July, 1854; assistant engineer, Punjab, Nov., 1855; superintendent, civil buildings, Lahore, Aug., 1856; executive engineer, March, 1857; during the mutiny served at the siege and capture of Delhi, the relief and capture of Lucknow, and various engagements (medal and clasps); assistant to chief engineer, Oudh, April, 1858; assistant secretary, public works department, to chief commissioner, Oudh, July, 1865; principal, Thomason Engineering College, March, 1871, to May, 1877; superintending engineer, 1st grade, deputy inspector-general military works, and secretary, defence committee, Feb., 1879; secretary to agent to governor-general, Baluchistan, public works department, Feb., 1881; chief engineer, and secretary to chief commissioner, British Burma, public works department, Jan., 1883; chief engineer and joint secretary, buildings and roads and railway branches, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, July, 1885; chief engineer, 1st class, March, 1886; retired, Nov., 1887.

LANG, GEORGE LUKIS, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1858; arrived in India, March, 1858; from Nov., 1858, to Nov., 1866, served in Oudh as assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer; from Nov., 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, deputy commissioner, Jhansi, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, Aligarh, April, 1877, and was subsequently posted to Bulandshar; officiating district and sessions judge, July–Sept., 1880; has acted for various periods as commissioner in the Agra, Rohilkund, and Fyzabad divisions; commissioner of Jhansi, July, 1889; retired, May, 1891.

LANG, JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 28th Nov., 1890, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

LANG, RICHARD TICKELL MONTGOMERY, Colonel, Bengal Cavalry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1859; from May, 1862, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and officiating judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, April, 1877; officiating additional civil and sessions judge, Peshawur, April–Nov., 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Mooltan, March, 1881, and subsequently in the Rawal Pindi Division; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1882.

LANGLEY, EDWARD HARTLEY RAYNSFORD, Brigade-Surgeon, B.A. (Dub.), M.R.C.S. (Lon.), late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Bombay medical service, 23rd July, 1858; arrived in India, 28th Sept., 1858; was employed under the military department, and as acting civil surgeon in various stations; served with 5th regiment, N.L.I., in China in 1860–62; appointed presidency surgeon and marine surgeon, Bombay, Oct., 1876; also in medical charge of the European General Hospital, May–June, 1882; brigade-surgeon, June, 1884; retired, Nov., 1889.

LANSDOWNE (MARQUESS OF), RIGHT HON. HENRY CHARLES KEITH FITZMAURICE, G.M.S.I., G.M.I.E., G.C.M.G., Honorary D.C.L. (Oxford).—Born, 1845; educated at Eton, and Balliol College, Oxford; succeeded to the marquisate in 1866; a lord of the treasury, 1868 to 1872; under secretary for war, 1872 to 1874; under secretary for India, April to July, 1880; governor-general of Canada, May, 1883; appointed governor-general of India, and assumed office, 10th Dec., 1888; hon. D.C.L., Oxford, 1888.

LARKINS, ARTHUR BROOKS, Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed assistant superintendent, 30th Oct., 1860, and employed on various lines, including Tavoy–Siam line; superintendent, March, 1886, and held charge of various divisions; in charge, check office, Calcutta, April, 1892.

LARMINIE, WILLIAM, late Store Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 2nd Aug., 1873; retired, 1887.

LARMINIE, WILLIAM REA, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open
competitive examination of 1859; arrived, 28th Dec., 1860; from Nov., 1861, served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1879; officiating commissioner, Orissa division, and superintendent of Tributary Mchals, Cuttack, June, 1883; officiating commissioner, Dacca, April, 1885; commissioner, Dacca division, Oct., 1886; retired, Aug., 1880.

LARYMORE, ALEXANDER DOUGLAS, Jail Department, Bengal.—Served in the Behar cavalry as trooper, 1857-8; joined the Bengal police as assistant superintendent, 31st July, 1862; district superintendent, June, 1872; on famine relief duty, Nov., 1874; superintendent, Midnapore jail, Jan., 1877; superintendent of Alipore jail, March, 1884; has also officiated as inspector-general of jails.

LAST, ARTHUR WALTER WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces and Oudh).—Educated at Westminster, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 16th Nov., 1891, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

LATHAM, FRANCIS LAW, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Judicial Service, Bombay.—Served as acting remembrancer of legal affairs, 23rd May, 1872, to 1st Jan., 1873; also acted as advocate-general, and as judge of the high court, Bombay, for various periods between 1st Jan., 1880, and 5th March, 1884; advocate-general, Bombay, 6th March, 1884; additional member of the Bombay legislative council.

LA TOUCHE, CECIL D'URBAN, Colonel, I.S.C., late Cantonment Magistrate, Bombay.—Ensign, 29th July, 1850; arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1850, and served on military duty up to Nov., 1883, and subsequently as cantonment magistrate, Poona; returned to Europe, 1888.

LA TOUCHE, HENRY CHRISTOPHER DIGGES, late Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, Nov., 1868, as executive engineer, Punjab northern state railway; Agra-Gwalior railway survey, Nov., 1872; engineer-in-chief, Sindia state railway, construction division, Nov., 1879; Bundelcund railway surveys, 1881; engineer-in-chief, Jhansi-Manikpur state railway, Sept., 1883; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1885; engineer-in-chief, Bellary-Kistna and Cuddapah-Nellore railways, March, 1886; lent to Southern Mahatta Railway Company, Jan., 1888; superintending engineer, 2nd class, March, 1889, and 1st class, Feb., 1890; retired, May, 1892.

LATOUCHE, JAMES JOHN DIGGES, B.A., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer, till Dec., 1871, when he was transferred as settlement officer to Ajmere; also served as officiating assistant commissioner of Bewar and officiating deputy commissioner, Ajmere; returned to N.W. Provinces, 1875, and was appointed district superintendent of police, 1st grade, Bulandshahr, Sept., 1875; served subsequently in various districts in officiating appointments as settlement officer, magistrate and collector, and district and sessions judge, and was promoted to joint magistrate, 1st grade, July, 1882; settlement officer, 1st grade, Gorakhpur, Nov., 1883; from Aug., 1886, served in Upper Burma as commissioner of the Southern division; rejoined the N.W. Provinces as magistrate and collector, April, 1890; officiating commissioner, Allahabad, May, 1891; acting chief secretary, Nov., 1891; member of lieutenant-governor's council, Dec., 1891; author of 'Gazetteer of Ajmere-Mairwara.'

LATOUCHE, WILLIAM PAGET, Colonel, I.S.C., late Salt Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay army, Sept., 1854; arrived in India, 17th Jan., 1855; was employed on military duty, and served in the Persian war, 1856, and the mutiny campaign, and was also appointed assistant magistrate, Dec., 1859, and assistant district superintendent of police, Jan., 1865; acting political superintendent, Palanpur, June-Nov., 1867; from Dec., 1867, served in the Bombay police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent (1st grade, May, 1882), and also acted as superintendent of the Bombay, Baroda, and C.I. railway company's police, Nov., 1868, to Nov., 1869; on special duty, June, 1879, to Feb., 1880; from Feb., 1883, served as deputy collector of salt revenue; returned to Europe, 1887.

LAUDERDALE (EARL OF), Rt. Hon. FREDERICK HENRY MAITLAND, Lieutenant-Colonel, I.S.C.—First commission, 4th Hussars, Feb., 1861; served in Central India on civil employ from 1869 as boundary officer, and political assistant; 2nd assistant agent, Indore, 1877; 1st assistant agent, Indore, 1878; additional political agent and superintendent, Charkhari, 1883; retired, Jan., 1886.

LAUGHLIN, ROBERT CAMPBELL, M.I.E.E., late Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as assistant superintendent, Oct., 1866; held charge of various divisions, chiefly in Madras and Bengal, and charge of the telegraph stores, Calcutta; class iv., 2nd grade, Oct., 1887; retired, May, 1891.

LAUGHTON, DANIEL WILSON, Major-General, I.S.C., late Berar Commission.—First commission in the army, Jan., 1854; arrived in Madras, April, 1854; from Jan., 1865, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, small cause court judge, and cantonment magistrate; acted as inspector-general of registration, Jan., 1873; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Feb., 1885; retired, May, 1886.

LAURIE, HENRY MONTAGUE, B.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1887; assistant commissioner, Central Provinces, Dec., 1887; officiating under secretary to the chief commissioner, Nov., 1890, to Jan., 1891.

LAURIE, LEWIS KOSSUTH, B.L., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 27th Oct., 1873; from Nov., 1873, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting deputy commissioner, and acting district superintendent of police; acted as registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, July, 1880, to March, 1883, and as small cause court judge, Nagpur, in 1881, 1882, and 1887; acting assistant secretary to the chief commissioner, 1883-85; acting commissioner of excise, superintendent of stamps, and
inspector-general of registration, July-Oct., 1883, and again, March, 1885; acting director of agriculture, and junior secretary to chief commissioner, Sept.-Oct., 1884; under secretary to chief commissioner, Oct., 1885; assistant commissioner, Oct., 1887; acted as secretary to chief commissioner in 1889 and 1890; judge, small cause court, Jubbulpore, Jan., 1890; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1890; commissioner of excise, Jan., 1891; officiating inspector-general of police and jails, May, 1891; confirmed in that appointment, April, 1892; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1892; author of a digest of rulings of judicial commissioners, C.P., in civil cases (1881), and some manuals relating to the Central Provinces.

LAURIE, MAXWELL, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Watson's College, Edinburgh, and Edinburgh University, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Burma division of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Burma, 9th Dec., 1889, and served as assistant commissioner and settlement officer.

LAW, VICTOR EDWARD, Colonel, Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras cavalry, April, 1859; acted as government agent at Chepak, paymaster of Carnatic stipendiaries, and Persian and Hindustani translator to government, July, 1866; attache, foreign department, July, 1872; served in Rajputana as superintendent of railway police, 1872 to 1877; political agent, Jeypoor, 1877, and afterwards in Ulwar, 1877-1883; officiating political agent, Charkhari, 1883; assistant at Sujangarh to governor general's agent in Rajputana, Feb., 1884; agent to governor general with king of Oudh, and superintendent of political pensions, March, 1884; appointed to the political charge of ex-Amir Muhammad Yakub Khan of Kabul, Aug., 1884; officiated as political agent, Mussoorie, 1890-91.

LAWRENCE, ALEXANDER JOHN, C.I.E., late Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1856; served from March, 1858, in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from March, 1864, served in the Central Provinces as settlement officer of Bhandara; re-attached to N.W. Provinces, Feb., 1869, and served as settlement officer and officiating magistrate and collector; member of the commission under the military department on the Lawrence asylums, June to Nov., 1872; on special duty with the government of India, home department, Dec., 1872; officiating civil and sessions judge, Mainpuri, June, 1874; magistrate and collector, Etawah, Oct., 1874, and subsequently of Agra; officiated for various periods as commissioner, Agra division; commissioner of the Allahabad division, April, 1885, and Meerut division, April, 1889; C.I.E., May, 1888; retired, Nov., 1891.

LAWRENCE, EDWARD, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1878, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer; acted as assistant to the political resident at Aden, March, 1882, and as under secretary to Government, political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the governor's council for making laws and regulations, April, 1885; compiler of general administration report for 1884-85; acted as assistant judge and sessions judge, and as under secretary to government, in revenue, financial, and general departments; under secretary to the government of India, finance and commerce department, April, 1889; deputy accountant-general, Bombay, April, 1890; officiating accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, March, 1891.

LAWRENCE, HENRY JOHN, Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Infantry, Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 14th February, 1862; from Aug., 1866, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; district judge, Nov., 1884; additional divisional judge, Amritsar, Jan., 1885; officiating divisional judge, Jan., 1887, and again in 1889; divisional judge, April, 1889.

LAWRENCE, HENRY STAVELEY, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Haileybury College, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 23rd Nov., 1890; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1891.

LAWRENCE, RICHARD CHARLES, General, C.B., I.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—First commission, Bengal infantry, June, 1834; served in the Sutlej campaign in 1846, and was present at the battle of Sobraon (medal); second in command, Loodianah regiment, Dec., 1847; assistant commissioner, Punjab, April, 1849; captain of police, Lahore division, Jan., 1853; served in the Indian mutiny as political officer in charge of the Cashmere contingent, under General Wilson, in 1857; and was present at the assault and capture of Delhi (brevet of major, C.B., medal with clasp); military secretary to lieutenant governor of the Punjab, 1860; deputy commissioner, Simla, April, 1862; resident, Nepaul, 1867 to 1872.

LAWRENCE, WALTER ROPER, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1879, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from Sept., 1881, to April, 1884, served in Ajmere and Merwara as officiating political assistant and assistant commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; in charge Ajmere treasury and office of registrar of assurances, May, 1882; under-secretary to government, Punjab, Feb., 1885, and again in April, 1886; under secretary to government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Sept., 1886; officiated as secretary in 1888; settlement officer, Kashmir, April, 1889; C.I.E., Jan., 1891.

LAWRIE, EDWARD, Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, M.B., Indian Medical Department.—First commission, Bengal medical service, 1872; surgeon-major, March, 1884; residency surgeon, Hyderabad, April, 1885; is also superintendent of vaccination, superintendent of medical school, and surgeon to the Afzalganj hospital.

LEA, JAMES HERBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1888, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.
LEARY, A.S., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at the Moravian colleges of Fulneck in Yorkshire, and Neuwied on the Rhine; temporary clerk, India Office, 15th Nov., 1860; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

LE BRETON, WILLIAM INGLIS, Lieutenant-Colonel, I.S.C., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined the royal artillery, Dec., 1864; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1865; joined the public works department, Nov., 1866, and served as assistant engineer in the Bombay presidency till Nov., 1869, and subsequently as assistant controller and deputy controller of accounts in the Punjab, N.W. Provinces, and Bombay; controller, 3rd class, and examiner of railway accounts, Bombay, Sept., 1874; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, Nov., 1877; from Dec., 1879, served as examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, and was promoted to 2nd class, May, 1886; also officiated as examiner of public works accounts, Sept.-Dec., 1883, and port storekeeper, state railways, March-June, 1884; examiner, public works accounts, Bombay, Feb., 1887; retired, June, 1889.

LEE, HARRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Yarmouth Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, March, 1876; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Oct., 1885; chairman of the commissioners, Calcutta, April, 1890.

LEE, WILLIAM HERBERT, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1887; and served as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Assam as assistant commissioner, June, 1890.

LEEDS, ROBERT JAMES, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1861; served from Aug., 1862, in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating deputy superintendent of the family domains of the Maharaja of Benares, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from Nov., 1879, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge; retired, April, 1887.

LEEDS, WILLIAM HENRY ARTHUR ST. JOHN, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Cheltenham College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885; transferred to Burma, as assistant commissioner, Nov., 1888; officiated as director of land records and agriculture, Nov., 1890, to Feb., 1891.

LEES, DONALD HECTOR, Bengal C.S.—Educated at North London Collegiate School, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 1st Dec., 1890, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

LEE-WARNER, JOHN, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; served in various districts of Madras from April, 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate and acting cantonment magistrate; on special duty, inquiring into condition of poorer classes, North Arcot and Salem, Jan., 1868; boundary arbitrator between the Kalastri Zemindari and Madras district, Sept., 1868; special assistant collector, Madura, for the management of the Ramnad estate, Dec., 1871, to March, 1878; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1882; acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, May, 1884; district and sessions judge, Kistna, Oct., 1884; collector and magistrate, Dec., 1884; retired, Jan., 1890.

LEE-WARNER, WILLIAM, M.A., C.S.I., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby School, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th November, 1869; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1870; officiating director of public instruction, Berar, Feb., 1872; private secretary to governor of Bombay, May, 1872, to Nov., 1874, and Jan.-Dec., 1876; on special duty in the secretariat, Nov. 1874; acting under secretary to government, political, judicial, and educational departments, and acting secretary to the legislative council, Bombay, Nov., 1874; from Dec., 1876, to Aug., 1878, served in Sind as assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of registration, acting educational inspector, and acting commissioner; acting junior collector and magistrate, Satara, March, 1881; on special duty as member of the education commission, Calcutta, 1882; on special duty at the Nira canal, April, 1882; from Jan.-Oct., 1884, acted as junior under secretary to government of India, foreign department, and as private secretary to the president in council of the governor-general (Jan.-Feb.), and was on special duty in the foreign department, March-June, 1884; acting press commissioner, Sept., 1884; acting under secretary to government of India, foreign department, Oct., 1884; first assistant collector and acting director of public instruction, Bombay, March, 1885; on special duty in the Hyderabad State, Nov., 1885; acting political agent, Kolhapur, and Southern Mahratta country, Jan., 1886; also president of the Regency Council, Kolhapur, May, 1886; secretary to government of Bombay, political, &c., departments, Aug., 1887; C.S.I., Jan., 1892.

LE FANU, WILLIAM JOSEPH HENRY, B.A., B.L., Madras C.S.—Educated at Kingstown School, Tipperary Grammar School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived, 28th Oct., 1865; served in Madras revenue and judicial departments from Oct., 1866, in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, and joint magistrate, acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; district and sessions judge, Kistna, Dec., 1883; collector and magistrate, Cuddapah, Jan., 1886; North Arcot, Nov., 1888; compiler of 'Salem District Manual.'
LEGEYT, PHILIP HARRISON, Colonel, I.S.C., late Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 27th March, 1851; was employed under the military department, including service with the Persian expeditionary force (medal and clasp); served subsequently with the Gujarat Irregular Horse, and also acted as assistant political agent, Mahi Kantha (April, 1858); from May, 1863, served in the political department as assistant political agent, Kathiawar and Cutch, and magistrate of the district of Bhavnagar; political agent, Mahi Kantha, 1872-1880; political superintendent, Palanpur, Sept., 1880; 1st grade, political agent, Feb., 1885; returned to Europe, 1889.

LEGGATT, EDWARD OWEN EVERY, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School, and Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, and Dec., 1883; served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and was appointed assistant superintendent and judge of the small cause court, Dehra Dun, April, 1890; joint magistrate, May, 1890; officiating district and sessions judge, April, 1892.

LEGGATT, ERNEST HUGH EVERY, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School, and Keble College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 15th Dec., 1891, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

LEITNER, GOTTLIEB WILLIAM, M.A., Ph.D., LL.D., D.C.L., Barrister-at-Law, late Education Department, Punjab.—Served in education department as principal of the Lahore College from 12th Nov., 1864, and was promoted to 2nd grade of the department, Nov., 1880; in July, 1867, was deputed to Kashmir for a philological examination of the Kashmiri and Chilasi dialects; on special duty in connection with the school text-book committee at Simla, May, 1877; attended the congress of Orientalists at Florence, Oct., 1878; officiating director of public instruction, Punjab, July, 1879; on special duty with education commission, May, 1882; retired in 1886.

LELY, FREDERIC STYLES PHILPIN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th December, 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting city survey and inquiry officer at Ahmedabad, acting talukdari settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; in charge of the Sachin state, Oct., 1881; first assistant collector, Surat, Dec., 1884; administrator of the Porbandar State in Kathiawar; junior collector, June, 1890; member of Deccan agriculturists' relief act commission, 1891-92.

LEMAN, GEORGE DOWNTON, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed principal assistant to the collector and magistrate and agent, Ganjam, Dec., 1866; acting civil and sessions judge, Guntoor, July, 1867, and afterwards at Tellicherry; acted as collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, in 1868, and again in 1875 and 1881-82, and as Imam commissioner in 1869; from Feb., 1872, to Nov., 1877, served as collector and magistrate of Kistna, and subsequently in Ganjam and Coimbatore; retired, March, 1888.

LE MESSURIER, AUGUSTUS, C.I.E., Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bombay Engineers, Dec., 1856; served in the Indian Mutiny at the sieges of Forts Beyt and Dwarka; joined the Bombay public works department, as assistant engineer, May, 1860; was employed on the Karachi harbour works, on irrigation in Sind, on the Bombay harbour defences, &c.; executive engineer, March, 1863; deputy consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, Aug., 1864; served in the Abyssinian expedition, 1868 (medal); deputy consulting engineer for railways in Sind, Aug., 1871; acted as consulting engineer, Lahore, April-July, 1875; acted as secretary to the railway transport committee at Delhi, in 1875-76, and to a similar committee at Agra, 1876-77; deputed to Brussels exhibition to report on continental system of transport by railways, Aug., 1876; superintending engineer, May, 1877; officiating under secretary to government of India, railway branch, May, 1877, to Nov., 1878; served in the Afghan war, 1879-80, (medal and brevet of lieutenant-colonel); engineer-in-chief, Mysore state railway, Nov., 1879; joint secretary to chief commissioner, Mysore, 1880; on special duty reporting on timber-cutting operations in east of France, April, 1880; manager, Mysore state railway, Feb., 1881; consulting engineer to Mysore government, and secretary to chief commissioner, Coorg, March, 1882; superintending engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1883; engineer-in-chief, Bangalore-Harihar railway; 3rd chief engineer, March, 1887; on special duty, military department, Dec., 1887; officiating consulting engineer, railways, Calcutta, Feb., 1888; 2nd chief engineer, April, 1888; on special railway duty, Dec., 1888; chief engineer and secretary to government of Punjab, May, 1889; reverted to military duty, June, 1892.

LE MESURIER, HAVILLAND, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1886; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Assam, Nov., 1886; assistant secretary and personal assistant to chief commissioner, March, 1891; transferred to Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, April, 1892.

LE MESURIER, JOHN, Lieutenant-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1852; second lieutenant, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1855; served in the public works department in Sind from June, 1856, as assistant engineer and executive engineer, and was employed on the Nara works and the Rohri canal, Hyderabad; served with the Persian expedition, 1856-57 (medal and clasp); on special duty, Karachi, Jan., 1867; acting superintending engineer for irrigation in Sind, April, 1871, to Dec., 1873, and for various periods between 1875 and 1880; superintendent of works, Western Indus, Karachi, Dec., 1873; superintending engineer, Jan., 1879; officiating chief engineer for irrigation and under secretary to government of Bombay, June-Aug., 1883; (temporary) chief engineer, 3rd class, and chief engineer for irrigation, and joint secretary to government, public works depart-
ment (irrigation), March, 1884; superintending engineer in Sind, Jan., 1886; retired, March, 1887.

LETHBRIDGE, Alfred Swaine, M.D., C.S.I., Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 30th Sept., 1867; served from March, 1872, as superintendent of central jail and officiating civil surgeon, Bhagulpore; officiating inspector-general of prisons, sanitary commissioner, and superintendent of vaccination, British Burma, July, 1876; officiating sanitary commissioner, Bengal, May, 1877; inspector-general of jails, Bengal, Jan., 1878; C.S.I., May, 1890; president of the factory commission, Sept., 1890; president, native passengers ship committee, Nov., 1890; resumed his post as inspector-general of jails, March, 1891; general superintendent of operations for the suppression of thagi and dakaiti, April, 1892.

LEtheren, S. K., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at King's College, London; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 6th July, 1877.

LEUPOLT, John Cunningham, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1862; from Aug., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; from Aug., 1882, served in the judicial department as civil and sessions judge; retired, April, 1889.

LEVESON, Henry George Ashworth, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Marlborough College and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Burma division of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Burma, 14th Dec., 1889, and served as assistant commissioner; acting assistant superintendent, Southern Shan States, May, 1891.

LEVINGE, Edward Vere, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1888, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

LEVY, Frank, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton School, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 15th Nov., 1887, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate.

LEWIS, Edwin Morris.—Superintendent, Bengal secretariat press, April, 1869; superintendent of government printing, Bengal, Sept., 1877.

LEWIS, Thomas Crompton, M.A. (Cambridge), Punjab Educational Service.—Appointed professor, government college, Lahore, 13th Oct., 1881; promoted to 3rd grade of graded staff, Feb., 1886; and grade, April, 1886; principal of government college, Lahore, May, 1886.

LIARDET, Charles Aylmer, Colonel, I.S.C., late Revenue Survey Department, Madras.—Ensign, Madras infantry, Oct., 1855; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1855; Madras staff corps, Sept., 1866; served in the Madras revenue survey department from Oct., 1868; on famine relief works, Jan., 1877, to March, 1878; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Sept., 1884; retired, April, 1888.

LIDDERDALE, Robert, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon, late Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1858; superintendent of vaccination, 8th November, 1869; in medical charge, Jalpaiguri, in addition to his own duties, June, 1872; sanitary commissioner, Bengal, April, 1880; professor of hygiene, Medical College; rank of surgeon-major, Jan., 1870; deputy surgeon-general (local rank), Bengal, Jan., 1884; retired, Jan., 1889.

LIGHTFOOT, Jabez, Railway Department, Government of India.—Appointed from the Scinde, Punjab, and Delhi railway as deputy manager, North-Western state railway, Jan., 1886; class 1, revenue establishment, state railways, July, 1886; manager, Punjab section, March, 1887; Sind section, May, 1887; auditor, Oudh and Rohilkund railway, Jan., 1889; transferred to superior accounts establishment, Sept., 1889; acted as manager, Oudh and Rohilkund railway, in 1890, and again in 1891; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Madras, Oct., 1891.

LILLINGSTON, Edward Gordon, Colonel, I.S.C.—First commission in army, 30th Aug., 1859; from 5th Feb., 1864, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, and was appointed assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Aug., 1867, officiating political agent, Hill Tipperah, Feb., 1874, superintendent of the central jail, and the European penitentiary at Hazaribagh, May, 1875, and deputy commissioner, and grade, March, 1886; 1st grade, Aug., 1887; reverted to military department, March, 1892.

LIMOND, David, Major-General, C.B., R.E., late Public Works Department, Punjab.—First commission, Bengal engineers, 1850; assistant engineer, public works department, Bengal, Feb., 1853; during the mutiny, served at relief and defence of Lucknow (medal and clasp); executive engineer, Cawnpore, 1858; officiating supervising engineer, Allahabad, April, 1867, and in Bengal, western circle, from March, 1868; transferred to Rawal Pindee, Jan., 1869; supervising engineer, military works, Rawal Pindee, April, 1872; in 1879-80 served as commanding engineer, Peshawur Valley field force (medal, C.B.); chief engineer, 3rd class, military works, April, 1881; chief engineer and secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1883; chief engineer, 1st class, July, 1884; retired, 1886.

LINDSAY, Benjamin, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at the Methodist College, Belfast, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and in Oudh as assistant commissioner.

LINDSAY, Charles Robert, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Woolwich, and Haileybury; appointed to the Bengal civil service, 1844; arrived in India, 1845; served in the revenue and judicial departments in the N.W. Provinces; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Farakhabad, 1858; magistrate and collector, Farakhabad, 1862; extra judge of the Sudder court, Agra, 1863; civil and sessions judge, Mainpuri, 1865, and subsequently of Goruckpore and Moradabad; judge of the chief court, Punjab, 1869; retired, 1880.

LINDSAY, James Gavin, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department.—Lieutenant, Madras engineers, Aug., 1855; joined the public works
department as assistant engineer, Dec., 1857; during the mutiny served at the battle of Banda, (medal and clasp); served subsequently as executive engineer in Banda and Orissa; deputy consulting engineer for railways, 1863; executive engineer, 1st grade, railway survey, Mysore, April, 1870; officiating superintending engineer, and engineer-in-chief, Northern Bengal railway, 1872; acted as director of state railways, N.E. system, and joint secretary to Bengal government, Nov., 1878, to March, 1879; engineer-in-chief, Harnai and Gulistan-Karez sections of Kandahar railway, Feb., 1880; served in the Afghan Campaign, 1879-80 (medal); superintending engineer and secretary to resident, Hyderabad, March, 1881; engineer-in-chief, Southern Mahratta railway, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer, 1st class (supernumerary), April, 1881; services lent to Southern Mahratta railway company, May, 1884; engineer-in-chief, Bolan railway, April-June, 1885; 3rd chief engineer, March, 1887; 2nd chief engineer, April, 1888; retired, April, 1891.

LINDSAY, WILLIAM, Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Winchester; junior clerk, India Office, 31st Jan., 1867; private secretary to parliamentary under secretary of state, 1877-81; senior clerk, Jan., 1882.

LIST, GEORGE HENRY, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as personal assistant to superintending engineer, 12th April, 1873; executive engineer, July, 1875; assistant secretary, railway branch of public works secretariat, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Oct., 1879; served subsequently on various railways; acted as manager and engineer-in-chief, Muttra-Hathras and Cawnpore-Farukhabad railways in 1881; superintendent, way and works, North-Western railway, Nov., 1891; superintending engineer, 3rd class, March, 1892.

LISTER, ALLEN LINDSAY, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Rossall School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from March, 1865, in the grades of assistant and sub-collector, and was placed on special duty in connection with the relief of the poorer classes, South Arcot, Jan., 1868; on famine duty, Sept. to Dec., 1877; on special duty, Irrigation and Canal Company, Jan., 1878; collector and magistrate, South Canara, July, 1882; district and sessions judge, Nov., 1882, in Vizagapatam, and afterwards in the Godavari district; retired, March, 1890.

LISTON, JOHN, Colonel, I.S.C.—Arrived in India as ensign, 29th May, 1856; served with the Bundelcund field force in the campaign of 1859; from Aug., 1863, served in Jhansi, Kumaon, and Ajmere, as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Lalitpur, Dec., 1879; officiating commissioner, Jhansi, Aug. to Nov., 1882; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1887; retired, Nov., 1889.

LITTLE, CHARLES, Surgeon-Lieut.-Col., M.D., M.C., L.R.C.S., L.M., Madras Medical Service.—Arrived in Madras, 1st Nov., 1872, and served under the military department; civil surgeon, Akola, Jan., 1877; sanitary commissioner, inspector-general of dispensaries, and superintendent of vaccination of the Hyderabad assigned districts, July, 1881; surgeon-major, March, 1884; surgeon-lieut.-colonel, March, 1892.

LITTLE, FREDERICK ARTHUR, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Acted as government solicitor and public prosecutor, Bombay, Oct.-Nov., 1879, and May to Nov., 1883, and was confirmed in this appointment, May, 1884.

LITTLE, THOMAS DAVID, M.I.C.E., Bombay Public Works Department.—Joined the service June, 1859, and arrived in India, Oct., 1859; appointed assistant engineer, Aug., 1862, and executive engineer, Jan., 1869; superintending engineer, Sept., 1880; was an additional member of the governor's council for making laws and regulations, Dec., 1889 to May, 1890; chief engineer, Nov., 1891.

LIVESAY, JOHN JAMES, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 14th Nov., 1861; from Jan., 1863, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner, and was appointed magistrate and collector, and grade, Oct., 1878; employed on famine relief duty, March to Oct., 1874; retired, March, 1888.

LOYD, ERNEST THOMAS, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Charterhouse, Shrewsbury, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Feb., 1882; transferred to N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1885; and served as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; officiating city magistrate, Lucknow, Dec., 1886; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, March, 1889; 1st grade, Nov., 1891.

LOYD, FRANCIS, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at the College School, Gloucester; appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College in 1844; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and session judge; judicial assistant to magistrate, Satara, 1860; judge and session judge, Dharwar, 1861; judge and session judge, Poona, and agent for Sirdars in the Deccan, 1866; judge of the high court, Bombay, 1869; retired in 1873.

LOCH, JAMES HENRY, M.D., Deputy Surgeon-General, late Central Provinces.—Joined the Bengal medical service, Dec., 1854; arrived in India, 31st Jan., 1855; served under the military department till Aug., 1859, including service with the Oudh field force in 1855, and at the relief of Azamgarh, 1858 (medal), and subsequently in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon in various stations and superintendent of jail, and held medical charge of the lieutenant-governor's camp in 1869-70, and again, 1872 and 1873; brigade-surgeon, Nov., 1879; deputy surgeon-general, Central Provinces, Jan., 1884; retired, Jan., 1886.

LOCH, WILLIAM, Lieut.-Col., I.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, March, 1866; served in the 14th Foot; joined the Bombay staff corps, May, 1868, and served subsequently in the Sind horse; assistant political superintendent, Sawantwari, May, 1877; assistant to general superintendent of
operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoitee, 1878; 2nd assistant to governor-general's agent, Indore, 1879; assistant at Banswarra and Pertabgurh, 1880; during the Afghan war was on political duty with Major-General Sir R. Phayre's force, marching to the relief of Kandahar (medal); 2nd assistant agent, Beloochistan, in charge of Pishin valley, Nov., 1880; acting assistant resident, Western Rajputana, and boundary settlement officer in Marwar, Dec., 1881; confirmed, April, 1886.

LOCH, WILLIE WALKER, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Glenalmond, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; acting principal of the Raja's school, and tutor and governor of the Gaekwar, Baroda, April-Nov., 1880; first assistant collector and railway magistrate, Oct., 1882; junior collector and magistrate, Sept., 1883; senior collector and magistrate, Nov., 1890; acting commissioner of customs, &c., Bombay, May, 1891; also British delegate for the Portuguese-Indian Treaty; acting commissioner, Northern Division, April, 1892.

LOGAN, ALEXANDER COCHRANE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer; officiating under secretary to government in the judicial, political and educational departments, and secretary to legislative council, April, 1890, to Jan., 1892.

LOGAN, ROBERT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Royal Academy, Inverness, and University College, London; matriculated at the London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1869; served in the Central Provinces from 1869 to 1881, in the grade of assistant commissioner, and officiated as district superintendent of police, March, 1872, inspector of schools, Dec., 1873, to March, 1874, and registrar of the judicial commissioner's court, April, 1874, to Dec., 1875; from April to Nov., 1881, served in the financial department in Bengal as deputy accountant-general and officiating accountant-general; appointed assistant comptroller-general in class III of the financial department, Sept., 1881; acted as under-secretary, government of India, finance and commerce department, from Nov., 1881, and was confirmed in this appointment, July, 1883; officiated as accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, and deputy commissioner of paper currency, Aug.-Oct., 1883, and as deputy accountant-general, Feb., 1884, and again in 1885; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, March, 1884; officiating deputy accountant-general, Bengal, Sept., 1884; officiating accountant-general, Punjab, March, 1885; deputy accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Dec., 1885; officiating accountant-general, Punjab, April, 1887; class 2 of enrolled officers, Nov., 1887; accountant-general, Bombay, and commissioner of the issue of state paper currency, March, 1890; officiating comptroller and auditor-general.

LOGAN, WILLIAM, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Musselburgh Grammar School, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and acting district and sessions judge; collector and magistrate of Malabar, March, 1876; on special duty, Feb., 1881, as commissioner for inquiring into certain important matters in the Moplah districts; fellow of University of Madras, March, 1881; member of forest draft bill committee, March, 1882; acting member, board of revenue, Nov., 1882; acting resident of Travancore and Cochin, May, 1883 to Feb., 1884; on special duty at Madras in connection with report on land tenures of Malabar, Feb., 1884, and again in connection with the Attipadi valley suit, July, 1884; retired, 1888; has published a collection of treaties, engagements, &c., relating to British affairs in Malabar, 1879; and edited Mr. Graeme's glossary of Malayalam words and phrases, 1882.

LOKENDRA NATH PALIT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1886, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

LONGE, FRANCIS BACON, Captain, R.E., Survey of India Department.—First commission, 2nd Feb., 1876; assistant superintendent, survey department, March, 1880; deputy superintendent, April, 1888; 3rd grade, Dec., 1890; served in Afghan war, 1879-91, and with the Suakim expeditionary force, 1885.

LORD, WALTER FREWEN, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School, London, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; retired, Feb., 1889.

LORIMER, JOHN GORDON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Dundee Institution, High School, Dundee, Edinburgh University, and Christ College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 23rd Nov., 1891, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

LOVE, HENRY DAVISON, Major, R.E., Madras Education Department.—Educated at University College, Bath, and Royal Military Academy, Woolwich; lieutenant, R.E., 12th September, 1872; acted as inspector of schools for science and art department, 1875-76; admitted to Madras establishment, Oct., 1876; arrived in India, 5th December, 1876; first assistant master, civil engineering college, July, 1877; on special duty in connection with Madras harbour works, Dec., 1877; served subsequently in the P.W. Department, and acted as deputy consulting engineer for railways in 1878 and 1879, and as deputy chief engineer and under-secretary to government, irrigation branch, June-Nov., 1879; assistant examiner of accounts, Nov., 1879; principal, civil engineering college, Jan., 1880; fellow of Madras University, March, 1881; member of committee in connection with scheme of technical education, Sept., 1885; compiled a 'Manual of Hydraulics,' 1886.

LOVE, ROBERT, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Royal Academy, Belfast, Queen's College, Galway, and Emmanuel College, Ca-
bridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 16th Nov., 1897, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

LOVETT, BERESFORD, Colonel, C.B., C.S.I., R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1858; arrived in India, Sept., 1866; joined the public works department, April, 1861, and served in the Punjab till Sept., 1866, when he was transferred to the Persian telegraph department; assistant commissioner, Seistan boundary commission, Sept., 1870; rejoined P.W. department as executive engineer, Sept., 1872; C.S.I., Feb., 1873; attached to Bori Valley field force, Nov., 1877 to Jan., 1878; served in the Afghan war, 1878-79; transferred to Bengal, Feb., 1881; British consul at Astrabad, Sept., 1880 to Jan., 1883; superintending engineer, Bengal, 1885; transferred to military works department, April, 1886; commanding engineer, Hazara field force, Sept., 1888; C.B., 1889.

LOVETT, HARRINGTON VERNEY, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Sherborne, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant commissioner.

LOWIS, CECIL CHAMPAINE, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Newton College, Devonshire, Government Gymnasium, Gottingen, and Corpus Christi College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service (Burma) after open competition of 1885; arrived in Burma, 8th Jan., 1888, and served as assistant commissioner and registrar to judicial commissioner, Burma; under secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1891.

LOWIS, EDMOND ELLIOT, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 1st Feb., 1857; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1858; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Sept., 1861; deputy commissioner, Western Dooras, Oct., 1867; deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Oct., 1867; magistrate and collector, Maldah, Dec., 1867; officiating civil and sessions judge, Aug., 1868; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1872; commissioner, Chittagong division, March, 1875; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1879; officiating opium agent, Behar, Jan. to Nov., 1879; commissioner, Dacca division, Dec., 1885, and in the Rajshahi division, Oct., 1886; retired, Dec., 1891.

LOWNDES, THOMAS, Major-General, I.S.C., late Police Department, Burma.—Joined the Madras army, and arrived in India, Dec., 1854; served in the Burma police department from March, 1861, as superintendent; on special mission to Chiangme, March-May, 1871; political agent, Bhamo, May, 1872, to Oct., 1873; 1st grade, superintendent, May, 1875; inspector-general of police, British Burma, Jan., 1876; appointed to special duty in Upper Burma, Dec., 1883; retired, Aug., 1887.

LUARD, CHARLES HENRY, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission as lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1855; joined the public works department as assistant engineer, Lower Provinces, Nov., 1857; deputy superintendent, Western Jumna canal, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1859; assistant principal, Thomason College, 1863; assistant secretary, government of India, public works department, officiating as deputy consulting engineer for railways, Bengal, March, 1865; deputy superintendent, Ganges canal, 1865; confirmed as deputy consulting engineer, Bengal, Oct., 1867; officiating under secretary, government of India, railway branch, Oct., 1873 to 1875; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, June, 1874; officiating mint master, Calcutta, July to Oct., 1876; officiating consulting engineer, Lucknow, 1877; consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, 1884, and subsequently at Calcutta, Dec., 1885; chief engineer, and class, May, 1886; 1st class, March, 1887; while on leave, in 1887, deputed to attend railway conference at Milan; consulting engineer for railways, Dec., 1889; retired, Jan., 1890.

LUCAS, ARTHUR, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1884; also forest settlement officer, March, 1886.

LUCAS, WILLIAM HENRY, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service, after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1888; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1889.

LUDLAM, JOSEPH T., late Registry Department, India Office.—Served under the India Board from 1838; registrar at India Board, 1859, and continued in charge of the records till 1867, when he was transferred to the registry department, India Office, as extra assistant to registrar; retired May, 1888.

LUDLOW, EDMUND SAMUEL, C.I.E., Colonel, I.S.C., Hyderabad Administration.—Served with the Madras Native Infantry from 1858 to 1864, and with the Saugor Field Division in 1859; from Oct., 1864, served in Mysore and Coorg as assistant superintendent; judge of the small cause court, Bangalore, 1874 and 1875; assistant commissioner, June, 1874; cantonment magistrate, Secunderabad, Sept., 1881; services lent to H.H. the Nizam's government, and appointed judge of the suburban court, Hyderabad, Feb., 1884; inspector general of police to the Nizam's government, April, 1884; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, May, 1887; 2nd class, July, 1889.

LUFKIN, GEORGE, India Office.—Clerk to the clerk of the works, India office, 21st June, 1860; clerk of the works, Aug., 1874; surveyor and clerk of the works, April, 1882.

LUGARD, HENRY IBBETSON, Colonel, I.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Dec., 1853; was employed under the military department till 1864, also serving in the Madras police in 1857 and 1860-61; from Jan., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted as superintendent of the school of industry, Jubbulpore, May to Sept., 1869; cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, March, 1873; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1877.

LUKE, STEPHEN PAGET WALTER VYVYAN, C.I.E., M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as assistant superintendent, 16th Jan., 1863; arrived in India, 29th Feb., 1868, and served in Bengal, Madras, and N.W. Provinces; had charge of
field telegraph with Peshawur Valley force, Nov., 1878, and with Afghanistan force, Sept., 1879; appointed C.I.E.; superintendent, April, 1880; on special duty in director-general's office in connexion with field telegraphs, Jan., 1887; officiated as director, construction branch, in 1887 and 1888; has held charge of various divisions, including Madras, July, 1889; on special duty, Calcutta, Jan., 1890; director, construction branch, April, 1890; officiating deputy director-general of telegraphs, April, 1892.

LUMSDEN, JOHN JAMES FOOTE, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Gorakhpur, July, 1874; on special duty to Naini Tal, July-Sept., 1875; commissioner, Fyzabad division, Dec., 1879, and subsequently of the Benares division, and agent to the governor-general; senior member of board of revenue, Nov., 1889; member of the lieutenant-governor's legislative council, Jan., 1891; retired, Nov., 1891.

LUMSDEN, SIR PETER STARK, General, G.C.B., C.S.I., Council of India.—Ensign, Bengal army, Dec., 1847; assistant executive engineer, 1849; served with the force employed in various expeditions against the frontier tribes in 1852-6; deputy assistant quartermaster-general at the action of Punghao, 15th April, 1852; served in the expeditions against the Boree Afrereedees in 1853; against the Mohmund tribe in 1854; and the Meranzaie tribe in 1855; and in the Meranzaie and Kooran expeditions of Nov., 1856; on a special military mission to Afghanistan, 1857-1858 (medal and clasp); assistant quartermaster-general, Sept., 1858; accompanied China expedition in 1860; and present at actions of Sinho and Tangchow, assault and capture of Taku forts and advance on Pekin (medal, 2 clasps, and brevet of major); deputy quartermaster-general, April, 1863; with Bhootan field force in 1865 (clasp); quartermaster-general, May, 1868; officiating resident, Hyderabad, 1872; adjutant-general, Sept., 1874; chief of the staff, 1879; member of council of India, 1st Dec., 1883; Afghan boundary commissioner, Sept., 1884, to June, 1885.
