LUSHINGTON, EDWARD HARBORD, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1841; arrived in India, 2nd June, 1841; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate of Chittagong in 1847, and afterwards of Patna; deputy collector of government sea customs, Calcutta, 1855; collector, Nuddea, 1856; junior secretary, board of revenue, Lower Provinces, 1857; acting commissioner of the Burdwan, Manbboom, and Singbboom district, 1857-58; Mutiny medal; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Nuddea, 1861; secretary to government of Bengal, 1861; secretary to government of India in the financial department, government director of Bank of Bengal, and member of mint committee, 1863; retired, 1871.

LUSON, HEWLING, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Olave's, Southwark, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1884, and served as assistant magistrate and collector; officiating under secretary to government, judicial, &c., departments, Dec., 1890; confirmed, Oct., 1891; acting under-secretary to government of India, home department, April, 1892.

LUTTMAN-JOHNSON, HENRY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Winchester, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating private secretary to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, April, 1872; acting under secretary, government of Bengal, department of scarcity and relief, Oct., 1873, to Feb., 1874; transferred to Assam, Feb., 1874, as deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, and secretary to chief commissioner; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, July, 1879; judge and commissioner, Assam Valley districts, May, 1886.

LYALL, SIR ALFRED COMYN, K.C.B., K.C.I.E., D.C.L., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Central Provinces, April, 1864, and served as deputy commissioner, officiating secretary to chief commissioner, and officiating commissioner of the Nagpur division; transferred to Hyderabad assigned districts, July, 1867, and appointed commissioner, West Berar, Aug., 1867; secretary to the government of India, home department, March, 1873; from Nov., 1874, served in the foreign department of the government of India, and was appointed resident, 1st class, and agent to the governor-general in Rajputana, and chief commissioner of Ajmere; on special duty in England, Aug., 1876; secretary to government of India, foreign department, April, 1878; on special political duty in Kabul, March, 1880, and again in Sept., 1880; K.C.B., May, 1881; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, and chief commissioner of Oudh, 17th April, 1882; C.I.E., May, 1882; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887; retired, Dec., 1887; appointed member of the Council of India, 17th Jan., 1888; D.C.L. (Oxon.), 1889; author of 'Rajputana Gazetteer,' 'Berar Gazetteer,' 'Asiatic Studies,' 'Manual of the Law of the Hyderabad Assigned Districts,' 'Life of Warren Hastings,' 'Verses written in India,' and 'Natural Religion in India' (Rede Lecture for 1891).

LYALL, CHARLES JAMES, M.A., LL.D., C.I.E., Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College School, King's College, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiated at various times as under secretary to government, and as junior secretary, Oct., 1872; assistant under secretary to government of India, foreign department, April-June, 1872; from April, 1873, served under the government of India in the department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, and was appointed under secretary to govern-
ment, Sept., 1873, and was placed on special duty, Sept., 1878; transferred to Assam as officiating secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1880; officiating judge and commissioner, Assam Valley districts, 1883, and July, 1888; secretary to chief commissioner, Oct., 1883; officiating secretary to government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Feb.-Nov., 1886, and in the home department, Aug., 1889; on special duty to report on penal settlement, Port Blair, Dec., 1889; secretary to government of India, home department, Nov., 1890; author of article on 'Hindustani Literature' in Encyclopaedia Britannica, 1880; 'Sketch of the Hindustani language,' 1880; 'Translations of ancient Arabic Poetry,' 1885; and 'Guide to the transliteration of Hindu and Muhammadan names in the Bengal army,' 1885.

LYALL, DAVID ROBERT, C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 25th Sept., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; officiating commissioner, Dacca division, March, 1878, and Presidency division, Feb., 1882; inspector-general of police, March, 1883; officiating commissioner of Chittagong, Oct., 1884; confirmed, Aug., 1887; officiated as political officer with the Lushai expeditionary force in 1889; C.S.I., Jan., 1891; member of revenue board, May, 1892.

LYALL, SIR JAMES BROADWOOD, G.C.I.E., K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury in 1858; arrived, 8th April, 1858; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, and deputy commissioner; settlement commissioner, Mooltan and Derajat, March, 1874; financial commissioner, Punjab, Jan., 1879; resident in Mysore and chief commissioner of Coorg, Dec., 1883; also judicial commissioner of Coorg; graded in the political department as resident, 1st class; lieut.-governor of the Punjab, April, 1887 to Nov., 1892; K.C.S.I., June, 1888; G.C.I.E., May, 1892.

LYLE, HENRY WARD, LL.B., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Winchester, and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1887, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant commissioner; assistant magistrate and collector, July, 1891; joint magistrate, Oct., 1891; deputy superintendent, family domains of Maharaja of Benares, April-July, 1892.

LYNCH, SIDNEY S., late Medical Department, Bengal.—From 16th Nov., 1853, served in Assam as civil medical officer, and inspector of landing of native labourers, and from Jan., 1866, in Bengal, as superintendent, presidency jail; superintendent of the Alipore jail, and ex-officio deputy inspector-general of jails, Lower Provinces, Jan., 1871; officiating health officer, port of Calcutta, May, 1879; confirmed in this appointment, April, 1882; retired, 1889.

LYON, GEORGE KENNETH, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1877; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, Aug., 1885.

LYON, ISIDORE-BERNADOTTE, C.I.E., Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Col., M.R.C.S., L.S.A., F.I.C., late Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical service, 31st March, 1865; arrived in India, 1st March, 1866; acting professor of anatomy and curator of museum, Grant Medical College, March, 1866; professor of chemistry, Grant Medical College, and chemical analyser to government, Jan., 1867; in addition to these appointments was also third physician at the Sir Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital, July, 1867, to Oct., 1872, professor of medical jurisprudence, Grant Medical College, from July, 1868, and professor of chemistry at the Elphinstone College from Dec., 1875; on special duty conducting petroleum experiments, Oct.-Nov., 1882; brigade surgeon, Sept., 1887; acting principal, Grant Medical College, June to Dec., 1888; C.I.E., May, 1889; retired, April, 1892.

LYON, PERCY COMYN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's School, Bruton, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 1st Jan., 1884; served in Assam as assistant commissioner and personal assistant to the chief commissioner; officiated as private secretary to lieutenant-governor of Bengal, Dec., 1888, and again in 1890; under secretary to government of Bengal, judicial, political and appointment departments, June, 1890; officiating under secretary to the government of India, revenue and agricultural department, April, 1891; assistant settlement officer, Cuttack, Nov., 1891; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Dec., 1891.

LYTTELTON, HON. NEVILLE GERALD, Col., Rifle Brigade.—1st commission, ensign, Rifle Brigade, 17th Jan., 1865; Major, Feb., 1882; Col. (army), Nov., 1886; A.D.C. to lord lieutenant of Ireland, Jan., 1869, to Oct., 1873; served in the Jowaki expedition of 1877 (medal with clasp); private secretary to secretary of state for war, April, 1880, to Aug., 1882; A.D.C. to chief of staff expeditionary force, Egypt, Aug.-Oct., 1882, including battle of Tel-el-Kebir (medal with clasp, bronze star, brevet lieutenant-colonel, 4th class Osmanieh); assistant military secretary to governor of Gibraltar, Jan., 1883, to March, 1885; military secretary on personal staff of governor of Bombay, 31st March, 1885, to 11th April, 1890.

MACAULIFFE, MICHAEL, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Newcastle School (Limerick), Springfield College, and Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 9th Feb., 1864, and served as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Dec., 1882; divisional judge, Nov., 1884; author of 'Life of Baba Nanak,' and of articles on the Sikh religion in the 'Calcutta Review,' 1889-91.

MACAUSLAND, REDMOND CONYNGHAM SAMUEL, Captain, I.S.C., Judicial Department, Punjab.—Lieutenant, 13th Nov., 1872; arrived in India, 9th March, 1873, and served in the military department, and in the Punjab as cantonment magistrate; 1st class cantonment magistrate, Dec., 1887.
MACCARTIE, CHARLES FALKINER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Manchester Grammar School, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1870, and served in Bombay till Nov., 1872, and subsequently in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting principal assistant, additional sessions judge, and acting collector, magistrate, and agent, and was placed on special settlement duty, Nov., 1882; transferred permanently to the Madras civil service, Jan., 1882; officiating postmaster-general, Madras, April-Dec., 1883; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants, May, 1884; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1884; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Chingleput, Feb., 1885; acting secretary, board of revenue, Dec., 1885, to May, 1886; collector and magistrate, Jan., 1886; private secretary to governor of Madras, Dec., 1891.

MACCARTIE, FREDERICK FITZGERALD, Surgeon-Major, M.B., B.Ch. (Dub.), Bombay Medical Service.—Joined the service, 30th March, 1878, and arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1878; served on general military and jail duty and as deputy sanitary commissioner; appointed health officer of port of Bombay, June, 1884; served under the government of India in the finance department as assay probationer in Bombay in 1886 and 1889; reverted to his appointment as health officer, Jan., 1890; surgeon-major, March, 1890; acting deputy assay master, Bombay mint, April, 1891 to May, 1892.

MACDONALD, DENIS PETER, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Port Blair Administration.—Joined the service, 1st April, 1873, and officiated as medical officer with various regiments; on special duty in Egypt, Aug.-Nov., 1883; medical officer, 11th Bengal Lancers, Nov., 1883; and Gurkhas, July, 1887; served with the field hospital, Lushai expedition, Nov., 1889; senior medical officer, Port Blair, July, 1890.

MACDONALD, DONALD, Colonel, I.S.C., late Survey of India.—First commission, Bengal infantry, Oct., 1853; arrived in India, Dec., 1853; appointed to the survey department, revenue branch, Dec., 1860; revenue surveyor, Jan., 1865; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1866; promoted to 2nd grade, Jan., 1878, and 1st grade, Jan., 1887; in charge of the N.W. frontier survey, 1879-1884; officiating assistant surveyor-general, March, 1886; confirmed, Sept., 1887; reverted to military duty, 1890.

MACDONALD, ROBERT GRAHAM, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Served in the subordinate accounts establishment, Oct., 1863, to Dec., 1867; examiner of railway accounts, Oudh, Dec., 1867; auditor, Oudh and Rohilkhand railway accounts, Jan., 1870; examiner, railway accounts, Madras, 1875; W. Rajputana railway, 1876; assistant accountant-general, Calcutta, Jan., 1878; examiner of accounts, Punjab, 1881; N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1882; examiner of military works accounts, 1883; inspector of public works accounts, 1884; officiated as deputy accountant general, and under secretary to government, Nov., 1885, to Feb., 1886, and April, 1886, to March, 1887, and again May, 1887; examiner, and class, in the accounts establishment, May, 1886; examiner, 1st class, Oct., 1889; officiating accountant-general, public works department, and deputy secretary to government of India, accounts branch, May, 1888, and April, 1890; deputy accountant-general and under-secretary, Sept., 1888; president of public works accounts committee, Oct., 1888; and of the railway accounts committee, Oct., 1890; officiating accountant-general, public works department, and deputy secretary to government of India, Sept., 1891.

MACDONNELL, SIR ANTONY PATRICK, M.A., K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 3rd Nov., 1865; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1866; on special duty in the Bengal secretariat, May, 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1874; officiating magistrate and collector, 1875; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, May, 1881, and again, Jan.-April, 1882; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, Sept., 1881, and again, April, 1882; confirmed as secretary, government of Bengal, revenue and general departments, July, 1884; lieutenant-governor's council, Nov., 1884; officiating secretary, government of India, home department, March, 1886; confirmed in this appointment, March, 1887; C.S.I., June, 1888; officiating chief commissioner, Burma, Sept., 1889; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Nov., 1890; K.C.S.I., Jan., 1893.

MACDOUGALL, JAMES WILLIAM, Colonel, I.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, June, 1858; arrived in India, 24th Sept., 1858; from Feb., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; acted at various times as cantonment magistrate of Kamptee, and as small cause court judge of Nagpur, April, 1871, to March, 1873; held charge of the model farm, Nagpur, in addition to other duties, 1873-79; deputy commissioner, June, 1880.

MACE, F. L., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Second class clerk, 1st Sept., 1891.

MACEWEN, ROBERT SUTHERLAND TAYLOR, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal Judicial Department.—Sub-assistant commissioner, Sonthal commission, Sept., 1862; officiating assistant commissioner, May, 1863; clerk of the Calcutta court of small causes, July, 1866; served from Dec., 1870, as judge, Calcutta court of small causes, and was promoted to 2nd judge, Oct., 1884; served temporarily as recorder of Rangoon on various occasions; published 'The Practice of the Presidency Courts of Small Causes under Act XV. of 1882,' 1883.

MACFARLAN, JOHN, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury, 1857; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1857, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, Satara, till 1860; deputy collector and magistrate, in Sind, 1860-61; second assistant collector and magistrate at Poona and Dharwar, 1862 to 1864; acting collector and magistrate, Kanara, April, 1866; first assistant collector and magistrate, Nasik, July, 1866; acted as postmaster-general, Bombay, 1870-72, and from Feb., 1873, and was appointed postmaster-general, Madras, in 1875; officiating postmaster-general, Bengal, April, 1877, to Dec., 1878; retired, Dec., 1878.

MACGEORGE, HENRY JOHN, late Central Pro-
vices Commission.—Joined the service as deputy superintendent of Jhansi, 10th June, 1854; deputy collector, Betul, Nov., 1856; assistant commissioner, Wardha, Dec., 1860; in charge of settlement duties, Wardha and Chanda, Dec., 1862, to April, 1863; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1877; retired, 1890.

MACGREGOR, JAMES LISTER LAIRD, Forest Department, Bombay.—Joined the service, 1st Dec., 1871; arrived, 16th Jan., 1872, and served as assistant conservator and deputy conservator of forests; conservator, 3rd grade, Dec., 1886; 2nd grade, May, 1891; 3rd grade (new scale), April, 1892.

MACIVOR, IVAR, Captain, I.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Sub-lieutenant, 18th Hussars, Oct., 1872; arrived in India, March, 1873; 1st regiment, Central India Horse, Aug., 1877; assistant to governor-general's agent, Central India, Oct., 1878; assistant to political resident, Persian Gulf, Feb., 1880; 1st assistant to governor-general's agent, Baluchistan, Jan., 1885; political agent, Zhob, Jan., 1890.

MACKAY, DUNCAN LACHLAN MACPHERSON, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Madras College, and University, St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1875, and was appointed assistant commissioner at Jubulpore; transferred to Burma, July, 1876; 1st grade assistant commissioner, Aug., 1886; cantonment magistrate, Rangoon, May, 1888; officiating deputy commissioner, May, 1892.

MACKENZIE, SIR ALEXANDER, B.A., K.C.S.I., Bengal C.S.—Educated at King Edward VI.'s Grammar School, Birmingham, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 11th Dec., 1862; assistant magistrate and collector, Shahabad, Sept., 1863; from Feb., 1866, to Dec., 1873, served as under secretary, junior secretary, and officiating secretary to government of Bengal; on famine duty, Dec., 1873; officiating secretary, board of revenue, Nov., 1875, and again in 1877; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Moorshedabad, July, 1876; also in charge of office of agent to governor-general; junior secretary, board of revenue, May, 1877; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, general and revenue departments, July, 1877; secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, Oct., 1877; lieutenant-governor's council, Jan., 1879; secretary, government of India, home department, April, 1882; C.S.I., May, 1886; chief commissioner of Central Provinces, March, 1887, and of Burma, Dec., 1890; K.C.S.I., Jan., 1891; author of 'History of the Relations of the Government with the Hill Tribes of the N.E. Frontier of Bengal.'

MACKENZIE, GORDON THOMSON, Madras C.S.—Educated at King William's College, Isle of Man, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1869, and served in various districts of Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; assistant commissioner, Nilgiris, Aug., 1881; acting collector and magistrate, Kistna, Sept., 1881; head assistant collector, Nilgiris, Feb., 1882; acting registrar, high court, July, 1883; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1883, and acting secretary, Nov., 1884; president of the municipal commission, Jan., 1885; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Nov., 1886; acting district and sessions judge, Kistna, Nov., 1887; confirmed Oct., 1888; compiled district manual of Kistna.

MACKENZIE, KENNETH JAMES LOCH, Colonel, C.I.E., I.S.C., Berar Administration.—Joined Madras artillery from Addiscombe, 11th June, 1858; from April, 1862, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts, as assistant commissioner, assistant conservator of forests, and deputy commissioner; judicial commissioner, July, 1889; commissioner, March, 1892; C.I.E., Jan., 1893.

MACKENZIE, STEPHEN COULL, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon-Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1866; served from 15th Oct., 1869, as professor of hygiene, Calcutta Medical College, also officiating as assistant surgeon at the Presidency General Hospital; superintendent, presidency jail, in addition to his own duties, Jan., 1871; junior surgeon, Presidency General Hospital, Dec., 1873; officiating health officer, port of Calcutta, Feb., 1877; superintendent of Campbell Medical School and Hospital, Sealdah, professor of medical jurisprudence, Calcutta Medical College, and police surgeon, Calcutta, Jan., 1878; also appointed, in addition to his other duties, superintendent of lock hospitals in Calcutta and its suburbs, Nov., 1879, and coroner's surgeon.

MACKENZIE, THOMAS DUNCAN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served in the Bombay presidency as assistant collector and magistrate; secretary, Baroda Inquiry commission, Nov., 1873; from Nov., 1875, acted as under secretary to government in the revenue, financial, and general departments, and was confirmed in this appointment, Nov., 1877; member of civil and military examination committee, April-Oct., 1879; from Nov., 1879, served as acting collector and magistrate, and was placed on special duty at Baroda, March-Aug., 1880, in connection with the settlement of the affairs of Mir Zulfikar Ali; acting junior collector of salt revenue, Bombay, Nov., 1882; junior collector and magistrate, Broach, May, 1884; collector, magistrate and political agent, Khandeish, Feb., 1886; acted as chief secretary to government of Bombay for various periods from May, 1886; commissioner, Southern Division, May, 1886; chief secretary to government, revenue, financial and general department, May, 1891.

MACKENZIE, SIR WILLIAM, Inspector-General of Hospitals, M.D., K.C.B., C.S.I., late Madras Medical Service.—A.M. of King's College, Aberdeen, 1830; M.R.C.S., London, 1832; M.D., University of Aberdeen, 1836; assistant surgeon in the Madras medical service, 1835; served with the 8th light cavalry, Madras, 1837-1839, and with the army of His Highness the Nizam of Hyderabad, 1839-1862; was superintendent of the Bolaram Medical School, 1842-44; served with the Ellicott field force; against the insurgent Rohillas in 1841, and again in Nov., 1851, with the cavalry field force, under Brigadier W. Mayne; staff-surgeon with the Central India field force, 1857-58, and with the Berar field force, Nov., 1858, to March, 1859,
and was present at numerous engagements; deputy inspector-general of hospitals, Mysore Division, March, 1863; inspector-general, Aug., 1866; inspector-general and head of the medical department, March, 1867; retired, Aug., 1871; appointed honorary physician to the Queen, July, 1867; author of a treatise on the medical topography of Ellickpoor, and papers on the Indian Materia Medica, and has translated into Hindustani, 'Gregory's Practice of Physic,' and 'Thomson's Conspectus of the British Pharmacopoeia.'

MACKIE, ANDREW WALLACE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Universities of Edinburgh and St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, March, 1874; and again, in Nellore, March, 1877; assistant to director-general of statistics, Feb., 1875; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Oct., 1884; transferred temporarily to the Punjab, July, 1889; district and sessions judge, Feb., 1890.

MACKINTOSH, H. D., Store Department, India Office.—Writer, 27th June, 1874; clerk specially attached, 25th Sept., 1892.

MACKINTOSH, JAMES SIMON, M.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Royal Academy, Inverness, Edinburgh University, and Oriel College, Oxford; called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant secretary, and officiating under secretary to government; private secretary to the lieutenant-governor, Feb.-April, 1874; officiating secretary to government, N.W. Provinces, Aug.-Nov., 1875; junior secretary to government, July, 1876; secretary, board of revenue, Aug., 1877; magistrate and collector, Jan., 1886.

MACLAGAN, EDWARD DOUGLAS, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Winchester and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1886, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiated as under secretary to government of Punjab in 1888, 1889, and 1890; superintendent of census operations in the Punjab, April, 1890.

MACLEAN, CHARLES SMITH, C.B., C.I.E., Major-General, I.S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, 14th Dec., 1853; served in the Indian mutiny, 1857, China war, 1860, Afghan war, 1878-80, and Mashud-Waziri expedition, 1881; consul-general at Meshed, March, 1880; agent to governor-general, and consul-general for Khorassan and Seistan, Nov., 1889; returned to Europe, Dec., 1891.

MACLEAN, FREDERICK GURR, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the department as assistant superintendent, 1st Sept., 1868; studied submarine telegraphy in England for four months; arrived in India, Feb., 1869; held charge of various sub-divisions, and of construction of line on Kandahar state railway, 1879; held charge of various divisions, and was graded class iv., grade 3, Oct., 1887, and grade 2, April, 1890; personal assistant to director of telegraphs, April, 1890; in charge, Sind and Baluchistan division, Feb., 1892.

MACLEANE, CHARLES DONALD, Mus. Doc., M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Bath Grammar School, Shrewsbury Grammar School, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived, 19th Dec., 1865; acting inspector of schools, Oct., 1866; assistant collector, Dec., 1867; acting cantonment magistrate, Sept., 1868; acted for various periods as under secretary to government of Madras, and sub-secretary to the board of revenue; on special duty in preparing annual administration report, Nov., 1876, and again, Sept., 1878; on special duty revising standing orders of the board of revenue, Oct., 1877; and again in June, 1886; under secretary to government in chief secretary's department, July, 1880; fellow of the University of Madras, March, 1881; Canarese translator to government, April, 1881; member of board of examiners, Jan., 1882; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1883; on special duty at Madras in connection with preparation of 'Manual of Administration,' Nov., 1883, and again, Aug., 1884 and 1886; sub-secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1884; acting collector of sea customs, Madras, and protector of emigrants, Feb., 1884; on special duty as president of the committee on Muhamadan Educational Endowment, Aug., 1885; Tamil translator to government, Sept., 1885; collector and magistrate, Anantapur, Feb., 1886; on special duty in the general record department, Feb., 1886, and also to collect information for the finance committee, June, 1886; collector and magistrate, Nellore, March, 1888.

MACLEOD, BANNATYNE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Collegiate School, Edinburgh University, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector, and forest settlement officer; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Jan., 1889.

MACLEOD, DONALD GRANT, M.A., LL.D., B.L., Judicial Department, Burma.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge, and Inner Temple; judge of the court of small causes, Rangoon, Sept., 1869; judge of Moulmein, March, 1876.

MACLEOD, RODERICK, M.D., Bengal Medical Service.—House physician, Medical College Hospital, Calcutta, 24th June, 1865; served as medical officer at several stations, and was appointed health officer of the port of Calcutta, Oct., 1889; in addition officiated as protector of emigrants and superintendent of emigration, Jan., 1891; and was appointed to that post, March, 1892.

MACLEOD, RODERICK HENRY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College, London, and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating cantonment magistrate, and district and sessions judge; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Dec., 1886, and 1st grade, Feb., 1890;
assistant commissioner, 1st grade, July, 1889; judge, small cause court, Allahabad, April, 1891; district and sessions judge, May, 1891.

MACMILLAN, MICHAEL, B.A., Bombay Educational Department.—Joined the service, 12th June, 1878, as professor of logic and moral philosophy, Elphinstone College; was also lecturer in these subjects at Deccan College, June-Dec., 1882; promoted to 3rd grade of the department, Nov., 1890; professor of English literature, Elphinstone College, April, 1892.

MACMULLEN, GEORGE READE, Captain, I.S.C., Police Department, Burma.—First commission, 11th Sept., 1876; served in the Burmese war, 1887-88 (medal and clasp), and Miranzai expedition, 1891; appointed deputy inspector-general of military police, Burma, March, 1892.

MACNABB, SIR DONALD C., K.C.I.E., C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury in 1853; served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Peshawur, 1865; commissioner, Hisar division, 1872, and subsequently in the Lahore, Rawal Pindi, and Peshawur divisions; retired, 1881; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887.

MACNABB, JAMES WILLIAM, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1852, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and was promoted to deputy commissioner, Aug., 1861; commissioner and superintendent, Umballa, Nov., 1875, and afterwards in the Hissar and Delhi divisions; retired, March, 1886.

MACNAGHTEN, CHESTER, M.A., Bombay Educational Department.—From July, 1866, to Dec., 1870, held the appointment of tutor to the minor Maharajah of Durbhunga under the court of wards, Bengal; joined the Bombay educational service, 19th Dec., 1870, and served from that date as principal of the Rajkumar College, Kathiawar.

MACONACHIE, GEORGE ARCHIBALD, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, M.D., C.M., Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867; was employed under the military department till Jan., 1872, including service in the Abyssinian campaign (medal), and subsequently as ophthalmic surgeon and professor of ophthalmic medicine and surgery and comparative anatomy at the Grant Medical College, Bombay; also presidency surgeon from June, 1880; acted as principal, Grant Medical College, in 1881, and from April, 1892.

MACONACHIE, JAMES ROBERT, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and London University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 9th Jan., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating judicial assistant; officiating settlement secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1880; officiating postmaster-general, Punjab, July, 1884; on special duty under the government of India, foreign department, Sept.-Oct., 1885; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1887; author of 'Agricultural Proverbs of the Punjab,' and a report on the settlement of the Delhi District.

MACONOCHIE, ALEXANDER FRANCIS, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Westminster, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883; acting joint administrator, Rajpipla, Oct., 1886, and again in 1890; survey and settlement superintendent, Baroda.

MACONOCHIE, EVAN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Sherborne School, and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1889, and served as assistant magistrate and collector; acted as administrator, Sachin State, Dec., 1890, and again in May, 1891.

MACPHERSON, ANDREW KENNEDY, Lieut.-Colonel, I.S.C.—First commission, 10th Dec., 1865; arrived in India, 6th March, 1866; from April, 1871, served as cantonment magistrate at various stations in the Punjab, and was promoted to the 1st class, Dec., 1879; officiating in the judge advocate-general's department, May, 1886, to March, 1888; employed under government of India, home department, in 1891, and again from April, 1892.

MACPHERSON, SIR ARTHUR GEORGE, K.C.I.E., Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at the University and King's College, Aberdeen, and University of Edinburgh; called to the bar, Inner Temple, 1852; 1st judge of Calcutta small cause court, 1859; secretary to the government of Bengal, legislative department, 1862; officiating deputy secretary to the government of India in the home department (legislative), 1863, and appointed assistant secretary, Oct., 1864; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1865; acted as chief justice, 13th Feb. to 25th June, 1875; retired, 1877; legal adviser to the secretary of state, Nov., 1879; secretary in the judicial and public department, India Office, Feb., 1882; K.C.I.E., Jan., 1889.

MACPHERSON, CHARLES GORDON WELAND, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 30th Dec., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and superintendent of police; supernumerary under secretary to government of Bombay in the public works department for relief purposes, Nov., 1876; on famine relief duty in Madras, as secretary to personal assistant to the governor, Sept., 1877, to Jan., 1879; from April, 1879, acted as under secretary to government of Bombay, political and judicial departments, and secretary to the governor's council for making laws and regulations, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1881; acting private secretary to governor of Bombay, Dec., 1880, to March, 1881; acted as secretary to government, political, secret, judicial, and educational departments, in 1884 and 1885; acting special judge under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act, April-July, 1885, and again in 1886; 3rd grade judge and sessions judge, Shikarpur, Nov., 1885; on special duty in the political department of the secretariat, Dec., 1885; 2nd grade judge, May, 1887.

MACPHHERSON, DUNCAN JAMES, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at the High School and University, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1878; served in revenue and judicial departments,
Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Sept., 1888; on special duty under board of revenue, 1882-85.

MACPHERSON, GEORGE MORISON, M.A., LL.D., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, small cause court judge, and judge and sessions judge in various districts; 1st grade judge, Oct., 1880; judicial commissioner in Sind, Jan., 1885; also judge of the sadar court, Oct., 1887; acted as commissioner in 1886.

MACPHERSON, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Gymnasium, Old Aberdeen, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty under board of revenue, July, 1875; joint magistrate, May, 1884; superintendent of Dehra Dun, Aug., 1886; deputy commissioner, July, 1890; magistrate and collector, April, 1891.

MACPHERSON, JOHN MOLESWORTH, B.L., Legislative Department, Government of India.—Educated at Westminster School; advocate of the high court, Calcutta; served from Dec., 1877, as deputy secretary to the government of India in the legislative department; officiated as secretary from Oct., 1887, to Jan., 1888, and again in 1889; editor of 7th edition of 'Macpherson's Law of Mortgage in British India,' and compiler of 'Lists of British Enactments in force in Native States.'

MACPHERSON, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1856; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating civil and sessions judge; magistrate and collector, Nov., 1866; district and sessions judge, Dec., 1874; judge of the high court of judicature, Calcutta, 10th Jan., 1885.

MACPHERSON, WILLIAM CHARLES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1877; assistant magistrate and collector, Patna, Dec., 1877; transferred to Assam, July, 1878, and served as assistant commissioner, assistant secretary and officiating secretary to chief commissioner, and officiating inspector of schools; transferred to Bengal, Oct., 1884; under secretary to government of Bengal, Nov., 1885; officiating under secretary to government of India, revenue and agricultural department, Jan., 1888, and home department, April, 1888; joint magistrate and deputy collector, May, 1888; officiating director of land records and agriculture, Bengal, May, 1892; author of 'An Aid to Revenue and Magisterial Duties in Bengal.'

MACRAE, JOHN KENNETH, Burma Commission.—Joined the Burma commission as officiating assistant commissioner, 20th July, 1860; registrar to the court of the recorder, and judge of the court of small causes, Moulmein, May, 1864; deputy commissioner, July, 1869; town magistrate, Akyab, Nov., 1874; boundary officer, Nov., 1880; 1st grade, deputy commissioner, Sept., 1883; president, Akyab municipal committee, Jan., 1885; acted as commissioner of Arakan, Nov.-Dec., 1885; of the Irrawaddy division, Feb.-April, 1887.

MACRURY, COLIN WILLIAM, Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Bombay Sanitary Department.—Joined the service, 1st April, 1869; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1869; on general duty in Sind, deputy sanitary commissioner, Feb., 1878; deputy superintendent of census in Sind, 1881; surgeon-major, April, 1881; sanitary commissioner to the government of Bombay, May, 1888.

MADDEN, JOHN MELLISH, Colonel, Bombay Infantry.—Ensign, Bombay army, Sept., 1859; employed on military duty, including service in Abyssinia in 1868, up to 1876; served subsequently as assistant cantonment magistrate, Poona; appointed cantonment magistrate, Ahmadabad, January, 1880; colonel, Sept., 1889; reverted to military department, 1892.

MADDOX, STUART LOCKWOOD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Worcester College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1888, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

MAGRATH, HENRY MARSH SEPTIMUS, Colonel, I.S.C., Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, 5th April, 1858; officiated as magistrate and president of the municipal commission, Bangalore, May, 1884, to March, 1885; district magistrate and president municipal commission, Bangalore, Feb., 1887; acted as civil and sessions judge in 1887.

MAGUIRE, HUGH FITZJOHN TYREL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1878; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and deputy collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Jan., 1889; officiated as political agent and assistant secretary to the government of India, foreign department, Feb., 1889; on special duty in connection with census work, in Calcutta, Nov., 1890.

MAHADEV GOVIND RANADE, RAO BAHAADUR, C.I.E., M.A., LL.B., Judicial Department, Bombay.—Served from 28th May, 1866, in the educational department, and was appointed assistant professor of English literature at the Elphinstone College, Bombay, Oct., 1868; also served in the judicial department as assistant reporter to the high court, Bombay, acting magistrate of police, acting small cause court judge, and subordinate judge (June, 1872); acting presidency magistrate, Bombay, Jan.-March, 1881; appointed under the Deccan Agriculturists' Relief Act to inspect and supervise the lower courts in districts of Poona and Satara, Aug., 1881; judge of the court of small causes, Poona, Feb., 1884, and was in charge of duties of law lecturer, Deccan College, Jan.-April, 1885; member of a committee on public expenditure; C.I.E., Feb., 1887; confirmed as
special judge under Deccan Agriculturists Relief Act, May, 1887.

MAHESH CHANDRA NYAYARATNA, MA-HAMAHOPADHYAYA, C.I.E., Bengal Education Department.—Served in the education department from 10th January, 1864, as assistant professor, and professor in the Sanskrit College, Calcutta, and was appointed principal, May, 1885; 3rd class of the education department, March, 1884; author of 'Tulsi Mimansa,' 'Loopta Sambatsara,' &c.

MAITLAND, JOHN, Surgeon-Major, M.B., M.C. (Edinburgh), Madras Medical Department.—Joined the service 31st March, 1876; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1876, and served on civil, military, and famine duty; 2nd surgeon, general hospital, Madras, Feb., 1882; professor of materia medica and pharmacy, Medical College, April, 1882; surgeon-major, March, 1883; surgeon to the governor of Madras, March, 1889; civil surgeon, Coconada, Jan., 1891; senior medical officer, Ootacamund, April, 1891.

MAITLAND, WILLIAM J., C.I.E., India Office.—Educated at the Edinburgh Academy, and abroad; temporary clerk, 3rd Nov., 1866; junior clerk, July, 1867; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1878; private secretary to the secretary of state (Viscount Cross), August, 1886; C.I.E., Feb., 1887; deputy government director of Indian guaranteed railways, June, 1892.

MALLETT, FREDERICK RICHARD, F.G.S., F.C.S., late Geological Survey of India.—Appointed from England as assistant in the geological survey, and joined, 12th Feb., 1859; was employed in various districts of Bengal, Central India, the Central Provinces, Assam, Sikkim, and Bhutan; keeper of the mineral collections in the museum, Oct., 1875; 1st grade officer, Jan., 1883; deputy superintendent, April, 1883; designation changed to superintendent of survey; author of contributions to the survey publications; retired, 1889.

MALLETT, ROBERT TREFUSIS, late Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the Bombay public works department, Jan., 1868; executive engineer on the Punjab northern state railway, Nov., 1868; superintendent of works, Ravee section, April, 1873; temporary superintending engineer, Indus Valley railway, Jan., 1877; engineer-in-chief, Indus Valley railway, April, 1879; director of stores, railway branch, Oct., 1880; engineer-in-chief, Rewari Ferozepur railway, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer, 1st class, Jan., 1883; engineer-in-chief, Ferozepur bridge, in 1885; transferred to North-Western railway as chief engineer, Jan., 1886; chief engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1885; engineer-in-chief, Chenab bridge project, May, 1887; temporarily held office of director-general of railways, Aug., 1887; officiating consulting engineer, Sept., 1887; chief engineer, 2nd class, March, 1889; retired, March, 1892.

MALLOCK, HENRY ARCHIBALD, Colonel, I.S.C., late Indian Telegraph Department.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, Dec., 1853; joined the telegraph department, Jan., 1861; superintendent, 1st grade, and storekeeper, Dec., 1866; director of construction, April, 1868; deputy director-general, June, 1883; officiating director-general, Nov., 1886, to Feb., 1887, and March, 1888; reverted to military department, 1889.

MALTBY, EDWARD PENNYCUICK, Lieut.-Col., late Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Jan., 1861; arrived in India, 7th Feb., 1861; served in civil employ in the Mysore commission from Jan., 1864; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1877; small cause court judge, and town and cantonment magistrate, Bangalore, March, 1879; district magistrate and collector, and president, municipal commission, in the civil and military station of Bangalore from March, 1881; retired, Jan., 1887.

MAN, EDWARD HORACE, C.I.E., Port Blair Administration.—Joined the service as assistant superintendent, 3rd Nov., 1869; was in charge of Nicobar Islands in 1871 and 1874, and from 1883 to 1888; officiated for various periods as deputy superintendent, and was appointed 1st assistant superintendent, Jan., 1888; deputy superintendent, April, 1891; C.I.E., Jan., 1893; joint author of a work on the South Andaman language; has also published a monograph on 'The Aboriginal inhabitants of the Andaman Islands,' and a 'Grammar and Dictionary of the Central Nicobarese Language.'

MANCE, SIR HENRY CHRISTOPHER, C.I.E., late Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed to the Indo-European telegraph department, July, 1863; superintendent, Kurrachee, Persian Gulf section, Sept., 1866; engineer and electrician, Sept., 1879; C.I.E., Jan., 1883; retired, 1886.

MANCHERJI PESTANJI KHAREGHAT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Xavier's College, Calcutta, University College, London, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1884; assistant collector, March, 1885; acting assistant judge and sessions judge, July, 1888; 2nd assistant, Nov., 1891.

MANDER, ALFRED THOMAS, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Bombay.—Joined Addiscombe, Feb., 1854; 2nd lieutenant, Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1857; served in the Bombay public works department, from March, 1858, as assistant and executive engineer; superintending engineer, Nov., 1866; retired, Sept., 1889.

MANDERSON, THOMAS CLARIDGE, Colonel, R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Aug., 1858; joined the public works department, July, 1860, as assistant engineer, N.W. Provinces; executive engineer, Punjab, April, 1866; transferred to military works, 1872; served in the Rawal Pindi, Meerut, and Lahore commands, and was promoted to superintending engineer, 2nd class, March, 1886; officiating inspector general, military works, April-Nov., 1886; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1890.

MANISTY, GEORGE ELDON, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Ruabon Grammar School, Marlborough College, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 6th Dec., 1873; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1884; magistrate and collector, July, 1890.

MANN, GUSTAV, late Forest Department, Assam.—Assistant in government cinchona plantations, Darjeeling, Nov., 1863; assistant
conservator of forests, Bengal, Dec., 1864; from Nov., 1868, served in the Assam forest department, and was promoted to conservator, 3rd grade, Sept., 1882; 2nd grade, Jan., 1888; retired, May, 1891.

MANN, JOHN, M.A., Education Department, Bengal.—Joined the service, 21st Oct., 1878, as professor, Presidency college; professor, Hooghly college, Jan., 1879; principal, Krishnagur college, Jan., 1883; professor, Presidency college, March, 1888; professor, Hooghly college, June, 1889.

MANNERS-SMITH, JOHN, V.C., Lieutenant, I.S.C., Foreign Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 10th March, 1883, and served under the military department until Nov., 1887, when he was appointed attaché in the foreign department; on special duty to Sikkim, in connection with the negotiations with the Chinese Amban, Nov., 1888; assistant to the officer on special duty at Gilgit, June, 1889.

MANSER, ROBERT, Surgeon-Major, Bombay Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1st Oct., 1877; served in the military department, and on civil and jail duty; from May, 1882, served in the European General Hospital as assistant surgeon, and professor of materia medica in the Grant Medical College; professor of pathology and curator of museum of that college, April, 1887; second physician of Jamsetji Jijibhoy Hospital and professor of medicine and therapeutics, Nov., 1888; first physician, Nov., 1889.

MANSFIELD, SAMUEL, C.S.I., late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service in 1834; served as assistant collector and magistrate in various districts, and was appointed political agent, Rewa Kantha, 1847; collector and magistrate, Kandeish, 1852; revenue commissioner, northern division, 1859; commissioner, Sind, 1862; member of council, Bombay, 14th May, 1867; retired in 1872.

MANSON, ALEXANDER, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Highgate Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1863; arrived, 12th Nov., 1864; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating district and sessions judge, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Aug., 1885; also served as second inspector of registration offices, Aug., 1876; officiating commissioner, Chittagong division, Nov., 1885, and July, 1886; retired, July, 1889.

MARDOCK, EVELYN JOHN, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Clifton College, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. provinces as assistant commissioner.

MARETT, JAMES RICHARD, Colonel, I.S.C., Oudh Commission.—First commission, ensign 2nd Grenadiers, 4th Feb., 1858; served during the Jynteah and Kassia rebellion in 1862-63, and captured the Kassia rebel chief; also during the Bhutan campaign, 1865 (medal and clasp); from July, 1867, served under foreign department of government of India; assistant commissioner, Oudh, July, 1867; sub-judge, 2nd grade, Aug., 1879; and 1st grade, Dec., 1881; officiated for various periods as district judge, deputy commissioner, and judge of the small cause court, and was confirmed as district judge, March, 1887.

MARINDIN, CHARLES RANDAL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; famine relief duty, Tirhoot, Feb., 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Nov., 1884; magistrate and collector, April, 1889.

MARKBY, SIR W., K.C.I.E., late Judge of the High Court, Calcutta.—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; doctor of civil law, fellow of All Souls College, fellow of Balliol College; recorder of Buckingham, 1864-66; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1866 to 1878; vice-chancellor of the university of Calcutta, 1877-78; K.C.I.E., Jan., 1889; justice of the peace for county of Oxford; author of 'Elements of Law' (Clarendon Press, Oxford).

MARKHAM, ALEXANDER MACAULAY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Down and Connor Diocesan School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1862; from Jan., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating postmaster-general, officiating cantonment magistrate, settlement officer, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Allahabad, Nov., 1880; member of committee for considering revised rules for Patwaris and Kanungos, Nov., 1880; member of grass supply committee under military department of government of India, Oct., 1881; officiating commissioner, Rae Bareli division, March to July, 1882; and of Jhansi division, May to Sept., 1887; district and sessions judge, April, 1889.

MARKHAM, CLEMENTS ROBERT, C.B., F.R.S.—Educated at Westminster School; appointed a naval cadet, 28th July, 1844; midshipman, July, 1846, and passed for lieutenant, R.N., Dec., 1851; served in the Arctic expedition in search of Sir John Franklin, 1850-57; explored Peru and the forests of the Eastern Andes, 1852-54; from July, 1854, served as clerk under the India board of control, and on the transfer of the government of India to the crown, in 1858, was appointed a clerk in the correspondence department of the India office; private secretary to the parliamentary under-secretary of state (Mr. T. G. Baring), 1862 to 1864; assistant secretary in the public works department, 1867-71, and in the judicial, public, and revenue department, from 1871 to 1877, when he retired from the service; appointed C.B. (civil), May, 1871; was employed in introducing chinchona cultivation into India, 1859-66, and visited India and Ceylon; geographer to the Abyssinian expedition, 1866-67, and was present at the storming of Magdala; secretary to the Hakluyt Society, 1858 to 1866; secretary to the Royal Geographical Society, 1863 to 1887; in 1874 was created by the King of Portugal a commendador of the order of Christ; and by the Emperor of Brazil a chevalier of the order of the Rose; author of 'Franklin's Footsteps,' 1853; 'Cuzco and Lima,' 1855; 'Travels in Peru and India,' 1862; 'Quichua Grammar and Dictionary,'
1863; 'Threshold of the Unknown Region,' 1874; 'History of the Abyssinian Expedition,' 1869; 'Life of Lord Fairfax;' 'Life of Admiral Fairfax;' 'A Naval Career in the Olden Time;' 'History of Persia,' 1873; 'History of the War between Peru and Chili;' 'Peru,' 1880; 'The Sea Fathers;' 'Irrigation in Eastern Spain,' 1867; 'Memoir on the Indian Surveys,' 1871; 'Life of the Countess of Chinchon;' 'Peruvian Bark;' and 'Missions to Thibet,' 1877; has also translated and edited various works, including 'Embassy of Clavijo to the Court of Timour;' 'Royal Commentaries of Garcilasgoa de la Vega;' 'Chronicle of Cieza de Leon;' 'Memoir of Alonzo Henriquez de Guzman;' 'Report of Pascual de Andagoza;' editor of 'Early Voyages of the East India Company,' and 'Voyages of Baffin;' wrote the 'Reports on the Moral and Material Progress of India,' for 1871-72 and 1872-73, and edited the 'Geographical Magazine,' 1872 to 1878.

MARRIOTT, CHARLES RICHARDSON, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Wellington College, and Pembroke College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1875; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Dec., 1887; officiating collector of customs, Calcutta, May, 1891; magistrate and collector, Dec., 1891; junior secretary to revenue board, March, 1892; confirmed as collector of customs, Calcutta, July, 1892.

MARYAT, ERNEST LINDSAY, Lt.-Col., R.E., late Railway Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1859; probationary assistant engineer, Mhow, Bombay, Nov., 1862; assistant engineer, Central Provinces, Oct., 1864; executive engineer, Bombay public works department, Jan., 1866; assistant consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, June, 1869; consulting engineer for reclamation, Bombay, April, 1870; acted for various periods as deputy consulting engineer, Bombay; acting under secretary to government of Bombay, public works department, April, 1874; acting manager, Dhond and Manmad state railway, Dec., 1878; confirmed as deputy consulting engineer, Bombay, March, 1879; executive engineer, 1st grade, June, 1880; manager, Punjab northern state railway, in 1st class of the state railway revenue establishment, Nov., 1880; retired from the public works department, 1887.

MARSDEN, FREDERICK JOHN, B.L.—Clerk of the crown, 14th May, 1873; officiating magistrate, Calcutta police, and coroner, Oct., 1874; presidency magistrate and coroner, Dec., 1877; chief magistrate, Calcutta, March, 1878; also judge of the court for the trial of pilots, and of the court of survey, port of Calcutta.

MARSHALL, ALEXANDER CHALMERS, Barrister-at-Law, Punjab Commission.—From 2nd Feb., 1867, served in the subordinate executive and judicial departments as assistant commissioner and officiating judge, small cause courts, and judicial assistant; appointed judge, small cause court, Sept., 1881, and judicial assistant, Nov., 1884; extra judicial assistant commissioner, Dec., 1889.

MARSHALL, CHARLES HENRY TILSON, Colonel, I.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1859; from July, 1865, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and judicial assistant; officiating private secretary to lieutenant-governor, Oct., 1878; superintendent, Chamba state, Oct., 1879; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Sept., 1886; from Dec., 1886, served under foreign department, government of India; returned to the Punjab, Nov., 1888, and was appointed divisional judge, May, 1889; author of a 'Monograph of the Capitonidae' (with G. F. L. Marshall), 'The Game Birds of India' (with A. O. Hume), 'The Ornithology of the Hills about Murree,' and 'The Ornithology of Chamba.'

MARSHALL, GEORGE FREDERICK LEYCESTER, Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., C.I.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1860; joined the public works department, 28th March, 1864, and served in the irrigation department, N.W. Provinces; executive engineer, Sept., 1868; special assistant, irrigation branch, N.W. Provinces secretariat, 1876; officiating assistant secretary to government of India, civil works branch, Oct., 1876, to May, 1877, and again in 1878; confirmed in this appointment, Sept., 1879; officiating under secretary, government of India, public works department, railway branch, Nov., 1881, to Feb., 1882; under secretary, government of India, civil works branch, June, 1882; member of committee on reorganisation of the public works department, Sept., 1883; superintending engineer, Dec., 1884; officiating superintending engineer and secretary to agent to governor-general, Rajputana, April, 1887; superintending engineer and public works secretary, Rajputana and Central India, 1888; chief engineer and secretary to government of Punjab, public works department, June, 1892; C.I.E., Jan., 1893; author of 'A Monograph of the Capitonidae' (with C. H. T. Marshall), 'Birds-nesting in India,' and 'The Butterflies of India, Burma, and Ceylon.'

MARSHALL, LOUIS, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces and Oudh).—Educated at Rugby, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 15th Dec., 1891, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

MARTELLI, NORTON CHARLES, Lieutenant-Colonel, I.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, 15th foot, Oct., 1864; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, Oct., 1870; served in civil employ from 1872 as assistant cantonment magistrate, Morar, and political assistant in Rajputana; magistrate of Aboo, and assistant in the thuggee and dacoity department, 1875; guardian and tutor to Maharaj of Alwar, Aug., 1876; served in Beloochistan, 1880-81, as political officer, Jacobabad, Quetta, and the Bolan; assistant at Banswarra and Pertabgurh, and superintendent of operations for control of Moghias, Oct., 1881; officiating political agent, Baghelcund, 1882, and in 1886; political agent, Bhopawur, 1885; political agent, Eastern States of Rajputana, June, 1888.

MARTIN, CAULFIELD AYLMER, LL.D., Education Department, Bengal.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed, 22nd Nov., 1864; served as professor at the Dacca College, and at the Krishnagur College; inspector of
schools, March, 1874; 2nd class, educational service, August, 1877.

MARTIN, CHARLES WILLIAM WALL, B.A., LL.D., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from March, 1865, in various districts as assistant collector and magistrate, acting small cause court judge, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; collector and magistrate, South Canara, Nov., 1882; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1883, in Cuddapah, and afterwards in Salem; retired, April, 1889.

MARTIN, EDWARD JAMES, M.I.C.E., and F.R.I.B.A., late Public Works Department, Bengal.—Appointed by the secretary of state, May, 1859; arrived in India, 6th Sept., 1859; served in the Punjab in the buildings and roads branch as assistant engineer and executive engineer till 1869-70, when he was transferred to the N.W. Provinces, and posted to the Rajputana state railway; officiated as engineer-in-chief, Tirhut state railway, April, 1877; engineer-in-chief, Rangoon and Irrawaddy Valley state railway, Aug., 1877; also ex-officio manager of the line, April, 1878; transferred to Bengal, railway branch, and appointed engineer-in-chief of the Central Bengal system of state railways, Nov., 1878; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Jan., 1880; transferred to Bengal provincial branch, Jan., 1880; on special duty under the chief engineer, Bengal, as government architect, April, 1881; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Feb., 1882; deputed to Indore on special duty, Jan., 1884; superintending engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1885; officiating chief engineer, and secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, June, 1888; 2nd chief engineer, May, 1889; chief engineer and joint secretary to government of Bengal, Jan., 1890; retired, 1891.

MARTIN, GERALD WARD, Major, I.S.C., Assay Master, Bombay Mint.—Ensign, 88th Foot, 22nd June, 1867; joined Roorkee College, Nov., 1869, and obtained certificate as civil engineer; admitted to the staff corps, March, 1871; from March, 1871, to July, 1878, served as assistant superintendent of survey in Assam, in the Deccan topographical survey, and in the Soane irrigation survey; transferred to the financial department for employment in the assay department, July, 1878, and acted as deputy assay master in the Calcutta and Bombay mints; appointed assay master, Bombay mint, May, 1884; also served with the Afghan expeditionary force as assistant superintendent of survey, 1879-80 (medal and clasp for Kabul), and with the Waziri expeditionary field force.

MARTIN, HENRY, M.B., Surgeon-Major, Staff of Governor of Bombay.—Surgeon, 6th March, 1880; served with the Zhob Valley expedition of 1884; appointed medical officer to Lord Harris, Governor of Bombay, April, 1890.

MARTIN, JAMES WENTWORTH, Madras Public Works Department.—Arrived, 8th March, 1868, and served in the Madras presidency as assistant engineer, executive engineer and superintending engineer (pro tem.).

MARTIN, WILLIAM THOMAS, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Regent's Park College, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1865; from July, 1867, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1881; judge, 3rd grade, April, 1885; 2nd grade, June, 1889.

MARTINDALE, ARTHUR HENRY TEMPLE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; served in the foreign department of the government of India from Oct., 1877, to Oct., 1879, and from June, 1881, to May, 1882, as attaché, officiating political agent, 3rd class, and assistant secretary to government, and was placed on special duty Dec., 1881; officiating under secretary to government of India, home department, May-Aug., 1882; from Aug., 1882, served again under the foreign department of the government of India as political agent at Kotah, and assistant secretary to government; junior under secretary, Oct., 1884; officiating assistant to resident in Mysore and secretary to the chief commissioner of Coorg, Feb., 1885; officiating resident and chief commissioner, May-June, 1885; political agent, 3rd class, April, 1886; first assistant and secretary for Berar to the resident, Hyderabad, Nov., 1886; political agent, Quetta and Pishin, April, 1887; 1st assistant to governor-general's agent, Central India, Oct., 1888; political agent, Bhopal, July, 1890, and Jallawar, Jan., 1892; officiating commissioner, Ajmere, April, 1892.

MARTINEAU, ALFRED EDWARD, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1889, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

MASSY, CHARLES FRANCIS, Lieut.-Colonel, I.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 11th June, 1868; from June, 1870, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner, and was placed on special duty to settle boundary disputes in Feb. and Oct., 1874; on a deputation to Kashmir, Aug.-Dec., 1876; political officer with the Punjab native chief contingent, Nov., 1878; on special duty in connection with Viceregal Durbar, at Lahore, Nov., 1880; on special duty to inspect the Punjab-Rajputana border, Nov., 1883; officiating divisional judge, Jullundur, April, 1885; superintendent, Kapurthala state, Aug., 1886; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1890.

MASSY, GEORGE, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, Medical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 11th April, 1866; from April, 1867, served in the Punjab as civil surgeon, superintendent of jail, and superintendent of vaccination; deputy sanitary commissioner (sub pro temp.), Nov., 1880; civil surgeon, 1st class, Oct., 1881; from April, 1887, to April, 1888, acted as superintendent of lunatic asylum, and medical officer in charge of the Government College, Lahore.

MASTER, CHARLES GILBERT, C.S.I., Barrister-at-Law, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; served in Madras as assistant collector and
magistrate from Sept., 1855; deputy secretary to government in revenue department, Dec., 1859; commissioner of income tax, 1860–1865; secretary to the board of examiners, April, 1861, to Jan., 1866; acting sub-secretary to the board of revenue for various periods between 1862 and 1866; acting civil and sessions judge, Calicut, May, 1869; on special duty in Godavari and Kistna on irrigation works, May to Nov., 1869; from Nov., 1869, to May, 1877, served as collector and magistrate of Nellore, and other districts; secretary to government, revenue department, June, 1877; chief secretary to government, June, 1882; additional member of the legislative council, June, 1882; ordinary member of council, Madras, Jan., 1884; president of the committee in connection with the Draft Tenancy Bill, July, 1885; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; retired, Jan., 1889.

Masters, Edward Stewart, Captain, I.S.C., Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, 9th Aug., 1873; served under the military department until Sept., 1891, when he was appointed cantonment magistrate, Secunderabad, and judge, small cause court.

Masters, John, Bengal Police Department.—Joined the service, 21st July, 1861; assistant superintendent of police, June, 1863; district superintendent, April, 1870; 1st grade, Feb., 1890.

Matthew, George Felton, C.I.E., Railway Branch, Government of India.—Joined the public works department, June, 1876, as assistant to the manager, Rajputana state railway; officiating traffic superintendent, Indus Valley state railway, June, 1879; 2nd class, traffic department, Jan., 1880; Kandahar railway, March, 1880; C.I.E., Jan., 1882; officiating manager, Nizam's railway, March, 1882; Rajputana-Malwa railway, Dec., 1884; 1st class, 3rd grade, April, 1887; North-Western railway, April, 1888; attached to office of secretary to government of India, public works department, Oct., 1888; deputy manager, North-Western railway, May, 1890; officiated as manager, July–Oct., 1890, and as traffic superintendent in same year; also as manager, Burma state railway, from April, 1892.

Matthews, Henry Montagu, C.I.E., M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Burma.—Appointed 4th grade executive engineer, 8th Oct., 1868; arrived in India, Dec., 1868; served in British Burma, and was promoted to 1st grade executive engineer, Oct., 1877; employed in examining, repairing, and reporting on lighthouses, British Burma, Jan.–March, 1878; transferred to railway branch as engineer-in-chief and manager of the Rangoon and Irrawaddy Valley state railway, Nov., 1878; officiated as chief engineer and secretary to the chief commissioner, public works department, Oct., 1880, and again in 1886; 1st class, 1st grade, state railway revenue establishment, Jan., 1882; also chairman, Rangoon port trust; C.I.E., Feb., 1887; retired, 1887.

Mathias, Henry Vincent, Colonel, I.S.C., late Police Department, Central Provinces.—Ensign Bengal infantry, Dec., 1849; in command, Nagode divisional military police, Oct., 1862; from 1st July, 1865, to 1886, served in the police department, Central Provinces, and was promoted to district superintendent of police, 1st class, April, 1875; reverted to military duty, 1885.

Matthew, Right Rev. Henry James, M.A., D.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 15th Feb., 1867, and served in N.W. Provinces and Bengal as chaplain of Allahabad and Fort William, and as domestic chaplain to the lord bishop; from Jan., 1877, served in Punjab as senior chaplain, and was appointed archdeacon, Aug., 1878, and bishop's commissary, March, 1883; appointed bishop of Lahore, Dec., 1887.

Matthews, Harold Francis, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Tonbridge School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1871; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Bengal and Assam; officiating superintendent of emigration and embarkation agent, Sept., 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Nov., 1884; district and sessions judge, Jan., 1889.

Maude, Henry, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1877, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating senior secretary to financial commissioner, Nov., 1884; officiating undersecretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1885; confirmed, April, 1885; officiated as junior secretary to the government of the Punjab in 1888, 1889, 1890, and 1891; confirmed, April, 1892.

Maude, Walter, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Highgate School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Nov., 1883; acting under secretary to government of Bengal, general, revenue and statistical departments, April, 1889, and March, 1890; confirmed, Aug., 1890; officiating secretary in same departments, July, 1892; acted as collector of customs, Calcutta, in Sept., 1890.

Maxwell, Frederick Doveton, Lieutenant, I.S.C., Burma Commission.—First commission, July, 1882; supernumerary assistant commissioner, July, 1885; assistant commissioner, July, 1887; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1891.

Maxwell, Henry St. Patrick, C.S.I., Major, I.S.C.—Educated at Wellington College and Sandhurst Military College; arrived in India, 26th March, 1869; joined as ensign, 100th Foot, April, 1869; from May, 1873, served in civil employ in the Assam commission; served in the Daila expedition, 1874–75; acted as political officer, Naga Hills, Feb. to July, 1878; political officer with the Naga Hills expedition, Oct., 1878, to April, 1880 (medal); inspector of immigrants, Jan., 1881; from May, 1881, acted as deputy commissioner in the Garo Hills; political officer with the Aka field force, Dec., 1883, to Feb., 1884; deputy commissioner, Sept., 1885; acted as inspector-general of police in 1887; chief political officer, Manipur, April, 1891.

Maxwell, William, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Belfast Methodist College, Royal University of Ireland, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 3rd Dec., 1891, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

Mayes, Herbert Frederick, B.L., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Dover College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed
to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1888; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1890, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

MAYHEW, ALFRED HERCULES, Lieut.-Col., I.S.C., Sind Commission.—First commission Madras army, June, 1861; arrived in India, 4th Jan., 1862; from July, 1865, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, acting political superintendent of Thar and Parkar, head assistant collector, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty in the military department, March, 1882; in charge of office of district superintendent of police, Jacobabad, May-Aug., 1883, and March-May, 1884; deputy commissioner, Upper Sind frontier, Dec., 1884; collector and magistrate and district registrar, Shikarpur, and political agent, Khairpur State, Dec., 1885; lieutenant-colonel, June, 1887.

MAYNARD, HERBERT JOHN, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School and St. John's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1886, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating under secretary to government of Punjab, April, 1890, and again from March, 1891; under secretary, revenue department, Nov., 1891.

MAYNE, ARTHUR, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Christ's Hospital and Emanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1888; arrived in India, 27th Oct., 1890, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner; also registrar, judicial commissioner's court, March, 1892.

MAYO, JOHN H., Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Brighton College; East India House writer, old establishment, 28th Feb., 1855; junior clerk, marine department, 1860; statistical department, 1862; senior clerk, Jan., 1872; military department, 1875; assistant secretary in the military department, Dec., 1892.

M'BLAINE, FREDERIC, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at private schools and at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1886, and served as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, Jan., 1890.

McARTHUR, ALEXANDER DONALD, Lieut.-Colonel, R.E., India Public Works Department.—Appointed assistant engineer, March, 1869; executive engineer, Sept., 1872; officiating under-secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, April, 1885, and again in 1887; in charge of office of chief engineer and joint secretary, Nov.-Dec., 1885; superintending engineer, 3rd class, July, 1891; 2nd, March, 1892.

McCABE, ROBERT BLAIR, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1876, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1884; on special duty as political officer, North Lushai, Sept., 1890; author of an outline grammar of Angami Naga language, 1887.

McCALLUM, EDWIN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Wesleyan Connexional School, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting junior collector and magistrate; second assistant collector, May, 1884; first assistant collector, April, 1887.

McCarthy, Samuel Trant, late Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Patrick's College, Carlow; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed sub-collector and joint magistrate, Chingleput, Oct., 1877; acted as collector and magistrate, Cuddapah, Sept., 1879, to March, 1881; district and sessions judge, Jan., 1882, in the district of Vizagapatam, and afterwards in Kistna, Madura, and Chingleput; retired, Jan., 1891.

McCleverty, William Anson, General.—Entered the army from the Royal Military College, Sandhurst, and obtained a commission in the 48th regiment, March, 1824; brigade major to the western auxiliary column, Coorg field force, March-April, 1834; temporarily attached to the engineer department at Gibraltar, 1840-41; deputy quartermaster-general in the Australian Colonies, July, 1846, to April, 1857; commanded the troops in New Zealand during the native disturbances in 1847 (medal); assistant adjutant-general in Scotland, Jan., 1859, to Feb., 1860; in command of the presidency division of the Madras army, April, 1860, to April, 1865; in command of the southeastern district of England at Shorncliffe and Dover, 1866-67; commander-in-chief of the Madras army, with local rank of lieutenant-general, and member of the governor's council, July, 1867, to April, 1871.

McColl, Hugh Ernest, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Clifton College, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1891, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner.
