McConnell, James Frederick Parry, M.D., Surg.-Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1870; house-surgeon to the Calcutta medical college hospital, Oct., 1871; professor of pathology in the medical college, and resident physician to the college hospital, March, 1872; also officiated as professor of the comparative anatomy section of the college museum, in July, 1873; officiating civil surgeon, 24-Pergunnahs, and medical inspector of emigrants, Sept.-Nov., 1878; surgeon-major, April, 1882; superintendent of vaccination, Feb., 1883; officiating professor of materia medica and clinical medicine, medical college, and medical inspector of emigrants, April, 1883, and again, July, 1885; civil surgeon, 24-Pergunnahs, medical officer, Alipore Jail, and ex-officio deputy sanitary commissioner, 1885; appointed professor of materia medica and second physician, medical college hospital, Oct., 1891; also medical inspector of emigrants, April, 1892.

McCorkell, Gilmour, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Foyle College, Londonderry, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and ma-
gistrate, acting educational inspector, acting district superintendent of police, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting district judge; 1st grade assistant judge, Feb., 1886; senior assistant judge, April, 1890.

McCULLAGH, J. R., Lieut.-Col., R.E., India Survey Department.—First commission, 18th Dec., 1861; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1865, and served with the Bengal sappers and miners; appointed to the public works department, Nov., 1863, and to the great trigonometrical survey of India, March, 1869; assistant superintendent, Jan., 1872; deputy superintendent, July, 1882; 3rd grade, Jan., 1887.

McDERMOTT, BENJAMIN KENICOTT SELBY, Burma Commission.—Was appointed preventive officer on the Mandalay line, 20th Dec., 1872; superintendent of wharves, Rangoon port trust, April, 1874, and chief inspector of police, July, 1875; assistant superintendent of police, Oct., 1880, and district superintendent, Oct., 1882; appointed to the commission as assistant commissioner, Jan., 1887; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1891.

McDONELL, WILLIAM FRASER, V.C., late Bengal C.S. — Appointed from Haileybury College, June, 1849; arrived in India, 10th Jan., 1850; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector (1st grade, Champaran, April, 1864); on special duty, May, 1858; settlement officer, Shahabad, July, 1859; superintendent of stamps and stationery, Dec., 1865; civil and sessions judge, 1st grade, Nuddea, March, 1868; commissioner, Bhagulpore division, April, 1874; judge, high court, Calcutta, Aug., 1878; retired, April, 1886.

McDOUGALL, H. R. L., Deputy Surgeon-General, M.D., L.R.C.S., L.M. (Ed.), late Bombay Medical Department.—Joined the service, 1858; civil surgeon, Rajkot, Oct., 1875; acted as superintendent of vaccination, Oct.-Nov., 1882; brigade-surgeon, May, 1883; superintendent of Matheran, March, 1884; retired, May, 1886.

McGANN, TERENCE JOSEPH, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut. - Colonel, Madras Medical Service.—Joined the service, 1st April, 1867; senior surgeon, Bangalore, and sanitary commissioner, Mysore, Sept., 1870.

McINTOSH, HENRY JAMES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and the University of Edinburgh, and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1886, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; officiating under-secretary to government, financial and municipal departments, April, 1892.

McIVER, CHARLES, Bombay Police Department.—Joined the service as assistant superintendent of police, Karachi, 16th March, 1867; superintendent, March, 1873; district superintendent, Aug., 1875; 1st grade superintendent, July, 1883; district superintendent, Hyderabad, March, 1880.

McKEON, GEORGE, late Store Department, India Office—Served in the Bombay ordnance department, Sept., 1831, to May, 1859; sub-inspector of stores, India store depot, July, 1860; supervisor, 1st grade, March, 1877; retired July, 1888.

McLAUGHLIN, FREDERICK HUBERT, LL.M., B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury grammar school, and Magdalen College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 21st Jan., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1877; from April, 1876, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, March, 1884; retired, March, 1890.

McLEAN, JOHN JAMES, M.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the International College, Ealing, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1875, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating district judge; joint magistrate, 1st grade, July, 1889; judge, small cause court, Allahabad, March, 1890, and again, Dec., 1890; district and sessions judge, March, 1891.

McLEOD, GEORGE EDMONSTONE, late Assam Commission.—Appointed extra assistant commissioner in Oudh, 14th Feb., 1870, and assistant commissioner in Assam, March, 1875; inspector of labourers, Feb., 1882; deputy commissioner, May, 1888; retired, 1892.

McLEOD, HARRY, Lieut.-General, R.A., Madras Political Department.—First commission, 1st Nov., 1853; commissary of ordnance, May, 1879; deputy inspector-general of ordnance, Madras, Sept., 1880; superintendent, gun carriage factory, Sept., 1881; inspector-general of ordnance, Sept., 1886; consular agent, Pondicherry and Karikal, Aug., 1891.

McLEOD, KENNETH, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Col., M.D., late Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, March, 1865; civil surgeon, Jessore, 20th Feb., 1866; on special duty as member, cattle plague commission, Dec., 1869; secretary to inspector-general of hospitals, Jan., 1871; officiating professor of surgical and descriptive anatomy, Calcutta Medical College, and ex-officio 2nd surgeon, College Hospital, April, 1874; also officiating medical inspector of emigrants, Calcutta, and officiating matrine surgeon, Jan., 1875; rank of surgeon-major, March, 1877; professor of surgery, Medical College, and ex-officio 1st surgeon at the hospital, Jan., 1880; also health officer for town of Calcutta, Feb., 1880; brigade-surgeon, June, 1888; retired, April, 1892; author of several publications on cattle diseases, including the report of the cattle plague commission, 1871, and on medico-legal subjects; also of 'History of the Medical Schools of the Bengal Presidency,' 'The Sanitary Past, Present, and Future of Calcutta,' 'Operative Surgery in the Calcutta Medical College.'

McMILLAN, ALEXANDER, M.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Aldenham grammar school, and Brasenose College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settler's officer; officiating assistant secretary to government, Aug., 1874; under secretary to govern-
ment, March, 1876; deputy superintendent, family domains of Maharaja of Benares, March, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1883; from April, 1884, served as officiating district and sessions judge and small cause court judge; district and sessions judge, April, 1887.

McMINN, CHARLES WILLIAM, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 21st Jan., 1863; from July, 1864, to Feb., 1879, served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, settlement officer, assistant commissioner, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was placed on special duty for completion of Oudh gazetteer, July, 1872, also at Simla, July, 1873; from March, 1879, served in the Central Provinces and was appointed deputy commissioner, 1st class, Jubbulpore, Nov., 1884; officiated as commissioner in 1887; deputy commissioner, Damoh, Feb., 1888; Chanda, Jan., 1890; Hoshangabad, May, 1891; retired, Aug., 1891; compiled Gazetteer of Oudh, 1877.

McNEILE, CHARLES, Colonel, I.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1858; from Dec., 1861, served in the Punjab police department as assistant superintendent and officiating district superintendent; from May, 1865, served in the commission as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and judicial assistant; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Sept., 1881; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, March, 1886; retired, March, 1888.

McNEILE, JOHN MAGEE, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Bengal.—Joined at Addiscombe, Aug., 1854; 1st commission, Bengal Engineers, June, 1856; arrived in India, 10th April, 1858; from May, 1858, served in the public works department as assistant engineer, and executive engineer in Bengal; also as assistant superintendent, Alguada Reef Lighthouse works, 1860-65; officiating superintendent of works, Ajmere and Mairwara, 1874-1876; re-transferred to Bengal, Nov., 1876; superintending engineer, 3rd grade, Jan., 1879; transferred temporarily to Punjab, Oct., 1879; officiating superintending engineer and secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, public works department, Jan., 1880; confirmed in this appointment, Jan., 1882; chief engineer, 3rd class, special, and joint secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, Jan., 1884; officiating chief engineer and secretary to government of Bengal, July, 1885, to Oct., 1886; and chief engineer, Nov., 1887; secretary to the government of Bengal, Jan., 1890, and 1st chief engineer, Feb., 1890; reverted to military duty, March, 1892.

McNEILL, DUNCAN, Colonel, I.S.C., Police Department, Punjab.—Joined the service, 8th Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1855; served in the suppression of the mutiny at Sitabaldi, 1857, and with the Kamptee Flying Column in 1858-59; also with the expedition to the Pachmarhi Hills, and at the capture of Harrakote, Nov., 1859; assistant district superintendent of police, Punjab, July, 1862; district superintendent, 5th class, April, 1867; 1st class, May, 1890.

McNEILL, JAMES, Bombay C.S.—Educated at University College, Blackrock, Royal University, Ireland, and Emanuel College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 22nd Nov., 1890; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1891.

McPHERSON, HUGH, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Paisley Grammar School, Glasgow University, London University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 28th Nov., 1891, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

McQUEEN, SIR J. W., Brigadier-General, K.C.B., A.D.C., I.S.C.—1st commission, Bengal Infantry, April, 1854; arrived in India, 15th May, 1854; employed in military department up to 31st Dec., 1882; served throughout Indian mutiny campaign of 1857-8, including siege and capture of Delhi, relief of Lucknow; commanded 4th Punjab infantry in Oudh and Rohilkund campaign of 1858; served against the Kabul Khel Waziris in 1860 (medal and clasp), and in the Jowaki Afrereedee expedition, 1877-8 (clasp); served in Afghan war, 1878-80 (medal and two clasps, C.B.); served in Mahsud Waziri expedition, May, 1881; military secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1883; brigadier-general, commanding Hyderabad contingent, Sept., 1885; commanding Punjab frontier force, Oct., 1886; commanded Hazara expedition, 1888 (medal); K.C.B., April, 1889; aide-de-camp to the Queen.

McRAE, JOHN GRAHAM, Colonel, I.S.C., late Forest Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 10th July, 1858, and served in the Bombay Presidency on military duty till March, 1867, and subsequently in the revenue survey department as assistant superintendent; on military duty, Nov., 1867, to July, 1868 (field service in Abyssinia), and again Dec., 1870, to Nov., 1871; from Nov., 1871, served in the Bombay forest department as deputy conservator; conservator of forests in Sind, Aug., 1878; 2nd grade conservator, Dec., 1886; retired, May, 1891.

MEAD, CHARLES CLEMENT, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1885.

MEAD, HENRY ROBERT, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1857, and served in the Madras public works department from Jan., 1858, as assistant engineer, and executive engineer (4th grade, Jan., 1866), and was placed on special duty on the Neringipeth Anicut project, March, 1871; superintending engineer, Oct., 1878; on special duty in Travancore, Feb., 1882; 1st class superintending engineer, April, 1886; chief engineer, 2nd class, and joint secretary to government, public works department, irrigation branch, March, 1887; acting chief engineer and secretary to government, Oct., 1888; retired, Sept., 1889.

MEADE, MALCOLM JOHN, Captain, I.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—1st commission, 9th Aug., 1873; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1873; served under the military and foreign departments, and was appointed
officiating political assistant, Rajputana, March, 1878; assistant to resident, Hyderabad, and assistant general superintendent in thuggee and dacoity department, Aug., 1878; from 1879, was assistant to governor general's agent in Central India for various periods; boundary settlement officer, Bhopal, June, 1875; superintendent of operations for control of Monghyas, July, 1885; additional political agent, 1st class, and political agent, Baghelkhand, and superintendent of Rewah State, May, 1887; political agent in Bhopawar, Dec., 1889; officiating political agent, Baghelkhand, and superintendent of Rewah State, March, 1891; political agent, Bhopal, Dec., 1891.

MEADE, Sir Richard John, General, K.C.S.I., C.I.E., Indian Staff Corps.—Educated at Royal Naval School; appointed a cadet, Bengal Infantry, 1st March, 1838; arrived in India, July, 1838; served with the 65th and 54th regiments, N.I., and also temporarily in the commissariat department; interpreter and quartermaster, 65th regiment, N.I., Jan., 1844; station staff at Nowgong, Oct., 1845; and in command, 6th Infantry, Gwalior Contingent, Dec., 1845; brigade major, Gwalior Contingent, postmaster, Gwalior, and cantonment magistrate, Morar, Nov., 1851; also paymaster and commissariat officer, May, 1853; served with 65th Regiment, N.I., in Burma, 1853-1855, and was appointed assistant adjutant-general, Pegu division, Oct., 1854; on the mutiny of the Gwalior contingent, escaped to Agra, where he raised a body of cavalry, subsequently known as "Meade's Horse"; in June, 1858, escorted Maharaja Sindha back to Gwalior, and was present at the battle that place, Sindha's palace being surrendered to him personally; was afterwards employed as special commissioner in Gwalior to deal with the Gwalior State troops; in 1859 joined brigadier-general Sir R. Napier's force, and received the surrender of Raja Man Sing, and captured the rebel leader, Tantia Topee; in July, 1859, surprised and routed a large body of rebels at Gurroya in the Jhansi district; brevet-major, mutiny medal and clasp for Central India; political agent, Gwalior, April, 1860; governor-general's agent in Central India, and opium agent, Maiwa, Nov., 1861; chief commissioner of Mysore and Coorg, Feb., 1870; president of special commission to inquire into charges against the Gaekwar of Baroda, Oct., 1873; member of the commission to investigate the charge preferred against the Gaekwar of attempting to poison the resident, Colonel R. Phayre, C.B., Feb., 1875; appointed to the charge of the Baroda state as agent and special commissioner, April, 1875, and superintended the measures necessary for the reorganisation of the administration, and the selection of a successor to the deposed Gaekwar; resident at Hyderabad, Dec., 1875, to March, 1881; C.S.I., June, 1866; K.C.S.I., May, 1874; C.I.E., Jan., 1878; lieutenant-general in the army, Sept., 1884; general, Jan., 1889.

MEADOWS, Charles John Walford, Surgeon-Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1869; from 26th April, 1872, served as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon at various stations in Bengal; also officiated as superintendent of medical school, Dacca, 1888-90.

MEDLICOTT, Arthur Louis, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1889, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner; personal assistant to chief commissioner, Nov., 1890, to Feb., 1891.

MEDLICOTT, Henry Benedict, M.A., F.R.S., F.G.S., late Geological Survey of India.—Engaged for service in India from the geological survey of Great Britain; joined appointment in India, March, 1854; professor of geology, Roorkee College, Aug., 1854, to Oct., 1862, when he rejoined the geological survey as deputy superintendent for Bengal; received the Indian mutiny medal for special services in Rohilkund; was variously employed in Bengal, Assam, Central India, Rajputana, Central Provinces, &c.; superintendent of the geological survey (subsequently designated director of the geological survey), April, 1876; fellow of Calcutta University, and member of the faculty of arts and engineering, April, 1876; retired, April, 1887; author of numerous contributions to the survey publications, and of a manual of the geology of India (in part).

MEIKLEJOHN, David Ogilvy, B.L., Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector, Hoogly, Dec., 1870; from Oct., 1871, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting district superintendent of police, and acting deputy commissioner, and was placed on special famine duty in Bengal, Feb., 1874; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, Dec., 1882; judge, small cause court, Jubulpore, April, 1885; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Bilaspur, Sept., 1889; 3rd class, Sept., 1891; 2nd class, March, 1892.

MEIKLEJOHN, George Forbes, B.L., Coorg Administration.—Joined the service, 30th Nov., 1867, as probationary assistant superintendent; confirmed, June, 1868; special deputy commissioner, March, 1881; deputy commissioner, Bangalore, and president of Mysore municipality, Nov., 1889; commissioner of Coorg, Jan., 1891.

MELHUISH, William Francis, M.I.E.E.; Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as inspector, 29th May, 1865; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1865, and served in Bengal and Bombay; accompanied Persian Gulf cable expedition, Oct., 1866; superintendent, April, 1880; personal assistant to director-general, Dec., 1881; held charge of various divisions, including Bengal, Madras, Bombay; class IV., 1st grade, April, 1889; electrician, May, 1889; attached to office of director-general of telegraphs, Feb., 1891; director, traffic branch, Feb., 1891.

MELITUS, Paul Gregory, Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Marylebone, All Saints' Grammar School, Marlborough College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1880; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; assistant commissioner in Assam, Nov., 1886; acted as assistant secretary to chief commissioner in 1889; and as postmaster-general, Calcutta, in
1890; under secretary to government of India, home department, Jan., 1891; officiating deputy secretary, Jan., 1892.

MELLOR, CHARLES WARREN, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Corpus Christi College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Oct., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Nov., 1879; 1st grade, Feb., 1882; retired, Aug., 1887.

MELVILL, SIR PETER MELVILL, Major-General, K.C.B.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School; ensign, Bombay army, 1819; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1819; was employed with the revenue survey of Guzerat, 1822 to 1827; fort adjutant of garrison of Bombay, and A.D.C. to the governor, 1828; on special duty in Calcutta as assistant to the Bombay military member of the financial commission, 1829; 1st assistant to resident in Cutch and Sind, 1836; political agent in Cutch, 1838; secretary to government of Bombay in the military and marine departments, Dec., 1840, to April, 1859; appointed K.C.B., 1860; retired with honorary rank of major-general, Dec., 1861; was a member of Lord Hotham's committee on the amalgamation of the Indian with the British army in 1860, and of the royal commission appointed to report on the memorials of the Indian officers in 1863.

MELVILL, PHILIP SANDYS, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1846; arrived in India, 4th Oct., 1846; attached to the Punjab, and served as assistant to the resident at Lahore, and assistant commissioner; settlement officer in the Hoshiarpur and Amballa districts, 1850-54; deputy commissioner, Amballa, Jan., 1854; commissioner, Hissar division, 1860 to 1862, and subsequently of the Delhi and Rawal Pindi divisions; officiated as financial commissioner of the Punjab in 1869, and again in 1873, and as judicial commissioner of the Central Provinces in 1870-71; commissioner, Jullundur division, 1872 to 1875, and officiated as judge of the chief court of the Punjab in 1873 and 1874; member of commission for investigating the charges brought against the Gaekwar of Baroda, 1875; agent to the governor-general and resident, 1st class, at Baroda, Oct., 1875; retired, Jan., 1882.

MENZIES, HUGH CHRISTIAN, Colonel, I.S.C., late Berar Commission.—Ensign, Dec., 1849; Arrived in India, 7th June, 1850, and served under the military department in Madras, and took part in the operations against the insurgents in the Parla Kimdi District, 1857; served in Burmah from Aug., 1859, as assistant commissioner and officiating deputy commissioner; from Oct., 1860, served as superintendent of police in Madras, and was engaged in the organisation of the police in the South Malabar districts, and in the Hyderabad assigned districts from Oct., 1862; from Dec., 1864, served in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, and small cause court judge at Amraoti; inspector-general of registration, Aug., 1871; deputy commissioner, April, 1878; reverted to military duty, 1887.

MENZIES, OSWALD, Colonel, I.S.C., Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 26th Aug., 1854; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1854; from March, 1861, served in the police department, Punjab, as district superintendent, and was promoted to deputy inspector-general, July, 1880; inspector-general of police in the Punjab, and under secretary to government, March, 1885.

MEREDITH, ARTHUR, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Dulwich College; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner and district judge; officiating under secretary, revenue department, Dec., 1886; officiated as deputy commissioner and as district judge for various periods in 1887-90; district judge, and officiating divisional judge, April, 1891.

MERES, WILLIAM FITZPATRICK, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oakham Grammar School, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived 29th Nov., 1864; from Sept., 1865, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and in Assam (March-Dec., 1881), and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1878, and district and sessions judge, 2nd grade, March, 1883, and 1st grade, Aug., 1888; acting judicial commissioner, Burma, Feb., 1885; president of the educational syndicate, Burma, Feb., 1885; retired, 1890.

MERK, WILLIAM RUDOLPH HENRY, C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Kornthal, Wurtemberg, the Grammar School, Old Aberdeen, and the University of Aberdeen; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 1st Dec., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty, Jhelum, March, 1877, and in the Khyber Pass, 1879, and again as assistant political agent, Sept., 1879; assistant resident, Kandahar, Nov., 1880; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, Sept., 1882, and again, Feb., 1884; on special duty with the Afghan boundary commission, Aug., 1884; C.S.I., Feb., 1887; deputy commissioner, Peshawar, Aug., 1890, and again from Dec., 1891; district judge, Peshawar, 1890-91.

MERRIMAN, CHARLES JAMES, General, C.S.I., R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, June, 1850; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1852; assistant engineer, Sept., 1853; field engineer, Persia, Nov., 1856; executive engineer, Hyderabad, Sept., 1857; and subsequently at Kurrachee and at Aden, 1866; superintending engineer in Sind, May, 1868; in N.W. Provinces to examine irrigation works, Sept.-Nov., 1869; acting chief engineer for irrigation and under secretary to government of Bombay, 1871, and again in 1873 and 1877-79; chief engineer and secretary to government of Bombay, general, and buildings and roads branches, March, 1880; retired from the public works department in 1885.

MERRIMAN, JOHN HENRY, Salt Department, Madras.—Served in the Madras revenue survey
department from June, 1868, to Oct., 1880; on special duty in Ganjam for settling boundary disputes, March, 1877; from Nov., 1880, served in the salt department as assistant commissioner, and was on special duty in the office of the commissioner of salt and abkari revenue, Jan.-April, 1885; deputy-commissioner, salt revenue, Dec., 1885.

MERRIMAN, WILLIAM, C.I.E., Colonel, R.E., Military Works Department.—Joined the service 12th Dec., 1856, and arrived in India, Feb., 1859; appointed special assistant engineer, harbour defences, Bombay, Nov., 1862; executive engineer, Jan., 1864; acted as under secretary to government in 1864; served under the home government, May, 1866, to March, 1882; returned to India as executive engineer, 1st grade, March, 1882; served as superintending engineer of West of India coast defences in 1883; chief engineer, Sept., 1890; Bombay command, July, 1891.

MESTON, JAMES SCORGIE, Bengal C.S. (North West Provinces).—Educated at Grammar School and University of Aberdeen, and at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1885; served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, June, 1890; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, May, 1890; 3rd grade, Feb., 1891; settlement officer, April, 1892.

METCALFE, CHARLES THEOPHILUS, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1857; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments; deputy commissioner and civil officer, Bhutan field force, Oct., 1864; senior superintendent of survey, May, 1869; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, June, 1871; additional commissioner, Patna division, March, 1874; officiating inspector-general of police, Oct., 1876; officiating commissioner of police, Calcutta, Nov., 1876; officiating opium agent, Behar, July, 1884; officiated as commissioner in various divisions between 1876 and 1884, and was appointed commissioner of the Orissa division, and superintendent of tributary Mehals, Cuttack, Sept., 1884; retired, Oct., 1889.

METCALFE, EDWARD PARR, M.A., Madras Educational Department.—Appointed, 10th Nov., 1872, and served as head-master of Rajahmundry school, and acting inspector of schools; fellow of Madras University, March, 1880; 3rd class, educational department, May, 1884; principal of Rajahmundry college, Oct., 1887.

MEYER, CHARLES HARDWICK LOUW, M.D., Surgeon-Captain, Bombay Educational Department.—Joined the service, 2nd Dec., 1887; professor of physiology and histology and of hygiene, Grant Medical College, Jan., 1889.

MEYER, WILLIAM STEVENSON, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Blackheath Missionary School, University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 25th Dec., 1881, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments, Oct., 1886; confirmed, Nov., 1888; acting under secretary to government, revenue department, Nov., 1889 to Jan., 1890; acting secretary to the commissioner of salt, &c., in 1890, 1891 and 1892; deputy commissioner of salt, &c., revenue, Sept., 1891; acting secretary to commissioners of land revenue in 1891, and from July, 1892.

MICHAEL, JAMES, Lieut.-General, C.S.I., I.S.C.—Educated at the Temple School, Brighton; also studied on the Continent, and at the Military Academy, Edinburgh; ensign, Madras infantry, Dec., 1844; in 1848 was appointed to organise a scheme of forest conservancy, which he superintended till the establishment of a regular forest department in 1856; assistant chief engineer, Hyderabad, March, 1857; executive engineer, Secunderabad, Sept., 1862; superintendent of family payments and pensions, and curator of government books, Madras, 1865 to 1876; commissioner for Madras at the Universal Exhibition, Paris, 1867; acted as deputy secretary to government of Madras, military department, 1869; commissioner for India to the Vienna Exhibition, 1873 (appointed commander of the Order of Francis Joseph of Austria); fellow of the University of Madras, 1874; attached to the staff of H.R.H. the Prince of Wales during his visit to Madras, 1875; secretary to the government of Madras, military department, Feb., 1876 to 1883; C.S.I., March, 1876; commissioner for India to the Edinburgh Forestry Exhibition, 1884; royal commissioner for the Colonial and Indian Exhibition, 1886.

MICHAEL, WALTER HENRY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Newark grammar school, and at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 5th December, 1887, and served in the revenue survey department and as assistant to collector and magistrate.

MICHELL, THOMAS BERNARD, Colonel, I.S.C., late Assam Commission.—First commission as ensign, Feb., 1858; arrived in India, 29th Jan., 1860; from March, 1866, served in the Assam commission, and was promoted to deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Jan., 1885; also served temporarily in Bengal as cantonment magistrate, Dum-Dum, July, 1877, to Nov., 1878; retired, March, 1886.

MIDDLETON, JAMES RUSSELL, M.A., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Andrew's, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate, Kaladgi, Aug., 1883; senior collector and magistrate, Nov., 1886; acted as commissioner, southern division, March to June, 1889; collector and magistrate and district registrar, Nasik, June, 1889; also political agent of the Surgana state; retired, 1890.

MILES, SAMUEL BARRETT, Colonel, I.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Bombay infantry, Aug., 1857; from Nov., 1867, served as cantonment magistrate and assistant resident, Aden; assistant political agent, Mekran Coast, 1871; from Oct., 1872, served as political agent and consul, Muscat; officiating political agent, Turkish Arabia, and consul-general, Baghdad, 1873-80; political agent, Zanzibar, 1881; returned to agency of Muscat, 1883; graded as political agent, 1st
class; acting political resident, Persian Gulf, April, 1886; political resident, Meywar, Dec., 1890; author of several papers on the history and geography of southern and eastern Arabia.

MILLER, Sir Alexander Edward, Kt., B.A., Q.C., LL.D., Government of India.—Educated at Rugby and Trinity College, Dublin, where he obtained scholarship, 1st gold medal in mathematics and physics, and 2nd gold medal in classics, besides the Berkeley medal in Greek; hon. LL.D. in 1875; called to the bar (Lincoln's Inn), 1854; Q.C. in 1872; examiner in law, London University, 1874-9, and for council of legal education, 1877-8; legal member of railway commission, 1877-88; master in lunacy, 1889; appointed legal member of the government of India, Dec., 1890; took up his post, 8th April, 1891.

MILLER, Arthur, Library, India Office.—Writer, 11th Oct., 1867; clerk, 2nd class, March, 1880.

MILLER, John Francis James, Lieutenant-Colonel, I.S.C., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 13th Nov., 1868, as assistant engineer; executive engineer, Sept., 1874; served through the Afghan campaign, 1879-80 (medal); superintending examiner, Nov., 1890.

MILLER, John Ontario, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1879, and served in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, as assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, and assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Jan., 1883; under secretary to government, May, 1884; private secretary to the lieutenant-governor of the N.W. Provinces, Oct., 1886; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1887; settlement officer, 3rd grade, Oct., 1888; 2nd grade, Oct., 1890; director of land records and agriculture, March, 1892.

MILLER, Leslie Creery, Madras C.S.—Educated at Charterhouse, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1883; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1884; head assistant collector, June, 1890; manager, Pittapur estate, Jan., 1891, to June, 1892.

MILLETT, H., Barrister-at-Law, late Bengal Judicial Service.—Professor of English law, Presidency College, Calcutta, April, 1870; officiating judge, Calcutta court of small causes, Oct., 1871; receiver, high court, April to Dec., 1873; officiating assistant secretary, government of Bengal, legislative department, Dec., 1873, to April, 1875; first judge, Calcutta court of small causes, Jan., 1876; retired, 1889.

MILLETT, Montague, Colonel, Bengal Infantry, late Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 1857; arrived in India, 16th Oct., 1857; from Sept., 1864, served in the police department, Punjab, as assistant superintendent, and district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade superintendent, June, 1884; services placed at the disposal of government of India military department, Oct., 1887.

MINNS, Walter Hardwick Christopher, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Marlborough, and New College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1891, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

MIR SHUJAAT ALI KHAN, Madras C.S.—Served in the Madras revenue and judicial departments from Aug., 1876, in various subordinate posts, and was appointed by the government of India as probationer for the civil service from 15th Dec., 1881; assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Nov., 1889.

MIRZA ABBAS ALI BEY, B.A., Bombay C.S.—Appointed in India probationer under the native civil service rules, and joined the service as assistant to the collector of Thana, 1st April, 1890.

MITCHELL, Horace, Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Paul's School; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 27th March, 1885.

MITCHELL, Thomas Candy, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at University of Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1875, and served as assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal; from May, 1876, served in Burma as assistant commissioner and boundary and settlement officer; on special forest demarcation duty, Nov., 1880; on special duty in connection with waste land grants in Arakan division, March, 1882; deputy commissioner, 4th grade, Aug., 1886; assistant commissioner, April, 1888.

MITTER, Gopal Lal, Bengal Administration.—Appointed vice-chairman of the commissioners of Calcutta, 3rd Sept., 1884.

MOBERLY, Charles Morris, Colonel, I.S.C., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Ensign, and European regiment, Madras, May, 1855; joined the public works department, May, 1867, as examiner of railway accounts, Madras; controller of accounts, Calcutta, 1873; officiating deputy accountant-general, March, 1876; examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Calcutta, March, 1878; Rajputana railway accounts, 1879; acted as manager, Rajputana railway, May-Aug., 1881; on special duty as secretary to railway conference, Jan.-March, 1884; examiner, 1st class, in the accounts establishment, Jan., 1886; examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, March, 1887; reverted to military department, July, 1892.

MOBERLY, Henry, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Andrew's College, Bradfield, and King's College School, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and forest settlement officer; special assistant to collector and magistrate, Nov., 1888; special settlement officer, Malabar and South Canara, July, 1892.

MOCKLER, Edward, Colonel, Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Aug., 1859; served as assistant resident, Aden, Dec., 1866-1873; on civil employ, Mekran coast, from 1873; assistant to the governor-general's
agent, Beloochistan, Oct., 1879; assistant agent and consul, Busreh, Turkish Arabia, Nov., 1881; acted as political agent, Muscat, 1883, and again April, 1886, and April, 1887; graded as political agent, 2nd class; assistant political agent, Basra, Oct., 1883; political agent, Muscat, April, 1886; Basra, Jan., 1887; resumed his post at Muscat, April, 1887; officiating political resident, Turkish Arabia, Nov., 1891; confirmed, May, 1892; author of an Arabic grammar, a Beluchi grammar, &c.

MOHENDRO NATH BOSE, late Judicial Department, Bengal.—From 26th Feb., 1859, served in the subordinate judicial service, Bengal, and was appointed subordinate judge, 4th grade, Sept., 1868; small cause court judge, Mindapore, Feb., 1872; 1st grade subordinate judge, and small cause judge, Hooghly, Serampore, and Howrah, May, 1877; officiating judge, highcourt, Jan., 1882; judge of the principal courts of small causes in Nuddea and Jessore, and of the courts of small causes at Krishnagur, Ranaghat, and Bongong, Oct., 1884.

MOHSIN BADRUDIN TYABJI, Bombay C.S.—Educated at St. Mary's Institute and St. Xavier's College, Bombay, and at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1887; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1888.

MOIR, WILLIAM, M.A., M.B., Brigade Surgeon, late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 20th Jan., 1866; arrived in India, 27th April, 1866, and was employed in various military medical charges; from June, 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as civil assistant surgeon and superintendent of jail at Mainpuri, and afterwards at Meerut, and was placed in medical charge of the lock hospital at the latter place; held medical charge of camp of lieutenant-governor, 1863-64; superintendent, meteorological observatory, Meerut, June, 1868; rank of surgeon, Jan., 1872; surgeon-major, Jan., 1875; officiating chemical examiner, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1878 to March, 1879, and again in April, 1888; brigade surgeon, April, 1888; retired, April, 1891.

MOIR, WILLIAM ROBERT GRAY, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Charterhouse and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

MOLESWORTH, SIR GUILDFORD LINDSAY, K.C.I.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Educated at the College of Civil Engineers, Putney; in 1852 was chief assistant engineer on the London, Brighton, and South Coast Railway, which he left in order to superintend the construction of buildings and machinery in the Royal Arsenal at Woolwich, during the Crimean war; afterwards practised as a consulting engineer in London for some years; was awarded the 'Watt' medal and the 'Manby' premium by the Institution of Civil Engineers in 1858, for a paper read before the institution on the 'Conversion of Wood by Machinery;' engineer on the Ceylon railway, 1859; chief engineer, Ceylon government railway, 1862; director-general of the railway, 1865; director of public works in 1867; consulting engineer for state railways to the government of India, April, 1871; acted as director-general of railways and deputy secretary to government of India, March-June, 1880; K.C.I.E., June, 1888; retired, 1889; fellow of the University of Calcutta; a British delegate to the international monetary conference, Brussels, 1892; is the author of many publications on engineering, monetary, and other subjects, including a 'Pocket-book of Engineering Formulae,' which has passed through twenty-one editions; of 'Proposals for the Establishment of Decimal Coinage,' in Ceylon, 1865, and in India, 1871; of Reports on the Public Works of Ceylon, 1869, on Light Railways in Ceylon, 1870, on the Festiniog Railway, 1871, or State Railways in India, 1872, and on the Madras Harbour, 1884; 'Iron Manufacture in India,' 1884; 'Suggestions for the Establishment of an Engineer Volunteer Corps for India,' 1865; 'Imperialism for India,' 1885; 'Text-book of Bimetallism,' 1886, &c., &c.

MOLONY, EDMUND ALEXANDER, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1886, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector and assistant commissioner.

MONAHAN, FRANCIS JOHN, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at the Oratory School, Birmingham, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1885, and served as assistant magistrate and collector; officiated in 1889 as under secretary to the government of Bengal in the financial and municipal departments, and subsequently in the general, revenue, and statistical departments; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Dec., 1891; transferred to Assam as officiating deputy commissioner, March, 1892.

MONAHAN, JAMES HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Oratory School, Edgbaston, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881.

MONEY, ALONZO, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1843; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Backergunge, 1846; superintendent of survey, Monghyr, 1850; magistrate and collector, Behar, 1857, and afterwards of Shahabad and Tirhoot; magistrate, collector, and salt agent, Pooree, 1859; controller of government salt-chowkies, 1860; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Bhaugulpore, 1863; commissioner of Patna, and member of council of the lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1869; member of revenue board, Lower Provinces, 1869; district and sessions judge, Bareilly, and member of revenue board, 1875; retired, 1878.

MONEY, ROBERT COTTON, Major-General, I.S.C.—First commission in army, 20th March, 1855; from 1st March, 1861, served in the non-regulation commission, Bengal, and was appointed deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1877; manager of the Durbhunga Raj estate, April, 1876, to Jan., 1878, and again, Jan., 1880; retired, April, 1886.

MONEY, WILLIAM JAMES, C.S.I., late Bengal
C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1853; served in the revenue and survey departments in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant superintendent of survey, and was employed as civil officer with the troops in the Sonthal insurrection, 1855-56; private secretary to Sir James Outram, chief commissioner of Oudh, Aug., 1857; during the mutiny was present at several engagements, and was a member of the garrison of Lucknow; mutiny medal; served subsequently in Bengal and N.W. Provinces, and was appointed superintendent of revenue survey, 1860, in Jessore, and afterwards in other districts; magistrate and collector, and salt agent, Cuttack, 1861; officiated as district and sessions judge, Mymensingh, from 1869, and was confirmed in that appointment, Sept., 1873; retired, 1879.

MONK, HUGH LEWIN, M.I.C.E., India Public Works Department.—Apprentice engineer, 1st Sept., 1865; assistant engineer, April, 1866; transferred to state railways, Dec., 1869; executive engineer, Sept., 1873; engineer-in-chief, Mu valley railway, April, 1891; supervising engineer, 3rd class, Jan., 1892.

MONRO, ALEXANDER, M.A., B.C.L., B.L., Education Department, Central Provinces.—Arrived in India, 2nd June, 1879; inspector of schools, 4th class, graded educational department, June, 1879; fellow of Madras University, March, 1885; member of the conference on the school fee question, Aug., 1886; inspector-general of education, Central Provinces, Jan., 1889.

MONRO, JAMES, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Arrived in India, and appointed a junior civil servant, 27th Jan., 1858; served as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating under-secretary to the government of Bengal, and in April, 1864, was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector; from Sept., 1864, served for various periods as officiating magistrate and collector, deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, and secretary to the board of revenue; appointed magistrate and collector, Feb., 1872, and district and sessions judge, April, 1874; inspector-general of police, Bengal, Jan., 1878; on special duty to report on the system of village police, Nov., 1882; commissioner of the presidency division, March, 1883; retired from the Bengal civil service, 1884, and was appointed director of criminal investigations in Scotland Yard; in Nov., 1888, was appointed chief commissioner of metropolitan police, but resigned that office, June, 1890.

MONTEATH, ALEXANDER M., C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, Edinburgh University, and Haileybury College, from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1856; arrived in India, 1857; assistant magistrate and collector, Allahabad, 1858; assistant secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1859; under secretary to government of India, financial and home departments, 1861; director-general of the post office of India from 1867 till his retirement in 1881, during which period he was placed for about two years on postal duty in England including the representation of India at the postal conference at Berne in 1876.

MONTEATH, JAMES, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Royal Academical Institution, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; on special duty in Bombay in connexion with the Kanara land assessment case, Nov., 1873; also acted for various periods as under secretary to government of Bombay in the revenue, financial, and general departments, under secretary to government in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the Bombay legislative council, and as assistant judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan; appointed under secretary to government, revenue, financial, and general departments, May, 1884, and acted as secretary, Sept.–Dec., 1884 and March, 1889; private secretary to the governor, Oct., 1886; acting collector of land revenue, &c., Bombay, April, 1890; junior collector and magistrate, Aug., 1891.

MONTGOMERY, JAMES ALEXANDER LAWRENCE, Major, I.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 26th Feb., 1868; from Nov., 1870, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; settlement officer, 1st grade, Sept., 1880; director of settlement and revenue records in the Punjab, Dec., 1885; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, May, 1887; 2nd grade, May, 1889; author of a report on the settlement of the Hoshiarpur district.

MOORE, ERNEST ANDREW, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Bradfield College and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Burma division of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in Burma, 25th Nov., 1889, and served as assistant commissioner.

MOORE, GEORGE MONTGOMERY J., Lieut.-Col., R.A.—Military secretary on personal staff of the governor of Madras (Rt. Hon. Sir M. E. Grant Duff, G.C.S.I., C.I.E.), 1st April, 1884 to 1886; president of Madras municipal commission.

MOORE, JOHN GEORGE, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1856; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1856, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector, magistrate, and political agent; served in Sind from Dec., 1862, to Nov., 1870, as assistant commissioner, educational inspector, branch registrar-general, and acting commissioner; junior collector and magistrate, Sattara, Oct., 1876; senior collector and magistrate, Sept., 1877; on special duty as president of the jail commission, July–Sept., 1878; was subsequently collector and magistrate of Poonah, and acted on several occasions as commissioner of the southern and central divisions, Bombay, and as commissioner of customs, salt and opium, Feb., 1885; acting commissioner of customs, salt, opium, and abkari, and reporter-general of external commerce, May, 1887; and grade commissioner, and commissioner, central division, July, 1888; 1st grade, Sept., 1888; temporary member of governor's council, March, 1890; retired, Nov., 1891.

MOORE, LEWIS, Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867;
arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1869, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, sub-collector and joint magistrate (Dec., 1884), acting district and sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; district and sessions judge, Dec., 1888; compiled 'Trichinopoly District Manual.'

MOORE, Ross Arthur Leslie, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Dulwich, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1883; 2nd assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1891.

MOORE, Sir William James, Surgeon-General, K.C.I.E., late Medical Department, Bombay.—First commission, Indian medical department, 1852; was employed on regimental and other military duty till April, 1862, when he was appointed residency surgeon at Jodhpur, and afterwards at Marwar; served from Aug., 1867, in Rajputana as agency surgeon and superintendent-general of dispensaries and vaccination; acting deputy surgeon-general, Bombay, 1877; deputy surgeon-general, Oct., 1877; surgeon-general with the government of Bombay, 1st April, 1885; hon. surgeon to the Viceroy; retired, Feb., 1888; K.C.I.E., May, 1888.

MORELAND, William Harrison, B.A., LL.B., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

MORGAN, Charles, Registry Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 22nd April, 1857; assistant to registrar, Oct., 1874; despatch clerk, Oct., 1892.

MORGAN, Sir Walter, late Madras High Court.—Called to the bar, Middle Temple, 18th Nov., 1844; clerk of legislative council of India, 1854-59; master in equity of the supreme court, Calcutta, 1859-62; puisne judge of Calcutta high court, 1862-66; chief justice of the high court of the N.W. Provinces, 1866-71; and of the high court of Madras from 1871, until his retirement in 1879.

MORIARTY, Arthur Stephen, B.L., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1880, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge.

MORISON, William Thomson, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Fettes College, Edinburgh, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1881, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer; transferred to Burma as assistant-commissioner, 1887; deputy commissioner, May, 1889; re-transferred as 2nd assistant, Nov., 1891.

MORRIS, John George, I.S.C., Captain, Berar Administration.—Joined the service, 28th February, 1874, and served under the military department to Nov., 1890; acted as boundary settlement officer, Bhopal, to Nov., 1882; officiating cantonment magistrate, Saugor, Dec., 1882; confirmed, March, 1883; assistant commissioner, April, 1887; special assistant commissioner, July, 1890.

MORRIS, Sir John H., K.C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1847; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1848; served in the Punjab as assistant resident, Lahore, assistant commissioner and assistant settlement officer in the Trans-Sutlej division; settlement officer, Mooltan, 1854; magistrate and collector, Allahabad, May, 1862; settlement commissioner, Central Provinces, Sept., 1863; judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, June, 1868; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, May, 1870; retired, 1883.

MORRIS, Matthew, Police Department, Punjab.—Appointed to the police department, 12th Feb., 1861, as assistant district superintendent; served in the various grades of the department, and was promoted to be district superintendent, 1st grade, March, 1888.

MORRIS, Robert, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at High School, Glasgow, University of Glasgow, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Jan., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, March, 1885; head assistant, Jan., 1891; acting deputy accountant general, Madras, April, 1891; confirmed, May, 1891.

MORRISON, Frank, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Served in the telegraph department, Sept., 1863, to Feb., 1864; rejoined government service, and was employed in the accounts establishment (public works) in Bombay, Sind, the Punjab, and Calcutta; deputy controller, Nov., 1874; examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Lahore, Dec., 1875; examiner, Indus Valley railway, June, 1878; examiner of P.W. accounts, Hyderabad, Dec., 1879; Northern Bengal railway accounts, May, 1882; examiner, 3rd class, May, 1886; acted as examiner of guaranteed railway accounts, Bombay, 1886-87; examiner, southern Mahratta railway company, March, 1887; examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Madras, March, 1888; government examiner of accounts, East Indian railway, Nov., 1891.

MORSHEAD, Leonard Frederick, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1889, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

MORTON, Boyce William Dunlop, Major-General, I.S.C., late Non-Regulation Commission, Bengal.—First commission, 9th June, 1848; served in Assam from June, 1854, as junior assistant and principal assistant to the commissioner; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Goalpara, April, 1861; superintendent of Darjeeling, Dec., 1866; on special duty for conducting the prosecution of Captain Playfair, Aug., 1876; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; retired, Aug., 1885.

MOSCARDI, Edward Henry, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Somersetshire College, Bath, and Worcester College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 7th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; on special duty compiling the general administration report of the Bombay
Presidency, Aug., 1881; from Dec., 1881, served in the judicial department, and was appointed and grade assistant judge, Oct., 1883, and 1st grade, April, 1890.

MOSLEY, HERBERT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Bishop’s Stortford Collegiate School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from April, 1865, served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, and 2nd grade, May, 1884; and 1st grade, March, 1888; retired, Jan., 1891.

MOULE, HORACE FREDERICK D’OYLY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector, and was placed on special duty in 1872 to conduct the prosecution of the sub-judge of Mirzapur; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Sept., 1879; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, June, 1884; 1st grade, Dec., 1886; officiated as district and sessions judge, July and Oct., 1887, and May-Aug., 1888; secretary, board of revenue, Jan.-May, 1886; officiating commissioner, Lucknow division, March, 1890; confirmed, Nov., 1891.

MOUNSEY, CHARLES HERBERT, B.L., Madras C.S.—Educated at King’s College School; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived, 3rd Dec., 1878, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant sessions judge, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; head assistant, Anantapur, May, 1886; sub-collector and joint magistrate, June, 1890; acting district and sessions judge in 1890 and 1891; compiled and edited the ‘Reports of the Meriah Agents (Ganjam),’ and wrote a ‘History of the Ganjam Mahals.’

MOWAT, M., M.A., late Education Department, Bengal.—Professor, Presidency College, June, 1876; Dacca College, Jan., 1878; officiating inspector of schools, Nov., 1879; professor, Patna College, Feb., 1880; officiating principal, Patna College, May, 1883; 3rd class of the education department, July, 1883; officiating principal, Hooghly College, April, 1885; retired, 1891.

MUHAMMAD ABBAS, MIRZA, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces and Oudh).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 16th Feb., 1880; confirmed as covenanted civil servant, March, 1882; and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner; joint magistrate, Oct., 1888.

MUHAMMAD AFZAL KHAN WAZIR-ZADAH, C.S.I., Sirdar, Lieutenant-Colonel, 11th Bengal Lancers.—Appointed British agent at the court of H.H. the Amir of Kabul, March, 1882; A.D.C. to governor-general; retired, 1885.

MUHAMMAD AFZAL KHAN, SIRDAR, KHAN BAHAUDUR, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Probationer under native civil service rules, 3rd March, 1881; assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Oct., 1885; services placed at disposal of foreign department, government of India, April, 1891; British agent at Kabul, June, 1891.

MUHAMMAD ALI, SAIFID, B.A., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Appointed to be a probationary assistant magistrate and collector under the statutory rules, 4th April, 1887; confirmed in the civil service, 17th April, 1889, as assistant magistrate and collector.

MUHAMMAD ASLAM KHAN, KAZI, C.M.G., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Officiating extra-assistant commissioner, 10th Sept., 1881; on special duty in civil secretariat, Dec., 1881; probationer under native civil service rules, Nov., 1882; assistant commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; on special duty with Afghan boundary commission, Aug., 1884, to Nov., 1886; appointed Mir Munshi to Punjab government, May, 1887; native attache to foreign office, April, 1888; assistant commissioner, March, 1889; officiated as district judge in 1890, and deputy commissioner in the same year, and from March, 1891.

MUHAMMAD HADI, SAIFID, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Appointed under the native civil service rules probationary assistant magistrate and collector, 5th April, 1890; assistant director of land records and agriculture, Dec., 1891.

MUHAMMAD HYAT KHAN, KHAN, C.S.I., Punjab Commission.—Joined the service, 16th April, 1858; extra-assistant commissioner, Punjab, March, 1862; promoted to assistant commissioner, Jan., 1872; C.S.I., May, 1872; on special duty with the camp of exercise at Hassan Abdal, 1873; officiating political assistant with the Kurram field force, 1878; political officer with the staff of Sir F. Roberts, Kabul field force, 1879-80; officiating judicial assistant, March, 1876; officiating district judge, at various periods from Nov. 1884; confirmed, Dec., 1886; divisional judge, March, 1890.

MUHAMMAD ISHAK KHAN, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces and Oudh).—Appointed a probationer under native civil service rules, Jan., 1884; confirmed in the civil service, Aug., 1886; assistant magistrate and collector, April, 1888; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1889; joint magistrate, May, 1890.

MUHAMMAD RAZA KHAN SAHIB, Madras C.S.—Served from Jan., 1874, in subordinate posts in the Madras revenue and educational departments, and in Hyderabad as attache to the resident; appointed by the government of India to be a member of the Madras civil service, 3rd Nov., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1883; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Feb., 1890.

MUHAMMAD SAMI-ULLA KHAN, MAULVI, C.M.G., Judicial Department, N.W. Provinces.—Joined the service as sub-judge, 1st May, 1873; district judge, sub-pro tem., April, 1885 and April, 1886; officiated as district judge in 1886 and 1887, and was confirmed in the appointment, May, 1887.

MUIR, ARCHIBALD MUNGO, Major, I.S.C., Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, 4th hussars, 30th Sept., 1868; served in the Afghan war, 1878-80, including the action of Takht-i-Pul, and siege of Kandahar (medal and clasp) in Sept., 1873; appointed private secretary and A.D.C. to lieut.-governor N.W. provinces, from Aug., 1878; served in the foreign department in 1878, as assistant agent to the governor-general.
in Rajputana, and afterwards as political officer at Kandahar, and as assistant general superintendent for the suppression of thuggee and dacoity; assistant boundary settlement officer, Central India, Nov., 1883, and in Rajputana, Nov., 1885; cantonment magistrate at Nasirabad, April, 1886, and afterwards at Hyderabad; and assistant and assistant secretary for Berar to the resident, Jan., 1889; political agent, S.E. Baluchistan, July, 1890; political agent, Bhopawar, April, 1892.

MUIR, JOHN FAIRLIE, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh Academy, and Rugby School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 10th Oct., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Sept., 1869, to April, 1874, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting assistant secretary and personal assistant to the chief commissioner, and acting deputy commissioner; from April, 1874, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; 1st assistant collector, May, 1880; junior collector and magistrate, April, 1887; senior collector, June, 1890.

MUIR, JULIUS WOOD, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Dumfries Academy, and Edinburgh University; called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, officiating magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; joint magistrate, and grade, July, 1883; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, in Oudh, Sept., 1885; district and sessions judge, Nov., 1889.

MUIR, SIR WILLIAM, K.C.S.I., D.C.L., LL.D., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Kilmar-nock Grammar School, and Edinburgh and Glasgow Universities; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury, 1837; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1837; settlement officer in Cawnpore and Bundelkund, 1840-1843; officiating collector, Futtehpore, 1844-1845; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1852; member, board of revenue, 1856; in charge of intelligence department at Agra during mutiny, 1857; secretary with Lord Canning at Allahabad for N.W. Provinces, 1858; reverted to board of revenue, 1859; member of legislative council of governor-general, 1864; foreign secretary, government of India, 1865; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, 1868-1874; financial member of governor-general's council, 1874-76; member of council of secretary of state, 1876-85; principal, Edinburgh University, 1885; honorary D.C.L. of Oxford, and LL.D. of Glasgow and Edinburgh; author of 'Life of Mahomet and History of Islam to the Era of the Hegira, 1858; 'Annals of the Early Caliphate,' 1883, and other works on the same subject; pamphlet on indigenous education in Futtehpore, 1845; papers on revenue settlement in the N.W. Provinces and Oudh, &c.

MUIR, WILLIAM JAMES WEMYSS, Colonel, I.S.C., late Foreign Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant Bengal artillery, Dec., 1858; assistant agent to governor-general, Rajputana, Sept., 1863; assistant general superintendent, thagi and dakaiti, June, 1864; political superintendent, Sirohi, Sept., 1865; officiated for some time as agent of Haraoti and Tonk; political agent, Moorsheadabad, 1876; cantonment magistrate, Neemuch, 1879; Haraoti and Tonk, 1880; graded as political agent, 1st class; cantonment magistrate, Ajmere-Merwara, May, 1889; officiating political agent, Ulwar, Aug., 1889; retired, June, 1892.

MUIR-MACKENZIE, JOHN WILLIAM PITTS, M.R.A.C., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant political agent in charge of Jath state, and forest settlement officer; on famine duty in 1876 and 1877; on duty at Royal Agricultural College, Cirencester, Oct., 1886, to Oct., 1887; 2nd assistant collector and magistrate, Nov., 1887; acting director of land records and agriculture, Feb., 1888; under secretary to government of India in revenue and agricultural departments, March, 1889; officiated as secretary in 1889, 1890, and 1891.

MULLALY, CHARLES MYLNE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Southampton Grammar School, Hartley Institution, Southampton, and London University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1883; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Nov., 1887; acted as secretary to the commissioners of salt, &c., revenue, in Aug., 1891.

MULLEN, DOUGLAS FRENCH, Surgeon-Major, M.D., Foreign Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 31st March, 1877; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1877, and served on general and military duty; from April, 1878, served under the foreign department in medical charge of the Meywar Bhil corps, and officiating residency surgeon, Meywar; was confirmed in the latter appointment, Nov., 1886.

MULLINS, JOHN, Lieut-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—2nd lieutenant, Madras engineers, 8th Dec., 1848; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1850; assistant civil engineer, Feb., 1852; served as 1st class district engineer in Nellore and Tanjore, 1858-64; consulting engineer for the irrigation and canal company, Madras, May, 1864, to Aug., 1869; under secretary to government, public works department, Feb., 1869; chief engineer for irrigation and joint secretary to government of Madras, public works department, Nov., 1870; acted as chief engineer and secretary to government in 1875 and 1877; president, irrigation committee, famine commission, Oct., 1878, to Jan., 1879; on special duty for drawing up the Bangalore water supply scheme, Oct., 1883; services replaced at disposal of military department, in 1884; retired, 1886; author of 'Madras Irrigation Manual.'

MULOCK, FRANCIS BERRY, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Portora Royal School, Enniskillen, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of
1869; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; on special duty as assistant private secretary to lieutenant-governor on occasion of visit of H.R.H. Prince of Wales, Dec., 1875, to March, 1876; on special duty for arrangements connected with Imperial assemblage at Delhi, Nov., 1876; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, April, 1886; joint magistrate, 1st grade, April, 1887; magistrate and collector, Feb., 1890.

MULOCK, Henry Pilkington, Bengal C.S. (North - Western Provinces).—Educated at Kingstown School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1865; from Feb., 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred temporarily to Bengal for employment on Behar famine relief works, Dec., 1873, to Oct., 1874; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1878; district and sessions judge, 3rd grade, Aug., 1886; 2nd grade, Dec., 1890.

MULOCK, William Bury, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived 28th Nov., 1862, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant registrar of the high court, and assistant collector and magistrate; from April, 1873, to Nov., 1876, served as assistant commissioner and branch inspector-general of assurances in Sind, also as inspector of education, May–Nov., 1873, and was on various occasions in charge of the office of the commissioner; junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Panch Mahals, and political agent, Rewa Kantha, Jan., 1880; acting collector of Bombay, and superintendent of stamps and stationery, June, 1884; senior collector and magistrate, Nasik, March, 1885; acting commissioner, northern division, Sept., 1888; retired, Nov., 1889.

MUNRO, James Hume, Madras C.S.—Educated at Newcastle-on-Tyne grammar school, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in Madras, 21st Nov., 1886, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to the collector and magistrate.

MUNRO, W. H., Accounts Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India office, 31st Jan., 1861; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

MURDOCH, David Doig, Madras C.S.—Educated at University of Aberdeen, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived, 7th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate in Kistna and Chingleput, Sept., 1884; head assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1890.

MURPHY, Matthew Joseph, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, Blackrock, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived in India, 21st Dec., 1891, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

MURRAY, Alan, Major-General, I.S.C., late Oudh Commission.—Arrived in India, 4th Feb., 1857, as ensign, Bengal Fusiliers; during the mutiny served at the siege of Delhi, and was present at the relief of Lucknow, Nov., 1857; served subsequently with Sir James Outram's force, Nov., 1857 to Feb., 1858, and took part in the pursuit of the rebel Tantia Topee, Jan., 1859 (medal and two clasps); served in the Oudh Police department as assistant superintendent from June, 1866 to April, 1867, and subsequently in the Oudh commission as assistant commissioner, and assistant settlement officer; junior secretary to chief commissioner, 1874–1878, and acted as director of public instruction, Jan.–March, 1874, and as personal assistant to chief commissioner, April-Aug., 1876; attaché in foreign office, Nov., 1876 to Jan., 1877; in charge of Oudh Gazetteer, Aug., 1877 to Feb., 1878; officiated as cantonment magistrate and wasika officer, Lucknow, in 1879, and in 1881–82; district judge, April, 1886; deputy commissioner, Kheri, April, 1886; retired, March, 1887.

MURRAY, John, Inspector-General of Hospitals, M.D., late Bengal Medical Service.—Educated at Peterhead, and Marischal College, and University of Aberdeen; A.M., 1828; M.D., University of Edinburgh, 1831; M.R.C.S., London, 1831; assistant surgeon, Indian medical service, 1832; field surgeon at the battle of Aliwal, 1846; surgeon, 1848; deputy inspector-general of hospitals, 1853; inspector-general of hospitals, 1865; retired Jan., 1871; has written various papers on cholera and its treatment.

MUTHUSWAMI AIYAR, Sir Tiruvarur, B.L., K.C.I.E., Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from 1st May, 1854, in various subordinate posts in the Madras educational, revenue, and judicial departments; deputy collector, July, 1859; magistrate of police, Nov., 1868; judge of the court of small causes, Madras, May, 1871; fellow of University of Madras, April, 1872; on duty at the Imperial assemblage, Delhi, Jan., 1877; C.I.E., Jan., 1878; judge, high court, Madras, Aug., 1883; acted as chief justice in 1891; K.C.I.E., May, 1892.

MYLNE, Right Rev. Louis George, M.A., D.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Bombay.—Arrived 4th July, 1876; installed as Bishop of Bombay, 6th July, 1876.

NANDA KRISHNA BOSE, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Employed in the education department from Aug., 1878; appointed under the native civil service rules, and served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, from Jan., 1880, as assistant magistrate and collector on probation; confirmed in his appointment in the civil service, Sept., 1881; joint magistrate and collector, June, 1890.

NANNEY, Lewis Charles, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, L.F.P.S., L.S.A., late Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 31st March, 1886; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1886; served under the military department, also acting as civil surgeon at various stations, and as superintendent of jail; acting presiding surgeon, Madras, 1872–73; superintendent, lunatic asylum, Madras, Oct., 1875; also professor of materia medica, medical college, July, 1876; surgeon-major, March, 1878; medical officer, Coonoor and Kotagiri, 1879–1881, and at Ootacamund, 1881–1883; special sanitary officer, Ootacamund, Aug., 1881, to July, 1883; civil surgeon, Cannanore, July, 1883; civil surgeon, Trichinopoly, June,
NAPIER AND ETTRICK (BARON), RIGHT HON. FRANCIS NAPIER, K.T.—Attaché to the embassy at Vienna in 1840, and afterwards at Constantinople; served as secretary of legation at Naples and St. Petersburg, and was appointed secretary of embassy at Constantinople in 1854; British minister at Washington, 1857, whence he was transferred to the Hague, 1858, to St. Petersburg in 1860, and to Berlin in 1864; governor of Madras, March, 1866 till Feb., 1872; on the assassination of Lord Mayo, acted temporarily as viceroy; was president of the Social Science Association at Plymouth in 1872; and presided over the education section of the Association at Glasgow, in Oct., 1874; a royal commissioner on the Highland Crofters' question, March, 1883.

NAPIER, ALAN BERTRAM, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Rossall school, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 24th Sept., 1889, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, and registrar of the judicial commissioner's court; under secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1892.

NAPIER, HON. GEORGE CAMPBELL, C.I.E., Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Infantry, late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1861; from July, 1867, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and officiating small cause court judge; on special duty, March, 1874, in Persia, and again, Feb., 1881, at Kandahar; private secretary and aide-de-camp to lieutenant-governor of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1882, to Sept., 1883; judicial assistant, Feb., 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; superintendent, Kapurthala State, April, 1885; retired, April, 1887.

NARAIN DAS, RAJ BAHADUR, Oudh Judicial Department.—Served in the postal department from June, 1855; temporary extra assistant commissioner, March, 1867; sub-judge, 3rd grade, Oct., 1881; judge of the small cause court, June, 1882; officiated as district judge, June, 1885, and April, 1887.

NARENDRA NATH, DIWAN, M.A., Punjab Administration.—Appointed probationer under native civil service rules, 3rd Feb., 1888; assistant commissioner, Feb., 1890.

NARSINGRAO BHOLANATH DIVATIA, Bombay C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, Jan., 1844, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; confirmed in the Bombay civil service, March, 1886.

NARUL HUDA, SYED, B.A., LL.B., B.L., Bengal C.S.—Joined the service 4th Aug., 1886, as officiating munsiff; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1887.

NASH, ALFRED MOSES, M.A., Education Department, Bengal.—Appointed, 11th Jan., 1875; arrived, 31st March, 1875; served as assistant professor, presidency college, and officiating inspector of European schools; and class of the education department, April, 1883; professor, presidency college, Nov., 1890; also registrar, Calcutta University, May, 1891.
