SETON-KARR, WALTER SCOTT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, where he gained honours, in 1842; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1842; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate of Jessore, 1847; under secretary, government of Bengal, 1847-53; member of council of education, 1853; collector of Tirhoot, 1857; civil and sessions judge, Jessore, 1858-60; president of indigo commission, 1860; secretary to government of Bengal, 1860-61; legislative council of India, 1861; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Chittagong, and member of council of lieutenant-governor of Bengal, 1862; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, July, 1862, to April, 1868; foreign secretary, government of India, April, 1868; retired, 1870; vice-chancellor of the University of Calcutta in 1868 and 1869; is a member of the council of Marlborough College.

SEWELL, EBENEZER JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at University College, London; ap-
pointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1872, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting principal assistant collector and additional sessions judge, and acting collector and magistrate; on famine duty, June, 1877, to Sept., 1878; senior assistant collector and magistrate, Ganjam, June, 1882; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Dec., 1887; district and sessions judge, Oct., 1889; collector and magistrate, Feb., 1890; district and sessions judge, North Arcot, Jan., 1891.

SEWELL, HENRY, M.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Radley, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; served in Madras, as assistant magistrate and collector, acting small cause court judge, acting under secretary to government in the revenue department, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting district and sessions judge, North Arcot, June, 1874, to April, 1875; from May, 1875, served as collector and magistrate, Trichinopoly, and political agent, Pudukkota; district and sessions judge, North Arcot, Nov., 1886; collector and magistrate, South Arcot, Nov., 1887; retired, Jan., 1891.

SEWELL, ROBERT, Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1868, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-secretary to the board of revenue, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; on famine duty, Oct., 1877, and on special duty in connection with the archaeological survey of the Madras presidency, Jan., 1881, and again, Jan., 1883; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Tinnevelly, Sept., 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1887; acted as collector and magistrate, and in Sept., 1888, was appointed district and sessions judge, Kistna; collector and magistrate, Bellary, Feb., 1890; district and sessions judge, March, 1890; collector and magistrate, Jan., 1891; author of the following works, published by order of government:—'A Report on the Amaravati Tope, and Excavations on its Site,' 1880; 'Chronological Tables for Southern India from the 6th Century, A.D.,' 1881; 'A Sketch of the Dynasties of Southern India,' 1883; volumes I. and II. of the 'Archaeological Survey Series of Southern India,' 1882 and 1884; 'Early Buddhist Symbolism,' 1886; &c.

SHAKESPEAR, ALEXANDER MURISON WAKE, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1878, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, and grade, Aug., 1887; private secretary to lieutenant-governor, March, 1888; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Jan., 1890; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1890.

SHANKAR PANDURANG PANDIT, RAO BAHADUR, M.A., Political Department, Bombay.—Joined the service as 5th grade district deputy collector and magistrate, June, 1872 (having previously held acting educational appointments); employed on special duty in Surat in 1873, and in England in 1874; oriental translator to government, June, 1879; and grade deputy collector, and Huzur deputy collector, Dec., 1887; administrator of the Porbandar state, Feb., 1890.

SHANKER MADHO CHITNAVIS, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Appointed a probationer for the civil service under the statutory rules, July, 1885; admitted member of the statutory service, and appointed assistant commissioner, Oct., 1887.

SHARP, F. W., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Milton College, Ellesmere; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, March, 1885.

SHARP, HENRY GRANVILLE, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Horncastle Grammar School, Marlborough College, and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1868; served in the revenue and judicial departments in Bengal; on special duty at Madras on famine relief work, Feb., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Dec., 1878; magistrate and collector, Oct., 1884.

SHARPE, CHARLES FERGUSON, Colonel, L.S.C., late Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign, 1st Feb., 1851, and served under the military department till Sept., 1858, when he was appointed to the Oudh military police; medal for mutiny services; from Feb., 1859, served as district superintendent in the police department in Oudh, and was promoted to 1st grade, April, 1876; reverted to military duty, March, 1891.

SHARPE, F. R., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at Christ's Hospital; writer, India office, 7th Aug., 1877; clerk, 2nd class, Sept. 1878.

SHARPE, HENRY GRATTAN, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Dublin High School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 12th Nov., 1890, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

SHARPIN, VEN. FREDERICK LLOYD, M.A. (Exeter College, Oxford), late Ecclesiastical Department, Bombay.—Joined the service, Aug., 1865; arrived in India, 13th Oct., 1865; served as chaplain at various stations in Bombay and Sind; senior chaplain, Oct., 1875; senior presidency chaplain, June, 1880; archdeacon and commissary, June, 1886, also chaplain of Satara; retired, Oct., 1888.

SHAW, ARTHUR TREVOR AMBROSE, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Cheltenham College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1883, and served as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, Feb., 1886; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1890.

SHAW, CHARLES G., late Store Department, India Office.—East India House writer, old establishment, 17th Jan., 1855; junior clerk, store department, July, 1855; senior clerk, June, 1860; assistant to director-general, Nov., 1876; retired, 1889.

SHAW, GEORGE WATSON, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Hertford Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competi-
tive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1879, and served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, May, 1883.

SHAW, PATRICK DUNLOP, B.L., Judicial Department, Madras.—Acted as presidency magistrate at various periods from May, 1880; as crown prosecutor and public prosecutor from July, 1887; and as chief judge, Madras court of small causes, July, 1889.

SHAW-MACKENZIE, CHARLES FORBES HUDSON, Barrister-at-Law, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 21st Aug., 1850, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate up to Feb., 1864, and subsequently as judge and sessions judge in various districts; retired, Sept., 1885.

SHAW-STEWART, JOHN HERON MAXWELL, Major-General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Madras Engineers, June, 1851; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1853; served in the Madras public works department from Jan., 1854, as assistant engineer and executive engineer; served in the China campaign, 1860 (medal and two clasps); deputy secretary to government, public works department, Dec., 1863; under secretary to government, Oct., 1866; controller, public works accounts, Madras, May, 1867; consulting engineer for railways, Madras, Oct., 1867; chief engineer, Oct., 1870; joint secretary to government, railway branch, Feb., 1877; chief engineer, 1st class, and secretary to government, public works department, Sept., 1883; additional member of council, Madras, for making laws and regulations, Sept., 1883; retired, Sept., 1886.

SHEPHARD, HORATIO HALE, M.A., B.L., Madras Judicial Department.—Professor of law at Presidency College, Madras, 1st Oct., 1873; acted as government pleader from time to time from Dec., 1874; fellow of Madras University, March, 1881; appointed government pleader, June, 1881; additional member of Madras legislative council, March, 1885; advocate-general of Madras and officiating judge of high court, Jan., 1883; confirmed as judge of high court, July, 1889.

SHEPPARD, GEORGE FREDERICK, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1854, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; acting collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, Jan., 1870; on special duty in Bombay, March, 1870; collector of salt revenue, Bombay, Dec., 1871; collector and magistrate, Kaira, Feb., 1873; senior collector and magistrate and political agent, Kaira, Nov., 1875; on special duty at Poona, Oct., 1878; from Nov., 1880, acted as commissioner, and was confirmed as 2nd grade commissioner, Oct., 1882; 1st grade commissioner, March, 1886; retired, May, 1889.

SHEPPARD, WILLIAM DIDSBURY, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Hereford Cathedral School and New College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1834; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1836; assistant collector and magistrate, Oct., 1837.

SHERER, JOHN WALTER, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1846; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; assistant secretary to government of N.W. Provinces, 1852; on special duty under board of revenue to report on reh efflorescence, Western Jamuna Canal, 1856–57; magistrate and collector of Cawnpore, 1857; civil officer with General Havelock's column in 1857, in the advance on Cawnpore; special commissioner to try rebels; commissioner to enquire into claims against the former king of Oudh, 1864; member of jail committee, Calcutta, 1864; judge of Allahabad, 1871, and afterwards of Azimgurh and Mirzapore; retired 1877.

SHERIDAN, PHILIP, Post Office Department, Government of India.—Served in the postal department, Punjab, from March, 1861, as postmaster, assistant superintendent of military horse van dak, and inspector; chief superintendent, travelling post office, Allahabad, Dec., 1873; chief inspector of post offices, Assam, Dec., 1873; assistant director-general of the post office of India, July, 1880; inspector of railway and mail service, Nov., 1885; deputy director-general of the post-office of India, April, 1888; officiated as postmaster-general, Calcutta, in 1889 and 1890; postmaster-general, Lahore, July, 1891.

SHERRING, CHARLES ATMORE, B.A., Bengal C.S. (N.W.Provinces).—Educated at Westminster and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

SHEWAN, ALEXANDER, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Gymnasium, Aberdeen, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1873, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant political agent in charge of Jath state, and acting forest settlement officer; on famine duty in 1876 and 1877; on special forest duty in connection with the dahl cultivation settlement in Ahmednagar, March, 1881, and Feb., 1882; from Jan., 1885, served as assistant judge and sessions judge; acting under secretary to government, Bombay, political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the legislative council in 1886 and 1892; administrator of the Rajpipla state, Nov., 1887.

SHIPLEY, REGINALD HEBER, Madras C.S.—Educated at Winchester and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 20th Dec., 1883; and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; special assistant, July, 1890.

SHIRRES, LESLIE PITTEDRIGH, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Aberdeen and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1882; served in the revenue and judicial department of Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; officiated as under secretary to government of Bengal, Feb., 1887, and was confirmed, Jan., 1883; officiated as under secretary to the government of India, department of finance and commerce, in Nov., 1887, and again from April, 1888; officiating junior secretary to board of revenue, April, 1889; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Aug., 1890.
SHORTREDE, Robert, Audit Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 1st Feb., 1864; junior examiner, Sept., 1866; senior examiner, July, 1873.

SHIRIRAM BHIKAJI JATAR, Rao Bahadur, B.A., Hyderabad Administration.—Served in the Bombay education department from Jan., 1859, in the Marathi translator's office, and as assistant master in the high schools at Bombay and Belgaum, and head master of the Carwar English school; from July, 1867, served in Berar as deputy educational inspector, and acting head master, high school, Amraoti; educational inspector, Aug., 1876; director of public instruction, Hyderabad assigned districts, Aug., 1884.

SHURLOCK, H. J., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, Aug., 1886.

SHUTTLEWORTH, Allen Thornton, Forest Department, Bombay.—Appointed to the Indian marine, Nov., 1835; arrived in India, 21st April, 1836; served in the Persian War, including the bombardment of Bushire and Mohumerah (medal), and in the operations against the Wagheers in Okhamandal; from Nov., 1863, served in the Bombay forest department as assistant conservator, and deputy conservator, and was appointed conservator of forests and superintendent of botanical gardens, Sept., 1869; 1st grade conservator, Nov., 1881; while stationed at Alibag as deputy conservator of forests was instrumental in saving upwards of a hundred lives from different wrecks; these services were acknowledged in different ways by the government of Bombay, the Bombay Harbour Board, and the merchants of Bombay; Albert medal of the 1st class; medals of the Royal Humane Society, the Shipwrecked Mariners' Company, and Lloyds, &c.

SIBTHORPE, Charles, Surgeon-Colonel, L.R.C.S., F.K. and Q.C.P. (Dublin), Madras Medical Department.—Assistant surgeon, 1st April, 1870; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1870; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Banda, July, 1874; from May, 1875, to Nov., 1880, served as resident surgeon, general hospital, Madras, and professor of pathology and materia medica in the medical college, and acted for various periods as surgeon, general hospital, and professor of surgery, and as ophthalmic surgeon, and professor of ophthalmic surgery and physiology; also served in the Afghan war, 1878-79 (medal); and in the Burma expedition, 1885-6; surgeon-major, April, 1882; from Oct., 1882, served as fort surgeon, inspector of seamen at Madras, and professor of anatomy at the medical college, also acting as secretary and statistical officer to the surgeon-general, Her Majesty's forces, April-Aug., 1883, and as principal medical storekeeper, Madras, Sept., 1883; fellow of Madras University, March, 1884; surgeon, general hospital, and professor of surgery, &c., medical college, Jan., 1883; deputy surgeon-general, 1892; reverted to military duty, May, 1892; in charge of Rangoon district; author of a 'Clinical Manual.'

SILCOCK, Henry Foster, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Drogheda Grammar School and Kingstown School, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1874, and served as assistant magistrate and collector, acting district superintendent of police, acting cantonment magistrate, and forest settlement officer; on famine duty in 1876 and 1877; and assistant collector, April, 1887; on special duty, Nov., 1889; 1st assistant collector, April, 1890.

SILCOCK, James Greer, B.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Armagh Royal School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived, 16th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating judicial assistant; on special duty at Peshawur, Feb., 1881; officiated as district judge, Oct., 1883; to Jan., 1885, and as divisional judge, April, 1885, and again April, 1888; district judge, 2nd grade, June-Nov., 1888, and March, 1889; deputy commissioner, April, 1889.

SIM, Henry Alexander, Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1876; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1878, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate and acting collector and magistrate; from Jan., 1883, served as deputy conservator of forests, Kurnool, and forest settlement officer; special assistant to collector and magistrate, Malabar, Feb., 1886; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, March, 1886; employed under government of India as officiating deputy accountant-general, Aug.-Nov., 1887; deputy accountant-general, Madras, Jan., 1888; acting secretary to the commissioners of land revenue, April, 1888, and again from July, 1890; sub-collector and joint magistrate, July, 1890.

SIME, John, M.A., LL.D., Education Department, Punjab.—Professor, Government College, Agra, April, 1866; from Sept., 1870, served in the Punjab in the 3rd grade of the education department as principal, Delhi College, till 1877, and subsequently as professor, and officiating principal, Lahore College; inspector of schools, Aug., 1887; on special duty at Naini Tal, educational commission, April-May, 1885; tutor to H.H. the Maharaja of Patiala, May, 1885; promoted to 2nd grade of the department, March, 1886; director of public instruction, Punjab, and under secretary to government in the educational department, Oct., 1890; author of 'Man and his Duty,' and of works on arithmetic and mensuration.

SIMPSON, Sir Benjamin, Surgeon-General, K.C.I.E., M.D., late Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1853; served in civil employ from 1860, as assistant surgeon in Bengal, and was in medical charge of the Bhootan mission in 1863; on special duty on north-eastern frontier, 1867-68; civil surgeon, Darjeeling, April, 1868; from Jan., 1871, served as civil surgeon of Patna with charge of the Meetapore jail; on special duty to the cinchona commission, Feb., 1871; surgeon-major, Oct., 1873; guardian to the Maharajah of Cooch Behar during his visit to Europe, March, 1878; deputy surgeon-general, southern Afghanistan field force, 1881; principal medical officer, Quetta, 1881; deputy surgeon-general, March, 1882; sanitary commissioner, Central Provinces, 1882; surgeon-general in the Punjab, 1883-84; surgeon-general, Bengal, 1884-85; sanitary
commissioner, and surgeon-general with the government of India, March, 1885; K.C.I.E., Feb., 1887; retired, March, 1890.

SIMSON, JOHN HOPE, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at foreign schools and at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 30th Oct., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

SIMSON, D., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Grammar School and Marischal College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, in 1845; arrived in India, 5th April, 1846; served in the N.W. Provinces, and in the Punjab in the grades of assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and deputy commissioner; commissioner in Oudh, June, 1850; extra judge, court of Sudder Dewanny and Nizamut Adawlut, N.W. Provinces, April, 1864; judge, chief court, Punjab, April, 1868; retired, 1872.

SINCLAIR, DAVID, Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, M.B., C.M., Jail Department, Burma.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1st Oct., 1869; arrived in Madras, 14th May, 1870; from 1871, served in British Burma, and was employed in the analysis of potable waters in cantonments, April, 1871, to Dec., 1872; served subsequently as superintendent of the central jail at Moulmein, with occasional charge of the central jail at Rangoon; also officiated as civil surgeon and superintendent of lock hospital at Moulmein in 1874, and was in medical charge of the general hospital in that year; officiating inspector-general of prisons, British Burma, May-Oct., 1875, and again July, 1882; appointed superintendent of the central jail at Rangoon, Feb., 1883; inspector-general of jails, sanitary commissioner, superintendent of vaccination, and in charge of civil medical department, Burma, Jan., 1884.

SINCLAIR, D. E., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Westminster School, King's College School, and Merton College, Oxford; writer in post office, British museum, and admiralty, 1873-80; supervisor, 2nd grade, India store depot, Aug., 1880.

SINCLAIR, WILLIAM FREDERICK, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Armagh Royal School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting railway magistrate, and was on special duty for demarcation of forests in Khandesh, April, 1873, and in Alibag, Jan., 1874; on special duty, Poona, Nov., 1875; forest demarcating officer, Thana, Jan., 1876; on famine duty, April-Aug., 1877; first assistant collector and forest settlement officer, Feb., 1883; junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Cambay, March, 1890; senior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Thana, March, 1892; author of 'Notes on Arboriculture in the Bombay Presidency.'

SKINNER, JOHN ALLAN CLEVELAND, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Wellington College, and Keble College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1885; supernumerary assistant commissioner, Khandwa, Nov., 1885; registrar, judicial commissioner's court, April, 1888; assistant commissioner, Jan., 1890; acted as under secretary to chief commissioner, May, 1889.

SKINNER, RUSSELL MORLAND, Col., I.S.C., late Police Department, Bengal.—First commission, 7th Dec., 1855; joined the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent, 1st grade, April, 1862; district superintendent, Aug., 1863; on special duty, June, 1873; 1st grade district superintendent, Aug., 1876; retired, April, 1888.

SKIPWITH, GRAY TOWNSEND, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, 11th June, 1838; joined public works department, Oct., 1860; 1st assistant engineer, Nov., 1863; executive engineer, April, 1865; assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, and assistant to chief engineer, Feb., 1870; assistant secretary to government of India, public works department, Feb., 1872; 3rd superintending engineer, Feb., 1880; 2nd superintending engineer, March, 1887; officiated as chief engineer and joint secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, public works department, irrigation, Feb. to May, 1889; and again in Nov., 1889; 1st superintending engineer, Dec., 1889; charge of 1st circle irrigation works, April, 1890.

SKRINE, FRANCIS HENRY BENNET, Bengal C.S. — Educated at Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1870; assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal, Dec., 1870; on famine relief duty, May, 1874, and Oct., 1877, to April, 1878 (in Madras); superintendent of Salem central jail, Jan., 1878; joint magistrate and deputy collector, May, 1884; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1887.

SLACK, FRANCIS ALEXANDER, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Taunton College School, University College, Oxford, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1874; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1876; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; settlement officer of wards' and attached estates in Chota Nagpur; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Jan., 1888; officiated as commissioner, Chittagong, Sept., 1890, and as district and sessions judge, July, 1891; magistrate and collector, May, 1892.

SLADEN, JOSEPH, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, Nov., 1888, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; assistant commissioner in Sind, Oct., 1891.

SLATER, JOHN SAMUEL, Educational Service, Bengal.—From Sept., 1870, to Nov., 1875, served in the public works department, Punjab, as engineer apprentice and assistant engineer, on the Bari Doab and Indus canals; from Nov., 1875, served in the Bengal education department as professor, civil engineering department, Presidency College, and, from April, 1880, as professor of the Howrah Engineering College; officiated as principal in 1881; 3rd class of the education department, March, 1881; principal, Sibpur Engineering College, Dec., 1891.

SLIGHT, ANDREW MURE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Royal College, Mauritius, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil
service after open competition of 1887; arrived 12th Nov., 1889; served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate.

SLOCOCK, FRANCIS SAMUEL ALFRED, Madras C.S.—Educated at Marlborough and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1891, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

SLOCOMBE, C., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd July, 1892.

SLY, FRANK GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1887, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner.

SMALLEY, HENRY, Colonel, R.E., late Madras Public Works Department.—Arrived, 7th June, 1858, and served in the Madras presidency as acting assistant engineer and executive engineer; superintending engineer, Dec., 1890; reverted to military department, 1892.

SMART, ALEXANDER WILLIAM, R.E., Major, Madras Public Works Department.—Joined the service, 15th July, 1868; from March, 1871, served in Madras as assistant engineer and executive engineer; acting principal, college of engineering, Feb., 1891, to Jan., 1892.

SMEATON, DONALD MACKENZIE, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at the Abbey Park Institution, St. Andrew's, and St. Andrew's University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 22nd Nov., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from May, 1870, served in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 3rd grade, Feb., 1877; transferred to British Burma as settlement secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1879; on special duty in India, April, 1882; secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, in the land revenue and agricultural department, and director of agriculture, May, 1882; officiating director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Aug., 1884, and was confirmed in this appointment, May, 1886; officiating chief secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, April, 1887; commissioner, central division, Upper Burma, May, 1888; financial commissioner, March, 1891; in May, 1892, officiated for a short time as chief commissioner of Burma; author of an annotated edition of the N.W. Provinces Revenue Act of 1873, 'The Currency of India,' and 'The Karens of Burma.'

SMEATON, ROBERT, M.A. (Class. and Phil.), LL.D., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Abbey Park Institution and University of St. Andrew's; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer; first assistant secretary to government, July, 1876; under secretary, May, 1877; junior secretary, Aug., 1877; officiated for various periods as secretary to government in the Oudh revenue department, and also in the judicial department; secretary to government, financial department, May, 1884; member of lieutenant-governor's council, Dec., 1891.

SMITH, ALBERT CHARLES, Lieut.-Colonel, R.E., Madras Public Works Department.—Arrived in India, 5th Jan., 1864; joined the public works department, Sept., 1864, and was appointed assistant engineer, Oct., 1865, and executive engineer, March, 1870; proceeded to England on home duty, Feb., 1871, and returned to Madras, Nov., 1873; held charge of 4th and 6th circles, and was appointed superintending engineer, Sept. 1889; officiating joint secretary in the public works department, with charge of general buildings and road branch, April-July, 1891.

SMITH, ALEXANDER, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marischal College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; from Dec., 1857, served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector, and was appointed senior superintendent of survey, Aug., 1872, magistrate and collector, 1st grade, March, 1875, and commissioner of the Orissa division, and superintendent of tributary Mehals, Cuttack, Oct., 1879; commissioner, Presidency division, July, 1884; retired, Dec., 1891.

SMITH, A. CREMER, Store Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, India office, 23rd June, 1865; junior clerk, store department, Nov., 1866; senior clerk, Nov., 1876.

SMITH, CHARLES JOHN, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—1st commission, Madras engineers, Dec., 1855; arrived in India, 26th Dec., 1857; assistant engineer in the Madras public works department, Jan., 1858; executive engineer, Nov., 1865; appointed to carry out certain investigations in connection with the flood waters of the Cauvery, Dec., 1869; executive engineer, 1st grade, and deputy consulting engineer for railways, Oct., 1870, to 1883; under secretary to government, public works department, May, 1872; superintending engineer, 1st class, Sept., 1883; consulting engineer and joint secretary to government, railway branch, 1883; chief engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1883; 2nd class, May, 1888; 1st class, Dec., 1889; re-appointed consulting engineer, July, 1889; reverted to military duty, July, 1891.

SMITH, F. WHITMORE, Military Department, India Office.—Educated at Bedford School and Cheltenham College; temporary clerk, India office, 23rd Jan., 1864; junior clerk, military department, July, 1866; senior clerk, Jan., 1880.

SMITH, GILBERT LESLIE, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Twyford School and St. Andrew's University; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 9th Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating judicial assistant; on famine duty in Bengal, Feb., 1874; employed under the public works department in taking up land for the Punjab northern state railway, Aug., 1877, to Feb., 1878; officiating divisional judge, April, 1886, May, 1887, and June, 1888; district judge, 2nd grade, Jan., 1887; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1889.
SMITH, Henry Andrew Felton, Police Department, N.W. Provinces and Oudh.—Joined the service, 7th Aug., 1861; inspector of police, April, 1866; assistant district superintendent, July, 1867; district superintendent, March, 1876; 1st grade, Jan., 1892.

SMITH, Henry Scott, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Trinity College, Stratford-on-Avon, and Keble College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1886, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner.

SMITH, John, late Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 22nd Jan., 1875; retired, May, 1886.

SMITH, John Macdonald, Colonel, I.S.C., late Jail Department, Madras.—First commission, Madras infantry, 20th April, 1855; served in the China expedition with the 12th regiment N.I.; staff corps, Nov., 1861; assistant to the agent in Vizagapatam, Dec., 1861 to 1868; junior assistant collector, Ganjam, 1870-1878; wrote a hand-book in the Khond language; superintendent of central and district jails, Rajahmundry, April, 1880, to April, 1882, and was on special duty in 1881 as secretary to the special commissioner on his tour to the northern districts; from June, 1882, to Dec., 1885, served as paymaster of pensioners, Bangalore, and also acted as district magistrate and president of the municipality of that place, 1883-84, and in 1885; chief presidency magistrate, Madras, Dec., 1885; acting inspector-general of jails, Feb., 1890; confirmed, March, 1891; reverted to military department, Aug., 1892; author of a hand-book in the Khond language.

SMITH, Joseph, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 25th Sept., 1861; from Sept., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Etah, Aug., 1881, and afterwards at Etawah and at Bandia; officiating district and sessions judge, July, 1886; retired, April, 1887.

SMITH, Sir Robert Murdoch, K.C.M.G., Major-Gen., R.E., late Indo-European Telegraph Department.—Appointed to the Indo-European telegraph department, Aug., 1863; director of the Persian section from June, 1865; director in chief, Indo-European telegraph department, March, 1887; retired, Feb., 1888.

SMITH, Samuel G., Accounts Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, India office, 6th Jan., 1883.

SMITH, Sidney, Major, R.E., Madras Public Works Department.—First commission, 13th Jan., 1869; served in Egyptian expedition, 1882 (medal, clasp and star); joined the department, 27th July, 1883, as executive engineer and officiating deputy consulting engineer, Madras; acting under secretary to government, May, 1888; appointed deputy consulting engineer and under secretary to government, Feb., 1890.

SMITH, Thomas, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 31st Oct., 1861; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and deputy commissioner; appointed district and sessions judge, Tipperah, Dec., 1877, and served subsequently in the judicial department; 1st grade district and sessions judge, Nov., 1881; retired, Jan., 1888.

SMITH, Thomas W., Store Department, India Office.—Appointed 2nd class clerk, India Store Depot, 23rd May, 1888.

SMITH, Turton, Police Department, Punjab.—From 26th March, 1863, served in the police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade superintendent, May, 1881; between Dec., 1871, and Sept., 1878, also served in the postal department as officiating assistant director-general of post offices, and as officiating postmaster-general at Bombay, Aug., 1876, and at Madras, May, 1878; officiated for various periods as deputy inspector-general of police.

SMITH, Vincent Arthur, B.A., M.R.A.S., M.A.S.B., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 2nd Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Nov., 1874, to Nov., 1880, served in the settlement department in Hamirpur, and was appointed assistant settlement officer, 1st grade, Jan., 1878; on special duty in the Allahabad district, Nov., 1880; served subsequently as assistant magistrate, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector, and was also settlement officer of Basti, 1883-84; joint magistrate, 1st grade, July, 1885; magistrate and collector, June, 1889; author of 'The Settlement Officer's Manual,' 'Coinage of the Early Gupta Dynasty,' and 'Greco-Roman Influence on the Civilization of Ancient India.'

SMYTH, George, B.A., C.E., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating registrar of the chief court, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, March, 1880; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Oct., 1883; divisional judge, and grade, April, 1889; commissioner and superintendent, Nov., 1880.

SMYTH, John Watt, Barrister-at-Law, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857, and was appointed assistant magistrate and collector, Agra, Nov., 1858; transferred to Punjab, May, 1859, and served as assistant commissioner, and as personal assistant to the financial commissioner, and to the judicial commissioner; registrar of the chief court, Feb., 1866; deputy commissioner, Oct., 1869; officiated as commissioner and superintendent of the Lahore division in 1869, 1872, and 1879, and as additional commissioner of Amritsar, 1874-77; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st class, April, 1877; judge, chief court, March, 1880; retired, 1885.

SMYTH, Ralph Graham, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Burma.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, 7th Dec., 1855; from 6th Nov., 1857, served in the public works department in
the Central and N.W. Provinces as assistant engineer; served in the field force at Lucknow, and at the final capture of Lucknow, 1858 (medal and clasp); officiating garrison engineer, Lucknow, June, 1859; on military duty, May, 1861; re-appointed to public works department, April, 1862, and served in Bengal as assistant engineer and executive engineer (Jan., 1864); on special duty in investigations connected with river Selye, and with reservoirs in the Purulia and Palamow districts, Nov., 1867, to May, 1869; served in the Ramghur and Burbee divisions and on the Grand Trunk Road, and was promoted to executive engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1870; superintending engineer, July, 1876; transferred to Hyderabad, Dec., 1881, as secretary to resident in the public works department; 1st class superintending engineer, Sept., 1882; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, Aug. to Dec., 1885; retired, Dec., 1889.

SMYTH, THOMAS WATT, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1862, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and small cause court judge; registrar of the chief court, 1867-70; deputy commissioner, April, 1877; on special duty in the civil secretariat, Feb. and Oct., 1882; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, Aug., 1882; additional commissioner, Jullundur, Umballa, and Amritsir divisions, April, 1883; divisional judge, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; officiating judge, chief court, March, 1886; confirmed as judge of the chief court, Jan., 1887; retired, April, 1889; author of 'Acts and Regulations applicable to the Punjab.'

SNOW, PHILIP CHICHELEY HYDE, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Haileybury and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1876; assistant commissioner, Delhi, Nov., 1876; from March, 1877, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, assistant cantonment magistrate, and small cause court judge, and personal assistant to the chief commissioner; from Nov., 1881, served in the Bombay presidency as assistant collector and magistrate and district registrar, and was permanently transferred to the Bombay civil service, June, 1885; forest settlement officer, Dec., 1885; acting under secretary to government, political, judicial, and educational departments, Sept., 1886; 2nd assistant collector, Nov., 1887; 1st assistant collector, Dec., 1890.

SORABJI PADAMJI PESTANJI, Bombay C.S.—Probationer under the native civil service rules, 14th Jan., 1880; confirmed as member of the Bombay civil service, March, 1882; served as assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer; 2nd assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1889.

SPANKIE, ROBERT, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton and Haileybury; entered the Honourable East India Company's service in 1844, and was attached to the N.W. Provinces; magistrate and collector, 1853; district judge, 1859; extra judge, Sudder Dewanni and Nizamut Adawlut, Agra, 1864, and officiated as judge in that court in 1865 and 1866; officiated as puisne judge of the high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, on its establishment in 1866, and in 1867 was confirmed in this appointment, which he held till his retirement on 31st May, 1881.

SPEARMAN, HORACE RALPH, Colonel, I.S.C., Burma Commission.—Ensign, 91st Highlanders, 18th Dec., 1857; probationary assistant engineer, public works department, 1862; from Dec., 1862, served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner and assistant secretary to the chief commissioner (Feb., 1868); also officiated as secretary to the chief commissioner, and as director of public instruction; officiating assistant political agent, Bhamo, March, 1871; appointed a deputy commissioner, Jan., 1877, and was promoted to 1st grade, Aug., 1886; on special duty in Rangoon, Feb., 1879, and Feb., 1883; president, Rangoon municipal committee, May, 1883, and again, Jan., 1886, and of the Akyab municipal committee, Jan., 1884; member of the education syndicate, Feb., 1886; commissioner, April, 1890; author of 'British Burma Gazetteer.'

SPEDDING, ROBERT DECY, M.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1861; served from Aug., 1862, as assistant magistrate and collector and joint magistrate and deputy collector; deputed to conduct demarcation of boundary between districts of Banda and Hamirpur and the native states of Bundelkhand, Oct., 1870; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Jhansi, April, 1879; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Gorakpur, Dec., 1879, and subsequently in Moradabad; officiated as commissioner in the Agra division in 1884, and in the Benares division in 1886; commissioner, Rae Bareli division, Oct., 1889; Agra division, April, 1891; retired, July, 1891.

SPENCE, JAMES KNOX, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College and Royal Military Academy, Woolwich; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 29th Oct., 1865, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from May, 1878, to Oct., 1880, served in the postal department, as acting postmaster-general, Bombay, also in the Punjab and Bengal; junior collector and magistrate, and political agent, Kolaba, June, 1885; senior collector and collector of land revenue, customs, &c., Bombay, superintendent of stamps, &c., Nov., 1888; acting commissioner of customs, &c., Dec., 1889; also British delegate for the Portuguese treaty; acting commissioner, northern division, March, 1891; confirmed, Nov., 1891.

SPENCER, CHARLES GORDON, Madras C.S.—Educated at Marlborough and Keble College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived 26th Nov., 1890, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

SPENCER, HUGH, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Bristol grammar school, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1888, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

SPENCER, LIONEL DIXON, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, M.D., Indian Medical Depart-
ment.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, March, 1865; served under the civil department in the Central Provinces, and with the Central India horse; from Oct., 1871, served as agency surgeon, Eastern States, Rajputana; on special famine duty, Oct., 1877, and acted as political agent, Karauli, in 1877, and in Bharatpur, 1878; in 1879 was in medical charge of the Marwar and Jaisalmir agency; from March, 1881, served as agency surgeon, Rajputana, and superintendent-general of dispensaries and vaccination.

SPRING - BRANSON, JAMES HENRY, B.L., Madras Judicial Department.—Crown prosecutor and public prosecutor for town of Madras, 4th July, 1885; acting advocate general, March, 1887; additional member of Madras legislative council, March, 1887; advocate general, Madras, Sept., 1889.

SPRY, ARTHUR HUME, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived, 22nd Oct., 1857, and served in Bombay as assistant collector and magistrate, special officer of income tax, acting collector and magistrate, assistant political agent, and acting talukdari settlement officer; junior collector and magistrate, Dharwar, Dec., 1878; senior collector, Kaira, Oct., 1882; on special duty in the Cambay state, Feb., 1883; retired, 1886.

SRI LAL, PANDIT, B.L., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Appointed by the government of India a probationer under the statutory civil service rules; assistant magistrate and collector, 30th March, 1880.

SRINAVASA RAGHAVA AIYANGAR, SESHAYANGAR, B.A., DEWAN BAHAADUR, Madras Registration Department.—Joined the service as vernacular clerk in collector's office, Tanjore, Nov., 1870; head accountant, revenue board's office, March, 1878; and assistant, Nov., 1879; and 1st assistant, Aug., 1880; inspector-general of registration, Madras, Sept., 1889.

SRINIVASA RAO, PATEKI, DEWAN BAHAADUR, Judicial Department, Madras.—Served in the judicial department in various capacities from 16th Dec., 1844; appointed police magistrate, Madras, May, 1871; fellow of Madras University, Nov., 1875; small cause court judge, Madras, April, 1880.

STACE, EDWARD VINCENT, C.B., Lieut.-Col., I.S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1862; from June, 1871, served in the Bombay revenue survey department as assistant superintendent, and as boundary settlement commissioner (July, 1872); between May, 1873, and March, 1875, acted as assistant political resident, Aden, and also as cantonment magistrate; from April, 1875, acted as assistant political agent, Kathiawar, and was on special duty with the son of H.H. the Jam of Navanagar, May, 1877; also acted as assistant political agent of Kolhapur and Southern Mahratta country, and as superintendent of surveys under the Rajasthani court, Kathiawar; second assistant resident at Aden, Sept., 1880; assistant political agent, Kathiawar, Dec., 1881; joint administrator, Rajpipla, Feb., 1885; lieutenant-colonel, July, 1887; first assistant political resident at Aden, and political agent for the Somali coast, Feb., 1889; acted as political resident at various periods.

STACK, GEORGE AUGUSTINE, Bengal Education Department.—Served from 1st Jan., 1868, as professor at the Agra, Bareilly, and Dacca Colleges, and acted at different times as principal of the Bareilly College, inspector of schools and principal of the Krishnagur College; professor, Patna College, Jan., 1883; 3rd class of the education department, July, 1886; professor in the Presidency College, Feb., 1888.

STACK, OLIVER STOKES, late Police Department, Bengal.—From 8th June, 1859, to May, 1862, served as deputy magistrate and deputy collector; from May, 1862, served in the police department, and was appointed district superintendent, 1st grade, Oct., 1878; deputy inspector-general, July, 1885; officiating inspector-general, June, 1886; retired, Oct., 1890.

STALEY, ALFRED EVELYN, B.L., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Paul's School, Concord, U.S.A., and St. Peter's College, Radley; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1875; attached to N.W. Provinces; served in revenue and judicial department as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating joint magistrate and deputy collector; transferred to Bengal, Jan., 1880; officiating under secretary, government of Bengal, March, 1884, and again in 1885; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Aug., 1886; acting junior secretary to revenue board, March, 1890; district and sessions judge, Dec., 1891.

STANDEN, BERTRAM PRIOR, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Uppingham, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service (Burma) after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1888, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner; transferred in same capacity to Central Provinces, Jan., 1891; appointed also registrar, judicial commissioner's court, Nagpur, March, 1891; acting commissioner of excise, May, 1892.

STANHOPE, RIGHT HON. EDWARD, M.P.—Born 1840; educated at Harrow and at Christchurch, Oxford, where he graduated B.A. in 1862; M.A., 1865; elected fellow of All Souls' College, 1862; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1865, and joined the home circuit; was one of the assistant commissioners on the employment of women and children in agriculture, 1867; sat in the House of Commons for Mid-Lincolnshire from Feb., 1874, till the general election of 1885, when he was returned for the Horncastle division of that county; parliamentary secretary to the board of trade, Nov., 1875, to April, 1878; under-secretary of state for India, April, 1878, to April, 1880; vice-president of the committee of council on education, June to Aug., 1885; president of the board of trade, Aug., 1885, to Jan., 1886; secretary of state for the colonies, Aug., 1886; secretary of state for war, Jan., 1887, to Aug., 1892.

STANSFIELD, RIGHT HON. JAMES, M.P.—Born in 1820; educated at University College, London, where he took the degree of LL.B.; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, 1849; was returned to parliament for Halifax, April, 1859; appointed a lord of the admiralty in April, 1863; resigned in April, 1864; under-secretary of state for India, Feb. to June, 1866; third lord of the treasury, Dec., 1868; joint secretary to the treasury, Oct., 1869; president of the poor
law board, March, 1871; was first president of the new local government board, Aug., 1871, to Jan., 1874, and again March-Aug., 1886.

STANTILL, W., Public Works Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; clerk, 2nd class, India Office, 25th Sept., 1882.

STAVELEY, Sir Charles William Dunbar, General, G.C.B.—Educated at the Scottish Naval and Military Academy, Edinburgh; 2nd lieutenant, 87th Foot, March, 1835; assistant military secretary to Col. W. Staveley, in Mauritius, Feb.-Nov., 1842, and at Hong Kong, June, 1847, to Dec., 1850; A.D.C. to Lieutenant-General Earl Cathcart, in Canada, March, 1845, to May, 1847; served the Eastern campaign of 1854-55, including the battles of Alma and Balaklava, and the siege of Sebastopol (medal, C.B., Sardinian and Turkish medals, and 5th class of the Medjidie); brigadier-general in North China, 1860-1862 (medal); from Feb., 1862, to June, 1863, was in command of the troops during the operations against the Taepings, in the vicinity of Shanghai, resulting in the capture of the entrenched camp of Onkatz, and the towns of Kadin, Tsinpoo Cholin, Najow, and Tserspo; K.C.B., March, 1865; from March, 1865, to Sept., 1867, served as brigadier-general in the Bombay presidency, and was in command of the northern division and the Poon brigade successively; was second in command in the Abyssinian expedition, 1867-68, and was present at the action of Arrogee, and capture of Magdala; received the thanks of parliament, and was promoted to a major-general, 1868 (medal); major-general on the staff, western division, Devonport, Jan.-March, 1869; commander-in-chief, Bombay, and member of the governor's council, Oct., 1874, to Oct., 1878; G.C.B., May, 1884.

STEAD, Ven. Samuel, M.A. (Oxon), late Ecclesiastical Department, Bombay.—Joined the service, March, 1863; arrived in India, 24th April, 1863, and served as chaplain at Karachi, Sholapur; cantonment of Belgaum, and Poona; senior chaplain, April, 1873; archdeacon and commissary, Nov., 1878; also held charge of the diocese of Bombay, Oct., 1877, to Nov., 1878, and Oct., 1883, to June, 1884; retired, June, 1886.

STEANE, W.C., Registry Department, India Office.—Temporary clerk, 9th Nov., 1860; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

STEAVENSON, Joseph, B.A., Judicial Department, Madras.—Served from 25th Feb., 1878, as acting registrar of the high court (original side), Madras, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1880.

STEDMAN, Edward, C.B., Major-General, I.S.C., late Burma Police.—1st commission, 10th Dec., 1866; major, Dec., 1880, and lieutenant-colonel, Dec., 1886; served in the Hazara campaign, 1868 (medal with clasp), and in the Afghan war of 1878-80; with Sir Frederick Roberts in the march to Candahar; and present at the battle of Candahar (medal with clasp and bronze decoration); served in the Burma expedition of 1886-7, and commanded the operations in the Shan states; inspector-general of police, Upper Burma, May, 1887; and of Burma, Oct., 1888; appointed quarter-master general in India, March, 1892.

STEDMAN, Edward Brittain, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Shrewsbury; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; officiating director of settlements and revenue records, March, 1887; confirmed, May, 1887; designation changed to director of land records and agriculture; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1889; officiating director of land records and agriculture, April, 1892; officiating revenue secretary to government, May, 1892; author of 'Report on the Settlement of the Jhang District.'

STEEL, Charles Denton, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Wesleyan Connexional School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1876, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, and grade, Oct., 1886; assistant superintendent and judge, small cause court, Dehra Dun, in 1888-9; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, April, 1889; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Jan., 1890; district and sessions judge, April, 1891; on special duty, May, 1891; author of 'Allahabad Gazetteer.'

STEEL, Henry William, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Caius College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1862, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; services placed temporarily at disposal of public works department in connection with Punjab northern state railway, July, 1874; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1878; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; 1st grade, Jan., 1887; retired, May, 1889.

STEEL, John Philip, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1855; joined the public works department, March, 1860, as assistant engineer, Bengal; executive engineer, April, 1868; officiating assistant to chief engineer, and assistant secretary to government of Bengal, July, 1871; officiating under secretary, government of India, public works department, March, 1873, to 1875, and again Feb., 1877; superintending engineer and secretary to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, May, 1879; superintending engineer, 1st class, May, 1886; officiating chief engineer and secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1887; officiating secretary to chief commissioner, Central Provinces, Oct., 1887; chief engineer and joint secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1888; 3rd chief engineer, April, 1888; officiated as secretary to government, Feb.-May, 1889; and again Nov., 1889; confirmed Dec., 1889; 2nd chief engineer, Dec., 1889; retired, March, 1892.

STEINBELT, Jean Mari Conrad, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Jan., 1863, served in N.W. Provinces and Oudh as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Mirzapur, Sept., 1878; from April, 1881, served as civil and sessions judge.
in Banda, and afterwards at Azamgarh; retired, April, 1837.

STEINBERG, ALFRED FREDERICK, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Dulwich College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1881, and served in Assam as assistant commissioner; transferred to Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1892; officiating district and sessions judge, March, 1892.

STEPHEN, ARTHUR, M.A., M.B., Surgeon-Lieut-Colonel, Medical Department, Punjab.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1867; served under the military department in the Punjab as assistant surgeon and surgeon; Lahore medical school, 1874; superintendent of jail, Lahore, 1876; surgeon-major, Sept., 1879; statistical officer to government of India, sanitary and medical department, 1880; officiated as sanitary commissioner, Punjab, in 1885 and 1886, and was confirmed, Nov., 1886.

STEPHEN, CARR, Barrister-at-Law.—Served in the Punjab from 11th June, 1856, as extra assistant commissioner and small cause court judge; extra judicial assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oct., 1875; officiating divisional judge, Nov., 1885, to Jan., 1886; has published 'Indian Registration Act,' 4th edition, 'Handbook for Delhi,' and 'Archaeology of Delhi.'

STEPHEN, SIR JAMES FITZJAMES, K.C.S.I., M.A., an Honorary Fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge, D.C.L., Oxford, LL.D., Edinburgh, and LL.B., London.—Educated at Eton, King's College, London, and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he graduated B.A. in 1852; called to the bar at the Inner Temple, Jan., 1854; went the Midland Circuit, and became recorder of Newark-on-Trent (1859-69); legal member of the council of the governor-general of India, Dec., 1869 to 1872; appointed by the Inns of Court professor of common law, Dec., 1875, and a member of the councils of legal education and law reporting; K.C.S.I., 1877; a member of the royal commission appointed to enquire into the provisions of a draft code relating to indictable offences, 1878; judge of the high court of Justice (Queen's bench division), Jan., 1879 to 1891; president of the ordnance inquiry commission, 1886-7; has published 'General View of the Criminal Law of England,' 1863; 'Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity,' 1873; 'History of the Criminal Law,' 3 vols., 1883; 'The Digest of the Law of Evidence'; 'Digest of the Criminal Law,' 4th Edition, 1887.

STERNDALE, R. A., late Financial Department, Government of India.—Served during the mutiny as a volunteer, 1857, and took part in the operations in Central India (medal); lieutenant, Behar station guards, Jan., 1858; from Aug., 1859, served in the Central Provinces as deputy collector and assistant settlement officer; from June, 1864, served in the financial department in Nagpore, Calcutta, and the Punjab, as assistant commissioner of paper currency, acting assistant accountant-general, acting deputy accountant-general, and acting assistant comptroller-general; 3rd class of financial department (new scheme), Aug., 1880; assistant accountant-general, Bombay, Jan., 1884, and Madras, Nov., 1887; retired, 1890; is a fellow of the Royal Geographical and Zoological Societies; author of 'Mammalia of British India and Ceylon,' 'Denizens of the Jungles,' 'Seoni; or Camp Life on the Satpura Range,' a 'Topographical and Historical Account of the District of Seoni,' 'Turkey and India; or Our Indian Moslems,' 'The Afghan Knife,' and other works; joint editor of the 'Journal of the Bombay Natural History Society.'

STEVENS, CHARLES CECIL, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at University of Melbourne; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 2nd Feb., 1862; from Jan., 1863, served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Oct., 1873; officiating secretary, board of revenue, April, 1882; commissioner, Aug., 1885; officiating chief secretary to government of Bengal, May-Nov., 1890; member of revenue board, Dec., 1891.

STEVENS, JOHN FOSTER, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Birmingham Grammar School, at Versailles, and at King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 16th Oct., 1865; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, May, 1876; district and sessions judge, Sept., 1884; officiating judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, Dec., 1891.

STEVENSON, GEORGE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College, Aberdeen, and Glasgow University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Assam, Jan., 1880, and served as assistant commissioner; deputy commissioner, Sylhet, Jan., 1885; returned to Bengal, May, 1889; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, June, 1889; magistrate and collector, July, 1889.

STEVENSON-MOORE, CHARLES JAMES, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Felsted School, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1887, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

STEWARD, ARTHUR BENNET, B.A., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 5th Nov., 1870, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant political agent, acting junior collector and magistrate, and acting forest settlement officer; second assistant collector, Dec., 1882; acting postmaster-general, Bombay, Aug., 1884, to May, 1885; acting assistant judge, Poona, and assistant agent for Sardars in the Deccan, Oct., 1885, judicial assistant to political agent, Kathiawar, Nov., 1887; 3rd grade judge and sessions judge, May, 1891.

STEWART, ALFRED J., Political Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 27th Sept., 1892.

STEWART, SIR DONALD MARTIN, Bart., General, G.C.B., G.C.S.I., C.I.E.—Ensign, Bengal army (infantry), 12th Oct., 1840; adjutant, 9th Bengal native infantry, 1845; interpreter and quartermaster, 9th N.I., 1852; served against the hill tribes on the Peshawur frontier in 1854-5, and against the Bussee Kheyl tribes
in 1855 (medal and clasp); commanded volunteers in Allyghur district, May and June, 1857; deputy assistant adjutant-general, Delhi field force, June, 1857; assistant adjutant-general of army, Dec., 1857; was present at siege and capture of Lucknow, and the operations in Rohilcund (medal with two clasps); deputy adjutant-general in India, Feb., 1863; brigadier-general, Abyssinian expeditionary force, 1868 (medal and C.B.); in command of Peshawur district, July, 1869; chief commissioner of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands, 1871; in command of Lahore Division, April, 1876; commanding Kandahar and Southern Afghanistan force, 1878-80; commanding at Kabul and in Northern Afghanistan, 1880, till withdrawal from that country; received the thanks of both houses of parliament (K.C.B., G.C.B., baronet, and medal with clasp); military member of governor-general's council, 1880; commander-in-chief in India, and extraordinary member of the governor-general's council, 1881; member of council of India, 16th Dec., 1885.

STEWART, ROBERT BARTON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Dulwich and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 27th Dec., 1886; assistant collector and magistrate, May, 1887.

STEWART-WILSON, CHARLES, B.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh High School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1886; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, Dec., 1890; officiating under-secretary to government, Oct., 1889; confirmed, Aug., 1891; officiating post-master-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1892.

STIFFE, A.W., Commander, late R.I.M.—From 24th Feb., 1849, served in the Indian marine as midshipman, lieutenant, and senior lieutenant, and assistant surveyor; served in Persian war, 1856-57; on special survey for telegraph cable in Persian Gulf, Nov., 1862; on special duty in Turkish Arabia, Feb., 1863; engineer, Persian Gulf telegraphs, and commanding 'Amberwitch,' Oct., 1863; officiating director, Persian Gulf telegraphs, April-Aug., 1866, and Sept., 1869, to Jan., 1871; also electrician, Aug., 1871; on special duty in England, May, 1875, and May, 1878; in command of cable steamer 'Patrick Stewart,' May-July, 1879; port officer, Calcutta, Aug., 1879; officiating superintendent of marine, July, 1880; ex officio shipping master of Calcutta, Feb., 1882; was also president of board of examiners in seamanship, registrar of shipping and wrecks, and presidency magistrate; retired, 1888; has brought out new charts and pilots of the Persian gulf and Mekran coast; also a new chart of Maskat, and a description of the Hooghly.

STIMPSON, E. J., Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 21st May, 1873; resigned, 24th June, 1879; reappointed, 10th July, 1880.

STOGDON, ABRAHAM WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Uppingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; judicial assistant, Sept., 1877; services placed temporarily at disposal of government of India, military department, Feb., 1881; deputy commissioner, Aug., 1883; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; 2nd grade, March, 1889; and 1st grade, Nov., 1889; officiating judge of the chief court in 1889, 1890, and from March, 1891.

STOKER, THOMAS, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Rathmines School and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1872, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; deputy superintendent of family domains of Maharaja of Benares, March, 1878; 1st assistant secretary to government, April, 1884; under secretary to government, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, May, 1884; officiated as secretary to government in the financial department in 1885 and 1886; settlement officer, Bulandshahr, Sept., 1886; inspector-general of registration, and commissioner of excise and stamps, Nov., 1891.

STOKES, GABRIEL, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Kilkenny College, Royal School, Armagh, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1871, and served in Bombay till Dec., 1872, and afterwards in Madras as assistant magistrate and collector, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting principal assistant, and acting collector and magistrate; acting additional under secretary to government of Madras in the revenue (famine) department, May, 1877, to April, 1879; transferred permanently to the Madras civil service, Sept., 1878; on special duty preparing Madras administration report, Sept., 1879; acting Canarese translator to government, Feb., 1880; acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments, July, 1880; deputy superintendent of census operations, Sept., 1880; sub-collector and joint magistrate, South Arcot, May, 1886; collector and magistrate, Aug., 1889.

STOKES, SIR HENRY EDWARD, K.C.S.I., B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Minehead Diocesan School, Kilkenny College, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, 4th Jan., 1864; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1866; under secretary to government of Madras in the departments under the chief secretary, Aug., 1866; acting collector of sea customs and protector of emigrants, Madras, Jan., 1871; fellow of the University of Madras, Feb., 1875; sub-secretary, board of revenue, July 1875; on special duty under government of India, with the Madras salt commission, Jan.-Sept., 1876; secretary, board of revenue, Jan., 1877, to Feb., 1878, and additional secretary on famine duties, Feb., 1877; district and sessions judge, South Malabar, Oct., 1879; collector and magistrate, Salem, June, 1881; member of forest draft bill committee, April, 1882; member of local self-government committee, June, 1882; secretary to government of Madras in the revenue department, Jan., 1884; acting chief secretary to government, Oct., 1886; additional member of
council, Madras, for making laws and regulations, Oct., 1886; chief secretary to government, Oct., 1887; temporary member of governor's council, July, 1888; appointed ordinary member and assumed office, 9th Nov., 1888; C.S.I., May, 1889; K.C.S.I., May, 1892.

STOKES, Henry John, B.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Columba College, Rathfarnham, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; assistant collector and magistrate, Oct., 1863; served in Bombay from Oct., 1864, to Jan., 1870, and subsequently in Madras, and was appointed principal assistant, July, 1871, district and sessions judge, Kistna, June, 1877, and collector and magistrate, Madura, June, 1879; on special famine duty, Madura, Aug., 1877; district and sessions judge, Madura, Jan., 1884; collector and magistrate, North Arcot, Oct., 1884; member of draft tenancy bill committee, July, 1885; district and sessions judge, Coimbatore, May, 1886; on deputation as a member of the public service commission, Nov., 1886; on special duty in connection with rent recovery bill commission; retired, July, 1889.

STOKES, Whitley, C.S.I., C.I.E., Hon. D.C.L., Oxon., LL.D., Dublin, Barrister-at-Law, Inner Temple, late of Legislative Department of the Government of India.—Reporter to the high court and acting administrator-general, Madras, 1863-4; served subsequently as assistant secretary to government of India, legislative branch of home department, secretary to the governor-general's legislative council, and secretary to the government of India in the legislative department; law member of the council of the governor-general, May, 1877, to May, 1882; president of Indian law commission, 1879; in 1868, framed the scheme for collecting, copying, and cataloguing the Sanskrit MSS. preserved in India, in recognition of which he was made honorary member of the Deutsche Morgenlandische Gesellschaft; correspondent of the Institut de France (Académie des Inscriptions et Belles Lettres), fellow of Calcutta University, and honorary fellow of Jesus College, Oxford; author of 'A Treatise on the liens of legal Practitioners,' 'On Powers of Attorney,' ('Bythewood and Jarman's Conveyancing,' vol. VIII., part I); 'Hindu Law Books,' Madras, 1865; the 'Indian Succession Act, with a Commentary,' Calcutta, 1865; the 'Indian Companies Act, 1866, with Notes'; the 'Older Statutes in force in India, with Notes,' 1874; the 'Unrepealed General Acts of the Governor-General of India, with Chronological Tables,' &c., 3 vols., Calcutta, 1875 and 1876, the 'Anglo-Indian Codes,' vol. I., 1877, and vol. II., 1888 (Clarendon Press, Oxford); the 'Tripartite life of Patrick, with other documents relating to that Saint,' 1887; and various philological works published in Germany, France, and England.

STONE, Samuel James, Police Department, Punjab.—Appointed assistant district superintendent of police, 10th March, 1861; district superintendent, Nov., 1872; served in Assam from Dec., 1884, to March, 1885, when for a short time he was on special duty at Rawalpindi; resumed his post in the Punjab, April, 1885; promoted to 1st grade, Sept., 1888.

STOREY, Henry Francis, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, Nov., 1868, as executive engineer on the Punjab northern state railway; transferred to the Neemuch-Nasirabad railway surveys, 1878, and subsequently to the Indus Valley railway; engineer-in-chief, Kandahar state railway, March, 1880; engineer-in-chief, Indus Valley and Kandahar railways, Oct., 1881; superintendent of way and works, Sukkur, 1883; officiating manager, Indus Valley railway, Nov., 1885; superintending engineer, North-Western railway, Jan., 1886; superintending engineer, 3rd class, May, 1886; 2nd class, Feb., 1888; officiating secretary to resident, Hyderabad, June, 1888; confirmed in that appointment, Dec., 1889; 1st superintending engineer, Dec., 1889.

STRACHAN, Right Rev. John Miller, D.D., M.D., Ecclesiastical Department, Burma.—Appointed Bishop of Rangoon, 30th June, 1882.

STRACHEY, Sir John, G.C.S.I., C.I.E., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1842; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant commissioner and assistant magistrate and collector; senior assistant, Kumaon, 1848; magistrate and collector, Moradabad, 1854; officiating commissioner of Kumaon, 1861; president of commission to inquire into cholera epidemic of 1861; judicial commissioner, Central Provinces, 1862; president of the sanitary commission with government of India, 1864; chief commissioner, Oudh, 1866; member of governor-general's council, 7th March, 1868; acting viceroy and governor-general on death of Earl of Mayo, 1872; lieutenant-governor, N.W. Provinces, 1874; retired from the civil service, 1876; financial member of the governor-general's council, 23rd Dec., 1876, to 1880; left India, Dec., 1880; member of council of India, 14th July, 1885; joint author with Lieutenant-General R. Strachey of 'The Finances and Public Works of India, 1882; author of 'India,' 1888, and of 'Hastings and the Rohilla war,' 1892.

STRACHEY, Richard, Lieutenant-General, R.E., C.S.I., F.R.S.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1836; was employed on irrigation works in the N.W. Provinces from 1840, and appointed executive engineer, Ganges canal, July, 1843; under secretary to government of India, public works department, 1857; secretary to government, Central Provinces, 1857; consulting engineer, railway department, Sept., 1858; secretary to government of India, public works department, 1862; inspector-general of irrigation, and chief engineer, 1st class, Dec., 1866; additional member of governor-general's council, 1866; inspecting engineer of machinery and stores for state railways, India office, 1871; member of council of India, 1875, to 18th July, 1878; special duty in India, 1878; officiating financial member of council of governor-general, 1879; officiating member of council of governor-general, 1880; president of the famine commission, 1880; reappointed member of council of India, 1879; president, royal geographical society, 1887; retired from the Council of India, on his appointment as chairman of the East Indian railway company, 1889; appointed a representative of India at the international monetary conference, Brussels, Aug., 1892.

STRAFFORD (Earl of), Right Hon. George Henry Charles Byng.—Born in 1830; educated at Eton and Oxford; sat in the House of Commons for Tavistock, 1852-1857, and for Mid-
dlesex, 1857, to Jan., 1874, when he succeeded to the upper house, as Viscount Enfield; attached to Earl Russell's special mission to Vienna, 1855; parliamentary secretary to the poor law board, 1865, till July, 1866; under secretary for foreign affairs, Dec., 1870; under secretary of state for India, Sept., 1880, to Dec., 1882; succeeded to the earldom of Stratford in 1886.

STRAHAN, CHARLES, Lieut.-Colonel, R.E., Survey of India Department.—First commission, Bengal engineers, June, 1860; arrived in India, Oct., 1862; joined the survey department as military 2nd assistant, Sept., 1863; served with the Bhutan field force in charge of reconnoitring party, Oct., 1865, to July, 1866 (medal and clasp); surveyor, 3rd grade, Dec., 1867; served with the Peshawur field force in Afghanistan, 1879 (medal, brevet of major); deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Jan., 1884; assistant surveyor-general in charge of cartographic and engraving branches, May, 1884; deputy superintendent, 1st grade, April, 1886, officiating also as deputy surveyor-general (revenue branch); confirmed, July, 1892.

STRAHAN, GEORGE, Colonel, R.E., Survey of India Department.—Obtained commission from Addiscombe, Dec., 1858; arrived in India, Nov., 1860; served under the military department, and also in the irrigation branch, public works department, till July, 1862, when he was appointed to the survey department; served as assistant in the Gwalior and Central India survey, and afterwards held charges in the Rajputana, Mysore, and Khandesh surveys; deputy superintendent, Nov., 1867; officiating assistant surveyor-general, in charge of engraving and cartographic branches, Calcutta, April-July, 1883; deputy superintendent, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; on duty in Europe, April-Aug., 1885; deputy surveyor-general (trigonometrical branch), Oct., 1889.

STRAIGHT, SIR DOUGLAS, K.T., B.L., late Judicial Department, N.W.
