Provinces and Oudh.—Called to the bar at the Middle Temple, Nov., 1865; counsel to London banks association from 1868; junior counsel, treasury prosecution, from 1877; sat in House of Commons as member for Shrewsbury, 1870 to 1874; appointed one of the royal commissioners to inquire into corrupt election practices at Boston, 1875; puisne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, June, 1879; fellow of Calcutta University, June, 1883, and of the Allahabad University, Nov., 1887; officiated as chief justice of the N.W. Provinces high court in 1883, 1884, and 1886; retired, April, 1892; Kt., Aug., 1892.

STRATTON, JOHN PROUDFOOT, Brigade Surgeon, M.D., late Bombay Medical Establishment.—Assistant surgeon, Bombay medical service, Oct., 1852; between 1854 and 1859 was employed as residency surgeon, Baroda, also serving as assistant resident, 1857-59; from Sept., 1859, served as assistant resident in Bundelcund; political agent, Bundelcund, June, 1864; surgeon-major, Oct., 1872; political agent, Meywar, 1881; resident, Western states, Rajputana, July, 1881, and in the Eastern Rajputana states, 1882, till Dec., 1885, when his services were replaced at disposal of military department; retired, Dec., 1886.

STREATFIELD, CLAUDE ARTHUR CECIL, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces and Oudh).—Educated at Marlborough and Pembroke College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived 21st Nov., 1891, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

STREATFIELD, HENRY CUTHBERT, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College and Pembroke College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1887, and served as assistant magistrate and collector; officiating under-secretary to the government of Bengal, financial and municipal department, June, 1890; confirmed, Nov., 1890; officiating in the judicial, &c., departments, April, 1892.

STREET, B. H. G., Store Department, India Office.—Writer, 30th June, 1874; clerk, 2nd class, Sept., 1878; supervisor, 2nd grade, India store depot, Oct., 1883.

STREET, HENRY ALFRED, Captain, R.I.M., Presidency Port Officer, Madras.—Commander of 'Tenasserim,' Dec., 1876, to June, 1880; assistant secretary to government of India, military (marine) department, June, 1880 to March, 1882; on duty in Bombay, 1882-84; assistant director, Indian marine, April, 1884; 1st grade commander, Dec., 1886; port officer, Madras, Dec., 1887.

STRICKLAND, WILLIAM ALEXANDER WICKEDE, Captain, I.S.C., Burma Commission.—1st commission, Oct., 1880; assistant commissioner, Aug., 1886.

STROVER, GEORGE AUGUSTUS, Colonel, I.S.C., Burma Commission.—Joined the service as ensign, Jan., 1857; arrived at Madras, Feb., 1857; served in the Burma commission from 14th April, 1862, as assistant commissioner and cantonment magistrate; officiating magistrate and small cause court judge of Rangoon, 1866; superintendent of hill tribes, North Arakan, Sept., 1868; from Aug., 1869, to Sept., 1875, served in the political department as assistant political agent at Bhamo, and political agent at Mandalay (Jan., 1872); from Nov., 1877, served as deputy commissioner of Toungoo, and acted as commissioner of Arakan, Aug. to Nov., 1883; 1st grade deputy commissioner, July, 1881; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1885; commissioner, May, 1889.

STUART, ANDREW EDMUND CASTLE-STUART, F.G.S., F.L.S., F.R.G.S., Madras C.S.—Educated at Wellington College and Kingstown School, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived, 17th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and forest settlement officer; special assistant to the collectors of Nilgiris and Malabar for settlement purposes, Aug., 1886; head assistant to collector and magistrate, July, 1888; special settlement officer, Malabar and S. Canara, June, 1891; compiled a 'Manual of the Wynad.'

STUART, CHARLES AUGUSTUS, Postal Department, Bombay.—Served from 23rd Nov., 1855, as postmaster in Mysore, Madras, and Hyderabad; presidency postmaster, Madras, Jan., 1864; from March, 1865, served in Bombay as presidency postmaster, and also officiated for various periods as postmaster-general, Bombay, Punjab, and Madras.

STUART, CHARLES JOSEPH, Colonel, I.S.C., late Madras Revenue Department.—Arrived
in India, 21st Aug., 1852; served in the Madras revenue settlement department from April, 1861, as assistant director and deputy director; special assistant to collector of Kurnool for survey and settlement purposes, April, 1871, to Nov., 1873, and again in Chingleput, Dec., 1873, and in Madura, April, 1882; 1st grade of deputy directors, June, 1883; retired, 1889.

STUART, GEORGE HENRY, M.A., Madras Educational Department.—Educated at Emmanuel College, Cambridge; joined the service, 14th Aug., 1882, as principal, Kumbakonum College; has acted at various periods as principal, Presidency College, and as professor of English literature and of mathematics there.

STUART, HAROLD ARTHUR, Madras C.S.—Educated at High School, Bishop's Stortford, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1879; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1881, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant secretary to government in the judicial and legislative departments (Dec., 1884); acting under secretary to government, revenue department, Jan., 1886; sub. pro tem. under secretary in the chief secretary's department, Oct., 1886; under secretary to government, revenue department, Sept., 1888, and chief-secretary's department, Nov., 1888; acting private secretary to governor of Madras, Nov.-Dec., 1889; provincial superintendent of census operations, March, 1890.

STUART, LOUIS, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces and Oudh).—Educated at the Charterhouse, and Balliol college, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived 17th Dec., 1891, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

STUART, SIR ROBERT, Knt., Q.C., late High Court, N.W. Provinces.—Educated at Perth, and afterwards at the University of Edinburgh; called to the Scotch bar, July, 1840; and to the English bar at Lincoln's Inn, June, 1856; practised at the chancery bar as an equity draughtsman and conveyancer, and as an advising counsel; practised also in the House of Lords and privy council, and before parliamentary committees of both houses until 1868, when he was appointed Q.C., and soon after elected a bencher of his inn; appointed chief justice of the North-West Provinces, India, and knighted, August, 1871; retired, March, 1884; is a member of the general council of the University of Edinburgh, and has been a frequent contributor to periodical literature, especially on legal subjects; author of many legal pamphlets.

STUART, R. G., late Political Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 19th Feb., 1873; clerk specially attached to the political and secret department, Feb., 1876; retired, April, 1891.

STURROCK, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at the High School, Dundee; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1853; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1864; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1866; acting secretary to government in the revenue department, Nov., 1873; boundary commissioner between Canara and Mysore, May, 1873, and again in 1880-81; Canarese translator to government, Jan., 1874; under secretary to government in the chief secretary's department, July, 1875; additional sub-secretary, board of revenue, for special duty with famine commission, Nov., 1878, also acting as secretary, Jan., 1879; sub-secretary, board of revenue, Oct., 1879; collector and magistrate, Oct., 1883; acting fourth member of board of revenue and commissioner of salt revenue, &c., in 1888 and 1889.

STURT, W. NEVILLE, Political Department, India Office.—Educated at Repton; temporary clerk, 1st May, 1862; junior clerk, store department, 1862; accountant-general's department, 1865; military department, 1863; private secretary to parliamentary under-secretary of state, 1863-64, and 1868-77; senior clerk, revenue department, April, 1877; transferred temporarily to political and secret department, April, 1890.

SULLIVAN, HENRY EDWARD, C.S.I., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1850; served in revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed small cause court judge, Cuddalore, Sept., 1866; civil and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Dec., 1866; collector and magistrate, Bellary, March, 1868, and subsequently of Trichinopoly; officiating director of revenue settlement, Feb., 1874; acting member, board of revenue, and president of the committee for examination of assistants, April, 1876; in charge of the Inam department, May, 1876; acting resident of Travancore and Cochin, March, 1877, to Feb., 1878; board of revenue, April, 1878; famine commission, Jan., 1879; 1st member, board of revenue, and commissioner, uncovenanted civil service examinations, Jan., 1879; on duty studying records of famine commission, April, 1879; on special duty in Godavari district, investigating causes of the disturbances in Rumpa country, July, 1879; on duty to England as member of famine commission, Oct., 1879, to July, 1880; additional member of council for making laws and regulations, Jan., 1881; in charge of settlement department, Feb., 1881; ordinary member of council, June, 1882; president of local self-government committee, June, 1882; retired, Dec., 1886.

SUMBRAMANIYAM, NARANAIYAR, B.A., B.L., Madras, Judicial Department.—Acted as administrator-general, Madras, May, 1891, to Feb., 1892; appointed judge, Madras small cause court, April, 1892.

SURYA KUMAR AGASTI, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Appointed under the native civil service rules assistant magistrate and collector, Purneah, on probation, March, 1885; confirmed in the statutory civil service, April, 1887.

SUTTON, E. W., Political Department, India Office.—Second division clerk, Census office, 7th April, 1891; and class clerk, India office, 1st September, 1891.

SWAIN, W. H., B.Sc., Military Department, India Office.—Clerk, and class, 4th June, 1881; B.Sc. (Honours), London University, 1882.

SWAMINATHA AIYAR, TIRUVARAR MUTUSWAMI AIYAR, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Madras University; appointed probationer for the civil service, Nov., 1883; confirmed as a member of the Madras civil service, Jan., 1885, and appointed assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1887.

SWETENHAM, EDMUND, Colonel, I.S.C., late Public Works Department, North-Western
Provinces.—Joined public works department from Roorkee college, Nov., 1853, and served in the Punjab; resigned on obtaining commission in the army, March, 1857; served in the N.W. frontier campaign, 1858 (medal); reappointed to public works department, Feb., 1859, and served in N.W. Provinces, buildings and roads branch; executive engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1869; transferred to British Burma, May, 1872; transferred to Central India, and served from Sept., 1874, to Aug., 1880, as executive engineer, Mhow division, and acted for various periods as chief engineer, and secretary to governor-general's agent; transferred to N.W. Provinces, buildings and roads branch, Aug., 1880, and promoted to superintending engineer, 3rd class, Sept., 1880; 2nd class, July, 1884; 1st class, permanent, April, 1883; retired Feb., 1890.

SYAD ALAY MAHOMED, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Acting extra assistant commissioner, 4th class, 26th Jan., 1881; probationer for the native civil service, Dec., 1882; appointed member of the civil service, and supernumerary assistant commissioner, Dec., 1883; judge, small cause court, April, 1892.

SYAD NUR-UD-DIN KHAN, Bombay C.S. —Served in Hyderabad from May, 1879, as attaché to Resident, judge of small causes, &c.; assistant commissioner, Jan., 1883; under secretary to Hyderabad state, Jan., 1885; appointed a probationer under native civil service rules, March, 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1888.

SYKES, ROBERT, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Giggleswick Grammar School and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1888; and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; on special duty, Nov., 1889.

SYMES, EDWARD SPENCE, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 26th Oct., 1875, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Burma, Aug., 1876; served as assistant commissioner, and was placed on special duty in the secretariat, July and Nov., 1878; on special forest demarcation duty, Feb., 1879; personal assistant to chief commissioner, May, 1879; junior secretary to chief commissioner, June, 1881; also officiated as secretary to the chief commissioner for various periods, and as settlement secretary, March-May, 1882; secretary to chief commissioner and officer in charge of Delhi state prisoners, April, 1886; C.I.E., May, 1886; chief secretary to chief commissioner, April, 1887; commissioner, Minbu, July, 1890; resumed post as chief secretary, Dec., 1890.

SYMNS, ROBERT CORSER MONFTONT, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Westminster, King's College School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service (Burma) after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1888, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

SYMONDS, WILLIAM POWELL, Bombay C.S. —Educated at Hereford Cathedral School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; member of the central committee for departmental examinations, April, 1884; acting under secretary to government, revenue, financial, and general departments, 1884; forest settlement officer, March, 1887; 2nd assistant collector, and acting director of land records and agriculture, Aug., 1887; acting first assistant collector and magistrate, Poona, Nov., 1887; on special duty, Kathiawar, March, 1889; postmaster-general of Bombay, May, 1889.

SZCZEPANSKI, HENRY CHARLES ANTHONY, Colonel, I.S.C., Berar Commission.—First commission, Bengal infantry, June, 1857; arrived in India, 9th Sept., 1857; was employed under the military department up to 1860, including service during the mutiny (medal); assistant commissioner, Punjab, July, 1860; on special famine duty, Nov., 1861; transferred to Hyderabad assigned districts, Nov., 1864, and served as assistant commissioner, cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, and deputy commissioner (1st class, Feb., 1885); officiated as judicial commissioner at various periods, and as commissioner in 1888 and 1889.

Tabor, Francis Samuel, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces and Oudh).—Educated at St. Paul's School and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 26th Nov., 1890, and served as assistant magistrate and collector.

TAHEIRUDDIN AHMED, B.L., Bengal C.S.—Appointed probationer under the native civil service rules, 9th March, 1890; assistant settlement officer in Orissa, March, 1891.

TALBOT, ADELBERT CECIL, Lieut-Colone', C.I.E., I.S.C., Foreign Department, Government of India.—First commission, royal artillery, Jan., 1867; joined the Bengal staff corps, 1869, and served with 4th cavalry, Hyderabad contingent; on special duty with the Afghan commissioner, Seistan Arbitration, 1872-73; officiating assistant agent, Rajputana, 1873; attaché, secretariat, foreign department, 1874; officiating assistant secretary to the government of India, legislative department, and officiating secretary to board of examiners, Calcutta, 1875-76; acting assistant resident, and assistant general superintendent, thagi and dakaiti department, Hyderabad, 1878; 1st assistant agent, Rajputana, Feb., 1878; fellow of Calcutta University, March, 1879; additional political agent, Eastern Rajputana states, 1881; political agent, Bhurtapore and Kerowlee, 1882; political agent, Bikanir, 1883; graded as additional political agent, 1st class; officiated as resident in Turkish Arabia, June, 1888; political agent in Bikanir, May, 1890; officiating resident, Persian Gulf, March, 1891; confirmed, Sept., 1891; edited a revised edition of 'Aitchison's Treaties,' 1876.

TALBOT, GERALD H., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Peter's College, Radley; supervisor, 1st grade, India store depot, 16th June, 1877.

TALBOT, WALTER STANLEY, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Wellington College and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived 31st Oct., 1890, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; officiating under secretary to government, May, 1892.
TANNER, Henry Charles Baskerville, Colonel, Indian S.C., late Survey of India.—First commission, Bombay artillery, June, 1854; accompanied the Persian expeditionary force of 1856 (medal and clasp); joined the survey department as assistant in the Sind revenue survey, Oct., 1862; was afterwards employed in the Central Provinces revenue survey, and was in charge of the Bombay city survey, Dec., 1869; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, April, 1870; was subsequently employed in the Bhawalpur revenue survey, and the Deccan survey, and accompanied the Lushai expedition in 1871-72, and the Khyber column in the Afghan campaign, 1878-79; was afterwards in charge of the Darjeeling and Nepal boundary parties, Nov., 1882; deputy superintendent, 2nd grade, Oct., 1884; employed with the Tibet mission from May, 1886; reverted to military duty, 1890.

TATE, Alexander Chambers, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant, Anantapur, Sept., 1888; principal assistant, Vizagapatam, Jan., 1892.

TATE, William Jacob, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1874, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate; head assistant collector, Salem, Jan., 1883; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1889; district and sessions judge, March, 1890.

TAUNTON, A.G., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at the Jesuits' College, Tournay; writer, India store depot, 29th July, 1868; clerk, and class, Aug., 1878.

TAWNEY, Charles Henry, C.I.E., M.A., Education Department, Bengal.—Joined the department, Nov., 1864, and served as professor, Presidency College, up to Nov., 1876, when he was appointed principal of the college, and promoted to 1st class of the educational service; officiating director of public instruction, Aug., 1879, and again in 1885, 1887, 1889, and from April, 1892; is also registrar of the Calcutta University.

TAWNEY, James Walter, late Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Repton School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 23rd Dec., 1863; served as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant commissioner, Bhootan, till Oct., 1865, and subsequently in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; also acted as small cause court judge, and cantonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, in 1873, and as small cause court judge of Nagpur in 1876; deputy commissioner, 4th class, Oct., 1881; retired, April, 1889.

TAYLER, Skipwith Henry Churchill, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 2nd March, 1853; between July, 1854, and Sept., 1872, served as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector, 1st grade; from Sept., 1872, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, March, 1875; retired, April, 1887.

TAYLER, William Vansittart Graham, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 6th Nov., 1855; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Pubna, Oct., 1866; retired, 1890.

TAYLOR, Sir Alexander, G.C.B., General, R.E.—Educated at Hofuzi, Switzerland, and Addiscombe military college; 1st commission, 9th June, 1843; major, Jan., 1858; colonel, March, 1864; lieutenant-general, Oct., 1877; and general (honorary rank), Dec., 1878; entered the Indian public works department, 26th Dec., 1846, as assistant engineer; executive engineer, Jan., 1848; superintendent of the Lahore and Peshawur road, Dec., 1849; superintending engineer, Nov., 1856; officiating secretary to the government of the Punjab, public works department, Jan., 1865, to Jan., 1867, and Feb., 1871, to Feb., 1872; chief engineer, April, 1872; deputy inspector-general of military works, 1870-1873; president of the defence committee of India, 1876, 1877, 1878; president of the royal Indian engineering college, Cooper's Hill, from Nov., 1880; served throughout the Sutlej campaign (medal with clasps for Ferozeshah and Sobraon), and throughout the Punjab campaign, 1848-9, being present at the action of Sooruj Khoond, the capture of Mooltan, and the battle of Goojerat (medal with 2 clasps); served throughout the Indian mutiny of 1857-8; present at the operations before, and at the siege and capture of Delhi; commanded the Bengal engineers at siege and capture of Lucknow (medal with 2 clasps); served during the Umbeyla campaign, 1863; C.B. in 1858, K.C.B. in 1877, and G.C.B. in 1889.

TAYLOR, Franklin Eden, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1884; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1886; and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, Aug., 1891; acted as under-secretary to government in 1891.

TAYLOR, Frederick Beatson, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's Hospital, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1874; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1886; district and sessions judge, Dec., 1891.

TAYLOR, George Noble, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, in 1840; served in the grades of assistant and head assistant collector and magistrate, and was appointed secretary to the college and university boards, and assistant collector of customs at Madras in special charge of the salt department, 1849; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Rajamundry, 1851; acted as collector and magistrate of Nellore in 1857, and
of South Arcot in 1858; Inam commissioner, 1853; special commissioner for railways, Calcutta, to report upon the affairs of the East Indian railway, May, 1863, and subsequently held a similar post at Bombay; provisional member of governor-general's council, 1864; ordinary member of council, March, 1865; retired, March, 1870.

TAYLOR, Herbert Douglas, Madras C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and St. Peter's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1886; manager of Jeypore estate, Feb., 1890.

TAYLOR, James, Financial Department, Government of India.—Joined the financial department, 1st Sept., 1865, and served in Bengal as assistant to the accountant-general, and deputy accountant-general; assistant comptroller-general, June, 1879.

TAYLOR, S. A., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at Epsom College; junior clerk, India office, 31st Jan., 1867; senior clerk, Jan., 1890.

TEAGUE, George F., Funds Department, India Office.—Senior book-keeper, funds department, India office, 28th Sept., 1866; head book-keeper, March, 1873; designation changed to senior clerk, Oct., 1892.

TEMPLE, Henry Martindale, Major, I.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Sub-lieutenant, 41st regiment, June, 1872; arrived in India, Sept., 1872; extra aide-de-camp to lieutenant-governor, Bengal, Dec., 1875; junior attache, foreign department, government of India, March, 1876; senior attache, June, 1877; cantonment magistrate, Nasirabad, Feb., 1878; assistant to resident, Hyderabad, and assistant general superintendent, thagi and dakaiti, Oct., 1880; officiating judicial superintendent of railways, Nizam's Dominions, June, 1881; assistant to governor-general's agent, Baroda, Nov., 1882; boundary settlement officer, Bundelkhand, Nov., 1884; political agent, Kalat, May, 1885; political assistant, 1st class, March, 1886; political agent, South Eastern Baluchistan, May, 1887; and at Kalat, Nov., 1887.

TEMPLE, James Herbert, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Burnley Grammar School, Repton School, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed member of the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India 20th Dec., 1889, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

TEMPLE, John Alexander, Colonel, I.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, Dec., 1860; arrived in India, 8th Aug., 1861; from Feb., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and acted at various times as cantonment magistrate, Saugor, Jubbulpore, and Kamptee; small cause court judge, Jubbulpore, May, 1872–74, and again, 1877; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1884.

TEMPLE, Sir Richard, Bart., G.C.S.I., C.I.E., D.C.L. (Oxon), LL.D. (Cantab), late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1849; served in the N.W. Provinces and Punjab in the grades of assistant commissioner and assistant magistrate and collector; settlement officer, trans-

Sutlej division, 1852; secretary to chief commissioner, Punjab, 1854; commissioner, Lahore, 1859; chief commissioner of currency and chief assistant to financial member of council, 1860; chief commissioner, Central Provinces, 1865; resident, Hyderabab, 1867; member of governor-general's council, 25th April, 1868; president of the statistical committee, 1868; lieutenant governor of Bengal, 1874; governor of Bombay, 30th April, 1877, to 1880; retired from the civil service in 1877; chairman of the board of visitors, Royal Indian Engineering College, Cooper's Hill, 1880; in Nov., 1885, and again in July, 1886, was returned as M.P. for Evesham, and in 1892 for Kingston; has been a member of the London School Board since 1884; vice-chairman, 1885–8; author of 'Men and Events of my Time in India,' 1882, 'Oriental Experience,' 1883, &c.

TEMPLE, Richard Carnac, Major, I.S.C.—First commission, 4th Jan., 1871; from 11th Aug., 1879, served in the Punjab as assistant cantonment magistrate, and cantonment magistrate, and was promoted to 1st class magistrate, Oct., 1882; transferred to Burma as cantonment magistrate, Mandalay, March, 1887; assistant commissioner, April, 1887; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1888; provisional superintendent of census, 1890; president of the Rangoon municipality, Feb., 1891; author of 'Notes on the Transliteration of the Burmese Alphabet,' 'A dissertation on the proper names of the Punjabis,' 'Wide awake stories' (Punjabi and Cashmiri Folk Tales), and other works; also founded and conducted 'Indian Notes and Queries,' and edited the 'Indian Antiquary.'

TENNANT, James Francis, Lieutenant-General, C.I.E., R.E.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1847; arrived in India, 7th March, 1849; assistant engineer, Ganges canal, 1849 to 1851; assistant in the great trigonometrical survey of India, 1851 to 1859; was garrison engineer to the Delhi field force, and served at the siege and assault of Delhi, and at the siege and capture of Lucknow (medal with two clasps, and brevet of major); government astronomer at Madras, Oct. 1859, to Oct., 1860; commandant, sappers and miners, Oct., 1860, to Sept., 1863; served in the public works department, Sept., 1863, to July, 1871, as executive engineer in Burma, and in the Punjab and Bengal; while on leave was appointed to observe eclipse of the sun, 1867–68, and was deputed for a similar duty in 1871; served as mint master, Calcutta, from July, 1871, to Jan., 1884; on special duty in England, Feb.–April, 1872; superintended the observations of the transit of Venus at Roorkee and Lahore, 1876; C.I.E., Jan., 1879; retired from military service and civil duties on 10th Jan., 1884; is a fellow of the Royal Society, and of the Royal Astronomical Society.

TEUNON, William, Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at University of Aberdeen, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 24th Dec., 1883; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1884; transferred to Assam assistant commissioner, Jan., 1883.

THOM, William, Surgeon-General, F.R.C.S., late Bombay Medical Service.—Educated at
Marisch College, and University of Aberdeen, and at University College, London, and in Paris; F.R.C.S., England; fellow of University of Bombay; assistant surgeon on the Bombay establishment, 1841; served under the military department, first with the artillery, and then with the 3rd regiment native infantry, the 2nd Belooch battalion, the Bombay fusiliers, and the 17th native infantry at Baroda; surgeon, 1854; served subsequently at Belgaum and Poona; in medical charge, marine battalion, Bombay, May, 1860; garrison surgeon, and surgeon to the European general hospital, 1861; served on the medical board of the India office, 1866-67; deputy inspector-general of hospitals, March, 1867; surgeon-general, Feb., 1874; retired, Sept., 1877.

THOMAS, GEORGE EBENEZER, M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Burma.—Appointed from the East India railway as assistant engineer, 28th Aug., 1867, and posted to the Central Provinces; transferred to the Punjab northern state railway, March, 1868; locomotive superintendent, Punjab northern state railway, April, 1875; executive engineer, April, 1876; transferred to Indus Valley state railway, Nov., 1878; 2nd class, revenue establishment, July, 1879; transferred to British Burma, Nov., 1881; class 1, grade 3, revenue scale, Jan., 1887; retired, 1889.

THOMAS, HENRY SULLIVAN, F.L.S., F.Z.S., late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, sub-collector, and joint magistrate, acting collector of sea customs, member of the board of examiners, and acting civil and sessions judge; from May, 1867, to Sept., 1874, served as collector and magistrate of South Canara, and subsequently at Tanjore, and as political agent for French settlement at Karikal; from April, 1878, served on the board of revenue, Madras, and acted as secretary to government in the revenue department in 1878-79; in charge of the Inam department, Jan.-April, 1879; president, board of examiners, Oct., 1881; on special duty as a member of the local self-government committee, Sept., 1882; on duty to Calcutta as an additional member of the governor-general's council for laws and regulations, Dec., 1882, and again, Dec., 1883; on special duty in connection with the pearl fisheries at Tuticorin, and deputed to study system of management in force in Ceylon, March-May, 1884; 1st member, board of revenue, July, 1884; on deputation to Tanjore district to report on necessity for granting remissions, April, 1885; fellow of Madras University, March, 1886; on special duty to Madura, March to Sept., 1886, and to Delhi, to attend conference on agricultural and veterinary questions, March, 1888; on special duty drawing Fisheries Bill, April, 1888; retired, Jan., 1889; has published 'A Report on Pisciculture in South Canara,' 1870; 'The Rod in India,' 1881; and 'A Report on Pearl Fisheries and Chank Fisheries,' 1884.

THOMAS, ROBERT MOSELY BRYCE, Colonel, I.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission as ensign, 6th Jan., 1859; arrived in India, 26th Feb., 1859; from Oct., 1864, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, acting deputy commissioner, and acting small cause court judge, and was appointed can-

tonment magistrate, Jubbulpore, Nov., 1876, and subsequently at Kanpetee; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Dec., 1885; officiating inspector-general of police and jails, April, 1892.

THOMAS, WILLIAM CHARLES, Lieut.-Colonel, Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as officiating adjutant of military police, Mainpuri, Dec., 1858, having previously served as a volunteer in General Havelock's cavalry, 1857-58; adjutant of military police, Oct., 1859; inspector of district police, Jan., 1861; district superintendent of police, May, 1861; officiated as assistant inspector-general of the government railway police, July-Oct., 1868; on special duty with the camp of the lieutenant-governor, Dec., 1876, and again in March, 1878, with the governor-general's camp; 1st grade superintendent, Lucknow, April, 1885; junior deputy inspector-general of police, May, 1886; senior, Jan., 1890.

THOMASON, CHARLES SIMON, Major-Gen., R.E., late Public Works Department, India.—Lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1852; joined the public works department, July, 1855, as deputy superintendent, Ganges canal; during the mutiny served at the battle of Budlekeserai and the siege of Delhi (medal and clasp); executive engineer, Oct., 1858; superintendent, Rohilkund canals, Dec., 1864; officiating superintending engineer and deputy secretary, public works department, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1873; on special duty to Madras, in connection with harbour work, 1877-79; superintending engineer and secretary to governor-general's agent, Central India, Aug., 1880; superintending engineer, 1st class, March, 1882; retired, May, 1888.

THOMPSON, ARTHUR, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at St. Cuthbert's, Ushaw, and University of London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1876, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting principal assistant, assistant sessions judge, acting sub-collector, and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate, and district and sessions judge, head assistant collector, Cuddapah, Nov., 1884; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1890; district and sessions judge, N. Malabar, June, 1891.

THOMPSON, C. T., Registry Department, India Office.—Educated at the City of London School; clerk, 2nd class, India office, 19th March, 1883.

THOMPSON, DANIEL ROBERT, Surgeon-Major, M.D., C.I.E., M.R.C.S., and L.M., late Madras Medical Service.—Acting civil surgeon, Tellicherry, April, 1865, to Sept., 1866; joined the Indian medical service as assistant surgeon, 1st April, 1867; arrived in India, 6th Nov., 1867; and served under the military department, also acting as Zillah surgeon and superintendent of jail at Chingleput, April, 1868; and at Tinnevelly, April, 1869, to Sept., 1870; in medical charge of garrison, lock hospital, and meteorological observatories, Bellary, Dec., 1873; resident surgeon, general hospital, Madras, and professor of pathology and materia medica in Medical College, March, 1875; from May, 1875, served as surgeon, 1st district, Madras, and medical inspector of emigrants; also superin-
tendent of auxiliary provincial medical school, and native infirmary, Royapooram; C.I.E. for special famine services in 1876-78, 1st Jan., 1879; surgeon major, April, 1879; retired, May, 1883.

THOMPSON, David William, Educational Department, Punjab.—Served in the education department from March, 1862, as master in the Zillah Schools at Lahore and Amritsar; inspector of schools, May, 1870; 3rd grade of the department, Nov., 1883.

THOMPSON, Frederick C., Public Works Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, accounts branch, 9th March, 1872; public works department, Aug., 1875; editor of India Office List, 1885-7; senior clerk, 1887.

THOMPSON, George, B.A., Educational Department, Central Provinces.—Head master, Saugor high school, Sept., 1869, to Oct., 1875, served from Oct., 1875, as inspector of schools, Central Provinces; was deputed to attend educational conferences at Naini Tal in 1885 and 1886; officiating inspector-general of education, May to Nov., 1889.

THOMPSON, Henry Edward, M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as Morse assistant, 12th May, 1857; arrived in India, 12th Sept., 1857; superintendent, Dec., 1866; has held charge of various divisions, including Malabar, Bangalore, Arakan, Nagpur, and Rajputana.

THOMPSON, Henry Mungo, B.A., M.I.C.E., Bombay Public Works Department.—Joined the service, July, 1856, as assistant engineer; executive engineer, April, 1871; acted as superintending engineer in Sind in 1884 and 1885, and from Nov., 1890; confirmed, June, 1892.

THOMPSON, Herbert, Bengal C.S (Burma).—Educated at St. Peter's School, York, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1891, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

THOMPSON, Richard Horatio Ely, Forest Department, Central Provinces.—Joined the service as overseer of the government tea plantation, Gurhwal, Oct., 1855; assistant superintendent, Kumaon forests, Jan., 1860; assistant conservator of forests, April, 1864; transferred to Central Provinces, Aug., 1871; deputy conservator, Oct., 1871; on special duty in 1880 and 1885; services lent to government of Ceylon, June, 1887; conservator, April, 1892.

THOMPSON, Ross, Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission, June, 1858; arrived in India, 14th Jan., 1861; joined the public works department, Aug., 1863; executive engineer, April, 1867; district engineer, presidency, April, 1875; consulting architect to government, May, 1875; commanded Queen's Own sappers and miners throughout the Afghan war, 1879-80 (medal); rejoined public works department, Nov., 1880; acted as deputy chief engineer and under secretary to government, Oct., 1881; posted to West Coast division, Oct., 1884; Presidency division, April, 1886; Nilgiri division, July, 1890; Trichinopoly division, Nov., 1890.

THOMPSON, Alexander, late Education Department, N.W. Provinces.—Served in Oudh, Aug., 1866, to April, 1877, as inspector of schools, and acted as director of public instruction in 1866 and 1868; from April, 1877, served as professor of English literature in the Agra College, and acted for various periods as principal; confirmed, July, 1883; retired, April, 1892.

THOMSON, Andrew, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, Dec., 1885; served in Burma as assistant commissioner; transferred to Upper Burma on special duty, March, 1886; personal assistant to chief commissioner, March, 1887; officiated as under secretary to chief commissioner, Feb. to April, 1888.

THOMSON, George, Brigade-Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, M.B., Medical Department, Punjab.—Arrived in India, 7th April, 1866; served in military department to July, 1879; services placed at the disposal of the Punjab government, and appointed officiating civil surgeon, 2nd class, Aug., 1879; confirmed in his appointment, Sept., 1880; medical adviser to H.H. the Maharaja of Patiala, in 1882, 1888, and 1889, and from Sept., 1890.

THOMSON, James, M.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Grammar School, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1871, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; sub-collector, joint magistrate and principal assistant to collector, magistrate and agent, Godaveri, June, 1885; collector and magistrate, Nov., 1889.

THOMSON, John Brown, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at the Academy, and University, Edinburgh; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, Nov., 1870, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating magistrate and collector, officiating small cause court judge, and officiating cantonment magistrate; joint magistrate, 2nd grade, Feb., 1882; deputy superintendent of family domains of Maharaja of Benares, Nov., 1882; registrar of the high court, N.W. Provinces, May, 1884; magistrate and collector, April, 1889; officiated as secretary to government in 1889 and 1890.

THOMSON, Robert George, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Islington Proprietary School, and University of London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1872; arrived in India, 13th Nov., 1874, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner and settlement officer; junior secretary to financial commissioner, Dec., 1882; officiating under secretary (revenue department) to government, Punjab, June, 1883; officiating junior secretary to government, Jan., 1884, and again in 1885 and 1886; senior secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1886; on special duty revising rules under the Punjab land revenue bill; postmaster-general, Punjab, Feb., 1888; junior secretary to government of Punjab, and officiating revenue secretary, April, 1890; confirmed, April, 1892.
THOMSON, SAMUEL JOHN, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as surgeon, 1st Oct., 1877; arrived in India, 27th April, 1878; served on military, general, and jail duty, and as officiating deputy sanitary commissioner, and was confirmed in that office, May, 1885; officiated as sanitary commissioner in 1887, 1888, and 1892; author of 'Sanitary Principles.'

THORBURN, SEPTIMUS SMET, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, officiating divisional judge, and settlement officer, and officiating commissioner and superintendent; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Jan., 1881; deputy commissioner, April, 1883; officiating commissioner and superintendent, April, 1889; confirmed, Jan., 1892; author of 'Bannu, or Our Afghan Frontier,' 'David Leslie,' and a report on the settlement of the Bannu district.

THORBURN, WALTER MILLER, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Dalhousie College, and University, Halifax, University of Edinburgh, and King's College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Oct., 1884; district and sessions judge, Dec., 1890.

THORNHILL, EDMUND BENSLEY, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 16th Aug., 1854; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating small cause court judge; from Feb. to Sept., 1865, served in Oudh as officiating deputy commissioner, Fyzabad; magistrate and collector, Banda, March, 1872; civil and sessions judge, Banda, Nov., 1877; retired in 1885.

THORNHILL, GEORGE, C.S.I., late Madras Civil Service.—Educated at Rugby, and Haileybury, and appointed to the Madras civil service in 1842; arrived in Madras, 7th April, 1843; served as assistant to collector and magistrate in various districts, and was employed as civil officer in connection with the construction of the Godavari and Kistna anicuts; principal assistant to collector and magistrate, Ganjam, 1856; collector and magistrate, Kistna, 1861; member of board of revenue, 1870-78, during which period he was frequently employed by government on special duties of various kinds; was also appointed director of bank of Madras, and commissioner for uncovenanted civil service examinations, 1875; retired, 1878.

THORNHILL, HENRY BEAUFOP, Captain, North-Western Provinces Administration.—1st commission, 23rd April, 1873; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1873; on field service, Afghanistan, Oct., 1878, to April, 1879 (medal); cantonment magistrate, Feb., 1887; appointed deputy superintendent, Port Blair, May, 1888; cantonment magistrate, N.W. Provinces, April, 1891.

THORNTON, ARTHUR PARRY, Major, I.S.C., Foreign Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 14th foot, 14th Sept., 1867; arrived in India, Jan., 1868; admitted to the Bengal staff corps, Sept., 1871; served under government of Bengal in Purneah and Burdwan as relief circle officer during famine, March-Dec., 1874; served under the foreign department of the government of India from Jan., 1875, and acted as assistant agent to governor-general, Rajputana, and as magistrate, Mount Abu, and assistant general superintendent for suppression of thuggee and dacoity; in charge of office of political agent, Marwar, Jan.-March, 1877; attached to foreign office during Delhi durbar, 1876-77; on military duty, 1878-79; from March, 1879, served under foreign department as cantonment magistrate at Morar, and at Nasirabad; assistant to governor-general's agent, Rajputana, Jan., 1882; cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Secunderabad, Feb., 1884; political agent, Bhopawur, May, 1886; Harowtce and Tonk, March, 1889.

THORNTON, EDWARD, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse, and at Haileybury College, where he obtained honours, and from which he was appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1829; arrived in India, Feb., 1830; served in the N.W. Provinces, first as settlement officer, and afterwards as magistrate and collector; commissioner in the Punjab, Jhelum division, 1849-58; made C.B. for his services during the mutiny; judicial commissioner of the Punjab, 1858; retired, 1860.

THORNTON, EDWARD LABOUCHERE RUTHVEN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Marlborough, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1891, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate.

THORNTON, JAMES HOWARD, Surgeon-Colonel, C.B., B.A. and M.D., late Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1856; from 9th Nov., 1861, served as civil assistant surgeon and civil surgeon, besides service under the military department; rank of surgeon-major, Jan., 1868, and brigade surgeon, March, 1882; principal medical officer with the Indian forces, Egypt, 1883; C.B., Aug., 1885; deputy surgeon-general, Punjab frontier force, June, 1886; retired, Aug., 1891.

THORNTON, LESLIE MELVILLE, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 1st Jan., 1881, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant secretary to government N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Oct., 1883; under secretary to government, Oct., 1886; officiated as financial secretary, Feb., 1891, and district and sessions judge, April, 1891; joint magistrate, Aug., 1891.

THORNTON, THOMAS HENRY, C.S.I., D.C.L., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and St. John's College, Oxford (1st class, moderations; Pusey and Ellerton Hebrew scholar; 2nd class, final schools); appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition, 1855; assistant commissioner, Punjab, 1857-59; personal assistant to financial commissioner, Punjab, 1859-60; personal assis-
tant to judicial commissioner, 1860-62; small cause court judge, Lahore, 1862-63; deputy commissioner, Delhi, 1863-64; secretary to the government of the Punjab, 1864-78, and was on two occasions temporarily in charge of the administration of the province; acted as foreign secretary to the government of India, 1876-77; additional member of governor-general's council, 1877-79; judge, chief court, Punjab, 1878-81; retired, 1881; fellow of University of Calcutta, 1875; vice-president, University College, Lahore, 1879.

THUILLIER, Sir Henry Edward Landor, General, Kt., C.S.I., R.A., F.R.S., late Survey of India.—Educated at Addiscombe, 1831-32; first commission, Bengal artillery, Dec., 1832; arrived in India, 19th Oct., 1833; served in the survey department, from Dec., 1836, and conducted the surveys of Jyntee, the Poorer division of Cuttack, and the district of Cachar, and part of Sylhet; while on furlough to England, 1844-46, was orderly officer of Warley barracks for a year; deputy surveyor-general of India, Jan., 1847, to March, 1861, when he was appointed surveyor-general of India; retired Dec., 1877; lieutenant-colonel, 1861; companion of the Star of India, May, 1870; knighted in 1879; major-general in 1870; lieutenant-general, July, 1879; general, July, 1881; colonel commandant, R.A., Jan., 1883; joint author of the 'Manual of Survey for India.'

THUILLIER, Henry Ravenshaw, Colonel, R.E., Survey of India.—Addiscombe, Aug., 1855, to June, 1857; lieutenant, Bengal engineers, June, 1857; arrived in India, 29th April, 1859; appointed to the survey department as assistant in the great trigonometrical survey, May, 1859; deputy superintendent, Sept., 1860; officiating superintendent, great trigonometrical survey, April-Oct., 1870; 1st grade deputy superintendent, Oct., 1878; deputy surveyor-general in charge of the revenue survey branch, Oct., 1884; acting surveyor-general from Feb., 1886; was confirmed, Feb., 1887.

TIDY, William Meymott, M.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1860; served in the N.W. Provinces from Aug., 1862, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Sept., 1878; retired, 1886.

TINNEY, G. F., Registry Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 4th July, 1882.

TODD-NAYLOR, Henry Paul, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Shrewsbury, and University College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882; transferred to Burma as assistant commissioner, March, 1886; officiating cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, April, 1886; deputy commissioner, May, 1890; C.I.E., Jan., 1890.

TODHUNTER, Charles George, Madras C.S.—Educated at Aldenham Grammar School and King's College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 26th Nov., 1890, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and in the revenue survey department.

TOMKINS, William Percival, C.I.E., Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—First commission, June, 1860; joined the public works department, June, 1863, as assistant engineer, Assam; transferred to Rangoon, British Burma, Jan., 1865; acted as assistant to chief engineer and assistant secretary to chief commissioner, Jan.-Aug., 1865; executive engineer, Oct., 1866; transferred to military works branch, Nov., 1873; assistant secretary to government of India, civil and military works branch, April, 1880; superintending engineer and secretary to agent to governor-general, Beloochistan, 1882; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Aug., 1884; 2nd class, May, 1888; 1st class, Dec., 1889; C.I.E., Jan., 1890; chief engineer, Sept., 1890.

TOMLINSON, Thomas Armstrong, Madras Revenue Survey Department.—Appointed 10th Aug., 1859, and served as assistant superintendent; deputy superintendent, June, 1866; on special duty, Pudukota boundary, 1887, and in 1888.

TOTENHAM, Loftus Richard, Bengal C.S.—Appointed from Haileybury College; arrived, 11th July, 1856; served as assistant, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; also as superintendent of stamps and stationery, Jan., 1866, and registrar of the high court, Dec., 1866; from Jan., 1874, served in the judicial department as district and sessions judge, and officiated as superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, Feb., 1878; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 16th July, 1879.

TOWERS, Robert Mason, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 21st Jan., 1863; assistant magistrate and collector, Aug., 1863; from July, 1867, served in the judicial department as small cause court judge and district and sessions judge; judge of the principal courts of small causes in Nudda and Jessore, Feb., 1879; from Jan., 1878, to Feb., 1880, served as officiating judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur; served subsequently as district and sessions judge, and was promoted to 1st grade, May, 1885; retired, 1888.

TOWLE, Arthur Henry, Store Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 12th Dec., 1892.

TOWNSEND, Stephen Chapman, Surgeon-General, C.B., late Bengal Medical Service.—Educated at the Grammar School, Ottery St. Mary, Devon, and the London Hospital Medical School; assistant-surgeon in the Indian medical service, June, 1852; arrived in India, 26th Sept., 1852; employed in regimental and other military duty to Feb., 1862, and served in the Burma campaign, 1852-53; civil surgeon, Nagpur, Jan., 1865, to March, 1868; sanitary commissioner, Central Provinces, March, 1868, to Oct., 1878, and officiated as sanitary commissioner with the government of India, Feb., 1877 to March, 1878; rank of deputy surgeon-general, Dec., 1873; principal medical officer with the Kuram field force under General Sir F. Roberts, April, 1879; and was wounded in action, Sept., 1879; surgeon-general with the Punjab government, April, 1880; Companion of the Bath, Feb., 1881; retired, Dec., 1883.

TOYNBEE, George, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1864; arrived, 27th Nov., 1865; assistant magistrate
and collector, Aug., 1866; superintendent canal revenue, Oct., 1871; on famine relief duty, Nov., 1873; officiating secretary, board of revenue, lower provinces, Dec., 1874; second inspector of registration offices, April, 1877; on special duty connected with compulsory irrigation rate, May, 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Dec., 1877; special duty at the Bengal secretariat, July, 1878; magistrate and collector, Feb., 1884; commissioner, Cuttack division, May, 1891; author of 'Sketch of the History of Orissa from 1803 to 1828,' 'Sketch of the Administration of the Hugli District from 1795 to 1845,' and 'A Chowkidari Manual.'

TOZER, Henry J., B.A., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 10th Jan., 1882; B.A. (Honours), London University, 1889.

TRACY, Thomas Burrowes, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1857; arrived in India, 29th Dec., 1857; served in the N.W. Provinces from Nov., 1858, as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Muttra, April, 1877; from Feb., 1883, served as civil and sessions judge, and acted as judicial commissioner in Oudh, 1884-85; retired, Sept., 1887.

TRAFFORD, Richard Wylme, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1864, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating cantonment magistrate; judicial assistant, April, 1879; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Dec., 1886, and 2nd grade, Nov., 1889; retired, Oct., 1891.

TRAIL, David Henry, Colonel, R.E., late Bengal Public Works Department, Accounts Branch.—1st commission, Madras engineers, 1856; from Sept., 1859, served in the Madras public works department; served in the China war, 1860, and was present at the battle of Sinho, and capture of Tangku and Taku forts (medal and clasp); employed in the great trigonometrical survey of India, March, 1862; assistant engineer, 1st grade, Sept., 1865; from Jan., 1866, was employed in the accounts branch of the public works department, and served as controller of accounts in Mysore, Madras, Punjab, and Central Provinces; transferred to Bengal, Nov., 1882; examiner of public works accounts, 1st class, Feb., 1884; officiating accountant-general, and deputy secretary, government of India, P.W. department, April-June, 1885; examiner, public works accounts, Bengal, Dec., 1887; retired, Nov., 1890.

TREASURE, W. H., Legal Department, India Office.—Clerk to the legal adviser to the secretary of state, June, 1877; solicitor of the supreme court, 1887; assistant to the legal adviser, Aug., 1892.

TREMENHEERE, Charles William, Lieut.-General, C.B., R.E., late Public Works Department, Government of India.—Educated at Adiscombe; 2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, 11th Dec., 1829; served as civil engineer in Dharwan, 1833-40, and as executive engineer Surat and Broach, and acting superintending engineer, Guzerat, 1843-46; assistant executive engineer, Aden, Jan., 1846, to Feb., 1847; from Dec., 1848 to March, 1850, served in Scinde as executive engineer, Kurrachee, and acting superintending engineer; dock yard, Bombay, March, 1850, to May, 1853; acting secretary, military board, May, 1853, to Jan., 1854; on special duty, Bombay, designing reclamations, docks, and fortifications, Jan., 1854, to Jan., 1855; major, Sept., 1855; deputy consulting engineer, railway department, Jan., 1855, to Aug., 1856; garrison engineer, Bombay, and acted as superintending engineer, Poona circle, 1856-57; was commanding engineer to the forces under Sir Hugh Rose, and General Roberts, 1857-58, and was present at the sieges of Awah and Kotah, and the engagements of Sanganeeer and Kotarea; Indian mutiny medal and clasp for Central India; military C.B., March, 1861; superintending engineer, southern provinces, Feb., 1860; chief engineer, Scinde, May, 1862; chief engineer, presidency, Nov., 1866; major-general, March, 1867; political resident, Aden, with command of the brigade, Dec., 1870; retired with honorary rank of lieutenant-general, July, 1874.

TREMENHEERE, James Henry Apperley, Madras C.S.—Educated at Lancing and Cheltenham Colleges; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1875, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting assistant commissioner (Nilgiris); from May to Aug., 1883, served in Mysore as acting civil and sessions judge; served subsequently in Madras as head assistant collector, and acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and was appointed acting assistant secretary to government, judicial and legislative departments, June, 1884; officiating private secretary to the governor of Madras, May to Aug., 1885; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Aug., 1888; collector and magistrate, July, 1890; district and sessions judge, Aug., 1890.

TREMLETT, James Dyer, M.A., Barrister-at-Law, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1860, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and deputy commissioner; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Hissar, Aug., 1878; additional commissioner, Umballa and Jullundur, Nov., 1880; promoted to deputy commissioner, 1st class, Sept., 1881; commissioner and superintendent, Delhi, April, 1883; additional judge, chief court, April, 1884; divisional judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; judge, chief court, Punjab, Sept., 1886; retired, March, 1889.

TRETHEWY, Anthony William, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1883; served in the North West Provinces, as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, March, 1890.

TREVELYAN, Ernest John, B.L., Calcutta High Court.—Advocate, high court, Calcutta, 1875-83; officiating secretary, board of examiners for pleaders, &c., 1875-82; officiating magistrate, Calcutta, N. division, 1876; puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1885;
also president, board of examiners for pleaders and mookhtars, 1886.

TREVOR, ARTHUR CHARLES, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Lincoln College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 28th Oct., 1861, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector of stamp revenue and political agent, acting collector of Bombay and superintendent of stamps and stationery, acting municipal commissioner, and deputy commissioner of customs and opium (June, 1877); collector of customs, Bombay, April, 1879; acting commissioner of customs, and collector of salt revenue, May, 1884, and July, 1888; senior collector, Dec., 1884; collector of salt revenue, Oct., 1885; and grade commissioner and commissioner of customs, salt, opium, and abkari, and reporter-general of external commerce, Sept., 1888; also British delegate for the Portuguese treaty; 1st grade commissioner, and acting commissioner in Sind, May, 1889; confirmed in the latter post, Nov., 1890; member of Bombay council, Sept., 1892.

TREVOR, CHARLES BINNY, late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service in 1830; arrived in India, 12th June, 1832; served in Bengal, in the grades of assistant commissioner, assistant collector and magistrate, and joint magistrate, and deputy collector; magistrate of Backergunge, June, 1840; superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, 1849; judge of sudder dewanny and nizamut adawlut, Presidency, 1859; judge of the high court, Calcutta, 1863; retired in 1867.

TREVOR, EDWARD WALTER, Colonel, I.S.C., Sind Commission.—1st commission, April, 1855; arrived in India, 8th May, 1855; appointed acting superintendent of bazaars and cantonment magistrate, Neemuch, March, 1864; from Nov., 1864, served in Sind, as deputy collector and magistrate, acting district superintendent of police, and acting collector and magistrate; on military duty, Oct., 1879, to Jan., 1881, as general transport officer, Khyber line, and director, Kuram transport; deputy commissioner, Upper Sind frontier, Jan., 1881; on special duty to Calcutta, in connection with the prosecution of commissariat frauds, Nov., 1881; collector and magistrate, Hyderabad, Dec., 1883; has acted as commissioner in Sind.

TREVOR, FREDERICK G. B., Judicial and Public Department, India Office.—Educated at St. Peter's School, York, and Marlborough College; East India House writer, old establishment, 10th March, 1838; junior clerk, public, educational, and ecclesiastical departments, Aug., 1860; senior clerk, July, 1875; judicial and public department, 1877; assistant secretary in that department, June, 1887.

TREVOR, GEORGE HERBERT, C.S.I., Colonel, I.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—Joined the Madras artillery, 5th April, 1853; from June, 1852, served in the Central Provinces as inspector of schools, and was secretary to the Jabalpur exhibition committee in 1866; subsequently acted as cantonment magistrate, assistant secretary to chief commissioner, and assistant commissioner; from Oct., 1867, acted as assistant resident, Hyderabad; secretary for Berar, April, 1877; deputed to accompany Sir Salar Jung on his tour to Europe in 1867 as political officer; political agent, 1st class, July, 1881; officiated as resident at Hyderabad, May-June, 1882; officiating resident (2nd class) and commissioner, Ajmere-Merwara, Nov., 1885, and confirmed in those appointments, Nov., 1887; agent to governor-general, Rajputana, and chief commissioner of Ajmere-Merwara, March, 1890.

TREVOR, JOHN SALUSBURY, C.S.I., Major-General, late R.E.—Passed out of Addiscombe, June, 1847; 2nd lieutenant, Bombay engineers, April, 1848; assistant superintendent of roads and tanks, 1849-55; transferred to railway department in Aug., 1855, as deputy consulting engineer; municipal commissioner, Bombay, 1865; resigned appointment in railway department, 1864; rejoined the public works department in Nov., 1866, as executive engineer, 1st grade, Tapti irrigation; consulting engineer and under secretary to government of Bombay, railway branch, Nov., 1868; chief engineer, 3rd class, Sept., 1870; acting deputy secretary to government of India in railway branch, 1871-72; resigned appointment in Bombay railway department, 1874; in England, 1874-78; officiating deputy secretary to government of India, railway branch, June, 1878; resigned the army, 1879, continuing in the public works department; director-general of railways, and deputy secretary, railway branch, 1880; retired in 1881; chairman of the Bombay, Baroda, and Central India, and the Rohilkund and Kumaon railway companies, and a director in several other Indian railway companies.

TREVOR, SALUSBURY THOMAS, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Bengal.—1st commission, Dec. 1852; arrived in India, and Nov., 1854; from Jan., 1855, to Oct., 1863, served in British Burma as assistant engineer, executive engineer, assistant to chief engineer, and assistant secretary to chief commissioner in the public works department; transferred to Bengal, Oct., 1863; served as garrison engineer, Fort William, and supervising engineer, 3rd class, and was appointed secretary to chief commissioner, Assam, public works department, July, 1869; chief engineer, and joint secretary public works department, Bengal, March, 1881; on deputation in connection with International Exhibition buildings at Calcutta, July, 1883; chief engineer and secretary to government of Bengal, public works department, railways and roads and buildings, Jan., 1884; chief engineer, 1st class, July, 1885; retired, 1890.

TREVOR, WILLIAM SPOTTISWOODE, Major-General, V.C., R.E., late Public Works Department, India.—2nd lieutenant, Bengal engineers, Dec., 1849; arrived in India, 5th Feb., 1852; served in the Burmese war, 1852-53 (medal with clasps); employed on the Pegu survey, 1854; executive engineer, Bassein, Nov., 1855; was subsequently posted to Darjeeling and Dinapur; garrison engineer, Fort William, 1861; controller and examiner of accounts, Bengal, May, 1855; served the Bhutan campaign, 1855 (medal and V.C.); superintending engineer, Calcutta, Jan., 1867; consulting engineer to government of Bengal, irrigation, Jan., 1868; superintending engineer, military works, Calcutta, 1872; additional chief engineer for famine relief works, Bengal, 1874; officiating chief engineer and secretary to governor-general's agent, Indore, April-Dec., 1875; officiating chief engineer and
secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, Feb., 1876; chief engineer and secretary, British Burma, Dec., 1878; director-general of railways and deputy secretary to government of India, March, 1883; secretary to government of India in the public works department, Feb., 1882; retired, 1887.

TROWARD, THOMAS, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 9th Oct., 1869, and served in the Punjab as assistant cantonment magistrate, assistant commissioner, officiating judicial assistant, and officiating deputy commissioner; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1886; officiating divisional judge in 1887 and 1888, and appointed divisional judge, 3rd grade, May, 1889.

TRUEMAN, THOMAS, Colonel, Indian S.C., late Cantonment Magistrate, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1856, and served on military duty up to June, 1872, including the mutiny campaign under Sir Hugh Rose (medal and clasp), and subsequently as assistant cantonment magistrate at Poona and Kirkee, and cantonment magistrate, and city magistrate, Karachi; appointed cantonment magistrate, Ahmedabad, April, 1877, and subsequently at Belgaum; on famine duty, Sholapur, Sept., 1877; retired, Nov., 1883.

TUCKER, ALEXANDER LAZUN PENDOCK, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Winchester, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 28th Dec., 1882; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1883; forest settlement office, Bijapur, Feb., 1885; services placed at disposal of government of India, foreign department, April, 1888; assistant to resident at Hyderabad, and assistant secretary for Berar; settlement officer, Kotputli (Jeyore) in Rajputana; assistant to the governor-general's agent, Central India, April, 1890; in 1891 acted as under secretary to government of India, foreign department.

TUCKER, HENRY ST. GEORGE, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at University College, London; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and settlement officer; judicial assistant, 1st grade, Dec., 1883; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; appointed commissioner in Burma, May, 1886; retired, Sept., 1890; author of reports on the settlement of the Dera Ismail Khan and Kohat Districts.

TUCKER, HENRY PENDOCK ST. GEORGE, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, in 1842; arrived in India, 14th April, 1843; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge in various districts in the Bombay presidency, and acted as deputy registrar of the Sudder court in Bombay, in 1845-46, and as judge and sessions judge, in 1853, and in 1856-57; acting first assistant accountant-general, Bombay, July, 1858; acting civil auditor, Bombay, Dec., 1858 to March, 1859; collector and magistrate, North Canara, July, 1862; judge and sessions judge, Konkan, Aug., 1862; appointed to report on the measures necessary for a redistribution of judicial jurisdiction and modification of judicial establishments, Feb., 1863; officiating judge of the high court, Bombay, June, 1863; member of council, Bombay, 7th April, 1869; retired in 1876.

TUCKER, LOUIS HENRY EMILLE, C.I.E., Colonel, Bengal Infantry, Police Department, Punjab.—First commission, 1860; arrived in India, 11th April, 1861; from Sept., 1864, served in the police department, Punjab, as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; on special duty with Major Cavagnari in connection with Kabul war, Nov., 1878, and again with the staff of Major-General Bright, Sept., 1879; 1st grade, district superintendent, Sept., 1880; officiating deputy inspector-general, 2nd grade, March, 1885; confirmed in appointment, March, 1888; served under the government of India, home department, from Sept., 1888, to April, 1889; reappointed deputy inspector general of police, Punjab, May, 1889; C.I.E., Jan., 1891.

TUDBALL, WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Bedford Modern School and Christ Church, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1887, and served as assistant magistrate and collector; joint magistrate, March, 1892.

TUPP, ALFRED COTTERELL, B.A., F.S.S., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University College School, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived in India 29th Nov., 1862; from Oct., 1863, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and was placed on special duty for the conduct of the case of the Munsif of Mahoba, Dec., 1867, and again, July, 1869, for the preparation of a statistical memoir of Futehpur; assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, April, 1871; also subordinate judge from March, 1873; held charge of Provincial Gazetteer of N.W. Provinces, March, 1876, to Feb., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Azimgarh, Aug., 1877; transferred to the financial department, government of India, Nov., 1878, and served in Madras, till 1881, as deputy accountant-general, deputy controller-general, and accountant-general, and commissioner of state paper currency; officiated as accountant-general in Bombay, Dec., 1881, to Dec., 1882, and in Bengal from the latter date; officiating comptroller-general, Sept.-Oct., 1883; from Nov., 1883, served as accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, and deputy commissioner of paper currency; accountant-general, class I., Nov., 1887; accountant-general of Bombay and commissioner of the department of state paper currency, Bombay, Dec., 1887; accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Nov., 1888; retired, Oct., 1889; author of 'The Indian Civil Service and the Competition System,' 1875; 'The Statistics of the North-West Provinces of India,' 1876; The Imperial Gazetteer of India—N.W.P. portion, 1877; 'The Indian Civil Service List, and Record of Services,' 1880; 'The Paris International Monetary Conference of 1881, and Bimetallism,' 1881; 'The Competitive Civil Service of India, from 1856 to 1882,' 1882.

TUPPER, CHARLES LEWIS, B.A., Bengal
C.S. (Punjab). — Educated at Harrow, and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, and officiating under secretary to government, and was placed on special duty in office of financial commissioner, Sept., 1874, and with H.H. the Maharaja of Patiala, Nov., 1875; appointed under secretary to government of Punjab, April, 1877; officiating under secretary to government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Sept., 1878; officiating secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1880; from Feb., 1880, served under the government of India as acting under secretary and acting secretary in the revenue and agricultural department, and was placed on special duty, Sept., 1881 (in connection with the Bengal Rent Bill), and again, Feb., 1882; junior secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1882; on special duty in connection with scheme of local self-government, June-Oct., 1883; acted as secretary to government, April, 1884, to Feb., 1886, and was on special duty in connection with the frontier crime commission, Feb.—March, 1886; officiating secretary to government, Punjab, Dec., 1887, confirmed, Nov., 1888; chief secretary to government, March, 1890; author of 'Customary Law of the Punjab,' vols. I-III.

TURNER, Sir Charles Arthur, Kt., C.I.E., Council of India. — Educated at Exeter College, Oxford (fellow, 1855, B.A., 1856, M.A., 1859); called to the bar (Lincoln's Inn), 1858, and went the western circuit; appointed judge of the high court of judicature, N.W. Provinces, and arrived in India, May, 1866; acted as chief justice in 1870, 1875, and 1878; chief justice of the high court of judicature, Madras, Jan., 1879; fellow of the University of Madras, Jan., 1879; member of the Indian law commission, Bengal, Feb.—Sept., 1879; vice-chancellor of Madras University, April, 1880, and May, 1882; retired, 1st July, 1885; appointed member of the public service commission, 1885-6; member of the council of India, 2nd Feb., 1888.

TURNER, Edward, Madras C.S.—Educated at Shrewsbury, and University College, London; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived, 20th Nov., 1864; served in various districts of Madras from May, 1866, as assistant collector and magistrate, and was employed on state famine relief operations, Jan., 1877, to March, 1878; sub-collector and joint magistrate, April, 1882; collector and magistrate, Cuddapah, Jan., 1885; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, Feb., 1885; collector and magistrate, Madura, Jan., 1886.

TURNER, Henry Gribble, Barrister-at-Law, late Madras C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1866; from Aug., 1866, to Dec., 1867, served in the police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; on special duty, Madras, inquiring into condition of poorer classes, Jan., 1868; acting under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, March, 1875; postmaster-general, Madras, March, 1875, to June, 1881; from June, 1881, acted as collector, magistrate, and political agent, Vizagapatam; appointed district and sessions judge, North Arcot, June, 1884, but continued to act as collector, &c., at Vizagapatam, and was confirmed in this post, Nov., 1885; retired, July, 1890.

TURNER, Lawrence Herbert, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at City of London School, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant commissioner.

TURNER, Samuel Compton, Lieut.-Col., R.E., Military Works Department, Government of India.—1st commission, 17th April, 1866; arrived in India, 18th Dec., 1868, and joined the public works department as assistant engineer in Bombay, Jan., 1869; executive engineer, Feb., 1873; from Dec., 1873, served under the government of India; officiated as assistant secretary, military department, in 1886 and 1887; 3rd superintending engineer, March, 1890; 2nd, Nov., 1891.

Tute, Arthur Clifford, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at St. Peter's School, York, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1871; assistant magistrate and collector, in Bengal, April, 1872; on famine relief duty, Salem, March, 1877, and at Trichinopoly, Sept., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, July, 1884; magistrate and collector, March, 1888.

Tweedie, John, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived 13th Dec., 1860; assistant magistrate and collector, July, 1861; officiating superintendent, Chittagong hill tracts, June, 1863; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1864; officiating postmaster-general, Bengal, Aug., 1870, to March, 1873; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Oct., 1867; from June, 1874, served in the judicial department, and was appointed judge of the small cause courts, Kishnaghur, Ranaghat, and Meherpore, Oct., 1876; district and sessions judge, Jan., 1877.

Tweedie, Maurice, Colonel, I.S.C., Police Department, N.W.
