Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign, 23rd Oct., 1856; during the mutiny served with the field force in Central India, and subsequently with the mounted police in Oudh, and on the Nepal frontier (medal and clasp); from June, 1860, served as district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade, May, 1886; officiating deputy inspector-general of police, April, 1888; junior deputy inspector-general, Jan., 1890; author of 'A Chapter on the Fauna of the Province of Oudh,' for incorporation in the Oudh Gazetteer.

Tweedie, William, C.S.I., Colonel, I.S.C.—First commission, Bengal infantry, Jan., 1857; during the mutiny served in Oudh, and was present at the siege and capture of Lucknow, and afterwards took part in the pursuit of Tantia Topee in Central India (medal and clasps); adjutant, 1st cavalry, Hyderabad Contingent, March, 1859; acted as assistant to resident, Hyderabad, from 1863; served in the
Abyssinian Expedition, 1868 (medal and brevet of major); 1st assistant resident, Hyderabad, and general superintendent, thagi and dakaiti department, Oct., 1868; agent to governor-general, Moorshedabad, 1876-77; political agent, Gwalior, 1878-79; during the Afghan war was senior political officer with Major-General Bright, during advance on Kabul, and was in charge of Jalalabad division, March, 1880 (medal, C.S.I.); officiating political agent, Western Rajputana states, 1880-81; acted subsequently as resident in Western Rajputana, in Gwalior, and Turkish Arabia; officiating commissioner, Ajmere, March-June, 1885; officiating resident in Turkish Arabia, July, 1885; confirmed, March, 1886; reverted to military duty, Oct., 1891.

TWEDDY, GEORGE ALFRED, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at King's College School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1879, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and cantonment magistrate; joint magistrate, Nov., 1887; assistant commissioner, March, 1890; superintendent, Dehra Dun, April, 1891; has also officiated as magistrate and collector, and district and sessions judge.

TWIGG, JOHN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Repton, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate and forest settlement officer; special assistant to collector and magistrate, Dec., 1887; head assistant collector, Dec., 1890; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Nov., 1891.

TWIGG, JOHN HILL, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Royal School, Dungannon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from May, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and was deputed on special duty under the commissioner of cotton and commerce for the organisation of carriage and supply of fodder for Bengal, Feb. to Sept., 1874; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1880; magistrate and collector, 2nd grade, Hamirpur, April, 1882; 1st grade, Aug., 1885; additional commissioner, Benares division, April, 1889; retired, July, 1890.

TWISADAY, CHARLES EDWARD JAMES, Public Works Department, India Office.—Appointed to the London offices of the Indo-European telegraph department on the 29th July, 1869; accompanied director-in-chief to Constantinople in 1880, as personal assistant, and to the Persian Gulf in 1885 with the third Persian Gulf cable expedition, and afterwards to India; on abolition of London office of the Indo-European telegraph department, his services were transferred to India office, 1st Jan., 1889.

TWOMEY, DANIEL HAROLD RYAN, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at St. Stanislaus College, Tullamore, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 22nd Dec., 1884; assistant commissioner, British Burma, Dec., 1884; under secretary to chief commissioner, Jan., 1889; acted as secretary, July-Dec., 1890, and as junior secretary, Dec., 1890, to Feb., 1891; deputy commissioner, April, 1891; officiating junior secretary, March, 1892.

TYLER, SIR JOHN WILLIAM, Kt., C.I.E., M.D., F.R.C.S., L.R.C.P., L.M., L.S.A. (London).—Joined the service as officiating civil surgeon, Etah, 6th May, 1863; appointed also civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Mainpuri, April, 1869; superintendent, central and district jails, Meerut, April, 1873; superintendent, central and district jails, Agra, April, 1876; on special duty at the Calcutta Exhibition, Nov., 1883, to Jan., 1884; officiated as inspector-general of prisons in 1884; deputed for duty in connection with the Colonial and Indian Exhibition, March, 1886; C.I.E., June, 1886; on special duty in Dholepur State, Dec., 1886; deputed to accompany H.H. the Maharaja of Bharatpur to England for Her Majesty's Jubilee; Kt., 1888; inspector-general of prisons, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Sept., 1890.

TYRRELL, WILLIAM, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1858; arrived in India, 12th May, 1859; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating under secretary to government, officiating small cause court judge, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; registrar, high court, N.W. Provinces, Aug., 1870; magistrate and collector, Jan., 1878; civil and sessions judge, 2nd grade, Jan., 1882; puisne judge, high court, N.W. Provinces, Nov., 1882.

UMESH CHUNDER BATABYAL, M.A., Bengal C.S.—Master in the Sanskrit College, Calcutta, Aug., 1873; deputy magistrate and deputy collector, Feb., 1880; appointed member of the statutory civil service, May, 1888; assistant magistrate and collector, June, 1888.

UDNY, RICHARD, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at University of Aberdeen, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 25th Nov., 1869, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, Feb., 1885; on special duty, March to April, 1885; and again from Aug. to Dec., 1888; officiating divisional judge, Dec., 1890; officiating commissioner and superintendent, Peshawar, Feb., 1891.

UNDERWOOD, ORMSBY CHARLES HENRY, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Blairlodge School, Trinity College, Oxford, and University College, London; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 28th Nov., 1890, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

UNDERWOOD, WALTER GREGORY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Rossall School, and Chester College; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 17th Sept., 1870, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty to the Laccadives, Nov., 1881; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Tanjore, Dec., 1885; acting district and sessions judge, June, 1886; collector and magistrate, Jan., 1889.
UNWIN, ARTHUR HAMILTON, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's School, Sherborne, and Tonbridge Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; from Feb., 1873, served in British Burma as assistant commissioner, inspector of schools, acting judge of the small cause court, and acting director of public instruction; from Jan., 1880, served in the Bombay Presidency as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge, and acting judge and sessions judge; 1st grade, assistant judge, Oct., 1883; assistant judge and joint sessions judge, for Kaira and Panch Mehals, May, 1885; 3rd grade judge, and sessions judge, May, 1887.

UPCOTT, FREDERICK ROBERT, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, Dec., 1868, as assistant engineer; executive engineer, Nov., 1874; specially thanked for services in connection with the erection of the Jhelum bridge on Sindh-Sagar state railway, June, 1887; superintendent of way and works, Punjab section, North Western railway, Dec., 1887; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1890; engineer-in-chief, Bengal-Assam railway, northern section, Nov., 1891.

UPTON, JOHN G., late Registry Department, India Office.—East India house writer, old establishment, 16th April, 1845; assistant to registrar, July, 1860; despatch clerk, July, 1877; retired, Sept., 1892.

UPTON, ROBERT LECYSTER.—Government solicitor, high court of judicature, Calcutta, from 1881.

UPTON, SAMUEL RICHARD, Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Writer, 3rd Feb., 1876; clerk specially attached, Sept., 1892.

VAN SOMEREN, GODLIB JAMES, Colonel, late Forest Department, Government of India.—First commission, Madras infantry, Sept., 1859; appointed to the forest department, May, 1864; conservator of forests, Mysore and Coorg, May, 1866; transferred to Punjab, 1881; assistant comptroller-general of forest accounts under the financial department, Feb., 1883; conservator of forests, Berar, Jan., 1885; also director of the forest school from Aug., 1889; retired, Feb., 1892.

VARADA RAO, TUMALAPALLI, B.A., B.L., Madras C.S.—Educated at Madras University; probationer for the civil service, July, 1885; assistant to collector and magistrate, Dec., 1886; confirmed in civil service, Aug., 1887.

VAUGHAN, ERNEST LLEWELLYN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Blackheath School, and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in Madras, 10th Jan., 1888, and served in the revenue survey department, and as assistant to collector and magistrate; acting assistant accountant-general, Madras, May, 1892.

VAUX, ALFRED R. B., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Writer, 29th June, 1874; clerk specially attached, Sept., 1892.

VENGAL VENUGOPAUL CHETTI, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Madras Christian College, Madras University, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 21st Nov., 1890, and served as assistant collector and magistrate.

VENKATA JAGA RAO, CHENDIKA, B.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Madras University; appointed by government of India as probationer for the civil service, 22nd Dec., 1880; assistant collector and magistrate, April, 1883; retired, April, 1892.

VENKATRAO RUKMANGAD INAMDAR, B.A., LL.B., Bombay C.S.—Served in the subordinate judicial department from 27th Feb., 1880; appointed assistant collector in Bombay presidency under native civil service rules, 9th April, 1889; acting assistant judge and sessions judge, from same date.

VENNING, FREDERICK, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at University College, London; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1863; arrived in India, 24th Nov., 1864; served from Aug., 1865, to Nov., 1868, in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; from Nov., 1868, served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner, and acted as small cause court judge of Jubbulpore in 1874, and as secretary to the chief commissioner in 1878; inspector-general of police and prisons, Central Provinces, June, 1880; commissioner of the Jubbulpur division, Aug., 1881; and of the Nagpur division, Nov., 1883; acting judicial commissioner, June, 1889, Nov., 1890, and Sept., 1891; reverted to Nagpur appointment, Nov., 1891.

VENTRIS, HENRY, Revenue and Statistics Department, India Office.—Educated at Highgate School, and Brighton College; supernumerary writer, 2nd Feb., 1860; temporary clerk, Dec., 1860; clerk in registry department, Feb., 1864; junior clerk, revenue department, Jan., 1873; employed in records branch, 1879-1880; senior clerk, June, 1885.

VERNER, WILLIAM HENRY, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College, and Victoria College, Jersey; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1861; arrived and Dec., 1863; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed officiating assistant secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1867, joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1877, and district and sessions judge, Nov., 1879; also served as inspector of schools, April, 1866, and officiated as under secretary, government of India, home department, Feb., 1871, and as postmaster-general, Bengal, in 1871, 1872, and 1875; district and sessions judge, 1st grade, Oct., 1883; retired, Dec., 1888.

VERTUE, WILLIAM, Colonel, I.S.C., Central Provinces Commission.—First commission, June, 1857; from 2nd Dec., 1862, to May, 1865, served in the police department of the Central Provinces as acting district superintendent, and personal assistant to the inspector-general; from May, 1865, served as assistant commissioner, and acted as inspector of schools, and superintendent of the school of industry at Jubbulpur, 1867; cantonment magistrate, Saugor, Jan., 1877; small cause court judge, Nagpur, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, Sept., 1883.

VIBART, HENRY MEREDITH, Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—First commission as lieutenant, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, 30th Nov., 1859; assistant engineer in the
Madras public works department, Sept., 1861; executive engineer, Dec., 1866; on special duty in Bangalore, Nov., 1877, to Feb., 1878; in special charge of the restoration of Tiruoomal Naick's palace, Madura, Feb., 1878; acting deputy chief engineer for irrigation, and under secretary to government, public works department, March, 1879; superintendent of works, Presidency, April, 1880; superintending engineer, April, 1884; 1st class, June, 1888; retired, Dec., 1891.

VIDAL, GEORGE WILLIAM, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Eton, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1867, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, forest settlement officer, and acting collector and magistrate; on special duty connected with the Jath state, March, 1873; first assistant collector and magistrate, Dec., 1878; on special duty as a British member of the mixed commission at Goa, March—May, 1880, and Jan., 1885; president of the Bombay forest commission, Dec., 1885; junior collector and magistrate, Panch Mahals, and political agent, Rewa Kanta, Sept., 1886; collector of salt revenue, Sept., 1888; senior collector, March, 1890; acting chief secretary to government, Dec., 1890, to April, 1891.

VINCENT, ROBERT WILLIAM EDWARD HAMPE, Bombay Police Department.—Joined the service, 1st March, 1869, and served as inspector, officiating deputy commissioner and acting superintendent of police; assistant superintendent, May, 1875; superintendent, March, 1876; on special duty in 1875 and 1886; 1st grade, May, 1892.

VINCENT, WILLIAM HENRY HOARE, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ College, Brecon, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1887, and served as assistant magistrate and collector in Bengal.

VOWELL, CHRISTOPHER HENRY, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived, 4th Dec., 1867; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, Nov., 1877; magistrate and collector, July, 1884.

WACE, ALFRED AUGUSTUS, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Eton, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1868; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, Feb., 1880; also served as officiating inspector-general of registration, March, 1879; magistrate and collector, Nov., 1884; in 1891 served in Assam as acting judge and commissioner, Assam Valley district, July, 1891; officiating commissioner, Chota Nagpur division, May, 1892.

WADDINGTON, GEORGE, late Bombay C.S.—Appointed to the Bombay civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; arrived, 21st Dec., 1857, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; junior collector and magistrate, Kaladgi, Dec., 1878; senior collector, Aug., 1881; collector and magistrate, district registrar, and political agent, Sholapur, Oct., 1882; collector and magistrate, and district registrar, Ahmednagar, Nov., 1886; retired, Nov., 1891.

WAHAB, ROBERT ALEXANDER, Captain, R.E., Survey of India Department.—First commission, 29th April, 1873; assistant superintendent, survey department, Jan., 1883; deputy superintendent, 4th grade, July, 1888; 3rd grade, Feb., 1891; served in the Afghan war, 1879-80, in Mahsud Waziri expedition, 1881, Zhob Valley expedition, 1884, and with Hazara field force and Miranzai field force in 1888 and 1891.

WADE, EDWARD J., M.A., India Office.—Educated at Rugby, and Trinity College, Dublin (scholar and exhibitioner, first senior classical moderator and gold medallist); assistant librarian, India office, 23rd May, 1881; late editor 'Allen's Indian Mail.'

WAKE, HERWALD CRAUFURD, C.B., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College in 1851; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate of Shahabad, 1853; C.B., May, 1866; magistrate and collector, Patna, 1861; superintendent, Darjeeling, 1862; retired on invalid pension, 1868.

WALCH, GEORGE TURNER, M.I.C.E., Madras Public Works Department.—Appointed assistant engineer, 31st March, 1866; executive engineer, April, 1873; acted as deputy chief engineer, and under secretary to government, Feb., 1877; on special duty, Madras irrigation company's canal, July, 1882; had charge of Kurunool canal, and other works; superintending engineer, March, 1887; acted as chief engineer for irrigation, and as joint secretary and afterwards as secretary to government in 1888, 1889 and 1890; chief engineer for irrigation, Sept., 1889; joint secretary, public works department, with charge of irrigation branch, July, 1890; officiated as secretary, April—July, 1891; author of 'Notes on some of the Navigable Rivers and Canals of United States and Canada,' 1876.

WALKER, FRANCIS BLENNERHASSETT, Railway Branch, Government of India.—Appointed to the Bombay public works department, Sept., 1863; executive engineer, July, 1868; transferred to Punjab, January, 1870, and was employed on Punjab Northern state railway; served subsequently on the Neemuch and Western Rajputana state railways; transferred to Bombay railway branch, March, 1881, and subsequently to Bengal; engineer-in-chief, Northern Bengal and Tirhout railway extensions, March, 1883; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Dec., 1885; 2nd class, May, 1889; engineer-in-chief, East coast railway survey, Nov., 1889; 1st class superintending engineer, Feb., 1890; chief engineer, 3rd class, Jan., 1892.

WALKER, GEORGE CASSON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Winchester College, and New College, Oxford; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 6th Jan., 1878, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner; served under the foreign department of the government of India, Feb.—Sept., 1880; on special duty, Lahore, in connection with Viceregal durbar, Oct., 1880; from April, 1883, served in the financial department of the government of India, and was appointed assistant accountant-general, Punjab; transferred to office of accountant-general, Bengal, Dec.,
1883; from Feb., 1884, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating district judge; served under the government of India from Sept. to Nov., 1886; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade, April, 1887, and 1st grade, April, 1890; settlement officer, Lahore, Feb., 1888; also officiating director of land records and agriculture, May, 1892.

WALKER, GEORGE HERBERT DACRES, B.A., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed assistant secretary to government N.W. Provinces and Oudh, 1st May, 1874; served subsequently in accounts branch; officiating under secretary to government of India, public works department, Nov., 1882 and 1886, and appointed permanently, May, 1887.

WALKER, GEORGE WARREN, General, R.E., late Public Works Department, Madras.—Second lieutenant, Madras engineers, 9th Dec., 1842; assistant civil engineer, 1847; district engineer, Canara, Sept., 1859; superintending engineer, Coimbatore, May, 1863; chief engineer, and secretary to government of Madras, public works department, May, 1872; retired from the public works department in 1876.

WALKER, H. B., Store Department, India Office.—Matriculated at London University, 1875; clerk, 2nd class, India store depot, 6th July, 1877; 2nd grade supervisor, July, 1888.

WALKER, JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at the University of Aberdeen, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competition of 1883; arrived in Madras, 1st Dec., 1886, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; transferred to Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, Dec., 1890.

WALKER, JAMES THOMAS, General, R.E., C.B., LL.D., late Survey of India Department.—Appointed to the Bombay Engineers from Addiscombe, 9th Dec., 1844; assistant chief engineer, Bombay, May–Sept., 1846; executive engineer, Upper Sind, May, 1847, to Oct., 1848; served throughout the Punjab campaign, 1848–49, and was present at siege of Mooltan, and battle of Goojerat (medal and clasp); from 1849 to 1853 served as military surveyor of the Trans-Indus frontier from Peshawur to Dera Ishmail Khan, and was present at numerous frontier engagements; from Dec., 1853, to March, 1861, served as assistant in the great trigonometrical survey; during the mutiny of 1857 served with the Punjab moveable column, and subsequently as field engineer at Delhi (brevet of major, medal and clasp); in 1860 accompanied the Mahsud Waziri expedition (medal and clasps for frontier service); from March, 1861, to Feb., 1883, served as superintendent of the great trigonometrical survey, and from Jan., 1878, to Feb., 1883 also held the appointments of surveyor-general of India, and superintendent of topographical surveys, and carried out the amalgamation of the three survey departments; fellow of the Royal Society, 1865; C.B., 1877; hon. LL.D. of Cambridge, 1885; superintended the preparation and publication of the first nine volumes of the account of operations of the great trigonometrical survey; author of occasional papers for the Royal Geographical Society and United Service Institution, presidential address to the geographical section, British Association, in 1885, and contributions to the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

WALKER, JAMES WILLIAM, LL.B., Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at King's College School, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1868, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, and acting judge and sessions judge; on special duty in connection with the Baroda commission, Feb.–March, 1875; acting remembrancer of legal affairs, Jan.–March, 1880; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Ahmedabad, Feb., 1885; 1st grade, Nov., 1887.

WALKER, THOMAS GORDON, Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at the Gymnasium, Old Aberdeen, and University of Aberdeen; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Nov., 1872, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner, and was settlement officer of Ludhiana from May, 1878 to 1884; attached to civil secretariat on special duty in April, 1883; officiating under secretary to government, revenue department, Punjab, April, 1883; officiating senior secretary to financial commissioner, Sept. to Dec., 1883; officiating registrar of the chief court, Punjab, Nov., 1884, and April, 1887; officiating junior secretary to government, Aug., 1886, to Feb., 1887; on special duty, Punjab civil secretariat, Feb.–April, 1887; senior secretary to financial commissioner, Feb., 1888; commissioner of excise, and inspector-general of registration, &c., Nov., 1888.

WALKER, THORNTON, M.A., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1885, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and officiating assistant judge and sessions judge.

WALKER, WILLIAM, Deputy Surgeon-General, M.A., M.D., LL.D., F.R.C.S. (Ed.), late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 4th Aug., 1855; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1855, and held various military medical charges in Bengal and N.W. Provinces, including service in the mutiny campaign, 1857; superintendent, central prison, Agra, March, 1858; superintendent, government press, and curator, government books, N.W. Provinces, Sept., 1862; also chemical examiner, Dec., 1864; rank of surgeon, Aug., 1867; honorary magistrate, Allahabad, Aug., 1867; inspector-general of prisons and dispensaries, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1871; also for Oudh, March, 1877, to April, 1879; brigade-surgeon, Nov., 1879; deputy surgeon-general and inspector-general of civil hospitals, with local rank of surgeon-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Oct., 1882; officiating surgeon-general with the government of India, May, 1887; officiating in same appointment and as sanitary commissioner with the government of India, April, 1888; retired, Oct., 1890.

WALKLATE, HAROLD THORNTON, Audit Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 31st Oct., 1892.

WALL, RICHARD, M.A., LL.D., B.L., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Queen's College, Cork; appointed to
the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; served in N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Benares, Feb., 1877; officiating civil and sessions judge, May, 1877, and in 1883; commissioner of excise and stamps, and inspector-general of registration, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, Feb., 1882; retired, Oct., 1891; author of stamp, excise, and registration manuals.

WALLACE, A. C., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 17th Feb., 1872.

WALLACE, Sir Donald Mackenzie, M.A., LL.D., K.C.I.E.—Educated at the Universities of Edinburgh, Heidelberg, and Berlin, and the Ecole de droit, Paris; was "Times" correspondent in Russia, Austria, and the East, 1878-84; private secretary to the Marquess of Dufferin and Ava, when governor-general of India, 1884-8; was member of mission to Kabul, 1888; appointed to accompany the Czarewitch during his visit to India, 1890-91; author of 'Russia,' 'Egypt and the Egyptian Question,' &c.

WALLACE, William Arthur James, C.I.E., Colonel, R.E., Public Works Department, Punjab.—1st commission, Dec., 1860; arrived in India, April, 1864; assistant engineer, public works department, April, 1864; officiating deputy consulting engineer, railway branch, Bengal, Jan., 1866; assistant consulting engineer, Feb., 1870; executive engineer, 3rd grade, Sept., 1870; deputy consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Calcutta, Oct., 1871; acted as consulting engineer, Lucknow, and at Calcutta; on special duty in connection with Imperial assemblage at Delhi, acting as under secretary to government of India, Oct., 1876, to Feb., 1877; on deputation to England in connection with Paris Exhibition, 1878; secretary to railway conference at Calcutta, Oct., 1878; acting under secretary to government of India, railway branch, 1878-79; served in the Afghan war, 1879 (medal); engineer-in-chief, and manager, Northern Bengal state railway, Nov., 1879; 1st class state railway revenue establishment, Nov., 1879; served in the Egyptian campaign, 1882 (medal and clasp, and bronze star, 4th class, Osmanieh); officiating consulting engineer for guaranteed railways, Lahore, Oct., 1884; class 1, grade 1, revenue establishment, Oct., 1885; director, North-Western railway, May, 1887; deputed to Switzerland to examine the Abt system of railways, July-Oct., 1887; C.I.E., Jan., 1890.

WALLER, Hardress Edmond, Major-General, I.S.C., late Police Department, Bengal.—First commission, 10th Aug., 1852; joined the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent, June, 1862; district superintendent, March, 1863; 1st grade, district superintendent, March, 1884; retired, June, 1886.

WALLER, Richard Maunsell, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1865; arrived, 4th Dec., 1867; assistant magistrate and collector, Jan., 1868; officiating deputy collector of customs, Calcutta, Feb., 1877; joint magistrate and deputy collector, April, 1878; deputy commissioner, April, 1879; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1885.

WALLERSTEIN, Philip Herman, Major, I.S.C., Judicial Department, N.W. Provinces.—1st commission, 13th July, 1867; served with the 6th foot and 24th P.N.I.; admitted to the staff corps, Aug., 1869; officiated as cantonment magistrate, July, 1873, and Dec., 1880; confirmed, Jan., 1881; 1st class cantonment magistrate, March, 1887.

WALPOLE, Sir Horace G., K.C.B., Assistant Under Secretary of State, India Office.—Educated at Eton; temporary clerk, India office, 12th Dec., 1862; junior clerk, June, 1863; store department, 1863; accountant-general's department, 1863-64; public works department, 1864; resident clerk, 1870-77; senior clerk, April, 1877; private secretary to the permanent under secretary of state, 1866-74 (Mr. Herman Merivale, C.B.), and to the secretary of state, 1874-80 (the Marquis of Salisbury, 1874-78, and subsequently, Viscount Cranbrook); C.B., 1880; also served as clerk of the council from 1877, and was appointed assistant to the under secretaries of state in addition to his other duties, Sept., 1881; assistant under secretary of state, Nov., 1883, continuing to be clerk of the council; royal commissioner of the Colonial and Indian Exhibition, 1886; secretary to the royal commission on civil establishments, 1886-1890; K.C.B., Aug., 1892.

WALSH, Ernest Herbert Cooper, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trent College and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1882; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1884; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1884; joint magistrate and deputy collector, Oct., 1891.

WALTON, Frederick Thomas Granville, C.I.E., M.I.C.E., Railway Department, Government of India.—Appointed to department as engineer-in-chief, Oudh and Rohilkhand railway, 1st Jan., 1889.

WARBURTON, Harris Grant, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Dover College and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1885; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1887, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; acting assistant accountant-general, Bengal, Oct., 1891.

WARBURTON, Robert, C.S.I., Lieutenant-Colonel, I.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 24th Oct., 1862; from Sept., 1869, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating cantonment magistrate, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special political duty in Khyber, July, 1879; employed with Cabul force, Oct., 1879; officiating judicial assistant commissioner, Peshawur, Nov., 1881; political officer, Khyber, Feb., 1882; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, but to continue political officer, Khyber, Nov., 1884; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Nov., 1884; author of an account of the Boner and Amazai tribes, and a report on the district of Sughman; C.S.I., Jan., 1890.

WARBURTON, William Pleace, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon - Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the Indian medical department in 1866; arrived in India, 11th Dec., 1866; assistant-surgeon, Jullundur, Sept., 1867; surgeon to H.H. the Raja of Kapurthala, June, 1874; medical adviser to H.H. the Raja of Kapurthala, May, 1890; also officiated as superintendent of Kapurthala state, May to Aug., 1890; civil surgeon, 2nd class, Dec., 1891.
WARD, Alfred W., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, 2nd Aug., 1892.

WARD, George Ernest, B.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Wadham College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Sept., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, assistant superintendent of Dehra Dun, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Jaunpur, July, 1879; on special duty on the education commission under the government of India, 1882; commissioner, Jhansi division, July, 1885; retired, July, 1889.

WARD, Henry Constantine Evelyn, C.I.E., Colonel, I.S.C., late Central Provinces Commission.—Arrived in India, as ensign, April, 1855; was employed under the military department up to 1864, including service at the siege and assault of Delhi, 1857 (medal and clasp), and at the battle of Narouli, Nov., 1857; served also with Eusufzai expedition, 1858, and in the campaign against the Mahsood Waziris, 1859-60 (frontier medal); assistant commissioner, Dec., 1864; deputy commissioner, May, 1870; acting inspector-general of registration, superintendent of stamps, and commissioner of excise, Central Provinces, Nov., 1873; additional commissioner for the administration of affairs in Kalahandi, June, 1882; acting commissioner, Chhattisgarh division, March-Nov., 1883; and again in 1884; on special duty as special commissioner for the repression of dacoity in Nerbudda division, Feb., 1886; from June, 1886, served under the government of India, as minister of the Bhopal state; commissioner, Nerbudda division, Aug., 1889; reverted to military department, 1892.

WARD, Theodore Methuen, Colonel, late Survey Department, Sind.—Joined the service, 9th Dec., 1859; lieutenant, Bombay artillery, April, 1860; admitted to Bombay staff corps, Nov., 1864, and from that date served in the revenue survey department; lieutenant-colonel, Dec., 1885; superintendent, Sind revenue survey, June, 1889; reverted to military duty, 1890.

WARD, William Erskine, C.S.I., M.A., Bengal C.S. (Assam).—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1861, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and officiating magistrate and collector officiating under secretary to government of India, home department, Nov., 1865, to April, 1866, and again in 1867, and in department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, March, 1873; officiating magistrate of police, Calcutta, April, 1873; from Oct., 1873, served in judicial department as acting district and sessions judge, and was transferred to Assam, March, 1876, and served as judge and commissioner of Assam Valley districts; officiated temporarily as judicial commissioner of Central Provinces, Jan., 1883; fellow of University of Calcutta; officiating chief commissioner of Assam, July-Oct., 1883; and from Feb., 1885, to 1887; officiating judicial commissioner, British Burma, April, 1884; president of provincial committee for collecting exhibits of Assam for Calcutta Exhibition, 1883; judicial commissioner, Burma, May, 1886, continuing to act as chief commissioner of Assam; C.S.I., Jan., 1888; took charge of office in Burma, March, 1889; chief commissioner of Assam, May, 1891.

WARDEN, Augustus Brooke, late Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Kensington Grammar School, and Haileybury College; appointed to the Bombay civil service, 1842; served in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, and assistant judge and sessions judge, and was appointed judge and sessions judge of Ahmedabad, March, 1850; judge and sessions judge, and agent for governor, Surat, 1861; acting judge of the high court, May, 1863; judge and sessions judge of Poona, and agent for Sirdars in the Deccan, Sept., 1863; judge of the high court of judicature, Bombay, 1865; was also president of the departmental examinations committee for junior civilians for five years; retired, 1871.

WARDEN, Charles James Hislop, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—First commission, 1874; from 18th March, 1876, acted as civil surgeon of Bhagulpore, with medical charge of the central jail; on special duty in the excise department, board of revenue, Dec., 1876; officiating principal assistant to the opium agent, Behar, April-Oct., 1878; officiating superintendent, central jail, Bhagulpore, Nov.-Dec., 1879; professor of chemistry, Medical College, and chemical and opium examiner to government, Dec., 1879; member of opium committee, Oct., 1880; surgeon-major, March, 1886; services placed at disposal of military department, March, 1892.

WARDEN, Frederick, Commander, late Royal Indian Marine.—Joined the Indian navy, 2nd March, 1852; from Dec., 1865, served as port-master of Canning, and, in addition (from Jan., 1867), as assistant collector of customs and ex-officio superintendent of customs; from Dec., 1866, acted as assistant master attendant, and agent for government consignments, Calcutta, and from March, 1870, as agent for transports; also government prosecutor for trial of pilots, May, 1873, to March, 1876; officiating deputy master attendant, Aug., 1875; officiated as port officer, March, 1876, to Aug., 1879, and performed duties of superintendent of dockyard, from March, 1876, to Nov., 1877; assistant port officer, Aug., 1879; examiner in navigation, Nov., 1879; transferred to Rangoon as post officer, March, 1882; also superintendent of lighthouses, superintendent of mercantile marine, and transport agent; retired, Sept., 1890.

WARDEN, John Lodwick, B.A. (Oxon.), Barrister-at-Law, late Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 8th March, 1852, and served in the Bombay covenanted civil service as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant judge and sessions judge, and deputy magistrate in charge of the Adalat, Hyderabad; resigned the covenanted civil service, May, 1858; appointed extra assistant secretary to government of Bombay, in the judicial department, Dec., 1866; assistant judge and sessions judge, April, 1867, to June, 1868; acting magistrate of police, July-Oct., 1868; from Jan., 1869, served as small cause court judge, and was appointed 3rd judge, at Bombay, Dec., 1874, and second judge, May, 1883; retired, 1889.

WARRE, Sir Henry James, General, K.C.B.,
—Obtained commission from Sandhurst, 1836; ensign, 54th foot, 3rd Feb., 1837; from 1839 served as aide-de-camp to commander of the forces in British North America (Sir R. Downes Jackson, K.C.B.); during 1845 and 1846 was employed by colonial office in exploring a route for transport of troops from Canada to the Red River settlement, by Ottawa, and in surveying and reporting on the various settlements in the Oregon Territory, and on various islands on the coast of the Pacific; served in the Crimea from March, 1855, and succeeded to the command of the 57th regiment; present at the siege and fall of Sebastopol, the assaults on the Redan, and the surrender of Kinbourn (medal with clasp, C.B., 5th class of the Medjidie and Turkish medal); in 1858 was in command of a mixed force on the Tapte River in co-operation with the Central India field force, and was subsequently appointed brigadier at Mhow; military secretary to the commander-in-chief in India (Lieutenant-General Sir Hugh Rose, K.C.B.), June, 1860; served in the Maori war in New Zealand, 1861, and acted for a short time as governor of the province of Auckland; was subsequently in command of the troops on the west coast, and in the province of Taranaki (under martial law), 1863-66 (medal); from 1870-74 was stationed in Ireland as brigadier-general; commander-in-chief, and member of governor's council, Bombay, Nov., 1878 to 1881.

WARRY, WILLIAM, M.A., Political Department, Burma.—Appointed political officer on special duty in Burma, 10th Feb., 1887; adviser on Chinese affairs, April, 1892.

WATERFIELD, HENRY, C.B., Financial Department, India Office.—Educated at Westminster; junior clerk, 1st Sept., 1853; India board, financial and railway department, 1853; political and secret department, 1856; private secretary to president of the India board, 1858; India office, financial department, 1858; assistant private secretary and précis writer to the secretary of state, 1860; financial department, 1863; senior clerk, April, 1863; assistant secretary in the military department, 1867; public works department, 1871; secretary in the statistics and commerce department, 1874; secretary, financial department, 1879; C.B., Dec., 1885; author of the first report on the moral and material progress of India, 1866, and of a memorandum on the census of British India of 1871-72, both of which were presented to Parliament.

WATERFIELD, WILLIAM, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Westminster; appointed to the Bengal C.S. from Haileybury in 1852; arrived in India, 19th Nov., 1852; served in Bengal in the revenue and survey departments till 1859, when he was transferred to the financial department as 1st assistant to the accountant-general for India; acted as sub-treasurer, Madras, and as civil auditor and superintendent of stamps, Madras, Calcutta, and Bombay; from 1864 to 1877 served successively as civil paymaster, deputy accountant-general, and accountant-general, N.W. Provinces and Oudh; comptroller-general, 1877-80; retired, 1881.

WATERFIELD, WILLIAM GARROW, C.S.I., Colonel, I.S.C., Barrister-at-Law, late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1852; from Sept., 1857, served in the Punjab as personal assistant to commissioner of Delhi, and assistant commissioner; small cause court judge, Sept., 1863, to Nov., 1865; assistant settlement officer, Gujarat, Nov., 1865; deputy commissioner, Dec., 1867; on special duty for reporting on the Gujarat settlement, July, 1868; commissioner and sessions judge, Peshawur, Feb., 1878; commissioner and superintendent, Sept., 1878; on special duty, Nov., 1878 (with the Kurram field force); served under the foreign department of the government of India, 1881-82; retired, Nov., 1888; author of a report on the settlement of the Gujarat district.

WATERHOUSE, JAMES, Colonel, I.S.C., Survey of India.—Lieutenant, Bengal artillery, June, 1859; arrived in India, 11th Oct., 1859; assistant revenue surveyor, Lower Provinces, June, 1866; assistant surveyor with superintendence of the photozincographic operations in the office of the surveyor-general of India, July, 1866; assistant superintendent of survey, 1st grade, June, 1870; on special duty with the Indian eclipse expedition, Nov., 1871, to Jan., 1872, and for observing the transit of Venus, Oct., 1874, to Jan., 1875; in charge of Indian eclipse expedition to Nicobar Islands, March, 1875; assistant surveyor-general, April, 1874; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Jan., 1884; and 2nd grade, April, 1889; assistant surveyor-general in charge of photo-lithographic office, Calcutta, from Dec., 1886; author of a pamphlet on 'The Application of Photography to the Reproduction of Maps and Plans,' and other reports and handbooks on professional subjects.

WATERS, GEORGE, Surgeon-Lieut.-Colonel, L.R.C.S., L.R.C.P. (Ed.), Medical Department, Bombay.—Joined the Bombay medical service, 1st Oct., 1869; arrived in India, 27th May, 1870, and served in the military department, and as acting ophthalmic surgeon, Bombay, and civil surgeon at Bushire (1871-75); on special duty under the government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, March-April, 1877; surgeon to governor of Bombay, May, 1877; from Oct., 1881, served as third physician and registrar, Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital, curator of the pathological museum, and professor of pathology, Grant Medical College; also acted as first physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital, and professor of medicine, clinical medicine and hygiene; confirmed as first physician, Jamsetji Jijibhoi Hospital, and professor of pathology and morbid anatomy, and hygiene, Grant Medical College, Nov., 1888; presidency surgeon, 3rd district, Nov., 1889.

WATKINS, LAWRENCE AUGUSTUS, Judicial Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1863; served in the Bombay judicial department from Jan., 1865, as deputy registrar of the high court, clerk to the high court judges, and commissioner for taking affidavits; also acted as assistant commissioner for taking accounts, and assistant taxing master, Aug.-Oct., 1878.

WATSON, HERBERT EDWARD, Sind Commission.—Arrived in India, 29th June, 1864; from Nov., 1865, served in Sind as deputy collector and magistrate, and acted as political superintendent of Thar and Parkar, June, 1879; in charge of the special duty of the salt department in Sind, July-Oct., 1880; on special duty in the military department, June, 1881; head assistant collector in Sind, July, 1884; deputy commissioner, Thar and Parkar, June, 1885.

WATSON, SIR JOHN, Lieutenant-General,
K.C.B., V.C., I.S.C., late Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, Bombay infantry, 1848; served in Punjab campaign, 1848-49, Bozdar expedition, 1857, Mutiny, 1857-58, and Umbeyla expedition, 1863; from Sept., 1871, served as commandant, Central India Horse, and political agent; resident, 2nd class, and agent to the governor-general at Gwalior, April, 1877, also acting as agent for Central India; brigadier-general commanding cavalry brigade, Malta expeditionary force, 1873; commanding Punjab chiefs' contingent in Afghanistan, 1878-79; in political charge of the district of Kuram, Nov., 1879, to Nov., 1880; resident, 1st class, and agent to the governor-general, Baroda, Jan., 1882; retired from the political department, March, 1886.

WATT, GEORGE, M.D., C.I.E., Revenue and Agricultural Department, Government of India.—Appointed, 11th July, 1873; arrived, 4th Nov., 1873; served in the 3rd class of the Bengal education department as professor, Presidency, Hooghly, and Patna Colleges, and as officiating principal, Krishnagar College, and was placed on special duty in connection with the Burma-Munipore boundary expedition, Oct., 1883; services placed at disposal of executive committee of the Calcutta International Exhibition, Feb., 1883; served under government of India, revenue and agricultural department, from May, 1884; appointed to charge of imperial Indian economic court of Colonial and Indian exhibition; C.I.E., June, 1886; reporter on economic products, April, 1887; editor of the 'Dictionary of Economic Products.'

WAY, THEODORE ALBAN HENRY, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces and Oudh).—Educated at Clifton College and Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 26th Nov., 1890, and served as assistant commissioner.

WEBB, WILLIAM TREGO, M.A., late Educational Service, Bengal.—Joined the service, 6th April, 1875; professor, Dacca College, May, 1875; officiated as inspector of schools, Feb., 1877; professor, Presidency College, from Jan., 1878; officiating principal, Calcutta Madrassa, in addition to other duties, 1880, and again in 1887 and 1890; 3rd class, education department, Dec., 1880; retired, March, 1892; has published 'Hints on the Study of English,' 'Indian Lyrics,' and translations.

WEBSTER, EDMUND FORSTER, C.I.E., Barrister-at-Law, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1857; served in the revenue and judicial departments, Madras, and was appointed small cause court judge, Madura, May, 1867, and afterwards at Cuddalore; district and sessions judge, Cuddapah, June, 1873, and at Trichinopoly, Aug., 1873; collector and magistrate and agent, Tanjore, April, 1878; on special duty in connection with the famine commission, Oct., 1878, and again, Aug., 1881, as secretary to the famine code committee; member of the forest draft bill committee, March, 1882; secretary to government, revenue department, June, 1882; member of the local self-government committee, June, 1882; additional member of council for making laws and regulations, July, 1883, and again, July, 1885, and March, 1886; chief secretary to government of Madras, Jan., 1884; fellow of Madras University, March, 1884; member of the committee in connection with the draft tenancy bill, July, 1885; retired, Oct., 1887; C.I.E., May, 1888.

WEBSTER, HENRY BINNY, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service from Haileybury College, 1854; arrived in India, 17th June, 1854; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and assistant settlement officer, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Saharanpur, Nov., 1867, and subsequently at Gorakhpur and Meerut; commissioner, Jhansi division, Jan., 1878; inspector-general of police, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1880; retired, 1886.

WEBSTER, JOHN EDWARD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at the Charterhouse and Trinity Hall, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 26th Nov., 1891, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

WEDDERBURN, FRANCIS EDWARD KEIR, Madras C.S.—Educated at Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1878; arrived in India, 29th Nov., 1880, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; officiating political agent and assistant to the resident in Mysore, and secretary to chief commissioner of Coorg; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Nov., 1888; special assistant to collector and magistrate, Ganjam, April, 1890.

WEDDERBURN, HARRY GEORGE, B.L., Judicial Department, Madras.—Reporter for the Indian law reports (Madras series), June, 1881; law reporter, March, 1888; administrator-general, temporary, Aug., 1888; confirmed, March, 1889; acting advocate-general, and additional member of legislative council of Fort St. George, April, 1891 to Feb., 1892.

WEDDERBURN, SIR WILLIAM, Bart., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; arrived 25th Nov., 1860, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, acting judicial assistant to the commissioner in Sind, and small cause court judge; acting under secretary to government in the judicial and political departments, and secretary to the council for making laws and regulations, June, 1866; acting registrar-general of assurances, Oct., 1866; acting secretary to government in the judicial, political, educational, secret, and Persian departments, Dec., 1866, and again in 1870 and 1874; under secretary to government, judicial and political departments, May, 1867; acting registrar, high court, Jan., 1869; acting judicial commissioner in Sind and judge of the sadar court, May, 1874, to Feb., 1876; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, June, 1875; on special duty in Bombay, Nov., 1876; 1st grade judge and sessions judge, Poona, and agent for sardars in the Deccan, May, 1882; on special duty under government of India, April-May, 1884; acting judge, high court, Bombay, Jan., 1885; acting chief secretary to government, Oct., 1886; retired, May, 1887.

WEEKES, ARTHUR, M.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive
examination of 1860; arrived, 2nd Feb., 1862; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1885; on famine relief duty at Madras, Feb., 1877; retired, March, 1888.

WEIDEMANN, GEORGE LEVER, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Oriel College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1868; arrived in India, 23rd Nov., 1879, and served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner and deputy commissioner; on special duty in Rangoon, July, 1879; officiated as additional sessions judge, Oct.-Dec., 1890, and Jan.-March, 1892.

WEIR, CHARLES JAMES, Madras C.S.—Educated at Royal Academical Institution, Belfast, and Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 17th Nov., 1879, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, and assistant sessions judge; from May, 1884, served in Coorg as officiating first assistant commissioner and district magistrate; acting under secretary to government of Madras, revenue department, Oct., 1886; officiating under secretary to government of India, finance department, May, 1887, to April, 1888; officiating deputy accountant-general, Bengal, April, 1888; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Aug., 1888; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Jan., 1891; acting collector and magistrate in 1891 and 1892.

WEIR, JOHN WILLIAM ALLEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Godolphin School, Hammersmith, and University College, London; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 12th Nov., 1884; assistant collector and magistrate, Jan., 1885; also administrator, Sachin State, May, 1891.

WEIR, PATRICK ALEXANDER, Surgeon-Major, M.B., Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service in 1875; officiating and resident surgeon, presidency general hospital, Aug., 1876; on special duty with lieutenant-governor on tour in cyclone districts, Nov., 1876; superintendent of vaccination, and ex-officio deputy sanitary commissioner, March, 1882; principal assistant to opium agent, Benares, May, 1882; residency surgeon, Nepal, May, 1891.

WEIR, THOMAS, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Belfast; appointed to Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 8th Dec., 1867, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; deputy registrar, high court, Jan., 1870, to June, 1872; acted as registrar, high court, Feb., 1874, to Feb., 1880; Tamil translator to government, Jan., 1879; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, Godaveri, March, 1880; board of examiners, Jan., 1882; confirmed as registrar, high court, April, 1882; published the law of offences and criminal procedure, and the civil digest of rules and standing orders of the high court; from July, 1883, acted as district and sessions judge in the districts of Coimbatore, North Tanjore, and Madura, and was placed on special duty in connection with the reorganization of the subordinate judicial service, Nov., 1883; sub-secretary, board of revenue, Feb., 1886; district and sessions judge, Madura, Nov., 1887; officiating judge of high court, March, 1890 to Jan., 1891; author of 'Law of Offences and Criminal Procedure, as expounded by the High Court of Madras,' and of 'Civil Digests of Rules and Standing Orders of the Madras High Court.'

WEIR, THOMAS STEPHENSON, Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, Bombay.—First commission, Indian medical department, 1870; health officer, Bombay, from 1874; surgeon-major, April, 1882.

WELD, MATTHEW RICHARD, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Dublin University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served in various districts of Madras, as assistant magistrate and collector, acting cantonment magistrate, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acted as district and sessions judge, Kistna, Jan.-March, 1885, and as collector and magistrate in the same district from April, 1885; appointed district and sessions judge, Ganjam, Sept., 1888; Kurnool, May, 1889.

WELDON, THOMAS, C.I.E., Colonel, I.S.C., late Police Department, Madras.—Joined Addiscombe, Jan., 1852; ensign, Madras infantry, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, 12th April, 1854; from July, 1860, served in the Madras police department as assistant superintendent and superintendent; senior magistrate of police for town of Madras, March, 1867; on special duty, in connection with the note forgery case, July, 1872, to Jan., 1873; chief magistrate of police, Madras, April, 1877, on special duty in Burma in connection with the commissariat case, Nov., 1879; chief presidency magistrate, Madras, Dec., 1880; board of examiners, Jan., 1882; commissioner of police for town of Madras, Dec., 1885; C.I.E., May, 1888; reverted to military department, Dec., 1891.

WELLS, HENRY LAKE, Lieut.-Colonel, R.E., M.I.E.E., Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the public works department as assistant engineer, Feb., 1876; transferred to state railways, Dec., 1876; lent to military department, Dec., 1878, and served on special duty in Baluchistan, in opening up Thal Chotiali route, 1879; lent to telegraph department for surveys in connection with a telegraph line from Srinagar to Gilgit, Aug., 1879; again lent to military department for field service, 1880 (medal); transferred to Indo-European telegraph department as assistant director, Persian section, 1880; officiating director, May, 1883; confirmed, Jan., 1891; author of several reports on tours in Persia, &c.

WELLS, WALTER FOX WILLIAMSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Cheltenham; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 16th Nov., 1875, and served in Oudh as assistant commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; city magistrate, Lucknow, Oct., 1885; joint magistrate, July, 1886; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1891.

WELSH, WILLIAM HENRY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Haileybury; appointed after open competitive examination of 1874; arrived in Madras, 29th Nov., 1876, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting sub-collector,
assistant sessions judge, &c.; head assistant to collector and magistrate, Jan., 1885; senior assistant to collector and magistrate, Dec., 1887; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Aug., 1889; collector and magistrate, Nov., 1891.

WENLOCK (Baron), Right Hon. Beilby Lawley, G.C.I.E.—Educated at Eton and Trinity College, Cambridge; M.P. for Chester, April to July, 1880; was vice-chairman of County Council, East Riding; appointed governor of Madras, 20th Dec., 1890, and assumed charge of office, 23rd Jan., 1891.

WEST, Sir Raymond, K.C.I.E., M.A., Barrister-at-Law, F.R.G.S., LL.D., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Queen's College, Galway; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1855; arrived in India, 18th Sept., 1856, and served in the Bombay revenue and judicial departments as assistant collector and magistrate, assistant judge and sessions judge, officiating under secretary to government in the judicial and political departments, and acting judge and sessions judge; registrar, high court, Bombay, June, 1863; judicial commissioner and judge of the sadar court in Sind, June, 1872; judge of the high court, Bombay, Sept., 1873; on special duty as member of the law commission, Calcutta, April-Nov., 1879; vice-chancellor of the University of Bombay, Oct., 1886; member of council of governor of Bombay, 12th Nov., 1887; K.C.I.E., June, 1888; retired, April, 1892.

WESTERN, James Halifax, C.M.G., Lieutenant-Colonel, R.E., late Public Works Department, India.—First commission, Bengal engineers, 1860; arrived in India, Oct., 1862; assistant engineer, public works department, N.W. Provinces, Dec., 1863; Eastern Jumna canal, Jan., 1864; executive engineer, Ganges canal, June, 1868; superintendent of works, Betwa canal, Nov., 1881; transferred to Punjab as temporary superintending engineer, Sirhind canal, May, 1882; superintending engineer, 3rd class, Sept., 1882; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary for irrigation, Punjab, Nov., 1884; services lent to Egyptian government; retired, Jan., 1887.

WESTLAND, James, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Marischal College, Aberdeen, and Wimbledon School; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived 10th Oct., 1862; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, March, 1867; officiating magistrate and collector, Jessore, Aug., 1868; officiating junior secretary, government of Bengal, July, 1869; officiating superintendent and remembrancer of legal affairs, June, 1870; under secretary, government of India, financial department, Dec., 1870; officiating accountant-general, Bengal, April, 1873; accountant-general, Central Provinces, and deputy commissioner, paper currency, Nagpore circle, Dec., 1873; on special duty in the home department, Nov., 1875; inspector of local offices of accounts, Nov., 1877; accountant-general, Bengal, Oct., 1878; acting comptroller-general and head commissioner, department of issue of state paper currency, April, 1880, and was confirmed in this appointment, Sept., 1881; officiating secretary, government of India, department of finance and commerce, Nov., 1883, to Jan., 1884, Nov., 1885, and again Nov., 1887; to England on special duty, April-Sept., 1884; member of finance committee, March, 1886; officiating member governor-general's council, Aug., 1887; temporary member, Nov., 1887; C.S.I., June, 1888; secretary to government of India, department of finance and commerce, Nov., 1888; chief commissioner of Assam, July, 1889; retired, Oct., 1889.

WESTMACOTT, Edward Vesey, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Magdalen College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1861; arrived, 8th Jan., 1863; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was on famine relief duty, Jan., 1874; officiating commissioner, Dacca division, Aug., 1882; on special duty for the purpose of reporting on the existing chowkidary system, Nov., 1882; services placed temporarily at disposal of financial department, Oct., 1883; officiating inspector-general of jails, March, 1884; officiating commissioner, Burdwan division, in 1887, and again in 1888; commissioner of excise, Bengal, April, 1889; acted as commissioner, Presidency division in 1889, 1890, and 1891.

WESTROP, George Ralph Collier, Colonel, I.S.C., late Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, Dec., 1850; arrived in India, 27th Jan., 1851; was employed under the military department, including service in Khandesh against the rebel leader Tantia Topee, 1853; adjutant, Savantvadi local corps, Feb., 1859; acting assistant magistrate in Ratnagiri, May, 1860; assistant to political superintendent, Savantvadi, Nov., 1862; assistant political agent, Kolhapur, 1865-1869; in charge Southern Maharatta Jaghir states, 1869-1877; political superintendent, Savantvadi, and commandant of the local corps, Aug., 1877; deputed on special duty in the Savanur state in 1880; retired from civil employment, 1888.

WHALLEY, Paul, M.A., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived in India, 31st Oct., 1861; from Nov., 1862, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, officiating junior secretary, and under secretary to government; officiating under secretary to government of India, department of revenue, agriculture, and commerce, Dec., 1871, to Feb., 1872; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, May, 1877; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, in Oudh, Dec., 1877; magistrate and collector, Pilibhit, Nov., 1879; 1st grade magistrate and collector, Oct., 1883; retired, Feb., 1890; author of 'A Collection of the Laws and Rules of the Non-Regulation Provinces.'

WHEELER, Henry, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889; arrived, 14th Dec., 1891, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector.

WHEELER, Percy Cotterill B.L., late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 25th Dec., 1877, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; assistant settlement officer, Jaunpur, Nov., 1882; assistant commissioner, 2nd grade,
April, 1887; joint magistrate, Nov., 1888; officiating magistrate and collector, July, 1890; officiating district and sessions judge, March, 1891; retired, 1892.

WHISH, CHARLES WILLIAM, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Tonbridge School, and Blackheath Proprietary School; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 1st Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate, and officiating magistrate and collector; assistant commissioner, 1st grade, Oct., 1886; joint magistrate, 1st grade, April, 1887; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, Feb., 1890; magistrate and collector, July, 1890.

WHISHAW, JOHN CHARLES, M.D., Brigade-Surgeon, late Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Assistant surgeon, Bengal medical establishment, 23rd July, 1858; arrived, 3rd Sept., 1858, and held various military medical charges up to 1860; civil surgeon and superintendent of jail, Fyzabad, April, 1860; superintendent, central prison and district jail, Lucknow, Nov., 1867; also civil surgeon, Feb., 1868; officiating sanitary commissioner, Oudh, Oct., 1870, also ex-officio inspector-general of prisons, March, 1871; civil surgeon, and superintendent of lunatic asylum, Lucknow, Oct., 1873; also in charge of meteorological observatory, Lucknow, Dec., 1877; retired, Feb., 1886.

WHITE, EDMUND, late Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1865; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1867, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector and officiating magistrate and collector; officiating cantonment magistrate of Bareilly, Feb., 1880; deputy superintendent of census operations, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1880; also under secretary to government in the census department; on special duty in connection with census, Sept., 1882; joint magistrate, 1st grade, Nov., 1882; director of public instruction, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, June, 1885; member of lieutenant-governor's legislative council, Feb., 1889; director of public instruction, Oct., 1890; retired, Aug., 1892; author of 'Report on the Census, N.W. Provinces and Oudh,' 1881.

WHITE, HENRY FREDERICK, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service, 10th Dec., 1859; assistant engineer, Dec., 1860; 1st civil divisional engineer, April, 1865; executive engineer, Oct., 1866; charge of Rohilkund roads division; in charge of Mhow military works division, 1872, 1878, 1880; officiating chief engineer and secretary to chief commissioner, Burma, July, 1885; officiating superintending engineer and secretary to resident, Hyderabad, Sept., 1887; superintending engineer, May, 1888; thanked for services in connection with construction of Savage Island and Oyster Island lighthouses in 1890 and 1892; superintending engineer and secretary to agents to the governor-general for Rajputana and Central India, public works department, June, 1892.

WHITE, H. R., B.A., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 4th Dec., 1872; B.A., London University, 1882.

WHITE, HERBERT THIRKELL, C.I.E., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Dulwich College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 2nd Jan., 1878, and served in the Burma commission as assistant commissioner, and personal assistant to the chief commissioner; on special duty, Rangoon, April, 1880; officiating deputy commissioner, Thayetmyo, April, 1882; cantonment magistrate and small cause court judge, Thayetmyo, April-Sept., 1882, and again in 1883; officiated for various periods between 1880 and 1886 as assistant secretary, junior secretary, and secretary to the chief commissioner; also as director of agriculture, Aug.-Nov., 1884; secretary to the chief commissioner for Upper Burma, March, 1886; secretary to the chief commissioner, April, 1887; officiating commissioner, Northern division, Feb.-June, 1888; officiating chief secretary to chief commissioner, in 1888 and 1889; confirmed, July, 1890; commissioner, Dec., 1890; C.I.E., Jan., 1892.

WHITE, JAMES, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Marlborough College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1863, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; from Dec., 1873, to Nov., 1875, served in Rajputana under the foreign department of the government of India as officiating political assistant, 3rd class, and acted as superintendent, Rajputana state railway police, and also held charge of the office of political agent, Jaipur; served again under the foreign department of the government of India, May, 1876, to Dec., 1881, in Ajmere, as assistant commissioner and political agent, 3rd class, and officiated as resident (3rd class) and commissioner of Ajmere, May-Aug., 1878; also acted as general superintendent of operations for suppression of thuggee and dacoity, Nov., 1881; joint magistrate and deputy collector, N.W. Provinces, Jan., 1882; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, July, 1883; magistrate and collector, Aug., 1887.

WHITE, JOHN HUBBARD, Major-General, R.E., late Mint-Master, Bombay.—Second lieutenant, Bombay engineers, Dec., 1853; arrived in India, Nov., 1855; from June, 1856, served in the Bombay public works department as assistant engineer and executive engineer (for irrigation); from May, 1865, to Feb., 1874, served as deputy consulting engineer and acting consulting engineer for railways, Bombay; acting superintending engineer, Feb., 1874; acting chief engineer, and under secretary to government of Bombay, railway branch, June-Dec., 1874; transferred to financial department of government of India as acting mint-master, Bombay, June, 1876; rejoined the railway department, Feb., 1878; from March, 1879, served as mint-master and mint-engineer, Bombay; senior mint-master from Jan., 1884; retired, March, 1890.

WHITE, PHILIP JAMES, Oudh Commission.—Signaller in telegraph department, July, 1854; was employed in various capacities in several government offices till outbreak of mutiny, when he served with a body of volunteer horse and was present at various engagements (mutiny medal); deputy collector and deputy magistrate, Gorakhpur, Sept., 1858; assistant settlement officer, Nov., 1859; from March, 1863, served
in the Jhansi commission as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating settlement officer; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Dec., 1879; settlement officer, 1st grade, June, 1885, to March, 1888.

WHITESIDE, WILLIAM SOUTHHEY, late Madras C.S.—Appointed to the Madras civil service from Haileybury College, 1855; served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting deputy secretary to government, sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting civil and sessions judge, small cause court judge of Cuddalore, 1866-67, and acting collector and magistrate; collector and magistrate of North Arcot, Feb., 1873, and subsequently at Tanjore; on special duty as member of the forest draft bill committee in Ootacamund, May, 1882; served on the board of revenue from Aug., 1882, in charge of the Inam department; acting president of the board of examiners, Nov., 1882; acted as director of revenue settlement and agriculture, and Inam commissioner, April-July, 1884; on deputation in the southern districts for reporting on working of licence tax act, Dec., 1884; additional member of the governor-general's council for making laws and regulations, Nov., 1886; acting 2nd member, board of revenue, March, 1888; appointed 3rd member, Jan., 1889, and 2nd member, Oct., 1889; retired, Dec., 1890.

WHITEWAY, RICHARD STEPHEN, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University of London, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 10th Dec., 1868, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, acting assistant secretary to government, assistant settlement officer, and officiating magistrate and collector; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Oct., 1879; settlement officer, 3rd grade, on special duty at Aligarh, Nov., 1881; settlement officer, Ajmere and Merwara, Jan., 1883; deputy commissioner, 1st grade, March, 1888; magistrate and collector, April, 1888.

WHITMORE, JOHN, Barrister-at-Law, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Merchant Taylors' School, and Merton College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1866; arrived in India, 31st Dec., 1868; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal, and was appointed joint magistrate and deputy collector, Dec., 1878; officiating judicial commissioner, Chota Nagpur, Dec., 1881; district and sessions judge, Sept., 1885.

WHITTALL, RICHARD HENRY CECIL, Forest Department, Punjab.—Appointed to the department, 18th Oct., 1871; arrived in India, 18th Nov., 1871, and served in the N.W. Provinces; transferred to Burma, June, 1875; deputy conservator, Oct., 1876; transferred to Central Provinces, Aug., 1880; served also in Baluchistan, Oudh and Berar; officiating conservator of forests, Punjab, Jan., 1889; confirmed, Oct., 1889; 2nd grade, Jan., 1892.

WHITTEN, RICHARD JOHN, Northern India Salt Department.—Joined the service in Feb., 1862, as assistant patrol; deputy inspector, internal branch, Jan., 1867; on deputation to inquire into illicit manufacture of salt in Behar, 1869; personal assistant to commissioner of inland customs, Oct., 1869; collector of customs, Sept., 1871; on deputation to report on salt taxation in Sind, July-Aug., 1872; 1st grade collector, July, 1876; on deputation in Rajputana to report on salt sources in connection with proposed abolition of inland customs line, July-Oct., 1877; employed temporarily under government of Bombay in salt inquiries in Kutch and Kathiawar; deputy commissioner of inland customs, Dec., 1879; officiated as commissioner of Northern India salt revenue, May-June, 1835, and again in March, 1891.

WHITTLE, GEORGE, Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces and Oudh).—Educated at St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived, 28th Nov., 1890, and served as assistant magistrate and collector and assistant commissioner.

WHITWORTH, GEORGE CLIFFORD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Sandicroft School, Northwich, and Queen's College, Liverpool; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, acting assistant judge and sessions judge, and assistant agent for sardars in the Deccan; acting under secretary to government of Bombay in the political, judicial, and educational departments, and secretary to the governor's council, Jan., 1876; (pro tem.) under secretary to government in the public works department for relief purposes, Sept., 1877, to March, 1878; second assistant collector, Feb., 1881; judicial assistant to the political agent, Kathiawar, Nov., 1886; 2nd grade judge and sessions judge, Nov., 1887; author of 'The Theory of Relevancy for the purpose of Judicial Evidence,' an 'Anglo-Indian Dictionary,' 1885, and the 'Rajkumar Law Lectures,' 1888.

WICKES, THOMAS HAINES, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed as special assistant engineer, April, 1861; engineer to the suburban municipality, Calcutta, Jan., 1865; re-appointed executive engineer, public works department, Bengal, Nov., 1865; on special duty in the famine districts, May, 1874, and in connection with the Eastern Bengal railway, April, 1875, also with the secretary to the government of Bengal, March, 1878; assistant secretary to the government of Bengal, April, 1880; executive engineer, 1st grade, June, 1880; superintending engineer, 2nd class, March, 1886; 1st superintending engineer, temporary, April, 1888, and permanent, May, 1889; officiating chief engineer and joint secretary to government of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, June, 1888, and again from May, 1890; confirmed, July, 1891; chief engineer, 3rd class, July, 1891; 2nd class, March, 1892.

WICKHAM, W. A., Store Department, India Office.—Appointed 2nd grade supervisor, India store depot, 23rd Sept., 1889.

WIGHT, JOHN KNOX, B.A., Bengal C.S.—Educated at Queen's Collegiate School, Trinidad, and Clare College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 4th Dec., 1872, and served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector; on famine duty, April, 1874; transferred to Assam, Dec., 1874, and served as assistant commissioner and assistant inspector of immigrants; deputy com-
missioner, March, 1884; returned to duty in Bengal, May, 1890; district and sessions judge, June, 1890.

WIGNER, JOHN M., B.A., B.Sc., Store Department, India Office.—Educated at King's Lynn Grammar School, and London University; temporary clerk, India office, 17th July, 1862; junior clerk, Jan., 1867; senior clerk, July, 1885.

WILCOX, FREDERICK, Bengal Police Department.—Joined the service, 25th May, 1862, as assistant superintendent of police; district superintendent, June, 1873; 1st grade, July, 1891; officiated as deputy inspector-general in 1890, and from July, 1892.

WILD, ALBERT EDWARD, Forest Department N.W. Provinces and Oudh.—Joined the service, 11th Dec. 1890, as assistant conservator, and served in Burma and the Punjab; deputy conservator, Oct., 1876; conservator, 3rd grade, Jan., 1892; in charge, central circle, N.W. Provinces, April, 1892.

WILD, CHARLES EDMUND, B.A., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at City of London School and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1887; arrived in India, 17th Dec., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.

WILKINS, CECIL ANSDELL, Bengal C.S.—Educated at King's College School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1866; served in revenue and judicial departments, Bengal; officiating registrar, high court, April, 1880, and again from 1881 to 1884; on special duty in the high court, July, 1880; joint magistrate and deputy collector, March, 1884; registrar, high court, March, 1885; district and sessions judge, April, 1886; compiled revised editions of the High Court's Rules and Orders, in 1881 and 1883.
