WILKINS, WILLIAM HENRY, Colonel, I.S.C., Survey of India.—Joined the Bengal artillery, Dec., 1857; arrived in India, Jan., 1858; served with the Cawnpur field force, Feb.–March, 1858; studied at Thomason College, Roorkee, March, 1861, to Aug., 1862; served in the revenue survey from April, 1863, as assistant surveyor, and was employed in the Central Provinces, Punjab, Midnapur, Dehra, and British Burma surveys; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Oct., 1878; 2nd grade, Jan., 1887; 1st grade and assistant surveyor-general, Feb., 1891; in charge of map record and issue offices, May, 1891.

WILKINSON, ALFRED REGINALD, Lieut.-Colonel, Bengal Infantry, late Bengal Police.—First commission, 1860; from 10th July, 1863, served in the Bengal police department as assistant superintendent and district superintendent; attached to the special police levy for service in Bhutan, Oct., 1864; on special duty at the presidency, June, 1866; personal assistant to the inspector-general of police, 1869 to 1881; promoted to 1st grade district superintendent, June, 1886; also acted as deputy commissioner of police, Calcutta, and as deputy inspector-general; retired, 1889.

WILKINSON, FRANCIS HENRY, Madras C.S.—Educated at Milton Abbas School, Blackheath Proprietary School, and Pembroke College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived, 10th Nov., 1863; served in Madras from Feb., 1865, as assistant collector and magistrate, and acted as under secretary to government in the revenue department, Aug.–Nov., 1867; on special duty as arbitrator of boundary disputes, June, 1870; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Salem, April, 1878; district and sessions judge, South Malabar, June, 1882; judge of the high court, Madras, Nov., 1887.

WILKINSON, THOMAS ORMEROD, late Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Chudleigh Grammar School, and King's College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 3rd Dec., 1865, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating small cause court judge; officiated as registrar of the chief court in 1878, 1879, and 1880; judicial assistant, 2nd grade, Dec., 1883; district judge, 1st grade, Nov., 1884; divisional judge, 3rd grade, Jan., 1887, and 2nd grade, March, 1890; retired, Sept., 1890.

WILLCOCKS, ALEXANDER JOHN, M.D., Surgeon-Major, Medical Department, North-Western Provinces.—Joined the service as assistant surgeon, 30th Sept., 1873; arrived in India, 5th May, 1874; served on military, civil, and jail duty, and was appointed civil surgeon, and class, April, 1877; surgeon-major, Sept., 1885; civil surgeon, 1st class, Jan., 1888; officiating professor, Calcutta medical college, March, 1892.

WILLIAMS, ALBERT, LL.M., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Uppingham, Clifton, and Christ's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884; arrived in India, 8th Jan., 1886, and was appointed assistant-commissioner, Punjab; under secretary to government of Punjab, April, 1890; also officiating deputy commissioner, Jullundur, June, 1891, and Lahore, May, 1892.

WILLIAMS, EDWARD C. S., Major-General, C.I.E., R.E., India Office.—Commission in Bengal engineers, 1848; arrived in India, 1850; adjutant of engineers, Fort William, and studying machinery in Calcutta mint, 1850; extra assistant secretary, military board, 1851; superintendent, iron bridge yard, Calcutta, 1851–53; served with the Pegu expedition, 1852–53, as adjutant of engineers and in charge of engineer park (medal and clasp); superintendent, Pegu topographical survey, 1854–56; principal, Civil Engineering College, Calcutta, 1855–60; member of senate, Calcutta University; acted as under secretary to government of India, public works department, for one year, during mutiny; principal, Thomason College, Roorkee, 1861–62; under secretary, government of India, public works department, 1863–69; member of Bengal sanitary commission; in charge of office of inspector-general of forests for one year; acting mint-master and commissioner of paper currency, Bombay, 1867; deputy secretary, government of India, public works department (railway branch), 1869–74, and again, 1877–78; director of state railways, 1874–77; C.I.E., Jan., 1878; deputy government director of Indian railway companies, India office, March, 1880; government director, March, 1892.

WILLIAMS, FLEETWOOD, C.S.I., late Bengal C.S.—Appointed to the Bengal civil service
in 1829; arrived in India, 11th Jan., 1831; served in the N.W. Provinces in the grades of assistant commissioner, assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector; magistrate and collector, Bareilly, 1845; commissioner of revenue and circuit, Meerut division, 1857; retired in 1870.

WILLIAMS, GEORGE ROBERT CARLISLE, B.A., Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1864; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1865; from March, 1866, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and officiating magistrate and collector; promoted to joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, April, 1881; deputy commissioner, 2nd class, Jhansi, March, 1883; magistrate and collector, Dec., 1886; author of 'An Historical and Statistical Memoir of Dehra Dun,' and 'Gazetteer of Dehra Dun.'

WILLIAMS, HENRY CLISSOLD, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Haileybury College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 25th Oct., 1871, and served in the Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, officiating district superintendent of police, and officiating deputy commissioner; on famine duty in Bengal, Feb., 1874; from Nov., 1878, served in Assam as assistant commissioner; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 2nd grade, Jan., 1883; inspector-general of police and jails, superintendent of stamps and commissioner of excise, Assam, Sept., 1885; returned to Bengal as magistrate and collector, Nov., 1891.

WILLIAMS, RALPH KING, Public Works Department, Government of India.—From Nov., 1860, to Feb., 1873, served in the office of the consulting engineer for railways, Bombay, as accountant and deputy controller, and was appointed assistant examiner of guaranteed railway accounts in 1872; served in Madras from Feb., 1873, to March, 1878, and was appointed deputy examiner, May, 1876; acted as examiner of guaranteed railway accounts in Calcutta, March to May, 1878, and subsequently in Madras, and at Lahore, March, 1880; examiner, 4th class, Indus valley state railway accounts, Aug., 1880; transferred to Nagpur, Central Provinces, March, 1885; examiner, guaranteed railway accounts, Lahore, April, 1885; examiner, North-Western railway accounts, Lahore, Jan., 1886; 2nd class examiner, Dec., 1886; 1st class, Jan., 1892.

WILLIAMS, WILLIAM, M.I.E.E., late Telegraph Department, Government of India.—Joined the department as assistant superintendent, 16th Jan., 1868; arrived in India, 29th Feb., 1868; served in various divisions, and in 1874 was on special duty at Bombay in connection with introduction of duplex system; superintendent, April, 1880; attached to director-general's office for various periods, and was also personal assistant to director-general; held charge of various divisions, including Indore, Bombay, and Nagpur; retired 1890; author of 'Manual of Telegraphy.'

WILLIAMS-WYNN, ARTHUR W.—Educated at Westminster School and Christ Church, Oxford; graduated B.A. in 1878; called to the Bar (Inner Temple) 1882; appointed assistant private secretary (unpaid) to the Secretary of State (Viscount Cross), Aug., 1886; assistant private secretary, Dec., 1889; private secretary, June to Aug., 1892.

WILLIS, JOHN, Funds Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 3rd Nov., 1862; junior book-keeper, Nov., 1863; assistant book-keeper, Dec., 1881; clerk, Oct., 1892.

WILLOCK, WILLIAM ALEXANDER, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin, and Sidney Sussex College, Cambridge; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 12th March, 1870, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate; on special duty, Jan., 1876, as secretary to the salt commission; from March, 1879, served in the salt department as deputy commissioner and acting commissioner, and was also employed in suppressing the disturbances in the Gudum Hills, May, 1879; collector and magistrate, Dec., 1888; collector and agent, Vizagapatam, July, 1890.

WILLOUGHBY, MICHAEL WEEKES, Major-General, C.S.I., I.S.C., late Bombay Secretariat.—First commission, Bombay army, June, 1849; acted as secretary to government of Bombay in the military, marine, and ecclesiastical departments, from 21st May, 1880, and was confirmed in this appointment, Feb., 1881; returned to Europe, 1888.

WILLSON, James, M.A., Bengal Educational Service (Assam).—Educated at Trinity College, Dublin, 1870; professor, Cathedral Mission College, Calcutta, Jan., 1870; assistant geological survey of India, Sept., 1871, to Feb., 1873; professor, Hooghly College, March, 1873; Dacca College, Jan., 1874; Patna College, May, 1875; 3rd class of the education department, Aug., 1878; from Jan., 1879, served in Assam as inspector of schools, and was appointed director of public instruction, Assam, Jan., 1880; has edited Wilson's 'Dynamics.'

WILMER, JOHN RANDAL, Colonel, I.S.C., Survey of India.—Joined the service as lieutenant R.A., 22nd June, 1859; arrived in India, 27th Oct., 1860; served in the military department, and in Aug., 1869, was appointed to the staff corps and assistant superintendent topographical survey; deputy superintendent, July, 1882; in charge of Baluchistan survey party, Oct., 1885 to Oct., 1886; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, Feb., 1887; 2nd grade, Feb., 1891.

WILSON, ARTHUR, Legal Adviser, India Office.—Puisne judge, high court of judicature, Calcutta, 1878; president of the Crawford enquiry commission at Poona, 1888–9; legal adviser, India Office, 27th April, 1892.

WILSON, DAVID, M.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Hutcheson's Grammar School, Glasgow, University of Glasgow, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 4th Feb., 1886, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner; officiating deputy commissioner, Dec., 1890.

WILSON, FREDERICK ALEXANDER, Colonel, I.S.C., Political Department, Government of India.—First commission, as lieutenant, Bengal artillery, 8th June, 1860; arrived in India, Oct., 1860; admitted to the staff corps, April, 1869; extra A.D.C. to viceroy, Dec., 1869; from Nov., 1870, served under the foreign department of the government of India as guardian and tutor to the Nawab of Jaora, and
from 1874, as additional political assistant and political assistant in Jaora, in Central India, and at Tehri; tutor to the Maharaja of Mysore, June, 1876; 1st assistant resident, Hyderabad, Oct., 1879; political agent, 3rd class, Oct., 1881; agent to the governor-general with the King of Oudh, and superintendent of political pensions, March, 1882; boundary settlement officer and assistant to political agent, Bundelkhand, Jan., 1883; political agent, 2nd class, Jan., 1884; officiated as resident, and 2nd class, in Nipal, and political agent, Bhartpur and Karauli; political agent, Bundelkhand, Oct., 1886; served in the Bhutan campaign of 1864-65 (medal and clasp), the Hazara campaign of 1868, the Black Mountain (clasp).

WILSON, GEORGE, Captain, R.I.M., Marine Department, Burma.—Commander, Indian Marine, Aug., 1878; port officer, Bassein, April, 1882; acting assistant director of Indian marine, May, 1889; acted as post officer, Rangoon, in 1881 and 1889, and was confirmed in that post, Sept., 1890.

WILSON, GEORGE FREDERICK, Major, R.E., India Public Works Department.—Appointed assistant engineer, 20th May, 1875, and posted to state railways; assistant director, northeastern system, June, 1877, and again in 1879; assistant secretary, railway branch of public works department, Bengal, 1878; executive engineer, May, 1883; served in Soudan expedition (medal), and was employed on Soudan railway, 1884-85; assistant secretary to government of India, public works department, April, 1888; officiating deputy manager, North-Western railway, March, 1890; confirmed, April, 1891.

WILSON, JAMES, M.A., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Perth Academy, and University of Edinburgh; appointed to Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1873; arrived in India, 14th Nov., 1875, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, and officiating deputy commissioner; on special duty, Sirsa, April, 1879, and again, Oct.-Nov., 1880, in the civil secretariat; officiating under secretary to government, July, 1881, and again in 1884; on special duty at Simla for the purpose of writing the final report on the Sirsa settlement, Aug., 1883; officiating senior secretary to financial commissioner, April-May, 1886; deputy commissioner, Sept., 1890; author of works on tribal customs in the Gurgaon and Sirsa districts, and of the Sirsa settlement report.

WILSON, JOHN HATTON, M.I.C.E., late Public Works Department, Bengal.—Probationary assistant engineer, 5th March, 1856; served in the public works department in the Central Provinces, and temporarily in Oudh, 1865-67, as assistant engineer and executive engineer; temporarily transferred to military works branch, July, to Sept., 1879; in charge of the Nagpore and Chattisgarh railway reconnaissance survey division, Nov., 1881; superintending engineer, and transferred to Bengal, Dec., 1881; superintending engineer, 2nd class, Dec., 1885; 1st superintending engineer, temporary, March, 1886; retired, 1890.

WILSON, ROBERT HENRY, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 2nd Feb., 1862; served in the revenue and judicial departments as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, and magistrate and collector; officiating registrar-general of assurances, Sept., 1870; also officiating marriage registrar, Calcutta; officiating under secretary to the government of Bengal, Dec., 1870; inspector of registration offices, July, 1872; officiating inspector-general of registration, Sept., 1872; officiating secretary, board of revenue, July, 1877, and again in 1879; magistrate and collector, 1st grade, Aug., 1884; officiating commissioner, Burdwan division, Aug., 1884; employed under the public works department on the commission in connection with the Orissa canals, Nov., 1884; officiating secretary, government of Bengal, financial department, Feb., 1886; on special duty with the finance committee, 1886; retired, Sept., 1887.

WILSON, THOMAS CORBY, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Clifton College, and Trinity College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1883, and served as assistant commissioner, Central Provinces; acting district superintendent of police, Hoshangabad, Sept.-Nov., 1884; assistant settlement officer, June, 1886; settlement officer, May, 1888; transferred to Burma as deputy commissioner and officiating director of land records and agriculture, Feb., 1891.

WILSON, WILLIAM, M.A., late Madras C.S.—Educated at Marischal College, Aberdeen; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1859; served in the revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed district and sessions judge, Kistna, Feb., 1874, and collector and magistrate, June, 1877; on special duty for compiling irrigation accounts, Nov., 1875, and again Oct., 1879, and Aug., 1881; acting director of revenue settlement, April, 1878, to Sept., 1879; collector and magistrate, Coimbatore, Oct., 1879, to Aug., 1881; collector, magistrate and agent, Vizagapatam, July, 1882; acted as member of the board of revenue in 1882, 1883, 1884; director of revenue settlement and agriculture, Nov., 1882; in charge of the Inam department, March, 1883; also an additional member, board of revenue, April, 1883; permitted to visit on duty agricultural institutions in N.W. Provinces, and Bombay, Nov., 1883; fellow of Madras University, March, 1885; acting secretary to government of Madras in the revenue department, April, 1885; additional member of council for making laws and regulations, Sept., 1885; acting chief secretary to government of Madras, Oct., 1885; 3rd member of board of revenue, April, 1887; has acted as 2nd and 1st member of board; appointed 1st member and commissioner of land revenue settlement, &c., Jan., 1889; retired, Oct., 1890.

WILSON, WILLIAM HENRY, Colonel, I.S.C., Police Department, Bombay.—Arrived in India, 22nd Jan., 1857, and was employed on military duties till April, 1864, when he was appointed acting assistant political agent, Sadra; from Nov., 1864, served as assistant superintendent of police, subordinate magistrate, superintendent of railway police on Bombay, Baroda, and Central India railway, and district superintendent; promoted to 1st grade superintendent of police, June, 1883; acted as commissioner
of police for city of Bombay, Oct., 1885; to June, 1886; colonel, Dec., 1886; appointed commissioner of police, Bombay, July, 1888.

WILSON, WILLIAM HERBERT, Ph.D. (Heidelberg), F.I.C., F.C.S., F.G.S., Education Department, Madras.—Served from 4th Feb., 1875, as professor of physical science, Presidency College; fellow of Madras University, March, 1880; 3rd class, education department, June, 1882; in addition, registrar of Madras University, March, 1886; 2nd class, education department, Dec., 1888.

WILTSHIRE, CHARLES PALMER BLUETT, Bombay C.S.—Educated at the Proprietary School, Islington, City of London School, King's College, London University, and Middle Temple; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting port officer at Karwar, and superintendent, timber depot, Canara; boundary commissioner between Canara and Mysore, May, 1873; on famine duty, Dharwar, in 1876, 1877, and 1878; in charge of Huzur treasury in 1880 and 1881; 1st assistant collector, Sept., 1886; also forest settlement officer, Poona, June, 1881; translated the preliminary chapter of Mill's 'Political Economy' into Marathi.

WIMBERLEY, REGINALD JUSTUS, Colonel, late I.S.C.—Ensign, 3rd Bengal European regiment, 1850; served in the Punjab police force, Dec., 1861-67; commissariat department, March-Aug., 1867; from Aug., 1867, to 1872, served in Bengal as district superintendent of police; in command of police force to quell insurrection in the tributary Mehals, May, 1868; 1st assistant superintendent, Port Blair and Nicobars, April, 1872; called to the bar, Inner Temple, Nov., 1877; deputy superintendent, Dec., 1884; retired, Dec., 1887.

WINCHESTER, CHARLES BLAKE, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Blundell's School, Tiverton; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1873, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting forest settlement officer, and acting junior collector and political agent; on famine duty, Sept., 1877; 2nd assistant collector, Nov., 1886; 1st assistant collector, March, 1890.

WINCHESTER, E. C., Registry Department, India Office.—Writer, India office, 16th Dec., 1872; clerk, 2nd class, Nov., 1878.

WINDSOR, JOHN, Bengal C.S.—Educated at Old Trafford School, Manchester, and St. John's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1884; arrived in India, 28th Nov., 1887, and served as assistant magistrate and collector; in 1891 officiated as under-secretary, financial and municipal departments.

WINGATE, ANDREW, C.I.E., Bombay C.S.—Educated at Elizabeth College, Guernsey, Kensington Grammar School, University of London, and University of Heidelberg; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 8th Nov., 1869, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, and acting collector and magistrate; compiled Bombay administration report for 1874-75, and for 1875-76; in political charge of the Jath state, Feb.-Sept., 1876; additional secretary in the famine department under chief commissioner of Mysore, Aug., 1877; assistant secretary to famine commission, Aug., 1878; settlement officer in Oodeypore state, Aug., 1879; officiating resident, Meywar, and settlement officer, Kashmir state, Feb., 1887; junior collector and magistrate, Kanara, July, 1890; acting collector of salt revenue, Bombay, Oct., 1890; also acting commissioner of customs, &c., April, 1891; settlement officer, Oodeypore state, May, 1891.

WINGATE, JOHN BRUCE, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Old Aberdeen Gymnasium, Aberdeen University, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived, 28th Nov., 1890, and served in Burma as assistant commissioner.

WINMILL, GEORGE, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Joined the service as second sub-engineer, Indus valley railway, 17th Nov., 1875; Class IV, superior revenue establishment, July, 1878; Class III, July, 1879, and Class II, Jan., 1886; locomotive superintendent, Oudh and Rohilkhand railway, Jan., 1886.

WINNY, THOMAS H., India Office.—Appointed assistant to the surveyor and clerk of the works, India Office, Aug., 1885.

WINTER, EDGAR FRANCIS LATIMER, Benga C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Harrow, Trinity Hall, Cambridge, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1881; arrived in India, 20th Nov., 1884; attached to the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; under secretary to government, Nov., 1889.

WINTER, HENRY EDWARD, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Marlborough College, and King's School, Canterbury; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1866; arrived in India, 21st Nov., 1868, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant political agent, and acting collector and magistrate; first assistant collector and magistrate, and forest settlement and demarcation officer, Poona districts, Jan., 1883; 2nd grade judge, Jan., 1885; junior collector, and collector, and magistrate, district registrar, and political agent, Kolaba, Nov. 1888; senior collector, Dec., 1890.

WINTER, WILLIAM DE LAPPE, Bengal C.S. (Burma).—Educated at Harrow, and Trinity College, Cambridge; appointed after open competitive examination of 1889.

WINTERBOTHAM, HENRY MARTIN, Madras C.S.—Educated at Portland Grammar School, and London University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1867; arrived in India, 10th Nov., 1869, and served in Madras in the grades of assistant collector and magistrate, principal assistant, and sub-collector and joint magistrate; acting Malayalam translator to government, March-Dec., 1877; acting sub-secretary, board of revenue, June-July, 1883; acted for various periods as collector and magistrate, and as district and sessions judge in various districts; and was appointed collector and magistrate, Malabar, Aug., 1888.

WODEHOUSE, HONOURABLE ARMINE, India Office.—Assistant private secretary (unpaid) to secretary of state for colonies
WODEHOUSE, CHARLES, C.I.E., Colonel, I.S.C., Political Department, Bombay.—First commission, Bombay infantry, March, 1857; arrived in India, 6th April, 1857, and was employed under the military department, including service in the mutiny campaign, 1857-58 (medal and clasp for Central India); from March, 1867, served as boundary settlement commissioner, Baroda; from Sept., 1868, acted in the Hyderabad assigned districts as assistant commissioner, director of public instruction, and small cause court judge; acting assistant resident, Hyderabad, April to Nov., 1870; acting cantonment magistrate and judge, Secunderabad, Dec., 1870; acting assistant resident, Baroda, Jan., 1873; acting political agent, Rewa Kantha, Feb., 1873; from March, 1873, served in Kathiawar as political assistant, acting judicial assistant, and acting political agent, and was placed on special duty for the settlement of boundary disputes in the Gheer forest, July, 1874; also acted as private secretary to the governor of Bombay from May, 1876, to April, 1877; political agent, Mahi Kantha, Sept., 1881; and grade, political agent, Feb., 1885; acting political superintendent, Palanpur, April, 1885, and in Kathiawar, July, 1886; C.I.E., Aug., 1887; on duty in England in connection with the Jubilee, 1887; political agent, Kolhapur, &c., Feb., 1889.

WOLFE-MURRAY, FRANCIS D'ARCY OSBORNE, Madras C.S.—Educated at Harrow, and St. Andrew's University; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 19th Dec., 1877, and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting assistant secretary to government in the judicial and legislative departments, acting principal assistant collector, assistant sessions judge, forest settlement officer, sub-collector and joint magistrate, collector and magistrate, and district and sessions judge; appointed sub-collector, and joint magistrate, March, 1890; acting collector and magistrate, April, 1890.

WOLLASTON, ARTHUR N., C.I.E., Revenue and Statistics Department, India Office.—Educated at Stockwell Grammar School; entered the India office by open competition as writer, old establishment, 3rd March, 1859; junior clerk, political and secret department, 1860; senior clerk, Jan., 1873; assistant secretary, revenue, statistics, and commerce department, Jan., 1884; in charge of the revenue and statistics department, May to Oct., 1886, and April, 1887, to March, 1888; in 1877 published a translation of the 'Anvar-i-Suhaili or Fables of Bidpai'; in 1879 edited Sir Lewis Pelly's miracle play of 'Hasan and Husain'; appointed to succeed Sir F. J. Goldsmid as examiner in Persian at the Royal Staff College, Sandhurst, 1880; selected in 1881 by the science and art department to superintend the translation of the oriental inscriptions in the South Kensington Museum; in 1882 published an English-Persian dictionary, and in 1889 a larger work of the same kind; C.I.E., 1st Jan., 1886.

WOMACK, ARTHUR SHAW, Bengal C.S. (Central Provinces).—Educated at Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1880; arrived in India, 5th Dec., 1882; assistant magistrate and collector, Dec., 1882; transferred to the Central Provinces, July, 1885, and served as supernumerary assistant commissioner, and registrar of the judicial commissioner's court; assistant commissioner, Nov., 1888; judge, small cause court, March, 1892.

WOOD, EDWARD SEPTIMUS, Captain, late Forest Department, Oudh.—Arrived in India as lieutenant, 93rd Sutherland highlanders, 20th Sept., 1857; from Dec., 1859, served in the public works department on irrigation works, N.W. Provinces; officiated as conservator of forests, 1864-66; reverted to his regiment, Feb., 1866; appointed executive engineer, 4th grade, March, 1867; from April, 1867, served in the forest department, Oudh, and was appointed conservator, Oct., 1868; promoted to 2nd grade, Sept., 1882; 1st grade, Dec., 1888; retired, May, 1891.

WOOD, G. P., Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Educated at Marlborough College, and Addiscombe; writer, India Office, 25th Jan., 1869; clerk, 2nd class, Aug., 1878.

WOOD, JULIUS JOHN, M.B., Surgeon-Lieut.-Col., late Bengal Medical Department.—Joined the service, 1st May, 1868, and served on general and jail duty, and as superintendent of vaccination; on famine relief duty in April, 1874; deputy sanitary commissioner, Ranchi circle, Sept., 1888; retired, 1892.

WOOD, HENRY MACKENZIE MACDONALD, Lieut.-Colonel, I.S.C., Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 20th May, 1863; from April, 1867, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating deputy commissioner, and judicial assistant; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Nov., 1884; and grade, May, 1887; also district judge; officiating divisional judge, at various periods from July, 1886; and divisional judge, Nov., 1889.

WOODBURN, ARCHIBALD FRANCIS, Barrister-at-Law, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Ayr Academy, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1870; arrived in India, 11th Nov., 1872, and served as assistant collector and magistrate; also acted as forest settlement officer, and as junior collector and magistrate; second assistant collector, June, 1885; on special duty in judicial department in connection with Deccan Agriculturists Relief Act, July, 1888; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, Sept., 1888.

WOODBURN, JOHN, M.A., C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Ayr Academy, Glasgow University, and Edinburgh University; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863; from July, 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector; transferred to Oudh, Feb., 1865, and served as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, officiating personal assistant, and officiating secretary to chief commissioner; deputy commissioner, 3rd grade, Fyzabad, Aug., 1879; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, in the Oudh revenue department and forest branch, Jan., 1882; also in the Oudh political department, March, 1882; secretary to government of N.W. Provinces and Oudh, judicial department, May, 1884;
acted as chief secretary in 1884-86, and in 1887, and was confirmed in appointment, Nov., 1888; member of the lieutenant-governor's council, Dec., 1886; member of Viceroy's legislative council, Feb., 1891; resumed his post as chief secretary, April, 1891; again member of Viceroy's legislative council, Nov., 1891, to April, 1892; C.S.I., Jan., 1892.

WOODCOCK, ELBOROUGH MARTIN, Colonel, I.S.C., late Police Department, North-Western Provinces.—Arrived in India as ensign, 9th March, 1856; served with the Persian expeditionary force, 1856-57 (medal and clasp); appointed to Oudh military police, 27th Nov., 1858; from March, 1860, served in the police department as district superintendent, and was promoted to 1st grade, Oct., 1880; reverted to military department, Jan., 1892.

WOOD-MASON, JAMES, Indian Museum, Calcutta.—Educated at Charterhouse and Queen's College, Oxford; joined the service, 12th Oct., 1869, as assistant curator, Indian Museum; deputy superintendent, March, 1877; superintendent, Jan., 1887; has acted at various periods as professor of comparative anatomy, medical college, Bengal; author of reports on Tea-mite and Tea-bug of Assam, on 'The Rice-fly of Bengal,' on 'Diseases of Bengal Silk-worms,' &c., also of a 'Catalogue of Mantodia,' and various contributions to scientific journals.

WOODTHORPE, ROBERT GOSSETT, C.B., Colonel, R.E., Survey of India Department.—Joined the service, 25th June, 1865; entered the department as assistant superintendent, July, 1871; deputy superintendent, Nov., 1884; on special duty with Gilgit mission, May, 1885; on special duty in Europe, Feb., 1888; deputy quartermaster-general for intelligence, Simla, Feb., 1889; deputy superintendent, 3rd grade, survey department, June, 1892; served in the Lushai Expedition, the Afghan War, the Burma Expedition, &c.; has written various papers on military and geograpical subjects, and an account of the Lushai Expedition.

WOODWARD, HILLERSDEN, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oakham Grammar School, and Birmingham Grammar School; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1869; arrived in India, 28th Oct., 1871, and served as assistant collector and magistrate and acting railway magistrate; on special duty in connection with the Deccan Agriculturists Relief Act, Dec., 1882, and again, Aug., 1883; forest settlement officer, Sholapur, Nov., 1883; acting junior collector and magistrate, Belgaum, Sept., 1884; second assistant collector, May, 1885; 1st assistant collector and magistrate, July, 1888.

WOODWARD, WILLOUGHBY, M.A., late Bombay C.S.—Educated at Oakham Grammar School, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 26th Nov., 1863, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting magistrate of police at Bombay, and acting collector and magistrate and political agent; junior collector and magistrate, and district registrar, Panch Mahals, and political agent, Rewa Kantha, Aug., 1881; senior collector and magistrate and political agent, Satara, March, 1886; retired, March, 1890.

WOOTTON, J. J., Accounts Department, India Office.—Clerk, 2nd class, India office, 20th Feb., 1872.

WORDSWORTH, WILLIAM, C.I.E., M.A. (Oxon), late Educational Department, Bombay.—Joined the educational service, May, 1861; arrived in India, 10th July, 1861, and served as head-master of the Elphinstone Institution, Bombay, acting professor of history in the Elphinstone College, and assistant inspector of schools; from May, 1862, served as principal of the Deccan College, Poona, and also acted as professor of English literature; from June, 1872, acted as principal of the Elphinstone College, Bombay, and was also appointed to select the government records at the secretariat; confirmed as principal of Elphinstone College, and professor of logic and moral philosophy, Nov., 1874; principal, and professor of history and political economy, from June, 1878; also sheriff of Bombay, Dec., 1885; C.I.E., Feb. 1887; retired, 1890.

WORGAN, JOHN BERNEY, late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Cheltenham College; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; served in Bengal as assistant magistrate and collector, joint magistrate and deputy collector, magistrate and collector, and officiating district and sessions judge; from May, 1876, served in the judicial department, and was appointed district and sessions judge, 1st grade, July, 1879; retired, Dec., 1891.

WRIGHT, FRANCIS NELSON, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton, and Exeter College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 15th Jan., 1864; from Dec., 1864, served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and from May, 1870, to April, 1873, in the settlement department, and was appointed settlement officer, 3rd grade, Cawnpore, April, 1876; officiating director of agriculture and commerce, N.W. Provinces and Oudh, April, 1878, and again, 1880-81; joint magistrate and deputy collector, 1st grade, Nov., 1879; deputy commissioner, 2nd grade, March, 1885; magistrate and collector, April, 1885; officiating commissioner, Rae Bareli, Aug.-Oct., 1890; and Benares, April, 1891; commissioner, Allahabad, Nov., 1891; author of a memorandum on the 'Agriculture of Cawnpore,' 'Cawnpore Gazetteer,' 'Cawnpore Settlement Report,' and 'Report on Wheat.'

WRIGHT, FREDERICK, Police Department, Hyderabad Administration.—Arrived in India, 20th Aug., 1859; served as inspector in the Madras police from Jan., 1860; transferred to Hyderabad assigned districts, Aug., 1862, and served as assistant superintendent and district superintendent of police (1st grade, April, 1877); officiated for various periods as inspector-general of police, jails, and registration, author of 'Margadpradushk' (a treatise on the Indian Penal Code), 1878, a police manual of laws in 1883, and a schedule to all the penal acts of the government of India, 1841 to 1883-85.

WRIGHT, FREDERICK C. B., Store Department, India Office.—Junior clerk, 4th July, 1867; senior clerk, June, 1891.

WRIGHT, HENRY NELSON, Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Eton and Corpus Christi College, Oxford; appointed after open competitive examination of 1888; arrived 29th Oct., 1890, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector.
WRIGHT, JAMES McCallum, M.A., Bengal C.S. (North Western Provinces).—Educated at Fordyce School, University of Aberdeen, and University College, London; appointed to the Bengal civil service, after open competitive examination of 1883; arrived in India, 2nd Dec., 1885; assistant magistrate and collector, N.W. Provinces; joint magistrate, Nov., 1890.

WRIGHT, JAMES WALKER, M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed to the department in July, 1859; served in the Punjab as assistant and executive engineer; in charge of Madhopur workshops, March, 1868; executive engineer, military works, Chukrata road, and afterwards in the Jullundur division, 1872; transferred to the Punjab provincial list, Nov., 1879; superintending engineer, 2nd class, July, 1886; 1st class, May, 1889; officiating chief engineer, and secretary to chief commissioner of Burma, April, 1890; officiating chief engineer, buildings and roads branch, and joint secretary to government of Punjab, Sept., 1890; officiating secretary to chief commissioner of Assam, March, 1891; confirmed, with permanent rank of chief engineer, 3rd class, June, 1891; 2nd class, June, 1892.

WRIGHT, WILLIAM CHARLES, Public Works Department, Government of India.—Appointed probationary assistant engineer, Oudh, 23rd Sept., 1864; confirmed, 1st April, 1865; executive engineer, March, 1871; lent to Cawnpur municipality, Sept., 1884; in charge of provincial works, Agra division, and subsequently Lucknow division, 1885; services lent to Rampore state, Jan., 1890; superintending engineer, 3rd class, May, 1891; 2nd class, March, 1892.

WRIGHT, WILLIAM HENRY, B.A., Educational Department, North-Western Provinces.—Appointed 7th Aug., 1867, and served from 7th Dec., 1867, as professor, Benares College; professor of English literature, Muir Central College, Allahabad, July, 1872; 3rd grade of educational officers, July, 1872; principal, Bareilly College, Dec., 1873; officiating inspector of schools, June, 1875, to March, 1876; from Jan., 1877, served as professor at the Muir Central College, and officiated as principal of the Benares College, in 1878; 2nd grade of educational officers, Aug., 1888; principal of Benares College, Oct., 1888; has published a handbook of the education department, an account of the Muir Central College, and various educational works.

WYBROW, GEORGE DIGBY, A.M.I.C.E., Public Works Department, Madras.—Joined the service, 25th July, 1867, and served in the Madras Presidency as assistant engineer and executive engineer; superintendent engineer, Jan., 1892.

WYER, FREDERICK, B.A., late Bengal C.S.—Educated at Emmanuel College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1860; arrived, 31st Dec., 1861; served in the Bengal revenue and judicial departments, and was appointed magistrate and collector, 1st grade, May, 1884; officiated as commissioner of the Burdwan division in 1883; and of the Dacca division, in 1885; retired, May, 1887.

WYER, THOMAS ROWLAND, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at University of Glasgow, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 20th Oct., 1873, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and assistant settlement officer, and in acting appointments as joint magistrate, magistrate and collector, small cause court judge, and district and sessions judge; assistant commissioner, Nov., 1884; joint magistrate, March, 1888; settlement officer in addition, March, 1890; deputy commissioner, Nov., 1890; district and sessions judge, Dec., 1891.

WYLIE, HENRY, Lieut.-Colonel, C.S.I., Foreign Department, Government of India.—Ensign, Oct., 1861; arrived in India, 15th Nov., 1861; served with various regiments, and took part in the N.W. frontier campaign, 1863, the 2nd Yusafzai expedition (medal and clasp), the Bhutan Campaign, 1865 (clasp), the Abyssinian expedition, 1866 (medal), and the Hazara campaign, 1868 (clasp); on special duty in Beloochistan, with Major R. Sandeman, Nov., 1875, to Feb., 1877; assistant to governor-general's agent, Beloochistan, 1877; served in the Afghan campaign, 1878-80 (medal); C.S.I., Feb., 1881; assistant to the resident in Mysore, and secretary to chief commissioner, Coorg, 1882; political agent, Bhopawar, Feb., 1885; political agent, Jhalawur, April, 1885; political agent, Bhopal, March, 1887; officiating resident, Nepal, March, 1891.

WYLLIE, WILLIAM HUTT CURZON, Major, C.I.E., I.S.C., Foreign Department, Government of India.—Ensign, 106th Foot, Oct., 1866; arrived in India, Feb., 1867; served in the Oude commission, 1870-1879, as assistant commissioner and officiating cantonment and city magistrate; staff corps, 1868; acted as inspector-general of registration in 1875, and as junior secretary to government, Oude, 1876-77; from Jan., 1879, served under the foreign department, government of India, as cantonment magistrate, Nasirabad, assistant commissioner in Merwara and Ajmere, and as assistant to governor-general's agent, Beloochistan; served in Madras, 1880-81, as military secretary to the governor, and acted as private secretary; C.I.E., May, 1881; political agent, 3rd class, in political charge of ex-Gaekwar of Baroda, Mulhar Rao, 1881; assistant resident, Hyderabad, 1882; assistant commissioner, Ajmere, Nov., 1883; 1st assistant agent to governor-general, Rajputana, 1884; additional political agent, 1st class, Kotah, April, 1885; boundary settlement officer, Meywar-Marwar border, Nov., 1886; political agent, Kotah, Jan., 1889; officiating commissioner, Ajmere, July, 1891; officiating political agent, Jhallawar, May-July, 1891, and again, Jan., 1892.

WYNCH, LIONEL MALING, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at Bedford Grammar School, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1882; arrived in India, 7th Dec., 1885; assistant collector and magistrate, Feb., 1886.

WYNDHAM, PERCY, B.A., Bengal C.S. (North-Western Provinces).—Educated at Giggleswick Grammar School and Queen's College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competition of 1886; arrived in India, 13th Dec., 1889, and served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant commissioner.

WYNNE, SYDENHAM HENRY, B.A., Madras C.S.—Educated at the Royal Naval School, and Trinity College, Dublin; appointed to the Madras civil service after open competitive examination of 1871; arrived in India, 21st Oct., 1873,
and served in Madras as assistant collector and magistrate, acting cantonment magistrate, acting sub-collector and joint magistrate, acting collector and magistrate, and acting district and sessions judge; head assistant to the collector and magistrate, South Arcot, Oct., 1882; sub-collector and joint magistrate, Dec., 1887; collector and magistrate Jan., 1890.

YATE, CHARLES EDWARD, C.S.I., C.M.G., Major, I.S.C., Political department, Government of India.—First commission, ensign 49th regiment, 9th Nov., 1867; arrived in India, 27th Feb., 1868; admitted to Bombay staff corps, March, 1871; from August, 1871, served under foreign department of Government of India at Serohi, and with the Erinpuna irregular force, and afterwards with the Bhil corps; on special duty, Sind border, Sept., 1872, and Nov., 1873; boundary settlement officer, Meywar-Marwar border, Sept., 1874; and Mewar Tonk border, Dec., 1875; officiated for various periods as political assistant, assistant political agent, magistrate, and assistant to superintendent for suppression of thugee and dacoity; superintendent of operations for control of Moghias in Rajputana and Central India, Sept., 1879; served under the military department in Afghanistan, Feb. to May, 1880. When, under foreign department he was appointed political officer at Kalat-i-Ghilzai; political officer with Kabul-Kandahar field force under Sir F. Roberts on march to Kandahar, Aug., 1880, (bronze star); political officer with cavalry brigade at Kokern, Sept., 1880; and in Argandab Valley, Oct., 1880; political officer in charge of City of Kandahar, and with southern Afghanistan field force, Nov., 1889 to April, 1881 (medal and clasp for Afghanistan); subsequently served in the political department in Bhopal, Central India, and Bhopawar; attache with Afghan Boundary Commission, July, 1884; political assistant, 1st Class, July, 1885; on duty at Herat in connection with the fortifications, July, 1885; employed on various special services in connection with the Afghan boundary commission; political agent, Thal Chotiali, March, 1890; author of Gazettes of Meywar, Banswara and Partabgarh, &c.

YELD, HORACE PARR, Surgeon-Major, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the Indian medical department, 1874; was employed in the military department up to Aug., 1884, when he was appointed probationer in the assay department, Bombay mint; transferred to Calcutta mint, Sept., 1884; surgeon-major, March, 1886; deputy assay-master, Bombay mint, May, 1886, and Calcutta mint, Jan., 1888; officiating assay master, Bombay mint, April, 1888, and again in 1889 and 1892.

YOUNG, G. EDGAR, Registry and Record Department, India Office.—Appointed 2nd class clerk, 22nd May, 1888.

YOUNG, GEORGE GORDON, Colonel, I.S.C., late Punjab Commission.—Arrived in India, 23rd Oct., 1856; from June, 1858, served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, officiating small cause court judge, and assistant settlement officer; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1873; commissioner and superintendent, Jan., 1881; officiating 2nd financial commissioner, Feb.-Nov., 1883, and again April and May, 1890; reverted to military department, 1892.

YOUNG, WILLIAM, B.A., B.L., C.S.I., late Bengal C.S. (N.W. Provinces).—Educated at Heidelberg University and University College, London; called to the bar at the Middle Temple; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1856; arrived in India, 16th Dec., 1856; served in the N.W. Provinces as assistant magistrate and collector, and joint magistrate and deputy collector, and was appointed magistrate and collector, Basti, March, 1875; was subsequently posted to Mainpuri, Moradabad, and Muzaffarnagar; civil and sessions judge, and grade, Bareilly, Oct., 1880; and afterwards at Allahabad; judicial commissioner, Oudh, Aug., 1886; acting judge of high court, April-Dec., 1890; C.S.I., Jan., 1891; retired, Dec., 1891.

YOUNG, WILLIAM MACKWORTH, M.A., C.S.I., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Eton, and King's College, Cambridge; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1862; arrived in India, 12th Dec., 1863, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, assistant settlement officer, officiating secretary to financial commissioner, and officiating deputy commissioner; attached on special duty to office of financial commissioner, Oct., 1872; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, Oct., 1873; settlement secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1875; deputy commissioner, 3rd class, Jan., 1878; officiating superintendent, Kapurthala state, Feb., 1878; secretary to government, Punjab, Jan., 1880; promoted to commissioner and superintendent, May, 1887, but officiated as secretary to government until Dec., 1887; officiating secretary to government of India, Jan.-March, 1888; commissioner, Jullundur division, April, 1888; 2nd financial commissioner of the Punjab, April, 1889; officiated as 1st commissioner in 1890 and 1891; C.S.I., Jan., 1890.

YOUNGHUSBAND, ARTHUR DELAVAL, Bombay C.S.—Educated at Rugby, and Clifton College; appointed to the Bombay civil service after open competitive examination of 1875; arrived in India, 9th Dec., 1877, and served as assistant collector and magistrate, acting junior collector and magistrate, talukdari settlement officer, and assistant political agent; acted as private secretary to H.E. the governor, July-Oct., 1890; and as administrator, Rajpipla State, in 1888, and again from Nov., 1890; transferred to Central Provinces as assistant commissioner, Nov., 1891; deputy commissioner, Jan., 1892.

YOUNGHUSBAND, ROMER EDWARD, B.A., B.L., Bengal C.S. (Punjab).—Educated at Rugby, Clifton College, and Balliol College, Oxford; appointed to the Bengal civil service after open competitive examination of 1877; arrived in India, 14th Dec., 1879, and served in the Punjab as assistant commissioner, settlement officer, officiating judicial assistant, officiating deputy commissioner, and officiating district judge; officiating under secretary to government, Punjab, March, 1885; acted as junior secretary and as senior secretary to financial commissioner; confirmed as junior secretary to financial commissioner, March, 1886; under secretary to government of Punjab, Jan., 1883; officiating deputy commissioner, Dera Ghazi Khan, April, 1890.

ZORAB, JOHN MANOOK, M.B., Surgeon-Lieutenant-Colonel, Bengal Medical Service.—Joined the service, 30th March, 1872; served in the military department, and as civil surgeon, Balasore, March, 1837, and Cuttack, March, 1891.
